abstract: Which fish can walk on land?
article: Mudskippers, which are found in the Indo-Pacific region, have the ability to walk on land. Moreover, the species has adapted to living mostly on land, and also eat and mate on land. Out of water, they breathe with air trapped in their gill chambers and their skin. Other fish that can walk on land include 'Fishzilla' and 'Catfish'.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 61 million-year-old penguin fossil found, one of the oldest
article: Germany-based scientists have found a 61 million-year-old fossil of a giant penguin species, making it one of the oldest such discovery ever. The animal's body length was estimated to be about 150 centimeters, which is more than the height of the biggest penguin alive today. The find suggests that the evolution of penguins began during the time of the dinosaurs.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA releases posters for newly discovered solar system
article: NASA has released posters displaying the newly discovered 'TRAPPIST-1' solar system and comparing it with our solar system. The seven Earth-like exoplanets orbit their host star closer than Mercury orbits the Sun. But the new system's star, an ultra-cool dwarf, is cool enough for liquid water and possible life to survive on three 'habitable zone' exoplanets.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: International Space Station captures SpaceX's Dragon craft
article: International Space Station on Thursday successfully captured SpaceX's Dragon cargo spacecraft that was launched from NASA's Kennedy Space Center on Sunday. Dragon is expected to be unpacked in around four weeks, after which it will be sent on a five and a half hour return mission to Earth. The original docking attempt was aborted on Wednesday after a navigational error.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Video: Huge crack captured in the Antarctic
article: The British Antarctic Survey recently captured a footage of a huge crack in the Larsen C Ice Shelf on the Antarctic Peninsula. Satellite observations show the crack is continuously growing, suggesting that an iceberg of an area over 5,000 square kilometres is likely to break apart soon. If that happens, it will be among the biggest break-offs ever recorded.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Bees taught to play football, showcase complex learning
article: England-based researchers successfully taught bumblebees to roll a mini ball towards a target area, revealing learning abilities of the insect which were not known until now. The bees were found to solve the task in a different way than what was demonstrated, suggesting that observer bees did not simply copy what they saw, but improved on it, a researcher said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 4-stroke engine produces hydrogen from methane, captures CO2
article: US-based researchers have built a reactor that produces hydrogen on burning methane while capturing carbon dioxide emissions. A four-stroke engine was improvised by adding a catalyst, hydrogen-separating membrane, and CO2 sorbent which releases the gas into a cylinder and also reduces processing temperature. The team was able to produce hydrogen using six times less water than existing methods.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Research reveals for the first time how Parkinson's develops
article: New Zealand-based researchers have provided what they claim is the first strong evidence on how Parkinson's disease spreads in the brain. Pathological proteins, known as Lewy bodies, spread from cell to cell through tunneling nanotubes that act as conduits. The study further stated that non-neuronal cells in the blood vessels called pericytes, also appear to harbour and spread Lewy bodies.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Solar system with seven Earth-like planets discovered
article: Scientists have discovered a solar system, 40 light-years away in the constellation Aquarius, with seven Earth-like planets that could possibly support life, NASA has announced. Three of these are in the 'habitable zone', where liquid water and possibly life might exist, researchers added. This is the first time that so many Earth-sized planets have been found orbiting the same star.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: SpaceX successfully launches Dragon spacecraft for NASA
article: Elon Musk-led space exploration startup SpaceX on Sunday successfully launched its Dragon spacecraft which will deliver nearly 2,500 kg of cargo to International Space Station for NASA. Dragon spacecraft is also carrying strains of the MRSA superbug to study its behaviour in microgravity. The launch was conducted from the same pad used for NASA's first manned mission to the moon.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: World's first material to reach theoretical stiffness limits
article: US-based researchers have developed a foam-like pyramid-cross-cell structure claimed to be ''maximally stiff in all directions'' by theoretical bounds. Named 'Isomax', the solid foam is a stiff substance with air pockets and is claimed to be uncommonly strong for its mass. Its lightness, strength, and versatility could be applied to building, aerospace, and packaging industry, researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 1st expedition to cross the Arctic since 1894 announced
article: Scientists are embarking on an expedition to the Arctic to better understand climate change. The MOSAiC mission starting in 2019, would be the first in over a century after Norwegian explorer Fridtjof Nansen crossed the polar ice cap in 1894. During the year-long 2500-km trip, scientists would locally study the atmosphere, ice, and ocean via drones, remote stations, and satellites.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Printable solar cells to turn surfaces into power generators
article: Canada-based researchers have pioneered 'perovskite solar cells', cheaper than commercial solar cells, that could be imprinted on any surface to generate solar electricity. A technology to coat an electron-selective layer for extraction of generated electricity on the cells was developed which made the cells function at 20% energy efficiency for more than 500 hours, the researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists create coin-sized microscope on a single chip
article: US-based researchers have created an atomic force microscope (AFM), about 1 square centimetre in size, on a single chip. The design consists of a printed circuit board and sensors which move across surfaces to map out its contours, translating the microscopic movements into images. The advancement would reduce the price of AFM systems by several thousand dollars, the researchers said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Doctors successfully complete 50-hour-long face transplant
article: A team of US-based doctors recently announced that they successfully completed a near-total face transplant on 32-year-old Andy Sandness, who had attempted suicide in 2006, destroying most of his face. Doctors spent almost three years preparing for the surgery, which took more than 50 hours and repaired most of his face including the jaws, nose, teeth, cheeks and facial muscles.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Moon, Pluto rated as planets under newly proposed definition
article: To encourage exploration of more celestial bodies, a group of NASA scientists has proposed a new definition of planets, defining them as "round objects in space smaller than stars". Under this definition, over 100 solar system objects including the Moon and Pluto would become planets. However, the definition needs to be accepted by the International Astronomical Union to become official.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Treadmill for ants to study how they navigate home
article: Germany-based scientists built a custom spherical treadmill for desert ants to study how they navigate back home. The treadmill made of a styrofoam ball with sensors revealed that ants navigate using the Sun's position while counting their strides. It was also found that lost ants slow down and loop around until they have some sign of where to go.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft aborts NASA cargo delivery to ISS
article: Elon Musk-led space exploration startup SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft on Wednesday aborted its planned rendezvous with the International Space Station to deliver nearly 2,500 kg of cargo to NASA astronauts. Dragon's onboard computers triggered the abort after recognising an incorrect value in GPS data about the station's location when it was only 1,200 metres away from the ISS.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Video: SpaceX rocket lands on ground after successful launch
article: Elon Musk-led space exploration startup SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket on Sunday successfully landed on the ground after launching to space. It’s the third time that SpaceX has landed its rocket on solid ground post launch, but the first time a ground landing has been done during the daytime. SpaceX now has eight landed Falcon 9 rockets in its possession.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Origami-inspired bulletproof shield created
article: US-based engineers have created an origami-inspired lightweight bulletproof shield that can protect law enforcement from gunfire. The ballistic barrier, made with 12 layers of kevlar, weighs just 25 kgs. It can be folded compactly to store and takes only five seconds to expand and deploy, providing cover for up to three officers from several types of handguns.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: ISRO's record launch a wake-up call for China: Chinese Media
article: An article published in a Chinese daily has said that China could learn a "number of lessons" from India's record-breaking launch of 104 satellites, which also ''serve(s) as a wake-up call''. The article also mentioned that ''competition with India for commercial space launches may be inevitable" and China needs to focus on cost-control to compete with India's low-cost launch capabilities.

author: Tarun Khanna
abstract: We can set up space station, need a nod to start: ISRO
article: ISRO Chairman AS Kiran Kumar has said India has the capability to set up a space station and the day the country will take the decision on it, the space agency will begin the project. "We still talk about what would be the immediate benefits of a manned space mission. That's why India hasn't made up its mind," he added.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Alien particles damaging gadgets: Indian professor
article: Cosmic rays originating from outer space produce energetic particles on entering Earth's atmosphere. These 'alien' particles interfere with circuits in electronic devices by changing the stored data. Citing an event when a plane dove 690 feet in 23 seconds due to system failure, Professor Bharat Bhuva said that multiple circuits could be used in the same device to avoid failure.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Cabbage harvested aboard the International Space Station
article: NASA astronauts recently harvested their first Chinese cabbage aboard the International Space Station after spending nearly a month of tending to the leafy greens. While the station crew will get to eat some of the cabbage, the rest would be saved for scientific study back at NASA's Kennedy Space Center. Notably, this is the fifth crop grown aboard the station.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Sir David Attenborough to narrate BBC show 'Blue Planet II'
article: British naturalist and broadcaster Sir David Attenborough will be narrating BBC's 'Blue Planet II', a seven-episode series on marine life. The series, which will air this year, contains footage that was filmed over four years. Latest marine technology, including two unmanned submersibles, allowed the production team to record footage from 1,000 metres under the Antarctic Ocean.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Why all snowflakes have six sides?
article: Snowflakes contain six sides or points due to the way in which they form. Water molecules, made of oxygen and hydrogen have a fixed shape and join together in a hexagonal pattern to form ice crystals. As the snowflake grows based on temperature and available water, it branches into complex dendrites while maintaining the six sides.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: 15mm frogs among 7 new species found in Western Ghat forests
article: A new nocturnal species of frog, measuring between 12.2mm and 15.4mm, along with six other new species, has been discovered in the forests of the Western Ghats. The discovery has reportedly made the Western Ghats the second-largest global amphibian hotspot after Brazil’s Atlantic Forest. The frogs, known to make cricket-like sounds, had been overlooked due to their extremely small size.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Cheap uranium-extracting method from seas for nuclear power
article: Stanford researchers have developed an effective technology to extract uranium (fuel for nuclear power plants) from seawater. Improving upon three variables– capacity, rate and reuse, the team was able to extract three times more uranium than from existing methods. Cost-effective extraction from oceans could ensure endless uranium supply to facilitate a carbon-free energy future, researchers said.

author: Ankush Verma
abstract: Stephen Hawking helps raise funds for Palestinian school
article: Theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking has asked his Facebook followers to help fundraise for Palestinian physics students. "I would like to bring up a fundraising...to make a second Palestinian Advanced Physics School possible. Please consider making a donation...to support science in Palestine," his Facebook post read. The project has reportedly raised a total of around $11,000 (over ₹7 lakh).

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA biologist finds life in 50,000-year-old cave crystals
article: NASA scientists claim to have found ancient living microbes trapped in crystals that could be 50,000 years old. Believed to have lived off on minerals such as iron and manganese in the dormant caves of Mexico, the weird microbes were genetically at least 10% different than its closest relative, like humans are from mushrooms, said the lead biologist.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 'Family tree of stars' to reconstruct Milky Way's formation
article: Cambridge University scientists are studying chemical signatures, formation, and interrelation of Milky Way's stars to build an evolutionary family tree, aimed at understanding the galaxy's formation. Termed as 'Galactic archaeology', the study features 22 stars including the Sun, with the oldest star estimated to be 10 billion years old and youngest to be 700 million years old.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists link extreme wind, drought to 'sky rivers'
article: According to a recent study, 'sky rivers' are responsible for extreme weather such as prolonged drought and drastic winds. 'Sky rivers' are long, narrow corridors of concentrated water vapour suspended in the atmosphere. Researchers also found that these sky rivers were also associated with majority of the extreme wind events between 1997 and 2013 over Europe, which caused billion-dollar losses.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: New bleached corals found on the Great Barrier Reef
article: Fresh evidence of coral bleaching around the Great Barrier Reef has triggered fears of coral deaths. Bleaching is the phenomena when corals turn white after losing the algae living in their tissue due to warmer water. Sea temperatures rising 2ºC above normal is resulting in coral deaths due to bleaching and could greatly harm the tourism industry, authorities said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Crowdsourcing project to help predict smell of molecules
article: A crowdsourcing effort by an American university has devised a mathematical model that can predict the scent of a molecule. The model, which was prepared with a dataset of 476 molecules being classified into smells similar to rose, garlic and fish among others, could predict odour of 69 other molecules with 83% accuracy.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Volta got electrical battery idea from dissection of a frog
article: Alessandro Volta, credited with electrical battery's invention, got the idea when fellow Italian physicist Galvani observed that frog's legs twitched when touched by two metal rods, interpreting it as 'animal electricity'. However, Volta, who was born on February 18, 1745, considered electricity to be 'metallic' and piled metal disks between brine-soaked paper to make the first battery, in 1800.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 87 years since the discovery of Pluto
article: Pluto, which was once considered the ninth planet of the solar system, was discovered on February 18, 1930, by American astronomer Clyde Tombaugh. The celestial body is now recognised as 'dwarf planet' according to new definitions set by the International Astronomical Union in 2006. Pluto's name was suggested by an 11-year old girl, after the Roman god of the Underworld.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: How much does ISRO earn from launching foreign satellites?
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation's commercial arm 'Antrix', incorporated as a company in 1992, handles satellite launches for foreign governments and private companies. From the 44 satellites for foreign countries that ISRO launched between January 2014 and December 2016, Antrix earned revenues of ₹693 crore. This translates to an average cost of about ₹15.75 crore for each satellite launch.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Scientists claim there's a new continent called Zealandia
article: Scientists claim to have discovered a new continent 'Zealandia', a 4.9 million-square-km region in the Pacific Ocean comprising of New Zealand and a French island territory. It is "geologically separate and distinct from Australia and Antarctica" and the thinnest, most-submerged continent. Considered a collection of continental islands thus far, geologists now say they're all connected underwater.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: SpaceX aborts rocket launch 10 sec before planned liftoff
article: Elon Musk's startup SpaceX on Saturday aborted the launch of its Falcon 9 rocket 10 seconds before the scheduled liftoff due to odd movement of the rocket's engine steering. The launch has been rescheduled for today. The launch, aimed at sending supplies to NASA's International Space Station, is taking place from the same launch pad used for first Moon mission.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Elon Musk calls ISRO's achievement awesome & very impressive
article: American space exploration startup SpaceX's Founder Elon Musk on Thursday tweeted that ISRO's achievement is awesome and very impressive. "They (ISRO) are doing India proud," he wrote in another tweet. ISRO on Wednesday launched 104 satellites in one go, breaking the world record for the most number of satellites launched from a single rocket.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Heat flow used for the first time to levitate objects
article: In a first, US-based researchers have demonstrated levitation of various objects including glass bubbles and ice particles due to heat flow. The objects were placed in a vacuum chamber between plates with around 210ºC temperature difference and a stable levitation for over an hour was observed. Vacuum-levitation of macroscopic objects would be significant for space research, the students said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Human-made toxic pollutants found in deepest point on Earth
article: Scientists have found ''extraordinary'' levels of toxic pollutants in the 10-km-deep Mariana trench in the Pacific Ocean, the deepest known point on the planet. Small crabs captured from Mariana were found to be 50 times more contaminated than those surviving in China's industrially polluted rivers. The significant and disturbing results show no place is safe from human impact, said scientists.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Antarctic sea ice shrinks to smallest ever extent on record
article: Sea ice cover around Antarctica has reduced to its smallest ever on record, slumping by around 3,000-square-kilometres more than the previous record-low measured in 1997, as per the US National Snow and Ice Data Center. Notably, the Antarctic sea ice cover hit a record high in September 2014, with scientists believing that melting ice shelves contribute to ice cover growth.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Earthquakes can turn water into gold
article: Earthquakes turn water into gold as pressure causes sudden vaporisation of water, forcing gold formations along the fault lines in rocks, according to a study. As an earthquake travels along the fault lines, the mineral-rich water in the cracks evaporate, leading to the formation of gold and other minerals in the surrounding surface, approximately 10 kilometres below the Earth's surface.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Bill Gates warns bioterrorism can kill 3 cr people in a year
article: World's richest man Bill Gates has warned that a terrorist intent to genetically-engineer a deadly virus could kill more than 3 crore people in less than a year. Fearing a bioterrorism outbreak in the next 10-15 years, the billionaire philanthropist said that preparedness for a global pandemic is as important as nuclear deterrence and avoiding a climate catastrophe.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists trying to bring the extinct mammoth back to life
article: Harvard scientists are trying to resurrect the woolly mammoth which went extinct around 4,000 years ago. The team, currently at cell stage claims to be two years away from creating a mammoth-elephant hybrid embryo. Referred as 'mammophant', the animal would be an Asian elephant with mammoth features such as small ears, subcutaneous fat, long shaggy hair and cold-adapted blood.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: January 2017 was the third hottest January on record: NASA
article: January 2017 was the third hottest January since modern record-keeping began in 1880, according to the latest data released by NASA. Last month's temperature was 0.20°C cooler than January 2016, which was the warmest January on record. Notably, 2016 was the hottest year ever observed, with July 2016 being the absolute hottest month.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA announces winners of its ₹20-lakh Space Poop Challenge
article: NASA has announced the winners of its Space Poop Challenge, which required participants to develop a system inside a space suit that collects human waste for six days and routes it away without using hands. The winner, who received $15,000 of the total $30,000 (₹20 lakh), designed a small airlock, allowing inflatable items to be passed through and then expanded.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Chickens gene-edited to act as surrogates for rare breeds
article: UK-based researchers have genetically modified hens that don't produce their own chicks to use them as surrogates for rare breeds. For this, a bird fertility gene was edited and certain traits from rare breeds were implanted into the gene-edited chickens while they were developing inside an egg. The hens would grow up to produce eggs containing rare breed's genetic information.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: New 'living material' lights up in presence of chemicals
article: Researchers at MIT have designed a new ''living material'', a cell-infused hydrogel programmed to light up in the presence of certain chemicals. The material was used to make wearable sensors like gloves and bandages that light up on touching contaminated surfaces and infectious skin. Researchers believe the technology could be applied to medical diagnostics, pollution monitoring, and forensics.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Why Earth's inner core doesn't melt despite extreme heat?
article: Sweden-based researchers have proposed a new theory for Earth's crystallised iron core remaining solid despite being hotter than Sun's surface. On the edge of the inner core, pieces of crystals' structure continuously melt and diffuse only to be reinserted due to high pressure like ''shuffling deck of cards''. This energy distribution cycle keeps the crystal stable and the core solid.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: MIT researchers find first planet-induced motion in a star
article: In a first, MIT researchers have observed a star moving in response to its orbiting planet. The star's brightness and vibrations were found to be synchronised with its planet's orbit rate. The unusual behaviour could be attributed to the exoplanet's massiveness, researchers said. Notably, Sun being a million times bigger than Earth, is not affected by Earth's gravity or orbit.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Alps could lose 70% of their snow cover by 2100: Scientists
article: The Alps could lose up to 70% of their snow cover by the next century, according to Swiss scientists. Rain will likely replace snowfall across the Alps due to global warming, the scientists have added. Reportedly, even if global warming is limited to 2°C, the Paris climate change agreement target, the Alps would lose 30% of their snow by 2100.

author: Ankush Verma
abstract: UAE announces plan to build first city on Mars by 2117
article: Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE Sheikh Mohammad bin Rashid on Tuesday announced the 'Mars 2117' plan to build the first city on Mars in 100 years. "We aspire to great things, so...I today decided the UAE will...send humans to Mars," Rashid said. The city, reportedly the size of Chicago, will have a population of 6 lakh.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Signs of autism in infants can be spotted: Study
article: US-based researchers were able to detect signs of autism with 80 percent accuracy in infants with autistic older siblings. MRI scans of infants at 6,12, and 24 months of age showed that babies who developed autism experienced a hyper-expansion of brain surface area from six to 12 months. The study would help ''intervene'' autism before its diagnosis, said the lead.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: First live birth evidence in 250-mn-yr-old dinosaur relative
article: Researchers studying the fossil of a dinosaur-like animal have found the first-ever evidence of live birth in an animal group previously thought to only lay eggs. The 250 million-year-old "terrible-headed lizard" fossil revealed that it was carrying an embryo. While the animal would have measured 3-4 metres long, with a 1.7-metre-long neck, the embryo might have been 0.5 metres long.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Human brain always has a backup plan: Study
article: New research by Canada-based researchers has revealed that when humans are presented with two action options, the brain's motor neurons prepare for both possibilities before making a decision. This finding supports the idea that the brain represents the world as a range of potential actions and objects to interact with. The research may help in developing smarter robots and AI.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 'Key ingredients for life' found on dwarf planet Ceres
article: NASA's Dawn probe has detected organic compounds on Ceres, a dwarf planet in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. The compounds are thought to have formed on Ceres, rather than introduced by an asteroid impact. Holding ''key ingredients for life'', Ceres is a top contender after Mars for finding alien life in our Solar System, said the study lead.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Additive in candy, gum may alter digestive function: Study
article: US-based researchers claim that a common food additive 'titanium oxide', found in candy, chewing gum, bread and even toothpaste, slows down metabolism and significantly decreases absorption of nutrients like iron, zinc, and fatty acids in the gut. Though non-fatal, scientists advise avoiding food rich in the additive, like processed foods, especially candy.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA-funded website crowdsourcing search for 'Planet Nine'
article: A new NASA-funded website 'Backyard Worlds: Planet 9' lets the public search for possible undiscovered worlds in the outer reaches of our solar system. The project themed on finding the yet-undetected 'Planet Nine' relies on human eyes to find and flag ''interesting'' objects from NASA's all-sky data. 'Planet Nine' is a hypothetical planet in the outer Solar System beyond Neptune.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Science Express flagged off for climate change awareness
article: A Science Express train was flagged off by Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu on Friday on a seven-month journey that will cover 68 stations across the country to spread awareness about climate change. Named Science Express Climate Action Special, the 16-coach train is a collaborative initiative of Ministries of Railways, Environment, and Science and Technology.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: ISRO launches 104 satellites in one go, creates world record
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation on Wednesday successfully launched 104 satellites in one go, breaking the world record for the most number of satellites launched from a single rocket. Its PSLV launch system carried a 714-kg Cartosat-2 series earth observing satellite and 103 co-passenger satellites together weighing 664 kg. Russia held the previous record of 37 satellites, launched in 2014.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Company to send winner of its mobile game to space for free
article: Finnish space company Cohu Experience is launching a mobile game, the winner of which will be sent to travel the space free of cost. The game, Space Nation Astronaut Training Program (SNAP), will let players experience being an astronaut through a training program. The 100 top-ranked players will be eligible for a training session with a NASA astronaut.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Rubber that conducts heat but not electricity developed
article: US-based researchers have developed a new rubber material that conducts heat but not electricity. Nicknamed 'thubber', the material made of non-toxic liquid metal microdroplets can stretch over six times its initial length. Its applications could involve flexible electronics, device mounts to avoid overheating, lighted athletic wear and heated garments for injury therapy, said the lead researcher.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Mammals produced venom even before snakes were born: Study
article: Africa-based researchers have found evidence of the first ever venom producing species during fossil study of a pre-mammalian reptile 'Euchambersia'. Existing 10 crore years before snakes were even born, the dog-like animal developed venom-producing features in jaws to survive the harsh African conditions. The venom could have been used for either protection or hunting, said a palaeontologist.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Triangle-shaped molecule synthesised for the first time
article: A triangle-shaped carbon-based molecule has been synthesised for the first time since its prediction 70 years ago. 'Triangulene', made of six fused circular benzene molecules has an even number of atoms and electrons. Due to its unique geometry, two of its electrons are not able to pair up, which could make it magnetic and valuable for quantum computing, researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA shortlists 3 landing sites for Mars 2020 mission
article: NASA has shortlisted three potential landing sites for the upcoming Mars 2020 mission. They include Northeast Syrtis (a very ancient part of Mars' surface), Jezero crater (earlier a Martian lake), and Columbia Hills (potentially home to an ancient hot spring). The rover will conduct tests for habitability, search for ancient life, and collect samples for a possible return to Earth.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Newly invented material breaks symmetry of motion
article: Researchers have invented the first mechanical material that reacts asymmetrically with one rigid and one soft side. On applying force on the softer side, the effect on the other side is very small, whereas on applying the same force on the rigid side, it is amplified on the other side. The metamaterial's applications include soft robotics, prosthetics and energy harvesting.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Mice genetically modified to combat cocaine addiction
article: Canadian researchers have genetically modified mice to prevent 'learning' the memory of cocaine and thereby combat cocaine addiction. For the study, mice were kept in cages with cocaine in wallpapered sections. The modified mice were found to spend half as much time as the normal ones, as the drug blocked the formation of a memory of the drug-induced high.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA plans to search for life on Jupiter's icy moon Europa
article: NASA has released plans for a mission to land a spacecraft on Europa, one of Jupiter's 67 known moons. Previous fly-by missions to Jupiter's orbit have indicated the existence of an ocean underneath Europa's icy surface. The mission, planned for 2024, would analyse Europa for signs of life, potential human colonisation and better characterise its surface and subsurface.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: Which satellites were launched in ISRO's record flight?
article: ISRO's Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle on Wednesday put 714-kg Cartosat-2 series earth observation satellite and 103 other satellites in their orbits. ISRO's two nano satellites (INS-1A and INS-1B) were also launched, which are technology demonstration satellites. Out of the remaining satellites, 96 were from the US, with one each from the Netherlands, Switzerland, Israel, Kazakhstan and the UAE.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: ISRO helps US startup get 50-trillion-pixel image of Earth
article: The record-breaking launch of 104 satellites from one rocket by ISRO has helped US-based imaging startup Planet to begin releasing 50-trillion-pixel image of Earth's landmass every day. ISRO's launch included 88 satellites of the startup, which now has a total of 149 satellites in space, making it the largest fleet in space operated by a commercial entity.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: ISRO's journey from bullock cart to launching 104 satellites
article: A photo gallery shows ISRO's journey from its days when it had once tested India's first experimental communication satellite, APPLE, on a bullock cart in 1981. The space agency has come a long way from then with its successful 'Chandrayaan' mission and the historic 'Mangalyaan' (Mars Orbiter Mission). ISRO on Wednesday set record to launch 104 satellites in one go.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: $5tn project proposed to restore Arctic ice using 10mn pumps
article: US-based physicists have proposed a 10-year-long $5-trillion project to revive the Arctic ice using around 10 million wind-powered water pumps. The pumps would bring water to the surface for it to freeze and thicken the ice cap. It's unlikely that CO2 levels can be decreased in time to tackle climate change, so restoring sea-ice artificially is imperative, said the lead.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Equation developed to calculate human impact on Earth
article: Australia-based researchers have developed an equation to calculate human activity's impact on Earth. The 'Anthropocene equation' shows the rate of change of Earth system over last 40 years has been dominated by humans rendering natural processes negligible. Moreover, global temperature rise shows human-caused greenhouse emissions are causing climate change 170 times faster than natural factors.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Full moon, eclipse, comet observed on the same night
article: A full moon, a lunar eclipse and a green-coloured comet were all seen on the same night from some regions on the planet on Friday. The full moon coincided with a penumbral lunar eclipse, which occurs when the moon passes through the outer part of Earth's shadow. Meanwhile, Comet 45P made its closest approach to Earth on the same night.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Gravitational waves from Big Bang studied for the first time
article: In a first, Switzerland-based researchers have calculated the precise frequency of specific gravitational wave signals that would have emerged fractions of a second after the Big Bang. The signal's source 'oscillon', was caused by oscillations in the expanding space of the early universe. The existence of this phenomenon is yet to be proven by gravitational wave detectors at LIGO.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Darwin Awards honour those who die in 'stupid ways'
article: Darwin Awards, named in honour of English naturalist Charles Darwin, honour those people who have died in 'exceptionally stupid ways'. The awards celebrate individuals who eliminate themselves in an extraordinarily idiotic manner, thereby improving the chance of long-term survival of humans. The winners include a man trying to fight a lion and a priest who flew using 1,000 helium balloons.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Charles Darwin ate exotic animals like owl, hawk
article: When English naturalist Charles Darwin was a student at Cambridge, he formed the Glutton Club, which met on a weekly basis to eat "birds and beasts, which were before unknown to human palate". As part of the club, he ate exotic animals including a hawk, an owl, and an unnamed chocolate-coloured rodent. Darwin's 208th birth anniversary was observed on Sunday.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Researchers create battery that could last for over 10 years
article: Researchers at the Harvard University have created a liquid battery that could last for more than 10 years and remain non-corrosive and non-toxic. A liquid battery is a battery that stores energy in liquid solutions. The researchers modified the battery's molecules in the electrolytes in a way that the battery only loses 1% of its capacity every 1,000 cycles.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: SpaceX to launch rocket from pad used for first Moon mission
article: Space exploration startup SpaceX's next rocket launch will take place from Launch Complex 39A — the same launch pad used for the first Moon mission. In 1969,  the launch pad was used by the Saturn V rocket that first took people to the Moon. "We are honored to be allowed to use it," said SpaceX Founder and CEO Elon Musk.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: ISRO is like an Uber for satellites, tweets Chetan Bhagat
article: Congratulating ISRO's on its record-breaking launch of 104 satellites, author Chetan Bhagat compared the space research organisation to ride-hailing app Uber in a tweet. "Next time we want double century like Virender Sehwag," tweeted a user. "Sitaro ke aage jahan aur bhi hai," a user tweeted. "ISRO is becoming a synonym for doing the impossible," read a tweet.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA scientist detained at US border; asked to unlock phone
article: A US-born NASA scientist, Sidd Bikkannavar, was recently detained by the country's Customs and Border Patrol and asked to unlock his phone after flying back from South America. Issued by the NASA, Bikkannavar's phone was returned to him after it was searched. Bikkannavar's detainment comes amid US President Donald Trump's executive order banning immigration from seven nations.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 'Living diode' developed using cardiac cells
article: Scientists have created a 'living diode' using cardiac muscle cells and fibroblasts, found in heart tissue. A muscle-based circuitry arranges the two cell types in a rectangular manner, separating excitable and non-excitable cells, allowing unidirectional flow of electrical signals to achieve a diode function. The technology could allow organs to control attached mechanical devices, said the lead.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Big brother of Halley’s Comet ripped apart by a dead star
article: In a first, NASA witnessed a comet-like object disintegrate in a dead star's atmosphere. It was chemically similar but one lakh times more massive than Halley's Comet, prompting astronomers to nickname it as the comet's 'big brother'. Rich in elements essential for life, the object was destroyed by 'white dwarf', a star in its final stages due to fuel exhaustion.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA develops electronics to survive 'toxic' Venus missions
article: NASA recently completed a technology demonstration, enabling new scientific missions to Venus. The circuits withstood temperatures of 860º F (470º C) and extreme Venus-like atmospheric conditions for 521 hours, with the previous record being 127 minutes by a Soviet rover, which actually landed on the toxic planet in 1981. Notably, NASA has never landed a rover on Venus.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Bacteria can be engineered to produce electricity: Study
article: US-based researchers have chemically engineered bacteria that generate electricity naturally by introducing a protein replacement molecule into it. The iron-containing molecule facilitates conduction of the naturally produced electricity via cell membrane. The chemical method, cheaper than genetically modifying bacteria, could one day power wastewater treatment plants, said the lead researcher.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Huge reservoir of melting carbon located in western US
article: UK-based researchers used seismic sensors to map a deep-Earth area of melting carbon covering 18 lakh square kilometres in the western US. The amount of CO2 in the Earth's upper mantle is now believed to be 10,000 times more than previously estimated. The deep carbon reservoir would eventually surface via volcanic eruptions gradually contributing to climate change, the geologists claimed.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Not chosen for NASA space mission: Indian-origin astronaut
article: Shawna Pandya, an Indian-origin astronaut in Canada, has denied news reports claiming NASA had shortlisted her for its 2018 space mission. Pandya further clarified that she was neither a neurosurgeon nor an opera singer, adding that she wasn't affiliated with the Canadian Space Agency or NASA. Earlier, it was widely reported she would become the third Indian-origin woman in space.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Inventor of light bulb, Thomas Edison was born on this day
article: Thomas Alva Edison, popularly known as the inventor of the practical electric light bulb, was born on February 11, 1847, in the US. His greatest inventions include the phonograph and the motion picture camera. He was one of the first inventors to apply the principles of mass production to inventions for developing the first commercially viable electric bulb in 1879.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Fertility app approved as contraceptive for the first time
article: Nature Cycles, a fertility app which algorithmically monitors female fertility has become the world's first smartphone app to be officially approved for use as contraception. The app can now be prescribed by doctors in Europe and the UK instead of condoms or IUDs. Nature Cycles tells women when they can have sex with little risk of getting pregnant.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Canadian doctor to be 3rd Indian-origin woman to go to space
article: Dr Shawna Pandya, a neurosurgeon working at Canada's Alberta University Hospital has reportedly been selected for a space mission. When she takes off, she would be the third Indian-origin woman to go to space, after Kalpana Chawla and Sunita Williams. The 32-year-old was one of the two candidates shortlisted from 3,200 people for the 2018 space mission.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Newly made material contracts by record amount on heating
article: Japan-based researchers have developed a ceramic material that contracts up to 6.7% when heated, breaking the previous record by double. The negative thermal expansion was attributed to voids in the ceramic grains. Applications could involve mixing it with normal materials to produce a composite material with custom thermal expansion, typically zero for cryogenics and aerospace engineering.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists make battery that runs on air and carbon dioxide
article: US-based researchers have developed a rechargeable battery called a flow cell that can be recharged with waste carbon dioxide (CO2) emitted from fossil fuel power plants. The device works by taking advantage of the difference in CO2 concentrations between the surrounding air and captured emissions. Initial tests showed that the cell can maintain its performance for over 50 recharge cycles.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Massive Mars volcano erupted non-stop for 2 bn years: Study
article: A research by US-based scientists has revealed that sometime in its 4.5-billion-year history, Mars had a single volcano that erupted continuously for over 2 billion years. The finding is based on the study of a 2.4 billion-year-old meteorite found in 2012. Notably, the largest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons, is on Mars and is over 27 kilometres tall.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: MRI inventor, Nobel laureate Sir Peter Mansfield passes away
article: Sir Peter Mansfield, known for pioneering body scanning technique Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), recently passed away aged 83. The English physicist was awarded 'The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2003', for discoveries concerning the MRI. The University of Nottingham Emeritus Professor is also credited with further developing MRI, creating quicker scans with much clearer images.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: A fish species has 'flashlights' under their eyes
article: Splitfin flashlight fish have organs beneath their eyes that have light-producing bacteria, helping them to hunt and feed on prey. The 'flashlight', which can be turned on and off by blinking, sends Morse code-like signals. Research suggests that the fish blinks about 90 times a minute at night, with the light being on and off for roughly the same time.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: First flat lens created that can focus all colours of light
article: US-based researchers have created the first flat lens that works within the whole visible spectrum, from blue to green. Using an array of optimised nanopillars, an achromatic metalens was created, which simultaneously focuses all the wavelengths of visible light at the same distance. A single planar lens could replace the bulky curved lenses used in cameras and microscopes, researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Nearest Earth-like planet cannot sustain life: NASA
article: NASA has come up with a new model to determine a planet's habitability based on oxygen loss and not just presence of water. Solar system's nearest star 'Proxima Centauri' spews out huge amounts of stellar material, subjecting its planet to extreme X-ray and ultraviolet radiation causing oxygen to ionise and escape the atmosphere rendering sustenance of life unlikely, researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists discover two galaxies bridged by stars
article: Astronomers have discovered that the two largest satellite galaxies of the Milky Way appear to be connected by a bridge of stars. Known as 'The Magellanic Clouds', these galaxies are connected via a stellar bridge stretching across 43,000 light years. Researchers are studying the formation of these clouds and galaxies with the data obtained from the European Space observatory, Gaia.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists to teach dogs, mice to breathe underwater
article: Russia-based scientists plan to conduct 'liquid breathing' tests on dogs, mice and hamsters. Liquid breathing involves using biomedical technology to ventilate the lungs of air-breathing organisms with an oxygen-rich liquid. If successful, the technology will be tested on humans for medical research and military applications involving emergency evacuation of submarine crews from deep water.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: First nuclear test helps prove Moon's formation theory
article: US-based researchers studied radioactive glass from the first nuclear test (1945) at the Trinity site in New Mexico to examine theories about the Moon's formation. The study of volatile elements like Zinc gave further evidence to the 'giant impact theory' that moon was formed 4.5 billion years ago by the debris of a collision between Earth and a Mars-like planet.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Renewables constituted 90% of added power in Europe in 2016
article: Renewable energy sources made up nearly 90% of the power added to Europe's electricity grids in 2016. From the 24.5 GW of the added capacity, 21.1 GW was from wind, solar, biomass and hydro. Moreover, wind overtook coal to become Europe's second largest form of power by capacity after gas, with Germany alone installing 44% of the new wind capacity.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists study human language evolution via apes
article: UK-based scientists studied the communication calls of 'Orangutans', one of our closest ancestors. 'Kiss-squeaks' were analysed to understand t, p, k consonants as their sound depends on tongue-lip movement, rather than voice. They found that different signals were sometimes used to carry same information to reinforce a message like humans use 'car, vehicle, automobile' to convey the same meaning.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Surgeons remove 60-kg stomach tumour diagnosed as 'fat'
article: A California-based man recently got a 60-kg stomach tumour removed, earlier diagnosed as "just fat'' by a physician. The 57-year-old patient was largely confined to his living room as the lump made it difficult to walk. The 12-year-old tumour was found to be non-cancerous but still posed a potentially fatal risk because of its size, doctors said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: First ever rotating 'white dwarf' star discovered
article: Astronomers found the first 'white dwarf' pulsar since the discovery of the first pulsar (a rotating radiation-emitting star) 50 years ago. Until now, pulsars were only associated with neutron stars, a dense compact star usually 20-km wide and mass double that of the sun. Stars evolve into white dwarfs or neutron stars and eventually black holes depending on their mass.

author: Deepali Aggarwal
abstract: UN observes International Day of Women and Girls in Science
article: International Day of Women and Girls in Science is observed on February 11 each year to promote gender equality and encourage more women and girls to get involved in science and research. Women are increasingly graduating with life science degrees, however, there has been a decrease in female computer science graduates especially in developed economies, according to a UN report.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 3L yrs old undersea landslide revealed on Great Barrier Reef
article: Australia-based scientists have discovered the remains of a massive underwater landslide on the Great Barrier Reef. The event is thought to have happened more than 3 lakh years ago. Using 3-D simulations scientists found that a 27-metre high tsunami would have struck the coastline of present-day Australia scattering the debris across 30 kilometres.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA shares image of clouds carved by ‘gravity waves’
article: NASA shared a photograph of a rare cloud formation which appears like a ship carving its way through the sea. These ripples in the clouds are known as 'gravity waves'. Not to be confused with gravitational waves, gravity wave is a phenomenon of fluid dynamics resulting from displacement of a fluid, like water vapour, from a position of equilibrium.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Ultra-thin material can cool surfaces without using energy
article: US-based scientists have developed a thin, inexpensive material which can cool objects under direct sunlight without consuming water or electricity. The glass-polymer film, as thick as an aluminium foil, can cool rooftops by efficiently reflecting incoming solar energy while simultaneously allowing the surface to lose its own heat in the form of infrared thermal radiation.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Tree rings reveal unusual solar activity in the past
article: Researchers have identified a new type of solar event 7,000 years ago by carbon dating pine forests in California. The comparison of carbon-14 levels present in tree rings with known solar events reflected abnormal levels of cosmic radiation affecting the atmosphere at that time. Notably, solar activity on the Earth peaks and lows in roughly 11-year cycles.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Plants survive over one year in outer space
article: Two specimens of algae returned to Earth last June after 16 months on the exterior of International Space Station, are still alive despite standing extreme UV and cosmic radiations and temperature fluctuations in the vacuum of space. The algae began behaving normally within days of returning, but we are yet to examine potential damage to the algal DNA, researchers said.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Scientists develop 'lab on a chip' that costs less than ₹1
article: Stanford University scientists have developed a low-cost reusable "lab on a chip", using an ordinary inkjet printer that can detect lethal diseases like cancer and could potentially enhance diagnostic capabilities around the world. The inexpensive sequencing technology used in the chip allows experts to sequence tumour DNA to identify specific mutations and recommend personalised treatment plans.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Liver transplant saves life of boy with perpetual jaundice
article: Doctors at Apollo Hospital, Delhi cured a 13-year-old boy suffering from perpetual jaundice. In this rare condition, the liver does not produce an enzyme needed to break down a yellowish by-product of body's processes. The boy had to spend 12-15 hours per day under blue lights to help break it down, leaving liver transplant as the only option, doctors said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Japanese researchers use drones to pollinate flowers
article: In a first, Japanese researchers have used drones to pollinate flowers. To make their pollinator, the team stuck patches of horsehair under drones and also applied moist and sticky liquid ion gels on it to capture pollen grains. The drone was able to grab and release pollen from the male and female parts of pink and white Japanese lilies.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Baby born from 16-year-old frozen embryo in China
article: A 46-year-old woman in China gave birth to a healthy boy from an embryo that was frozen 16 years ago. She gave birth to her first child through the IVF procedure in 2000, and froze 18 of her other embryos. Out of those, she gave birth to her second son earlier this month, after China lifted the one-child policy.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: MIT develops ingestible battery that runs on stomach acid
article: MIT researchers have designed and demonstrated a small ingestible battery that is powered by the acidic fluids in the stomach. The 4-cm-long cylindrical cell can generate enough energy to power drug delivery devices and ingestible sensors for temperature, heart and breathing rate. During tests, the device was able to power a temperature sensor and transmit data wirelessly every 12 seconds.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Condom-free male contraceptive test on monkeys successful
article: A new male contraceptive gel 'Vasalgel' has been successfully tested on monkeys. The gel injected in 16 male monkeys before breeding, produced no side effects along with no pregnancies in females. The procedure, awaiting human trials, involves injecting a hydrogel in the sperm-carrying tube, vas deferens, rather than cutting it as in vasectomy, to filter sperms from the fluid ejaculation.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Japan's plan to clear space debris using 'fishing net' fails
article: A 700-metre-long fishing net-like structure, which was sent by Japan's space agency in December to clean up space debris, ended in failure as the agency could not deploy the steel structure in due time. The mission was aimed at cleaning up more than 100 million pieces of debris that were accumulated in over five decades of human space exploration.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Material can create electricity from light, heat, movement
article: Finland-based researchers have found that a material, called KBNNO, has the ability to generate electricity from sunlight, heat and kinetic energy, all at the same time. The material is not the best at any one type of energy conversion, however, it is relatively efficient at all the three types, with the study suggesting that the material can be improved.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 1st stable compound of chemically inactive helium confirmed
article: Helium, considered to be a chemically inert and unreactive gas due to its extremely stable and closed-shell electronic configuration, has been confirmed to form a stable compound (Na2He) with sodium under high pressure. These findings were so unexpected that it took more than two years to convince science reviewers and editors to publish their results, said the lead researcher.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Boeing's 'space taxi' will have over 600 3D-printed parts
article: American aircraft manufacturer Boeing has hired Oxford Performance Materials to make over 600 3D-printed parts for its Starliner 'space taxis' which will launch NASA astronauts into space. The parts will be printed with a plastic called PEKK, which is claimed to be as strong as aluminium and resistant to radiation and temperatures ranging from about -149ºC to 149ºC.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Astronomers find tail of stray black hole in the Milky Way
article: Japanese researchers accidentally found evidence of a hidden black hole while studying molecular clouds around a stellar explosion 10,000 light years away from Earth. They proposed two scenarios, where the expelled gas stream gets accelerated by an unknown gravitational pull, and one where the gas clouds start spinning into a dense stream both suggesting the existence of a black hole.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Sleep cuts neural links to make room for new memories: Study
article: A four-year-long study on mice shows that sleep makes some neural connections stronger and larger, while others are weakened or destroyed to make space for new memories. Neural connections' strengthening along with learning increases brain's energy consumption and may overload its information processing capacity, a scientist said, adding that sleep normalises overall strength of the connections.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Fukushima nuclear reactor radiation highest since 2011 leak
article: Radiation levels inside a damaged reactor at Japan-based Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station were found to be at their highest since the plant suffered a triple meltdown in 2011. Officials believe melted fuel that escaped pressure vessel is causing such toxic levels. The 2011 meltdown, considered among the worst ever, was initiated by a tsunami triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: East Asians genetically close to Stone Age primitives: Study
article: Researchers working on ancient DNA extracted from human remains in a Russian cave have found that the genetic makeup of modern East Asian populations closely resembles that of their Neolithic hunter-gatherer ancestors who inhabited the same region around 8,000 years ago. Notably, Western Europeans have a much different DNA from their local ancestors due to sustained migrations from Central Asia.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Sweden pledges to cut all greenhouse gas emissions by 2045
article: Sweden's deputy Prime Minister Isabella Lövin signed a climate bill aimed at cutting all greenhouse gas emissions in the country by 2045. Lövin said Sweden wanted to set an example at a time when ''climate sceptics are really gaining power in the world again''. She further said she feels encouraged by China's and India's pledges taken for Paris Agreement commitments.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Plants emit different odour when eaten by organisms: Study
article: A Germany-based study has found that plants emit different odour when eaten by insects or other small animals. This helps the plant to specifically attract natural enemies that feed on the herbivores eating them. The team also found that native plants can even recognise when they are being eaten by exotic herbivores, for which they emit a specific odour mixture.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: China becomes world's largest producer of solar power
article: China has surpassed Germany to become the world's largest producer of solar energy after nearly doubling its installed photovoltaic capacity in 2016. With the increased capacity, China generated 66.2 billion kilowatt-hours of energy last year, which however accounted for only 1% of its electrical output. The country further plans to double its current solar energy capacity by 2020.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Britain may not see Northern Lights after 2050: Study
article: UK-based scientists claim that Northern Lights over Britan's night sky would disappear by 2050 due to major shifts in solar activity. Plummeting solar activity would shrink sun's atmosphere by 33% and weaken its protective influence on the Earth making satellites and other devices vulnerable to solar blasts, said the study lead, stating the phenomenon may become exclusive to polar regions.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Meteorite confirms 200 cr years of Martian volcanic activity
article: Analysis of a Martian meteorite found in Africa has uncovered evidence of 200 crore years of volcanic activity on Mars, confirming the Red planet has some of the longest-lived volcanoes in the solar system. Notably, the largest Martian volcano Olympus Mons is nearly 27 kilometres high, almost triple the height of Earth's tallest volcano Mauna Kea in Hawaii.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA captures a star's death in 'rotten egg' nebula
article: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope captured a rare photograph of a dying star, transforming from a red giant to a planetary nebula and ejecting outer layers of gas and dust at almost 10 lakh kmph. The 'Rotten Egg' Nebula is called so because it contains sulphur, an element which smells like rotten eggs when combined with other elements.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: BBC to release episodes of Planet Earth II on Snapchat
article: BBC Worldwide and Snapchat's parent company Snap Inc are set to partner up to release six episodes of the nature documentary Planet Earth II on the mobile platform. The new episodes will run parallel to the debut of the show on BBC America on February 18. Each new episode of the show will be released on the platform weekly.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Ratan Tata unveils bus to support Indian team's moon mission
article: Ratan Tata on Tuesday unveiled 'Moonshot Wheels', a bus which will travel across the country to spread awareness about India's first private moon mission to be attempted by Bengaluru-based TeamIndus. The bus will travel to 11 states and carry astronomy models. TeamIndus is among five finalists for Google's Lunar XPRIZE competition and has signed a launch contract with ISRO.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists design a 'tree' which generates electricity
article: US-based scientists have built a biomimetic tree that mimics the branches and leaves of a cottonwood tree and generates electricity when its artificial leaves sway in the wind. It works on the principle of 'piezoelectric effect' in which small strips of specialised plastic inside the leaf stalks release an electrical charge when bent by moving air.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Rare monkey species spotted in Africa for first time
article: US-based scientists have recorded the first-ever video footage of a newly discovered population of critically endangered monkeys in the Congo basin, Central Africa. 'Dryas monkey', first reported in 1932, is a little understood species due to its elusive nature, said the researcher who underwent a tree climbing course to set up cameras high up the rainforest trees.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Homeopathy dangerous 'pseudoscience': Russia's science body
article: The Russian Academy of Sciences has become the latest body to declare homoeopathy as having "no scientific basis". The academy has termed homoeopathy as being dangerous and hopes for it to be presented as a "pseudoscience on par with magic, healing and psychic practices". The academy said that attempts to verify homeopathy's success had failed for over 200 years.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Preserved protein found in 195-mn-year-old dinosaur fossil
article: Researchers have found the first evidence of preserved proteins within a 195-million-year-old rib of the 'Lufengosaurus' dinosaur fossil. They believe that 'hematite' particles, which are formed in blood, acted as the catalyst for preserving the protein in vascular canals of the bones. These proteins are more than 100 million years older than anything previously discovered, said the study lead.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Quake bigger than Nepal 2015 may hit North India soon: Study
article: A study by the Wadia Institute of Himalayan Geology claims that an earthquake more catastrophic than the one experienced in 2015 in Nepal could hit parts of North India soon. The study of tectonic plate movement has revealed that the Indian Plate is moving towards the Eurasian Plate at 45 millimetres per year, building pressure under the region.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: New data transfer record created in Quantum computing
article: US-based scientists have set a new record of data transfer via superdense coding, a process by which the properties of particles like photons, protons, and electrons are used to store information. While computers transmit information in the form of bits (1 or 0), quantum bits can employ two states simultaneously and therefore represent more information than a traditional bit.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Injection may permanently lower cholesterol by altering DNA
article: Scientists have created a one-off injection that could lower the cholesterol levels of a person permanently by altering the structure of the person's DNA. A natural mutation of a specific gene, when disabled, lowers the risk of heart diseases. The injection will permanently alter the DNA inside some of the cells of a person's body.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Scientists create 3D projection of a nanoparticle
article: Scientists have used high-resolution transmission electron microscope to map 3D structural projections of an iron-platinum nanoparticle. The team captured 2D projections before using algorithms to stitch them together. The project will help spot flaws in nanoparticle products, which could help in health care. The project will help create a database that illustrates atom-level material properties.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Brain-reading tech allows talking to fully paralysed victims
article: A brain-computer interface has been used in Switzerland to read thoughts and conduct basic communications with "locked-in" patients, who have absolutely no control over their body. The technology detects brain activity of the patients, who have not been able to speak for years, enabling them to answer "yes-no" questions. The accuracy of the system was reported to be about 75%.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: World's tiniest hammer built to test impact on brain cells
article: US-based scientists have created world's tiniest hammer, named μHammer (microHammer), to study what happens when a force is applied to brain cells. This would enable precise measurements of physical, chemical and biological changes that occur when cells are subjected to mechanical stress. The technique may provide a better view of neural conditions like Alzheimer's and traumatic brain injuries.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Wind turbine breaks world record for 24-hr energy generation
article: Denmark-based MHI Vestas Offshore unveiled a prototype 9-megawatt wind turbine which broke the world record for energy generation over a 24-hour period by a single turbine. The 220-metre-tall V164 turbine, considered as the world's biggest wind turbine in production, achieved 2,16,000 kilowatt-hours over 24 hours, which is reportedly enough to power an average Indian household for over 200 years.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Milky Way being pushed at 20 lakh km/h by an unknown force
article: As per a recent research, Milky Way is being pushed across the universe at 20,00,000 kmph by an unknown repellent force from a cosmic dead region, dubbed "dipole repeller". It's been known that a galaxy "supercluster" 750 million light-years away is pulling the Milky Way, but researchers suspected that apart from a pull, it is also experiencing a pushing force.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: There is a hill on Mars named after Kalpana Chawla
article: NASA named seven hills on planet Mars after the crew members of the Space Shuttle Columbia who lost their lives while returning from their mission. The crew, including India-born astronaut Kalpana Chawla, died when the space shuttle disintegrated on re-entering Earth's atmosphere on February 1, 2003. "The Columbia crew...made the supreme sacrifice in the name of exploration," announced NASA.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Second person to walk on moon Buzz Aldrin walks the ramp
article: Former astronaut and the second person to walk on the Moon, Buzz Aldrin walked the ramp at a fashion event in New York. Buzz, accompanied by renowned science educator 'Bill Nye the Science Guy', was part of Nick Graham's fashion show, where he revealed his 'Life on Mars' menswear collection, featuring garments printed with rockets, planets and representing Martian features.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Study offers first evidence of universe being a hologram
article: A recent study offered the first-ever observational evidence of the universe being a vast, complex hologram. Scientists said evidence from early universe fits into the hologram explanation as well as it does with Big Bang theory. In the 90s, physicists had conceptualised that our 3D 'reality' (plus time) is a projection of a 2D surface containing information on its boundaries.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Taste buds are replaced every ten days
article: The average lifespan of a taste bud has been estimated to be approximately 10 days. Apart from their natural cycle, which ranges from 10 days to two weeks, taste buds are also renewed when hot food items burn the tongue. The tongue regrows the cells, which develop their normal sense of taste within days.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Astronauts' brains change shape during spaceflight: Study
article: MRI scans before and after space missions revealed that astronauts' brains compress and expand during spaceflight, according to a US-based study. The study was based on 12 astronauts who spent two weeks in a spacecraft and 14 who spent six months on the International Space Station. Researchers observed that the gray matter volume increased in regions that control leg movement.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA spots farthest galaxies powered by massive black holes
article: NASA has identified the farthest gamma-ray blazars, a type of galaxies whose emissions are powered by supersized black holes. Light from these blazars began its journey when the universe was 1.4 billion-year-old, nearly 10% of its present age. The presence of such massive black holes challenge existing theories on how they could grow in a young universe, said the lead.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Earth's oxygen is being sent to moon by solar winds: Study
article: Earth's ozone layer oxygen is being carried to the moon covering almost 4,00,000 km by solar winds, according to a new report. The process, which has been occurring for 2.4 billion years, happens for five days every month when Earth is aligned between the sun and moon. However, this isn't enough to develop breathable atmosphere on the moon, researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Over 3-km long crack found in Arizona in the US
article: A gaping 3.2-kilometre-long crack has been found in the barren land of Arizona, US, possibly created due to the withdrawal of groundwater for agricultural activities, say geologists who warn that it might continue growing. The crack was first spotted in Google Earth imagery by a geologist with the Arizona Geological Survey and was recently filmed using a drone.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create world’s first heat-driven transistor
article: Sweden-based researchers claim to have developed world's first heat-driven transistor, where a single-degree temperature rise is sufficient to cause a detectable current variation. The device has many applications like heat cameras and medical dressings where healing process can be monitored. A transistor is a semiconductor device primarily used to switch or amplify electrical power in circuits.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA puts some of its moon landing photos up for auction
article: A set of photographic prints from NASA's archives is up for auction in New York. The selection includes photos from the first and last manned moon landing featuring Neil Armstrong of Apollo 11 in 1969 and Eugene Cernan of Apollo 17 in 1972 respectively. The gallery also showcases the first American spacewalk by Ed White in 1965.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Material 200 times tougher than steel made using cooking oil
article: Australia-based scientists have used soybean oil to create graphene, a material 200 times stronger than steel. The technology 'GraphAir' involves heating soybean oil to decompose it into carbon building blocks which were cooled into a graphene film, thinner than a human hair. Even leftover cooking oil could be used for this which would drastically reduce its price, said the lead.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Low oxygen delayed Earth's evolution by 200 crore yrs: Study
article: A UK-based study claims that low levels of atmospheric oxygen in Earth's middle ages held back evolution for around 200 crore years. Although oxygen was introduced in the atmosphere around 240 crore years ago, it was consumed at the same rate by organic material until the rise of oxygen production through photosynthesis, which was sufficient for life to evolve.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: India largest contributor to cancer deaths worldwide
article: India continues to remain the largest contributor to cancer deaths at 22 lakh every year, out of the global figure of 88 lakh. According to doctors, 70% of Indian cancer patients consult the doctor at the terminal stage. Smoking, alcohol and unhealthy diet are the leading factors, with lung, breast, colon, prostate and stomach being the most frequent cancer types.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA spacecraft captures Saturn's rings in high detail
article: NASA released new images captured by Cassini spacecraft which is currently in its 'Ring-Grazing' orbit phase observing Saturn's rings of icy debris. Launched in 1997, Cassini has been touring the Saturn system since arriving in 2004. It has made numerous discoveries, including an ocean within the moon Enceladus, and liquid methane seas on another moon, Titan.

author: Deepali Aggarwal
abstract: Over 100 world heritage sites degraded by humans: Study
article: A study has warned that over 100 Natural World Heritage Sites are being severely damaged by encroaching human activities since 1993. The study found increased human footprint in 63% and forest loss in 91% of the 223 sites. India's Manas wildlife sanctuary was found to have the maximum human footprint while North America and Australia have the worst forest loss.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Mystery behind Bihar's fatal illness outbreak in 1995 solved
article: Indian scientists have solved the mystery of an illness that spread in Muzzafarpur, Bihar in 1995, killing almost 300 out of 1,000 affected. Occurring annually during summers, the outbreak was attributed to high litchi consumption on an empty stomach by children from litchi orchards around. Notably, litchi has a toxin called hypoglycin which inhibits production of glucose in the body.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: How do we study the stars?
article: Astronomy, which is a natural science that studies celestial objects, is believed to be the oldest science in human history. Astrophysicists mainly use light to study distant stars to find out the star's composition and structure. Using different kinds of telescopes, including infrared, ultraviolet, and X-ray, they study the characteristic wavelengths of the light emitted by a star.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: ISS astronaut stars in video showing his daily life in space
article: French astronaut Thomas Pesquet aboard the International Space Station collaborated with French musician Yuksek for a music video depicting his everyday life in space. He is on a six-month mission on the Earth-orbiting spacecraft to perform around 50 scientific experiments for the European Space Agency and France's space agency CNES. ''Music makes the world go round'', tweeted Pesquet.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Remnants of a 'lost continent' found under Mauritius
article: Researchers have confirmed the existence of a "lost continent" under Mauritius in the Indian Ocean. The "lost continent" was left over during the break-up of Gondwana, a supercontinent comprising Antarctica, Australia and Africa, among others, almost 180 million years ago. It was subsequently covered by young lava during volcanic eruptions on Mauritius.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Fish found to communicate with one another using urine
article: Swiss researchers have found a fish species that communicates through urine. They placed the 'cichlid' fish in containers with opaque and transparent barriers and found aggressive patterns and high urine emissions when fish were able to see each other. Upon introducing tiny holes in the partitions, allowing urine's movement through the barrier, a noticeable change in fish behavior was observed.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists claim to produce Tuberculosis-resistant cows
article: Scientists in China claim to have genetically engineered 11 cloned calves using a gene-editing technique which has shown heightened resistance to tuberculosis. As many as 12 genetically modified calves were born, 11 of which survived for more than three months and did not show any unwanted side effects from the process, researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Water detected in atmosphere of Jupiter-like exoplanet
article: Astronomers have detected the presence of water molecules in the atmosphere of a nearby exoplanet. Located 50 light years away, '51 Pegasi b' is the first exoplanet discovered orbiting a star and the first known 'hot Jupiter'. It has a high surface temperature, as it orbits its parent star very closely, at a distance of only 75 lakh km.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists create world's first human-pig hybrid
article: US-based researchers have created the first-ever human-pig hybrid by injecting human stem cells into early-stage pig embryos. The hybrid embryos were essentially pig, with a small human contribution of around one in 10,000 cells. The development has increased the prospects of growing human organs inside animals which could then be used in transplants.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Scientists find 'earliest known human ancestor'
article: Researchers have discovered the fossilized traces of the earliest known ancestor of humans - a microscopic sea animal called Saccorhytus coronarious. Thought to have lived 540 million years ago, the creature has a bag-like body, a huge mouth and no anus.
