Researchers have called it the starting point of the evolutionary path that led to fishes and ultimately to humans.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Physicists confirm 'time crystals' as a new form of matter
article: Physicists have discovered a new form of matter, 'time crystals', that break the symmetry of time. These crystals have a structure that repeats in time as they're ‘kicked’ periodically, like the way Jell-O jiggles when it is tapped, researchers said, calling it the first example of ‘non-equilibrium matter'. In the future, the 'time crystals' could be used in quantum computers.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Dress made using world's second strongest material
article: In a first, UK-based fashion-technology firm CuteCircuit has created a dress made of graphene, the second strongest material known. Graphene, which is also the world's thinnest material and the best-known conductor of electricity, enables the dress fitted with LEDs to change colours in sync with wearer's breathing. The designers hope this advancement could be used to make programmable dresses.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Indian space observatory spots a star 'eating' a bigger body
article: India's first dedicated space observatory ASTROSAT has captured the rare phenomenon of a small, 6-billion-year-old star 'preying' on a bigger celestial body. Scientists said the smaller star, also called a blue straggler, is becoming bigger, hotter and bluer by sucking out the bigger celestial body's mass and energy, causing its eventual death.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Study explains prolonged effects of LSD
article: A US-based study claims to be the first to explain the long-lasting effects of the drug LSD. Held by serotonin receptors that regulate happiness and anxiety, the drug lingers in the brain for up to 12 hours. The findings could help chemists produce shorter-acting versions of the drug for clinical uses in anxiety or post-traumatic stress disorder.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: 'Survival gene' found that prevents growth of TB bacteria
article: Scientists have discovered a 'survival gene' that prevents strains of tuberculosis (TB) from mutating into drug-resistant 'superbugs'. They screened nearly every gene (11,000) in TB-causing mycobacteria for mutations on a specific antibiotic and found a DNA repair enzyme, produced by 'NucS' gene that prevents the mutations. Notably, 18 lakh people died from the airborne disease last year.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Metal found to conduct electricity but not heat
article: US-based scientists have found that metal vanadium dioxide (VO2) can conduct electricity without conducting heat. The material's conductivity can also be fine-tuned by mixing it with other materials. The team found that the thermal conductivity attributed to its electrons is ten times smaller than what would be expected. The find could help convert waste heat from appliances into electricity.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists identify brain hormone that triggers fat burning
article: A team of US-based scientists headed by an Indian-origin biologist has identified a brain hormone that appears to trigger fat burning in human gut. They researched on roundworms since their brain produces similar signalling molecules as humans. A hormone 'FLP-7' was found, secreted by neurons to trigger fat burning in response to high levels of a gut regulating neurotransmitter 'serotonin'.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: New artificial skin created that can feel temperature change
article: A US-Swiss research collaboration has created an artificial skin capable of detecting temperature changes. They fabricated synthetic wood to create a thin transparent temperature sensitive film which reacts via electrical impulses. It could have various applications like on prosthetic limbs to restore temperature sensing, wound healing, and improving human-robot interactions, said project lead.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: There is a jellyfish that can age backwards
article: A species of jellyfish, Turritopsis dohrnii, can age normally as well as backwards, making it theoretically 'immortal'. In case of starvation or physical damage, the jellyfish transforms its existing cells into a younger state, according to a research. Capable of reversing the ageing process, the species is believed to be the only immortal creature in the world.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: AI found to be as good as doctors at spotting cancer
article: Stanford researchers have developed a deep learning based artificial intelligence that they claim is as good as human doctors at detecting skin cancer by looking at clinical images. Harnessed using Google's image recognition algorithm, the AI trained using almost 130,000 skin disease images, could further be developed for smartphones to facilitate easy access and early detection, researchers said.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Universe is expanding up to 9% faster than expected: Study
article: A new study using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has found the universe is expanding 5-9% faster than expected. Astronomers recalculated universe's expansion rate with improved techniques for faraway galaxies, which is higher than predictions by Einstein's general theory of relativity. The findings may be an important clue to understand dark energy, dark matter and dark radiation, said study lead.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists working on deflecting asteroids headed for Earth
article: A Spain-based international project is aimed at deflecting asteroids away from Earth using projectiles. Researchers studied an 18-metre wide asteroid which exploded into thousands of meteorites over Chelyabinsk, Russia and caused hundreds of injuries. They concluded that physical properties like the composition, internal structure and density are fundamental in determining a successful deflection.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Earth made its own water deep inside the mantle: Study
article: Canadian researchers have claimed that water might have formed inside Earth, rather than arriving from space through collisions with icy comets billions of years ago. Simulations showed that reactions of liquid hydrogen and quartz at conditions similar to Earth's upper mantle formed water trapped inside quartz itself, leading to high pressure that could trigger earthquakes deep below the surface.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Mathematician proposes to stop Tsunamis using sound waves
article: A UK-based mathematician has proposed that Tsunamis could be stopped using acoustic gravity waves. These naturally occurring sounds waves can travel thousands of metres deep in the ocean. If engineered, they can be fired repeatedly at an incoming tsunami to reduce its height, and dissipate its energy over a large area until it reaches the shore, said the researcher.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Scientists raise doubt on first-ever hydrogen metal claim
article: Harvard scientists recently claimed to have created a 'shiny' metallic form of hydrogen for the first time ever. It was achieved by pressurising liquid hydrogen between two diamond tips higher than those existing in Earth's core. However, several other researchers have raised doubts on the claim and believe the shiny material observed may have been alumina residue from the diamonds.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: 'Light pillar' phenomenon witnessed in Russia
article: The 'light pillar' phenomenon, wherein multicoloured pillar-like patterns appear suspended in the sky, has been witnessed in numerous Russian cities. A Russian Academy of Sciences member explained the phenomenon, "The air was humid and then the water started to crystallise. Basically, pieces of ice or snowflakes started to form in the air." The phenomenon occurs when ice crystals reflect light.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Air travel's radiation risk higher than known before: NASA
article: A study by NASA has found that the risk of radiation doses at elevated altitudes during air travel is higher than expected. NASA sent giant helium-filled weather balloons with measurement devices into the stratosphere. The radiation is a result of the showering of high-energy particles from space which can cause DNA breakdown, affecting the functioning of cells.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: All corn diet turns hamsters into 'crazed cannibals': Study
article: France-based researchers have reported that a diet of only maize is turning wild hamsters in corn fields into deranged cannibals that devour their offspring. The reason being the unbalanced diet leaves rodents starving and deficient in vitamin B3. However, in a set of experiments when corn-based diets enriched with B3 were provided, hamsters didn't eat their offspring.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Facebook addiction may depend on one's genes: Study
article: A new UK-based study has found that genes may strongly influence how people use social media sites such as Facebook, chat rooms and online gaming. By comparing online media use in more than 8,500 twins, scientists found heritability was of considerable importance for time spent on all types of media, including entertainment (37%), online gaming (39%) and social networking (24%).

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA develops a new test for life on other planets
article: NASA scientists have designed a new test for life on other planets, 10,000 times more sensitive than current methods. The test based on chirality works by analysing 'amino acids', the structural building blocks of all life. Chiral molecules come in "left" and "right"-handed forms. While amino acids from non-living sources contain both forms, acids from living organisms are mostly "left-handed".

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: US Navy uses hagfish slime to make bulletproof equipment
article: US Navy scientists have created a synthetic version of hagfish slime that has mechanical properties similar to Kevlar, a material used for bullet proof vests. Hagfish are eel-like fish that secrete a protective viscous slime when attacked by predators. "The synthetic hagfish slime may be used for ballistics protection, firefighting, diver protection, or anti-shark spray,'' said the project lead.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Sahara Desert was 10 times as wet as today, claims study
article: The Sahara, world's largest hot desert, was a green area covered with vegetation 5,000 to 11,000 years ago, with rainfall up to ten times more than today's, a study has claimed. It used rainfall records to depict a 1000-year period about 8,000 years ago, when the Sahara became drier. The 1000-year dry period caused people to leave, scientists suggested.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Climate change may increase mercury level in fish by 7 times
article: Swedish researchers have found that rising global temperatures could increase mercury levels in fish by up to seven times. In simulations, they found that extra rainfall drives up the amount of organic material flowing into the seas. This alters the food chain, adding another layer of complex organisms which boosts the concentrations of mercury up the line, reaching humans.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: NASA pays tribute to crew of 'Apollo 1' tragedy
article: NASA marked the 50th anniversary of its fatal Apollo 1 launchpad fire with the first public display of the scorched hatch in Florida. The hatch had trapped three astronauts inside the spaceship's cockpit during a routine pre-launch test on January 27, 1967. NASA later made dozens of design changes leading to the historic Apollo 11 moon landing in July 1969.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Alzheimer's disease could begin before birth: Study
article: Canada-based researchers have found that Alzheimer's disease could begin in the womb or just after birth if the fetus or newborn does not get enough vitamin A. The study, performed on mice, found that even a mild vitamin A deficiency increased the production of a protein which helps in killing neurons during Alzheimer's and facilitates the disease.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Indian team selected to land a spacecraft on moon
article: Bengaluru-based 'TeamIndus' is among the five international finalists for a $20-million award (approximately ₹136 crore) by Google Lunar XPRIZE. To win, a privately-funded team must land a robot on the moon that travels at least 500 metres and sends high-definition video and images back to Earth. TeamIndus has taken a contract from ISRO to launch its unmanned spacecraft.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Hydrogen turned into metal for the first time
article: In a first, Harvard scientists have succeeded in creating metallic hydrogen by squeezing a liquid hydrogen sample using two diamonds. The feat was achieved by subjecting the sample to pressures above those existing in the core of the Earth. The material is theorised to have a wide range of applications, spanning from room-temperature superconductors to powerful rocket propellant.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: China is planning world’s brightest light source facility
article: China is planning to build the world's brightest light source facility in Beijing, the China Daily reported. Expected to start in 2018, the project will effectively be a next-generation synchrotron radiation facility and will create the brightest X-rays worldwide. The facility, dubbed Beijing Light Source, will cost $698 million (₹4,760 crore) and is estimated to be completed in six years.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Doctors save woman's life by removing her lungs for six days
article: In a first, doctors in Canada saved a young mother's life by removing her infected lungs. She had just hours to live as the bacterial infection had grown resistant to antibiotics shutting her organs, doctors said. A small artificial lung was connected to her heart and a successful lung transplant was done six days later after they found a donor.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Gene-editing therapy eliminates cancer in two infants
article: UK-based doctors have cured two infants who were diagnosed with a previously incurable form of leukemia, in the world's first attempt to treat cancer with genetically engineered immune cells from a donor. The two girls have remained disease-free after almost a year of their treatment. In each case, the immune cells were genetically engineered to attack cancer cells.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Asteroid passes by Earth 30% closer than the Moon
article: For the second time in just three weeks, a new-found asteroid, the size of a bus passed between the Earth and the Moon at roughly 27,000 kmph. Asteroid 'Rerun', which was discovered on January 20 and is estimated to be 4-14 metres in diameter, came within two-thirds distance of moon and Earth on January 25.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: New 100-million-year-old 'ET-like' insect species discovered
article: Scientists have discovered a 100-million-year-old insect species which appears like the alien character from the movie 'ET', preserved in amber in Myanmar. The insect has a triangular head with bulging eyes giving it the ability to see almost 180° by turning its head sideways. Aethiocarenodea, a new scientific order has been created to be assigned to the insect.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Firm makes technology to turn dragonflies into living drones
article: Biomedical solutions company Draper is developing a technology to turn dragonflies into 'living drones'. The main component of the DragonflEye project is a solar panel-equipped backpack to harvest energy. It also has a navigation system to send commands to neurons that control the insect's flight. The dragonflies could potentially act as surveillance systems or pollination machines.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Memory erasing therapy tested to treat alcohol addiction
article: UK-based researchers are testing a therapy involving ketamine, an anaesthetic known for its potential to treat depression, to "erase" drink-related memories and overcome alcohol addiction. Ketamine is known to block a brain receptor which is required for the formation of memories. Scientists are using the drug to "hijack" and then over-write the memories that drive addiction in people.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study links shape of brain with different personality traits
article: Researchers have found that brain's shape is linked with different personality traits. Scientists associated thickness and amount of folding in brain's cortex with personality traits like neuroticism (negative emotional state tendency) and openness. High neuroticism level was linked with increased thickness and reduced folding in cortex regions while openness was associated with opposite patterns.

author: Deepali Aggarwal
abstract: World underprepared for future disease outbreaks: Study
article: The world remains "grossly underprepared" for outbreaks of infectious diseases which are likely to become more frequent in coming decades, according to a study. Researchers said better preparedness could have prevented most of the 11,000 deaths caused due to the Ebola outbreak. The study recommended improvements to outbreak-related research, WHO reforms and to broaden humanitarian response system.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists produce artificial silk from cow's milk
article: Sweden-based scientists have developed artificial silk using proteins of cow's whey, the liquid which remains after milk has been curdled and strained. Under the influence of heat and acid, the proteins assembled to form nanofibrils, with the thickness and length of the silk fibres depending on the concentration of proteins. The development could pave way for novel biosensors.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New metamaterial can switch from soft to hard
article: University of Michigan researchers have developed a technique to design a metamaterial which can change its level of solidness, switching from soft to hard and vice versa. Metamaterials are man-made materials whose properties come from the way it is constructed rather than from what it's composed of. Shifting between hard and soft states does not change or damage the material.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Trial finds 2 cancer drugs instead of 1 increase survival
article: Scientists have discovered that using a combination of two drugs for treating pancreatic cancer greatly increases patients' chances of survival for a longer time. Clinical trials have found that 29% of patients who were given two chemotherapy drugs, gemcitabine and capecitabine, lived for at least five years after diagnosis, compared with 16% who received only one of the drugs.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: Researchers build a 1,000-watt 'super laser'
article: British and Czech researchers have successfully fired a 1,000-watt 'high peak power laser', claimed to have average power 10 times more than any other of its kind. Although there are a couple of petawatt (15 zeros) lasers in the US and Japan, but they can only fire few times a day producing a lesser 'average power' output, researchers said.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Black hole model found to be turning into superfluid state
article: Researchers at the University of Waterloo have modelled a theoretical black hole that changes into a form which mathematically behaves identically to how liquid helium behaves when it turns into the superfluid state. These kinds of black holes are said to be existing in a higher-dimensional space-time with properties different from the ones existing in our universe.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Bursts of methane may have warmed early Mars: Study
article: A new US-based study has suggested that early Mars may have been warmed intermittently by bursts of methane, a greenhouse gas. Interactions between methane, carbon dioxide and hydrogen in the early Martian atmosphere may have created warm periods, which could have supported liquid water on the surface around three to four billion years ago.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Cause of supervolcano eruption 73,000 years ago found
article: International researchers have decoded what triggered the eruption of Indonesian supervolcano Toba about 73,000 years ago, considered as one of the largest eruptions witnessed by mankind. Scientists found that quartz crystals that grow in the magma, register chemical and thermodynamical changes in the magmatic system prior to eruption, characterised by change of composition of oxygen's isotopes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Ants genetically modified to show how animal societies work
article: In an effort to understand the impact of genetics on the societal behaviour of animals, US-based researchers genetically modified an ant species to see how the changes affect their social behaviour. Eliminating the genes for olfactory receptors (related to a sense of smell) led to the ants wandering alone for days, as against their standard preference for socialising in groups.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Wasps compete for the 'best trade deals': Study
article: A UK-based study has found wasps follow the 'supply and demand' theory and compete for the best trade deals with trading partners. 'Helper wasps' raise the offsprings of dominant breeders in exchange for staying in the nest. When alternative nesting options are available, dominant wasps compete to give the 'best deal' to 'helper wasps' and allow them to work less.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US research scholars planning to make beer on moon
article: A group of University of California research scholars is planning to make beer on the moon by sending a fermentation vessel aboard an Indian spacecraft, set to launch this year. The experiment will test the viability of yeast on the moon, as it is important for development of pharmaceuticals and yeast-containing foods like bread in outer space.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Astronomers discover one of the brightest distant galaxies
article: International researchers have discovered one of the brightest distant galaxies in the universe, located at 11.4 billion light years from Earth. Identified as 'BG1429+1202', the newly discovered galaxy emits Lyman alpha radiation, one of the brightest in the ultraviolet range. The discovery was possible after the galaxy's apparent brightness was increased by the zooming effect of another galaxy.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA video shows global climate change over the years
article: US space agency NASA has released a video showing the global climate change since modern record-keeping began in 1880 till the last year. The video shows that from the 1980s onwards, the cooler years (blue) decreased significantly and warmer years (orange, red) went on increasing. NASA declared 2016 as the warmest year on record last week.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists recreate Jupiter's atmosphere in lab
article: In a first, researchers have simulated Jupiter's atmosphere in a laboratory and have demonstrated the swirling winds or "jets" on the planet. Recently, Juno spacecraft had found that ammonia gas not only exists in the planet's upper atmosphere but also plunges into its gaseous interior. Scientists demonstrated the winds likely extend thousands of kilometres below Jupiter's visible atmosphere.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: British astronaut Tim Peake to return to ISS for 2nd mission
article: British astronaut Tim Peake is set to return to the International Space Station (ISS) as he'll be tasked with conducting new scientific research aboard the station. Peake, who became the first British astronaut aboard the ISS in 2015 and completed a six-month stint aboard it, will be working with the European Space Agency (ESA).

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Public to choose Jupiter picture sites for NASA's Juno probe
article: US space agency NASA has developed a webpage which allows the public to vote for the best locations in the atmosphere of Jupiter, which would then be imaged by the Juno spacecraft. JunoCam, the camera aboard the spacecraft, will take the selected pictures during its close flyby of the planet, which will be then posted for the voters for processing.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Brain scan of premature babies may predict disability risks
article: A new research suggests that scanning brains of prematurely born babies may help predict whether the infant will develop disabilities later. The study found that premature babies diagnosed with greater white matter injury volume in the brain were 79 times more likely to develop thinking problems by age of 18 months, and 64 times more likely to develop movement problems.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists prove that microbes could survive on Mars
article: US-based researchers have proved that microbes could survive on Mars despite its harsh environment. The research is rooted on methane's detection on Mars by Curiosity probe, and that most of Earth's methane is produced by living organisms. By imitating Martian conditions in test tubes, scientists found that microbes could survive for 3-21 days, and possibly exist underneath the planet's surface.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Overcooked potatoes, burnt toast could cause cancer: FSA
article: The Food Standards Agency (FSA) has warned that eating overcooked potatoes and burnt toast can increase the risk of cancer. The risk has been linked with consumption of too much acrylamide, a chemical found in starchy foods cooked at high temperatures, and has been shown to cause cancer in animals. The warning also covers cereals, biscuits and chips, among others.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Sun has followed same routine for 29 crore yrs, finds study
article: Germany-based scientists have suggested the sun has been following the same routine for at least 29 crore years. Scientists found the sun underwent a sunspot cycle of approximately 10.6 years during ancient times, quite similar to the 11-year cycle of modern times. A sunspot cycle is a time after which sun's illumination completes one round of increasing and decreasing brightness.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New method that may help pair cells with smartphones devised
article: Scientists have genetically modified bacterial cells, enabling it to recognise body's electronic signals, and then used it to control bacteria's protein synthesis. These cells were reprogrammed to respond to redox molecules which move electrons in biological system via chemical reactions. The advancement would let smartphones, which communicate via electrons, pair with cells and treat diseases.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Ultrasound used to push RNA inside cells to treat diseases
article: MIT researchers have been able to push RNA strands into the colon (large intestine) cells using bursts of ultrasound waves. Low-frequency ultrasound waves make bubbles in a solution, which later burst, pushing the RNA into cells. Using the approach in mice, scientists reduced the production of a protein involved in inflammatory bowel disease (intestinal disorder) by seven to ten times.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Children with asthma are more likely to become obese: Study
article: A new research has found that children with asthma are 51% more likely to become obese within ten years of being diagnosed, as compared to the kids who do not have respiratory problems. It is believed that asthmatic children may be at greater risk of gaining excess weight because difficulty in breathing causes them to exercise less.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: The Sun appears white in space instead of yellow
article: The Sun, which appears white in space, seems yellow on Earth because of the Earth's atmosphere. Sunlight comprises a spectrum of colours that together produce the colour white. However, in the atmosphere, the colours blue, indigo and violet are scattered away, thus making the Sun appear yellowish-orange to the human eyes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Archaeologists find man whose tongue was replaced by stone
article: A Roman British skeleton has been discovered in England's Northamptonshire with the tongue apparently severed and a flat stone pushed into his mouth. The man was buried face down and archaeologists have suggested that the mutilation might be a harsh form of punishment. A study of facedown burials has suggested the practice was used to disrespect the deceased.

author: Parichit Mainra
abstract: China builds world's largest solar farm
article: China has reportedly built the world's largest solar park which can produce about 850 MW of power in Qinghai province. The Longyangxia Dam Solar Park occupies 27 square kilometres and has been expanded several times since its construction began in 2013. The farm was built at the cost of around $875 million (around ₹6,000 crore), according to reports.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New satellite captures detailed full-disk view of Earth
article: One of the most detailed full-disk view of the Earth has been captured by National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's latest weather satellite, GOES-16. It extends from the West African coast to the island territory of Guam in the Western Pacific, including North and South America and the surrounding oceans. The images were taken from a height of approximately 36,000 kilometres.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Ultrafast camera images ‘sonic boom’ of light for first time
article: In a first, US-based researchers have filmed light creating a 'sonic boom' - officially known as a photonic Mach cone - using a new ultra-speed camera capable of taking 100 billion frames in a second. The real-time video shows light pulses leaving behind cone-shaped wakes of light, just like aircrafts flying at speeds faster than sound, creating sonic booms.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists engineer first ever 'semi-synthetic' organism
article: US-based scientists have engineered the world's first stable semi-synthetic organism by expanding E. coli bacteria's genetic code to six letters using human-created DNA bases. While every living organism on Earth is formed by a four-letter DNA code represented by G, T, C and A, the DNA of the modified organisms are made with two additional synthetic bases, X and Y.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Man grows tree that produces 40 varieties of fruit
article: Professor Sam Van Aken has created a tree variety, through a process called 'chip grafting', which bears 40 varieties of stone fruits including peaches, plums and cherries. The 'Tree of 40 Fruit' begins to bear fruits in the summer months. Aken has created more than twelve such trees, that have been planted around the United States.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: A quarter of the bones in human body are found in the feet
article: With each foot consisting of 26 bones, the feet comprise a quarter of the bones found in the human body. Out of the 206 bones in the body of an adult, 52 are found in the feet, with each normal foot additionally comprising around 30 joints and over 100 ligaments. However, some people may have 28 bones in each foot.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Smart jacket diagnoses pneumonia 3 times faster than doctor
article: Ugandan engineers have invented a 'smart jacket' which they claim diagnoses pneumonia up to three times faster than a doctor. The sensors inbuilt in the biomedical jacket pick up sound patterns from the lungs, breathing rate and body temperature. The processed information is then sent to a mobile phone app via Bluetooth, to estimate the strength of the disease.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New molecule developed reverses antibiotic resistance
article: US-based researchers have developed a new molecule that reverses antibiotic resistance in multiple strains of bacteria at once. The molecule works by attacking an enzyme called 'NDM-1', which makes bacteria resistant to a wide range of penicillins. The development will help treat infections which were previously easily treatable, but have grown immune to antibiotics.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Viruses found communicating with each other
article: In a first, Israeli scientists have found viruses communicate with one another to coordinate their attack during an infection. Bacterial viruses (phages) leave messages for other viruses by secreting peptide molecules. This helps later phage generations to 'count' how many previous viruses have succeeded in infecting the host cells, and decide whether it is preferable to attack or lie dormant.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mosquitoes modified genetically to reduce dengue spread
article: In a first, US-based scientists have genetically engineered Aedes aegypti mosquitoes to develop increased resistance against dengue virus. Scientists engineered the mosquitoes to break the pathway between infection and transmission of virus to healthy people. This was done by modifying the mosquitoes to produce more of certain proteins so that they produce fewer copies of the virus in their guts.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Good nutrition in pregnancy equals an year of school: Study
article: An international study has found that multiple micronutrient supplements taken by a mother during pregnancy can add an equivalent of up to one full year of schooling to a child's cognitive abilities at 9-12 years of age. Conducted on around 3,000 Indonesian children, scientists found that a nurturing environment is more strongly correlated than biological factors to brain development.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Periodic table links elements with their origin
article: US-based astronomer Jennifer Johnson has created a periodic table which links elements in our solar system with their origin. It categorises the sources of elements under six physical processes of the universe, including the 'Big Bang fusion' and 'cosmic ray fission'. For instance, oxygen originated from supernovae and is listed under 'exploding massive stars' category.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Doctors test 'miniature' MRI scanner for premature babies
article: Doctors in England's Sheffield city are testing a 'miniature' MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scanner for imaging the brains of premature babies. It is one of the only two purpose-built neonatal MRI scanners in the world. Research has shown that MRI is a better technique to visualise the structures of brains in infants, as compared to ultrasound.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: S'pore's 1st ISS satellite can orbit twice as long as others
article: Singapore's first satellite which was launched from the International Space Station (ISS), AOBA VELOX-III, is claimed to stay in orbit for twice as long as similar satellites. A new thruster technology will keep the 110-metre habitable satellite at an orbiting speed of 27,000 kilometres per hour for up to six months, double the three-month lifespan of such satellites.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop 'blood-repellant' material
article: US-based scientists have developed a blood-repellant material which they claim can prevent blood clots in patients getting medical implants. A "superhemophobic" titanium surface was created by growing chemically-altered surfaces acting as barriers between titanium sheets and blood. If successfully applied, it could form the basis for surgical implants with lower risk of rejection by the body.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Diabetes may shorten life by nine years: Study
article: A study in China has found that people diagnosed with diabetes may live up to nine years less on an average, mainly due to inadequate treatment particularly in rural areas. By studying the association of diabetes with mortality in five lakh adults, scientists found that diabetic people had twice the risk of dying during the follow-up period compared to non-diabetics.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop 'vaccine' against fake news
article: UK-based researchers have developed a "vaccine" to immunise people against fake news as misinformation can psychologically cancel out the influence of accurate statements. The technique involves delivering legitimate facts to people along with a dose of misinformation. This helps them develop resistance against fake news, so that they become less vulnerable to distorted news in future.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Fossils of wolf-sized giant otter species found in China
article: Scientists in China's Yunnan province have discovered a new wolf-sized giant otter species based on the findings of over 6-million-year-old fossils, that measured up to 2 metres tall. Identified as Siamogale melilutra, the newly discovered otter species is estimated to weigh about 50 kilograms, outweighing the largest otter known to be living today by about 20 kilograms.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: NASA declares 2016 as warmest year on record
article: US space agency NASA on Wednesday declared that 2016 was the warmest year since modern recordkeeping began in 1880. The year 2016 was warmer by 0.99°C compared to 2015, making it the third year in a row to set a new record for global average surface temperatures. Earth's average surface temperature has risen by 1.1°C since the late 19th century.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Drugmaker fined ₹681 crore for hiking price by 85,000%
article: Irish drugmaker Mallinckrodt has been fined ₹681 crore for increasing price of a life-saving medication by as much as 85,000%, and preventing other pharmaceutical firms from developing a similar drug. The price of the drug HP Acthar Gel, used to treat infants of spasms and multiple sclerosis, was slowly increased from ₹2,728 to more than ₹23 lakh for one vial.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: OLED electrodes developed from graphene for first time
article: For the first time, graphene, the world's second toughest material, was used to develop functional OLED electrodes. The breakthrough by German researchers can be integrated into touch displays and in turn could pave the way for a variety of smart material applications. An OLED (organic light-emitting diode) produces brighter light while using less energy than existing LCD and LED technologies.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 33% of adults diagnosed with asthma do not have it: Study
article: A Canada-based study has claimed that one-third of the adults who had been diagnosed with asthma in the last five years did not have active asthma, and over 90% of them were safe being off-medication for one year. By accessing records of 530 patients, scientists found in 49% cases, physicians had not ordered airflow tests needed to confirm the diagnosis.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Doctors successfully treat brain cancer using malaria drug
article: US-based doctors have used a malaria drug to successfully treat a 26-year-old brain cancer patient who had become resistant to chemotherapy. Lisa Rosendahl, who diagnosed of cancer aged 21, was treated with a drug combination that included the anti-malarial drug chloroquine. The drug was found to stop cancer cells' chemotherapy resistance, leaving the disease vulnerable to the targeted treatment.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Apples that do not brown for 3 weeks to go on sale in Feb
article: Genetically modified apples that do not oxidise or get brown for three weeks after slicing, will go on sale in Midwest in February. Developed by Canadian company Arctic Apples, the feat was achieved by 'silencing' polyphenol oxidase (PPO) expression. These non-browning apples and their trees grow in orchards just like the non-modified ones, the company said.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Diamonds can be made from peanut butter
article: While trying to mimic the extreme conditions found beneath the Earth's surface, scientists have previously converted peanut butter into diamonds. The carbon-rich peanut butter was placed and compressed between two diamonds, creating a 'stiletto heel effect'. Diamonds were used for the experiment as they have closely-linked carbon atoms and can withstand high amounts of pressure.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Animal-like sunspot twice the size of Earth captured
article: A set of newly released images captured by ALMA telescope has revealed an animal-like sunspot, measuring nearly twice as large as the diameter of the Earth. A sunspot is a transient feature that occurs in regions where the sun's magnetic field is extremely concentrated and powerful. It is lower in temperature, making it appear relatively darker than the surrounding regions.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: NASA sends 6 scientists to Hawaii to simulate life on Mars
article: NASA has sent six scientists to a dome on top of a volcano in Hawaii to simulate life for astronauts travelling to Mars. They will spend eight months in isolation with a 20-minute lag in communication with mission control team. This mission is the fifth of its kind to help NASA study human behaviour and performance during long space missions.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: In pictures: Top picks of the week in wildlife photography
article: British national daily newspaper The Guardian has curated the best wildlife pictures from the natural world of the past week. The picked images include wild geese flying over a snowy field in north-east Germany, two stag deers hugging each other at Bandipur National Park in India, and a jellyfish being eaten by turtles in Byron Bay in Australia, among others.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Astronomers search for signs of life on nearby exoplanet
article: US-based astronomers are searching for signs of life on an exoplanet called Wolf 1061c. It is one of the three known planets of a star system Wolf 1061, located approximately 14 light years away from Earth. The exoplanet has already been known to lie within the habitable zone -  a region where liquid water could exist on its surface.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Sea levels could rise by 6 to 9 metres over time: Study
article: A new study has found sufficient evidence that Greenland and Antarctica's ice sheets are highly sensitive to a small increase in sea temperatures, suggesting that this could raise the sea levels by 6 to 9 metres over centuries. Current sea surface temperatures are following the same patterns as those during the last interglacial period, which witnessed similar sea level increase.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: What causes deterioration of vision in astronauts?
article: US-based researchers have found that the deterioration of vision in astronauts is possibly due to a lack of day-night cycle in intracranial pressure (pressure inside skull) in space. It has been found that intracranial pressure in zero-gravity conditions is higher than when people are standing or sitting on Earth, but lower than when people are sleeping on Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study explains mechanism behind strength of human hair
article: US-based scientists have come up with a correlation between the structure and properties of human hair, and have explained the mechanism behind its strength and resistance to breaking. It was found that the combination of cortex and matrix components of hair gives it the ability to withstand stress and strain. The faster the hair is stretched, the stronger it is.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: ₹3,000 crore pledged aimed at preventing global epidemics
article: In an effort to prevent global epidemics, leaders at the World Economic Forum have pledged to donate ₹3,136 crore for a vaccine initiative. The amount caters to half of what is needed for first five years of the programme. Initially, vaccines would be developed for Lassa, Mers and Nipah, all caused by viruses that have transferred from animals to humans.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Solar storm-induced blackouts can cost $40 bn daily: Study
article: An international study has claimed that solar storm-induced electricity blackouts could cost over $40 billion or ₹2.7 lakh crore to the US economy on a daily basis, supplemented by an international supply chain loss of almost ₹48,000 crore ($7 billion). A solar storm is a large explosion in the sun's atmosphere and involves the sudden release of stored magnetic energy.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Image shows Saturn's moon orbiting within gap of its rings
article: A photograph captured by NASA's Cassini spacecraft shows Saturn's small moon Daphnis creating waves while orbiting within a gap in the planet's distinctive rings. The image was captured by the spacecraft at a distance of approximately 28,000 kilometres from Daphnis, and is the closest view of the miniature moon ever obtained.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists map retreating Arctic ice over the years
article: Scientists have mapped the retreating Arctic ice over the years, spanning from 1850 till 2016. It was found the Arctic keeps breaking records for receding ice cover due to increasing temperatures. The retreating sea-ice cover hit an all-time low in 2012 with a loss of over 32 lakh square kilometres of ice cover, as against the global average since 1979.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Leopard, snow leopard seen sharing same habitat for 1st time
article: In a first, a leopard has been caught on camera in the territory of snow leopards in Tibetan plateau, raising concerns that the habitat competition could further reduce the latter's numbers. Warmer climate is causing leopards to live even at higher altitudes. With less than 7,000 snow leopards left globally, they have been listed 'Endangered' on the IUCN red list.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Babies remember their birth language: Study
article: Scientists have discovered that babies build knowledge about the language they hear in the first few months of their birth, which can be retained easily via re-learning. The study, conducted on adults who were exposed to Korean language in their childhood, found that they were able to pronounce the Korean consonants in a better way than those who were not.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop robotic 'heart sleeve' that helps it beat
article: Harvard researchers have developed a customisable soft robot that fits around a heart like a sleeve and helps it beat. The robotic device works by twisting and compressing in synchronisation with a beating heart and boosts cardiovascular functions weakened by heart failure, a condition in which the organ cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Over 50% of world's wild primates face extinction: Research
article: A recent research has revealed that 60% of the world's primates including gorillas, apes and monkeys face extinction because of hunting, agriculture and industrial activities. The species that come in contact with humans also face unusual threats like infections from diarrhoea-causing bugs. While 73% primate species in Asia face extinction, around 87% do so in Madagascar, the report added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Project 'City of Trees' aims to plant 30 lakh trees
article: A project titled 'City of Trees' is aimed at planting around 30 lakh trees in Greater Manchester area in England over the next 25 years. Apart from a measure of increasing greenery in the region, the project has collaborated with the University of Manchester to test how trees can help reduce surface water flooding in built-up areas.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Sun and memories help ants navigate: Study
article: International researchers have found that ants navigate towards the right path by plotting the sun's position in the sky and combining it with visual memories related to their surroundings. Ants walking backwards occasionally look behind them to check their surroundings and use sun's relative position to maintain their course towards their nest, regardless of the way they are facing.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Researchers reconstruct brain of extinct Tasmanian tiger
article: In a first, international researchers have reconstructed the brain architecture of the extinct Tasmanian tiger (thylacine), making new revelations about its intelligence and social life. By comparing the brain of thylacine with that of its closest relative, the Tasmanian devil, it was found that the former had a larger cortex, which was required for planning and decision making while hunting.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Moth species named after Trump for similarity in hairstyles
article: A new endangered species of moth has officially been named Neopalpa donaldtrumpi after United States president-elect Donald Trump, as scientists believe the species shares his hairstyle. The biologist who discovered the species, which has yellowish-white scales on its head, said he hoped its name would highlight the need to preserve fragile environments.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Startup developing device to identify diseases from voice
article: US-based startup Canary Speech is using machine learning to develop a way of analysing conversations to identify a number of diseases, including Parkinson's, Alzheimer's and dementia. After examining patients' speech patterns, the startup has developed algorithms based on signs such as softening of voice and quality of speech in order to identify several neurological and cognitive diseases.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Silicon identified as the 'missing element' in Earth's core
article: A team of Japan-based researchers has suggested that silicon accounts for the remaining 5% of the Earth's core, which was known to consist mainly of iron (85%) and nickel (10%). By imitating Earth's core's temperature and pressure conditions in the laboratory, scientists showed the missing 5%, which was unknown till now, could be explained by silicon dissolved into iron-nickel alloys.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Last man to walk on Moon, Eugene Cernan passes away at 82
article: Eugene Cernan, the last man to walk on Moon, passed away aged 82 on Monday. An American astronaut and a retired Naval officer, Cernan landed on Moon in December 1972 during NASA's Apollo 17 mission. It became the longest lunar landing flight of 301 hours and 51 minutes and made Cernan the eleventh person to land on Moon.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US firm plans a 5-km-high skyscraper that eats smog
article: US-based materials science firm Arconic has envisioned a 5-km-high skyscraper coated with a self-cleaning material that absorbs smog. The chemicals in the coating interact with light and water vapor, pulling in pollutants from the air. The skyscraper is estimated to be built by 2062 using 3D printing technology to create walls that would also be able to withstand high winds.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: World's lightest mechanical watch weighing 40 grams unveiled
article: The world's lightest mechanical watch weighing 40 grams was unveiled on Monday by the University of Manchester along with McLaren F1 and watchmaker Richard Mille. The watch's case is made with graphene composite Graph TPT, which is lighter than any other watchmaking material. Graphene, discovered at the University of Manchester in 2004, is the world's first one-atom-thick 2D material.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Leopard shark switches from sexual to asexual reproduction
article: A leopard shark in an aquarium in Australia has reproduced asexually, marking a switch from sexual reproduction, after she was separated from her mating partner in 2012. It is the first reported case of sexual transition for the shark species and only the third reported case among all vertebrates. In asexual reproduction, offspring arises from a single organism.

author: Gaurav Shroff
abstract: India officially becomes Associate Member State of CERN
article: India on Monday officially became an associate member of the European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN), deemed as the world's largest nuclear and particle physics laboratory. Indian scientists played a significant role at CERN including the construction of the Large Hadron Collider, which helped confirm the Higgs boson. The membership would cost India approximately ₹78 crore per year.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: In pictures: Remembering the last man to walk on the Moon
article: American astronaut Eugene Cernan was the last man to leave a footprint on the Moon's surface during NASA's Apollo 17 mission in December 1972. Cernan was one of only three people to go to the Moon twice. En route to Moon, Cernan's crew captured an iconic photo of Earth with an entire hemisphere fully illuminated, popularly remembered as 'Blue Marble'.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists detail one of the most thorough marijuana studies
article: American scientists have combined over 10,000 recent scientific abstracts to explain the benefits and harmful effects associated with marijuana. The new study concluded that marijuana has therapeutic uses for chronic pain, multiple sclerosis, and reducing nausea and vomiting from chemotherapy. However, it can potentially harm the babies in the womb and can lead to respiratory problems if smoked.

author: Ankush Verma
abstract: UK to shut down Antarctic base due to huge crack in ice
article: The UK will shut its British Antarctic Survey base and move out all scientists by March, after a huge crack was found in the ice in October last year. Adding that the crack does not pose an immediate threat, officials said the scientists will be removed until the danger is assessed. The scientists are expected to move back in November.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: India plate wasn't isolated before Eurasian collision: Study
article: International researchers have claimed that there was a connection between India, Europe and Asia, around 5.4 crore years ago, as against the long-held view that India was largely isolated before colliding with the Eurasian plate. Scientists found similarity between fossils of midges occurring in India, Europe and Asia at that time, suggesting that the connection enabled creatures to move around.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Pre-pregnancy blood pressure influences child's sex: Study
article: According to a recent study, mother's blood pressure before conception may influence the gender of her future child. Scientists found that the women who delivered male child had higher blood pressure prior to pregnancy than those who conceived a female child. Scientists were able to identify the tendency by analysing over 1,400 female participants from China.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Massive alligator caught on camera in Florida
article: A giant alligator was recently spotted in central Florida, which is considered as one of the most massive gators ever seen in the US state. Affectionately known as the "Big Humpback" due to its long spine, the alligator is estimated to be between 3 to 4 metres long. The footage of the alligator has gone viral on social media.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Restoring extinct species would take 80 lakh years: Study
article: US-based scientists have claimed that at least 80 lakh years will be taken to restore the species which were recently lost due to extinction. Scientists studied the effect of recent extinction by compiling data on an ecologically diverse group of bats. Recent extinctions have pulled species from natural equilibrium, and millions of years would be taken to restore the balance.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Startup charges ₹5 lakh to inject patients with young blood
article: California-based startup Ambrosia has invited volunteers for clinical trials in which it will charge people ₹5.4 lakh to inject them with blood from donors aged 16-25. The volunteers, who are required to be at least 35 years old, will receive 1.5 litres of plasma. Ambrosia believes the process will improve appearance and muscle tone and even slow down aging.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Japan aborts mini-rocket mission shortly after liftoff
article: Japan's space agency JAXA on Sunday aborted its mission to use a mini-rocket to launch a satellite, following a glitch in the communications system shortly after liftoff. The rocket, which was reportedly one of the smallest satellite-carrying units in the world, was carrying a 35-centimetre satellite. According to local media reports, the mission was aborted three minutes into the launch.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Long winters after asteroid crash killed dinosaurs: Study
article: Germany-based researchers have come up with a new theory about the cause of extinction of dinosaurs around 66 million years ago. As per the theory, formation of sulphuric acid clouds after the asteroid impact blocked sunlight and resulted in long-lasting winters, destroying the food web. The theory is based on computer simulations imitating the asteroid's impact on life on Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Massive gravity wave spotted in atmosphere of Venus
article: Japanese probe Akatsuki has spotted a massive gravity wave in the atmosphere of Venus using cameras onboard the spacecraft. Stretching over 10,000 kilometres from end to end, it is deemed as one of the largest gravity waves ever recorded in the solar system. Scientists believe the stationary wave was produced by surface winds when they slammed into a 4,500-metre-high mountain.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Vampire bat species found feeding on human blood
article: A South American species of vampire bat, which was previously thought to feed only on birds' blood, has been found feeding on human blood. Brazil-based scientists analysed the faeces of bats and found human blood in three of the excrement samples of the hairy-legged vampire bat. Scientists suggested that human disruption of the bat's habitat made it change its diet.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New software predicts the time of heart failure
article: Imperial College scientists have developed a new software which creates virtual 3D hearts by replicating the real organ and predicts their failure time. Created by analysing MRI images of each patient's heart, the 3D heart automatically learns the features which are the predictors of the organ's failure. The software has been demonstrated to give an accuracy of about 80%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Physicists predict when quantum systems will fail in future
article: In a first, scientists at the University of Sydney have accurately predicted the future failure of quantum systems, and have used the information to prevent their breakdown. Scientists worked with qubits, the fundamental building blocks for most quantum-enabled technology, for this development. This could be used to make quantum technology more accurate and reliable in future.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Aerospace startup raises $20 million to fully fund moon trip
article: US-based Moon Express, which is competing in Google's Lunar X-Prize to become world's first private company to land on the moon, has raised $20 million in Series B-1 funding. The startup announced it has fully financed its maiden mission to the moon with total funding of $45 million. Moon Express is competing with teams from Israel and India among others.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New 5D technique helps diagnose diseases from phone images
article: US-based researchers have developed a new 5D technique for analysing images, which they claim may help diagnose diseases from pictures taken using cell phones. The fluorescent imaging technique has been used to locate proteins and other molecules in cells and tissues. It could help scientists understand which molecules are produced in large amounts in cancer and other diseases.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Oceans may have more plastic than fish by 2050: Study
article: The World Economic Forum has reported that there could be more plastics than fish (by weight) in the ocean by 2050, if no action is taken immediately. In order to address the issue, industry leaders have suggested an initiative aimed at increasing the recycling of plastic packaging from current 14% to 70%, by using re-usable alternatives and improving packaging design.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Earliest galaxies radiated green light: Study
article: UCLA researchers have discovered that most of the early galaxies that formed in the first one or two billion years of the universe, radiated a specific wavelength of green light. Green galaxies are rare as it takes stars much hotter than those found in the modern universe to make green light. This will help study the formation of early galaxies.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers sequence Coffee Arabica's genome
article: Researchers at the University of California released the first public genome sequence for Coffea Arabica, the coffee species responsible for more than 70 percent of the global coffee production. The genome information is crucial for the development of high-quality, disease-resistant coffee varieties that can adapt to climate changes when grown in different regions.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Prince Charles writes book on climate change
article: Prince Charles has co-authored a Ladybird book on climate change with environmental campaigners Tony Juniper and Emily Shuckburgh. 'The Ladybird Book on Climate Change,' the first in a new series for adults, will be published later in January. Notably, Prince Charles has referred to climate change sceptics as the "headless chicken brigade" in the past.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Nasa releases stunning image of Jupiter's megastorm
article: NASA has released a detailed image of the Great Red Spot, a megastorm in Jupiter's atmosphere that is much larger than the Earth and has continued for centuries. It also shows a series of white oval-shaped storms, dubbed the 'string of pearls'. The image was created by a citizen scientist using raw data from JunoCam instrument on the Juno spacecraft.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Moon found to be 140 mn yrs older than previous estimates
article: A new research has found that the Moon is 4.51 billion years old, almost 140 million years older than previous estimates. Researchers used Uranium-Lead dating on fragments of the mineral zircon, which was obtained from samples retrieved during the 1971 Apollo 14 mission. The new estimate of the Moon's age is believed to be accurate up to 10 million years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover the function of human appendix
article: US-based researchers have identified that the human appendix, which is often viewed as a vestigial organ with little-known use, may serve as a reservoir for beneficial gut bacteria. Mammals with an appendix were found to have higher concentrations of lymphoid tissue in the cecum, a pouch from which the appendix develops, suggesting that appendix serves as a secondary immune organ.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US lady killed by bacteria resistant to every antibiotic
article: A woman in her 70s has been killed by a superbug that is resistant to every available antibiotic in the world, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. The victim was tested with 26 different antibiotics in an attempt to cure a bacterial infection of Klebsiella pneumoniae. She had recently returned to the US after visiting India.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Chemists break world record to build tightest knot ever made
article: By linking 192 atoms in a chain with eight crossings, University of Manchester chemists have produced the most tightly knotted structure created till date. The tightness of a knot is defined by the distance between points where the chain of atoms cross each other. The breakthrough knot is only about 20 nanometres long, and was made using the 'self-assembly' technique.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Moon may have formed from series of impacts on Earth: Study
article: Israel-based scientists have proposed a new theory about the formation of the moon. The new study claims the lunar body formed from a series of rocky bombardments that struck Earth over 100 million years ago. Scientists showed around twenty impacts could have dislodged enough material from the Earth into space to form orbiting moonlets, which merged to form the moon.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New material 10 times stronger, 20 times lighter than steel
article: MIT researchers claim to have designed a 3D form of graphene, which is 10 times stronger than steel with a density of just 5% of steel. The 3D graphene structures have been created by compressing flakes of two-dimensional graphene forms using heat and pressure. These were then fused to form one of the strongest and lightest materials known till date.

author: Deepali Aggarwal
abstract: Obama thanks NASA for carrying his signature to Mars
article: The twitter account of NASA's Curiosity Mars rover on Thursday posted a photo of a plaque which it carried to the Red Planet in 2012 with signatures from the country's top officials including US President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden. Responding to the honour, Obama tweeted, "That is out of this world. Thanks."

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Costa Rica got 98% of electricity in 2016 from renewables
article: As much as 98.1% of electricity used by Costa Rica in 2016 was supplied by renewable energy sources, according to Costa Rican Electricity Institute. Hydropower, wind energy and geothermal energy accounted for most of the electricity demands of the country's 49 lakh people. Notably, the Central American nation ran entirely on renewable energy for over 250 days last year.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Rare ruby seadragon species caught on camera for first time
article: A rare ruby seadragon species has been filmed for the first time in the wild in Australia's Recherche Archipelago. It also marks the first time the 25-cm-long fish has been seen alive since its discovery in 2015 through DNA sequencing of museum specimens. Two seadragons were filmed feeding and swimming through the ocean for 30 minutes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists use fat to make wounds heal without scars
article: US-based researchers have figured out a way to make wounds heal as normal regenerated skin without developing scars. A scar tissue looks different from regular skin because it does not contain any fat cells or hair follicles. Scientists used this skin characteristic to transform the myofibroblast cells, present in healing wounds, into fat cells to avoid scarring.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New drug claims to regenerate rotten teeth
article: UK-based researchers have developed a therapy which they claim can regenerate rotten teeth and reduce the need for fillings. The therapy uses an Alzheimer's drug to enhance the natural ability of teeth to repair themselves by activating stem cells present in the mouth's dental pulp. It allows teeth cells to rebuild cavities, extending from the surface to the root.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Medicine being both overused and underused globally: Study
article: An international study has revealed medicine and healthcare are both being underused and overused globally. Up to 70% hysterectomies (surgical operation to remove uterus) in the US and more than 50% antibiotics prescribed in China are inappropriate healthcare, the study claimed. The Caesarian section delivery rate is soaring, while the simple use of steroids to prevent premature births is lagging.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New found asteroid came within 2 lakh km of Earth
article: A newly found asteroid, named '2017 AG13', came within 2.1 lakh kilometres of the Earth on Monday, which is a little over half of the moon's distance from our planet. The 11-34 metre wide asteroid was first spotted on Saturday and was moving at a speed of 16 kilometres per second when it passed the Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Hot chilli peppers linked with decreased mortality: Study
article: A new US-based research has found that consumption of red hot chilli peppers is associated with a 13% reduction in total mortality, especially in heart attacks and strokes. Scientists have related the possible cause of health benefits to its principal component capsaicin, which is known to prevent obesity, regulate coronary blood flow, and possess antimicrobial properties.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists estimate the mass of Milky Way galaxy
article: Canada-based scientists have approximated that the Milky Way weighs between 400 to 580 billion solar masses. The sun's mass is 2 nonillion (2 followed by 30 zeroes) kilograms or 3.3 lakh times the Earth's mass. Apart from the visible matter forms like stars and planets, the mass of dark matter was also estimated through its gravitational influence on visible objects.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Spread of cancer shown to reduce by 75% in tests
article: A UK-based study on genetically modified mice has found that the spread of cancer-causing tumours can be cut by as much as 75% by altering the immune system. Scientists identified 23 genes that are involved in regulating the spread of cancers. It was found that targeting one of these genes called Spns2, led to 75% reduction in tumour spread.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Physicists create a new form of hydrogen
article: Austrian physicists created negatively charged hydrogen clusters, a previously unseen form of hydrogen. The existence of hydrogen in ion clusters has been known for the past 40 years, with positively-charged clusters already existing. The researchers injected cold liquid helium droplets with hydrogen before exposing it to an electron beam, resulting in creation of negatively charged hydrogen ions.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Milky Way ripped off some stars from another galaxy: Study
article: A recent Harvard research has revealed the 11 farthest known stars in Milky Way were ripped from two nearby dwarf galaxies. Researchers used computer models to simulate the galaxies over the past 8 billion years. The results showed one galaxy, weighing 10 billion times the Sun's mass initially, lost about 33% of its stars and 90% dark matter over time.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Weekend exercise is as good as daily workout: Study
article: A new study has claimed that people who do all exercise in one or two days of the week (weekend warriors), lower their risk of dying by 30%, about as much as people who exercise three or more times. Scientists found the risk of cardiovascular death was similar for weekend warriors and regular exercisers, about 40% lower than inactive adults.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New fault in Indian Ocean may trigger more quakes: Study
article: Researchers have found evidence of a possible new plate boundary forming on the Indian Ocean floor in Wharton Basin, which could trigger more earthquakes in future. The fault system has been linked to two of the largest interplate earthquakes which struck the ocean's Andaman-Sumatran region in 2012. A similar earthquake could result in new plate boundary and more interplate quakes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Baboons make vowel sounds similar to humans: Study
article: International researchers have found that baboons can make at least five vowel sounds like humans despite having a high larynx (voice box). It was previously thought that the low larynx allows humans to make vowel sounds, as against the nonhuman primates which have a high larynx. Scientists suggested that like humans, baboons controlled their tongue positions to produce vowel sounds.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists trigger killer instinct in mice using light
article: US-based researchers have developed a method which uses light to trigger killer instinct in mice with the flick of a switch. It enabled scientists to identify the brain circuits involved in predatory behaviour. When the switch was on, the mice pursued almost anything in their path like insects and even inanimate objects. They behaved normally when the switch was off.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Stem cells used to regenerate outer layer of human heart
article: US-based researchers have used stem cells to regenerate the external layer of a human heart using stem cells. Firstly, scientists derived the cardiac progenitor cells from human stem cells, and then the progenitor cells were treated with chemicals to sequentially activate and then re-activate a group of signal transduction pathways made of proteins, forming the epicardium cells.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Rusty bumblebee 1st wild bee in US to get federal protection
article: The US Fish and Wildlife Service on Tuesday listed the rusty patched bumblebee as an endangered species, making it the first wild bee in the country to gain such federal protection. Known as Bombus affinis, its population has declined by nearly 90% since the late 1990s. Its falling numbers have been attributed to climate change, habitat loss and pesticides.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Blind mouse found to navigate like a bat
article: The Vietnamese pygmy dormouse, known to be essentially blind due to a folded retina, navigates just like a bat, a study has found. The rodents make ultrasonic sound waves similar to those used by bats to sense their surroundings. These waves bounce off objects, allowing the dormouse to determine where objects are in space, a technique known as echolocation.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers genetically edit bacteria to combat brain tumors
article: American researchers have genetically engineered Salmonella, the bacteria responsible for food poisoning, to attack tumours responsible for brain cancer instead of the gastrointestinal tract. The researchers rendered Salmonella, perpetually deficient in a crucial amino acid known as Purine which is found in tumorous brain cells, reaching where the bacteria self-destructs alongside tumorous cells.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: New primate species named after Star Wars' Luke Skywalker
article: Chinese scientists are calling a new species of primate the Skywalker hoolock gibbon after Star Wars character Luke Skywalker. They chose Skywalker because they are Star Wars' fans and because the Chinese characters of its scientific name, Hoolock tianxing, mean "heaven's movement." After actor Mark Hamill shared the news, many tweeted pictures of Hamill as Skywalker alongside pictures of apes.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: China to set up world's highest altitude telescopes in Tibet
article: China has started building the world's highest altitude gravitational wave telescopes in Tibet, close to country's Line of Actual Control with India. With a budget of $18.8 million, the telescope will detect and gather precise data on primordial gravitational waves in the Northern Hemisphere. The telescope, located 5,250 meters above sea level, is expected to be operational by 2021.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Stephen Hawking was on the Oxford rowing team
article: English theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking, who turned 75 on Sunday, used to be in the University College Boat Club at Oxford, before being paralysed due to ALS. He wasn't a rower but the coxswain, who controls steering and stroke rate. Hawking, who was called as the adventurous type, sometimes damaged the boat by steering through very narrow gaps.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: B'desh 'tree man' regains use of hands after 16 surgeries
article: A 27-year-old Bangladeshi named Abul Bajandar, dubbed the "tree man" for the bark-like lesions over his body, regained use of his hands after undergoing at least 16 surgeries for the treatment of one of the rarest diseases. Around five kilograms of growths were removed from his body, who is one of only four people to be diagnosed with epidermodysplasia verruciformis.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Giant iceberg set to break away from Antarctica: Scientists
article: A 5,000-square-kilometre iceberg is poised to break away from Antarctica, scientists say. Just 20 kilometres of ice is preventing iceberg Larsen C from floating away, as a rift growing for over a decade has suddenly widened. Scientists say that the break-off, expected to be among the ten largest ever recorded, is not driven by climate change.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA releases image with highest black hole concentration
article: NASA has released the deepest X-ray image showing the highest concentration of black holes ever obtained. Produced after an observation time of 11.5 weeks by NASA's Chandra observatory, it shows the growth of black holes over billions of years beginning after the Big Bang. These black holes grow mostly in bursts rather than by slow accumulation of matter, scientists suggested.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Risk of catastrophic asteroid impact real: White House
article: A recently released White House document has stressed that risks of catastrophic impacts of Near-Earth Objects (NEOs), defined as asteroids or comets that come near Earth's orbit, are real. Titled 'National Near-Earth Object Preparedness Strategy', the document has a detailed plan to prepare for such events. Enhancing NEO detection and developing NEO deflection methods are among the listed goals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA releases rare photo of Earth & moon as seen from Mars
article: NASA has released a rare detailed image of the Earth and the moon as seen from Mars at a distance of approximately 200 million kilometres from our planet. The composite view has been created by combining the images of the Earth and the moon, while retaining the correct positions and sizes of the two bodies relative to each other.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA explains why Moon dust levitates above lunar surface
article: A recent NASA study has explained why micron-sized dust particles "levitate" several centimetres above the lunar surface even though there is no wind or flowing water on the moon to propel them up. The lunar dust particles which scatter light generate large electrical charges and particle-particle repulsive forces among the neighbouring particles, causing them to lift off the surface.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA detects exocomets plunging into a star
article: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has detected exocomets (comets outside the solar system) plunging into a young star named 'HD 172555', at around 95 light-years away from Earth. Scientists have suggested that the presence of these comets provides circumstantial evidence for "gravitational stirring" by an unseen Jupiter-sized planet, where comets deflected by its gravity are hurled into the star.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Source of mysterious deep space radio waves discovered
article: In a first, astronomers have pinpointed the source of mysterious radio waves called fast radio bursts (FRBs) coming from the deep space outside Milky Way. These high-energy flashy radio waves were coming from a dwarf galaxy located 3 billion light years away from Earth. FRBs emit as much energy in a millisecond as the sun does in around 10,000 years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 1st African-American woman to go to ISS will launch in 2018
article: NASA astronaut Jeanette Epps is set to become the first African-American crew member to board the International Space Station (ISS) when she flies to the orbital post in May 2018. She would be accompanied by veteran astronaut Andrew Feustel, who made his first trip to the ISS in 2011. More than 200 astronauts have visited the space station till date.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Black hole rips apart star, spews fragments across galaxy
article: Harvard researchers have found that a star ripped apart by the gravity of a black hole can reinvent itself to form hundreds of planet-sized gas balls. These cosmic "spitballs" are then flung throughout the Milky Way galaxy at speeds of over 30 million kilometres per hour and could even come within a few hundred light-years of Earth, scientists suggested.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: China is creating a new geological map of Moon
