article: Scientists in China are creating a 1:2.5 million scale geological map of the moon, according to Chinese media. The map would provide information on geology, structure, rock types and would reflect the timeline of the lunar evolution. A sketch version of the lunar map, 4.36 metres by 2.2 metres, is expected to be finished by 2018 and released by 2020.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Black hole and colliding galaxies seen together for 1st time
article: International astronomers have discovered a cosmic particle accelerator created by the combination of two of the most powerful phenomena in the universe – a supermassive black hole and the collision of two giant galaxy clusters. The colliding galaxies are dubbed as a "double whammy", featuring the galaxy clusters Abell 3411 and Abell 3412, located about two billion light years away.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New drug claims to reduce spread of skin cancer by 90%
article: Researchers from Michigan State University have developed a new compound which they claim can reduce the spread of cancerous melanoma cells by up to 90%. The drug works by targeting the gene activity or transcription process that causes the skin cancer disease to spread. According to the World Health Organisation, over 1.3 lakh melanoma skin cancers occur globally each year.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Brain region that recognises faces keeps growing: Study
article: Researchers from Stanford University recently discovered that the brain region which specialises in recognising faces continues to develop even in adulthood, as against the long-held view that brain settles after puberty. By comparing brains of children with those of adults, scientists found that the density of fusiform face area, the brain region which helps recognise faces, increases with age.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Climate change could bleach 99% coral reefs by 2100: Study
article: Almost 99% of the world's coral reefs could undergo severe bleaching by 2100 due to climate change, a recent study has claimed. When sea water turns warmer than usual, corals expel the symbiotic algae living in their tissues, causing them to turn white. Although bleaching does not kill the corals instantly, it makes them more vulnerable to fatal diseases.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists predict the explosive birth of a star in 2022
article: US-based scientists have predicted a new star will be created in 2022 following the merger and explosion of a binary star (two stars orbiting each other). As per the prediction, the new star will be visible through naked eyes and will be one of the brightest in the sky for about six months before gradually returning to its normal brightness.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Nissan's self-driving cars to use NASA's Mars Rover tech
article: Nissan has said its autonomous cars will use the Seamless Autonomous Mobility technology built by NASA for the Mars Rover. On facing an uncertain situation, the vehicle will park itself in a safe spot and request help from a command centre. A human assistant will assess the situation and "paint" a virtual lane for the car to drive itself through.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover rare double-ringed galaxy in space
article: Scientists have spotted a rare double-ringed elliptical galaxy, approximately 359 light years away from the Earth. Identified as PGC 1000714, it has a 5.5 billion-year-old core at its heart that looks red and is circled by a faint blue ring. While the rings are made up of mostly of young stars, the core is made of older stars.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Diesel cars 10 times more toxic than trucks and buses: Study
article: According to a recent European study, diesel cars are 10 times more toxic than diesel trucks and buses due to stricter European Union testing standards applied to larger vehicles. Nitrogen oxide emissions per kilometre for diesel cars were found to be double that of heavy-duty vehicles. Diesel cars emit about six times more toxic gases than allowed, the study claimed.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Living near high traffic increases risk of dementia: Study
article: A Canada-based research has found that people living near high-traffic roads are at a greater risk of developing dementia than those living further away. The study found that people who lived within 50 metres of busy roadways had a 7% higher chance of developing the brain disorder, compared to those who lived more than 300 metres away from high-traffic roads.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop a new heat dissipation method
article: Rice University researchers have shown that placing cones between graphene and carbon nanotubes would form 'nano-chimneys' that help heat escape. Heat is transferred through phonons and scientists eliminated barriers that block the heat conduction by creating phonon-friendly cones. The discovery could help scientists to develop a strategy to channel heat away from nano-electronics.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop light-based control system of human cells
article: US-based researchers have developed a method which uses light to control proteins inside living human cells with the flick of a switch. It allows scientists to activate or deactivate proteins without changing their functions, and even control their activation period at different cell points. Scientists can control how much of a protein is activated by controlling the intensity of light.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make antibiotic spider silk that can heal wounds
article: UK-based researchers have developed a technique to produce a spider silk biomaterial that can be used to avoid infections for a longer time period. Scientists modified the silk fibres to incorporate an antibiotic levofloxacin, maintaining the antimicrobial activity for at least five days. The technique could be tailored to applications used in drug delivery and wound healing.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 3D ocean map created to help with marine conservation
article: Scientists have created a detailed 3D map of oceans which could help conservationists and government officials in making decisions related to marine conservation. The global ocean map sorts water masses around the world into 37 categories of different temperatures, salinity, oxygen and nutrient levels and includes the waters between the surface and the ocean floor.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US Navy-trained dolphins to help find endangered porpoises
article: In an effort to save Mexico's vaquita porpoises from extinction, US Navy-trained dolphins will use their sonar to help find the last few dozens of the species. The porpoises would be captured and moved to a bay in the Gulf of California where they would be protected from fishing. Vaquitas are the most endangered porpoise species in the world.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New organ discovered inside human body
article: Irish professor J Calvin Coffey has identified a new organ called mesentery in the human body, connecting the abdomen to the intestine. Previously thought to be a group of structures, it has now been classified as one continuous organ. Although the function of the organ is still unclear, scientists believe abdominal diseases can be categorised in terms of this organ.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: ₹100 cr reward for anyone from Andhra who wins Nobel: CM
article: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister N Chandrababu Naidu has announced a ₹100 crore reward for any scientist from the state who wins the Nobel Prize. "India has not been able to produce many Nobel Prize-winning scientists despite having abundant talent. Those who had won...settled in other countries," he said. Naidu added that the incentive should inspire young scientists to work hard.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA captures image of ISS crossing the sun
article: A NASA photographer was able to capture an image of the International Space Station (ISS) just as it was making its way in front of the sun at a speed of about 28,968 kilometres per hour. Noel Kowsky captured several images of the event and 10 of them were combined to give a single composite view of the ISS.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Bill Gates invests $140 mn to make a device to prevent HIV
article: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has announced an investment of $140 million in Intarcia Therapeutics, a US pharma company developing a device that could help prevent HIV infections. The company makes matchstick-size devices that are implanted under a person's skin to continuously release preventive drugs. One device can hold up to a year's supply of medicine.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: SpaceX explains why its Falcon 9 rocket exploded
article: Elon Musk-led space exploration startup SpaceX on Monday said that its Falcon 9 rocket exploded during the launch in September 2016 due to a buildup of oxygen in the aluminum liner. The explosion destroyed Facebook's satellite being carried by the rocket. SpaceX said that it will implement design changes to prevent any anomaly in the future.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: World's oldest killer whale presumably dead at 105 years old
article: The world's oldest killer whale, fondly known as Granny, has not been seen since October and is presumed to be dead at an estimated age of 105 years. The female orca, also known by her official name J2, was being followed to study whale menopause. Only humans, orcas and short-finned pilot whales are known to undergo menopause among mammals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Dinosaur eggs took 3 to 6 months to hatch: Study
article: A US-based study has revealed that it takes about 3-6 months for dinosaur eggs to hatch, disproving the long-held theory that dinosaur incubation duration was 11-85 days, similar to birds. The study further linked this incubation period to the extinction of dinosaurs. For the study, the team analysed the jaws of embryo fossils from two dinosaurs and visualised teeth formation.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: We need a superhighway in space, tweets Amazon's Jeff Bezos
article: Amazon Founder Jeff Bezos on Thursday tweeted his support for constructing a "superhighway in space." Bezos shared an article which said NASA should focus on developing infrastructure in space like human habitats with vegetable gardens and gas stations instead of building rockets. The article proposes that rockets be provided by private ventures like Elon Musk's SpaceX and Bezos' Blue Origin.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Parental obesity may delay child’s development: Study
article: A new study has found that obesity of parents could cause developmental delays in their children and could affect their analytical skills. The study found that those having obese fathers were more likely to have difficulty in interacting with others. Children of obese mothers could have difficulty with controlling movement of small muscles such as those in fingers.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Quadrantid meteor shower to peak tonight
article: The International Meteor Organisation has forecast that the Quadrantid meteor shower will be visible to people living in India post midnight and on the morning of 4th January. The Quadrantids are known to produce meteors at a rate of 50-100 per hour and come about when Earth passes through debris from a broken-up comet called 2003 EH1.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: India will be among top 3 in science & tech by 2030: PM Modi
article: While inaugurating the 104th Indian Science Congress at Sri Venkateswara University in Tirupati on Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said that India will be among top three countries in science and technology by 2030. Reportedly, over 14,000 scientists and scholars from across the country are participating at the five-day annual event, including Nobel laureates from different countries.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Indian firm captures carbon dioxide to make baking powder
article: An Indian firm named Carbon Clean Solutions has developed a technology, which is being used by a thermal power station in Tuticorin to capture carbon dioxide from its coal-powered boiler and use it for making baking powder. The firm has claimed that it would capture around 60,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per year using its carbon capture and utilisation technology.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists to send signals to exoplanet to contact aliens
article: Scientists at Messaging Extraterrestrial Intelligence (METI) are planning to send radio signals to Proxima Centauri b, Earth's closest exoplanet, by 2018. Scientists are aimed at initiating communication with any potential alien life at the planet and are expecting to raise $1 million annually for running the transmitter. This would be the first effort to send intentional messages into space.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: After Mars, ISRO targeting missions to Jupiter, Venus
article: After the successful Mars Orbiter Mission, Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is looking to explore other planets like Jupiter and Venus, Associate Director M Nageswara Rao said. "Studies are going on and it may take a few years from now to have a concrete plan," he added. Rao said a follow-up mission for Mars Orbiter Mission is also being planned.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA releases video citing its top space milestones in 2016
article: NASA has released a video highlighting the top space achievements made by the space agency in 2016. The milestones include the launch of NASA's first asteroid sampling mission and the measuring of Antarctic ice for the eighth consecutive year. In 2016, NASA scientists also discovered that the observable universe contains around two trillion galaxies, 10 times more than previously thought.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Brain and teeth did not evolve together in humans: Study
article: A new study has claimed that evolution of brain and teeth size were not linked in humans, challenging the long-accepted view that reduction of teeth size in hominins (Homo sapiens' ancestors) is correlated with having a larger brain. By measuring evolution rates of teeth and brains of human ancestors, scientists found their evolution was influenced by ecological and behavioral factors.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Indians make new wound-dressing material from bamboo plants
article: India-based scientists have developed a compound made of bamboo cellulose and silver nanoparticles which has antibacterial properties and is claimed to treat skin injuries in a better way. According to scientists, bamboo was chosen for the research as it grows faster and has longest internode segment, allowing the isolation of appropriate-sized cellulose nanocrystals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Researchers grow needle and thread-like diamonds
article: Russia-based scientists have developed a technique which allows mass production of needle and thread-like diamond crystals. Scientists have obtained micrometre-sized diamond crystals in the form of geometrically correct pyramids and have also studied the luminescence and electron emission properties of these diamond crystals. The needle diamond crystals could be used in various types of sensors.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop control system for genetic engineering
article: Researchers from the University of California have discovered a way to inactivate the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing system using newly identified proteins that are produced by bacterial viruses. These anti-CRISPR proteins would help in enabling more precise control of CRISPR applications and would also help in blocking the harmful uses of the gene-editing technology.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make artificial hairs to help robotic limbs feel
article: China-based scientists have developed artificial hairs using magnetic cobalt-based microwires that are claimed to be as flexible as human hairs. Currently, scientists are trying to integrate the hairs with the robotic arms to mimic the human sense of touch. If successful, the development would allow the disabled people to 'feel' their surroundings better with prosthetic limbs.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 3D images reveal features of polar ice caps of Mars
article: Researchers working with US-based Planetary Science Institute have developed 3D subsurface images revealing structures within the polar ice caps of Mars. The images show a larger volume of frozen carbon dioxide contained in the south polar cap and bowl-shaped features that may be impact craters within polar caps. The observation may enhance the understanding of the Red Planet's climate changes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists create interactive 3D models of human joints
article: Oxford scientists have created interactive 3D computer models of human joints showing how common medical complaints such as knee and shoulder pain have arisen and how we are likely to evolve in the future. By combining 128 slice CT scans of bones from humans, hominids, primates and dinosaurs, scientists plotted changes in the shapes of species throughout the human lineage.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: China to conduct personal record 30 space missions in 2017
article: According to China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation, the country plans to conduct around 30 space launch missions in 2017, a record-breaking number in the country's space history. Reportedly, most of the space missions would be carried out by Long March-5 and Long March-7 rockets. The latter would be used to send China's first cargo spacecraft Tianzhou-1 into space.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Science missing out on non-English research: Cambridge study
article: Based on a recent study, University of Cambridge scientists have argued that science is missing out on important non-English research as English has been adopted as a sort of 'lingua franca' (common language) in the scientific community. It revealed that over one-third of current science journals are published annually in non-English languages, which can result in these findings being overlooked.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Climate change may be lengthening bird wings: Study
article: A new US-based study has found that the wings of ringneck parrots have increased by 4-5 millimetres over the past 45 years, suggesting that the wing length of some birds may be lengthened due to climate change. According to scientists, the increased wing length might help the birds to shed excess heat to adjust with the rising temperatures.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: Genetic Modification neither solution nor evil: H Vardhan
article: Genetic modification is neither a solution nor an evil, Union Science and Technology Minister Harsh Vardhan has said. Genetically modified crops are only one aspect to address nation’s food security, he added. Further, the minister also promised to evolve a solution which is best suited for the people as well as acceptable to farmers.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Gun violence spreads like infectious social epidemic: Study
article: According to a US-based study, gun violence spreads like an infectious disease through social networks, and one person who is infected by gun violence can infect a group of people. By analysing a social network of individuals who were arrested during an 8-year period in Chicago, scientists found that over 60% of all gun violence happened through these social networks.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: What were the most notable scientific events of 2016?
article: The year 2016 saw several significant scientific events and discoveries, one of which was the discovery of gravitational waves, regarded by many as the breakthrough of the year. Some other notable events in the scientific society include the announcement of four new elements that helped complete Periodic Table's seventh row and birth of the first-ever baby using the three-parent technique.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA scientists design ice shelters for astronauts on Mars
article: Scientists at NASA's Langley Research Center have designed 'The Mars Ice Home', a concept of a dome-like shelter meant to accommodate astronauts when they set their foot on Mars. The concept is a large inflatable inner tube, which is surrounded by a shell of water ice. It is lightweight and can be transported and deployed with simple robotics.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: We are vulnerable to a deadly epidemic, warns Bill Gates
article: Billionaire philanthropist Bill Gates on Friday said the world is vulnerable to fatal diseases over the next decade as the global emergency response system is not strong enough. "I cross my fingers all the time that some epidemic like a big flu doesn't come along in the next 10 years," said the Co-founder of Microsoft.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: One-breath test can detect 17 diseases including cancer
article: Researchers from the Israel Institute of Technology have created a device that uses a person's single breath to identify 17 different diseases including cancer and Parkinson's disease. While the device isn't accurate enough yet for real-life clinical diagnoses, it can detect diseases in their early stages. The device correctly diagnosed 86% of the patients during testing.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 9th creature named after US President Barack Obama
article: A newly discovered Hawaiian coral reef fish has become the 9th creature to be named after US President Barack Obama. Identified as Tosanoides obama, the fish was discovered during an expedition inside Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument in Hawaii. Apart from the fish, the US President also has a spider, a lizard and a bird named after him.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: British-Indian professor receives knighthood from Queen
article: Shankar Balasubramanian, an Indian-origin British professor has been knighted by Queen Elizabeth II for his contribution to the field of science and medicine. The Herchel Smith Professor of Medicinal Chemistry at Cambridge University was honoured for his work as a co-inventor of Next Generation DNA sequencing. "His work has spawned an entirely new discipline of Bioinformatics," his citation read.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: SpaceX teases the 'most powerful rocket in the world'
article: Elon Musk-led aerospace manufacturer SpaceX has teased Falcon Heavy, which it claims is the most powerful operational rocket in the world. The rocket, which is scheduled to launch in 2017, can lift 54,000 kg into the orbit. SpaceX has said the rocket can carry twice the payload of the next most powerful rocket Delta IV Heavy, at one-third cost.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Inventor of waterproof garments was born 250 years ago
article: Charles Macintosh, the Scottish inventor of Mackintosh waterproof raincoat was born on December 29, 250 years ago. Macintosh patented the process of making waterproof garments in 1823, created by sandwiching two pieces of fabric with dissolved rubber solution in the middle. Google published a doodle to mark Macintosh's birthday with him standing in the rain and testing his invention.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: What is Broken Heart Syndrome?
article: Broken Heart Syndrome, also called stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a temporary heart condition that is often triggered by stressful situations, such as the death of a loved one. The Broken heart syndrome is often preceded by an intense physical or emotional event. In a notable example, actress Carrie Fisher's mother passed away a day after her death.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Comet would be visible with binoculars over next week: NASA
article: NASA has announced that a comet which is currently approaching towards the inner solar system, will be visible with binoculars in the night sky over the next week. The comet called C/2016 U1 NEOWISE was first detected by NASA's NEOWISE mission in October. Another mysterious object called 2016 WF9 is estimated to approach Earth's orbit on February 25, 2017.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Astronauts aboard ISS do the Mannequin Challenge in space
article: French astronaut Thomas Pesquet on Thursday shared a video of the crew aboard the International Space Station performing the Mannequin Challenge. In the caption, Pesquet wrote, "On Sunday we generally have a day off with the crew and we often have a bit of fun in microgravity...The result is kind of sci-fi spooky don't you think?"

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists identify new approach to recycle carbon dioxide
article: University of California scientists have identified a key enzyme to convert carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide. This process could further be adapted to recycle the greenhouse gas into commercial chemical products like biofuels. Scientists discovered that the Azotobacter vinelandii bacterium could reduce carbon dioxide and release carbon monoxide in the presence of nitrogenase enzyme.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Drugs for diabetes, hypertension could treat cancer: Study
article: A combination of an anti-hypertensive drug and diabetes medication can effectively combat cancer cells, according to a Switzerland-based study. Scientists found that when mice affected with liver cancer were treated with a combination of metformin (type 2 diabetes drug) and syrosingopine (hypertension drug), the enlargement of their liver was reduced and some tumours disappeared fully.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA's robotic rover finds purple rocks on Mars
article: US space agency NASA's robotic rover 'Curiosity' has captured photographs showing purple rocks on the surface of Mars. Scientists have suggested that the findings could be a hint to what caused the Red Planet to lose most of its water, as purple colouration is caused by the presence of haematite, typically formed in aqueous environment.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New technology developed to detect skin cancer early
article: US-based scientists have developed an automated technology which is capable of detecting melanoma, one of the most dangerous forms of skin cancer, at its early stages. In the new technique, images of lesions are processed and then quantitative data, like number of colours, are extracted using computer programmes. According to WHO, around 1,32,000 melanoma skin cancers occur globally every year.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Impossible to know when brain matures: Harvard scientist
article: Harvard psychologist Leah Somerville has argued that it is impossible even for neuroscientists to define when a brain "reaches maturity" by using current neuroscience tools. While there are structural differences between an adolescent and adult brain like grey and white matter volumes, a single developmental timeline cannot be made as different brain parts mature at different rates, Leah added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Hubble telescope spots a galaxy that acts as laser
article: NASA's space telescope Hubble has spotted a galaxy which is located over 370 million light years away from Earth and acts as an astronomical laser that beams out microwave emission. Identified as IRAS 16399-0937, the galaxy hosts a megamaser which is around 100 million times brighter than the masers found in galaxies like the Milky Way.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Emotional experiences affect memory of future events: Study
article: US-based researchers have found that an emotional experience which persists for over 20-30 minutes can influence how one remembers and attends future experiences. Researchers demonstrated that ordinary experiences that followed emotional ones were better remembered in future as compared to the experiences which were not exposed to any emotion-evoking stimuli.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Which is the biggest single-celled organism?
article: Caulerpa taxifolia, a green algae and a species of seaweed that can reach 30 centimeters long, is believed to be the largest single-celled organism in the world. Its surface area is enhanced with a frond-like structure. It is coenocytic, meaning it is a single cell with multiple nuclei, making it like a multicellular organism but without the divisions between cells.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Birds migrating earlier as temperatures rise: Study
article: Global temperature increase is causing migrating birds to arrive at their breeding grounds earlier, a University of Edinburgh research has revealed. The study found that for every degree of temperature increase, the birds arrive a day earlier. According to scientists, reaching their breeding grounds earlier could cause them to miss out on maximum availability of food and nesting places.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 5% of dark matter in universe lost since Big Bang: Study
article: In a first, Russia-based scientists have found that about 5% of the dark matter in the universe has been lost since the Big Bang. The estimation was made using data from observations of various cosmological effects. Dark matter comprises approximately 27% of the universe, whereas ordinary matter which makes up all stars and galaxies adds up to only about 5%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Only 7,100 cheetahs are left in the world: Study
article: There are only 7,100 cheetahs remaining on the Earth, a recent study by Panthera and Wildlife Conservation Society has revealed. Currently, the animals are placed in the 'vulnerable' category of the IUCN's Red List of Threatened Species. Loss of prey, illegal trafficking and habitat loss have been held responsible for the decreasing number of the world's fastest animal.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study maps how brain recognises familiar faces
article: A US-based study has mapped the process by which brain recognises familiar faces regardless of variations in expression due to happiness or neutrality. Using brain-imaging tools, researchers studied how information is processed starting from when an image of a face first enters a person's eye, until the time when the person is able to recognise the face's identity.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists deliver customised cancer therapy with nanodiscs
article: University of Michigan researchers have developed a technology which uses nanodiscs to deliver customised therapeutic vaccine for treating cancer. Scientists used nanodiscs to "educate" the immune system so that immune cells attack cancer cells in a personalised manner. When combined with another technology, the nanodiscs helped in killing melanoma cancer tumours in mice within 10 treatment days.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New Arctic bird species discovered from 90-mn-yr-old fossil
article: US-based scientists have discovered a new bird species in the Canadian Arctic based on the findings of 90-million-year-old fossils. Identified as Tingmiatornis arctica, the prehistoric bird is believed to offer an evidence of an intense warming event during Cretaceous period. Understanding of historic climate records would help in determining the effect of climate change on different species.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA astronauts to conduct spacewalks for power update
article: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station are set to conduct two spacewalks in January to upgrade the orbital outpost's power system, US space agency NASA said. Astronauts will install adapter plates and hook up electrical connections for six new lithium-ion batteries delivered to the orbital laboratory early this month. The spacewalks are scheduled for January 6 and January 13.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Omega-3 fatty acid may reduce asthma risk in children: Study
article: A recent study has found that taking certain omega-3 fatty acid supplements during pregnancy can reduce the risk of asthma in children. The study found that the women who were prescribed 2.4 grams of long-chain omega-3 supplements during their third trimester of pregnancy, reduced their children's risk of asthma by 31%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: World's most heat resistant material identified
article: With a record melting point of nearly 4000°C, hafnium carbide has been identified as the world's most heat resistant material. A team of UK-based researchers found that hafnium carbide can withstand temperatures up to 3958°C. Using a new heating technique that was able to provide higher temperatures, the material was found to exceed its existing records of withstanding high temperatures.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Temperatures around North Pole hit melting point of ice
article: Areas around the North Pole hit the melting point temperature of ice (0°C) on Thursday, as a heatwave drew abnormally warm air northwards. Although there aren't any weather stations at the Pole, a nearby floating buoy in the Arctic Ocean reported zero degrees. Reportedly, the arctic recently lost about 1,48,000 square kilometers of ice cover in one day.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Vaccine shown to give 100% protection against Ebola
article: An experimental vaccine has been shown to provide 100% protection against the Ebola virus in a trial led by the World Health Organisation. Among the 5,837 people in Guinea who received the vaccine, no Ebola cases were recorded ten days or more after the vaccination. Ebola is a viral disease with an average fatality rate of around 50%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: In pictures: Top picks of the week in wildlife photography
article: British national daily newspaper The Guardian has curated the best wildlife pictures from the natural world of the past week. The picked images include the last known male northern white rhinoceros in Kenya, macaques playing on a motorbike in Jaipur in India, and a dolphin leaping out of the water in South Africa's Eastern Cape province, among others.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Dinosaur species turned vegetarian after losing teeth: Study
article: China-based scientists recently discovered a dinosaur species called the Limusaurus that developed sharp teeth for eating meat after birth, but lost them after reaching adulthood, thereafter becoming vegetarian. By comparing 19 fossilised remains of the two-legged dinosaur, scientists found that the Limusaurus' teeth transitioned into a toothless beaked jaw as the bird-like species grew up.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: First manned mission entered moon's orbit on Christmas Eve
article: Apollo 8, the first manned mission sent to orbit the moon, entered the lunar orbit on Christmas Eve in 1968. The spacecraft left Earth's orbit on December 21 with astronauts Frank Borman, Jim Lovell and William Anders. These astronauts became the first to see Earth as a whole planet, to witness earthrise and to directly see the moon's far side.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Star may come within 0.2 light yrs of Earth in 1 million yrs
article: According to a Polish study, a star named Gliese 710 which is currently 64 light years away from Earth, could come as close as 0.2 light years of Earth in just over a million years. Scientists have suggested that the sun-like star could come close enough to deflect the orbit of asteroids in outer solar system, potentially towards the Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mongolia's air quality becomes 5 times worse than Beijing's
article: Mongolia's air quality has become five times worse than that of Beijing, which recently faced its worst smog of the year. Mongolia's air had almost 80 times the recommended fine particulate matter (PM 2.5) limit set by the WHO. According to government data, PM 2.5 levels peaked at 1,985 micrograms per cubic meter in Mongolia's Bayankhoshuu district on December 16.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New device can detect 17 diseases from a person's breath
article: A team of international researchers claims to have developed a device that can detect 17 different diseases, including cancer and Parkinson's disease, just from a person's exhaled breath. It uses nano-rays to determine the air's chemical composition and identify "signatures" pertaining to any of the diseases. Each disease produces a unique biomarker based on the amounts of 13 different components.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Solar power is cheapest energy form in 58 nations: BNEF
article: In a first, solar energy has become the cheapest form of electricity in 58 developing countries including China and India, according to Bloomberg New Energy Finance (BNEF) data. As per the data, the average price of solar energy in these countries has dropped to ₹11.2 crore per megawatt during 2016, just below the corresponding wind energy figure of ₹11.25 crore.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Astronomy pioneer who helped discover dark matter dies at 88
article: Vera Rubin, an American astronomer who helped find evidence of dark matter, died of dementia at the age of 88 on Sunday. The astronomy pioneer examined more than 200 galaxies in her lifetime. Rubin was the second female astronomer to be elected to the National Academy of Sciences and also received the National Medal of Science in 1993.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists send information using a single particle of light
article: US-based scientists have developed a semiconductor device that allows an electron to send its quantum information to a single particle of light or photon. This could help in developing silicon-based quantum computers, with the photon transmitting information to other electrons. The electrons, acting as data units, would help in creating connections that form a quantum computer's circuits.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Teams from India, Japan partner to share ride to moon
article: India's entry to Google Lunar X Prize competition, Team Indus has partnered with Japanese team Hakuto to carry its four-wheeled lunar rover to the Moon’s surface. Earlier this month, Team Indus announced that it had signed a launch contract with ISRO to launch its lunar lander and rover with the PSLV rocket.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists build bacteria-powered battery on a paper sheet
article: US-based scientists have developed a bacteria-powered battery on a single sheet of paper, which is capable of powering disposable electronics. A ribbon of silver nitrate underneath a thin layer of wax on one half of a chromatography paper acts as cathode, and a reservoir holding bacteria-rich liquid on the other half of the paper forms the anode.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 1st functional pacemaker cells made from human stem cells
article: Canada-based scientists have developed the first functional pacemaker cells using human stem cells, which have been shown to regulate heart beats in rats just like a biological pacemaker. A pacemaker is a device which is placed in the chest or abdomen to help control abnormal heartbeats using low-energy electrical impulses. The development could lead to an alternate biological pacemaker therapy.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains how plastic can be converted into fuel
article: A video details a study in which polyethylene, commonly known as plastic, was converted into energy. The researchers took plastic from bottles, food packaging, shopping bags and mixed it with a catalyst, turning the plastic into an alkane, a compound which is usually burned for energy. The scientists thus broke down plastic into alkane oil products, namely diesel.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Self-healing transparent stretchable conductor developed
article: In a first, US-based scientists have developed a self-healing ionic conductor, which they claim could be electrically activated for powering artificial muscles. Apart from the self-healing property, the material is also transparent and mechanically stretchable. The advancement could enable robots to self-heal after mechanical damages and could also help extend the lifetime of batteries.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Simulation shows Rosetta space probe's journey around comet
article: The European Space Agency (ESA) has made a four-minute simulation showing the complete journey of Rosetta spacecraft, which performed a detailed study of the Comet 67P before crash-landing on its surface in September. Launched in 2004, the spacecraft was missioned to investigate if the comet can provide answers to the origins of the solar system and life on Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Bats' loud random noises are used for communication: Study
article: An Israel-based study on bat vocalisation has found that Egyptian fruit bats actually communicate with each other when they make loud noises in their colonies. Using a voice-recognition system, scientists connected these sounds to social situations like arguing over food and mating. Until now, it wasn't clear whether the calls served a specific purpose or were simply loud random noises.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Optical microscope with record magnification developed
article: Germany-based scientists have developed a new fluorescence microscope, which they claim has 100 times better resolution than conventional light microscopy and is up to 20 times sharper than the best light microscopy methods till date. Known as MINFLUX, the microscope has been shown to achieve nanometre-level resolutions and allows one to optically see individual molecules.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Low-carbon sources accounted for 50% of electricity: UK govt
article: In a first, half of the electricity generated in the UK has come from low-carbon sources like wind turbines and solar panels between July and September, official figures have confirmed. Notably, the rise in the use of low-carbon sources has been attributed to new wind farms and solar farms, and the closing of several coal power stations in the country.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make 3-atom-wide wire using smallest diamond bits
article: Stanford scientists have used the smallest possible diamond bits (diamondoids) to assemble atoms into three-atom-wide electrical wires. The core of each block of the nanowire is formed by copper and sulphur atoms, while diamondoids form the insulating outer shell. The technique could be used for making fabrics that produce electricity and optoelectronic devices that employ both current and light.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Robot captures rare footage beneath the Antarctic sea ice
article: An underwater robot deployed by the Australian Antarctic Division scientists has captured a rare glimpse of the life forms beneath the east Antarctic sea ice. The footage of the underwater world shows dandelion-like worms, spidery starfish and coconut-shaped sponges, among others. These species thrive in water that is covered with about 1.5-metre-thick ice almost throughout the year.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Champagne tastes better with bigger bubbles: Study
article: A French study has claimed that champagne tastes better with bigger bubbles, contradicting the age-old perception that smaller the bubbles, better is the champagne. Scientists discovered that the presence of bigger bubbles, of size around 3.4 mm, increases the release of aerosols in the air above the surface, enhancing the amount of aromatic compounds that goes into a drinker's nose.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Graphene conducts 1000 times more current than normal: Study
article: International researchers have recently shown that graphene, a two-dimensional crystalline form of carbon, can withstand about 1,000 times more current on nanoscale than regular materials, without suffering any damage. Scientists demonstrated that carbon atoms when knocked out of the graphene film by highly-charged xenon ions, are refilled with another carbon atom within some femtoseconds.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Video explains the purpose of Earth's magnetosphere
article: The magnetosphere is a region wherein charged particles are controlled by the Earth's magnetic field. According to the video, the Sun releases radioactive, charged plasma called coronal mass ejection (CME) which are deflected by the magnetosphere. Further, it acts as a shield against cosmic rays emitted from other space objects, which can otherwise cause permanent damage to brain cells.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Distinctive brain pattern identified in dyslexic patients
article: MIT scientists have identified a distinctive neural signature in the brains of people with dyslexia, which they believe could explain why these people have learning disorder. Scientists found that the brain of a dyslexic patient has a diminished ability to adapt to repeated input, suggesting that the brain's plasticity which supports its ability to learn new things is reduced.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Earth's N Hemisphere witnesses year's shortest day on Dec 21
article: The Northern Hemisphere of the planet observed the Winter Solstice, the shortest day and longest night of the year, on December 21. A Solstice is an astronomical event when the tilt of Earth's axis with respect to the Sun is maximum. This day also marks the longest day of the year in the Southern Hemisphere, called the Summer Solstice.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 420-km-wide molten iron jet discovered below Russia, Canada
article: International researchers have discovered a 420-km-wide molten jet of iron which is nearly as hot as the sun's surface and is speeding beneath Russia and Canada. The jet's speed is estimated to have tripled since 2000 and is three times faster than liquid streams in Earth's outer core. The discovery was made by measuring magnetic field variations below Earth's surface.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 102-yr-old scientist wins case for office in college campus
article: Dr David Goodall, renowned as Australia's oldest scientist, has won a battle to keep working on the campus of Edith Cowan University. The 102-year-old was ordered to work from home over concerns for his safety. However, the university has agreed to give him an office at its Mount Lawley campus, which would reduce his earlier travel time of 90 minutes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: World's oldest water sample found to be 2 billion years old
article: University of Toronto scientists have discovered the oldest water sample dating back to about two billion years, more than 500 million years more ancient than the previous oldest samples. The water pool was found at a depth of nearly 3 kilometres in a Canadian mine. The discovery could give clues about life forms beneath the surface of other planets.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Harvard creates world's smallest radio receiver
article: Harvard engineers have created the world's smallest radio receiver, whose building blocks are crystal defects the size of two atoms in diamonds. The minuscule radio can withstand extremely harsh environments due to diamond's inherent strength, researchers said and added that the receiver could have various applications ranging from a Venus probe to a pacemaker in a human heart.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists copy climate change data fearing Trump crackdown
article: Researchers across North America are attempting to back up data from climate change research in case the Trump administration orders its removal. An independent project Climate Mirror aims to copy public environmental data before Trump takes office in January. Notably, US Department of Energy recently refused Trump's request to name employees attending climate change meetings.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Dubai woman has baby from ovary frozen when she was 9
article: A 24-year-old woman from Dubai, Moaza Al Matrooshi, had a baby using ovary tissues that were frozen from before she reached puberty. She delivered a baby boy at a privately-run hospital in London on December 13. Moaza had decided to freeze her ovarian tissue because she was born with a blood disorder called thalassaemia.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Everyone has brown eyes: Study
article: A new study led by optometrist Gary Heiting has revealed that all eyes are brown, and their colours appear to be different because of the amount of pigment cells called melanocytes in the iris. The study showed that blue-eyed people have fewer melanocytes, making their eyes appear lighter in colour, while the brown-eyed people have more of these pigment cells.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: S Korean fusion reactor sustains plasma for record 70 sec
article: The Korean Superconducting Tokamak Advanced Research nuclear fusion reactor in South Korea has sustained high performance plasma in a stable state for 70 seconds, the longest ever recorded time for this type of reaction. The reactor used superconducting magnets cooled to -269°C to maintain plasma at temperatures up to 300 million°C, nearly 20 times that in the Sun's core.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Solar system discovered with 'planet-eating' host star
article: Chicago-based astronomers have discovered a planetary system around 300 light years away, whose host star appears to have 'swallowed' some of its planets. The six billion-year-old star, which is similar to the Sun, was found to contain four times more lithium than expected, as well as heat-resistant elements usually found in rocky planets.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists use 'pregnancy fluid' to strengthen weak bones
article: UK-based researchers have found that stem cells harvested from pregnant woman's amniotic fluid (the protective fluid that surrounds baby in the uterus) can be used to strengthen weak bones. The study showed that stem cell infusions led to 78% fewer fractures in mice with a brittle bone disease. The finding could help treat astronauts who lose bone mass in space.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: China launches satellite to monitor global CO2 emissions
article: China has launched atmospheric CO2-monitoring TanSat satellite on Thursday, in an effort to curb and monitor greenhouse gas emissions. The 635-kg satellite will measure global carbon dioxide levels every 16 days over the next three years and help policy makers and scientists gather independent climate change data. Notably, China is the world's largest emitter of CO2.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Discovery of 163 new species in Southeast Asia confirmed
article: As many as 163 new species including a dragon-like lizard and a rainbow-headed snake have recently been discovered by scientists in Greater Mekong region in Southeast Asia, according to a report by World Wildlife Fund. These species have been discovered in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand and Vietnam, and include three mammals, nine amphibians, 11 fish, 126 plants and 14 reptiles.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Phone-based device to combat antimicrobial resistance made
article: UCLA researchers have developed a smartphone-based test reader that conducts automated antimicrobial resistance testing, with 98.2% detection accuracy. The device connects to a smartphone and can hold up to 96 testing wells. Each of the wells contains a different antibiotic dose and the lowest antibiotic concentration that prevented the bacterial growth is used to track drug resistance.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Test devised to detect gender, racial bias in AI decisions
article: A team of researchers led by Google scientist Moritz Hardt has developed a methodology to detect whether any gender or racial bias is introduced by Artificial Intelligence algorithms into the decision-making process. The approach works on the concept that nothing more about an individual's race or gender is revealed by the decision, than what can be extracted using input data.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists design soft robot that mimics biological movement
article: Harvard researchers have developed a model to automatically design a soft robot that can perform desired biological movements. The team used the tool to develop a soft robot that bends like an index finger and twists like a thumb when powered by a single pressure source. This could be used to design a wearable robot that assists the limb's motion.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Processed meat could worsen asthma symptoms: Study
article: As per a new French study, higher intake of cured or processed meat, like ham and sausages, may worsen the symptoms of asthma. Conducted on nearly 1,000 people, the study found that those consuming four or more weekly servings of processed meat were 76% more likely to experience worsening asthma symptoms like shortness of breath and chest tightness.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Panda's minimum space requirement is 115 square kms: Study
article: According to a recent study, pandas prefer about 115 square kilometres of space for living and are less likely to dwell in smaller areas. By examining five of the six regions in the world where pandas thrive, researchers found that the aforementioned dimensions are essential for 90% probability of finding a panda.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Physicists observe light spectrum of antimatter for 1st time
article: European physicists have reported the first ever optical spectrum measurement of antimatter, revealing it to be the exact mirror image of ordinary matter. Antimatter is composed of particles with same mass as matter, but with opposite charges. The experiment, that compared antihydrogen with hydrogen, is consistent with the theory which states the two should have identical spectroscopic properties.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mystery sound from world's deepest ocean part identified
article: A mysterious, metallic sound that has been recorded in Mariana Trench, the world's deepest part of the oceans, might be from a minkle whale, according to a US-based research. Dubbed as the "Western Pacific Biotwang", the sound includes frequencies spanning from as low as 38 hertz to as high as 8,000 hertz and lasts between 2.5 seconds and 3.5 seconds.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Birth of atmospheric ice clouds observed for the first time
article: In a first, US-based scientists have witnessed at the sub-micrometre scale, the birth of crystals that come up together to form atmospheric ice clouds in the laboratory. By replicating the atmospheric temperature, pressure and humidity conditions in a chamber, scientists witnessed water vapour forming ice onto a tiny mineral particle, a process known as heterogeneous ice nucleation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Laser therapy shown to destroy prostate cancer in trials
article: A laser therapy involving the injection of a light-sensitive drug has successfully been shown to destroy tumour cells which cause prostate cancer. The treatment, called Vascular-targeted Photodynamic therapy (VTP), was tested on 413 patients across ten European countries. The therapy was seen to cause only short-term urinary and erectile problems, which were resolved within three months.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: Japan successfully launches solid fuel rocket
article: Japan's space agency on Tuesday announced that it successfully launched a 26-metre-long rocket named Epsilon-2, which put a satellite that helps study radiation belts in orbit. Epsilon-2 is part of a new generation of solid propellant rockets which can reduce launch costs up to one-third. Reduction in cost can allow countries to put more communication and weather satellites in space.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Jupiter's 'string-of-pearls' storms captured by NASA probe
article: NASA's Jupiter probe Juno has captured one of the eight massive counterclockwise rotating storms that appear like a string of pearls over the southern hemisphere. The image was taken by the JunoCam imager as the spacecraft performed its third close flyby about 24,600 km from Jupiter. Since 1986, the number of these oval storms has varied between six and nine.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: First chikungunya vaccine made from harmless virus
article: In a first, US-based scientists claim to have developed a vaccine for chikungunya fever from an insect-specific virus that does not affect people. Scientists used an Eilat virus clone to design a hybrid virus-based vaccine, which is structurally identical to the natural chikungunya virus. The hybrid virus can replicate in mosquitoes, but not in mammals.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: World's smallest snowman created
article: A 0.003-millimetre-tall snowman, created by the Western University in London, is reported to be the smallest snowman in the world. The eyes and mouth of the snowman were cut using a focused ion beam, while its nose and arms were made using platinum. Made using three 0.9 micron silica spheres, the snowman can be seen using an electron microscope.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Pregnancy causes long-term changes to brain structure: Study
article: A new research on brain scans has revealed that pregnancy causes long-lasting physical changes to a woman's brain. Scientists found that pregnancy leads to reduction in grey matter volumes in brain, which are the regions linked to the ability of empathising with others. Notably, these changes were found to last for at least two years after the child's birth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA successfully launches 8 satellites from an airplane
article: US space agency NASA has successfully launched a constellation of eight microsatellites into space from the 'belly' of an airplane. The satellites, meant to improve hurricane forecasting, were fired from a height of around 12 km and were put in an orbit 500 km above Earth's surface. The launch is a part of $157 million Cyclone Global Navigation Satellite System.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: UK becomes first country to approve three-parent babies
article: Britain has become the first country in the world to legally offer "three-parent baby" fertility treatments after regulators gave the green light. The technique, which uses DNA from two women and a man, would allow mothers who carry disease-causing mutations in their mitochondrial genes to give birth to children free of the illness.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Ghost shark' filmed for 1st time in Northern Hemisphere
article: A species of deep-sea fish known as the chimaera or 'ghost shark', has been filmed for the first time in the northern hemisphere. Known to live at depths of more than 2 km, the chimaera belongs to a group of species that emerged 300 million years ago. Male chimaeras are known for having a retractable sex organ on their heads.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 3,000-year-old Egyptian mummies 'virtually unwrapped'
article: Egyptian mummies up to 3,000 years old have been virtually unwrapped for the first time in a joint British-Australian exhibition. A dual-energy computed tomography (CT) scanner was used to obtain thousands of image slices of the mummies, with volumetric software then used to create 3D visualisations. One scan revealed a priest's daughter from about 900BC with plaque in her arteries.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Book stating Newton's laws of motion fetches ₹25 crore
article: A Principia Mathematica First edition by Sir Isaac Newton, which states the laws of motion and universal gravitation, recently auctioned for over ₹25.5 crore. The 1687-published work became the most expensive printed scientific book ever auctioned. The book was described by Albert Einstein as "perhaps the greatest intellectual stride that it has ever been granted to any man to make".

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Roads split land on Earth into 6,00,000 fragments: Study
article: A global map of roadless areas has shown that increased road construction has split the land on Earth into 6,00,000 fragments. Over 50% of these fragments are smaller than 1 sq km, an area insufficient to support significant wildlife. Among the last remaining large roadless areas are the tropical rainforests and boreal forests in Northern Russia and Canada.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 58 yrs since launch of world's 1st communications satellite
article: The world's first communications satellite was launched on December 18, 1958. Named Project SCORE (Signal Communications by Orbiting Relay Equipment), the satellite broadcasted a Christmas message from then-US President Dwight Eisenhower via an on-board tape recorder. "Through the marvels of scientific advance, my voice is coming to you from a satellite circling in outer space," said Eisenhower.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Boron detected on Mars for the first time
article: NASA's Curiosity rover has detected boron for the first time on the surface of Mars. Scientists believe this indicates Martian groundwater may have had temperature, alkalinity and mineral content suitable for hosting microbial life in the ancient past. Boron and the clay deposits found near it underline the mobility of elements and electrons, which favours life, a Caltech professor remarked.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Arctic saw warmest year on record, temp up 3.5°C since 1900
article: Average temperatures in the Arctic have risen by 3.5°C since 1900, according to a report by the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Temperatures in the region continue to rise at double the rate of the planet as a whole. In 2016, Arctic witnessed its warmest year on record, with sea ice hitting second lowest level on record in September.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 3.6 mn-yr-old early human footprints found in Tanzania
article: Footprints of five ancestors of humans who lived more than 3.6 million years ago have been discovered preserved in volcanic ash in Tanzania. They are believed to have belonged to three females, a male and a child from the Australopithecus species of walking apes. Analysis of the footprints have led scientists to infer that the male had multiple female mates.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New device bypasses spinal cord injury to restore movement
article: California-based medical researchers have developed an electrical stimulation implant that bypasses injuries in the spinal cord to restore limb movement. The stimulation forces the spinal cord to use alternative pathways to transmit brain's signals to body parts. Tests conducted by the team have shown that the device can improve a quadriplegic patient's finger mobility and grip strength by 300%.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Asteroid impact in ocean may vaporise 250 mn tons of water
article: Data scientists at US-based Los Alamos National Laboratory have used high performance computing to simulate the effects of a giant asteroid landing in the ocean. Their models showed that a 250-metre asteroid landing in water would vaporise nearly 250 million tons of water, launching water vapour to the stratosphere where it would act like a greenhouse gas.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Video gives scientific reason why 'honeymoon phase' ends
article: 'Honeymoon phase' in a relationship is marked by activation of two brain regions, rich in dopamine, a chemical associated with pleasure. Further, an increase in cortisol levels causes feelings of infatuation and obsession. As cortisol decreases, one starts feeling less obsessive. However, that doesn't mean one can't be madly in love with someone even after decades, according to the video.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Underwater network offers glimpse into deep-sea eruption
article: A network of submerged sensors offered scientists the first detailed glimpse of an underwater volcanic eruption in action. Scientists had been observing deformations in the seafloor due to magma accumulation under Axial Seamount in the Pacific, which finally started erupting in April 2015. Observing this will help understand and predict more complex land volcanic eruptions, scientists have added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ceres dwarf planet has more water than Earth: Study
article: Scientists behind NASA's Dawn probe have revealed the dwarf planet Ceres located in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter holds more water than Earth by weight. The team estimated that Ceres is composed of up to 30% water at poles, which explains its ice volcano and salt crater. Scientists believe liquid water flowed inside Ceres during its early years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rats smile and express happiness with their ears: Study
article: Rats demonstrate feelings of happiness by lowering their ears, according to Switzerland-based researchers. They subjected a group of rats to positive and negative experiences by tickling them and blasting them with white noise respectively. Rats being tickled were found to emit more high-pitched squeaks and their ears became droopier and pinker, which was attributed to being in a relaxed state.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Study explains how world's biggest diamonds are formed
article: As per a recently published research, some of the world's biggest and most valuable diamonds are formed from metallic liquid deep inside Earth's mantle. Studying leftover offcut pieces from diamonds, US-based researchers found tiny metallic grains trapped inside. Such diamonds are formed at depths greater than 400 km underground and are ejected by minor volcanic eruptions, the study suggested.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: How does in vitro fertilisation work?
article: In patients undergoing in vitro fertilisation, follicle stimulation hormone is administered at levels that are higher than naturally occurring to produce multiple eggs through controlled overstimulation of ovaries. The eggs are retrieved just before ovulation. Fertilisation occurs either by incubating the eggs with thousands of sperm or by using a needle to place a single sperm inside the egg.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Runners, musicians have better connected brains: Study
article: Runners and musicians have better connected brains, according to an Arizona-based research. Analysis of MRI scans revealed that runners had better connectivity in brain regions such as the prefrontal cortex, which handles planning, decision-making and multitasking. Earlier research had found similar link between functional connectivity and fine motor control required to learn a musical instrument.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Dark matter-ordinary matter interaction seen for 1st time
article: A first of its kind analysis of spiral galaxies 10,000 times smaller than the Milky Way galaxy has revealed interactions between dark matter and ordinary matter. These interactions, where dark matter appeared to mimic visible matter in its mass distribution, cannot be explained by gravitation alone, and require a new model of particle physics, said the Italy-based researchers.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: How does the skin hold body fluids without leaking them?
article: Epidermis, the topmost layer of human skin is responsible for holding all body fluids inside. Among the numerous layers of epidermis is the 'stratum granulosum', configured in a three-dimensional checkerboard pattern with 14 sides, which makes the skin leakproof. Further, the cells in this region produce a glue, which binds this shape together, so that the skin doesn't fall apart.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Video: Why is glass transparent?
article: When light passes through any substance, the photons' energy, if in the right amount, helps electrons jump from their initial state to excited state. In glass, electron rows are so far apart that photons do not provide sufficient energy for the electron to jump to the next row. Photons pass through glass unabsorbed, making glass transparent, according to the video.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video discusses what leukemia is
article: Leukemia is a form of cancer that begins in stem cells found in the bone marrow. Leukemias are often caused by just one or two DNA modifications, while most cancers require many of them, allowing leukemias to arise faster than other types of cancer. This might be one contributing factor as to why it is the most common childhood cancer.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How radiation changes your DNA?
article: Radiation which refers to the emission of energy as electromagnetic waves can cause changes in the DNA. When a high-energy particle or wave hits an atom, the atom absorbs the energy, possibly inducing chemical changes in the tissue. If radiation affects many cells at once, it can further cause radiation poisoning, resulting in damage to the structure of the DNA.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA releases map of carbon dioxide movement in atmosphere
article: NASA has released a 3D visualisation of complex patterns in which carbon dioxide in the atmosphere increased, decreased and moved around the globe from September 2014 to September 2015. For the map, scientists tracked the rising concentration of carbon dioxide for decades using ground-based sensors. The simulation will help "give a coherent view of the carbon cycle", scientists said.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How do astronauts train for space?
article: A video details the numerous training programs astronauts undertake besides courses in engineering, medical sciences and public speaking. To prepare for possible scenarios, astronauts are made to spend weeks in a cave, deprived of natural light and familiar surroundings. The video states that they are also left stranded in deserts and frozen tundra, with the aim of developing team skills.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Video explains 3 kinds of 'multiverse' models
article: A video lists three kinds of 'multiverses', proposed universe models which haven't been confirmed yet. As per the 'membrane' model, our universe is embedded within a larger super-universe. 'Bubble universe' model states that since other parts of the universe exists far away, we'll never see them. 'Many worlds' model, proposes that every possible alternate timeline for the universe is real.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Humans unprepared for sudden asteroid strike: NASA
article: Humans are unprepared to deal with situations in which a sudden asteroid or comet strikes the Earth, NASA scientist Joseph Nuth has warned. He recommended building an interceptor rocket as a backup, alongside an observer spacecraft. As a last resort, humans would have to use nuclear warheads to blow up potential cosmic threats before they strike, another scientist added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Einstein's relativity fails at black hole's edges: Study
article: Einstein's theory of general relativity breaks down at the edges of a black hole, according to researchers studying the gravitational wave events recorded by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory. The researchers claim they have found 'echoes' in the waves produced by two black holes merging, which contradicts the relativistic principle that nothing can escape a black hole.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ultra-rare quasicrystal found in Russian meteorite
article: An international team of researchers has discovered an ultra-rare quasicrystal, reportedly the third ever to be found in nature, in a sample from a meteorite that landed in Russia. The object was found consisting of aluminium, iron and copper. Quasicrystals are a form of solids intermediate between disordered amorphous solids and crystals which have repeating structures of atomic lattices.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Star 'dies' after passing close to supermassive black hole
article: A flash in the sky observed in 2015 was actually a supermassive black hole consuming a star that strayed too close to it, according to new research. Earlier called 'the brightest supernova ever detected', the phenomenon ripped the star apart in a process called 'spaghettification', which released a burst of radiations nearly half a trillion times brighter than the Sun.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Tumour found in 255mn-yr-old fossil of sabre-toothed beast
article: Washington-based scientists have found one of the oldest known tumours, in the fossil of a sabre-toothed, mammal-like beast that lived 255 million years ago. Composed of tiny tooth-like structures, the benign tumour was found embedded beside the root of the creature's enlarged canine tooth. The animal belonged to an extinct group of carnivores that mixed mammal-like and reptile-like traits.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Water's properties at supercooled temp measured for 1st time
article: US researchers have measured the properties of supercooled liquid water for the first time, using a laser-based cooling technique. They found the time taken for supercooled water to crystallise into ice drops reduced from nanoseconds at -11ºC to hours at -147ºC. The study ruled out the possibility of a singularity temperature where supercooled liquid water snaps instantaneously into solid ice.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 500-yr-old longest living clam reveals climate change effect
article: UK-based scientists studying the world's longest-living animal, a 500-year-old quahog clam, claimed to have discovered a 'worrying' effect of climate change on its shells. Growth rings on the 500-year-old animal's shells showed that from 1800, changes to the world's oceans took place at the same time or lagged behind changes to the atmosphere, instead of preceding them.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Christmas presents sent to International Space Station
article: A Japanese cargo ship called Kounotori or 'white stork' delivered Christmas presents to astronauts aboard the International Space Station on Tuesday. The Kounotori capsule, which also contained supplies including food and water, was grabbed by the astronauts using a robotic arm while hovering hundreds of miles above Chile. An astronaut said the crew was 'really excited' to accept the delivery.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Distant planet's clouds made of ruby and sapphire minerals
article: A giant gas planet around 1,000 light-years from Earth is covered with clouds that appear to be made from corundum, the mineral that rubies and sapphires are made of, according to the first exoplanet meteorology report. Based on analysis of four years of Kepler satellite telescope, the planet was estimated to have surface temperatures above 2,000°C, near corundum's boiling point.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Researchers give 'Harry Potter' name to new spider species
article: A group of researchers in Mumbai has named a newly-found species of spider 'Eriovixia gryffindori', after the fictitious wizard Godric Gryffindor from the Harry Potter series. It has been named after the character owing to its similarity to the Hogwart's magical Sorting Hat. The spider, which is around 7-millimetre in length, was found in the central Western Ghats in Karnataka.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ammonia detected in lower atmosphere for the first time
article: In a first, ammonia gas has been detected in the upper troposphere, atmosphere's lowest layer. Concentrations of the nitrogen-hydrogen compound were highest above China and India, likely due to agricultural expansion, as ammonia is an ingredient. Scientists believe, although ammonia emissions rise with global warming, its presence could have a cooling effect and contribute to cloud formation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Jupiter formed somewhere in the outer solar system: Study
article: US researchers have developed a new theory suggesting Jupiter was formed somewhere in the outer solar system. As it accumulated its thick atmosphere, Jupiter's changing mass distribution caused it to migrate inward to where the asteroid belt is today. Later, Saturn's formation created a gravitational tug, pulling both planets back out to their current positions, the study's simulations suggested.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Heat-powered refrigerator made that uses sound wave engine
article: Tokyo-based researchers have developed a heat-powered refrigerator that functions by generating sound waves to convert heat energy to work. The 'multistage travelling wave thermoacoustic engine' refrigerator was able to achieve minimum cooling temperatures of -107°C at hot temperatures of less than 300°C. This means that the device could be powered by waste heat from industries.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Planet around dying star offers glimpse into Earth's future
article: Astronomers are observing a planet orbiting the evolved star L2 Puppis, in an attempt to predict Earth's future when the Sun swells 100 times into a 'red giant' five billion years from now. L2 Puppis was nearly identical to the Sun five billion years ago, and its planet orbits it at a distance twice that between the Earth and Sun.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Dinosaur skeleton sells for $1.2 million at French auction
article: A 75% complete dinosaur skeleton fetched $1.2 million at a French auction, bought by an unnamed buyer. The 7-metre long, 2-metre tall skeleton was unearthed in 2013 in the Jurassic Era Morrison Formation, the most abundant source of dinosaur fossils in North America. It belonged to an allosaurus, a carnivore that went extinct 135 million years ago.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Extra-hard diamond to cut ultra-solid materials created
article: Australia-based researchers have created a nano-sized form of diamond harder than jewellers' diamonds, that can be used to cut through ultra-solid materials in mining sites. Naturally found at some meteorite impact sites and called Lonsdaleite, the new diamond's crystal structure has a hexagonal arrangement of carbon atoms, which imparts extra strength over cubically structured normal diamonds.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Spherical cloud appears in the sky over Japan
article: A rare spherical cloud was seen hovering in the afternoon sky over the Japanese city of Fujisawa, south of Tokyo, according to reports and photographs by a local. An atmospheric scientist claimed that the 'cloudball' was some form of cumulus fractus, low-hanging, fragmentary clouds that have been broken off the edges of larger clouds by strong winds.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: How are galaxies formed?
article: A video suggests galaxies originated from gas clouds which collapsed into stars due to their internal gravity to form separate galaxies. According to another theory, stars began forming in smaller clumps post Big Bang. These clumps then merged with other clumps, getting bigger to form galaxies. The video further explores the role of black holes in galaxy formation.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How does our imagination work?
article: Imagination is a complex process that requires sophisticated coordination inside the brain. A video discusses the mental synthesis theory, suggesting how neurons combine together to form images in the brain. It further details the role of the brain's prefrontal cortex and how numerous electrical signals help to induce imagination.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Warmer Arctic temperatures causing reindeer to get smaller
article: Rising Arctic temperatures owing to global warming are causing reindeer to shrink in size, according to a new study. Over a 21-year period, researchers have observed 12% average decline in body mass in Norwegian Svalbard reindeer. This is because warming climate triggers rainfall that turns soft snow cover into hard ice, cutting off the animals' moss and grass food supply.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Strong magnetosphere may allow life on closest star's planet
article: The presence of strong magnetic field and thick atmosphere may favour the possibility of life on Proxima b, simulations by US-based researchers have revealed. Proxima b is a planet orbiting Proxima Centauri, the nearest star from the Sun. If the planet has a weak magnetosphere, then any life would likely be extinguished by its star's flares, the study further claimed.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Aerosol may cool planet without ozone damage: Study
article: Harvard researchers have identified a new aerosol to mitigate global warming effects without damaging the ozone layer.
