The team found that calcite, a constituent of limestone, could counter ozone loss by neutralising emissions-borne acids in the atmosphere, while also reflecting light and cooling the planet. However, this is a supplement and not a solution to climate change, the researchers added.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What would happen if the Earth was hollow?
article: A video explains what would happen to a person if they jumped into a hole that went all the way through the Earth. The person would undergo the Coriolis effect, experiencing apparent deflection to the right. The video further discusses what would happen if the hole went from pole to pole, assuming no air resistance, or friction.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Pesticide stops bees' buzzing and affects pollination: Study
article: Neonicotinoid, the world's most widely used insecticide, hinders the ability of bees to vibrate flowers and shake out the pollen to fertilise crops, according to a Scotland-based study. The pesticides reduce learning and memory in bees. Many flowers, like those of crops like tomatoes and potatoes, must be shaken to release pollen, which bumblebees do by 'buzzing' their flight muscles.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Peripheral vision is partly brain-generated illusion: Study
article: What humans see out the corner of their eyes is partly an optical illusion generated by the brain, according to an Amsterdam-based study. The study showed, in certain circumstances, the brain 'fills in blanks' in the visual field outside the area of direct focus, conjuring the illusion of having as much visual information about the periphery as in the centre.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video discusses the future of human evolution
article: A video details how evolution is based on natural selection, where those with traits that make them better adapted to the environment tend to survive longer. According to scientists, women in the future will be shorter and slightly heavier, giving them higher reproductive success. Additionally, the human brains might get a bit smaller, possibly due to better efficiency.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Hot hydrogen atoms found in Earth's upper atmosphere
article: Using NASA's satellite remote sensing, researchers have discovered hot hydrogen atoms at an altitude of 250 km, in an upper layer of the atmosphere called the thermosphere. Earlier, atomic hydrogen had been theorised to exist at altitudes above several thousand kilometres. Atomic hydrogen plays a crucial role in scattering Sun's ultraviolet radiation and preventing the loss of water from Earth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Japan launches 'fishing net' to collect space garbage
article: Japan on Friday launched a spaceship carrying a 700-metre-long tether to pull some of the space debris from Earth's orbit out into the atmosphere, where it will burn. The tether was made by a 106-year-old fishing net company using aluminium and steel. There are more than 100 million space debris pieces in orbit, moving at 28,000 kmph around the Earth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: What is space debris and how is it formed?
article: Space debris is the collection of defunct man-made objects in space, like old satellites and spent rocket stages. It also consists of fragments from collisions, one of which happened in 2009 and was the first hypervelocity collision between two satellites, at 11.7 kilometres-per-second. Japan on Friday launched a fishing net-like tether to drag some space debris out of Earth's orbit.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA, Stephen Hawking working on 60,000 km/s 'nano-starship'
article: NASA researchers have joined forces with theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking to build a 'nano-starship' that can travel at 60,000 km/s, around one-fifth the speed of light. Among a number of options proposed, the ship could be designed as a self-healing silicon chip. If successful, the ship, called 'StarChip' could reach Earth's closest star system, Alpha Centauri, in around 20 years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New crystal smaller than human hair enables night vision
article: Australia-based researchers have designed a nanocrystal around 500 times smaller than the human hair that turns darkness into visible light. The crystal can absorb very low levels of light, and modify its intensity, shape and colour to tune it for human visibility. This can be used to create light-weight night-vision glasses, the researchers added.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: World's oldest astronaut John Glenn dies aged 95
article: The world's oldest person to venture into space and first American to orbit the Earth, John Glenn passed away on Thursday at the age of 95. Glenn spent almost nine days on the space shuttle orbiter Discovery aged 77 in 1998. As a Marine Corps Major, John Glenn set a record for the first transcontinental flight to average supersonic speed.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers use magnets to pull bacteria out from blood
article: Swiss and US-based researchers have developed a new method to purify human blood by removing harmful bacteria using magnets. The team coated antibodies that bind to harmful bacteria with iron particles, which the bacteria latched onto. The blood was then passed through a dialysis machine in which magnets pulled the antibodies and their pathogen particles.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 44 years since the last astronauts walked on the moon
article: NASA astronaut Eugene Cernan became the 12th and last human being to walk on the moon exactly 44 years ago on December 11, 1972. He was part of the Apollo 17 lunar mission, NASA's final mission that aimed to land humans on the moon. Till now, 24 men have travelled to the Moon, but only 12 actually walked upon it.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Tail of a 6-inch-long baby dinosaur found frozen in amber
article: In a first, a 99-million-year-old tail belonging to a 6-inch-long baby dinosaur has been found trapped in a piece of amber at a Myanmar market. Measuring 1.4 inches long, the tail was found complete with feathers, soft tissue, eight bone segments, and is believed to have belonged to a maniraptoran, two-legged bird-like feathered dinosaur that lived during the Cretaceous period.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Mars colonisation project delays launch by 5 years
article: Dutch not-for-profit organisation Mars One, which aims to establish a permanent human settlement on Mars, has pushed back the launch of its first manned mission from 2026 to 2031. The company, which was recently acquired by Switzerland-based company InFin Innovative Finance, has cited a new financial strategy as the reason behind the delay.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 2,500-year-old pottery reveals human organs and killer virus
article: Researchers have found remains of human blood, organs and a killer virus inside pottery unearthed in Germany, dating back around 2,500 years. The discovery, which is the first known archaeological record of a virus, was made after analysing proteins stuck to pottery fragments. The virus, identified as Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, is a fatal tick-borne disease still prevalent globally.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Device to power mobile through swipes developed
article: Michigan State University researchers have developed a new device that allows users to power their smartphones by just swiping. The device, a nanogenerator, harvests and stores energy from the human motion that is enough to keep a mobile phone charged for at least one week. The device can also be used to power wearables with human motion.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Hidden images created with commercial inkjet printers
article: Utah-based researchers have devised a low-cost method to use commercial inkjet printers to print hidden images that are only visible when illuminated with properly polarised radiation. Silver-carbon ink with slightly varying conductivities was used to print apparently identical images, each of which produced an image corresponding to the change in conductivity when beamed with terahertz radiation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA recreates Venus' harsh surface conditions on Earth
article: NASA's Glenn Extreme Environments Rig (GEER) project has successfully recreated the corrosive surface conditions on Venus in a 14-ton steel chamber in Ohio. Venus' surface atmosphere, about 100 times thicker than Earth's surface air, consists of about 97% carbon dioxide, and trace acidic gases at temperatures averaging 460°C. The project was designed to help develop Venus-safe space equipment.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: What does coffee do to our brain?
article: The caffeine in coffee suppresses adenosine, a chemical which builds up in the brain as the day progresses, resulting in tiredness. Further, coffee stimulates adrenaline production which increases the heart rate and opens up the airway. It also affects dopamine levels by preventing its reabsorption in the brain, making us feel happy.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Fish evolve to become 8,000 times resistant to toxic waste
article: Researchers have discovered a fish species off the US coast that has mutated to be 8,000 times more resistant to toxic waste than normal fish. The small striped killifish, known for living in heavily polluted waters, has very high levels of genetic variation, which enables it to undergo rapid mutations to block molecular pathways that cause damage in toxin-affected cells.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Polar bear numbers to drop by 1/3rd as sea ice melts: Study
article: Polar bear populations could drop 33% by mid 21st-century, according to a US-based assessment of the effects of dwindling Arctic sea ice on the world's largest bear. Notably, the International Union for the Conservation of Nature has classified the polar bear as "vulnerable", or at high risk of extinction in the wild, with an estimated 26,000 remaining specimens.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: CRISPR Pioneers among TIME Person of the Year '16 runners-up
article: The TIME magazine has named CRISPR Pioneers among its Person of the Year 2016 runners-up. Dr Carl June's team was chosen as her technique CRISPR, "allows scientists to easily and inexpensively find and alter virtually any piece of DNA in any species". Their "ultimate goal is to test CRISPR's greatest potential: its ability to treat diseases in humans", TIME said.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: New NASA spacecraft will refuel, repair satellites in space
article: NASA has commissioned a new type of satellite dubbed as 'Restore-L Spacecraft Bus', that will be able to refuel and repair other satellites while they are still in orbit around Earth. The spacecraft will help prolong the life of existing satellites and reduce operation costs. It could also be used for cleaning space debris or testing asteroid capture platforms.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: MIT technique uses blinking LED lights to treat Alzheimer's
article: Using LED lights flickering at a specific frequency, MIT researchers have shown that they can substantially reduce the toxic beta amyloid protein plaques seen in Alzheimer's disease, in the visual region of a mouse brain. The treatment induces brain waves known as gamma oscillations, which help the brain suppress beta amyloid production and stimulates cells responsible for destroying the plaques.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Spread of cancer fuelled by fat: Study
article: The spread of cancer is controlled by the presence of a certain type of fat, as revealed by a Barcelona-based study on mice. The study found that a cancerous cell uses a fatty acid receptor molecule known as CD36 to absorb lipid fats to power metastasis, an energy-intensive process that enables it to spread throughout the body.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Monkeys have vocal anatomy suited for human speech: Study
article: An Old World monkey called the macaque has the vocal anatomy required to produce 'clearly intelligible' human speech but lacks the brainpower needed to do so, according to a Princeton research. The findings suggest that human speech developed primarily from the evolution of the brain, and is not linked to vocalisation-related anatomical differences between humans and their primate relatives.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA shares collection of its best images of the cosmos
article: NASA has shared a collection of its best images and videos of the cosmos on idea-sharing platform Pinterest. The images have been selected from across NASA's many missions in aeronautics, astrophysics, Earth science, and human spaceflight, among others. Included are the images of Pluto, Jupiter, Saturn and its biggest moons Titan and Rhea, planetary nebulae and galaxies.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: How does the body know what time of the day is it?
article: An interconnected system of 'timekeeper proteins' inside the brain help the body keep track of what time of the day is it. The CLK protein helps us stay awake while the PER protein deactivates the gene producing CLK, so that the body can sleep. Additionally, our day and night cycles also rely on external factors like light and temperature.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA probe sends first images of Saturn's rings in new orbit
article: NASA's Cassini spacecraft has sent back its first photos since beginning the latest 'ring-grazing' phase of its Saturn-orbiting mission. The images show scenes from above Saturn's northern hemisphere, including the planet's distinct hexagonal jet stream. As the final phase of its mission, Cassini is set to perform 20 orbits, passing close to the outer edges of Saturn's main rings.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Genes responsible for promoting cross-pollination found
article: The cluster of associated genes responsible for the mechanism by which plants promote cross-pollination with other specimens has been identified by UK-based biologists. First proposed by evolutionist Charles Darwin, the genetic mutation causes plants to evolve multiple distinct forms of flowers, where male and female reproductive organs differ in length to inhibit self-fertilisation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Mind-controlled robotic hand developed for quadriplegics
article: Germany-based scientists have developed a mind-controlled robotic hand that allows people with certain types of spinal cord injuries to perform everyday tasks like drinking from a cup. By wearing a cap that tracks brain activity and eye movement, users can send signals to a tablet computer that controls the glove-like device attached to their hand.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Robot that can perform multiple vertical jumps developed
article: UC Berkeley researchers have designed a robot that can jump upward and then spring off a wall, resulting in the highest robotic vertical jumping agility ever recorded. The robot, named Salto, was inspired by animals known for agility, including the bush baby and the agama lizard. According to the researchers, the robot has applications in future search and rescue missions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 4.6 bn-year-old cosmic dust found on European city rooftops
article: Cosmic dust particles dating back to the birth of the solar system around 4.6 billion years ago have been discovered on rooftops in Paris, Oslo and Berlin. Previously, similar space debris has only been discovered in Antarctica and in deep reaches of oceans. This discovery is expected to help researchers gain insights into how the early solar system evolved.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: All man made objects on the planet weigh 30 trillion tonnes
article: Scientists have calculated that the combined mass of the 'technosphere', which defines all human-made things on the planet, weighs approximately 30 trillion tonnes. The 'technosphere', includes all human structures such as buildings, roads, and bridges, and also smaller items on the planet. The 30-trillion tonne mass spread across Earth's surface area would amount to over 50 kgs per square metre.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Length of Earth day increasing by 2 milliseconds per century
article: The length of a day on Earth is increasing by around 2 milliseconds every century, according to a team of international astronomers. This increase was primarily attributed to moon's gravity and tidal effect, which causes water to pile up effecting a drag on Earth's spin. The length of an Earth day will reportedly reach 25 hours in two million centuries.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Startup claims honeymoon on moon possible in 10 yrs at ₹6L
article: Space exploration startup Moon Express' Co-founder Naveen Jain has predicted that trips to the moon will be possible in the next 10 years for as low as ₹6.7 lakh ($10,000). Jain said he believes that by 2026, there will be a gentleman on his knees asking, "Honey, will you go to the moon with me for our honeymoon?"

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Births by surgical incision affecting human evolution: Study
article: As per an Austrian research, the regular use of Caesarean section, or C-section, for delivering babies is impacting human evolution. The C-section, unlike vaginal births, uses surgical incision to deliver babies. The study claims women's pelvic canals are not evolving to accommodate babies' growingly larger heads. This has increased obstructed childbirths by 20% since 1960s, scientists added.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers discover world's oldest polluted river
article: A team of researchers has discovered possibly the world's first polluted river, contaminated approximately 7,000 years ago. The now-dry riverbed in the Wadi Faynan region of southern Jordan has evidence of early pollution caused by the combustion of copper. Humans from that time period had begun transitioning from making tools out of stones to making tools out of metal.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: China develops non-toxic propellant for orbiting satellites
article: Chinese scientists have developed a non-toxic propulsion system to enable satellites to carry more payload and save on launching costs. The ammonium dinitramide (ADN) propellant was tested successfully in the recently launched Shijian-17 satellite. According to scientists, the new propulsion system helps an orbiting satellite sustain its altitude against atmospheric drag and gravity.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Polar sea ice the size of India has vanished: Study
article: Sea ice in the Arctic Ocean and off the Antarctic coast has shrunk from the 1981-2010 average to a record low after losing 3.84 million-square-kilometers of ice cover, equivalent to India's area, climate scientists have said. They have attributed the decline in ice cover to human-caused greenhouse emissions and an El Niño weather event.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Magnetic brain stimulation can recover lost memories: Study
article: Small jolts of electricity to the brain (or a pulse of transcranial magnetic stimulation) can help revive recent memories, according to a US-based study. The brain can slow near-term memories to a dormant state, which remain ready to come back when necessary. The technique, which cannot be applied to long-term memories, can help treat short-term memory loss and other diseases.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Fossils of possibly the 1st animal to walk on land uncovered
article: Fossils of what may have been the earliest four-legged vertebrate animals to walk on land have been discovered in Scotland. The lizard-like creatures lived about 355 million years ago, a time when the ancestors of modern reptiles, birds and mammals are believed to have emerged from swamps. The discovery also bridges a 15 million-year gap in fossil records.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Solar panels nearing energy break-even after 40 years: Study
article: According to a Netherlands-based study, the environment-friendly electricity generated by solar panels in the last 40 years will reach a break-even point in 2017, canceling out the polluting energy used to manufacture them. By the end of this year, solar panels will reach 300 gigawatts (GW) in capacity, meeting up to 1.5% of global electricity demand, the study added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Marine animal's existence confirmed 117 yrs after discovery
article: A deep-sea creature's existence has been confirmed in Monterey Bay of California, 117 years after it was first discovered in 1899. The giant larvacean, named 'Bathochordaeus Charon' after the mythical ferryman of the river Styx, is a tadpole-like creature that grows up to 9 cm in length, and feeds on minute particles which it filters through a metre-long, mucus 'house'.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rhythm of breathing affects memory, judgment: Study
article: According to scientists at US-based Northwestern University, the rhythm of breathing causes activity in the human brain that enhances memory recall and emotional judgments. In their study, individuals could identify a fearful face more quickly and were more likely to remember an object, if they encountered them when breathing in compared to breathing out.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Exposure to certain light affects the taste of milk: Study
article: According to a Virginia-based study, the taste of milk is affected by exposure to certain light. The study found that riboflavin, a key nutrient in milk, oxidises when exposed to fluorescent light, reducing nutritional content besides making the taste go "stale". The researchers suggested the use of light-blocking pigments in milk packaging to avoid a change in taste.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why do we have body odour?
article: Sweat, which has no smell, produces body odour when sweat gets into the folds of the skin where bacteria thrive. The bacteria eat the compounds found in sweat, and produce molecules that emit body odour. Additionally, diets can also affect the odour, with sulphur-rich meals enhancing the bad smell.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: What if we could only see the Moon from one spot on Earth?
article: A video states that the Moon is gradually moving away from the Earth, due to the interaction of the Moon and the Earth's tidal bulge. Over billions of years, Earth's rotation will slow down and the Moon's attraction to the bulge will speed up its orbit. The speed will make the orbit wider, pushing the moon farther and farther away.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video: Which animal kills the fastest?
article: A video suggests that the poison dart frog is the animal which kills the fastest. A single touch by the frog can kill a man weighing 90 kilograms in less than 10 minutes. The frog's poison, which is secreted from its skin glands, stops cells in humans from sending signals to each other, leading to heart failure and death.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists observe underwater pollination for the first time
article: For the first time, researchers have found evidence of underwater pollination, with microscopic crustaceans and tiny marine worms taking the roles of pollinators. Pollination is the act of transferring pollen grains from a flower's male anther to female stigma to create an offspring. Till now, scientists believed marine plants relied on water alone to spread their genes, to create offsprings.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Does the moon have a 'dark side'?
article: The Earth's gravity is so strong that only one side of the orbiting moon is visible, thus hiding the 'far side' which is "saturated with craters". The difference between both sides is believed to be a result of different thicknesses in the crust. A video states that the varied thickness may have been caused by the collision of 'two moons'.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Plants are capable of associative learning: Study
article: An Australia-based study has demonstrated that plants can learn about their environment by making links between events, an ability previously thought exclusive to animals. The study showed that pea seedlings, after initially being exposed to light from a particular direction, learnt to choose the best growth direction for survival by predicting the occurrence of light once it was removed.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Govt bans manufacturers from emitting greenhouse gases
article: The Indian government has issued directions prohibiting certain manufacturers from emitting HCFC-22 and HCF-23, a potent greenhouse gas with high global warming potential into the atmosphere. According to the directive, producers of HCFC-22 are mandated to file their report on the production of the ozone-depleting substances under the Ozone Depleting Substances Rules.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Art project lets people launch their laugh into space
article: Israeli artist Eyal Gever has launched a project titled '#Laugh' that will let people send sounds of their laughter to be 3D-printed in the International Space Station. People can download the #Laugh app to record their laugh, and the laugh voted the best will then be beamed up to the ISS, 3D-printed and ejected from the station into the orbit.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: First ever gravitational waves detector comes back online
article: The twin detectors of LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory), that made the first ever direct detection of gravitational waves, have recently been restarted. The system has undergone several enhancements, making the entire setup 25% more sensitive. LIGO made the first ever gravitational waves discovery in September last year, two days after it was restarted post an upgrade.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Giant galaxy spotted forming from 'cold soup' of gas
article: Astronomers have spotted the Spiderweb Galaxy, a giant object forming from an unusually dense 'cold soup' of molecular gas about 10 billion light years from Earth. In usual scenarios, galaxy clusters grow by cannibalising other galaxies. The Spiderweb, however, is forming from a gas cluster totalling more than 100 billion times the mass of the Sun, at temperatures of -200°C.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists find evidence of malaria's existence 2000 yrs ago
article: A new analysis of teeth collected from 2,000-year-old human remains from across the Italian peninsula have revealed evidence of malaria's existence during the Roman Empire. The study found mitochondrial genomic evidence of the malarial parasite 'Plasmodium falciparum' inside human teeth records. The findings may help scientists better understand the evolution of the human disease.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA developing autonomous drones to explore oceans
article: NASA researchers, in collaboration with other institutions, are developing submersible drones that can navigate and make decisions on their own, to help understand ocean phenomena and marine life. Autonomous 'robotic submersibles' can someday be used to explore icy oceans believed to exist on Jupiter's moon Europa, a favourable candidate to host life in the outer solar system, NASA added.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video: Where do galaxies come from?
article: A video suggests that before any stars had formed, everything was just spread-out gas and dark matter. Gravity would have caused slightly denser areas of dark matter to attract into clumps, pulling in bits of gas. Clusters of stars and their associated dark matter attracted together and merged, and then they gathered together, eventually forming the galaxies we see today.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Why do mosquitoes bite some people and not others?
article: Mosquitoes are attracted to the chemical scents emitted by people, based on their genes. Potentially blood O type is more attractive to mosquitoes. Other theories suggest that mosquitoes might be more attracted to people with high cholesterol or those who have excess amounts of uric acid. Furthermore, individuals drinking beer also attract mosquitos.

author: Parichit Mainra
abstract: Unmanned ISS cargo spaceship crashes minutes after launch
article: Unmanned cargo spacecraft Progress MS-04, which was delivering 2.6 tonnes of supplies to the International Space Station crashed shortly after takeoff on Thursday due to a malfunction, Russian officials said. Progress MS-04 was launched from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan and lost contact 383 seconds after the launch. Most of the debris burnt up in the atmosphere, they added.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why do airplanes take longer to fly West than East?
article: Even though the Earth spins at over 1,600 kmph to the East, airplanes take longer to fly West than East owing to the rotation's impact. The difference in time, to fly the same route in different directions, is caused due to the plane's relative movement in relation to the ground. Atmospheric winds called 'jet streams' also affect the speed.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Nihonium becomes Asia's 1st Periodic Table element discovery
article: Periodic Table element with atomic number 113, Nihonium (Nh) has become the first ever element to be discovered by an Asian country after it was officially revealed by the IUPAC on Wednesday. Along with three other elements that helped to complete the Periodic table, Nihonium was discovered and proposed by the RIKEN collaboration team in Japan in December last year.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's largest cluster of sinkholes found in China
article: Researchers have uncovered a cluster of 49 sinkholes in northwest China, the largest cluster of natural sinkholes in the world. These sinkholes run along a 200-km-long 'karst' landform belt in the Qinling-Bashan Mountains, with the biggest of them deeper than the height of the Eiffel Tower and wider than the height of the Empire State Building.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Brain portions fall asleep, wake back up all the time: Study
article: A new research by Stanford researchers has revealed that small regions of the human brain continuously fall asleep and wake back up all the time, even when the body is awake. A specific brain region remains in "sleep" state but shifts towards the "awake" state when it pays attention to a task. Scientists believe this phenomenon helps in conserving energy.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: US river once started flowing backwards after an earthquake
article: A series of tremors, which took place between December 1811 and March 1812 in the US, caused the Mississippi river to flow backwards for several hours. The soil in the bed of the river rose, temporarily changing its course and making it run backwards. Several boatmen also reported that temporary waterfalls had been created within the river.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Lightbulbs owned by Thomas Edison sell for ₹20 lakh
article: Buyers paid a total of over ₹40 lakh ($60,000) for items linked to famed inventor Thomas Edison in the US on Saturday, including ₹20 lakh ($30,000) for five lightbulbs. The bulbs were entered as evidence in a case where Edison sued three different companies for allegedly infringing on his patent for the incandescent bulb.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Indian scientist wins dark energy-related 10-year-old wager
article: Pune-based theoretical astrophysicist, Thanu Padmanabhan has won a $200 wager against a physicist from New Zealand based on a 'dark energy' related theory that he suggested at a conference 10 years ago. In 2006, Thanu had suggested that dark energy is just a mathematical term called the "cosmological constant" – an idea proposed and later discarded by Albert Einstein.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Indian startup signs contract with ISRO for mission to moon
article: Bengaluru-based aerospace startup Team Indus has become the first private entity to secure a dedicated Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle from ISRO. Team Indus is the only Indian team in Google's $20 million Lunar XPRIZE competition to become the first privately funded team to land a robot on the Moon that successfully travels 500 meters.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Nestlé claims it can cut sugar in chocolates by 40%
article: Swiss food conglomerate Nestlé claims that it has found a way to slash the sugar content in some of its chocolates by 40% without compromising their taste. The firm has reportedly discovered a way "to structure sugar differently" due to which sugar dissolves faster, and the tongue perceives a higher level of sweetness, even if less sugar is consumed.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Students create Martin Shkreli's $750 drug for just $2
article: Australian high school students have created anti-parasitic drug Daraprim's active compound in a laboratory for around $2, a year after American pharmaceutical executive Martin Shkreli increased the drug's price in USA from $13.50 to $750 apiece. Daraprim, which is on the World Health Organisation's list of essential medicines, is used to treat infections such as toxoplasmosis and malaria.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Why is Pluto no more a planet?
article: Pluto is not a planet anymore as it could not qualify the criteria of having cleared everything else out of its orbital path. It is only 0.07 times the mass of everything else in its orbit. Pluto was removed as a planet at the 26th general assembly of the International Astronomical Union in 2006, where astronomers also decided the criteria.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Mice can sense inhaled oxygen levels: Study
article: A study by a group of international scientists has revealed that mice can sense the oxygen level of the inhaled air using neurons in their nose. This newly-discovered sensory property relies on a couple of genes which are not the odour receptor genes. These genes also help in quickly identifying areas with low oxygen levels and then avoiding such areas.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Did a black hole create the Milky Way?
article: Scientists looked back 13.6 billion years to understand how the formation of stars in the Milky Way was stimulated by a black hole. According to a theory, a black hole with a "huge jet" smashes into dust, gases and neighbouring galaxies, resulting in the creation of stars by emitting radiation. This radiation causes the gas to clump together, forming stars.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Buzz Aldrin evacuated from South Pole after falling ill
article: Buzz Aldrin, the second man to walk on moon, has been evacuated from the South Pole after falling ill during a tourist visit. The 86-year-old was visiting Antarctica as part of a tourist group and was flown to the US Antarctic Program's research centre off the Antarctica coast. Aldrin had tweeted about the tour a few days earlier.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why does the Sun make a sound?
article: The sound of the Sun, which is too deep for human ears, is recorded by NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory by speeding up 40 days of recording into a few seconds. A video describes how the 'sound of chaos' is generated by sound waves creating ripples in the Sun's surface. The turbulence caused by gases is responsible for creating the sound.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Why do we get pimples and moles?
article: A three-minute video explains that humans get pimples when sebaceous glands produce excess of sebum, an oily substance. Since the skin's outer layers are shedding continuously, sometimes, dead skin cells get stuck with sebum, causing pore blockage and resulting in pimples. The video further explains that moles occur when cells in the skin grow in a cluster.

author: Tarun Khanna
abstract: ISRO to launch remote sensing satellite on Dec 7
article: Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) on Sunday announced that it is all set to launch PSLV-C36 carrying 1,235 kg remote sensing satellite RESOURCESAT-2A from the spaceport of Sriharikota on December 7.  The satellite would carry a high-resolution Linear Imaging Self Scanner camera, medium-resolution LISS-3 camera and an advanced wide field sensor camera that operates in various bands.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: First ever human heart transplant was conducted on Dec 3
article: South African surgeon Christiaan Barnard conducted the first ever human heart transplant surgery on December 3, 1967. 53-year-old Lewis Washkansky was transplanted with Denise Darvall's heart, a 25-year-old woman who was fatally injured in a car accident. Washkansky’s new heart functioned normally until he died of double pneumonia 18 days after the surgery.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers develop world’s first water-wave laser
article: Researchers have developed the first-ever water-wave laser. Light, which is delivered to small droplets of octane and water using optical fibres, bounces back and forth until enough energy builds up for it to escape as a laser beam. The discovery could help in usage of lasers for achieving better efficiency in studying microscopic cells and testing different drug therapies.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Religion affects the brain similar to taking drugs: Study
article: According to a new Utah-based study, religious experiences have a similar effect on the brain as taking drugs. Monitoring brain activity of 19 devout Mormons, scientists found increased activity in the brain's 'reward centre' whenever the subjects reported 'spiritual thoughts'. The same brain region is known to be associated with reactions to recreational drugs or listening to music.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video lists things astronauts are not allowed to do in space
article: A video discusses four things that astronauts are not allowed to do in space. It states that the astronauts are not allowed to have sex in space. They are also not allowed to have alcohol in space. Eating crumbly food and doing laundry are the other two things that astronauts are not allowed to do.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video: What is Alzheimer's disease?
article: Alzheimer's disease is a chronic neurodegenerative disease. In this disease, misfolded proteins called plaques and neurofibrillary tangles work together starting in a region called the hippocampus, which is responsible for forming memories. The proteins then invade other parts of the brain, creating changes that signal various stages of the disease.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video: Can we live with half of our brain?
article: A 4-minute video suggests that humans can live a nearly normal life with about half less brain, as per late John Freeman, a neurosurgeon at Johns Hopkins University.  The video, however, states that it would not be possible to live without the brain stem, which is at the top of the spine, as it controls heart, lungs and blood pressure.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video: Where does our music taste come from?
article: A 3-minute video suggests that our taste in music is probably linked to our memories of different songs, as per a psychological research. Developmental psychologists have noticed that the memories we form as a young adult tend to stay more detailed. The video further states that people report liking a thing more when they have seen or heard it before.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video explains what sea monkeys are
article: Sea monkeys are a hybrid of several species of brine shrimp. Harold von Braunhut, an inventor, developed a hybrid shrimp in 1957 to be sold as aquarium pets. Braunhut later decided to change the brand name to 'Sea Monkeys' by claiming that the creatures' tails made them look like monkeys who lived in water.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Biggest exposed crack on Earth's crust seen for the 1st time
article: Geologists have for the first time documented the Banda Detachment fault in eastern Indonesia, the biggest crack in Earth's crust. The fault represents a rip in the ocean floor exposed over 60,000 square-kilometres. The 7.2-km-deep abyss runs through the 'Ring of Fire', an explosive region where 90% of all earthquakes occur and 75% of all active volcanoes are found.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Official names of the 4 new Periodic Table elements revealed
article: The names of the four new elements discovered last year, that completed the seventh row of the Periodic Table, have been officially announced by the IUPAC (The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry). The newly-discovered elements with the atomic numbers 113, 115, 117 and 118 have officially been named Nihonium (Nh), Moscovium (Mc), Tennessine (Ts) and Oganesson (Og).

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Water in tiny tubes frozen at boiling temps at MIT
article: MIT researchers have found that inside tiny carbon nanotubes the width of a few molecules, water can freeze solid at temperatures above 105°C, which should set it boiling under normal conditions. This behaviour could lead to the development of 'ice-filled' wires at room temperature, which could conduct electricity up to ten times better than conventional conducting materials.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Does eating an ice cream actually heat up the body?
article: The breaking down of the ingredients of an ice cream, into usable blocks of energy creates heat in the body. The initial cooling effect of eating an ice cream is thereby overturned by the digestive process. This process is called thermoregulation, and it is done to maintain an optimal body temperature, thus involving a balance between producing and losing heat.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 2.5 bn-yr-old bacteria fossils uncovered that predate oxygen
article: Geologists have found 2.52 billion-year-old fossils of sulphur-oxidising bacteria in South Africa, the oldest reported till date, predating the formation of oxygen. Much larger than most modern bacteria, the discovered ancient bacteria fossils were found similar to single-celled organisms that live in deep-ocean sulphur-rich environments, where there are negligible traces of oxygen even today.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists use nuclear waste to make 'diamond batteries'
article: UK researchers have devised a way to convert nuclear waste into 'diamond batteries'. Taking used graphite rods from nuclear reactors, the researchers extracted the radioactive carbon-14 from the rods and concealed it inside artificial diamonds. These diamonds were shown to generate a small current when placed near a radioactive source. They could be used as low-power, long-life energy sources.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: We eat too much and move too little: Stephen Hawking
article: In a video advertisement addressing the seriousness of obesity and physical inactivity, British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking said "Today too many people die from complications related to overweight and obesity. We eat too much and move too little." The 74-year-old cosmologist added, "[H]ow being sedentary has been a major health problem is beyond my understanding."

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Great Barrier Reef sees record coral deaths this year
article: Warming ocean waters in 2016 caused the worst coral bleaching ever recorded in Australia's Great Barrier Reef, according to a recent study. The reef's worst-hit northern section witnessed around 67% coral death, the study added. Coral bleaching happens when water temperatures stay up for a sustained period, causing coral to expel colourful algae and assume a white, skeletal appearance.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'One of human's closely related worms can regrow body parts'
article: A Washington-based study has revealed that the acorn worm, one of the closest-related invertebrate species to humans, is capable of regenerating every major body part lost to injury, including the head, nervous system and internal organs. The worm, which inhabits the sand around coral reefs, has a genetic makeup and body plan similar to a class of animals including humans.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Virus evolving into 2 species observed in laboratory
article: Using a virus harmless to humans, US-based biologists have documented the evolution of a virus into two distinct species inside a laboratory flask. This process, known as speciation, was proposed by evolutionist Charles Darwin to explain the branching in the tree of life, where one species splits into two distinct species during evolution.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: ISRO seeks proposals for second Mars Orbiter Mission
article: Indian space agency ISRO is seeking scientific proposals for its second Mars Orbiter Mission to expand its interplanetary research. This comes after the Mars Orbiter Mission, which was India's first mission to Mars, successfully completed its first phase. No specific experiments have been finalised yet but MOM-2 will drastically widen ISRO's space program coverage, an official statement said.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: Chernobyl disaster site enclosed to prevent radiation leaks
article: The Reactor No 4 at Chernobyl, site of the worst nuclear accident ever, has been enclosed by a steel shelter designed to prevent radiation leaks from the site. The shelter costing over €1.5 billion (around ₹10,900 crore) is reportedly the largest land-based movable object constructed. The shelter will be made airtight by 2017, and will reportedly last 100 years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Teenage girls help build Africa's first private satellite
article: A team of 14 teenage girls from Cape Town, South Africa have helped build Africa's first ever private satellite, due for launch in 2017. As part of a high school science boot camp, the girls designed the payloads for the satellite which will orbit over Earth's poles and scan Africa's surface to collect information on agriculture and food security.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: West Antarctic ice shelf 'breaking up from the inside out'
article: In a first, Ohio-based researchers have discovered an ice shelf in West Antarctica breaking up from the the 'inside out'. Using satellite-imaging, they found that a 'deep subsurface rift' which had appeared 30 km into the ice shelf in 2013 had deepened, finally breaking off a 600 square-km iceberg in 2015. This behaviour has been attributed to a warming ocean.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists discover the first Antarctic ground beetle
article: Scientists have discovered fossilised forewings from what has been identified as the first species of ground beetle in Antarctica. The new species, named Ball's Antarctic Tundra Beetle, is also the second Antarctic insect with living descendants. Notably, Antarctica's insect fauna consists of only three flightless species, which is attributed to lack of moisture, vegetation and low temperatures.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: China's giant smog free tower is not effective: Report
article: According to a report by an NGO called China Forum of Environmental Journalists (CFEJ), the giant smog-sucking tower in China's capital city is failing to keep air pollution levels within acceptable limits. Named 'Smog Free Tower', the device has an effective range "very much limited to its immediate surroundings" and is "unstable" at keeping particulate concentration down, the report added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Grass that absorbs toxic pollutants from bombs made
article: US researchers have developed two genetically modified grass species that can absorb and break down toxic compounds widely used in explosives. After genes from RDX-eating bacteria were introduced into the grass, the best-performing strains were found to remove all RDX from a simulated soil within less than two weeks, retaining none of the toxic chemical in their leaves or stems.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What causes the Northern Lights?
article: The astronomical phenomena of Aurora Borealis, commonly known as Northern Lights, is caused when the Sun's energy produces a 'Solar Storm', spreading charged particles across space. The Earth's magnetic field and atmosphere react, 'exciting' these atoms and causing them to light up. The light show can also be observed in southern regions and is called Aurora Australis or Southern Lights.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Dutch kill nearly 2 lakh ducks to contain bird flu outbreak
article: Dutch officials killed 190,000 ducks to avoid an outbreak on a central Netherlands farm where inspectors confirmed the presence of a 'highly infectious' strain of bird flu, local media reported. Tests indicated that the birds were infected by an H5N8 variant of the disease which kills about 30% of infected birds, but is not known to infect humans, reports added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Video game to test laws of quantum physics launched
article: Spain-based Institute of Photonic Sciences is conducting a worldwide quantum physics experiment on Wednesday through a video game. Running in 12 different labs, the project needs contribution from at least 30,000 people to generate random sequences. The experiment aims to test Einstein's idea of 'local realism' which probes the effect of a particle on another remote 'quantum-entangled' particle.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists sequence 'living fossil' plant's genome
article: China-based researchers have sequenced the genome of 'Ginkgo biloba', one of the oldest extant tree species. Ginkgo is considered a "living fossil", which means its form and structure have changed very little in its 270 million years of existence. Given its longevity as a species, the ginkgo genome will foster studies concerning plant defences against insects and pathogens.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Hot springs in Chile could hold clues to life on Mars: Study
article: Arizona-based geoscientists have discovered silica features formed by biological activity in hot spring deposits in Chile's El Tatio. Nearly identical features were found at Mars' Gusev crater by NASA's Spirit rover several years ago. Notably, El Tatio experiences sub-freezing night temperatures and significant ultraviolet rays during the day, conditions similar to those observed on Mars.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What does space travel do to the body?
article: Space travel has numerous consequences on the body including weakening of bones caused by reduced density and the weakening of muscles due to less usage. Without an Earth-like gravity, astronauts could have vision problems resulting in flattening of the back of the eyeball. Space travel could also cause the heart to potentially lose mass because of decreased amounts of blood.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Engineers create three-atom-thick chip prototype
article: Stanford engineers have created the prototype of a chip three atoms thick, and the size of a human thumbnail. The team used a custom manufacturing process called chemical vapour deposition on a single layer of molybdenum disulphide, in which a sheet of molybdenum atoms is sandwiched between two sulphur atom sheets. This could lead to the development of ultra-thin displays.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Startup makes recyclable shoes from plastic bottles
article: San Francisco-based startup 'Rothy's Shoes', founded by Stephen Hawthornthwaite and Roth Martin, recycles plastic bottles to create sustainable shoes. The shoes have a carbon-free rubber sole and are created by a 3D knitting machine, which takes approximately six minutes to make them. Priced at about ₹8,500 (approximately $125), the shoes are anti-microbial, machine washable and recyclable.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Technique 'listens' to signals in bridges to detect damage
article: New York-based researchers have developed a non-invasive approach to 'listen' to relevant signals traveling through mechanical structures like bridges to diagnose damages. They applied 'optimal mutual information interaction', a technique to process data from accelerometers installed at various locations along a bridge to measure disturbance in each part in response to vehicles driving across.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Low-mass star explosion drove solar system formation: Study
article: According to Minnesota-based researchers, formation of the solar system may have been triggered by a low-mass supernova explosion. Examining meteoritic records, the researchers found an abundance of radioactive Beryllium-10, an element that is believed to be formed by a process called 'neutrino spallation' in supernovae. The explosion caused a dust-and-gas cloud to compress into the solar system.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: First ever naturally occuring silicon-carbon bond made
article: In a first, Caltech scientists have pushed living cells into making carbon-silicon bonds, a bonding previously achieved only through artificial means. They showed that a natural enzyme from a bacterium living in hot springs can be engineered to form carbon-silicon bonds inside living E. coli cells. Notably, all known life is based on carbon, an element chemically similar to silicon.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 49 crocodiles found inside 2,500-year-old crocodile mummy
article: A scan of a 2,500-year-old crocodile mummy in a museum in the Netherlands revealed 49 mummified crocodiles trapped inside. On display in the museum since 1828, the three-metre long mummy was found to contain two juvenile and at least 47 hatchlings. It is believed that the reptiles were preserved as an offering to Sobek, the ancient Egyptian crocodile god.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: In pictures: Top picks of the week in wildlife photography
article: British national daily 'The Guardian' has curated the best photos from the natural world of the past week ended on Friday. The gallery includes images of a lion attacking a wildebeest, a lone swan swimming, a squirrel eating a nut, an amphibious African antelope with its newborn and an Indian tiger cub, among others.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists develop 3D atlas of human embryo development
article: Netherlands-based scientists have compiled an interactive 3D atlas describing the development of a human embryo. Created from computer models built by reconstructing images of almost 15,000 embryo tissue stains, the atlas describes 17 different stages of embryonic development within the first two months of pregnancy, showing up to 150 organs and structures. This may help understand birth defects.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Coconut crab claw can create force 90 times its body weight
article: According to a recent Japan-based study, the coconut crab can exert a force nearly 90 times its body weight with its claw. The largest land invertebrate, the coconut crab, which inhabits islands in the Indian and southern Pacific oceans, can use its claws to exert up to 336.5 kg of force, which is comparable to adult lions' bite force.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Antarctic sea ice 'barely changed' in past 100 years: Study
article: The sea ice around Antarctica in the summer has 'barely changed' over the past 100 years, according to a study by London-based climate scientists. The study claimed that Antarctic sea ice has been transitioning between decades of high and low ice cover, rather than a steady downward trend. In contrast, Arctic sea ice has declined to hit all-time lows.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ice sheet larger than UK lies beneath Mars' surface: Study
article: Using ground-penetrating radar soundings from NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter spacecraft, scientists have discovered an ice sheet larger than the UK hidden beneath the planet's Utopia Planitia basin. Estimated at up to 170 metres thick and 50% pure, the ice sheet is believed to have resulted from a Martian ice age, buried before it could melt or evaporate into space.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New technique turns sugarcane waste into useful product
article: Indian researchers have devised a method to synthesise fluorescent carbon nanoparticles from sugarcane pulp. These carbon 'quantum dots', tiny enough for 110 billion to fit on a pinhead, are non-toxic and can be used as biosensors to image the human body from the inside or deliver drugs to specific body parts. Further, this can also reduce agricultural waste from sugarcane.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists develop artificial human lung to aid treatments
article: Czech scientists have developed a 3D printed model of a functioning human lung to simulate problems like asthma and other chronic diseases and their treatments. According to the scientists, the model can help devise more precise treatment methods tailored to individual patients. It can also be used as a reference model for developing inhaled drugs, the scientists added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Skin patch with instant sweat monitor app developed
article: US-based scientists have developed a flexible device that sticks to the skin and measures sweat levels to show how the wearer's body is responding to exercise. The low-cost device can analyse sweat for statistics such as lactate, pH or glucose levels and let the user know in real time if they should stop or change their activity.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New drug claims to limit, repair brain damage from strokes
article: UK-based researchers have discovered a drug that can potentially reduce the number of brain cells destroyed by stroke as well as help in repairing the damage done. The anti-inflammatory drug, interleukin-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1Ra), was found to promote neuron regeneration in mice with stroke. The drug is already licensed for use in humans for some conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Colour-changing graphene bubbles used to create 'pixels'
article: Dutch researchers have used graphene bubbles, that change colour as they expand and contract, to create 'mechanical pixels'. Single-atom-thick sheets of graphene were stretched over tiny cavities in silicon oxide panels, and were found to change colour with changes in cavity pressure. This may help develop more flexible, durable, and energy efficient displays than current LED technology.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What is the role of a bone marrow?
article: A video discusses how bone marrow, a spongy substance found in bones, manufactures bone marrow stem cells, which produce blood cells including red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets. The video explains how in case of diseases that impact these cells, a bone marrow transplant is needed to restart healthy cell production. It also explains different kinds of transplants.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Arctic ice melt may trigger uncontrollable global warming
article: Scientists have warned that rapid melting of Arctic ice can trigger 19 'climate tipping points' that may cause 'uncontrollable' climate change at the global level. Climate tipping points occur when a natural system, such as the polar ice cap, undergoes sudden change that has an irreversible effect on surrounding ecosystems.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists crowdfunding to help save endangered parrot
article: Researchers from the Difficult Birds Research Group at the Australian National University have launched an emergency crowdfunding campaign to help save the endangered orange-bellied parrot native to Australia. Only 3 female and 11 male specimens are currently surviving in nature, according to a 2016 estimate. The money raised will reportedly be used to help the birds breed in the wild.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Total circular rainbow spotted over Portsmouth harbour
article: A rare total circular rainbow that appeared over the coastal city of Portsmouth in the UK, has been caught on camera. These 'full' rainbows are visible only when water droplets are present in the air below viewing level, and therefore are usually only seen by pilots. This particular rainbow was spotted from atop Portsmouth's 100-metre Emirates Spinnaker Tower.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Zika mosquitoes quickly invade, adapt to new climate: Study
article: The Zika-bearing mosquito 'Aedes aegypti' is not only spreading rapidly but has shown ability to adapt quickly to different locales, climates and human activities, according to a Yale University ecology professor. Reportedly, the mosquito survives colder winters in Washington DC by entering sewers, while droughts in California drives it to swimming pools.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists identify 1,500 new virus species
article: An international team of scientists have identified nearly 1,500 new species of virus infecting more than 200 species of invertebrate animals dwelling on water and land. The viruses are estimated to have been existing for billions of years, exchanging genetic material to create new virus species. However, most of them pose little risk of human infection, the scientists added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Artificial gravity' device made to aid astronauts in space
article: US-based researchers have created an 'artificial gravity' exercise device to help astronauts on long-distance space missions fight health problems associated with weightlessness. The vacuum cleaner-like device seals around a person's waist, causing an apparent 'weight' on the lower body through a strong suction force. It could help preserve astronauts' muscular strength during Mars missions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Post-diet weight gain driven by gut bacteria 'memory': Study
article: According to an Israel-based study, regaining weight after a diet could be caused by gut bacteria retaining a 'memory' of the person's obesity. The study on mice revealed that obesity causes long-term changes in bacteria in the digestive tract, contradicting the previous belief that post-diet weight gains are caused by a return to bad eating habits.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Belgium to set up its own space agency in 2017
article: Belgium's Science Minister announced that the country will establish its own space agency in 2017. The Interfederal Space Agency of Belgium will help local industry retain the current 5% share in European Union's €7 billion-a-year space industry, she added. Belgium's local sector has about 60 firms, including the 96-year-old SABCA, which helped in Europe's Ariane rocket launch vehicle program.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New 3D structure shows optimal way to divide space
article: Belgian researchers have developed a new algorithm to divide 3D space into smaller substructures such that the total surface area of the substructures is minimal. Their algorithm divides space into 24 polyhedra, some with 12 plane faces and the rest with 16. This type of optimal space-partitioning could have practical medical applications, such as for designing lightweight artificial bone tissue.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Depression in young people linked to stomach disorders
article: According to a Swiss-funded research, depression in young people is often followed by arthritis and diseases of the digestive system. The study also found that skin diseases are common after anxiety disorders. The researchers added that certain physical diseases tend to occur more frequently in young people who have previously suffered from certain mental disorders, and vice versa.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rising social status can strengthen immune system: Study
article: A Duke University study on monkeys has revealed that a rise in social status correlates to a strengthened immune system. Studying rhesus macaque monkeys, known for their hierarchical social orders, the researchers showed that immune cells in low-ranking monkeys were less effective at fighting a bacterial infection. The same monkeys showed improved immune responses when their social rank increased.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Predatory bacteria can help eliminate superbugs: Study
article: Bacteria that feed on other kinds of bacteria can be used as 'living antibiotics' to help eliminate disease-resistant superbugs, according to UK researchers. Their lab test revealed doses of 'Bdellovibrio' bacteria reduced populations of food-poisoning 'superbug' bacterium up to 4,000 times. Another test reported 'Bdellovibrio' increased survival of superbug-infected fish larvae around 2.4 times.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Robot inspectors' introduced in Large Hadron Collider
article: The European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN) has introduced a robotic inspector to ensure fail-safe operations at the Large Hadron Collider, world's largest and most powerful particle collider. The Train Inspection Monorail is a vehicle built to transport instruments along suspended tracks. It can help monitor figures like oxygen level and temperature in real time.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientist seeks to analyse "sounds from deep space"
article: British physicist Martin Archer seeks to analyse the ultra-low frequencies coming from outer space, in his upcoming 'Space Sound Effects' project. It features compressed audio clips of 'cosmic noise' recorded by NASA in the solar system, modified for human audibility. Archer has invited public help to study these sounds, which he says can help predict potential cosmic threats.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Light travelled faster than gravity in early universe: Study
article: Two physicists have offered a hypothesis stating that light might have travelled faster than gravity in the early days of the universe. This violates Einstein's theory of general relativity, which states that light and gravity travel at the same rate. If proven, this could bridge the gap between the universe's apparently differing nature at the quantum and visible scales.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Tell consumers homeopathy does not work: US govt
article: The US Federal Trade Commission has demanded that homeopathic medicine producers must mention on the label that 'there is no scientific evidence that their product works'. "Homeopathic product claims are not based on modern scientific methods and are not accepted by modern medical experts," it said. It added that homeopathy runs against basic principles of chemistry, biology, and physics.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: India to become an Associate Member of CERN
article: India will soon become an Associate Member of the European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN), the world's largest nuclear and particle physics laboratory. CERN's Director General said that India's membership will open opportunities for Indian industries to participate directly in CERN projects. As a member nation, CERN requires India to make an annual contribution of approx ₹77 crore.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Paint that lets surfaces convert heat into electricity made
article: South Korea-based researchers have developed a thermoelectric paint, which captures heat from the painted surface and converts it into electricity. Made of thermoelectric bismuth telluride particles, the paint contains materials that enable it to coalesce upon heating, increasing its energy conversion efficiency. This can be applied to recover waste heat from buildings and vehicles.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA demonstrates fuel-free space propulsion system
article: NASA scientists have formally published their experimental evidence for a propulsion system that could power a spacecraft through vacuum without using any fuel or propellant. The 'electromagnetic drive' (EM drive) converts electricity into thrust by bouncing around microwave photons in a closed conical cavity. Theoretically, such lightweight engines could send a spacecraft to Mars in just 70 days.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA launches ₹20 lakh 'Space Poop Challenge'
article: US space agency NASA has launched a ₹20.6 lakh ($30,000) 'Space Poop Challenge' to develop a system that collects and routes human waste away from the body for up to six days, without using hands. The systems should address faecal, urinal and menstrual waste management in a space suit environment while protecting the safety and health of crew members.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Thunderstorm asthma' kills 4 people in Australia
article: Four people were killed and over 2,000 others experienced breathing difficulties after a rare outbreak of 'Thunderstorm asthma' hit Australia on Monday. Thunderstorm asthma occurs when a storm hits during a period of unusually high rye grass pollen. During thunderstorms, rye grass absorbs water from atmosphere, breaks into thousand pieces and goes straight to the lungs, triggering asthma attacks.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 1st Moon mission coder receives US' highest civilian award
article: Margaret Hamilton, the lead software engineer of the world's first successful manned lunar mission, Apollo 11, has been awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, US' highest civilian award. Hamilton headed the MIT department tasked with developing the guidance and navigation system software for the NASA project. Notably, Hamilton is often credited with coining the term 'software engineering'.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Water exists 400-600km into mantle, far deeper than believed
article: Water exists far deeper in the Earth than scientists previously believed, according to international researchers. Their study estimates that water is stored and transported through a high-pressure state of the mineral brucite, roughly 400 to 600 km into the mantle. Further studies will aim to estimate the amount of deep Earth water, which is crucial for geological activity.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Mars lander crashed at 540km/h after altitude misjudgement
article: A computer glitch on Europe's Schiaparelli Mars lander miscalculated the spacecraft's altitude, causing it to crash into the red planet's surface at a speed of 540 kmph on October 19, according to the European Space Agency (ESA). The computer had judged that the lander had reached the Martian surface when it was actually 3.7 km above the surface, ESA added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Only half of a chromosome is DNA: Study
article: DNA comprises only half the material inside chromosomes, the threadlike structures found in a living cell's nucleus that carry genetic information, according to a Scotland-based study. Around 47% of the chromosome's structure consists of a 'sheath' encasing the genetic material. Researchers suggest the sheath serves to keep chromosomes isolated to prevent 'errors' during the cell division process.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New type of seaweed nearly eliminates methane from cow burps
article: A Canadian agricultural scientist, assisted by a local farmer, has discovered a seaweed that nearly eliminates methane from cow burps and farts. Working to improve the farmer's initial seaweed 'mix' that reduced methane by around 20%, he eventually discovered the red seaweed species 'Asparagopsis taxiformis'. Notably, ruminant animals like cows amount to around 20% global greenhouse emissions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: In Pictures: Book featuring aerial Earth images by Tim Peake
article: British astronaut Tim Peake recently published 'Hello, is this planet Earth?', a book documenting his six-month stint aboard the International Space Station. It contains over 150 photographs of locations around the globe, clicked from a height of 400 km. Th images include snapshots of London and Dubai at night, auroras over UK and Canada, and pyramids in Egypt's El Giza.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Hyderabad institute makes ₹35 origami-inspired eye test
article: An eye care institute in Hyderabad has developed the 'Folding Phoropter', a low-cost eye test inspired by the Japanese folding tradition of origami. The device, which reportedly costs under ₹35, lets patients check their own vision for refractive errors. Notably, unchecked refractive errors are the primary cause of vision impairment in the developing world.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria found in polluted city air
article: Polluted city air contains traces of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, according to a recent study by Sweden-based researchers. The study showed a high level of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) in samples taken from the Chinese capital Beijing, known for its severe air pollution. Scientists have also warned that city smog may be spreading genetic material that makes viruses untreatable.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: SpaceX wins NASA contract for first survey of Earth’s water
article: Elon Musk-led aerospace manufacturer SpaceX has been selected by NASA to launch satellites aimed at surveying all of Earth's surface water for the first time ever. The satellite will survey at least 90% of the Earth's surface waters at least twice every 21 days. Previously, Musk said that profits from NASA contracts will help fund the company's Mars colonisation plans.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists develop technique that can help treat phobias
article: An international team of neuroscientists claim to have found a way to 'recondition' the human brain to overcome specific phobias. Their approach combined artificial intelligence (AI) and brain scanning technology in a technique called "Decoded Neurofeedback". If proven, the technique could lead to drug-free ways of treating patients with phobias or post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Extremely faint galaxy found orbiting Milky Way
article: Japan-based astronomers have announced the discovery of an extremely faint dwarf galaxy orbiting the Milky Way. Named Virgo I, the satellite is located in the direction of the Virgo constellation. Its discovery suggests the presence of a large number of yet-undetected dwarf satellites around the Milky Way and could hold clues to galaxy formation via assembly of dark matter.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA spacecraft to begin closest approach to Saturn's rings
article: NASA's Cassini spacecraft will soon begin a series of 'ring-grazing' orbits, during which it will make its closest approach to Saturn's rings since its 2004 arrival, the space agency said. Between November 30 and April 22, Cassini will make 20 orbits through the unexplored region at the main rings' outer edge, attempting to sample ring particles and trace gas molecules.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: NASA orbiter finds "huge" underground ice deposits on Mars
article: The data from NASA’s Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter has helped scientists discover a large deposit of ice beneath a region of cracked and pitted plains on Mars. The deposit, which is composed of 50% to 85% water ice mixed with dust and larger rocky particles, ranges in thickness from about 260 feet to about 560 feet.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ants behave as miniature farmers in Fiji: Study
article: An ant species found in the Pacific islands of Fiji behaves like miniature farmers, sowing and fertilising seeds of at least six types of a plant, a Munich-based study has shown. The ant, called 'Philidris nagasau', plants the seeds in tree-cracks, and defecates in them to help the seedlings grow and form hollow chambers, which offer housing to ant colonies.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Team manages to pause mouse embryos' development for a month
article: A team of US-based scientists has managed to keep mouse embryos in 'suspended animation' in a laboratory for a month. The process completely paused the development of the embryos, and also showed that they developed normally after their growth was unpaused. They used a drug that inhibited the activities of a protein called mTOR, which regulates different cellular processes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: EU offers tech expertise to India to combat air pollution
article: The European Union (EU) has offered its best technical expertise to India to combat air pollution problems, which have affected the country's several cities including Delhi, reports said. The initiative will involve top European companies that will offer clean air solutions to reduce pollution. Notably, four Indian cities featured in the world's ten most polluted cities listed by the WHO.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: MIT builds low-cost artificial muscle from nylon fibre
article: MIT researchers have developed a low-cost system to build artificial muscle from nylon fibre. Their approach relied on shaping and heating the synthetic fibres in a way that mimics the 'bending' motions of natural muscle tissue. Applications of this system could enable manufacturing universal-size clothing that adjusts to the contours of an individual's body.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ex-ISRO chief Prof MGK Menon dies aged 88
article: Acclaimed physicist and ex-Chairman of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), Prof MGK Menon passed away on Tuesday, aged 88 years. A recipient of the Padma Vibhushan, Menon had also served as Director of the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research at the age of 35. His scientific contributions are in the fields of particle physics and cosmic rays.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Astronauts celebrate Thanksgiving in space
article: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station (ISS) including Americans Peggy Whitson and Shane Kimbrough spent Thanksgiving in space. The menu included specially packaged dishes like 'turkey from a pouch', 'candied yams', and 'mashed potatoes'. As is tradition, the crew members will float around the table and discuss what they're thankful for this year, said Kimbrough in an earlier video.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Video explains the mass-energy equivalence equation
article: British national daily 'The Guardian' has released a two-minute video in which UK-based space scientist Maggie Aderin-Pocock discusses Albert Einstein's famous mass-energy equivalence equation. The equation, derived from Einstein's theory of special relativity, quantifies energy as mass multiplied by the square of the speed of light, dictating that energy and mass are interconvertible.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: North Pole is 20ºC hotter than normal
article: The temperature at the North Pole currently during polar night, where the night lasts for more than 24 hours, have reportedly reached 20ºC above average. "In reviewing records back to 1958, we could not find a more intense anomaly," researchers wrote. This is causing the Arctic's ice cover for the season to run at the lowest level since record-keeping began.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: China launches world's longest quantum communication line
article: China launched a 712-km quantum communication line on Sunday, stated to be the world's longest secure telecommunications network. Linking Hefei to Shanghai, the line is equipped with ultra-high security systems and is claimed to be hack-proof. It is part of a 2,000-km Beijing-Shanghai communication line, which will be connected to China's quantum satellite for space-to-Earth communication network.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 1st head transplant patients may use VR for preparation
article: Italian neurosurgeon Sergio Canavero, who claims to perform world's first human head transplant next year, has revealed he will use virtual reality to help patients prepare for their life with a new body. The process, which involves cutting patient's neck and spinal cord, and then attaching the head to the donor body, will be first operated on Russia's Valery Spiridonov.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Photoreceptor 50 times more efficient than human eye found
article: An international team of researchers has discovered a new type of photoreceptor (a molecule that allows eyes to receive light), claimed to be about 50 times more efficient in capturing light as compared to human eye photoreceptors. Identified as 'LITE-1', the photoreceptor was found in a type of roundworms and is only the third to be found in animals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: In Pictures: Top picks of the week in wildlife photography
article: British national daily newspaper 'The Guardian' has curated the best wildlife pictures from the natural world of the past week, ended on Friday.
