The picked images include a black-crowned night-heron catching a fish in Taiwan, a group of baboons crossing a river in South Africa and a closeup of a golden pheasant in China, among others.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Dinosaur-killing crater study shows how life may have begun
article: An international team of researchers have analysed rock samples from Chicxulub crater created by the dinosaur-killing asteroid, and have revealed that large asteroid impacts might have produced habitats for early life. Scientists found that asteroid impacts deformed rocks in such a way that it made them more porous and less dense, providing niches for simple organisms to take hold.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New 'super-earth' discovered 33 light-years away
article: Spain-based researchers have discovered a new 'super-earth' planet in orbit around a star around 33 light-years away. The planet, GJ 536 b, has an estimated mass around 5.4 times that of Earth, and orbits its parent 'red dwarf' star once every 8.7 days. A 'super-earth' planet is defined as one with mass between 1 and 15 Earth masses.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists trace back most powerful Fast Radio Burst ever
article: Scientists have traced the origin of the brightest Fast Radio Burst (high-energy flashy radio waves) ever received by Earth from space, coming from at least a billion light years away. By studying the signal's dispersion and distortion, scientists found that it travelled for at least a billion years to reach Earth and lasted for just a fraction of a second.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New process absorbs CO2 25% more efficiently than plants
article: Germany-based researchers have reengineered the mechanism used by plants to transform carbon dioxide (CO2) into useful products, to produce a 25% more efficient CO2-fixation process. Known as 'CETCH' cycle, the new process is up to three times faster at filtering out CO2 from the atmosphere, and is based on a molecular tool composed of 17 enzymes from 9 different organisms.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists explain the source of methane in oceans
article: US-based scientists have uncovered the mechanism behind 'marine methane paradox', which involves searching the origin of methane in ocean's surface waters, given that most of the methane-producing microbes cannot survive in oxygen-rich waters. Scientists revealed the paradox could be explained by bacterial degradation of dissolved organic matter in the upper ocean, creating methane as a byproduct.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA launches most advanced weather satellite into space
article: NASA successfully launched GOES-R, claimed to be the world's most advanced weather satellite, on Saturday from Florida. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration teamed up with NASA to rocket the spacecraft, which is the first in a series of four high-tech satellites initiative, valued at $11 billion. GOES-R is missioned to provide faster and more accurate weather forecasts for the US.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Firm develops fragrances that successfully block malodours
article: Firmenich in association with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has developed fragrances that successfully block malodours. The ingredients in the fragrances inhibit the activation of the olfactory receptors sensitive to malodours, which restricts the brain from perceiving the malodours. The fragrances are expected to encourage people to use toilets rather going to the bathroom outdoors.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: In pictures: Indonesian orangutans in rehabilitation
article: Indonesian orangutans recently appeared on the IUCN's critically endangered list, mainly due to the clearing of rainforest habitats for palm oil plantations. The pictures in the image gallery show how the orphaned, injured and captive orangutans are cared for and nursed back to health at a rehabilitation centre in Sumatra's Kuta Mbelin, before their release to their natural habitat.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Nat Geo magazine cover features Mangalyaan's Mars photo
article: An image of the planet Mars taken by ISRO's Mars-orbiting spacecraft Mangalyaan has found a place on the cover of the November edition of the National Geographic magazine. The spacecraft's launch had completed three years on November 5. The mission, which had cost ₹450 crore, was made to last six months but has now survived for three years.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Meteorite recovered from farm in Australia
article: Scientists have recovered a 1.15-kg meteorite from a farm several hundred kilometres north-east of Perth, Australia. The squashed brick-shaped meteorite, which fell near the town of Morawa around 8 pm on October 31, reportedly did not leave a visible impact on the ground where it was found. Notably, under federal government law, the meteorite belongs to the state.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Company creates system to help pilot's brain control a plane
article: USA's Honeywell Aerospace has modified a plane which enables it to be operated with a neuro-transmitting elastic cap, worn over the head by the pilot. The pilot wears the cap, which houses 32 electrodes, and manoeuvres the plane by focusing on the direction symbols on a screen. The brain's electrical activity is transmitted to the plane's control system.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Archaeologists find evidence of first potato farming
article: University of California archaeologists have found a new archaeological evidence supporting the belief that potatoes were first cultivated in South America's Peru. Scientists found microremains of cultivated potatoes on grinding tools from southern Peru, dating back to 3400 BC. These tools were used for breaking potatoes' skin, and tiny starch grains would get embedded inside them in the process.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: '6,000-yr-old amulet depicts technology still used by NASA'
article: Scientists have discovered a 6,000-year-old amulet, which they found was made through a technique called lost-wax casting, a process NASA uses to produce equipment which has even flown to Mars and the International Space Station. The age-old process of metal casting involves pouring molten metal into a mould that has been created by means of a wax model.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make plants produce 15% more food from sunlight
article: International researchers have genetically modified plants to increase the amount of sunlight which energy crop plants channel into food production, thereby increasing the yield by as much as 15%. Scientists have inserted extra gene copies to overcome the "inefficiencies in crops" by speeding the switch between absorption and release of heat by plants during the process of photosynthesis.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop technique which makes cameras 'faster'
article: Rice University researchers have developed a new technique which captures molecular images of chemical processes without needing a faster camera. Known as Super Temporal Resolution Microscopy (STReM), the enhancement uses a rotating phase mask to encode fast dynamics in each camera frame, allowing researchers to view and gather information at a frame rate 20 times faster than normal lab cameras.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Coral reefs may survive global warming: Study
article: A Panama-based study has unveiled that a few species of Orbicella coral had managed to survive the mass extinctions resulting from extreme cold conditions, about two million years ago. Scientists have suggested that the high genetic diversity of the corals, which helped them bear the cold, might also help them cope with the rising temperatures due to global warming.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Climate change may prevent volcanoes from cooling Earth'
article: Canada-based scientists have revealed climate change may impede the cooling effect of volcanoes as fewer eruptions will be able to reflect sunlight. Lower atmospheric layers expand with rising temperatures, making it harder for sulphur gases spewed by volcanoes to reach stratosphere. This would decrease reactions of sulphur gases with water to form aerosols, which reflect sunlight and cool Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Men identify Transformer faces better than women
article: US-based scientists have found that men are better at identifying different faces of Transformer toys compared to women, unlike prior scientific studies which concluded that either women are better at recognising faces or there is no gender difference. Scientists found women are better at recognising Barbie faces, supporting the hypothesis that experience plays a major role in facial recognition.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Ducklings maintain 2 memory banks of visual information'
article: A recent research by the University of Oxford has shown that newly hatched ducklings maintain two separate memory banks of visual information. Scientists found that the information related to objects seen with a single eye was processed only to one of the two hemispheres of the brain, unlike the case in most mammals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Great valley’ found on Mercury indicates it is shrinking
article: Scientists have recently discovered a "great valley" in Mercury's southern hemisphere, providing further evidence to the hypothesis that the planet is shrinking. Using images from NASA's  Messenger spacecraft, scientists have developed a topographic map suggesting the valley is the result of global contraction of a shrinking one-plate planet and is not caused by the pulling of lithospheric plates.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: More than 102 million trees dead due to California drought
article: With the death of 36 million trees since May, the death toll due to drought conditions in California has risen to over 102 million. The US state continues to face a severe drought since five years, marked by low mountain snowpack and warm temperature. The drought-stricken forests have increased the risk of catastrophic wildfires in the US state.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Hepatitis C tricks liver cells to destroy immune defenses'
article: A recent US-based research has uncovered that Hepatitis C virus destroys liver cell antiviral defenses by blunting the effect of important immune proteins called interferons. Scientists found that the virus protects itself by blocking signals that drive elements of liver cells' immune defenses and also inhibit production of receptors crucial for the cell's interferon-driven antiviral response.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: 14-year-old girl who died of cancer wins right to be frozen
article: A terminally ill 14-year-old girl who wanted her body frozen in the hope that she can be brought back to life at a later time, was granted her wish by a UK court, shortly before her death. "I think being cryo‐preserved gives me a chance to be cured and woken up, even in hundreds of years’ time," she had said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists spot 'roundest' object ever observed in nature
article: Germany-based researchers have discovered a star 5,000 light-years from Earth, described as the 'roundest' object ever observed in nature. Being twice as big as Sun with a mean diameter of 3 million km, the star's equatorial diameter is only 6 km more than its polar diameter. Notably, all celestial objects are 'slightly flattened' due to the centrifugal force of rotation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists edit human genes for the first time ever
article: China-based researchers have performed the world's first human gene-editing procedure where one or more parts of a specific gene are either inserted, removed or replaced. The technique was performed to track cancerous tumours in a lung cancer patient, who will be monitored for at least six months. If successful, the technology would help in developing treatments for several genetic diseases.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Injecting young human blood found to reverse ageing in mice
article: Injecting blood from young people into old mice reverses signs of ageing, according to a recent study by California-based anti-ageing company Alkahest. Blood plasma from 18-year-old humans was injected twice weekly into 12-month-old mice, that are equivalent to 50-year-old humans. The ageing mice were found to perform better on memory tests and also showed increased physical activity.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Woman gives birth to twins conceived 10 days apart
article: An Australian woman who was struggling to conceive fell pregnant twice in ten days due to a rare condition. Kate Hill conceived twins at different times even though she had unprotected sex once during the period, due to 'superfetation,' which allows women to conceive for the second time when pregnant.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Humans won't survive another 1,000 years on Earth: Hawking
article: While delivering a lecture on the origins of humans, British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking said, "I don't think we will survive another 1,000 years without escaping beyond our fragile planet." Hawking, who received a standing ovation at the Oxford Union debating society, had previously said, "I think the human race has no future if it doesn't go to space."

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New Zealand earthquake lifted seabed by 2 metres
article: The 7.8-magnitude earthquake that hit New Zealand after midnight on Sunday lifted up the seabed by around two metres, pushing it above the water's surface. Aerial photos show large purple patches of uplifted earth near the coastal town of Kaikoura in South Island. Several scientists said they have never seen an earthquake cause the New Zealand seabed to lift.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Online calculator made to predict chances of IVF baby
article: Scotland-based researchers have created an online tool to help couples find out their chances of having a baby over multiple cycles of In-Vitro Fertilisation (IVF) treatment. Called Outcome Prediction In Subfertility, the tool is based on data from around 113,000 women who have gone through IVF and lets couples estimate their chances both before and after their first IVF treatment.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Antibody that neutralises 98% HIV strains identified
article: US-based researchers have identified an antibody from an HIV-infected individual that neutralised 98% of all human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) strains tested. The antibody, N6, was found to bind to the virus in a way that prevents it from developing resistance or attaching on to immune cells. The antibody could be administered to HIV patients by under-the-skin injection, researchers added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Near-complete dodo skeleton expected to fetch ₹4.2 crore
article: An extremely rare, 95% complete skeleton of a dodo is anticipated to fetch around ₹4.2 crore (£500,000) when it goes on auction next week. The extinct bird's skeleton was put together over a period of 20 years by a private collector. Discovered by Dutch sailors in 1598, the flightless bird lived only on Mauritius and became extinct 70 years later.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 80,000 reindeer starve to death due to climate change
article: Over 80,000 reindeer in Arctic Russia have starved to death over the past decade owing to human-induced climate change, Finland-based researchers said. These were mainly in 2006 and 2013. In the two years, November's unusually warm temperatures led to heavy rains, turning the soft snow cover into hard ice and cutting off reindeer's food supply of lichen and other vegetation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Hidden underground ocean discovered on Pluto
article: Scientists have confirmed that Pluto harbours a hidden ocean beneath its central plain. Pluto's ocean, likely to be 'slushy' with ice, lies 150 to 200 km beneath the dwarf planet's icy surface, is about 100 km deep and contains as much water as all of Earth's seas. The discovery was made by analysing data collected by NASA's New Horizons mission.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists map Yellowstone volcano to find its fuel source
article: International researchers have started mapping the Yellowstone Supervolcano in the US, to provide insight into the vast subterranean systems that fuel its explosive volcanism. They are carrying out electromagnetic surveys to reveal the hydrothermal systems operating below one of the world's most dangerous active volcanoes, estimated to kill around 90,000 people almost instantly upon eruption.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Transplanted pig's heart survives in monkey for 51 days
article: South Korean scientists have successfully transplanted a pig's heart to a monkey, which has been reported to survive at least 51 days, surpassing the previous record of 43 days. The pig's heart was genetically modified to minimise risks of the monkey's immune system attacking the organ. Currently, transplant patients have to take immune-suppressing drugs to prevent transplant rejection.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA astronaut set to become oldest woman in space
article: NASA astronaut Peggy Whitson, at an age of 56 years, will become the oldest woman in space history after she takes off for the International Space Station (ISS) on Thursday. Notably, Whitson, who holds the record for most time spent in space by a woman, is also the first woman to become ISS commander. This will be Whitson's third spaceflight.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Mosquitoes can spread Zika, Chikungunya simultaneously'
article: According to Colorado-based researchers, mosquitoes can carry Zika and chikungunya viruses simultaneously and can secrete enough in their saliva to potentially infect humans with both in a single bite. A controlled experiment was conducted by feeding mosquitoes with blood containing Zika, chikungunya and dengue viruses, after which tests revealed that the insects had picked up the first two.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US scientists develop new way to image solar cells in 3D
article: US-based researchers have developed a new technique to map thin-film solar cells in 3D as they absorb photons. The imaging method uses a highly focused laser beam of infrared photons, which penetrates inside the photovoltaic material, to map optoelectronic dynamics both on and below surface. This would increase solar cell efficiency and help in unveiling more thin-film solar cell materials.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Ultra-fast electrons found outside Earth's magnetic field
article: NASA scientists have discovered ultra-fast electrons whizzing outside Earth's magnetic field, with speeds ranging close to that of light. The Sun has been known to fling supersonic electrons out into space, but they are deflected by Earth's magnetic field. Using data from NASA's THEMIS probe, scientists showed the electrons sprang further from those previously observed in Earth's foreshock region.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Video game is world's largest dementia experiment
article: Sea Hero Quest, a mobile-based video game that tests the users' spatial navigation skills, has become the largest dementia study in history. After having been played by over 2.4 million users, the game has generated 9,400 years' worth of lab-based research data since its launch in May. The gathered data will help scientists understand the disease's progress with age.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Dutch firm unveils concept space suit for Mars explorers
article: Netherlands-based firm Mars One, which aims to establish a permanent human settlement on the Red Planet by 2026, has unveiled its first concept of a space suit for humans. The pressurised suit will include a see-through bubble and an impact-resistant helmet to protect Mars explorers "under the most difficult conditions" and will be equipped for warding off life-threatening radiation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Owl-inspired wing design reduces wind turbine noise
article: A team of researchers has designed a 3D printed wing attachment inspired by owl's flight, which is claimed to reduce wind turbine noise by as much as 10 decibels. Scientists studying owl-flight acoustics have used the downy canopy of owl feathers to improve the man-made design of wind turbines by suppressing the noise-producing surface pressure, without impacting aerodynamics.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Pigs are optimistic and pessimistic just like humans: Study
article: A UK-based study has found some pigs are optimistic and go-getting while others are pessimists and moody, just like humans. The different personalities were revealed through an experiment which offered sugar-coated chocolates or 'disappointing' coffee beans to the animals. Pigs were found to be more pessimistic in a less enriched environment and more optimistic in a better-enriched environment.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Scientists create wearable sensor that can monitor heartbeat
article: Scientists have created a small stick-on wearable sensor that can monitor a user's heartbeat. The miniature stethoscope can pick up the motion of sound waves as they travel through the flesh and fluids of the body. The wearable can also measure throat vibrations when a person is talking and can be used as a possible tool for speech therapy.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How do X-rays see through the skin?
article: A video details German physicist Wilhelm Rontgen's discovery of X-rays and how the rays are used for medical applications. The X-rays, when produced from different angles, transfers its energy to form images of the internal human body parts. The video further explains how bones and soft tissues react to the X-rays.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What is blood pressure?
article: A video explains how the movement of blood exerts a force on the muscular walls of the blood vessels. The force, called blood pressure, rises and falls with the phases of the heartbeat. Several factors can increase the force on the walls of the pipes, including the properties of the fluid or the pipes' thickness.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New DNA-editing technique restores vision in blind rats
article:
US-based scientists have discovered a new DNA-editing technique which is capable of modifying DNA of even non-dividing cells, and has been used to partially restore vision in blind rats. Known as HITI, the technique can be used to modify DNA in brain, eye, heart and liver   
and could be used to fix 'broken genes' in brain and cure incurable diseases.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Doctors perform brain implant for the first time in history
article: Netherlands-based doctors have performed the first-ever brain implant on a 58-year-old woman paralysed by Lou Gehrig's disease, enabling her to communicate in day-to-day life via a speech computer. The disease-caused nerve degeneration had left her with control only over her eyes. The implant enabled her to control the computer using brain signals, spelling out messages at two letters per minute.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Mankind witnesses biggest 'Supermoon' in 68 years
article: Humans all across the planet on Sunday night witnessed what was the biggest and the brightest 'Supermoon' since January 1948. A 'Supermoon' event occurs when a full moon and the closest approach of the Moon to the Earth on its elliptical orbit coincides. According to NASA, the full moon will not come this close to Earth again until November 2034.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Trillionth of a billionth of a second measured for 1st time
article: German physicists have measured an atomic event with the precision of a zeptosecond– a trillionth of a billionth of a second, the greatest accuracy of time determination ever achieved. A zeptosecond is to a second what a second is to 31.71 trillion years. It also helped measure the entire process of an electron escaping its atom for the first time.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: In Pictures: Biggest 'Supermoon' in 68 years
article: People throughout the world on Sunday night witnessed the biggest and the brightest 'Supermoon' since January 1948, caused by the full moon coinciding with the Moon's closest point of approach to Earth in its orbit. The pictures in the image gallery include shots of the moon taken in New York, Washington DC, Berlin, Chile, Spain, Sydney and Russia, among others.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Pair of moose frozen mid-fight found in Alaskan river
article: An Alaska man has discovered a frozen pair of moose, who appear to have frozen during a battle, with antlers locked together. The male pair is believed to have been stuck in the ice while competing for the attention of a female, the discoverer said. He further added that he will use them as a wall mount in his home.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video explores 'how deep the ocean actually is'
article: A recent YouTube video explores ocean's actual depth and how it compares with the largest things humans have seen or built. According to the video, if all of Earth's land was shaved-off and dumped in the oceans, 3.2-km deep ocean would still be left. The video highlights that only about 5% of the ocean's floor has been accurately mapped.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Measles vaccine has saved 2 crore lives since 2000
article: According to a World Health Organisation report, vaccination against measles has saved an estimated 2.03 crore lives between 2000 and 2015, marking a 79% worldwide decrease in deaths caused by the infectious disease. However, with over 1.3 lakh deaths caused by measles in 2015, the report has also revealed that nearly 400 children still die from the disease every day.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Human intestine-inspired battery can give 5 fold improvement
article: British researchers have created a lithium-sulphur battery prototype with reportedly five times the energy density of standard lithium-ion batteries. It has an electrode coated with zinc oxide material with a structure resembling the finger-like protrusions lining the human intestine. This traps fragments of electrode's active material when they break off, increasing the battery's reusability.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 2016 will possibly be the hottest year on record: UN
article: According to the UN weather body World Meteorological Organisation (WMO), 2016 will possibly turn out to be the hottest year on record, surpassing the record-breaking temperatures of 2015. The WMO has revealed 2016's global temperatures are nearly 1.2°C above pre-industrial levels. Global warming caused by increased greenhouse gas emissions has been held responsible for the temperature increase.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Glowing 'halo' around sun observed in North Russia
article: A glowing circle around the sun owing to a natural phenomenon called the 'halo effect', has been observed in parts of Northern Russia. Also known as winter rainbows, the effect is created by sunlight refracted by atmospheric ice crystals, similar to how water droplets cause rainbows. Different forms of halos range from rings to arcs and spots in the sky.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New energy storage device that can be charged with heat
article: Texas-based researchers have developed a new concept of electrical energy storage, that allows charging using heat energy in addition to the traditional electrical charging method. The device, called a 'thermally chargeable solid-state supercapacitor,' uses temperature differences to induce movement of charged particles. If developed, it could be used to power wearable electronics using body heat.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Dams emit billion tonnes of greenhouse gases per year: Study
article: According to a US-based study, hydroelectric dams emit about a billion tonnes of greenhouse gases every year, contributing to nearly 25% more methane than previously estimated. The rotting vegetation due to dams account for about 1.3% of human-caused global emissions, the study added. Notably, methane contributes almost three-fold more to global warming than carbon dioxide over a 20-year course.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Green, blue flashes seen in NZ sky during earthquake
article: A video showing flashes of green, blue and white light in the sky, claimed to be taken at the peak of the 7.8 magnitude earthquake which struck New Zealand on Sunday, has surfaced online. The 'earthquake lights', reportedly lasted for about five to eight seconds. While such flashes have been reported earlier, there's no scientific consensus on why they occur.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's tallest tropical trees discovered in Borneo
article: Using an airborne laser-tracking system, Stanford University researchers have announced the discovery of fifty of the world's tallest tropical trees in a rainforest on the island of Borneo in Southeast Asia. Each tree has a reported height exceeding 90 metres, with one particular specimen reaching 94.1 metres (309 feet). The trees belong to the 'Shorea' group of species, researchers added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Some people are immune to Alzheimer's symptoms: Study
article: Some people are naturally immune to the symptoms of Alzheimer's even when they have the full-blown disease, a study by US-based Northwestern University has found. Post-mortems of eight people who died aged more than 90, revealed that although all had the toxic brain plaques and tangles characteristics of Alzheimer's, three of them had 'relatively intact' memory-forming brain regions.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Resistance-less super-current sets new distance record
article: Netherlands-based scientists have generated an alternative super-current (electric current which flows without resistance) and have sent it across a record distance of 600 nanometres. Consisting of electrons which spin synchronously, the newly generated superconducting current is capable of powering an electromagnet without energy loss and can be used in fusion reactors and MRI scanners.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: European scientists prepare to find oldest ice on Earth
article: A team of European scientists is set to depart for East Antarctica this month in search of the  oldest ice on the planet. Scientists believe the expedition would help them collect 1.5 million-year-old data about Earth's climate history. This would help in understanding how climate has changed over time as well as assess carbon dioxide's role in dictating climate change.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Cannabis smoking may double 'rare heart condition risk'
article: Smoking cannabis may double the risk of stress cardiomyopathy, a rare condition that temporarily weakens the heart, a US-based research has shown. The condition mimics the symptoms of cardiac arrest. Cannabis users experiencing an episode of stress cardiomyopathy are significantly more likely than non-users to go into cardiac arrest or need correction to abnormal heart rhythms, the study revealed.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Global carbon emissions have not risen in 3 years: Study
article: As per a recent Norway-based study, worldwide carbon emissions have not risen in the past three years, mainly due to declining coal consumption by China and US, the world's top carbon polluters. Carbon emissions of China and US fell 0.7% and 2.6% respectively in 2015, while the figures are projected to drop 0.5% and 1.7% this year, the study suggested.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Researchers use acoustic waves to move fluids at nanoscale
article: In a first, University of California researchers have successfully used acoustic waves to move fluids through small channels at nanoscale levels. By using surface acoustic waves with frequency of 20 megahertz, scientists were able to move fluids and particles through 50-250 nanometre tall slits. This could pave the way for manufacturing small devices that could be used for drug discovery.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Wearable device can reduce fat, treat type 2 diabetes
article: Japan-based scientists have developed a wearable medical device that can help diabetic elderly or overweight people to lose visceral fat and treat type 2 diabetes by improving blood glucose (sugar). The belt-type device helps in restoring the function of HSP72, the main protein of heat shock response, which otherwise has reduced functionality in type 2 diabetes patients.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Vitamin D may increase chance of breast cancer survival
article: According to California-based researchers, higher levels of Vitamin D in the blood may significantly improve survival in one-third of women diagnosed with breast cancer. The link between Vitamin D and breast cancer may be related to the vitamin's role in promoting normal mammary cell development, and inhibiting the reproduction and promoting the death of cancer cells, the study added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Second phase' of liquid water discovered
article: An international team of physicists has demonstrated that liquid water can 'switch' phases, exhibiting a varying set of properties. Examining properties like conductivity, refractive index and surface tension, they found that each property changed at different 'crossover' temperatures between 40°C and 65°C. This could be due to the 'fleeting' weak hydrogen bonds in water's structure, they added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Fruit flies can help understand how body responds to cold'
article: A US-based study has revealed that fruit flies can be used to investigate the genetic and neural bases of detecting cold stimuli and understand how the body responds to harmful stimuli. Scientists discovered that fruit flies have cold-sensing neurons called nociceptors, which when activated, alert them of possible environmental dangers and drive them to execute behavioural responses against cold.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Multi-drug resistant bug spreading globally in CF patients'
article: According to a University of Cambridge study, a majority of Cystic Fibrosis (CF) patients have acquired transmissible forms of a multi-drug resistant mycobacteria infection, which has spread globally. The study found the infection, which was previously thought to have been acquired from the environment, actually spreads from person to person and can cause life-threatening pneumonia in CF patients.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Lightning strikes can be used to predict storms: Study
article: A Washington-based study has shown that information on lightning strikes can be used to forecast storms. According to an author of the study, frequent lightning indicates heat-driven upward motion of air, which points to a storm. The study plans to use NASA's upcoming lightning-monitoring satellite to pinpoint storms over the Americas.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop tissue-engineered model of lung, trachea
article: US-based researchers have developed a tissue-engineered 3D model of lung and trachea, containing the diverse cell types present in the human respiratory tract. Scientists believe the model would aid the understanding of the regenerative process of lungs and help in repairing damaged lungs. It would provide a platform for studying the advanced stages of diseases and help in developing therapies.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Delhi boy grows vegetables without soil
article: Shantanu Singhal, a 17-year-old boy from Delhi, has started UNNAT, a project aimed to initiate soilless agriculture. Singhal has developed a kit that can be used to grow crops such as fenugreek, cabbage and spinach. While a pilot project based on Shantanu's experiment has been initiated by Uttar Pradesh government, Shantanu also spoke at TEDxPasadena in California about UNNAT recently.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Even physicists are 'afraid' of mathematics: Study
article: Physicists avoid highly mathematical work despite being trained in advanced mathematics, new research suggests. Analysing around 2,000 physics journal articles, the study found that articles are less likely to be referenced by other physicists if they have excessive mathematical equations. According to the study's authors, the solution might be clearer communication of highly technical work.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: In Pictures: Top picks of the week in wildlife photography
article: British national daily newspaper The Guardian has curated the best wildlife pictures from the natural world of the past week, ended on Friday. The picked images include a golden eagle in Scotland, a closeup of a red squirrel in Northumberland, an egret hunting for fish in Tokyo and a fox with its head planted in snow in Yellowstone National Park.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Calcium deposits possible cause of premature births: Study
article: American researchers have found abnormal calcium buildup in the foetus' surrounding membrane might be a possible cause of premature births. The calcium deposits reduce the elasticity of the normally elastic amniotic sac (fluid bag inside woman's womb), making it prone to rupture and triggering an early water breaking process. Notably, India tops the global preterm births list, followed by China.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: DNA-matching algorithm to breed endangered animals made
article: Australian researchers have created SWINGER, an algorithm that uses DNA information to match-make endangered animals for captive breeding. The software uses DNA patterns of individuals to figure out family relationships, then designs a breeding group for least related individuals to maintain genetic diversity. The first species being revived is a rare rainbowfish found in Queensland.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Brazilian bat is the fastest flying animal at 160kmph: Study
article: A Brazilian free-tailed bat can achieve speeds of over 160 kmph in horizontal flight, making it the fastest flying animal, according to a new Germany-based study. The feat has been attributed to the mammal's aerodynamic body shape and longer-than-average wings. The previous fastest known level-flying bird is reported to be the common swift, which can reach over 100 kmph.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Researchers collect tears to detect breast cancer in NZ
article: The Breast Cancer Foundation recently collected tears of several women in Auckland, New Zealand, in an attempt to study a new method of breast cancer detection. Under the study, women were shown films evoking tears, which were then collected in a device. The test aimed to improve the accuracy of cancer detection and provide an easier and more cost-effective method.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How can food be grown on Mars?
article: A one-minute video explores the possibility of growing food on Mars by using elements already present on the planet. The video states that while the top layer of soil on Mars can be toxic, the deeper layers of soil could be used to grow food in a special greenhouse. Additionally, synthetic biology could be used to form meat using microbes.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Student developing app for early autism detection
article: A New York-based undergraduate student and her professor are developing an app to detect early signs of the developmental disorder, autism. The app tracks eye movements of a child looking at pictures of social scenes to determine, in less than a minute, if a child is showing signs of autism spectrum disorder. Initial tests reported accuracies of up to 94%.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Common skin bacteria could protect against diseases
article: A Sweden-based researcher has shown that the most common bacteria on human skin could protect the skin from diseases. The bacteria secretes a protein called RoxP that apparently protects the skin from a condition called oxidative stress, in which reactive oxygen-containing chemicals or ultraviolet sun rays damage cells. Oxidative stress is believed to be a contributing factor to skin cancer.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New app explaining benefits of carbon dioxide launched
article: A new app that explains how carbon dioxide (CO2) can be used to make useful products, thereby lowering emissions, was launched at the Conference of Parties (COP22) in Marrakech, Morocco. In the app, users can simulate products using different sources of CO2, and observe how their decisions affect CO2 emissions and the amount of renewable energy required.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Child obesity linked to irregular sleep, skipping breakfast
article: Skipping breakfast and irregular sleep patterns have been identified as the key reasons behind childhood obesity by a recent London-based study. The study also confirmed the well-established increased risk of a child born to an obese mother ending up with excess weight themselves. The study challenges the widely-held view that rising childhood obesity rates are caused solely by overeating.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: First model Mars home goes on display in London
article: A model Mars home went on display in London on Thursday, offering a glimpse of what setting up house on the planet could look like. The domed pod has room for a bed, computer desk and space to grow plants. Reportedly, it is equipped to make breathable oxygen and supply water by sucking in the Martian atmosphere and dehumidifying it.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New smart material enables any surface to repel ice
article: Houston-based researchers have found a smart material that can be applied to any surface to repel ice and which "outperforms all others currently in use". The material, called magnetic slippery surface, which was made by coating one side with a magnetic material and the other with a magnetic fluid, reportedly has a significantly lower freezing threshold than conventional 'icephobic' surfaces.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Video shows 'bubblegum coral' at world's deepest trench
article: A US-funded research expedition to the Marianas region of the Pacific Ocean has produced a new video of marine life, featuring 'bubblegum coral'. Found at a depth of around 522 metres, the bright pink coral was seen hosting an "oasis" of living species, including a worm-like brittle star, strands of sponge, algae and a crab among others.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Dark matter may be found in a "hidden sector" of universe'
article: International physicists have proposed that dark matter is made of particles from one of the many "hidden sectors" theorised to exist outside of the "visible sector" that encompasses the visible universe. Hidden sector dark matter particles exert gravitational forces on visible sector particles through a 'portal', in accordance with M-theory, considered the fundamental theory of particle physics.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: First flu attack can affect lifetime risk: Study
article: A person's chances of contracting a new influenza strain are affected by the first strain they encountered, a US-based study suggests. The first flu strain leaves a permanent "imprint" on the immune system, giving robust protection against similar strains but weaker protection against less closely related varieties of the illness. This could explain patterns in flu pandemics, an expert added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: ISRO conducts moon landing tests amid Chandrayaan-2 plans
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has started conducting Moon landing tests for its Chandrayaan-2 mission at its Karnataka centre, reports said on Friday. Several craters resembling Moon's terrain have been created to test instruments and sensors on the lander of Chandrayaan-2. Chandrayaan-2 is ISRO's second mission to the Moon and will tentatively be launched between 2017-2018.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US launches high-resolution Earth-imaging satellite
article: A commercial high-resolution Earth-imaging satellite known as 'WorldView-4' was launched from California coast and lifted into orbit on Friday. The camera aboard the satellite is capable of taking high-resolution images of objects as small as 30 cm from space. This marked the ninth launch for United Launch Alliance, a joint venture by Lockheed Martin and Boeing.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Black hole jets can influence star formations: Study
article: A recent Greece-based study has suggested that black hole jets can influence the star formation in galaxies by heating and dispersing large amounts of gasses over vast areas. Scientists found that the jets consisting of beams of particles, drive multiple winds in a close by galaxy, which pose hinderances for star formation by increasing thermal and turbulent motions of gasses.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Failed 2003 UK Mars mission might have worked for months
article: According to a recent study, Beagle 2, the failed British mission to Mars in 2003, came "excruciatingly close" to success and did not crash-land on the Red Planet, unlike what previous analysis had claimed. The new study said the spacecraft might have worked for several months after landing on Mars, but was unable to send its data back to Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Climate, humans caused decline of once 2nd largest salt lake
article: According to a recent study, a combination of climate change and water usage are responsible for drying of the Iran's Lake Urmia, once the world's second-largest hypersaline lake. Around 60% of the lake's water decline was caused by climate change, such as precipitation changes, while 40% of the decline was attributed to water management, such as diverting water for irrigation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: TIFR to launch 10 scientific balloon flights with ISRO
article: A many as 10 balloon flights will be launched by the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research for scientific purposes from November 15 to April 30, 2017, in collaboration with ISRO and Department of Atomic Energy. The balloons would carry scientific instruments for high-altitude research and are expected to reach heights between 30-42 km, depending upon the experiments.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Narwhals, tusked whales of the Arctic, see with sound
article: US-based researchers have discovered that narwhals, the tusked whales of the Arctic, use clicking sounds produced by their tooth, for getting information about their surroundings instead of straining their eyes. Capable of producing up to 1,000 clicks per second, narwhals listen to their echoes to form reconstruction of preys or rocks, based on how sound waves bounce off nearby surroundings.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Stress changes brains of boys and girls differently: Study
article: According to a recent Stanford research, traumatic stress affects the brains of adolescent boys and girls differently. The brain-scanning study found that a brain region called the insula, that integrates emotions and actions and processes feelings and pain, undergoes accelerated maturation in adolescent girls with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), but not in boys with the same condition.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Flavoured e-cigarettes produce cancer-causing toxins: Study
article: A recent US-based study has revealed that smoking flavoured e-cigarettes can produce "unacceptably dangerous" levels of formaldehyde and other cancer-causing compounds. Scientists found that these toxic compounds are formed by thermal decomposition of flavouring compounds. The carcinogenic aldehydes' production was found to be exponentially dependent on concentration of flavouring compounds.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA space telescopes discover a brown dwarf
article: NASA's space telescopes have jointly discovered a brown dwarf (celestial object intermediate in size between planets and stars) during a microlensing, an event where a distant star brightens due to gravitational field of at least one foreground cosmic object. The newly-discovered body has a mass between 30-65 times of Jupiter and orbits a star of about half the sun's mass.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: First-ever semiconductor-free microelectronic device created
article: San Diego-based engineers have fabricated the world's first semiconductor-free, optically-controlled microelectronic device. Using a gold-based metamaterial, they built a microscale device that shows a 1,000% increase in conductivity when activated by low voltage and a low power laser. The discovery could lead to the development of more efficient solar panels.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How does the heart control emotions?
article: A four-minute video explains how the heart beat controls different emotions by changing the way a person processes incoming information. It further discusses a study that states that the heart rate can intensify feelings of fear and anxiety by sending signals to the brain via blood vessels. The video further details different studies to show how the heart affects emotions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: China keeps 'artificial sun' on for more than a minute
article: Chinese scientists have managed to sustain high energy plasma for over a minute in a nuclear fusion device that replicates the sun's energy-generating process. The experiment, conducted using the Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak (EAST), created plasma (a hot ionised gas), wherein atoms fused together to create energy at a temperature nearly three times hotter than the sun's core.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Life on Mars can only exist 'far beneath the surface': Study
article: According to a study by an international team of researchers, the Martian surface almost lacks water and is so dry that life can only exist 'far beneath the surface' on the Red Planet. The study also found that the Martian surface is 10,000 times drier than Earth's driest deserts, and has been that way for millions of years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Trump presidency a 'disaster for Earth', warn climatologists
article: Donald Trump's presidency could spell 'disaster for the planet', leading climate scientists have warned. "A Trump presidency... might make it impossible to stabilise planetary warming below dangerous levels", said another US climate researcher. Trump, who has dismissed climate change as a "Chinese hoax", vowed to phase out the Paris climate accord and Obama's Clean Power Plan.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Scientists make pen drive to test for HIV in under 30 mins
article: British scientists have developed a USB stick-based test to measure levels of HIV in the blood that produces results in under half an hour. The computer plug-in needs a single drop of blood to conduct the test and transmits the results to a mobile device. The technology could allow patients to monitor HIV levels at home with 95% accuracy.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Does water have an expiry period?
article: A three-minute video discussing whether water has an expiry period, explains how the chemistry of water changes on being exposed to air. It further details that water absorbs some amount of carbon dioxide, which is converted into carbonic acid. The acidity is known to not affect humans, however, the presence of bacteria can make it unfit for consumption.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Bangalore-based firm aims to be 1st private moon lander
article: Bangalore-based TeamIndus aims to become the first private company to land a spacecraft on moon, through Google's $20 million Lunar X-Prize competition, of which it is the only entrant. TeamIndus' mission involves launching a spacecraft with a surface rover through ISRO's Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle. If successful, it could become the first Indian company to make a 'soft' moon landing.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists edit genome to cure sickle cell anaemia
article: In a first, UC Berkeley researchers have fixed a genetic mutation responsible for causing sickle cell disease, using a genome-editing-technique known as 'CRISPR-Cas9'. The tool was used to edit the mutation in stem cells genome and replace it with a corrected version. Scientists have suggested the corrected cells could produce healthy RBCs, efficient enough to cure the disease in humans.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Recently killed elephants fuelling the ivory trade: Study
article: The illegal trade in elephant ivory is being fuelled almost entirely by recently killed African elephants, and not by tusks leaked from old government stockpiles, as had long been suspected, a new study has revealed. The study relied on nuclear bomb tests carried out in the 1950s and '60s to date elephant tusks and determine when the animal died.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Trump picks climate change sceptic to lead EPA transition
article: US President-elect Donald Trump has appointed prominent climate change sceptic, Myron Ebell, to lead his transition team at the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Ebell is the chairman of Cooler Heads Coalition, a non-profit group that 'questions global warming alarmism and opposes energy-rationing policies.' Trump had previously promised to 'cancel' The Paris Agreement on climate change.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Companies grow soil-free food to solve Arctic shortages
article: Alaska-based companies Native Kikiktagruk Inupiat Corp and Vertical Harvest Hydroponics are using soil-free techniques to grow vegetables in an attempt to solve food shortage issues in Arctic communities.  Their indoor gardens grow vegetables like kale and lettuce in nutrient solutions inside insulated shipping containers filled with LED lights, without warm climate or soil requirements.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New Zealand Geographic Photographer of the Year announced
article: British photographer Shaun Jeffers has won the landscape category at the 'New Zealand Geographic, Photographer of the Year' awards, for his shot of the glowworms at the Waitomo Glowworm Caves. The 27-year old had to abseil down to 35 metres to capture the scene in the deepest point of the Ruakuri Cave, lit entirely by glowworms.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Neanderthal genes helped man adapt to life outside Africa'
article: A Seattle-based study has revealed that breeding with other human forms like Neanderthals and Denisovans helped modern humans adapt to life after they migrated out of Africa. The study revealed as many as 126 instances in the modern human genome that show high frequencies of 'other-human' genes, with many of these influencing qualities like immunity and properties of the skin.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Prehistoric giant sea reptile discovered in Antarctica
article: A new species of giant sea reptile has been discovered in 66 million-year-old rocks in Antarctica. At about 10 m long, the 'Kaikaifilu' is the largest known marine predator found in the continent. It is a 'mosasaur,' a close relative of modern day lizards. It lived near the end of the dinosaur era, when Antarctica was a much warmer ecosystem.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Climate change could raise the temp over 7°C by 2100: Study
article: According to an international climate change expert team, the Earth could witness global warming of more than 7°C from pre-industrial levels by 2100. They argued that a warmer climate is more sensitive to greenhouse gases, leading to accelerated global warming. Notably, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change predicts maximum warming of 4.8°C by 2100 under the business-as-usual scenario.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rat study helps pinpoint brain's 'tickle' centre
article: A Germany-based study in rats has pinpointed the 'tickle centre' of the mammalian brain, showing for the first time that stimulating neurons in that region cause the rodents to emit ultrasonic squeaks similar to human laughter. Brain activity records show that the rats' 'somatosensory cortex' not only responded to the tickling sensation, but also triggered the 'giggles' that followed.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's smallest magnifying glass allows seeing single atoms
article: University of Cambridge researchers have created the world's smallest magnifying glass, which focuses light a billion times more tightly, down to the scale of single atoms. The team used highly conductive gold nanoparticles to make an optical 'picocavity,' small enough to fit only a single molecule. The findings could help develop light-based data storage devices.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Endangered species database may have misclassified hundreds
article: A new study claims that the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources' (IUCN) Red List of Threatened Species has misclassified the threats to hundreds of animals by failing to incorporate new technologies like satellite and aerial imaging. The study further reclassified 210 bird species with a higher threat level, including the grey-winged cotinga found in Brazil.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New 'bird-like' dinosaur species discovered in China
article: The remains of a new species of bird-like dinosaur have been unearthed in China. The sheep-sized creature had a crest on its head, a short skull, toothless beak, and wings, but was flightless. Named 'Tongtianlong limosus,' meaning "muddy dragon on the road to heaven," the dinosaur appears to have died after getting stuck in mud.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How does stress affect the body?
article: A four-minute video explains how stress is a "hardwired" physical response that travels throughout the entire body. The video states that in the short term stress can be advantageous, however in the long term it could cause damage to organs and cells throughout the body. The stress hormone is released by adrenal glands, which reaches the heart and causes hypertension.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Google machine learning being used to protect sea cows
article: In an attempt to protect the endangered sea cow, Queensland University researchers have used Google's TensorFlow machine learning software to create a detector that automatically spots the aquatic mammals in ocean images. The initial version of the detector could accurately spot 80% of the sea cows that had been confirmed in existing photos.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Leprosy revealed in red squirrels across British Isles
article: UK-based researchers have recently found the red squirrels across the British Isles carry the same bacteria which causes leprosy in humans. Scientists believe the endangered animals have been infected with the disfiguring disease for centuries, which causes lesions on their muzzles, ears and paws. However, scientists concluded the squirrels' leprosy infection poses little risk to humans today.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: England's white cliffs are eroding 10 times faster: Study
article: The white cliffs of southern England are eroding 10-fold faster than over the past few thousand years, a UK-based study has revealed. The erosion rate has been 22-32 cm a year since 150 years as compared to 6 cm a year in past 7,000 years. Climate change resulting in higher storm intensities has been held responsible for faster erosion rates.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New method to dissipate heat in electronic device discovered
article: An international team of researchers has recently discovered a new method to dissipate heat in electronic devices. Researchers modified the energy spectrum of acoustic phonons (elemental excitations), which spread heat through crystalline materials like a wave, by confining them to nanometer-scale semiconductor structures. The discovery could help in developing smaller and faster computer chips.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Seabirds eat floating plastic debris as it smells like food
article: As per a University of California research, seabirds are tempted into eating the floating plastic debris because it smells like their food. Scientists found that drifting plastic waste accumulates algae and gives off a smell akin to the krill, which many marine birds feed on. Plastic ingestion by creatures can damage their internal organs and can lead to gut blockages.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Researchers confirm decades-old theory of phase transitions
article: US-based researchers have confirmed a decades-old theory describing the dynamics of continuous phase transitions, in which quantum defects are formed where some matter is stuck between regions in distinct states. Scientists demonstrated the Kibble-Zurek mechanism (1976), which predicts how such defects will form in space and time, when a physical system goes through continuous phase transition.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Curie couldn't afford to buy element she had discovered
article: Marie Curie, who had discovered the element Radium, did not file a patent for the discovery and could not afford to buy it later for research. The discovery had led to 'Radium boom' and the element was sold for $100,000 a gram. Curie, however, did not express disappointment over not patenting the discovery and said, "Radium belongs to the people."

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Raman had booked ticket for Nobel even before announcement
article: Indian scientist, CV Raman had booked a ticket to Sweden to receive his Nobel Prize even  before the year's prizes were announced. The scientist had been hoping for a Nobel Prize since 1928 and was confident enough to win the award in 1930. Raman, who was born on November 7, 1888, was the first Indian Nobel Laureate in science.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Brain implant lets partly paralysed monkeys walk again
article: Swiss researchers have developed a brain implant that uses wireless signals to 'bypass' an injured section of the spinal cord and stimulate limb muscles, helping partially paralysed monkeys to regain the ability to walk. The 'brain-spine interface', which took seven years to build, helped both monkeys involved in the study regain full mobility in their paralysed limbs within three months.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Antibody which protects foetus from Zika virus identified
article: In a first, US-based scientists have identified a human antibody that prevents developing foetuses from becoming infected with Zika virus in pregnant mice. The anti-Zika antibody called ZIKV-117, was found to markedly reduce the levels of the virus in pregnant mice's foetuses by blocking the virus from crossing the placenta, as compared to those without antibody treatment.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Marie Curie is only woman to win Nobel Prize twice
article: Poland-born scientist Marie Curie is the only woman in history to be awarded the Nobel Prize twice. Curie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize in Physics with her husband for their research on 'spontaneous radioactivity'. The scientist was awarded the 1911 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for her discoveries of radium and polonium. Marie Curie was born on November 7, 1867.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists develop world's 1st light-seeking nanorobot
article: Hong Kong-based chemists have developed the world's first light-seeking synthetic nanorobot for potential biomedical applications. About the size of a human blood cell, the robot is made of a silicon titanium oxide semiconductor shaped in a 'tree-like' structure that attracts it towards the light. If further developed, these can be injected into patients' bodies for precise targeted medications.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Indians consume 119% more salt than recommended WHO limit
article: An average Indian consumes 10.98 grams of salt per day, 119% more than the recommended limit of 5 grams per day by the World Health Organisation, an Australia-based study claimed. The study, which analysed intake of 2.27 lakh Indian adults, listed Tripura at the top with 13.14 grams of salt being consumed per day in both rural and urban areas.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Twitter hashtag helps rare mutant 'lefty' snail find mate
article: A UK garden snail named Jeremy with one-in-a-million 'left-handed anti-clockwise spiralling shell' mutation has found a mate, named 'Lefty', with the same condition, after a nationwide search with the hashtag '#snaillove' was launched. Jeremy and Lefty's offspring will be used to study the genetics of this rare condition, which may help explain body asymmetry in other animals, including humans.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Southern hemisphere healed faster post dino-killing event'
article: According to a recent research, ecosystems in the southern hemisphere recovered more than twice as quickly as those in the north, after the asteroid impact that wiped dinosaurs from Earth around 65 million years ago. The theory overturns the previous idea that the effects might have been less severe in the south as it provided sort of refuge for species.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Interactive Periodic Table reveals how all elements are used
article: A US-based software engineer named Keith Enevoldsen has created an interactive periodic table, which pictorially illustrates how all the elements are used by humans on a daily basis. The table has been colour-coded and displays pictures illustrating the elements' uses such as toothpaste for fluorine, batteries for lithium, swimming pools for chlorine and balloons for helium.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why aren't humans naturally nocturnal?
article: A four-minute video explains how the pattern of sleep and wakefulness is connected to the amount of light entering the human eye. It also explains that when humans perceive daylight, the brain lessens the release of melatonin, making them feel more awake. The video also details how hormone levels fluctuate based on the darkness, causing widespread changes in our physiology.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Glass material almost as strong as steel made
article: Japan-based researchers have created a new type of glass that is stronger than many metals and almost as strong as steel. The strength was achieved by adding large amounts of an aluminium oxide-tantalum oxide mix. To counter the manufacturing challenge where the mix reacts with the surrounding surface, they devised a method of mixing the glass with the oxides mid-air.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How do optical illusions trick the brain?
article: A five-minute video details how the eye interprets surroundings to create images, in order to explain how optical illusions trick the brain. It further details how these illusions hack the eye-to-brain connection by predicting where the brain is likely to misjudge information and send false information. It further discusses three types of optical illusions-literal, physiological, and cognitive.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video shows world's population growth over the years
article: A video by the American Museum of Natural History shows how the human population grew and spread across the globe with time. It reveals that it took humans 2,00,000 years to reach the first billion, and only 200 years to go from 1 to 7 billion. World's population is estimated to reach 11 billion by 2100 if current trends continue.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Are we alone in the universe?
article: A three-minute video explores whether Earth is the only planet which can support life and the possibility of alien life. The video states that according to American astronomer and astrophysicist Frank Drake, there should be about 50,000 detectable civilisations in the galaxy. It further discusses various hypotheses about aliens and how they might not be close enough to communicate with.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New DNA test helps find family's ethnic, geographic history
article: Israel-based genealogy service MyHeritage has introduced a gene kit that it claims is capable of identifying the ethnic and geographic history of one's family. The online platform's $79 'MyHeritage DNA' kit offers test results in 3-4 weeks and even shows DNA matches with distant relatives. MyHeritage is giving 5,000 free testing kits to existing members to jumpstart its DNA library.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US military tests brain stimulation to enhance staff skills
article: US military scientists have developed and successfully tested electrical brain stimulators for enhancing multitasking skills of servicemen like drone operators. The brain stimulation kits use electrodes to send weak electrical currents through the skull and into specific parts of the cortex, to help neurons fire, and ultimately improve effectiveness in high-pressure situations.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Huge water-magma lake found 15 km below Bolivian volcano
article: An international team of researchers has discovered a lake, containing 10% water and rest partially molten rock at temperatures of almost 1,000ºC, 15 km below a Bolivian volcano. When the pressure falls in the liquid body, the water comes out, forming bubbles and driving volcanic eruptions. The team claimed that the find could help explain why and how volcanoes erupt.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why are paper cuts painful?
article: A two-minute video states that paper cuts are painful because the hands are full of nociceptors- pain receptors that respond to pressure and temperature. The video further details how paper cuts directly affect these nerve cells. It adds that edges of paper can damage skin cells like a 'saw' and leave fragments and chemicals that irritate the inner skin layer.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Carbon emissions fell from 50% to 40% in last decade: Study
article: A new research has revealed that annual carbon emissions remaining in the atmosphere, has fallen from about 50% to 40% in the last decade. Scientists found that between 1960 and 2000, carbon rise was increasing every year, but after 2000, global 'greening' has slowed its rise. However, scientists have claimed this amount is too small to halt global warming.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: AAP urges Centre to use artificial rain to tackle pollution
article: Delhi Environment Minister Imran Hussain on Monday urged the Centre to use artificial rain technology to tackle the rising levels of smog in the national capital, reports said. Other measures adopted by Delhi government to tackle pollution are water sprinkling and vacuum cleaning, reports added. Notably, China used cloud seeding to create artificial rain during 2008 Beijing Olympics.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Water detected on Solar System's largest metallic asteroid
article: Scientists have detected the presence of water on Psyche, the largest metallic asteroid in the Solar System. Scientists have proposed that the water-rich minerals detected on Psyche might have been delivered by carbonaceous asteroids that impacted Psyche in the past. The metallic asteroid is the target of a proposed NASA mission to explore the origin of planetary cores.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Majority studies found humans contributed to extreme events
article: The World Meteorological Organization has analysed the global climate of 2011-2015, the hottest five-year period on record. Out of the examined 79 studies published by the American Meteorological Society, more than half found that humans directly contributed to extreme events. Some of those studies found human-induced climate change has increased the probability of extreme heat by over 10 times.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video shows a lizard escaping from pack of snakes
article: The first episode of the British nature documentary series Planet Earth's second season featured an Iguana lizard escaping from a minefield of snakes by virtue of its speed and energy. Being dubbed as "the greatest scene in documentary history", the video has gathered over 5.5 lakh views on YouTube in one day.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Harvard scientists pinpoint physical source of consciousness
article: Harvard scientists have identified a network of three brain regions, which they believe might be the physical source of human consciousness. They found a connection between brain regions linked with arousal and awareness, two prerequisites for consciousness. A specific brainstem region and two cortex regions, linked with arousal and awareness respectively, work together to form consciousness.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Bronze Age city discovered in Iraq
article: German archaeologists have discovered a Bronze Age city in northern Iraq, believed to have established in about 3,000 BC and flourished for over 1,200 years. Settlement layers dating from the Akkadian Empire period, which is regarded as the first world empire in human history, were also uncovered. An extensive road network, residential districts and grand houses were revealed among others.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: World's largest living cat is a lion-tigress hybrid
article: The largest living cat is Hercules, an adult male liger (lion and tigress hybrid) currently housed at Myrtle Beach Safari, in South Carolina, USA, according to the Guinness World Records. Weighing 418.2 kilograms, he measures 3.33 metre in length and has a height of 1.25 metre till the shoulder. Hercules was recognised as the largest living cat in January 2013.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: At ₹7 a km, Mangalyaan's ride was cheaper than an auto
article: India's maiden Mars mission Mangalyaan incurred a cost of ₹7 per kilometre in covering the 65 crore km distance to the red planet, making it cheaper than an auto ride, PM Modi said in 2014. India is also the first Asian country to reach the Mars orbit, ahead of China and Japan. Mangalyaan was launched on November 5, 2013.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Nearly-naked' supermassive black hole spotted
article: Astronomers have spotted a 'nearly-naked' supermassive black hole emerge from the remains of a galaxy and move away at around 3,200 km-per-second. This happened as a result of the black hole's home galaxy passing through a bigger galaxy. The black hole is predicted to lose mass as it continues moving, until it eventually becomes invisible and, hence, untraceable.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: UK's longest earthworm killed for museum preservation
article: A 40-cm long earthworm, biggest ever found in the UK, has been killed so that it can be preserved and put on display at London's Natural History Museum. Nicknamed Dave, the worm weighed 26 grams, five times heavier and three times longer than an average earthworm. Notably, the previous record-holder was as long as Dave but weighed half as much.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Male participants quit birth control study over mood swings
article: A trial into a male contraceptive, which promised 96% effectiveness, was cancelled after some participants complained of side effects like depression, mood disorders and acne. These accounted for 6.2% of all participants, which is comparatively a higher number for side effects in contraceptive medication. However, despite the side effects, 75% of them said they would use this contraception method.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Mangalyaan was the cheapest Mars Mission in the world
article: India's first interplanetary mission Mangalyaan was developed at a budget of $74 million (₹450 crore), making it the cheapest Mars Mission in the world . Mangalyaan's cost was less than Hollywood space adventure film Gravity, made with $100 million (nearly ₹600 crore) and approximately one-tenth of the NASA's Maven explorer. India's Mars Orbiter Mission was launched on November 5, 2013.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Harvard creates solid metallic hydrogen in lab for 1st time
article: Harvard University physicists claim to have successfully produced solid metallic hydrogen in the lab for the first time. To make it, they needed to generate pressures of around 495 gigapascals, greater than that at the earth's core. Developed further, this will have potential applications like superconductors, high-efficiency rocket fuel and lightweight floating structures to support cities.

author: Jamal Mohammad
abstract: Scientists take first colour images with electron microscope
article: In a first, University of California researchers have developed a multicolour electron microscope, which has recently produced the first-ever coloured images of cells. The feat was achieved using three different kinds of layered rare earth metals. The microscope works by detecting when each metal loses electrons and records each unique loss as an artificial colour.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Solar flare cracked Earth's magnetic field: Study
article: Researchers at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research discovered a 'crack' in the magnetic field enveloping Earth, caused by bombardment of very high-energy plasma particles from a solar flare. The bombardment temporarily shrank the magnetosphere from 11 times to 4 times the radius of Earth, exposed the surface to cosmic radiation, and caused radio signal blackouts in high latitude countries.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA sets Guinness record for highest altitude GPS signal
article: NASA's Magnetospheric Multiscale Mission has set the Guinness World Record by setting up highest altitude GPS signal, at 70,000 km. The mission used four individual satellites that fly in a close pyramid formation tracing a highly-elliptical orbit around Earth. The satellites are used to map magnetic reconnection, a process that occurs as the sun and Earth's magnetic fields interact.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Canada investigates 'pinging' sound coming from Arctic floor
article: Canada's military is investigating a mysterious 'pinging' sound that is apparently coming from the Arctic sea floor. This comes after remote hunter communities in the Canadian Arctic raised concerns that the beeping sound is scaring animals away from a popular hunting area of open water surrounded by ice, which is usually abundant with sea mammals.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA paper shows fuel-free space propulsion system
article: NASA's test results on its Electromagnetic Drive revealed the propulsion system is capable of generating thrust in vacuum without any fuel or propellants. It generates thrust by bouncing microwave photons around inside a cone-shaped closed metal cavity. NASA has invited scepticism because it apparently violates Newton's third law, which dictates every action must have an equal, opposite reaction.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: November's 'Supermoon' to be biggest in almost 70 yrs
article: The full moon or 'Supermoon' predicted for November 14 will be the closest to Earth since 1948, appearing 30% brighter and 14% bigger than usual, according to NASA. The full moon won't come this close to Earth until November 2034, NASA added. The term 'Supermoon' denotes the phenomenon where the moon's closest orbiting point coincides with a full moon night.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Australian frog species flashes genitals to repel predators
article: A new frog species discovered in Australia flashes its brightly coloured genitalia as the last line of defence against potential predators. Found in coastal swampy regions, the frog has been named Mahony's Toadlet and is the size of an adult thumb. The amphibian's primary defence mechanism is blending into its environment, a technique common in small lizards and frogs.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How are radars used to study auroras at the North Pole?
article: A six-minute video discusses how radars use radio waves to help position things and how they are used to study auroras at the North Pole. Explaining what causes the light shows in the sky, known as Aurora Borealis, the video further details how an aurora-sensitive radar is made and how it functions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New weak atomic bond observed 14 years after being theorised
