article: A Purdue University physicist has observed a 'butterfly Rydberg molecule', a weak pairing of two highly excitable atoms, whose existence he predicted 14 years ago. Rydberg molecules are formed when an electron is pushed far from an atom's nucleus. This binding mechanism, in which the stray electron can grab and trap an atom, is a novel concept in chemistry.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: In pictures: Measuring Arctic ice melt from the sky
article: Germany-based climate scientist Thomas Krumpen has been flying above northern Greenland towards the North Pole to measure Arctic ice thickness for around six years. Lowering a torpedo from an aircraft towards the sea ice, his team is able to obtain data from otherwise inaccessible areas. Their findings reported a 42% decrease in sea ice thickness since 2010.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA developing aircraft wing that changes shape in-flight
article: NASA is working on an 'ultra-light' aircraft wing that actively changes shape during flight, for increased efficiency compared to traditional 'rigid' designs. The wing is constructed from blocks of advanced carbon fibre composite materials, assembled into an arrangement of repeating structures. It is equipped with actuators and computers that morph it into the desired wing shape during flight.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: NASA debuts interactive map for International Space Station
article: NASA recently launched an interactive map tool, called Spot the Station, to help track the International Space Station (ISS). The map will help locate, the 'third brightest object in the sky', from several thousand worldwide locations. By entering the location, it will be populated with blue pins, from where the space station will be visible in an 80-kilometre radius.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA carrying out asteroid strike emergency drills
article: NASA is carrying out emergency drills to prepare for an asteroid strike catastrophe. A recent exercise simulated a hypothetical asteroid of size up to 250 metres, predicted to strike Earth in 2020. This was done to discuss ways to collect and analyse asteroid collision data, and use that data to prepare the public to respond to a potential hit.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: UK scientists apply for genetically modified wheat trial
article: Researchers have applied for a licence to carry out a trial of a genetically modified (GM) wheat crop in Hertfordshire, UK. The GM wheat is claimed to convert sunlight into chemical energy more efficiently, boosting yields by up to 40%. If the government grants permission, the experiment would potentially be the second ongoing field trial in the UK.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What causes our nose to bleed?
article: A two-minute video explains what causes nosebleeds, a condition known as epistaxis. Describing different types of nosebleeds, the video adds that it is mostly caused by irritation to blood vessels in the nasal septum. The video, further detailing how humidity and temperature affect nosebleeds, explains how it can stopped by pinching the soft part of the nose for ten minutes.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Green 'airglow' spotted hanging over UK
article: Astronomers and 'aurora hunters' in the United Kingdom have reported sightings of a green 'airglow' in the night sky. The phenomenon, confusable with Aurora Borealis or the Northern Lights, is actually due to chemiluminescence. This is when some of the sun's energy excites and splits atmospheric oxygen molecules into atoms. The atoms then recombine, releasing light energy causing such 'airglows'.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How do vaccines work?
article: A four-minute video explaining how vaccines function, details the use of the first vaccine created by Edward Jenner, to protect a boy from smallpox virus. Further illustrating the working of the human immune system, the video states that scientists use vaccines to trigger the body's adaptive immune system. It further distinguishes between kinds of vaccines, such as attenuated and inactive.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Female scientists collaborate differently: Study
article: Female academicians in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics are less likely to be working internationally and are more likely to collaborate locally, a Northwestern University study has revealed. Analysis of complete publication records also suggested that women are underrepresented in paper authorships and granting of scientific prizes, as well as certain disciplines like Genomics.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA probe captures methane clouds on Saturn's moon
article: NASA's Cassini spacecraft has recently captured time-lapse videos of clouds of methane moving across Saturn's largest moon, Titan, with its cameras. The videos show the development of clouds which move over the moon's surface with speeds up to 10 metres per second, and eventually fade with time. Scientists believe these time-lapse videos would enhance their understanding about cloud dynamics.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why do people undress before freezing to death?
article: A four-minute video explores the tendency of people to undress while dying of hypothermia, a condition of having an abnormally low body temperature. Basing the discussion on the 2015 movie 'Everest' and numerous studies, the video states that people become disoriented towards the last stages of hypothermia and they begin to feel hot, thus leading to the 'paradoxical undressing'.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop drug that 'could cure HIV and AIDS'
article: Israel-based researchers have developed a drug they claim could cure HIV and AIDS, with trials showing up to 97% decrease of the virus count in blood samples in just 8 days. The new drug, which has a peptide as its active ingredient, works by causing the self-destruction of the HIV-infected 'CD4' cells, which prevents further spread of the virus.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Average US family destroys 200 sq m Arctic ice every year
article: Greenhouse gas emissions from an average four-member US family causes the loss of 200 square metre of Arctic sea ice annually, according to climatology experts. The study further stated, the shrinkage of the Arctic ice cap has progressed in direct correlation with the amount of human-generated greenhouse gases. The study predicted an ice-free Arctic by 2045 as the business-as-usual scenario.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Tobacco smoke causes 150 extra lung cell mutations: Study
article: Smoking cigarettes daily for a year causes nearly 150 extra DNA mutations in every lung cell, and around 100 more in each larynx cell, a collaborative study has claimed. The study also found mutations in organs not directly exposed to smoke, like the bladder and liver, and added that smoking accelerates the cellular clock that mutates DNA prematurely.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Newly-discovered asteroid came within 77,000 km of Earth
article: Astronomers at the Virtual Telescope Project (VTP) captured an asteroid 'eclipsed' by Earth as it flew by on Tuesday. Named 2016 VA, the 7-22 metre asteroid came within 77,000 km of Earth, about 20% of the Earth-moon distance, just hours after its discovery. In 2016, there have been 50 instances of asteroids coming closer than the moon, VTP added.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How does the subconscious mind work?
article: A two-minute video details the working of the subconscious mind, explaining how it controls human behaviour. The video states that as per Sigmund Freud, the father of psychoanalysis, the unconscious mind influences behaviour and contains suppressed memories. It further discusses studies to explain how the subconscious mind contains habitual knowledge and helps to process information quickly.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How could we create a second Earth?
article: A four-minute video explores the possibility of creating a second Earth through the process of terraforming, transforming a planet to resemble the Earth, especially so that it can support human life. The video further details the possibility and challenges of creating a human-suitable atmosphere on planets such as Mars, Venus and Mercury.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Toxic protein-stopping Alzheimer's drug tested successfully
article: A drug that 'switches off' production of toxic amyloid proteins that lead to brain plaques, a characteristic of Alzheimer's patients, has been tested successfully by US pharmaceutical major Merck. The trial was primarily aimed to test safety, but after dosing early-stage Alzheimer's patients for seven days, it also reported reduction in levels of two compounds known to build abnormal proteins.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA begins testing world's largest space telescope
article: NASA has begun testing the James Webb Space Telescope, the largest optical space telescope ever built. The $8.8 billion telescope has 18 gold-coated hexagonal plates that act as a sunshield to harness solar power while keeping the measuring devices cool enough. The telescope, which took nearly 20 years to build, will replace the 26-year-old Hubble Space Telescope.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Mutation might have made Ebola virus deadlier for humans'
article: A genetic mutation allowed the Ebola virus to infect humans more effectively during the 2014 African epidemic, two different studies claim. The first study claimed that twice as many people died during the later stages of the outbreak, as the viral strain evolved. According to the second study, prolonged human circulation enabled the virus to better adapt to human-to-human transmission.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: US researchers devise method to convert sewage into biofuel
article: US Department of Energy researchers have devised a new method to convert sewage into biofuel. The method, hydrothermal liquefaction, mimics the natural process by which crude oil is created in the earth's crust. The researchers have claimed that their approach eliminates the need for drying, which typically makes wastewater-to-fuel conversion inefficient and energy expensive.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rare 'eye-shaped feature' formed by galaxy collision
article: Using a radio telescope in Chile's Atacama desert, astronomers have observed a rare 'eyelid-shaped' feature of stars and hot gas, caused by two spiral galaxies, 114 million-light-years from Earth, grazing past each other. Such galactic 'eyelids' are seldom observed because they last up to tens of millions of years, a very brief moment in a galaxy's lifetime, an astronomer added.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: NASA celebrates 16 yrs of humans living in space with GIFs
article: US space agency NASA on Wednesday celebrated 16 years of astronauts living in space at the International Space Station by releasing GIFs. The ISS is the largest structure ever built in space and was assembled by five different space agencies representing 15 countries. The GIFs include one with the view of the 9/11 terrorist attacks from the space.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Star explosions source of 75% of universe's lithium
article: Stellar 'novae', or explosions in two-star systems where one is a 'white dwarf', produce nearly 75% of the universe's lithium, Spain-based researchers have confirmed. Studies of two-star system 'nova Sagittarii 1015 N.2' revealed unexpectedly large amounts of beryllium-7, an unstable element that decays into lithium. The rest of the lithium is believed to have formed just after the Big Bang.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Bones at UK Stone Age site found turning into jelly
article: Bones at Star Carr, a UK archaeological site dating back to the Middle Stone Age have been found decaying into jelly. The decay is being caused by the corrosive effect of sulphuric acid generated by draining of the land for agricultural purposes since the mid-20th century. Until then, the archaeological records had been naturally preserved by Star Carr's low-oxygen wetland.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Early Alzheimer's patients 7 times likely to be 'lonely'
article: Loneliness could be a factor in Alzheimer's disease, with around 7.5 times higher likelihood of loneliness in early stage patients, according to a new Harvard study. The study found correlation between social isolation and raised levels of amyloid, a toxic brain plaque-building protein associated with Alzheimer's. However, the study does not reveal whether social isolation is a cause or effect.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New model claims to solve 'biggest' problems in physics
article: A Paris-based research group has come up with an alternate model that claims to explain five of the 'biggest' fundamental problems in physics. The new model, dubbed 'SMASH', proposes six new fundamental particles, and could explain why there is more matter than antimatter, the rapid early phase growth of the universe, and even the nature of 'dark matter'.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What is the difference between hard and soft water?
article: A four-minute video explains how hard and soft water differs based on the mineral content. It further states that 'hard' water has a higher than normal concentration of minerals, such as calcium and magnesium. It adds that soap reacts with the minerals in the hard water to form insoluble compounds, as compared to the formation of lather in soft water.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA developing instrument to detect life on Mars
article: NASA is developing an instrument called 'Bio-Indicator Lidar Instrument' (BILI) to 'sniff' out signs of life on Mars. BILI is a fluorescence-based lidar, similar to radar in principle and operation, that uses light to detect and analyse the composition of atmospheric particles. The instrument is based on a technique typically used to monitor air to detect bio-hazardous chemicals.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists make first global map of human-emitted CO2
article: Finland-based scientists have created the first global maps of human carbon dioxide emissions, made solely from NASA's Orbiting Carbon Observatory-2 satellite data. Using a novel data-processing technique to separate human emissions from total levels, three main maps were created, centered on Earth's highest-emitting regions: the eastern United States, central Europe and East Asia.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Humans arrived in Australian interior 49,000 yrs ago: Study
article: Archaeologists have found evidence that humans arrived in Australia's arid interior around 49,000 years ago, 10,000 years earlier than previously believed. Excavation of a mountain rock shelter revealed artefacts including burnt eggshells, stone tools, and a bone from an extinct giant marsupial. These practices are believed to have developed after increasing aridity 'trapped' the migrant humans.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 165-mn-yr-old fossil of 'octopus-like' animals' ancestor
article: A recently studied 165 million-year-old 'octopus-like' fossilised creature may be the ancestor of an order of animals called 'Octopodiformes,' which includes modern octopuses and species like the vampire squid. The fossil, 'Proteroctopus ribeti,' lived during the Jurassic Period and was first described in 1982. It is rare for a fossilised octopus to be so "well-preserved", scientists claimed.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Soil could become significant CO2 source, experts warn
article: Soils will have limited potential to absorb carbon and will become a net source of atmospheric carbon dioxide, if current land reclamation practices continue, experts have warned. This will lead to loss of soils' fertility and water storage capacity, they added. At present, soil is known to slow man-made climate change by acting as a carbon sink.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Zebrafish protein may be key for spinal cord repair
article: A protein found in zebrafish may be key to the development of spinal cord repair treatments, Duke University scientists have claimed. Adult zebrafish can regenerate their spinal cords after a severing injury, owing to a 'connective tissue growth factor' (CTGF) protein. The protein triggers a "bridge" formation between the severed ends and completely repairs the damage within 8 weeks.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 2 Indians selected in London Mayor’s innovation contest
article: Two Indians have featured in the top ten selected candidates for the London Mayor's 2016 innovation competition, which involved entries from 49 countries. Malav Sanghavi bagged the fifth spot for his smart socket for amputees which customises their comfort level according to their activity, while Mustafa Khanwala's app which eliminates the need to queue in shops, achieved the tenth position.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Milk chocolate with benefits of dark chocolate created
article: US-based researchers have developed a method to give milk chocolate, the nutritional benefits of dark chocolate, without affecting the taste. By adding peanut skin extracts into milk chocolate, scientists have made milk chocolates with comparable antioxidant levels as the dark chocolates. If commercialised, the method would ease the consumption of compounds with proven health benefits.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists reveal chipmunk's stripes linked to gene change
article: Harvard University scientists have recently found that there is an evolutionary gene change which is responsible for the stripes of the chipmunks. The study found that a gene change causes skin cells to stop making dark pigment in the rodent's belly, causing light stripes. Scientists suggested these light distinctive markings helped the rodents to hide from daylight predators like birds.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New bionic eye helps blind woman see shapes, colours
article: California-based scientists claim to have developed a bionic eye implant which has helped a woman blind for seven years regain the ability to see shapes and colours. It consists of a small spectacle-mounted camera that sends electrical signals through a computer to skull implants. The implants were connected to the brain's visual processing region, enabling the subject to sense images.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: Italy earthquake made ground move 70 cm: Report
article: The recent 6.5-magnitude earthquake in central Italy has displaced the ground by nearly 70 centimetres, Italian scientists claimed on Tuesday. Italy's National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology has revealed that the quake was followed by around 1,100 after-shocks. The shallow earthquake on October 30 is reportedly the worst quake to hit Italy in 30 years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rising humidity turning oldest mummies into 'black slime'
article: The world's oldest mummified human remains, in northern Chile, are turning into black slime due to rising humidity levels associated with climate change. Believed to belong to the ancient Chinchorro hunter-gatherers, the mummies have been dated nearly 7,000 years old. Local officials have applied to the United Nations' cultural agency, UNESCO, to have them recognised as a world heritage site.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Harvard team builds cigarette-smoking robot
article: A team of Harvard scientists has built a chain-smoking robot to study lung diseases in humans. The robot can be fitted with 12 cigarettes at once and can be programmed to 'inhale' at different intensities and frequencies. The smoke is passed through a channel of living lung cells from patients with lung diseases to observe how they react to smoke.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA's Curiosity rover finds metal meteorite on Mars
article: US space agency NASA's Curiosity Mars rover recently found a metal meteorite on the Red planet. Dubbed as "Egg Rock", the meteorite is believed to be composed of nickel and iron as images captured by the rover show peculiar features found on metallic meteorites. Scientists have suggested the meteorite possibly came from the asteroid belt near the Red Planet.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Active volcano Mount Helens rests on a cold rock slab: Study
article: As per a US-based research, Mount St Helens, an active volcano responsible for one of the deadliest eruptions in US history, rests on a cold stone slab. Researchers found the volcano does not get its magma from underlying reserves, as it is too cool to be the heat source. They believe the actual magma source is far from its peak.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Venom of one of world's deadliest snakes could relieve pain
article: An international team of researchers has revealed the venom of blue coral snakes, one of the world's deadliest snakes, could be used to relieve pain. Scientists found the venom hits a particular type of sodium channel, important for the treatment of pain in humans. Dubbed as 'killer's killers', these snakes are known to have the world's biggest venom glands.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Human cells and neutron stars have similar structure: Study
article: According to a research by US-based researchers, human cells and neutron stars, the celestial bodies born from the death of stars, have similar structures. Both of the regimes were found to have evenly spaced sheets resembling multistory "parking garages". The similarity comes despite different operational forces, with nuclear forces holding neutron stars while entropic forces holding the other.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: High altitude can make us forget how to speak
article: A two-minute video explains how high altitudes can cause an inability to speak, which is a potential symptom of altitude sickness. As lesser amounts of oxygen reach the brain, there is a possibility of the body suffering from a high-altitude cerebral edema. The video further discusses how the increased pressure inside the brain can possibly cause death.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists find why cancer cells resist chemotherapy
article: UK-based scientists have identified a modification of proteins called histones, which make cancer cells resistant to chemotherapy by wrapping around the DNA of cancer cells, protecting them from chemotherapy treatment. Scientists suggested the development of resistance can be prevented by changing the speed in which the cancer cells repair damage to their DNA, caused by the chemotherapy treatment.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Elephant poaching costing Africa ₹167 cr annually: WWF
article: Elephant poaching is costing Africa nearly ₹167 crore ($25 million) annually in lost tourism revenue, according to a study by World Wide Fund for Nature scientists. Around ₹60 crore of that comes from tourists' direct spending, with the rest through farmers and other suppliers supporting tourism industry. Stronger anti-poaching measures cost less than current revenue losses, the study added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Energy source found hosting microbial life 2 km underground
article: Toronto-based researchers have found an energy source sustaining microbial life in water more than two kilometres underground in Northern Ontario. A radioactive isotope of sulphur in the underground rocks causes the water to liberate hydrogen, which is used by the micro-organisms to derive energy. These rocks were formed before oxygen appeared in the atmosphere 2.4 billion years ago.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why doesn't our skin tear easily?
article: A four-minute video explains why the skin, which is the largest organ of the human body, doesn't tear easily. The video discusses the skin's varying thickness and its different layers, in order to detail how its composition makes it resistant to tearing. It further explains the role of collagen, a structural protein in connective tissue to help resist rips.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New MIT tech helps machines explain basis of their decisions
article: MIT researchers have devised a new training technique that would reveal the basis for a computer's decision-making process, enabling the neural networks to explain the rationale behind their decisions. Researchers trained the neural nets on textual data to rank beers and found that they rated beers based on aroma and appearance, in almost the same way as humans.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: All science at risk of fraudulent research: UK think tank
article: According to UK-based think tank Global Warming Policy Foundation (GWPF), all science is "in deep trouble" with "fraudulent research" being published in peer-reviewed journals. It also claimed that "peer-reviewed" does not equal "policy-ready", and global warming threats are "exaggerated". GWPF is "illegitimately undermining confidence in climate research", a climate research centre has responded.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New theory explains how the moon got to its current position
article: According to an alternative model proposed by US-based researchers, the Earth was set spinning with its axis pointing towards the sun after a violent impact stripped matter away, forming the moon. Gradual dissipation of angular momentum caused the moon to slowly move away in a fluctuating orbit, until it reached its current orbit slightly tilted to the Earth's equatorial plane.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Indian researcher awarded by German Education Ministry
article: An Indian researcher was among the 25 scholars awarded for their 'green ideas' by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research. Twenty-nine-year-old PhD student Shamik Chowdhury was awarded for his research combining urban sustainability, resource efficiency, cleaner production and eco-innovation. He is studying environmental engineering at the National University of Singapore.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Context helps the brain react to sounds: Study
article: According to a New York-based study in mice, brain cells dedicated to hearing also rely on surrounding context from visual and other sensory cues, to interpret and react to familiar sounds. The study claimed that this is why a car horn triggers alertness in the street, but not while indoors. This may accurately explain situation-specific behaviours, such as exam-triggered anxiety.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: A tree reduces up to 24% nearby suspended particles: Study
article: A US-based study has reported that the average reduction of particulate matter (PM), near a tree is between 7-24%, as compared to normal surroundings. The study also estimated that the PM pollution, which is a mixture of dust, smoke, soot and other microscopic particles, could claim nearly 6.2 million lives each year by 2050, upon inhalation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA crowdsourcing ideas to study Moon's surface
article: US space agency NASA has put out a request inviting ideas from private companies and the science community about instruments that can be used to explore and study the surface of the Moon. The instruments would potentially be transported to the Moon between 2017 and 2020 on lunar landers that are currently being developed by private companies in the US.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Human brain is driven towards negative stereotypes: Study
article: As per a recent UK-based study, the human brain responds more strongly to information about unfavourably portrayed groups, suggesting brain's predisposed tendency to learn negative stereotypes. Scientists found that a network of brain areas, particularly in the prefrontal cortex, responded quickly to snippets about a "bad group", while the response tailed off in case of a "good" group.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Engineered spinach plants can detect explosives
article: In a first, MIT researchers have engineered spinach plants, which are capable of detecting hidden land mines and other explosives. By embedding spinach leaves with carbon nanotubes, scientists transformed spinach plants into sensors that can detect harmful chemical compounds called nitroaromatics found in explosives, and can then relay the information to a smartphone-like device.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Superconductivity induced in non-superconducting materials
article: University of Houston researchers have found a new method to induce superconductivity in non-superconducting materials by using assembled interfaces. Scientists demonstrated that enhanced critical temperature or the temperature at which a material becomes superconducting, can be achieved for calcium iron arsenide using artificially or naturally assembled interfaces with metallic layer stacking.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: American scientists turn carbon dioxide into fuel
article: US-based scientists have accidentally discovered a method to turn carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, into ethanol, a renewable fuel. The waste-to-fuel technology works through an electrochemical reaction with a 63% yield, and uses a single catalyst made of copper nanoparticles embedded in carbon spikes. Researchers believe the technology could be scaled up for industry level applications in future.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Man develops hepatitis after drinking 5 energy drinks a day
article: A 50-year-old builder was diagnosed with hepatitis C after consuming five energy drinks per day for three weeks, several reports said. The doctors diagnosed the builder after he complained of feeling unwell and abdominal pain, and had also developed jaundice. High quantity of niacin (vitamin B3), due to the overdosing of energy drinks, was blamed for the man's liver inflammation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientist uses lasers, 3D-printing to save desert tortoises
article: To help protect the desert tortoise species threatened by rising predatory raven populations, US-based biologist Tim Shields is testing laser rifle scopes to scare off the birds. He is also testing 3D-printed 'decoy' baby tortoises filled with noxious substances to repel the ravens. A camera-equipped patrol vehicle to track living tortoises while scaring away ravens is being developed as well.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Parent-led therapy can combat child autism symptoms: Study
article: A UK-based study into the effects of early intervention therapy designed to help parents communicate with their autistic children has shown long-term success in reducing the core symptoms of their developmental condition. In the study, autistic children and their parents were given social activity sessions, which were videotaped. These helped the parents improve communication with their children.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's largest nuclear weapon test happened 55 years ago
article: On October 30, 1961, the former Soviet Union detonated the 'Tsar Bomba' - world's largest nuclear weapon test in history. The 27-ton hydrogen bomb had a yield of 50 megatons of TNT, around 1,400 times stronger than the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombs combined. The explosion generated a mushroom cloud 7 times higher than the Mount Everest.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Butterflies taste food with their feet
article: Butterflies have taste sensors on their feet and by standing on a leaf, they can taste it to see if their caterpillars can eat it. The flying insects mainly consume liquids like nectar or juice from fruits, and sometimes even fluids from carcasses. They have a long, tube-like tongue called 'proboscis', which works like a straw to suck up liquid.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Patient Zero' didn't cause AIDS outbreak in US: Study
article: New research has removed blame from a gay man, dubbed 'Patient Zero', who allegedly 'introduced HIV/AIDS into US'. Canadian flight attendant Gaétan Dugas died of AIDS in 1984 after assisting with studies into whether it was caused by a sexually transmitted agent. Genetic techniques revealed that the virus entered US in the 1970s from a pre-existing epidemic in the Caribbean.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Scientists teach Morse code through Google Glass in 4 hours
article: US-based researchers have developed a system that teaches people Morse code within four hours using Google's smart headset, Google Glass. The system delivered a series of vibrations near the ear to participants who played games while feeling the taps and hearing the corresponding letters. Participants were able to write codes for every letter with 98% accuracy after the experiment.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Brazil to release mutant mosquitoes to fight disease
article: Scientists in Brazil are preparing to release millions of genetically modified (GM) male mosquitoes in an attempt to wipe out their disease-carrying relatives. The mutant specimens will mate with ordinary female mosquitoes, and the babies spawned will die quickly due to an inbuilt genetic flaw. After breeding, the males will also die, being programmed to do so.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 30 crore children live in areas with extreme air pollution
article: Around 30 crore of the world's children live in places where toxic fumes are more than six times the WHO limits, a new research by UNICEF has revealed. More than 20 crore of these children exposed to extreme air pollution levels, live in South Asia including India, which hosts six of the ten world's most polluted cities.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Naturally occurring 'anti-ageing' compound found
article: US-based scientists claim to have discovered a natural compound found in cabbage, broccoli and cucumber that produces 'anti-ageing effects'. Initial tests of the compound 'NMN' on elderly mice showed boosted levels of 'NAD', which is a compound involved in energy-production in the body. This enhanced physical activity, bone density and improved muscles, immune system, liver and eyesight.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: ISS crew lands on Earth after 115 days in space
article: US' Kate Rubins, Japan's Takuya Onishi and Russia's Anatoly Ivanishin landed safely in Kazakhstan on Sunday after their 115-day mission aboard the International Space Station (ISS). While flight commander Ivanishin had also undertaken a five-month mission at the ISS five years ago, molecular biologists Onishi and Rubins were returning from their first space mission.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Bolivia's glaciers shrunk by 43% since mid-1980s: Study
article: Bolivia, a country with 20% of the world's tropical glaciers, has witnessed a 43% decline in glacier size since the mid-1980s, Bolivia and UK-based scientists have found. The change has been attributed to human induced global warming. This is putting pressure on an already stressed water supply, while the meltwater lakes risk collapsing in sudden, catastrophic floods, the scientists added.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Years on Mercury are shorter than the day-night cycle
article: Mercury, the smallest planet in the Solar System, completes one revolution around the Sun in 88 Earth days. However, it takes almost 180 Earth days for the Sun to rise and set on Mercury. Being closest to the Sun, the planet has a short year but it spins much slower than the Earth, making the days long.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: More than 15,000 threat-posing asteroids found: ESA
article: The number of near-Earth objects (NEO) that pose a threat of crashing into the Earth has crossed 15,000, with many more yet to be identified, European Space Agency (ESA) astronomers have said. Around 90% objects larger than 1000 m have been discovered, but only 10% of 100 m NEOs, and less than 1% of 40 m ones have been found.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How does welding differ in space?
article: A seven-minute video explains how welding, a process that is used to diffuse metals by heating them, differs in space as compared to Earth. Explaining the fundamental structure of metals, the video states that in space if two metals come into contact they can fuse together without the need of heat or being melted.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Nose cartilage can help repair knee injuries
article: For the first time, doctors have grafted cartilage from the nose into the knees of patients with damaged connective tissue. They found that the nose cartilage grafts adapted to form new tissue that can withstand the mechanical stress of the knee joint. The procedure was less invasive, and the patients also reported less pain and better daily function.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists reveal how particles form in the atmosphere
article: University of Leeds scientists have published a study based on experimental data, explaining how particles are formed in the atmosphere. The study, conducted using Switzerland's CERN research facility's CLOUD laboratory, observes how certain molecules in the atmosphere cluster together and grow to form new particles called aerosols. Water condenses on these aerosol particles to form clouds.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Stone Age men may have caused biggest lion's extinction
article: Stone Age humans may have hunted to extinction the cave lion, the largest lion species believed to have ever existed, according to Spain-based researchers. Their findings also suggest that the feline, which grew up to 3.5 m long, were hunted down by the early humans so that they could use their fur to make rugs to line their cave floors.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Facial expressions may not be universal: Study
article: Facial expressions generally accepted to be universal may have different interpretations across cultures, Spain-based researchers have claimed. They found that an isolated indigenous community in the Trobriand Islands off Papua New Guinea associated a 'gasping' expression with threat instead of fear. The finding reinforces the idea that expressions are shaped by culture to gain meaning.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why do we get a sunburn?
article: A two-minute video explains how the ultraviolet rays emitted by the Sun cause sunburn. The video states that the high-energy light causes a reaction between some of the DNA's basic building blocks and thus damaging it. The video further adds that to protect the skin cells from the light, the body produces a pigment that absorbs the harmful radiation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Solar storms can weaken Earth’s magnetic field: Study
article: A team of researchers has recently found solar storms, which are mass and energy eruptions from solar surface, can weaken Earth's magnetic field. The weakened Earth's protective magnetic field would allow cosmic rays to easily reach Earth's atmosphere without being deflected. This could be dangerous for astronomers as they would be exposed to high-energy particles which can damage their DNA.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA time-lapse shows 32 years of Arctic ice shrinkage
article: A time-lapse video from NASA shows the shrinkage of Arctic sea ice from 1984 to 2016. In 1984, there was 1.8 million square km of ice that was at least five years old at its lowest annual amount. This "older" ice had shrunk to 110,000 square km by September 2016. The video also shows the seasonal circulation of the ice.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Placebo sweet spot for pain relief identified in brain
article: In a first, scientists have identified the brain region responsible for the 'placebo effect' in pain relief. Scientists found that the mid frontal gyrus area in brain identifies the placebo, a harmless pill made up of inert substances like sugar or starch, which results in substantial reduction of pain. This could aid designing of personalised medicines for chronic pain.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Software to make reliable energy-harvesting computers
article: Carnegie Mellon University researchers have created the first programming language to build reliable software for computers that operate by harvesting energy from their environment. The new language, called Chain, modifies the way computational operations manipulate the computer's memory, to ensure tasks execute correctly despite arbitrary power failures that occur in energy-harvesting devices.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Extreme weather effects may explain butterfly decline
article: UK-based scientists have found that extreme weather conditions like droughts or heavy rainfalls can prove harmful to the butterfly populations. Scientists found that precipitation during the cocoon life-stage was detrimental for many species, while extremely high temperatures during 'overwintering' life-stage resulted in early come-out of the larvae and subsequently being killed.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA's New Horizons relays last bits of data on Pluto
article: NASA's New Horizons mission relayed safely back to Earth the last bits of the 50-plus total gigabits of science data from its 2015 flyby of Pluto. New Horizons' recorders will now be cleared to make space for new data it will collect on the Kuiper Belt, a ring of bodies in the outermost reaches of the solar system.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Syringe preventing blood loss in haemophilic mice developed
article: Korean researchers have made a self-sealing syringe using a polymer coating which prevents blood loss in haemophilic mice, by successfully sealing the puncture made by the injection. The research could help human patients whose blood does not clot properly, such as diabetes or cancer patients, in getting an injection without continued bleeding done by the puncture of the injection.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: How do eyes see colour?
article: A one-minute video explains how the wavelength of light and the electromagnetic spectrum, the existing range of lights, helps the eye determine colours. The video discusses how the process of reflection and absorption of light causes humans to perceive the colours. It further discusses the primary colours of light and how they mix to create different shades.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World vertebrate numbers fall 58% in 42 years: WWF
article: Global populations of vertebrate animals have fallen by as much as 58% between 1970 and 2012, according to World Wide Fund's (WWF) annual 'Living Planet' report. Human activity including habitat loss, wildlife trade, pollution and climate change, is attributed to the decline. The report suggests that animals living in lakes, rivers and wetlands are suffering the biggest losses.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Why does Earth witness an Ice Age every 100,000 years?
article: Cardiff University researchers have tried to explain why Earth has witnessed an ice age every 100,000 years for the past million years. According to them, the oceans periodically exchange carbon dioxide with the atmosphere, similar to "inhaling" and "exhaling". During such an "inhalation" phase, global temperatures plunge, leading to vast ice sheets covering most continents.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: DNA of unknown human species found in Pacific Islanders
article: A genetic study has found traces of an unknown human species in the DNA of people living in South Pacific. The DNA markers did not match any currently known human species and were not derived from Neanderthals, Denisovans or Homo sapiens, researchers said. The discovery hints towards a new, previously unknown species, and could change the understanding of human evolution.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video shows fish-eye view of the International Space Station
article: NASA recently shared an 18-minute video displaying a fly-through of the International Space Station (ISI). The video, which spans different areas of the station, was produced by Harmonic, exclusively for NASA. The footage was shot in Ultra High Definition (4K) using a fish-eye lens for extreme focus and depth of field.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Restorers lift the lid on Jesus' tomb in Jerusalem
article: For the first time in centuries, the tomb in Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulchre, where Jesus' body is believed to have been laid after his crucifixion, has been exposed as part of a $4 million restoration project. The tomb is situated inside a structure known as the Edicule, which is being restored by a team of Greek conservationists.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New male contraceptive shown as effective as female pill
article: With an efficiency of 96%, a new contraceptive injection has been shown to be almost as effective as the female pill in preventing unplanned pregnancies. The trial involves injection of progestogen and testosterone hormones, for reducing sperm production and mitigating the testosterone-reducing effects respectively. Researchers are still working on alleviating related side effects like depression.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Bacterial "smart soil" could keep buildings stable'
article: UK-based researchers are developing bio-cement, a material that genetically engineered soil bacteria would produce in response to changing pressures in soil to reinforce the ground under building foundations. The team successfully modified common gut bacteria to glow in response to increased pressure. Eventually they plan to replace the 'glow' gene with a gene that triggers bio-cement production.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What happens to a person in a coma?
article: A five-minute video explains what happens to the body when a person is in a coma, a Greek word meaning 'deep sleep'. Coma is a state of unconsciousness, caused when the brain is injured or when the blood flow is cut off. The video further explains that a person in a coma doesn't respond to stimuli.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Swifts spend 10 months a year entirely airborne: Study
article: Common swifts spend ten months in a year entirely airborne, a recent study has claimed. Using miniature geo-locators, which also monitored motion and altitude, scientists followed 19 common swifts over a two-year period. They observed that some birds did not land once during their migratory period, suggesting that they eat and sleep in the sky.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover a new mineral merelaniite
article: A team of scientists have recently discovered a new mineral using Raman spectrometry. Identified as merelaniite, the new mineral has a layered structure consisting of tiny, silvery, cylindrical whiskers, rich in molybdenum, lead and sulfur. Merelaniite is made up of molybdenum disulfide layers alternating at the atomic scale with layers of lead sulfide, along with other elements including bismuth.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: World's largest marine park created in Antarctica
article: The European Union and 24 countries on Friday reached an agreement to create world's largest marine park in Antarctica, after five years of negotiations. The deal will protect over 1.5 million square kilometres of the Ross Sea, with 1.1 million square kilometres being designated a 'general protection zone' that outlaws fishing. The protections are set to expire in 35 years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Video explains technique to build artificial tissue
article: A new technique has been developed for assembling flexible polymers and living cells to build functional artificial tissue. Using electric fields, scientists can control the movements of tiny, cell-filled droplets between two glass plates, assemble them into a larger configuration, and treat the droplets to form adhesive gels. If refined, the technique could help develop artificial organs.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Hookworms could help fight asthma, immune diseases
article: Scientists have claimed that a protein found in hookworms can combat asthma and autoimmune diseases. A study has shown that a hookworm protein called AIP-2 suppresses airway inflammation in mice with asthma. The protein also apparently checks the growth of some immune cells in the blood of people with allergies.

author: Parichit Mainra
abstract: WHO asked scientists to withold cancer research
article: World Health Organization's cancer agency IARC asked scientists not to disclose documents related to their research on a "probably carcinogenic" chemical that is widely used as a weedkiller, reports said. This comes after the agency was asked to release the documents under freedom of information laws. IARC said it was only seeking to protect its work from external interference.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Dinosaur brain tissue discovered in 130m-yr-old fossil
article: A 130 million year-old rock found in Sussex, England bears the first evidence of fossilised dinosaur brain tissue, scientists have claimed. The discovery has raised speculations that the creature, believed to be a herbivorous 'Iguanodon'-like species, may have had an unexpectedly large brain. It has also shown that, unlike previously believed, brain tissue can be fossilised.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Magma uplifting giant dome atop world's 2nd highest plateau
article: A new study has found that magma injected into Earth's crust, has contributed to the uplifting of a massive dome atop the world's second highest continental plateau, the Altiplano-Puna plateau. Researchers suggested the dome, which stands over a kilometre high, is caused by crust's thickening due to low-density magma injection, which is believed to be Earth's largest active magma body.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Lithium battery failure wipes out NASA's robot
article: A recent fire at NASA's Jet Propulsion Lab due to lithium battery failure wiped out one of its robots before a test. With the current blast, NASA centres have seen at least four major explosions over the last decade. Reportedly, the explosion was caused due to the fault of the test engineers, who forgot to enable a power management system.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Climate change rate to turn Spain to desert by 2100: Study
article: A France-based study has predicted that southern Spain might be reduced to desert by 2100 if the current greenhouse emission rates remain unchecked. By modelling vegetation conditions in Mediterranean basin, scientists suggested that global temperature would rise up to 5°C by the end of the century, causing deserts to expand northwards and replace Mediterranean vegetation with deciduous forests.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA releases images of ESA's crashed Mars lander
article: NASA has released images of the area where the European Space Agency's Schiaparelli lander crashed, following its descent on October 19. The images show that the lander has created a 50-cm-deep crater onto the Mars surface, possibly due to explosion of a fuel tank. Schiaparelli was aimed at understanding the Martian atmosphere and determining the possibility of life on Mars.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ecologists raise alarm over mosquito-killing fish
article: Ecologists have warned of a predatory fish species, conventionally used to control mosquito populations by eating their larvae, posing significant ecological risks. The 'guppies' are an invasive species with high resilience and fast-growing young, that threaten biodiversity and drive out native fish populations. Moreover, guppy-infested waters show increased nitrogen levels that fuel algae growth.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Assassin bugs ambush spiders in their own webs'
article: A predatory insect species commonly known as 'assassin bugs' hunt spiders by sneaking up on them in their webs. In order to get to its prey, the assassin bug breaks threads of webbing using its forelegs, and holds on to the broken strands to mask vibrations that would otherwise put the spider on alert.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 74-mn-yr-old fossil reveals giant sea reptile battle
article: A 74 million-year-old fossil discovered in Canada reveals a battle between two giant sea reptiles called Mosasaurs. The skull of the 6.5 metre-long reptile had a large hole with an embedded broken tooth, that was found to belong to another Mosasaur. Researchers believe the fossil record points to mating behaviour or male competition and not a predatory attack.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: EU proposes total fishing ban on Atlantic sea bass
article: The European Union has proposed a total commercial fishing ban for sea bass in the Atlantic and whiting in the waters west of Scotland from next year, in order to prevent a collapse in fish stocks. The EU's proposal comes in the wake of fisheries-related research, which reveals that the sea bass numbers have fallen below "safe biological limits".

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Firefly light' enzyme used to monitor brain activity
article: Tennessee-based researchers have used a genetically modified form of luciferase, the enzyme used by fireflies to produce light, to optically monitor activity in the brain. Conventional electricity-based techniques are effective in monitoring individual and small groups of brain cells. The new optical technique offers potential to record the activity of large networks of brain cells simultaneously.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Subsurface map of moon reveals impact craters' origin
article: Using a subsurface map of the moon, scientists have offered an explanation for the formation of 'Mare Orientale', a 930 km-wide bull's-eye-shaped impact feature. Their theory states that the crater caused by smaller original impactor, collapsed inward to form 'Mare Orientale' 3.8 billion years ago. The findings could help understand how similar impacts influenced the early evolution of Earth.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Startup that helps monitor brain health raises $3 million
article: US-based cognitive health startup BrainCheck on Thursday raised $3 million (approx ₹20 crore) in seed funding for its app which lets users monitor their brain health. BrainCheck’s 5-minute long tests help users check for a concussion, or temporary brain damage from a blow to the head, and compare their results with average users.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New technology cures genetic blood disorder in mice
article: A new gene-editing technology developed by Carnegie Mellon University and Yale University, has successfully cured a genetic blood disorder in living mice. The new therapeutic approach, which relies on peptide nucleic acid molecules, was administered using an intravenous treatment. This could aid the technology's use in treating blood related genetic diseases in humans like sickle cell disease.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover two-headed shark embryo growing in lab
article: Spanish researchers have discovered a rare two-headed shark embryo growing in a lab, with each of the two heads having a mouth, brain, heart, stomach, liver and two eyes. The embryo, however, has a single body, intenstine and one set of kidneys. This is believed to be the first time the trait is observed in a shark that lays eggs.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Indian-origin 13-yr-old invents $5 clean energy device
article: Maanasa Mendu, a 13-year-old Ohio-based Indian-American girl, has developed a renewable energy harnessing device that costs $5. Dubbed as 'Harvest', the device uses solar cells coupled with a piezoelectric material to harness energy from the sun, rain, and wind. Mendu's design, which she wants to develop for commercial use in developing countries, won her the 2016 US Young Scientist Challenge.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: FDA approves a new drug as an alternative to chemotherapy
article: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of an immunotherapy drug, Pembrolizumab, as a first-line treatment for people with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC). The drug, which primes the immune system to fight cancer, can be accessed by patients without first having to receive chemotherapy. NSCLC reportedly accounts for up to 90% of all lung cancer patients.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Company selling beer to help save Great Barrier Reef
article: An Australian firm called the Good Beer Company is selling beer to fund the revival of the Great Barrier Reef, the largest living structure in the world. The company launched a crowdfunding campaign in December 2015 to launch its Great Barrier Beer. The firm will donate half of the profits from the beer sales towards the Reef's survival.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why is the brain located inside the head?
article: A four-minute video traces the history of evolution in order to discuss why the brain is located inside the head. The video discusses the 'basic body plan' that nature has used to organise bodies from head to toe. As the nervous system began to become more complex, the early brains became more powerful, needing to be protected inside the 'head'.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: Is it bad to hold your pee
article: A four-minute video stating that humans should urinate at least four to six times a day, discusses the effects of holding pee. Explaining the urinary system, the video explains how the bladder may burst on holding excess amounts of liquid or in some cases rupture the pouch, requiring a surgery to cure it.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Superbugs use "decoys" to avoid death by antibiotics'
article: Superbugs use "decoy flares" to distract antibiotic drugs that would otherwise kill them, a new research has claimed. Conducted on antibiotic-resistant 'MRSA' bacteria, the study found that the micro-organism releases a wave of 'decoy' fat molecules similar to the outer layer of its cellular body. These fat molecules are mistakenly targeted by drugs, which get consumed up in the process.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: MIT develops 3D-printed structures that shrink when heated
article: MIT engineers have developed 3D-printed structures which shrink when heated, unlike the usual behaviour of almost all solid materials which expand on heating. The star-shaped structures were developed using interconnected beams, which in certain architectures pull the structures inward, causing them to shrink when heated to about 282°C. The findings could lead to heat-resistant circuit boards.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What happens to the brain when you space out?
article: A three-minute video discusses the functioning of different brain regions in order to explain what happens to the brain when a person 'spaces out.' The video further talks about studies which state that after a person learns a task, it becomes a routine thus making the brain prone to spacing out.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 1st atomic-level image of 'Marijuana Receptor' created
article: In a first, an international group of scientists has created a 3D atomic-level image of the cannabinoid receptor, the molecular structure activated by tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), which is the active chemical in marijuana. The team said the finding could help answer why some THC-related molecules have complex and harmful effects, and could also guide drug design for pain, inflammation, and obesity.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Lifting weights could boost intelligence: Study
article: Regularly lifting weights could give individuals a cognitive boost, a new Australia-based study suggested. A group of people aged 55 to 86 with 'mild cognitive impairment' (a precursor of Alzheimer's disease) were put on a regime of weight lifting mixed with mental exercise. A causal link was found between an increase in strength and better functioning of the participants' brains.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Archaeologists accidentally discover 41 ancient shipwrecks
article: A team of maritime archaeologists has accidentally discovered 41 shipwrecks on the Black Sea bed, off the Bulgarian coast. Some of the newly discovered shipwrecks are projected to be thousands of years old while some are believed to belong to the more recent Ottoman period. The shipwrecks remained preserved due to low oxygen levels at the seabed.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Heading a football has immediate effect on the brain: Study
article: A study conducted at UK's University of Stirling has found that heading a football causes “significant” changes in brain function after repeated head impacts. The study tested a group of 19 footballers by making them head a ball 20 times and noted the players’ brain function and memory before and immediately after the heading sessions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Harvard scientists create 3D-printed heart-on-a-chip
article: Harvard University researchers have made the first entirely 3D-printed heart-on-a-chip with integrated sensing. They incorporated sensors into the device using six different inks, to facilitate the process of reliable data collection. Organs-on-chips, known as microphysiological systems, are synthetic replacements to living organ tissue and offer alternatives to traditional animal testing.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Long-term space flight gives back problems to astronauts
article: A NASA study has revealed that long-term space flights lead to spinal changes in astronauts, resulting in severe back pain and injuries. The study found that on an average, the cross-sectional area of muscles running along the spine decreased by 19% from pre-flight to immediate post-flight scans, out of which only two-third was recovered even after a month's period.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Europe's Mars lander's crash-landing caused by software bug
article: According to a researcher with the European Space Agency, a software error might have caused the crash-landing of its Schiaparelli Mars lander last week. The bug would have caused the lander to face problems in processing information from sensors, leading it to think that it was closer to the surface than it actually was, causing early cut-off of landing operations.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video describes most efficient way to destroy universe
article: A YouTube video describes the most efficient way of destroying the universe and explains a speculated theory that the process could be as easy as a 'self-destruct button'. The theory, dubbed vacuum decay, states that self-destruction is a concept of energy levels and stability. If the Higgs particles move towards stable vacuum state, the triggered chain-reaction would annihilate the universe.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why does hot pepper make you feel the burn?
article: A three-minute video explains how the spice from a pepper induces heat sensing pain receptors in the mouth to send a signal to the brain in about 0.02 seconds. Consumption of a hot pepper causes the 10,000 taste buds to burn which further causes the nervous system to  generate sweat. It further adds that the pepper's ingredients help kill bacteria.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Habitual lying gets worse over time as brain adapts: Study
article: Telling small lies makes the brain emotionally adapt to committing bigger dishonest acts, a study by London-based neuroscientists claimed. A strong reaction was observed in the emotion-related brain regions of first-time liars in a game, but this effect gradually reduced over time as they played. Further, as players got used to deceiving others for personal gain, they became more untrustworthy.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Begonia plant's blue leaves pull more energy from dim light
article: A new UK-based study has recently found that begonia plants use quantum mechanics and photonics to survive the darkness of the rainforest floor. Scientists found that the blue iridescence of the plant's leaves pulls more energy out of dim light than ordinary leaves. The increased light uptake was found to enhance the photosynthesis efficiency by up to 10%.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What really is Pluto's colour?
article: A three-minute video states that Pluto is rust-coloured, based on the findings of the nuclear-powered spacecraft under NASA's New Horizons mission. The video thus refers to Pluto as the 'the second red planet located in the solar system', the first one being Mars. The video further discusses that up until 2015, Pluto was believed to be 'an icy rocky body'.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: China's space lab Tiangong-2 launches micro-satellite
article: China's space laboratory Tiangong-2, which is orbiting the Earth with two astronauts onboard, launched a micro-satellite on Sunday, state-owned media reported. Weighing around 47 kg, the micro-satellite is roughly the size of a desktop printer and is missioned to take photographs of Tiangong-2 space station and Shenzhou 11 manned spacecraft with a series of visible light cameras.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New 414-legged millipede species found in a California cave
article: A new species of threadlike millipede was recently found in a California cave and is claimed to possess 414 legs. Identified as 'Illacme tobini', the crawly creature is believed to be the evolutionary cousin of  Illacme plenipes, the leggiest animal on the planet. Out of the arthropod's 414 legs, four have been established as "genital legs", used for transferring sperm.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Humans responsible for rise in shark attacks: Study
article: Australian researchers have found that a combination of global warming, coastal development and tourist activity like scuba diving, is partly to blame for a record increase in shark attacks. Warmer waters allow shark populations to increase rapidly and affect the distribution of sharks, while human activities, like increased shipping, interfere with their habitat leading to unprovoked shark bites.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Man-made noise puts animals at greater risk from predators
article: In a first, UK-based study on mongooses has found that man-made noise can have a detrimental impact on an animal's use of scent, putting them at greater risk of being attacked by predators. Scientists found that road-noise playback negatively affected the mongooses' ability to use olfactory information to detect predator faeces, making them more vulnerable to danger from predators.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists trace plant hormone pathway back 450 mn yrs
article: Purdue scientists have traced a plant hormone's function back to over 450 million years of evolution and have tracked the hormone's pathway that has been passed along and co-opted by new species. Scientists found that the abscisic acid (ABA), which is used by flowering plants to keep seeds dormant till germination, also plays a key role in determining ferns' sex.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Twice-born' baby underwent surgery before normal birth
article: Lynlee Boemer, a baby girl in Texas, was "born twice" as she was removed from her mother's womb prematurely for a critical operation and was then returned for another 12 weeks until her normal, healthy birth. She had to be taken out as a nearly 24-week-old foetus for a 20-minute procedure after doctors found an apparent tumour on her tailbone.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Humans will live in glass domes on Mars: Elon Musk
article: SpaceX Founder Elon Musk, who last month unveiled the plan to colonise Mars, has said the colony would have "glass panes with carbon fiber frames to build geodesic domes on the surface, and a lot of miner droids". He added, "You can build a huge amount of pressurised space for industrial operations and leave the domes for green living space".

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Universe expansion constant, not accelerating, claims study
article: According to an Oxford study, the universe is not expanding at an accelerating pace, but rather at a constant rate. The study analysed a dataset of 'supernovae', or massive star explosions, and found the data was more consistent with the constant expansion hypothesis. This casts doubt on the 2011 Nobel Prize-winning discovery stating that the cosmos is undergoing accelerating expansion.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Iceland drilling 5-km hole to tap energy from magma
article: Iceland Deep Drilling Project is drilling a 5-km deep hole aiming to tap energy from volcanic magma in the earth's crust. The renewable energy project, 'Thor', will utilise extremely high pressures to generate 'supercritical' steam, which is neither gas nor liquid but holds more energy than both. It is expected to be 10 times more efficient than traditional geothermal wells.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists find way to stop sperm's ability to swim
article: UK-based scientists have discovered a way to switch off sperm's ability to swim by making cell-penetrating peptides, which get inside sperm and make men infertile. These compounds stop the sperm from wiggling their tails, giving it no chance of fertilising an egg. The advancement could eventually help in developing male contraceptive pills.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rare snail with anti-clockwise shell struggles to find mate
article: A garden snail in the UK was born with a rare genetic mutation, causing its shell to spiral anti-clockwise. This lowered its chances of finding a potential mate, since snails mate face-to-face, sliding past each other on the right-hand side for their genitalia to meet. To copulate, it must beat one in million odds to find another 'sinistrally mutated' snail.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Blood molecule may help develop long-lasting battery: Study
article: A molecule that transports oxygen in blood could help develop longer-lasting batteries, according to Yale University researchers. The 'heme' molecule has been found to facilitate a process called 'oxygen evolution reaction', which increases the efficiency of lithium-oxygen batteries. These batteries have a much longer life than standard lithium-ion batteries used in consumer electronics.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Zika virus found to change human cells
article: The Zika virus changes part of the human genetic material to "hide in plain sight", says a new study by California-based researchers. When the virus enters a cell, the cell reacts by modifying the virus' RNA, activating human enzymes that could possibly impact the cell's barriers. The study could help develop drugs that combat Zika the way it targets cells.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: First snapshots of rapid chemical bonds breaking
article: Kansas-based physicists used laser imagery to capture the first real-time snapshots of chemical bonds breaking in quadrillionths of a second. They used an intense laser to remove an electron and initiate the breakup of an acetylene molecule, composed of two hydrogen and two carbon atoms. The advancement will help scientists better understand and control chemical reactions.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains the effect of altitude on human body
article: A four-minute video explains how the atmospheric pressure and oxygen amount is based on the altitude, to discuss its effects on the body. Stating that areas above 25,000 feet are called the 'Death Zone', the video elaborates the bodily changes it causes. It further explains how respiration rate and heart rate increase, as the body tries to get more oxygen.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: $100 mn project to make intelligence-boosting implant
article: Bryan Johnson, the Founder and CEO of US-based startup Kernel, has announced a $100 million investment into the development of a brain implant device which can boost human intelligence. According to Johnson, the first experiments for the device will focus on memory enhancement. He added that work was also being done on personalised algorithms to dictate an individual's brain function.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New giant herbivorous dinosaur discovered in Australia
article: The remains of a new species of giant herbivorous dinosaur have been found in the grasslands of Queensland, Australia. The 95 million-year-old species, named 'savannasaurus elliottorum', is a member of the dinosaur group 'sauropods', which have long necks and four thick legs. It belongs to a subgroup called 'titanosaurs', believed to be the largest dinosaurs to have ever lived.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Temporary oxygen deprivation could cure jet lag: Study
article: A temporary dip in body's oxygen levels could reverse the effects of jet lag, according to a new study conducted on mice. It was found that reducing the oxygen content by up to 33% for a two-hour span caused the mice to quickly adapt their circadian rhythm, the master body clock in the brain, to new conditions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: US announce initiative to promote use of small satellites
article: The US has announced an initiative to promote the use of small satellites or 'smallsats'. The project, "Harnessing the Small Satellite Revolution," will see collaboration between government agencies like NASA, and the private sector to find practical uses for these satellites. Smallsats can help provide internet access, monitor space traffic and can also be used as tools by planetary scientists.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Oldest known planet-forming disc discovered
article: Scientists claim to have discovered the oldest known circumstellar disc, a gas and dust ring that orbits a young star and from which planets can form as the material collides and aggregates. The disc was found orbiting a red dwarf star estimated to be around 45 million years old. Such discs usually fade away within 30 million years, scientists added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Effects of air pollution may be transgenerational'
article: Adverse effects of air pollution may linger on in Delhi for generations to come, a new study by the US-based National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences has revealed. The impact of air pollution may be transgenerational and can affect foetus' genes. Also, it may create a lot of incurable diseases like asthma, cancer and stroke, the study says.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: UV light treatment improves smartphone cameras: Study
article: Treating photodetectors, used in smartphone cameras, with UV light improves their frequency response, according to a study by Moscow-based researchers. They found that exposing a polymer-based photodetector incorporated with zinc oxide nanoparticles to UV light for 30 seconds increased its sensitivity nearly 5,000 times. The process is "quick, cheap and efficient", the researchers claimed.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Climate change can make fish swim towards predators: Study
article: According to a study by University of Exeter biologists, climate change impairs the survival instincts of fish and can even make them swim towards predators, instead of away from them. The team found high carbon dioxide levels affect the way in which brain processes signals from sensory organs and disrupts the senses of fish including their smell, hearing and vision.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Planet 9' could be found in 16 months, claim scientists
article: With up to 10 research groups looking for the solar system's hypothetical 'Planet Nine', astronomers have claimed the planet will be discovered within 16 months. The unidentified planet is believed to be responsible for long elliptical orbits of frigid objects in the outer solar system and is estimated to be about 10 times more massive than Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Simulation breaks virus apart to learn its assembling
article: Carnegie Mellon University researchers have developed a computer simulation which they claim can provide a platform to visualise the assembling of proteins and viruses. The simulation enables scientists to build the virus, crush the protein shells that encapsulate viruses and see what happens at high-resolution levels. The team believes this development can aid targeted drug delivery in future.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Jupiter image shows its sunlit swirling atmosphere
article: An image of the sunlit part of Jupiter and its swirling atmosphere was created by a citizen-scientist using data from Juno's JunoCam instrument, which have been made available for the public by NASA. The enhanced image titled 'Jupiterrise' was created by processing Juno's south pole images. Launched in 2011, Juno is on a mission to study Jupiter's origins and evolution.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: More than 2 soft drinks a day doubles diabetes risk: Study
article: A Sweden-based study has found that consuming more than two 200 ml soft drinks a day, more than doubles the chances of developing Type 2 diabetes. Scientists found that consuming about five drinks daily, increases the disease's likelihood by more than 10 times. Daily soft drink habit was also found to increase risks of less common autoimmune diabetes in adults.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: SAARC satellite likely to miss December deadline
article: The South Asian satellite project announced by PM Narendra Modi two years ago as a ‘gift’ to India's neighbouring nations, is likely to miss the December deadline. The delay has been attributed to ISRO's GSLV Mark III, the satellite launch vehicle which is scheduled to be sent to space in December 2016.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New smart gloves can monitor Parkinson's patients
article: US-based researchers have developed smart clothing, including gloves and socks, capable of monitoring Parkinson's disease patients. The clothing material is embedded with sensors which measure tremors and rigidity, the common symptoms of the neurological disease. The sensors relay all the data to the connected cell phone, which processes the data and can help the doctors manage treatment plans.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Eruptions on solar system's most volcanic body tracked
article: UC Berkeley astronomers have tracked around 50 volcanic hotspots on the surface of Jupiter's moon 'Io', known to be the most volcanically active body in the solar system. Scientists observed the heat coming off the active eruptions as well as cooling lava flows during a 29-month-period to determine the temperature and total power output of individual volcanic eruptions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Saturn's north polar region changed colours in 4 years
article: Images from NASA's Cassini spacecraft show the changing colours of Saturn's north polar region between 2012 and 2016. Scientists believe the colour change from a bluish to a more golden hue is due to seasonal effects, one of which is the increased production of photochemical hazes in the atmosphere as the north pole approaches summer solstice in May 2017.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make battery elements using fossilised algae
article: University of California researchers have used fossilised remains of single-celled algae called diatoms to create silicon-based anodes for ultra-high capacity lithium-ion batteries. Researchers found that preservation of the diatoms' cell walls could be used to create porous anodes that allow easy access for the electrolyte. These batteries could be used to power electric vehicles in future.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: India's Chandrayaan-1 helped NASA detect water on Moon
article: Using data from instruments aboard India's Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft, NASA scientists in 2009 found evidence of water locked in mineral grains on the moon surface. The findings represented the first detection of this form of water from lunar orbit. The researchers earlier used to believe that the moon rocks were completely dry and any water detected was considered contamination from Earth.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why do we get  dark circle under our eyes?
article: A two-minute video explains the science behind dark circles, stating that the area under the eye looks darker because the skin is thinner and doesn't have a lot of fat. The video further states that dark circles depend on the thickness of the skin and a person's genes. The video additionally discusses the correlation between tiredness and dark circles.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists claim hexagonal clouds behind Bermuda Triangle
article: American researchers claim to have found a possible reason behind the Bermuda Triangle where several ships and airplanes have disappeared.
