They analyzed a NASA satellite's images and found hexagonal clouds over the 1.3 million-square-km of ocean between Bermuda, Puerto Rico and Florida. These clouds could be creating 106-kmph wind "air bombs" capable enough to bring down planes and topple ships.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: '250,000-yr-old aluminium object may be UFO wreckage'
article: An aluminium object found buried in Romania has been dated nearly 250,000 years old, which the researchers believe is wreckage from an unidentified flying object (UFO). Tests revealed that the fragment contains almost 90% aluminium, a metal humans started manufacturing only about 200 years ago. The discovery has raised speculations that extraterrestrial life had visited Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: India's 1st lunar mission Chandrayaan-1 was launched in 2008
article: India's first ever mission to moon 'Chandrayaan-1' was launched successfully from Sriharikota on October 22, 2008. With a lift-off mass of 1,380 kg, the spacecraft was missioned to map a three-dimensional atlas of the moon and the surface's chemical and mineral composition. The mission was concluded when communication with the spacecraft was lost on August 29, 2009.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why we can't live stream from Mars?
article: A four-minute video details how radio waves help in capturing and transmitting pictures and data from satellites, in order to explain why it is not possible to transmit videos. The video states that it depends on how much information radio waves can carry. It further adds that the limiting factor in radio communications is the bandwidth or the wave frequency.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains science behind white lines on nails
article: A two-minute video describes the white lines on nails, which are sometimes called 'milk spots'. Breaking the myth that white spots are caused by calcium or zinc deficiency, the video states that they are usually a sign of "trauma to the nail", meaning it has been bumped or hit. In some cases, parallel white lines may also depict poisoning.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Indian-origin scientist 3D-prints 'real' hands in lab
article: A Michigan-based Indian-origin researcher and his team have created life-size 3D hand models, complete with fingerprints, using a high-resolution 3D printer that can produce the same ridges and valleys as a real finger. The team created the 'fake hands' to test the robustness and reliability of commercial fingerprint scanners used at banks and airport immigration counters.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mars lander lost signal one minute before landing: ESA
article: European Space Agency has confirmed that its ExoMars 2016 mission's landing module lost signal just one minute before it touched down the Red Planet's surface. However, scientists have not revealed whether it landed safely or crashed on the surface. Scheduled to land on October 19, the 577-kg lander began its descent on October 16, after separating from its mothership.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Human history mostly the history of stupidity: Hawking
article: Talking about the changes AI would bring, theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking said, "We spend a great deal of time studying history, which, let's face it, is mostly the history of stupidity." He was speaking at the opening of an AI centre at the Cambridge University. "It's a welcome change that people are studying instead the future of intelligence," he added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists create map of hydrogen associated with Milky Way
article: Scientists have created an animated "all-sky" map of the neutral atomic hydrogen emitted by the Milky Way galaxy and nearby galaxies. Dubbed HI4PI, the detailed map was produced using millions of observations and around 10 billion data points by the world's largest steerable radio telescopes in Germany and Australia. Neutral atomic hydrogen is the primary component of stars and galaxies.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study finds 1.8mn-yr-old evidence for right-handedness
article: US-based scientists have found what they claim is the earliest-known evidence of the bias against left-handers. By examining striations on teeth of the 'Homo habilis' fossil, scientists suggested these markings could have formed when the primate used a tool with right hand to cut the food in its mouth, while pulling it with the left.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Researchers find loophole in Second Law of Thermodynamics
article: US-based scientists announced they might have discovered a loophole in the 'Second Law of Thermodynamics', which states that entropy always increases. Scientists showed a mathematical construct to a possible local violation, predicting conditions under which the law is violated and entropy actually decreases. Scientists proposed the concept could be used to design a remotely-cooled "refrigerator".

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Volcano stopped 2016 Japan earthquake in its tracks'
article: Japan's 2016 Kumamoto earthquake may have been stopped in its tracks by the magma chamber underneath the active volcano Mount Aso, according to Japan-based geoscientists. Imaging of the ground beneath the volcano revealed that the rupturing caused by the earthquake abruptly stopped at a depth of 6 km, which coincides with the upper boundary of the volcano's magma chamber.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: European Mars probe destroyed after crash
article: Using images from NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, the European Space Agency (ESA) confirmed that its Schiaparelli Mars lander crashed violently on the Martian surface and possibly exploded on impact. Based on the markings on Mars' surface caused by the landing module, ESA estimated the lander dropped from a height of 2-4 kilometres, impacting at a speed greater than 300 kmph.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Smart sock adds sensations to prosthetic limbs
article: Austrian researchers have created a sock using conductive fabric to help provide lower limb amputees with a natural sense of touch through prosthetic limbs. The sock creates a pressure-sensitive grid covering the entire foot and ankle, which is connected to a ring of vibrating motors. Pressure on a certain part of the foot causes motors to vibrate at different frequencies.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Dinosaurs 'crossed continents' 10 crore years ago
article: Scientists have recently discovered two fossils belonging to sauropods in Australia, suggesting the giant dinosaurs were living worldwide about 10 crore years ago. Scientists have theorised that the dinosaurs originated in South America and reached Australia by crossing Antarctica. It is believed that global temperature increase helped them to traverse icy landmasses between continents.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Rubber hand illusion' reveals how brain understands body
article: Italy-based researchers have used the 'rubber hand illusion', a trick that deceives the mind into sensing a fake rubber hand as its own, to explore how brain combines information from the senses to create a feeling of body-ownership. Scientists found that when people experienced the illusion, the strength of electrical pulses that got through their real right hand dropped dramatically.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mice feel each other's pain: Study
article: Scientists have recently discovered that mice can scent when their fellows are suffering, even though they are out of sight. They found healthy mice housed in the same room with mice experiencing pain, are up to 68% more sensitive to pain themselves, irrespective of their own stress levels. This could help develop a novel mechanism for pain transmission among humans.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Tiny DNA tweaks made snakes legless: Study
article: Netherlands-based scientists recently found that the predecessors of modern snakes lost their legs and became limbless due to genetic tweaks. They found that the gradual mutations in DNA, located near a gene which is important for limb formation, keep that gene from turning on, leading to the evolutionary trend of limb reduction in snakes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Ripples in space could help understand cosmic rays: Study
article: As per a Sweden-based research, there are ripples or surface waves moving along the surface of shocks (particle accelerators) in space. By utilising measurements from NASA's Magnetospheric MultiScale satellites, scientists have suggested that these ripples could affect how plasma is heated and help in the understanding of cosmic rays (the high-energy radiations travelling through space).

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Female meerkats make twice as much testosterone as males
article: Duke University researchers have recently found that some female meerkats can produce twice as much testosterone as males. Scientists also found that the female meerkats with naturally high levels of testosterone-related hormones are more likely to be leaders. However, such females were found to have a weakened immune system as compared to the other female meerkats.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Global wine produce to fall by 5% due to 'climatic events'
article: According to International Organisation of Vine and Wine, 2016's global wine production is expected to fall by 5% due to "climatic events" like El Niño. Global wine output is estimated to fall to 259.5 million hectolitres, making 2016 one of the least productive years in last two decades. Argentina and Chile have been predicted to witness the biggest declines.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Spiders can 'tune' their webs to identify mates
article: According to an Oxford research, spiders can 'tune' their webs to help them locate and identify potential mates as well as prey. Scientists found that the spiders can control the tension and stiffness of their webs by transmitting vibrations in different frequencies through the spider silk, allowing them to control how sensory information is getting back to them.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Nurses spreading anti-vaccination messages face prosecution
article: Australian nurses and midwives spreading anti-vaccination messages through social media are facing prosecution, a statement by 'Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia' said. The statement also urged the public to report those promoting false or misleading information as it is prosecutable by law. According to WHO, vaccinations prevent up to three million annual deaths from diseases like measles.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists create holograms from neutrons
article: In a first, a team of scientists have used neutron beams to create holograms of large solid objects. Researchers used a beam of neutrons and an interferometer (a detector that measures interference patterns) to create direct visual representations of an object. Scientists claim the new holograms are capable of measuring even 10-micron sized structures within the object.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Rare sea creatures found in ocean trenches
article: Scientists have found several rare undersea creatures including "mud monsters" and purple orbs during expeditions to some of the Pacific's deepest trenches this year. Notably, around 500 new undersea methane vents, bubbling the greenhouse gas, have also been found as a result of the expeditions. Scientists believe the discoveries might help them in better estimating the methane emissions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Europe loses contact with its Mars lander during descent
article: European Space Agency said it lost contact with its ExoMars 2016 mission's landing module and is "uncertain" if the module landed on Mars in working condition. Scheduled to land on October 19, the 577-kg lander began its descent on October 16, after separating from its mothership "Trace Gas Orbiter", which has successfully launched itself into an elliptical orbit around Mars.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Artificial intelligence can destroy society: Stephen Hawking
article: British physicist Professor Stephen Hawking at the inauguration of Cambridge University's artificial intelligence (AI) centre on Wednesday said that AI will either "transform" society or destroy it. "Success in creating AI could be the biggest event in the history of our civilisation...but it could also be the last unless we learn how to avoid the risks," he said.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: How much force does it take to break a bone?
article: A three-minute video, stating an adult being has 206 bones, discusses how much force is needed to break a bone. Explaining how different bones have varying strengths, the video states that an estimated force of 4,000 newton could break the largest human bone, the thigh bone. It further adds that breaking a bone depends on how the force is applied.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Possible ninth planet may be causing solar system tilt
article: A possible ninth planet beyond Neptune may be responsible for the solar system's tilt, according to California-based astronomers. The plane on which the eight known planets orbit the sun, itself rotates at a 6° angle, making the sun appear angled. A giant planet orbiting about 30° off the other planets' plane, could account for that tilt, the astronomers suggested.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Why some people faint at the sight of blood?
article: A three-minute video explains how fainting at the sight of blood is related to a blood-injury phobia. According to the video, anxiety causes the blood pressure to increase and then decrease suddenly, causing a person to lose consciousness. The video further explains how blood being pumped away from the brain makes a person pass out.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 301 mammal species at risk due to meat trade: Study
article: A world-first global assessment of human hunting impacts found that 301 mammal species are primarily at risk from human hunting for the bushmeat trade. The list includes 168 primate species, 21 rodent species and 12 carnivore species. Earlier, in 2011, the Center for International Forestry Research had estimated that six million tonnes of bushmeat were being extracted each year.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: What happens to human bodies after death?
article: A four-minute video details what happens to the human body after death, stating how it passes through several stages before it begins decomposing. Once the heart stops beating, the blood immediately begins to settle in the body's lowermost parts. After skin's discolouration, the body begins to stiffen leading up to decomposition, the process in which bacteria breaks apart the body.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Higgs Boson scientist develops birth control algorithm
article: Elina Berglund, one of the scientists who helped discover the Higgs boson particle, has developed a birth control algorithm, which has an efficiency of 99.5%. The 'Natural Cycles' app's users need to input their body temperatures daily and it will tell them when they can have unprotected sex (a green day), and when to use contraceptives (a red day).

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mechanism behind animals' ability to sense temp change found
article: American biologists have recently uncovered the molecular mechanism which regulates animals' different behavioral responses to fast and slow rise in temperature. They found that when the thermosensory brain neurons sensed fast temperature change, a writhing response was stimulated and a protein called TRPA1 turned on quickly. These responses were less active when temperature increased slowly.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 10,000 endangered 'scrotum frogs' found dead
article: More than 10,000 Titicaca water frogs have reportedly been found dead in Peru's Lake Titicaca and its adjoining rivers, the only place the species can be found. These "scrotum frogs" are already listed as critically endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. Severely polluted waters have been cited as the possible cause of mass death of the amphibians.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Unknown X-ray 'bursts' in different galaxies spotted
article: Astronomers with NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory have spotted two X-ray sources erupting in two different galaxies, becoming 100 times brighter in less than a minute. One of the 'ultraluminous' X-ray sources was the brightest ever observed in an elliptical galaxy. Scientists have hypothesised that the phenomenon could be caused by star matter rapidly falling into an intermediate-mass black hole.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Bear known for walking on 2 legs killed by hunters: Reports
article: Pedals, a black bear famous for walking on its hind legs like a human, has reportedly been shot dead by hunters in New Jersey's first legal bow-and-arrow bear hunt in four decades. Anti-hunt activists have ascertained that the 151-kg heavy bear was one of the 562 bears shot by bows and guns in the six-day hunt in the state.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains what a stroke does to the body
article: A four-minute video discusses the effects of a stroke on the body, explaining how it can be caused by a clot in the blood vessels or because of internal bleeding in or around the brain. The video further states that strokes often result in permanent impairments such as paralysis, loss of sensory functions, or even regulation of emotions.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: In pictures: 2016 Wildlife photographer of the year
article: American photographer Tim Laman won the '2016 Wildlife Photographer of the Year' for his image 'Entwined Lives', showing a critically endangered Bornean orangutan making a 30-metre climb. Given for a story told in six images, the award judges photographs' story-telling power along with individual quality. The images will reportedly go on display at London's Natural History Museum from October 21.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Common cold medicine could stop cancer spread: Study
article: Japan-based scientists have discovered that a drug used for treating common cold could be used to stop the spread of bladder cancer, the seventh most common cancer in males worldwide. Scientists found that injecting flufenamic acid, an anti-inflammatory drug, suppresses the cancer cells' invasive tendencies in mice and also reduced its resistance to chemotherapy.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover physical source of depression
article: China and UK-based researchers claim to have identified the brain areas affected by depression. They found depression affects brain's lateral orbitofrontal cortex, which is responsible for a non-reward mechanism. Researchers said this link is likely the reason why people living with depression often feel a sense of loss associated with not receiving rewards, low self-esteem and unhappy memories.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Monkeys observed making sharp stone objects
article: Capuchin monkeys have been observed making sharp stone flakes that resemble the tools made by primitive humans 2-3 million years ago, proving the ability is not uniquely human. The monkeys, however, were found to make these objects without the intention to use them as tools. One explanation is that they seek out the quartz dust produced by smashing the rocks.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Tasmanian devil milk kills antibiotic-resistant bugs'
article: As per a study by Australian researchers, milk from Tasmanian devil, the world's largest surviving carnivorous marsupial, could kill antibiotic-resistant bacteria. It can also combat the facial tumour disease which has killed 80% of the Tasmanian devil population in 20 years. The study found the devil's milk contains antimicrobial peptides, effective against many pathogens including golden staph.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Venus might still have active volcanoes: Study
article: A German study suggests that Venus' volcanoes might still be active today as it claims that at least one of them erupted quite recently. Using near-infrared and high-resolution imagery, researchers discovered heat variations consistent with fresh lava flows around the 200-km wide 'Idunn Mons' volcano. The team however said it is not 100% sure that Idunn Mons is still active.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 2-month-old receives liver transplant in Gurgaon
article: A two-month-old Nigerian boy Ayogbadebo 'David' Oyetunde received a liver transplant in Gurgaon in August, doctors recently announced. David, weighing 2.1 kg during the surgery, is also the first child to survive neonatal hemochromatosis, a condition wherein excess iron is deposited in the liver and other organs. After nine weeks, he weighed 3 kg and had normal liver functions.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 15,000-yr-old cave art unveils hybrid of cattle, bison
article: Ancient DNA research has unveiled that Ice Age artists recorded a previously unknown hybrid species of bison and cattle on cave walls over 15,000 years ago. Known by the researchers as the 'Higgs Bison', the species is estimated to have originated over 120,000 years ago through hybridisation of extinct Aurochs and Steppe bisons, eventually becoming ancestors of modern European bisons.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA probe spots possible clouds over Pluto
article: NASA scientists claim to have identified cloud candidates over Pluto, based on images taken by its New Horizon mission in July 2015. The presence of clouds indicates that the weather on Pluto is "more complex than [previously] imagined", NASA said. The records also show Pluto's brightest areas are among the most reflective in the solar system and indicate surface activity.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists link migraines with gut bacteria
article: A recent study has found migraine sufferers have more gut bacteria, that have the ability to modify chemicals called nitrates, compared to people without migraines. Scientists hypothesised that greater bacteria amounts in the oral cavity may contribute towards migraine-triggering conversions of nitrates to nitric oxide, a chemical known to cause headaches by dilating blood vessels in the brain.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Quantum bit 10 times more stable than usual created
article: Australian engineers have created a new quantum bit that they claim can retain quantum information for 10 times longer than previously achieved. The new quantum bit, made up of a single silicon atom's spin merged with a strong electromagnetic field, is believed to dramatically expand the number of calculations that could be performed by future silicon quantum computers.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: $20 mn contest selects 27 solutions for CO2 emissions
article: A global competition organised by innovation engine Carbon Xprize has selected 27 teams as semi-finalists to compete for the $20 million prize. The teams will test their technologies for converting carbon dioxide emissions into valuable products over 10 months and will be scored on how much carbon dioxide they convert and the net value of their products.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Jupiter orbiter in 'safe mode' after software issue
article: NASA's Juno spacecraft went into safe mode just before its latest Jupiter flyby, making it unable to collect any scientific data. NASA said this was caused by a possible software issue, prompting Juno's onboard computer to initiate a 'safe' reboot, turning off instruments and some non-critical spacecraft components. Since July 4, Juno has made a Jupiter flyby every 53 days.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Aim for Nobel prize: Harsh Vardhan tells scientists
article: Union Minister for Science and Technology Harsh Vardhan has urged scientists to build great passion for scientific experimentation and to "keep eye on Nobel Prize". The appeal was made by the minister while speaking at the inauguration of a WHO cGMP plant which is a new addition to the Indian Institute of Integrative Medicine (IIIM), Jammu.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: September 2016 is the warmest September on record: NASA
article: September 2016 is the warmest September in the 136 years of modern record-keeping, according to a monthly analysis of global temperatures by NASA. The mean temperature of the month this year was 0.004ºC more than 2014 September, the previous warmest, and 0.91ºC more than the mean of September temperatures from 1951 to 1980.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Thomas Edison proposed to his wife in Morse code
article: American inventor Thomas Edison had proposed to his wife in Morse code, and she responded 'yes' in the same way. Edison had taught his wife the code so that they could converse secretly even when their families watched. In Morse code, letters can be represented by dots and dashes and even combinations of long and short light or sound signals.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Thomas Edison's 'last breath' is stored in a test tube
article: Henry Ford Museum displays a test tube reportedly containing American inventor Thomas Edison's last breath. Henry Ford and Edison were close friends, and Ford had asked Edison's son to preserve the inventor's last breath. The test tube is one of the several that were lying close to the death bed of Edison, who breathed his last on October 18, 1931.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Nazi magazine put Einstein's pic with label “Not Yet Hanged”
article: A Nazi organization once published a magazine with physicist Albert Einstein's picture on the cover, with the caption "Not Yet Hanged". The Nazis also attempted to boycott Einstein's study as 'Jewish Physics' and reportedly put a price on his head. Einstein decided to leave Germany to avoid Nazi hostility and arrived in the US on October 17, 1933.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 6 of 7 Americans to win the Nobel this year are immigrants
article: All six US-based Nobel winners in 2016 in Science and Economics are immigrants. Physics winners Duncan Haldane, Michael Kosterlitz and David Thouless are UK-born, Chemistry laureate Sir J Fraser Stoddart is Scotland-born and the Economics prize was shared by UK-born Oliver Hart and Finland-born Bengt Holmström. This was the first instance since 1999 that no American-born scientist claimed a Nobel.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Highest cliffs in the solar system are on Uranus' moon
article: The highest cliffs in the solar system are on Uranus' moon Miranda, according to the Guinness World Records. Named Verona Rupes, measuring nearly 33,000 feet high, they are more than ten times the height of the walls of the Grand Canyon in Arizona. The cliffs were discovered by NASA's Voyager 2 which encountered Uranus and its moons in 1986.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Zebra-donkey hybrid born in China zoo
article: A hybrid between a zebra and a donkey was born in a zoo in the Chinese city of Suqian. The animal, the offspring of a male donkey and female zebra, has the striped legs of a zebra but the head and body of a donkey. Although zebra-donkey hybrids are relatively rare, hybrids have been born in Italy and Mexico.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Healthy mice born from lab-grown eggs
article: Japanese scientists claim to have created healthy mice from lab-grown eggs using a sample of mouse skin cells. The team reprogrammed the mature cells back into immature ones, and grew them into egg cells. Then the eggs were fertilised using artificially grown sperm and put into adult female mice's wombs. The newborns from this technique went to have babies themselves.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Ultrasound slows brain's ageing: Study
article: A University of Queensland research on mice has recently discovered that ultrasound slows the ageing process of healthy brains. Scientists found that treatment with ultrasound scanning prevented the degeneration of neuronal cells in hippocampus region of brain, the region responsible for brain ageing. Scientists believe that the new anti-ageing approach could help in keeping human brain younger.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: World's largest nuclear power station to remain shut
article: Japan's anti-nuclear politician, Ryuichi Yoneyama, who recently became the governor of the Niigata city, has reportedly said he will not restart the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa power station, the world's largest nuclear power plant. The seven-reactor site with a capacity of eight gigawatts was shut down after the Fukushima disaster in 2011. Reportedly, only two of Japan's 42 reactors are currently running.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: In Pictures: Nikon microscope photography competition
article: Nikon has released the final round of photographs for its 42nd annual 'Small World' competition for photos clicked using microscopes. Over 2,000 images from all over the globe were entered into the competition, and 95 were selected for the finals. The images include a jumping spider's eyes, a butterfly's proboscis, a wasp's head and a human cell undergoing division.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains what causes cavities
article: A five-minute video explains how tiny microbes in the human mouth form communities of bacteria, depending on a person's sugar consumption. The video states that sugary foods cause an explosion of bacteria, who produce acids like the lactic acid which degrades the enamel covering of the teeth. Eventually, acid enters the inner layers of the tooth, thus, spreading the infection.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: Can humans survive prolonged space travel
article: A five-minute video explains how prolonged space travel would affect humans, with microgravity impairing muscle and bone growth, and high doses of radiation causing irreversible mutations. Explaining how humans have previously adapted to harsh conditions, the video however states humans could potentially "develop methods to program protective abilities" over a period of time.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Two secret Maya tombs unearthed in Guatemala
article: Archaeologists have unearthed two Maya tombs in Gautemala that are claimed to give insight about the snakehead emblemed Mayan dynasty. The artefacts including the jade-inlaid teeth and a puzzling sun-god pendant obtained during the excavations date back to 650-700AD (the era of Maya dominance). The findings could help in understanding the politics and war-related aspects of the "snake kings".

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Bill Gates-backed nuclear reactor design tech being made
article: Small, cheaper modular nuclear reactors are being developed in the US and are claimed to be safer alternatives as compared to traditional power plant designs. Funded by investors like Bill Gates, the reactors are designed to produce 50-300 MW power. The technique does not require pumps and relies on gravity and convection for cooling the reactors.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Stretchy fibres developed for implanting in body
article: MIT and Harvard researchers have co-developed a biocompatible and stretchable optical fibre which can be implanted in the human body. It is made from hydrogel, an elastic, rubbery material composed mostly of water. Scientists believe the bendable fibre could be implanted in the body in future to deliver therapeutic pulses of light and sense signs of disease.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA Space Station cargo successfully launched to ISS
article: NASA's latest commercial resupply mission Cygnus was successfully launched from Virginia into space on Monday. The spacecraft is missioned to deliver over 2,313 kilograms of cargo supplies to its International Space Station. The cargo aboard the Cygnus is estimated to support about 250 science and research studies including studies on fire in space and measuring neutrons.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ultraviolet view of Mars reveals cloud formation
article: Global images of Mars from NASA's MAVEN (Mars Atmosphere and Volatile Evolution mission) reveal previously invisible behaviour in the Martian atmosphere. They include the first images of "nightglow" that show how winds circulate at high altitudes. Further, ultraviolet imagery shows how ozone amounts change over the seasons and how afternoon clouds form over Martian volcanoes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 1st artificial cell-like spheres of proteins developed
article: German scientists have developed what they claim to be world's first artificial cell-like spheres from natural proteins. With attractive forces acting between individual hydrophobins (naturally existing protein molecules), it was found that a stable bilayer of natural proteins reconfigured to form a vesicle. The research could help in developing more precisely targeted drug-delivery systems.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Project to observe forests' reaction to global warming
article: A US-based research project is aiming to determine how tropical forests will react to rising temperatures caused by greenhouse gas emissions. The team is using suspended heaters in Puerto Rico's Luquillo forest to heat the soil and undergrowth to 4ºC above the forest's ambient temperature. Researchers suggest that tropical soils might release more carbon dioxide as temperatures rise.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Hawking's project investigating signals from 234 stars
article: Stephen Hawking and billionaire Yuri Milner-funded project, 'Breakthrough Listen initiative' is reportedly investigating strange signals from 234 stars that have the same periodicity. Reportedly, astronomers had been analysing light signals from 2.5 million stars observed by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. The project is investigating claims of extra-terrestrial life by two researchers.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists launch new Antarctic research mission
article: The first scientific full circumnavigation of the ice-covered Antarctica was officially launched on Monday, according to reports. The 'Antarctic Circumpolar Expedition' will reportedly witness the participation of over 50 scientists from 30 countries. The scientists will study Antarctica's islands including both landmass and ocean in an attempt to study climate change and measure pollution.

author: Parichit Mainra
abstract: Antibiotic use at record levels in European farms
article: "Critically important" antibiotics are being used in record quantities on farm animals across Europe, according to a report by the European Medicines Agency. Experts have warned that consuming meat of these farm animal might endanger humans as they will develop resistance to the drugs and this might also foster the development of superbugs resistant to the antibiotics.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 14,000-year-old cave paintings found in Spain
article: Around 50 rock paintings dating back to about 14,000 years have been unveiled in a cave located under a building in Spain's Lekeitio town. Measuring up to 150 centimetres long, the paintings depict horses, bisons and lions among others. The cave art has been marked "the most spectacular and striking" of its kind ever discovered on the Iberian peninsula.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Construction of Sir David Attenborough research ship begins
article: Construction of polar research ship 'RRS Sir David Attenborough' officially began on Monday in England. The $243 million research vessel, named after the British broadcaster and naturalist Sir David Attenborough, will explore the Antarctic waters up to depths of 6,000 metres and would be able to remain at sea for several months at a time.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Sensor for detecting vitamin B12 deficiency developed
article: Australia-based scientists have developed what they claim is the world's first optical sensor that can measure and track vitamin B12 levels in human blood serum. The sensor uses an optical measuring technique called Raman spectroscopy to produce a unique optical fingerprint of the target B12 molecules in less than a minute. Currently, the sensor is at a proof-of-concept stage.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New type of microscope uses nanowires as sensors
article: Switzerland-based researchers have developed a new type of Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) using nanowires as tiny sensors. With a diameter of 100 nanometres, the nanowires are composed of tiny filamentary crystals which are built-up molecule by molecule from various materials. Unlike the standard AFMs, the new device is capable of measuring both the size and direction of forces.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Man once dissolved Nobel medals to save winners from Nazis
article: The Nobel Prize medals of two German physicists, James Franck and Max von Laue were dissolved in 1940 to save the laureates from the Nazis. The medals were sent to physicist Niels Bohr's laboratory in Denmark, and they were dissolved after the Nazi occupation of Denmark. The medals were later recast using the original gold and presented to the laureates.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists reverse Alzheimer's disease in mice
article: University of Minnesota researchers claim to have reversed the memory loss characteristic of Alzheimer's disease in mice. The team found a potential target, a naturally occurring enzyme called 'caspase-2', which attacks brain cells by splitting a protein 'tau' in two, causing memory malfunctions. By reducing the level of 'caspase-2', the team discovered that existing memory losses were restored.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Astronomers identify 2 extra moons behind Uranus
article: Moscow-based astronomers have discovered what they believe are two previously-identified moons behind Uranus after re-examining old data collected by NASA's space probe Voyager 2. They found wavy patterns in two of Uranus' surrounding rings, consistent with gravitational pull from moons. Voyager 2 could not detect the two moons clearly as they are small, up to 14 km in diameter.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Kashmiri Red Stag to be declared as 'Critically Endangered'
article: The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) would be declaring the Kashmiri Red Stag or Hangul as a 'critically endangered species'. Hangul has been hunted over centuries and its habitat destroyed, leading to its wild population shrinking to 150. The IUCN had earlier categorised it as of 'Least Concern' by clubbing it with European and other 'red deer' species.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Europe's Mars lander starts descent to red planet
article: European Space Agency (ESA)'s Schiaparelli Mars lander on Sunday separated from its mothership and began descent towards Mars' surface. It will test technologies for Europe's first Mars rover, which will launch in 2020 and search for signs of past and present life. The lander and its mothership make up the ExoMars 2016 mission, a collaboration between ESA and Russia's Roscosmos.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Wild chimps filmed teaching offspring how to use tools
article: The first documented evidence of wild chimpanzee mothers teaching their children how to use tools has been captured by camera traps. The footage features a young chimpanzee using a fishing probe in the same way as demonstrated by its mother. Scientists believe such observations could help better understand the relationship between the cultural activities of humans and their closest relatives.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Exercising when angry could triple heart attack risk'
article: Exercising while angry or emotionally upset can increase heart attack risk by three times, according to a recent study. Being very angry more than doubles the risk of a heart attack within an hour, while heavy physical exertion does the same, earlier studies had suggested. Both can raise blood pressure and reduce blood supply to the heart, a researcher said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Fossil suggests dinosaurs made honking sounds
article: Dinosaurs made sounds similar to a crocodile honking or an ostrich booming, according to a recent fossil finding. Found in the Antarctic, the fossil is the oldest known vocal organ of a bird, that lived during the age of dinosaurs. The particular organ has not been found in other non-birdlike dinosaur fossils, dismissing the belief that dinosaurs squawked like birds.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Newly-found molecule may help fight obesity: Study
article: American researchers have identified a molecule called Beta-LGND2, that may help fight obesity and other metabolic diseases by converting 'bad' or white fat to 'good' or brown fat. Initial tests conducted on mice suggested that activation of Beta-LGND2 by the oestrogen receptor Beta triggers the conversion of white to brown fat. Brown fat increases metabolism, which helps with weight loss.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Harvard creates first quantum computer 'bridge'
article: Harvard University researchers have demonstrated for the first time, a bridge to link small quantum computers on a single chip. By forcefully embedding silicon atoms in a matrix of carbon atoms, they created a quantum network wherein all atoms behave like a single atom. Exciting those silicon atoms with a laser causes them to emit photons that carry quantum information.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA delays plan to put Juno closer to Jupiter
article: NASA has decided to delay the burn of its Juno probe's main rocket motor designed to put the spacecraft closer to Jupiter. The decision was taken in order to check the performance of a malfunctioning set of valves that are crucial to the firing of the spacecraft's main engine. The manoeuvre will be undertaken in December during a close flyby.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Lego-like wall to produce acoustic holograms developed
article: American researchers have developed a Lego-like wall made of synthetic materials that can create 3D acoustic holograms from sound waves. They used an array of 3D printed plastic material blocks containing spirals within, to modify a sound wave into any 3D shape at a specific distance. This could have applications in stereo speakers and ultrasound imaging.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Brain-fixing injectable wires to be tested on humans
article: A brain-fixing technology involving injection of wire mesh into the brains is scheduled to be tested on human patients with epilepsy, after its successful testing on mice. The technology developed by Harvard researchers uses a thin mesh made from gold and polymers. The technique works by preventing neurons' death and is claimed to treat Parkinson's and other neurological diseases.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop atom-sized MRI imaging technique
article: Australia-based researchers have developed an atomic-scale Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scanner, capable of imaging the structure of a single biomolecule. No information is lost or damaged using the new system which uses atom-sized quantum bits as highly sensitive sensors to image individual biomolecule atoms. The advancement may become a key tool for drug discovery and other biotech research.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Rare hunter's supermoon to appear this weekend
article: Two lunar events, a supermoon and a hunter's moon, are predicted to be witnessed simultaneously this weekend. A supermoon occurs when the moon is in the closest part of its orbit to Earth while a hunter's moon is October's full moon. The moon is estimated to appear about 14% bigger than the smallest full moon due to the rare event.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Gravitational waves may permanently alter spacetime'
article: Gravitational waves permanently alter the space-time fabric as they ripple through the universe, according to physicists. The concept, gravitational wave memory, dictates that once a gravitational wave passes through a region, the distance between two points in that region may not be the same as before. Gravitational waves are generated when objects with mass move around in spacetime.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New software can predict molecular chemical properties
article: Scientists have developed a new software called 'Knowledge-driven ligand extractor' (Knodle) which they claim can predict a molecule's chemical properties. It uses machine learning to determine an individual molecule's atomic hybridisation and bond states. The program can help develop effective drugs by reducing the number of trials needed to pinpoint how a drug interacts with its target.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains how sound can create light
article: A four-minute video explains a phenomenon called 'Sonoluminescence', meaning the "emission of short bursts of light from imploding bubbles in a liquid when excited by sound". According to the video, the effect can be produced by sound with the right frequency moving through water. The video further details how the change in air pressure produces heat, thus creating light.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Heavy cannabis use reduces bone density: Study
article: A University of Edinburgh research has revealed that people who regularly smoke large amounts of cannabis have reduced bone density and are more prone to fractures. The study also found that heavy intake of the drug lowers body weight, which could further contribute to bone thinning and consequently, increase the risk of osteoporosis in later life.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Electron spin info passed through a superconductor
article: In a first, Harvard researchers have transmitted electron spin information through superconducting materials. The electron spin was harnessed by creating an asymmetric arrangement for electron pairs' movements by building a sandwich with superconductors on outside and mercury telluride in middle. This could open new possibilities for storing quantum information in quantum superconducting devices.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Experts discover two 'cavities' in Egypt's Great Pyramid
article: Egypt's Great Pyramid of Giza could contain two previously unknown 'cavities', said scientists studying the millennia-old monument. Using radiography and 3D reconstruction, the scientists were able to point out two "voids" in the pyramid, one behind its northern face and another behind its north-eastern flank. The pyramid was built 4,500 years ago under ancient Egyptian Pharaoh Khufu.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: VR to be used to remind Mars astronauts of home
article: NASA scientists are researching on the prospects of using virtual and augmented reality experiences to help astronauts fight the "sensory and social monotony" of a Mars mission. Scientists hope to create a library comprising of inspirational messages, which would remind the astronauts of their mission on the Red Planet and help them feel connected with their families on Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Microbes that can convert coal to methane discovered
article: Japan-based researchers have discovered microbes capable of converting organic compounds from coal emissions directly into methane. Identified as 'ZC-1' & 'AmaM', the two microbe strains were found to convert methoxylated compounds to methane without any assistance from other methyl compounds. The find could support the future production of methane, which is a commonly used form of natural gas.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Britain fails to recycle 16m plastic bottles per day
article: A recent research has revealed that about 16 million used plastic bottles constituting almost half of daily British household usage, are not recycled and are passed to the landfill sites. These plastic bottles which eventually end up in oceans can have huge impacts on marine life. The number is estimated to spring up to 29 billion in next five years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Extinct wingless wasp found in 100-mn-year-old amber
article: Researchers have discovered a new extinct parasitic wingless wasp in Myanmar, encased in 100-million-year-old amber. The bug is part of the newly-created family named 'Aptenoperissidae', of which a female insect, named 'Aptenoperissus burmanicus, is the only known specimen in the modern world. Scientists have suggested the wingless insect could not fly but had a sharp stinger for attacking rivals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Archaeologists unearth child's 600-year-old shoe
article: Archaeologists unearthed a child's leather shoe during excavations at England's town of Newton Abbot, which they claim dates back to the 1400s. A number of other artefacts, including wooden barrels and a millstone, have also been unearthed at the site. The artefacts did not rot reportedly due to waterlogged clay soil which prevented organic materials like leather from being oxidised.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's largest solar plant costing $5 bn proposed
article: California-based renewable-energy developer SolarReserve is planning the world's largest solar energy project, costing an estimated $5 billion. The plant could generate energy equivalent to two nuclear power plants, enough to power one million homes. The proposed concentrated solar plant (CSP) is said to be built over 15,000 acres in Nevada's desert and will have a capacity of two gigawatts.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create mid-air display of 'floating pixels'
article: England-based researchers have created a levitating display of 'floating pixels', called JOLED, that can be controlled and manipulated using sound waves and electric force fields. In the display, each pixel can be rotated on the spot to show different colours and images. The technology may help create floating displays or bring computer game characters to life as physical objects.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Startup to launch 50 satellites to monitor Earth every day
article: Japanese startup Axelspace is working on project 'AxelGlobe', a constellation of 50 satellites equipped with imaging sensors, that will monitor the Earth every day. The startup will take six years to complete the project. Axelspace will provide a paid access to the collected data, that can be used to detect changes in specific areas of Earth and track crop growth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Coral captured ejecting algae under heat stress
article: In a first, Australian researchers have captured footage of coral from the Great Barrier Reef ejecting out algae in response to heat stress. Change in conditions such as temperature, light or nutrients cause corals to expel algae living in their tissues, turning them completely white. The team used a microscope and digital camera to record time-lapse videos of the coral.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Surface of moon changes every 81,000 years: Study
article: According to a study using data from NASA's lunar probe, the moon gets continuously bombarded by space rock causing its surface to change every 81,000 years, which is 100 times more frequently than previously thought. The study estimated that asteroid and comet crashes create on average 180 new craters at least 10 metres wide on the Lunar surface every year.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Antibody found to 'cure' HIV-like infection in monkeys
article: Scientists claim to have discovered an antibody that can 'functionally cure' immuno-viral infection in monkeys. Monkeys treated with the antibody, which is also used to treat inflammatory bowel disease, showed negligible simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) levels, 9 months after treatment was stopped. In conventional antiretroviral (ARV) therapies, virus levels relapse after treatment is stopped.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New project aims to map human body's 35 trillion cells
article: An international collaborative effort titled 'Human Cell Atlas Project' has been announced, which will aim to create a comprehensive map of the approximately 35 trillion cells in the human body. The project will attempt to decipher the types and properties of every cell a person contains, whether healthy or diseased, in a bid to speed up discoveries in medical science.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Paralysed man senses 'feeling' through robotic fingers
article: A 28-year-old US man left paralysed after a car accident has admitted experiencing the sensation of touch after a robotic arm was connected directly to his brain, in a world-first breakthrough. The 'brain-computer interface' used small electrodes surgically implanted in the man's brain and enabled him to feel pressure in his own fingers when the robotic ones were touched.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Observable universe contains 10 times more galaxies'
article: A new study using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has revealed that there are at least 10 times more galaxies in the observable universe than previously thought, increasing the number to around two trillion galaxies. According to the authors, the missing 90% of the universe's galaxies are too faint and too far away to be detected by the current telescopes.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Great Barrier Reef not dead, but severely stressed'
article: Following a writer's claim that the largest living structure the Great Barrier Reef "passed away in 2016 after a long illness", several scientists said the reef is severely stressed, but not dead yet. It would never recover from the most catastrophic bleaching event ever, the writer added. However, a scientist insisted parts of the reef would still live in 2050.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains what is dark matter
article: A seven-minute video explains what is dark matter, an unidentified type of matter comprising approximately 27% of the mass and energy in the observable universe. Dark matter, which came from the Big Bang, is assumed to conserve parity, meaning that it can't decay into ordinary matter. The video adds that dark matter is believed to be heavy and "rarely interactive".

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explores possibility of biologically not ageing
article: A three-minute video states that the right amount of stress and oxidation to mitochondria, the powerhouse of cell, could help stop or delay the body from ageing biologically. Explaining how the ageing process actually takes place in humans, the video discusses different studies that helped delay the ageing cycle in different species.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Grass to reduce methane emission from cows being made
article: Danish scientists are attempting to formulate a new type of grass which could be more efficiently digested by cattle, reducing the amount of methane gas cows generate. The project seeks to develop a strand of 'super grass' by 2024, that can also enable cows to produce more milk. Notably, around 90 million tonnes of methane is released annually by cattle.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA develops laser map of BWB airplane model
article: US space agency NASA's engineers have developed a technique to map the flow of air over a Boeing Blended Wing Body (BWB) airplane model. The 'particle image velocimetry' technique works by recording the movement of tracer particles pulsating across the model. This would allow smoother air flow over the wings and will help in reducing fuel consumption by the aircraft.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Massive iceberg breaks off from Canada's glacier
article: A massive iceberg recently broke off from Canada's Porcupine Glacier and is claimed to be the "biggest calving event" in North America in last three decades. Estimated to cover around 2 square kilometres, the iceberg is currently floating in British Columbian ice-fields. Notably, Porcupine Glacier has been thinning at a rate of around 2.5 inches per year.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Newly discovered plant neither photosynthesises nor blooms
article: A new species of mycoheterotrophs, small-sized plants which do not photosynthesise, has been discovered in Japan and has also been found to produce flowers that never bloom. Identified as 'Gastrodia kuroshimensis', the newly discovered species derives its complete nutrition from the host fungi and produces flowers in which self-fertilisation occurs within closed buds.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Rare hunter's supermoon to appear this weekend
article: Two lunar events, a supermoon and a hunter's moon, are predicted to be witnessed simultaneously this weekend. A supermoon occurs when the moon is in the closest part of its orbit to Earth while a hunter's moon is October's full moon. The moon is estimated to appear about 14% bigger than the smallest full moon due to the rare event.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Comet strike may have started ancient global warming'
article: According to a recent study, a comet may have struck Earth around 55 million years ago, triggering an atmospheric carbon surge, raising temperatures by up to 8°C and causing huge wildlife migrations and extinctions. As evidence to their claim, the researchers announced the discovery of glassy, dark beads that look like microtektites, the debris created when comets strike Earth.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: People with autism make more logical decisions: Study
article: People with autism are more likely to make logical decisions, a London-based study suggests. Autistic individuals were found less likely to follow intuition and emotions in decision-making, as compared to others who often 'follow their heart'. The study used a gambling test, revealing that people with a condition common in autism gambled on basis of numerical information rather than 'hunches'.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: MIT researchers set new record for nuclear fusion
article: In a first, MIT researchers have created the highest-ever plasma pressure, the key ingredient to producing energy from nuclear fusion, in a nuclear fusion device. By achieving 2.05 atmospheres of pressure in a magnetically-confined 'Alcator C-Mod' reactor, the feat surpassed the previous best by 15%. Notably, the reactor simulates fusion conditions of sun-like stars to produce carbon-free energy.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Experiment to weigh neutrinos starts in Germany
article: Germany-based physicists have started performing experiments to determine the mass of neutrinos, the universe's lightest particles, using a $66-million-machine. Scientists believe the KATRIN experiment would help to narrow the range of neutrinos' weight and will help in better understanding the history of universe. Over 150 scientists worldwide are reported to participate in the experiment.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Temperature difference drives droplets: MIT
article: MIT researchers have discovered that temperature difference drives fluid droplets across surfaces. By developing a system which allows precise control of droplets through temperature regulators, scientists found that temperature difference causing changes in surface tension drives water droplets. Scientists believe the finding could help in developing self-cleaning surfaces and de-icing methods.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New dwarf planet found in solar system beyond Pluto
article: Astronomers claim to have found a new dwarf planet in the outer reaches of the solar system, beyond Pluto. The rock, named 2014 UZ224, is about 530 km wide and 13.7 billion km from the Sun, and takes about 1,100 Earth years to orbit it once. Notably, experts predict there are around 1,000 potential dwarf planets in our solar system.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ancient rock formation may be world's oldest observatory
article: Researchers have calculated a stone formation's age at a historic Australian Aboriginal site, which they claim could prove to be the world's oldest astronomical observatory. The 10,000-year-old structure could also prove to be older than the Stonehenge and Egyptian pyramids. Named 'Wurdi Youang', the arrangement, formed using about 90 blocks of basalt, was reportedly used to track sun's movement.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Spiders can detect speech metres away, without ears
article: Spiders can detect human speech from several metres away, even though they do not have ears, a Cornell University research has discovered. Their acute sense of vibration is owing to sensitive hairs on their legs. The study, conducted on North American jumping spiders, further revealed the species was most sensitive to frequencies matching that of its natural predator, a wasp.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video lists lesser known facts about the Earth
article: A six-minute video by YouTube channel 'Top Lists' states some lesser known facts about the Earth, explaining that the Earth would be "smoother than a billiard ball" if shrunk, while maintaining its proportions. The video further states that there are "seas full of gold" with estimates of a minimum of 15,000 tons of gold available in the water bodies.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: PM Modi to inaugurate 104th Science Congress in Jan
article: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will inaugurate the five-day 104th Indian Science Congress at the Sri Venkateswara University in Tirupati on January 3, the organisers said on Friday. Andhra Pradesh CM Chandrababu Naidu will also accompany Modi. Nine Nobel prize winners, four in Physics, three in Chemistry, and one each in Economics and Peace would also take part in the meet.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Silkworms spin 'super silk' after eating graphene
article: Chinese researchers have created a carbon-reinforced silk, that is two times stronger than regular silk, by feeding silkworms mulberry leaves coated with graphene. The tougher, more durable, and more conductive silk has applications in wearable electronics and medical implants among others, researchers said. It is an easy way to produce high-strength silk fibres on a large scale, reports said.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Aus farm grows tomatoes in desert using solar energy
article: A farm in the South Australian desert is reportedly expected to produce over 15,000 tonnes of tomatoes per year using only solar energy and seawater. Greenhouse developer Sundrop Farms developed the $150 million farm, where nearby seawater is desalinated and used in the irrigation. Reportedly, the project was started in 2010 and scientists have been fine-tuning the design since then.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: European Space Agency to attempt Mars landing on Oct 19
article: The European Space Agency (ESA) will attempt to land its Schiaparelli landing module on the Martian surface on October 19. If successful, the ESA will become only the second space agency after NASA to land a spacecraft on Mars. The module, which was launched in March, will test the technology needed for Europe's 2020 rover landing on the Red planet.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Over-drinking may cause fatal water intoxication: Study
article: Australian researchers have found over-drinking may cause potentially fatal water intoxication, decreasing the blood's sodium concentration to become abnormally low. The researchers identified the mechanism that regulates fluid intake in the human body and showed a 'swallowing inhibition' to over-drinking. "Just drink according to thirst rather than an elaborate schedule", a researcher suggested.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 1st heartbeat occurs 16 days after conception: Study
article: According to an Oxford study done on mice, the first heartbeat occurs 7.5 days after conception, which is equivalent to 16 days in the human embryo. Until now, the first heartbeat was thought to occur eight days after conception in mice, equivalent to 21 days in human pregnancy. Notably, the heart is the first organ to form during pregnancy.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: 'Newly discovered Earth-like planet may have oceans'
article: Recently discovered Earth-like planet Proxima b, which lies in the "habitable zone" of the Proxima Centauri star, may be covered with oceans and support life, astrophysicists at France's CNRS institute have said. Proxima Centauri is about four light-years from Earth and is part of a three-star system called Alpha Centauri, which is the closest star system to the Solar System.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: California scientists discover new type of earthquake
article: Southern California-based scientists have discovered a new type of earthquake that occurs in the Earth's upper mantle as opposed to the understanding that earthquakes occur in the top half of the planet's crust. The new earthquakes occurred a lot deeper than expected, more than 24 kilometres deeper, and cannot be detected by traditional seismic sensors.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team of scientists propose "1st nation state in space"
article: A team of scientists and legal experts has proposed plans for the "first nation state in space", dubbed Asgardia. Its citizens will physically be on Earth and will be citizens of their own country simultaneously, the project lead said. The team would officially apply to the UN for the status of state if the applications cross one lakh, he added.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: China appoints basketball player as ambassador to Mars
article: China has appointed Basketball player Yao Ming as its ambassador to Mars, in order to promote country's first mission to the Red Planet in 2020. Ming is one of the eleven ambassadors the state has recruited to generate support for its Mars mission. China notably aims to send a rover to Mars to join NASA's Curiosity spacecraft.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Hubble detects 'cannonballs' shooting from star
article: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has detected giant "cannonballs", almost twice the size of Mars, being ejected from near a dying star 1,200 light-years away. The plasma balls zoom at about one-million-kilometres per hour, equivalent to covering the Earth-moon distance in less than 30 minutes. Scientists estimated that the event has continued once every 8.5 years for at least 400 years.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Mars-bound astronauts could develop dementia: Study
article: US-based researchers have warned that exposure to cosmic rays during extended trips to Mars may cause long-term severe cognitive side effects, including chronic dementia and memory loss. The study follows another research which showed short-term effects of space travel. "Many of these adverse consequences to cognition may continue and progress throughout life", researcher Charles Limoli said.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Giant jellyfish cover New Zealand coastline
article: Thousands of kilometres of the New Zealand coastline have been covered by giant jellyfish, including Lion’s Mane, the largest jellyfish in the world. Experts have linked warmer sea temperatures providing fertile breeding grounds and a lack of predators due to 'excessive' fishing, to the occurrence. Booming jellyfish populations are being reported worldwide, including in Britain and Japan.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: 'People with more money think they have more problems'
article: A recent study by Pennsylvania State University researchers has found that people with relatively more money and education report feeling a lot more stress at work than people with lower salaries and fewer degrees. People with higher incomes reported being about 28% more stressed and 8.3% less happy than workers with lower incomes and levels of education.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Material made for more sensitive heartbeat readings
article: London-based researchers have created a new sensor material that could enable a more sensitive reading of biological signals, such as heartbeats and brainwaves. The current electrochemical transistors measure biological signals but they are only able to measure certain signals. The new material enables detecting positively charged ions, which are important to study neuron activities in the body.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA to allow private firms to install modules on ISS
article: US space agency NASA has announced that it will let private companies install their own habitat modules and other capabilities to the International Space Station (ISS) starting this fall. The agency plans to give the low-Earth orbit to the private sector and claimed that it is working to support and grow the community conducting research and growing businesses in space.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Dog's tooth reveals 7,000 year-old 400-km hunting trip
article: UK-based archaeologists investigated a dog's tooth found near the prehistoric monument Stonehenge in England, which revealed a 400-kilometre hunting trip made 7,000 years ago. The trip made by a Stone Age hunter-gatherer and his dog is believed to be the earliest known journey in British history. The hunter was using a domesticated dog, probably for hunting, researchers said.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: South Africa gets Africa's 1st solar-powered airport
article: South Africa's coast town George has got the continent's first solar-powered "green" airport. The regional airport has 2,000 solar panels which produce up to 750 kW daily, while the regular requirement is 400 kW. The excess is supplied to the municipal power grid. The airport has lately reduced its carbon emissions by 1,229 tonnes, equivalent to 1,03,934 litres of fuel.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: UN ratifies 1st ever pact to curb aircraft emissions
article: The United Nations has ratified an agreement to curb the aircraft emissions, the first such pact to set worldwide limits on a single industry. The pact, adopted by 191 nations, sets the countries' airline emission in 2020 as their 'allowed discharge' limit. Airlines which will emit in excess will have to buy carbon credits to compensate for the discharge.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains whether gut feelings actually exist
article: A four-minute video explains how the bacteria in the gastrointestinal tract (gut) prompt the gut to turn into a complex neural network, thus inducing gut feelings. The video states that the network is sometimes called the 'second brain', with the gut-brain connection forming a two-way communication. The video further discusses how this connection is recognised to interpret gut feelings.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Brewery wastewater used to create energy storage cells
article: American researchers have developed a method which uses biological organism cultivated in brewery wastewater to create a carbon-based material needed to make energy storage cells. The process will reduce expensive wastewater treatment costs for beer makers and create renewable fuel cells, scientists said. Breweries reportedly use about seven barrels of water for every barrel of beer produced.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: 'Martian gardens' to find veggies to grow on Mars
article: Simulated "Martian Gardens" are being used by space agency NASA to find out the most suitable vegetables to grow during future manned missions to Mars. Martian soil consists of crushed volcanic rock with no organic material, making it nearly impossible for plant life to survive, NASA said. The soil used in "Martian Gardens" simulates the soil on the Red planet.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: 109 glacial lakes formed in Himachal in last two years
article: A total of 109 glacial lakes were formed in Himachal Pradesh in the past two years, a government study claims. The number of glacial lakes increased from 596 to 705, raising the danger of glacial lake outburst floods. The study has attributed the rise to the accelerated glacial melting in the Chenab, Ravi, Beas and Satluj river basins in Himachal.

author: Rini Sinha
abstract: Indian-origin man tests self-repairing roads in K'taka
article: Nemkumar Banthia, an Indian-origin professor based in Canada, has tested a self-repairing road in Thondebavi (90 kilometres from Bengaluru). These roads are made of fibres with a nano-coating that attracts water. Combining with unhydrated cement, this water enables cracks to heal and keeps the roads hydrated. The road, completed in late 2015, has survived almost a year without any problems.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Physicists create world's first Time Crystal
article: American physicists have created the first ever Time Crystal, a structure periodic in space and time first proposed by Nobel-prize winning physicist Frank Wilczek in 2012. In a Time Crystal, particles in their lowest-energy state move in a perpetual motion without releasing rotational energy. In crystals, the system is spatially unsymmetrical and releases energy to reach the lowest energy state.

author: Kabir Khan
abstract: Scientists want to send a telescope to Alpha Centauri
article: A consortium of private organisations are looking to send their own space telescope to our nearest neighbor Alpha Centauri. They've united together under the name Project Blue and hope to raise enough money to circumvent NASA and do it off their own backs. The group is backed by some heavyweight names including SETI, UMass Lowell and the BoldlyGo Institute.

author: Kabir Khan
abstract: New species of British Jurassic reptiles discovered
article: Scientists have identified a new species of extinct marine reptiles, that lived during the age of the dinosaurs, from fossils collected over a century ago. The newly identified species of British ichthyosaur, which resembled dolphins or sharks, were ocean dwelling reptiles. Ichthyosaur lived around 200 million years ago, a time when the UK was a small series of islands.

author: Parichit Mainra
abstract: China's 'extinct' baiji dolphin spotted
article: Chinese animal protection volunteers claim that they have spotted a freshwater 'baiji dolphin', which was declared to be 'functionally extinct' 10 years ago, in China's Yangtze River. In the 1950's, the river was home to over thousands of baiji dolphins, also known as 'white dolphins'. Their population diminished over the years due to overfishing, dam building, and pollution.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: British trio win 2016 Nobel Prize in Physics
article: The 2016 Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to the British trio of Duncan Haldane, David Thouless and Michael Kosterlitz for their work on exotic states of matter. The three physicists discovered a mathematical framework in the field of topography, to explain unexpected properties of solid materials. The discoveries have paved the way for designing materials with new properties.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: World's 1st satellite was the size of a beach ball
article: The World's first artificial satellite Sputnik I, launched by USSR 59 years ago on October 4, 1957, was about the size of a beach ball, measuring 58 centimetres in diameter. Carrying a radio transmitter, the satellite transmitted a signal to Earth for 23 days. Amid the cold war between US and USSR, Sputnik's launch directly led to NASA's foundation.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: International Space Station crew sees 16 sunrises every day
article: The International Space Station (ISS) crew sees 16 sunrises and sunsets every day, because of the Station's high speed. The ISS orbits at about 400 kilometres above the Earth at a speed of approximately 28,000 km/hr. It takes about 90 minutes to circle the Earth once, and the astronauts see a sunrise or sunset every 45 minutes.

author: Mansha Mahajan
abstract: Video: Launch of world's 1st artificial satellite Sputnik I
article: A one-minute video shows the launch of the world's first artificial satellite, Sputnik I, which took place on October 4, 1957. Launched by the Soviet Union, the satellite was 58 cm in diameter, weighed 83.6 kg, and took around 98 minutes to orbit the Earth. Notably, the satellite's launch marks the start of the Space Age.

author: Mansha Mahajan
abstract: Video explains 2016 Nobel Prize in Physics
article: A minute-long video explains this year's Nobel Prize in Physics, which has been awarded to British trio David Thouless, Duncan Haldane, and Michael Kosterlitz. The video explains how this year's laureates used a branch of mathematics called 'topology', to study unusual phases of matter like superfluids. The video claims that topological materials could be useful for new generations of electronics.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Boeing CEO claims to send people to Mars before Elon Musk
article: World's largest aerospace company Boeing's CEO Dennis Muilenburg on Tuesday unveiled a plan for commercial space flights and claimed to send people to Mars before SpaceX's Elon Musk. “I’m convinced the first person to step foot on Mars will arrive there riding a Boeing rocket,” said Muilenburg. He said Boeing is planning to make a supersonic aircraft for the purpose.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Earth hottest in about 115,000 years: Study
article: According to a recent study, Earth is currently hotter than it has been in last 115,000 years. Experts have suggested that with a heating rate of 0.18°C per decade, Earth is driving towards an interglacial era where sea level was 6-9 metres higher than today. The study estimated several hundred trillion dollars will be required to avoid runaway temperature rises.

author: Animesh Choudhary
abstract: Chemistry Nobel awarded for making world's smallest machines
article: Jean-Pierre Sauvage, J Fraser Stoddart and Bernard L Feringa won the 2016 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for the design and synthesis of molecular machines. The scientists had contributed to making machines 1000 times smaller than the human hair, including a four-wheel drive nanocar, molecular motors and lifts. The award also includes 8 million Swedish Krona (US$1.1 million) in prize money.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Only 1 person has won the Chemistry Nobel Prize twice
article: British biochemist Frederick Sanger remains the only person to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry twice. He received the award in 1958 and 1980 for his work on the structure of proteins and nucleic acids respectively. The Cambridge University Professor, was the fourth person to win a Nobel twice; after Marie Curie, Linus Pauling and John Bardeen.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Our part of Milky Way is 4 times bigger than thought'
article: An international team of radio astronomers has found that the 'Local Arm' region of the Milky Way containing the solar system extends to over 20,000 light-years, roughly four times larger than previous estimations. The study also suggested that the Milky Way galaxy does not have well-defined arms, but it is a spiral shape with branches.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 2,400-yr-old corpse found covered with cannabis plants
article: Archaeologists have unearthed a 2,400-2,800 years old corpse wrapped in cannabis plants in a prehistoric tomb in China. The team said the metre-long cannabis plants appeared to have been arranged as a "burial shroud". The findings reveal that cannabis was used by the people in local Central Eurasia for ritual or medicinal purposes during that time, researchers said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Meteorite crash 56 mn yrs ago led to first primates'
article: American geologists claim they have found evidence of a meteorite crash that happened about 56 million years ago, which might have given rise to the first primates. The event is known as the Paleocene period, wherein the planet witnessed rapid warming and increase in carbon dioxide levels. The event also gave rise to other mammals like Artiodactyla and horses.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Human lifespan has hit its natural limit at 115: Study
article: According to a recently-published research, human lifespan has hit its natural limit at around 115 years despite advances in medicine which help cure diseases affecting old people. Further, researchers suggested no one is likely to outlive Jeanne Calment, who died aged 122 as the oldest human that ever lived. For the research, demographic data from 41 countries was analysed.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New contact lens made that can check glucose levels
