article: Researchers at the University of Houston have developed a new type of contact lens that could allow non-invasive testing of glucose levels in tears. The lens was made using multiple layers of gold nanowires stacked on top of a gold film. The device uses surface-enhanced Raman scattering technique which monitors light's interaction with a material to determine its molecular composition.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Boys born using IVF technique inherit poor fertility: Study
article: According to a recent study, boys conceived using the IVF technique have almost half the sperm concentration and motile sperm count than average. The assisted reproductive technology involves combining sperm and egg in a laboratory dish and then transferring the embryo to the uterus. Researchers said the study confirmed that sons would inherit the problems that caused their father's infertility.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Smallest transistor is 50,000 times thinner than human hair
article: US Department of Energy has created the world's smallest transistor with a working one-nanometre gate, about 50,000 times thinner than human hair. The prototype was built with semiconductor materials called transition metal dichalcogenides, instead of silicon. Interestingly, the laws of physics had set a 5-nanometer limit on the size of transistor gates among conventional semiconductors.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Global dust storms could hit Mars soon: NASA
article: A global dust storm is likely to hit Mars in the coming months as the red planet is reaching the mid-point of its current storm season on October 29, space agency NASA's scientists have predicted. Correct prediction of the storms would be helpful for future astronauts, as it affects their health, electronics and solar energy availability, researchers said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Nobel panel member uses bagel to explain 'topology'
article: A member of the Nobel Committee for Physics, Professor Thors Hans Hansson explained the science behind 2016 Physics Nobel Prize-winning research using a cinnamon bun, a bagel and a pretzel. The three British scientists, who won the 2016 Nobel prize for physics, used a branch of mathematics called topology to explain unexpected properties of solid materials such as superconductivity.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Researchers find explanation for hidden ocean tides
article: In a first, MIT scientists have accurately simulated the "internal tides" which are hidden in the ocean interiors between warmer, shallow water, and colder, deeper water. The tides' chaotic patterns were explained by two oceanic structures between which "internal tides" rebound at particular angles. Scientists believe the simulations could result in better sonar and safer offshore structures.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: How is the universe expanding?
article: A five-minute video discusses a recent study stating that the universe is isotropic, meaning  not varying in magnitude depending on the direction of measurement. The video further uses an example of a balloon being continuously inflated to explain how the universe expands. It also uses the example explaining why the universe has no centre.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Trained bees found to transfer skills to other bees
article: British scientists trained bumblebees and found them to transfer the skills they have learned to other bees. Researchers said the experiments, often used to test the intelligence of apes and birds, showed for the first time that some insects can exhibit the behavior. In the experiments, 60% bees were able to successfully learn the skill by observing the trained bees.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Satellite tagging infection kills a rare orca
article: A rare male orca, or killer whale, which died this year, was killed by an infection caused by satellite tagging, the US environmental research agency has confirmed. Researchers said the tagging device used was not cleaned per protocol, causing a lethal infection. The 20-year-old whale was found dead near a Canadian island in March, a month after it was tagged.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA releases ISS footage of 'Hurricane Matthew'
article: NASA has released a footage of the Hurricane Matthew, a Category 4 storm, which was recently captured from the International Space Station (ISS). A major hurricane in the Caribbean Sea with wind speeds reaching up to 220 kmph, Hurricane Matthew attained Category 5 status late on Saturday. The Atlantic hurricane hit the Caribbean country Haiti late on Monday.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Another Saturn moon Dione may have subsurface ocean'
article: A subsurface ocean may lie deep within Saturn's fourth largest moon Dione, according to new data from NASA's Cassini spacecraft's mission to Saturn. The data's geophysical analysis has suggested an estimated 100-km thick crust is covering a 65-km deep subsurface ocean in Dione. Two of Saturn's moons, Titan and Enceladus, are already known to harbour subsurface oceans under icy crusts.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Prof takes classes on day of winning Nobel in physics
article: Duncan Haldane, who won this year's Nobel Prize in Physics, took his regular classes at Princeton University hours after learning that he has won the prestigious award. "It's a matter of duty or pride to go back and do one's job," Haldane said and added, "any one of them could discover something tremendous and new and win a Nobel Prize."

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New 20-million-yr-old extinct shark species identified
article: An international team of researchers has discovered a new extinct shark species based on the findings of 20-million-year-old fossilised teeth, that measured up to 4.5 centimeters tall. The newly discovered species has been named 'Megalolamna paradoxodon' and is believed to be ancestors of the great white sharks. Scientists have estimated the shark to be roughly four metres long.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Japan's Yoshinori Ohsumi gets 2016 Nobel Prize in Medicine
article: The 2016 Nobel Prize in Medicine has been awarded to Japanese cell biologist Yoshinori Ohsumi for his discoveries about autophagy or how the body's cells detoxify and repair themselves. He studied baker's yeast to find the genes that regulate this "self-eating" process. Ohsumi's work helps explain what goes wrong in a range of diseases, from cancer to Parkinson's.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's first artificial pancreas approved in US
article: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved the world's first artificial pancreas. The 'Medtronic MiniMed 670G' is a smartphone-sized device that continuously monitors blood sugar levels and delivers needed insulin to Type 1 Diabetes patients, and is expected to hit markets in spring next year. Notably, Type 1, or early onset diabetes has no known cure.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: 1st man-made object to go to space was created by Nazis
article: The Nazis created the V-2 rocket, which became the first man-made object to go to space after a successful test launch, 74 years ago on October 3, 1942. The rocket, created to be used in strikes during WWII, travelled 190 kilometres during the test launch. Notably, due to Nazi atrocities, more people died manufacturing it than were killed by it.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: World's tallest wood building is 53 metre high
article: The construction of the world's tallest 53-metre high wood building was recently completed in Canada. The carbon dioxide stored by the 18-storey wood building will reduce 2,432 metric tonnes of the gas, which is equivalent to taking 500 cars off the road for a year. It took less than 70 days and approximately $51.5 million to complete the building.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Hydropower accounts for 1.3% of greenhouse gases'
article: Hydropower reservoirs, which are considered to be a major source of low-carbon electricity, account for about 1.3% of world's annual human-caused greenhouse gas emissions, a new study has claimed. Methane was found to be produced by underwater microbes feasting on organic matter piled up in dam-trapped lake sediments. Scientists believe dams' increasing number could lead to severe climate impacts.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists claim to develop common cold vaccine
article: In a first, US-based researchers have developed what they claim is a single vaccine for several common cold types. Common cold is caused by several distinct virus types, called rhinoviruses, posing difficulty for creating a one-for-all vaccine. The vaccine, which was made by artificially introducing a wide range of rhinoviruses, helped monkeys and mice develop immunity against the disease.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Apollo astronauts signed autographs to pay for insurance
article: The crew of NASA's Apollo 11 to Apollo 16 missions signed autographs before taking flight which could be sold by the astronauts' families in the event of their death. The astronauts were not covered by a standard life insurance policy. Instead, they signed envelopes postmarked on important dates, giving them a high sale value, which were called 'Insurance Covers'.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Last Rabbs' treefrog dies, making species extinct
article: The world's last Rabbs' fringe-limbed treefrog died in Atlanta Botanical Garden on Friday, resulting in the species' extinction. Dubbed as Toughie, the baseball-sized frog, which was estimated to be at least 12 years old, was captured in Panama in 2005 and was kept in captivity since then. The species has not been seen in the wild since 2007.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 3.5-feet long dinosaur footprints found in Mongolia
article: A team of Mongolian and Japanese researchers has recently uncovered one of the biggest dinosaur footprints, measuring 3.5 feet long and 2.5 feet wide. It was discovered in Mongolia's Gobi desert and is reportedly 70-90 million years old. The footprint is believed to have belonged to long-necked Titanosaur, which could have been over 30 metres long and 20 metres tall.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: HIV patient shows no sign of virus following treatment
article: British researchers have developed a new treatment for the HIV virus which they claim has successfully removed all signs of the virus from a trial patient's blood. While HIV hides from the immune system to resist therapy, the new treatment first tricks the virus into emerging from its hiding places and then triggers the body's immune system to destroy it.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Indian-origin teen wins $50,000 at Google Science Fair
article: A 16-year-old Indian-origin South African student has topped the 'Google Science Fair 2016' contest in the US, winning a scholarship worth $50,000. Kiara Nirghin won the annual scholarship for making a super-absorbent material from orange peels to help soil retain water. Kiara believes her product will assist farmers and increase food security in drought-plagued areas by 73%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: UN to launch its first space mission in 2021
article: The United Nations (UN) is planning to launch its first-ever space mission aboard a US-based space transport company's spaceplane in 2021. The mission is aimed to provide opportunities to developing nations without established space programs to send payloads into space. The payloads will be selected by a UN space-wing in 2018 and will be launched into low-Earth orbit in 2021.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Meerkats are the most murderous mammals: Study
article: A Spanish study on violence among mammals has unveiled that meerkats are the most 'murderous' mammals, with around one in every five meerkats being killed by its own species. The study also found that when humans first evolved, they were six times more violent than an average mammal species, with one in every 50 individuals killed by other humans.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Einstein got his matriculation certificate on Oct 3, 1896
article: German-born theoretical physicist Albert Einstein was 17 when he received his matriculation certificate on October 3, 1896. He received a 6 in Geometry, Descriptive geometry, Physics, and History. He received his lowest grade in French, at 3. Notably, 6 was the highest grade in the Swiss education system.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Fabric that keeps body 3 degrees cooler created
article: Researchers from the Stanford University have developed a low-cost, plastic-based fabric that  allows a human to feel up to three degrees cooler than wearing cotton clothes. The fabric does not trap the body heat and allows it to pass through in the form of infrared radiation. The fabric is currently solid and flat, but misses a texture.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Wearable microscope that can see through skin made
article: UCLA researchers along with Alphabet's Verily division have developed a wearable microscope that can detect and monitor fluorescent biomarkers inside the skin. The glow-in-the-dark biomarkers are a vital tool for cancer detection and monitoring drug delivery. The device can be worn around the biceps and work by capturing fluorescent images obtained by hitting an angled laser at the skin.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New technique detects cocaine at minute concentrations
article: Spanish researchers have come up with a new technique of detecting cocaine at 'nanomolar' concentrations. The method combines silicon nanoparticles and a signal amplification system that uses gold nanoparticles to detect low levels of the addictive drug. It can also detect low concentrations of mycoplasmas, a type of bacteria without cell walls, which are of biomedical interest.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists identify neurons dedicated to social memory
article: A group of MIT scientists has identified neurons in brains of mice that are dedicated to storing memories of other mice or "social memories". The process helps shape mice's behaviour toward each other. The team also showed that they can stimulate or suppress these memories by manipulating the cells that carry the memory traces.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Fluctuating brain networks help handle complex tasks'
article: Stanford scientists have recently found that the networks between brain regions fluctuate depending on the complexity of tasks. A more integrated brain helps in better handling of complex activities whereas brain components are relatively isolated when at rest. It was also found that blood flow patterns in brains became more coordinated when the test subjects performed complex tasks.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'NASA cuts live feed from ISS after spotting UFO'
article: A UFO hunter has accused NASA of intentionally cutting live feed from the International Space Station (ISS) during which a UFO was allegedly spotted. Scott Waring claimed the 'tadpole-shaped illumination' caught during a live stream on Friday was some otherworldly object flying near the ISS. Scott further alleged that NASA is trying to hide 'evidence of alien life'.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: ESA releases last images taken by Rosetta space probe
article: European Space Agency (ESA) has released the last images captured by its Rosetta space probe, before it crash-landed on Comet 67P on Friday. The final descent allowed the spacecraft to study the comet's environment very close to its surface. Launched in 2004, Rosetta mission seeks to see if the comet can provide answers to origins of life on Earth.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Bees added to US endangered list for first time
article: Seven bee species including yellow-faced, or masked bees, once abundant in Hawaii have become the first bees to be added to the US federal list of endangered and threatened species. Threats to the species include factors like habitat loss, wildfires and the invasion of non-native plants and insects. Pollinators like bees are crucial for the production of several food crops.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mars crust contributing to its atmosphere: NASA
article: NASA's Curiosity rover has found evidence that chemistry within the surface material of Mars  contributed aggressively to the makeup of its atmosphere with time. The findings were obtained by isotopic analysis of xenon and krypton in the Martian atmosphere. Researchers have suggested that the isotopes of these gasses escaped from the crust due to surface impacts.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists fix fracture with 3D-printed synthetic bone
article: US-based scientists have successfully fixed broken spines and skulls in animals using 3D-printed synthetic bones. Composed mostly of a ceramic and biodegradable polymer, the 'hyper-elastic' bones quickly integrate with surrounding tissues to begin bone regeneration. Scientists believe the concept can lead to personalised bone implants in future to fix spinal and other bone injuries in humans.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New device claims to detect bacteria in water in 1 hr
article: Toronto-based startup Glacierclean has created a device which they claim can detect the presence of E. Coli bacteria in water within one hour. The system, which costs $2-3 per test, is based on a 'hydrogel matrix' which is inserted into water samples, and changes colour if the sample is infected. Traditional bacteria testing methods usually take up to 48 hours.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 3D-printed fish fossil may unveil human teeth origin
article: Australian researchers have created 3D prints of a 400 million-year-old fish fossil, which they claim may reveal the evolutionary origins of human teeth. High-resolution CT scans were used to study tissue structures of tooth-like denticles in the fossil's jaws. This helped scientists to study how and when teeth, a characteristic feature of animals with jaws, had originated in prehistoric times.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA telescope spots most luminous dual star system
article: NASA's Fermi telescope recently discovered the most luminous gamma-ray binary star system, which is also the first one found in another galaxy. Dubbed as 'LMC P3' and located 163,000 light-years away, the binary star system emits mostly high-energy gamma rays and consists of a normal star and either a neutron star or a black hole.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: World's 1st baby born using 'three-parent' technique
article: The world's first baby was born using the "three-parent" technique in Mexico to Jordanian parents in April, New Scientist reported on Tuesday. The procedure was carried out by American doctors, who first removed the nucleus from one of the mother's eggs and inserted it into a nucleus less donor egg. The resulting egg was then fertilised with the father's sperm.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Newborn baby in Bangladesh looks like an 80-year-old
article: A boy resembling an 80-year-old was born in Bangladesh's Magura district on Sunday with a rare premature ageing condition, 'progeria'. The child has "prominent signs of ageing" including facial wrinkles, shrunken body and hollow eyes. "I am not unhappy, nor do I feel any sorrow that my son is different," said the father Biswajit Patro, a farmer in Bhulbaria village.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Trip to Mars could cost same as buying a house: Musk
article: SpaceX Founder Elon Musk on Tuesday said the company was working to reduce the cost of a Mars trip from $10 billion per person to around $200,000, which is the median house price in US. To improve the costs by "five million percent", Musk has suggested methods like reusable ships, refilling in orbit, and using inexpensive methane as fuel.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Earth crosses 400 ppm carbon dioxide threshold
article: As per Climate Central reports, the Earth "permanently" passed a symbolic carbon dioxide threshold of 400 parts-per-million (ppm) in September. Higher carbon dioxide levels have resulted in greater global warming impacts with the Earth edging right up against the 1.5ºC warming threshold compared to the 1881-1910 average. Notably, July 2016 was the hottest recorded month in Earth's history.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Rosetta probe crash lands on comet to end mission
article: European Space Agency's Rosetta mission ended on Friday, making a final landing on its target comet 67P. The Rosetta spacecraft made a crash landing on the comet's surface, near a pit called Deir el-Medina. Launched in 2004, the mission seeks to see if the comet can provide answers to the origins of the solar system and life on Earth.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Receding Greenland icecap to expose US nuclear project
article: A top-secret American Cold War nuclear project, which lies buried underneath 35 metres of ice in Greenland's Camp Century, will likely be uncovered due to rising temperatures by 2090, scientists have said. Code-named 'Project Iceworm', the 4,000-km network of underground tunnels was dug out to launch 600 ballistic missiles at the USSR, a project abandoned in 1967.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Galactic Tick Day' was observed on September 29
article: The 235th 'Galactic Tick Day', since the idea's inception in 1608, was observed on September 29, 2016. Earth, along with the rest of the Solar System, completes one revolution around the Milky Way galaxy's centre every 225 million years. The shift of one centi-arcsecond, or around 0.0000027 degrees, is called a Galactic Tick, an event happening once every 1.7361 years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Synthetic arteries that grow when implanted created
article: US-based researchers have created synthetic arteries that grow when they are implanted in the body. Made from a gel seeded with living cells called 'fibroblasts', the arteries offer the possibility of a "one-time procedure" in children born with heart defects. Standard tissue grafts which are currently used often need to be resized, requiring young patients to undergo multiple surgeries.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: SpaceX's rocket to Mars will be reused 1,000 times
article: The planned rocket to take humans to Mars made by space exploration startup SpaceX led by Elon Musk, will be reused 1,000 times. The rocket will be able to carry 100 humans and their cargo in 80 days to Mars in the next 10 years. According to Musk, 1 million people will be needed to build a colony on Mars.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists identify 54 'bones of Milky Way's skeleton'
article: Germany-based researchers have recently identified 54 "bones of the Milky Way galaxy's skeleton", of which 45 had not previously been identified. The cold, dense filaments of gasses dubbed as the galactic "bones", form the building blocks of the galaxy's spiral arms. Ranging from 32-900 light years in length, scientists believe there are more 146 "bones" still undiscovered in the galaxy.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Elon Musk plans to generate fuel on Mars
article: While unveiling SpaceX's plan to transport people to and from Mars, the aerospace manufacturer's Founder Elon Musk has said fuel can be created on Mars with "relative ease". Since no rocket has ever been launched from Mars before, Musk has said SpaceX will build a "propellant farm" on the planet to synthesise Methane from the ice and carbon dioxide available.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Iron nanoparticles make immune cells attack cancer'
article: According to a recent Stanford research, iron nanoparticles activate the immune system to attack cancer cells in mice. Scientists found the nanoparticles triggers immune cells, called tumour-associated 'macrophages', which detect and eat individual cancerous tumour cells. Scientists believe the concept could hold in humans too and would complement the existing cancer treatments.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Each washing cycle releases 7L microplastic fibres'
article: According to a UK-based research, each cycle of a washing machine may release over 7,00,000 microplastic fibres into the environment. These microplastic particles, when injected into marine life, poison the food chain by disrupting their digestive tracts. Scientists found acrylic clothes released the most with about 7,30,000 particles per wash, around five times more than polyester-cotton fabric.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Birds avoid flying into each other by steering right'
article: Australia-based researchers have revealed that birds avoid crashing into each other mid-flight by veering to the right. The team released 5 pairs of budgerigars from opposite ends of a tunnel, and observed no collisions on 102 flights. The study also found that birds rarely fly at the same height. The findings have potential for automated anti-crash systems on aircraft.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's smallest mirror created with 2,000 atoms
article: Paris-based researchers claim to have created the world's smallest functional mirror, using just 2,000 atoms of caesium. The mirror uses an optical fibre 400 nanometres in diameter, more than 200 times thinner than a human hair, to align the chain of caesium atoms to reflect the light. This may prove useful in building light-based circuits that will magnify computing speeds.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Zika case in Utah may have spread via tears or sweat
article: According to reports, a 38-year-old man in Utah may have contracted the Zika virus through sweat or tears. He appeared to have caught the virus at his father's hospital bedside, who got infected during a trip to Mexico. As per a doctor, the man might have come in contact with his father's sweat and tears, but not his blood.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 2 extinct reptiles 100mn yrs apart found to be similar
article: A 220 million-year-old reptile fossil recently unearthed in Texas has been found to possess strong resemblances to a reptile, 'pachycephalosaur', that evolved 100 million years later. Both had enlarged domes of solid bone behind their heads above the brain. The recently found 'Triopticus Primus' fossil has a large eye socket-like pit in the skull, raising speculations of a 'third eye'.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What happened to flags on the moon
article: A five-minute video discusses what happened to the six flags that were placed on the moon by astronauts including Neil Armstrong and Eugene Cernan. Discussing the harsh environment of the moon with characteristics like abrasive lunar dust and the sun's unfiltered ultraviolet rays, the video states that according to general consensus, the flags have been bleached white.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Earth to witness 'Black Moon' this year
article: A rare lunar event called the 'Black Moon' will occur this year. The term refers to the occurrence of two 'new moons' in a single calendar month, an event that occurs once every 2-3 years. It will be 'witnessed' by the Western Hemisphere on September 30, and on October 31 by the Eastern Hemisphere.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Pigeons can distinguish words from non-words: Study
article: According to a research by researchers in New Zealand and Germany, pigeons can learn to distinguish between real words and non-words in English, becoming the first non-primate species with "orthographic" abilities. The test-pigeons were able to identify words by visually processing the letter combinations and were able to build vocabularies ranging from 26-58 words and more than 8,000 non-words.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Group sends LGBTQ flag into space to promote equality
article: A global nonprofit organisation, Planting Peace, sent an LGBTQ flag into space last month to declare space "LGBTQ friendly". Using a high altitude balloon, the pride flag aimed to show support to the ongoing fight for the community's fundamental human rights. The flag, which reached a height of about 34 kilometres above the Earth's surface, was launched from Wisconsin, US.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: One in 10 children have inbuilt 'AIDS defence': Study
article: One in 10 children have an immune system that stops them developing AIDS, a study reports. Scientists believe these children have an immune system that "ignores" the HIV, instead of attacking it and self-destructing in the process. This approach is similar to how several monkey species cope with immunodeficiency viruses, and suggests new immune-based therapies for HIV.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Insect group hears same sound twice to locate mate: Study
article: A species of Colombian bush-cricket has ears that enable it to hear the same sound twice in each ear, to accurately locate potential mates, a study reports. The insect has ears on its forelegs, shaped such that a single sound actually hits the eardrums twice, at different times and with different intensities, via an external and an internal route.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Theory claims DNA and RNA evolved simultaneously
article: A new study by US-based scientists claims that RNA and DNA, the fundamental units of life, evolved simultaneously four billion years ago. The scientists developed the hypothesis when they found DNA-RNA hybrid structures are very unstable. This contradicts the 'RNA world' hypothesis, which explains how RNA molecules evolved to create proteins and DNA, giving rise to complex life on Earth.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains how scars are formed
article: A three-minute video explains how scars are formed and why they exist for a long time. The video discusses how a deep wound affects the skin tissue and the structural protein collagen, causing a 'disfigurement' of the skin and 'reducing its overall functionality'. Additionally, it also discusses other organs that are vulnerable to scarring like the heart and lungs.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains science behind adrenaline rush
article: A two-minute video explains the science behind an adrenaline rush which transforms a person into a "super human". The video discusses how sensory information reaches the brain, from where the sympathetic nervous system sends a signal to the adrenal glands. The release of the hormone increases the heart rate and blood pressure, preparing a person for all kinds of situations.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: Enteric nervous system is like 'second brain'
article: A four-minute video discusses how the enteric nervous system, an extensive mesh-like network of neurons that controls the digestive tract, acts like a 'second brain'. According to scientists, 80-90% of the nerve fibres that transmit signals, are from enteric nervous system to the brain. Therefore, the video states that the system, like the brain, can initiate its own reflexes.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Elon Musk reveals plans to set up colony on Mars
article: SpaceX Founder Elon Musk on Tuesday revealed plans to set up a colony on Mars, by sending humans to Mars for $200,000 in 80 days within the next decade. “One path is we stay on Earth forever, and there will be some eventual extinction event... the alternative is to become a space-faring civilization and a multiplanet species,” Musk added.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Humans have no future if they don’t go to space: Hawking
article: In the recently launched book 'How To Make A Spaceship', physicist Stephen Hawking has said, "I think the human race has no future if it doesn’t go to space." He further said, "I believe that life on Earth is at an ever-increasing risk of being wiped out by a disaster, such as a sudden nuclear war, a genetically engineered virus."

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Mars visitors should be prepared to die: Elon Musk
article: Space exploration startup SpaceX's Founder Elon Musk, who on Tuesday unveiled a plan to send humans to Mars, said that people interested in going to Mars should also be prepared to die. "The first journey will be very dangerous, and the risk of fatality will be very high,” he added. Musk plans to send humans to Mars in 10 years.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Video: Albert Einstein's 'miracle year', 1905
article: A five-minute YouTube video explores Albert Einstein's 'miracle year' 1905 in which he published four 'landmark' theories in the history of science. Einstein proposed that light could be made up of particles, proved the existence of atoms, and gave the 'Theory of Relativity'. The physicist also proposed energy-mass equivalence equation, E=mc², and published it on September 27, 1905.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Earth hottest in about 120,000 years: Study
article: According to a new Stanford research, Earth is currently hotter than it has been in the past 120,000 years. The rise in global warming due to increased carbon dioxide levels have been held responsible for the increase in temperature. Further, the study claims if similar climatic conditions persist, Earth will witness another 4°C of warming over next few thousand years.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Phuket beaches ban swimming over poisonous creatures
article: The Layan, Nai Thon and Nai Yang beaches in the Thai province of Phuket have banned swimming and other water activities after poisonous jellyfish-like creatures were found on the premises. Sirinat National Park head Kittiphat Tharapiban said that park authorities discovered Portuguese man o' wars, which are siphonophores that can deliver a painful and sometimes fatal sting.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 5 lionesses behaving like males spotted in Botswana
article: According to researchers, five lionesses in Africa's Botswana have grown manes and are exhibiting masculine behaviour. Unlike typical lioness' behaviour, these lionesses have been roaring and mounting on other females. Researchers suggested high testosterone levels may be causing this behaviour and added that while some of the maned lionesses were observed mating, none of them became pregnant.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Video sums up Musk's Mars colonisation event in 5 mins
article: A YouTube video summarises SpaceX Founder Elon Musk's presentation on Tuesday in under five minutes. Musk unveiled the aerospace manufacturer's Interplanetary Transport System, which aims at setting up a fully self-sustaining civilisation on Mars within the next 40-100 years. He also outlined plans of setting up fuel farms on the planet to launch rockets from Mars to Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 70-yr-old tensile deformation prediction proved
article: In a first, Harvard scientists have proved a 70-year-old prediction which says that with the right amount of tensile force, a thick cube of soft material would suddenly deform into a thin, flat plate. The prediction, first made by physicist Ronald Rivlin, has remained purely theoretical until now. The research could help in making new architected materials with geometry-changing functionality.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mercury found to be tectonically active like Earth
article: A recent NASA-funded research has confirmed that Mercury's interior is cooling and contracting even today, making it the second tectonically active planet in the solar system besides Earth. Tectonic shifting of the crust beneath the surface is related to a planet's ability to host life. Hence, a better understanding of Mercury's tectonic activity might help identify habitable zones in space.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Schrödinger's cat behaviour filmed in atoms 1st time
article: In a first, scientists have filmed the behaviour of "Schrödinger's cat" in atoms, a paradox in which a cat placed in a box with poison, has a 50/50 chance of surviving. In the animations, two-atom iodine molecules split into excited and unexcited states simultaneously when hit with X-rays, showing that molecules also can exist in two different states at once.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Jeff Bezos tweets 1st images of space tourism rocket model
article: Aerospace startup Blue Origin's Founder Jeff Bezos on Monday tweeted images of the model of rocket 'New Glenn' aimed to take humans on a space tour. The rocket is named after the first US astronaut to orbit Earth. Bezos showed the images hours after SpaceX Founder Elon Musk tweeted images of the rocket engine aimed to take humans to Mars.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Roller coasters may help pass kidney stones: Study
article: According to a Michigan State University research, riding a medium-intensity roller coaster can result in painless passing of kidney stones. The researchers created a 3D-printed model of a real kidney with three implanted stones, and found that placing it at the ride's front resulted in 16.67% passing rate while sitting at back resulted in 63.89% passing rate.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Oldest protein dating back to 3.8 mn yrs recovered
article: African scientists have extracted the oldest protein fragments encased in an ostrich eggshell dating 3.8 million-years-old. The proteins were preserved as they were "entrapped" in the surface minerals. Until now, the oldest sequenced protein was believed to have come from a 7,00,000-year-old horse. The find is believed to enhance future understanding of ancient organisms, including human beings.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Bending semiconductors generates electricity: Study
article: In a first, Spanish researchers have shown semiconductors generate a voltage when bent and can bend in response to a voltage, disproving previous belief of the property being exhibited only by electrical insulators. Scientists found the response increases with the material's thickness. The findings may help in the use of semiconductors in applications like pressure sensors and micro-generators.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Possible water vapor plumes spotted on Jupiter's moon
article: NASA on Monday announced its Hubble space telescope has spotted what may be water vapour plumes erupting from Jupiter's moon Europa, supporting 2012 observations that a liquid water ocean is swirling under its icy shell. Estimated to reach over 160 kilometres, the plumes erupt at irregular intervals and then die down. The findings suggest potential habitable underwater life on Europa.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA's Hubble captures 'death' of Sun-like star
article: NASA's Hubble space telescope has captured the 'death' of a Sun-like star, about 4,000 light-years from Earth. The image shows 'NGC 2440' ending its life by casting off its outer layers of gas, forming a cocoon around the star's remaining core. With surface temperatures reaching over 2,00,000ºC, the star shed its mass episodically.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New ant species discovered in frog's belly
article: A new species of tropical ant has been discovered in Ecuador, inside the belly of a devil frog locally known as 'diablito'. Small ant-eating animals, such as the devil frog, typically forage for prey in places inaccessible to humans, often helping to find new species. Interestingly, the frogs get their poisonous properties from compounds found in the ants they consume.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists replicate 5,000-yr-old mummy's voice
article: Italian scientists have replicated the voice of Ötzi, the Stone Age mummy believed to be over 5,000 years old. Using CT scans, scientists have reconstructed Ötzi's mouth, throat and vocal cords, and used it to reproduce the "best approximation" of his vowel sounds. The mummy was discovered 25 years ago in Alp's glaciers and is Europe's oldest known natural mummy.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Toyota develops DNA analysis tool to boost agriculture
article: Japanese automaker Toyota announced it has developed a new DNA analysis technology that can simplify the process of identifying and selecting useful genetic information to increase agricultural productivity. Genotyping by the Random Amplicon Sequencing (GRAS) method can help analyse DNA in about one-tenth the time needed, and at one-third the cost of conventional techniques, the company claimed.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA-funded rocket reveals unknown X-ray source
article: A NASA-funded rocket has detected a previously unknown source of high-energy cosmic X-rays. X-rays were already believed to originate from the 'wind' of charged particles from the sun, with the new source found to be a 'Local Hot Bubble' of hot, charged gas enveloping the solar system. It also revealed high-energy X-rays that do not come from a known source.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains why fingers get wrinkly in water
article: A four-minute video explains why fingers and feet get wrinkly when exposed to water. Explaining the different layers of the skin, the video states that skin wrinkling is a function controlled by the sympathetic nervous system. The video further discusses studies that suggest wrinkled fingers provide a better drainage system to get water off the skin, thus, increasing the grip.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: First map created to show genetic wiring of a cell
article: University of Toronto researchers have created the first map that shows the genetic interaction network of a yeast cell. Analysing around 18 million possible combinations of 6,000 genes, the 15-year-long study found that every gene has multiple functional 'backups'. This indicates that to detect the cause of diseases, one should look for gene pairs instead of individual genes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: African elephants face worst decline in 25 years
article: According to IUCN's 'African Elephant Status' report, African Elephants have witnessed the worst decline in the last 25 years. Reportedly, the number of African elephants have dropped by 1.1 lakh over the past decade with around 4.5 lakh specimens left. Increased poaching activities for the elephants' tusks have been held responsible for the continental decline in numbers.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains how a wound heals itself
article: A four-minute video explains how a wound on the human skin heals itself through a "complex and a well-coordinated process". Discussing the structure of the skin and its various layers, the video states that a wound that penetrates the top layer called epidermis, heals itself  through a four-step regenerative process. The video also describes stages of wound like blood clotting.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: How the brain simplifies complex reality
article: A three-minute video discusses the 'Gestalt psychology' to explain how the brain simplifies complex reality by interpreting surroundings 'collectively'. Explaining how still images become a movie when put together, it lists principles like symmetry and continuity, that help the brain to organise visual information. It further discusses how the brain's perception affects reasoning and memory.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study finds link between faecal bacteria and obesity
article: UK-based researchers have discovered that a more diverse community of bacteria in human faeces is linked with lower levels of abdominal body fat. Scientists have also found that some of the faecal bacteria are heritable, partly explaining the passing of obesity through families. Notably, higher abdominal fat level is 'dangerous' as it is linked with greater risk of heart diseases.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: China begins operating world's largest radio telescope
article: China on Sunday began operating the world's largest radio telescope, the FAST (Five-hundred-metre Aperture Spherical Telescope). Measuring 500 metres across, the telescope took five years and $180 million to complete, and will be used to search for gravitational waves and signs of extraterrestrial life. It will reportedly take three years for its calibration before becoming fully operational.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Aboriginal Australians are the oldest civilisation'
article: A Cambridge University-led DNA study has confirmed that 'aboriginal' or native Australians are the world's oldest surviving civilisation. The findings show that all present-day non-African populations are descended from a single "wave" of migrants, who left Africa around 72,000 years ago. Aboriginal Australians descended directly from those migrants, who entered Australia about 50,000 years ago.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Will 'solve' cancer within next 10 years: Microsoft
article: Software giant Microsoft has claimed it will "solve" cancer within the next ten years. According to reports, the company has started working towards tackling the disease like a computer virus, that attacks and damages body cells. The company has reportedly developed a 'biological computation' unit, which aims to make cells into 'living computers' that can be reprogrammed to treat cancer.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Strongest magnetic field trapped in a superconductor
article: Guinness World Records recently recognised a record made by Cambridge University researchers in 2014, for trapping the strongest magnetic field in a superconductor. Scientists used silver-doped 'gadolinium boron carbon oxide' to achieve a field of 17.6 Tesla, surpassing the previous best by 0.4 Tesla. The research could facilitate the use of superconductors for developing energy storing devices.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Stephen Hawking warns against responding to aliens
article: British physicist Stephen Hawking in an online film, 'Stephen Hawking's Favorite Places' has warned against responding to aliens who might send a signal to Earth. Contact with other civilisations could be similar to when Native Americans first encountered Christopher Columbus which "didn't turn out so well", he said in the documentary which explores significant locations across the universe.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: ₹27k cr funding for 'wall of trees' to contain Sahara
article: As many as 21 African nations have partnered under the 'Great Green Wall Initiative for the Sahara and Sahel', with around ₹27,000 crore of pledged funding. The initiative proposes to build Earth's largest living structure, a 7,700-kilometre wall of trees, along the southern frontier of the Sahara Desert. It will aim to resist, and then reverse the desert's advance.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Neptune was predicted before it was actually discovered
article: The existence of an eighth planet in the Solar System beyond Uranus was mathematically predicted, based on Newton's gravitational theory, before it was actually discovered through a telescope on September 23, 1846. The predictions were based on irregularities observed in the orbit of Uranus due to a possible gravitational influence by another heavenly body, which turned out to be Neptune.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Man gets award for study on rats' sex life
article: A deceased Egyptian urologist was posthumously awarded at this year's annual Ig Nobel spoof awards for studying how trousers affect the sex lives of rats. Ahmed Shafik dressed rats in trousers of polyester, cotton and wool, and found that those wearing polyester showed 'significantly decreased' sexual activity, which he suggested could be due to electrostatic fields around the genitals.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'African sleeping sickness hides in human skin'
article: The parasite causing African sleeping sickness, a life-threatening disease, has been found to take refuge in and transmit through human skin. People with the parasite often show no symptoms of the disease and test negative to blood tests, leading to delayed diagnosis and less survival chances. This information can help eradicate the disease, which killed an estimated 9,000 in 2010.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Greenland ice sheet melting faster than expected
article: New research suggests scientists have underestimated the loss of ice in Greenland by 20 billion tons per year. Scientists estimated ice loss using satellite imagery adjusted to compensate for a phenomenon where the earth's crust rises after large ice amounts melt. The study suggests that around 270 billion tons of ice melted every year in Greenland from 2003 to 2013.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Heaviest human brain recorded weighed 2.3 kg
article: The heaviest human brain ever recorded according to Guinness was of a 30-year-old US male which weighed 2.3 kg. The record was first reported in 1992 and remains unbroken since then. In comparison, the brain of an average man weighs about 1.4 kg whereas Albert Einstein's brain reportedly weighed slightly below average at 1.23 kg.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Earth is slowly losing oxygen: Study
article: A new study from Princeton University has found that global oxygen levels in Earth's atmosphere have dropped by around 0.7% over the past eight lakh years. The findings were obtained by analysing trapped air bubbles in ice cores from Antarctica and Greenland. Scientists have proposed that cooling oceans could have reduced oxygen levels as it drives more oxygen-consuming microbe activity.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Battery directly charged by solar energy made
article: A US-based professor has developed a battery that directly stores solar energy into a tank of electrolytic liquid. For this, he used a 'redox-flow' battery, which stores energy in liquid electrolyte instead of solid electrodes, such as in lithium-ion batteries. The technique is claimed to be cheaper than conventional batteries, and can be used for grid-level electricity storage at night.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: UK professor creates 'hangover-free' alcohol
article: UK-based professor David Nutt claims to have created 'alcosynth', an alcohol that does not have negative effects like hangovers, nausea and dry mouth, while maintaining 'the positive qualities'. Nutt said that he has patented around 90 different 'alcosynth' compounds. He added that 'alcosynths', some of which "go very nicely into mojitos", could completely replace normal alcohol by 2050.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Portable vaccine kit works by adding only water
article: An international team of researchers has invented a portable drug-manufacturing system that only requires the addition of water for effective administration of drugs and vaccines, without requiring power or refrigeration. The technique works by adding water to a combination of two types of freeze-dried pellets, one holds raw materials of drugs and other holds DNA instructions for drug creation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 375 top scientists warn of 'immediate' climate threat
article: 375 members of US' National Academy of Sciences, including 30 Nobel laureates, published an open letter drawing attention to the imminent threats of climate change. The letter warns that US opting out of the Paris Climate agreement would be "severe" for global climate. It also predicts that nations which innovatively 'decarbonise' energy systems will be the new economic leaders.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New type of galaxy spotted using deep space images
article: American scientists have recently discovered a new type of galaxy using deep field images from NASA's Hubble telescope and Chile-based Atacama Large Millimetre/submillimetre Array (ALMA). They found the newly-spotted galaxies are rich in cold gases but are composed of fewer stars. Scientists believe the cold gas galaxies could help in understanding the formation of galaxies in the earliest stages.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video explores if a man can get pregnant
article: A four-minute video explores whether men can get pregnant or not. The video states that male pregnancies could be possible through ectopic implantation, wherein the implantation of the foetus happens outside the uterus. The missing pregnancy hormones could be supplemented with injections. However, the video suggests that it could be "dangerous" as such a pregnancy could even "kill" a person.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Study reveals history of how cats were domesticated
article: A DNA study has revealed new information on how cats were domesticated. The findings showed that humans first met cats after the development of agriculture, when cats were attracted by rats eating food-grains. A second migration 'wave' was suggested when Egyptians domesticated cats and took them across Eurasia. Interestingly, the study found that tabby cats evolved in the Medieval period.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Quakes on Mars could help support life: Study
article: US-based researchers have found that seismic activity on Mars could create favourable life conditions. The study shows silicon in rocks grinding together during earthquakes can react with water to generate hydrogen gas. This hydrogen helps bacteria called 'hydrogenotrophs' survive deep underground on Earth. Notably, NASA's 2018 InSight mission is scheduled to measure seismic activity on Mars.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Texas quakes caused by wastewater injections: Study
article: A series of earthquakes in Texas in 2012 was possibly triggered by wastewater injections while drilling for oil and gas, a new study has suggested. All earthquakes had originated beneath two wells where wastewater generated during oil production was pumped, causing Earth's surface to bulge. The wells reportedly had pumped in over 500 crore litres of water between 2007-2012.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Material to make more efficient solar cells found
article: Columbia-based scientists have found a material to manufacture solar cells more efficient than existing silicon energy cells. The new material, called hybrid organic-inorganic​ perovskites (HOIPs), are cheaper to manufacture in large scale and is tolerant to defects, unlike silicon cells which require 99.999% purity. Further, HOIP cells reportedly have much lower energy loss rates.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Horses can learn to communicate with humans: Study
article: A recent Norwegian study has found that horses can learn to use symbols for communication with humans. Scientists found that within two weeks of training, horses could tell if they wanted a blanket put on or taken off or stay unchanged. Interestingly, the choices made by the horses were not random but dependent on weather.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Blind people do math using brain's visual cortex'
article: American researchers have revealed blind people use the visual processing region of the brain besides the region associated with numerical reasoning, to do math. An MRI study on blind-since-birth individuals found the activity in the visual cortex increased with problem complexity. The finding challenges the idea that brain tissue intended for one function is only limited to closely related tasks.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Caspian terns found nesting 1,600 km farther than ever
article: The world's largest tern species, the Caspian terns have been found breeding above the Arctic Circle, nearly 1,600 km farther to the north than the species had been previously recorded. Global warming resulting in longer summers and its northward expansion has been held responsible for the shifting of these high-altitude seabirds, among other temperate species.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Pesticide manufacturers' tests reveal harm to bees
article: According to newly revealed research by pesticide manufacturers Bayer and Syngenta, their neonicotinoid insecticides are causing 'serious' harm to honeybees. The research conducted on the insecticides revealed high doses of Bayer's 'clothianidin' and Syngenta's 'thiamethoxam' are damaging health of bee colonies. Earlier, Syngenta had denied any damage by its products, contradicting its own study.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: How radio can be used to talk to astronauts
article: A four-minute video explains how a ham radio, an amateur radio broadcasting system, can be used to talk to astronauts from Earth. According to the video, ham radios using the HF range can bounce their waves off the ionosphere, creating a sky wave. Additionally, the International Space Station (ISS) has access to a ham radio, enabling them to communicate.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Surgeon claims head transplant possible by next year
article: Italian neurosurgeon Sergio Canavero has claimed that human head transplant can be possible by next year, following three animal studies. The process will involve cutting the neck and spinal cord, and reconnecting the neurons using polyethylene glycol solution. Reportedly, his first patient will be 31-year-old Valery Spiridonov, who had earlier volunteered for the first ever human head transplant.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: Samoa releases satellite pics to show hail wasn't joke
article: The island nation of Samoa witnessed a hail storm for only the second time in its recorded history, prompting a meteorologist to release satellite images to convince people that it was not a practical joke. Interestingly, Samoa's average temperature during this season is 29°C. The hail storm struck the eastern side of the country and lasted for 10-15 minutes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: China's first space station 'out of control'
article: Chinese space authorities have confirmed they have lost control of the country's first space station 'Tiangong-1', which is expected to crash into Earth's atmosphere in 2017. Most of the 8.5-tonne-station's parts are predicted to burn during the fall. The station, launched in 2011, was used as a testbed for technologies that will be used in China's large modular space station.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Einstein kept a picture of Faraday on his study wall
article: Physicist Albert Einstein kept a picture of English scientist Michael Faraday on his study wall, alongside pictures of Isaac Newton and James Clerk Maxwell. Faraday, who is considered one of the greatest scientists, established the idea of the electromagnetic field and discovered electromagnetic induction and the laws of electrolysis. Faraday was born 225 years ago on 22 September, 1791.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 1.178-micrometre Canadian flag sets world record
article: Canadian scientists have set a Guinness World Record for creating the smallest-ever national flag measuring 1.178 micrometres in length, about one-hundredth the width of a human hair. This comes ahead of Canada's 150th anniversary next year. The minuscule flag was created on a silicon wafer using an electron beam lithography system and is visible only with an electron microscope.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Toyota using human waste to power electric car
article: Yoshikazu Tanaka, the chief engineer of Toyota's hydrogen fuel-cell car Mirai, has revealed that the Japanese automotive manufacturer is converting human waste into hydrogen to fuel the car. Microorganisms are added to the solid waste from sewage to create biogas and eventually extract pure hydrogen. Mirai combines hydrogen and oxygen to make electricity, while only emitting water vapour.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA probe captures 1st image of the Sun's edge
article: NASA's twin STEREO probe has captured the first image of the Sun's outer edge, depicting a cloud of hot gasses over its surface. The gasses rise over 50,000 kms, around four times Earth's diameter, and are held there by the Sun's magnetic field. The work could help better understand NASA's solar mission's observations, which is expected to launch in 2018.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Blue whale has the largest heart on Earth
article: According to the Guinness World Records, blue whale has the largest heart among all living creatures. A whale's aorta (body's main artery) is large enough for an adult to crawl through and it pumps approximately 15,000 pints of blood as compared to 8 pints in a human. Additionally, the blue whale's heart beats only 5-6 times per minute on surface.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: DiCaprio invited to visit the Great Barrier Reef
article: The Australian government has invited Hollywood actor Leonardo DiCaprio to visit the Great Barrier Reef and help in its conservation efforts. This comes after DiCaprio’s comments on the recent bleaching impacts on world's largest coral reef system. Notably, 93% of the reef is affected by bleaching and almost a quarter of its corals are deemed to have died.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: NASA building largest, most powerful rocket in world
article: US space agency NASA is building the world's largest and most powerful rocket at its Michoud Assembly Facility, US. The rocket's 212-foot-long core will carry around 2.3 million pounds of liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen to fuel the engines. It is being prepared for moon missions in 2018, and other Mars and deep space explorations in the 2030s.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Video: Life and works of Michael Faraday
article: A YouTube video explores the life of the famous English scientist Michael Faraday, whose works played a key role in making electricity practically viable. His electromagnetic devices formed the foundation of electric motor technology. Faraday, who was born 225 years ago on September 22, 1791, received little formal education and mostly self-taught himself.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Quantum teleportation done over 12.5 km optical fibre
article: In a first, researchers have demonstrated 'quantum teleportation' over 12.5 km using an existing optical fibre telecommunications network. Quantum teleportation is a process by which quantum information, the exact state of atoms or photons, is instantly transferred from one location to another. If successfully implemented, the technology could make internet connections "unhackable".

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists to study Atlantic's microplastic pollution
article: Scientists are scheduled to set sail from the UK this week, to journey across the Atlantic Ocean to study the level of microplastics in zooplankton. Ingestion of the micrometre-sized plastics leads to increased mortality rates while decreasing reproduction in the zooplankton, the bottom organisms of marine food-web. Reportedly, scientists will travel up to 960 kms daily during the 46-day voyage.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Canada to impose carbon price to fight climate change
article: Canada will impose a minimum price on carbon emissions in provinces that do not adequately regulate emissions by themselves, in a bid to combat climate change, the country's environment minister Catherine McKenna has said. The new emissions regime will be incorporated sometime in October, she added. Four largest Canadian provinces currently have either a carbon tax or emissions-limiting system.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Zodiac signs have not been updated, says NASA
article: NASA has clarified that it has not updated the zodiac signs as it 'studies astronomy and not astrology'. The clarification came after reports emerged that NASA had updated the zodiac for the first time in 2,000 years. In an educational page for children, NASA had said that ancient Babylonians had invented the zodiac, but had ignored the Ophiuchus constellation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: '2015 Indonesia smog outbreak may have killed 1 lakh’
article: According to Harvard and Columbia University researchers, smog outbreak in Southeast Asia last year might have caused over 1 lakh premature deaths as against 19 deaths reported in Indonesia. Caused by the deliberate firing of Indonesian forests to clear land for agriculture, scientists claim the “killer haze” led to inhalation of fine particulate matter, leading to health problems like asthma.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Watching sad films boosts endorphin levels in brain
article: According to an Oxford research, watching traumatic films triggers the release of feel-good chemicals, endorphins, also dubbed as "natural painkillers", in the brain. Endorphins increase the level of pain tolerance and enhance feelings of group bonding. The study found, on an average, the pain tolerance level of the test subjects watching a tragic movie increased by 13.1%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Eucalyptus leaves may help produce jet fuel: Study
article: According to an international research, oil from the leaves of a particular eucalyptus species could be used to produce jet fuel. The study has found that 'monoterpenes' found in the eucalyptus oil can be refined through a catalytic process, resulting in a high energy density fuel. Renewable fuel is claimed to generate significantly lower carbon emissions than fossil fuels.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists date world’s oldest rock back to 4.02bn yrs
article: Canadian scientists have dated the world's oldest rock at 4.02 billion years old. The findings suggest the Earth's earliest crust was largely covered with an oceanic crust-like surface and not continental. The ancient rock is found to contain grains of zircon, which provide accurate dating. "Earth is constantly recycling itself, the crust is being deformed or melted", a researcher said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New software that can spot deadly bacteria developed
article: Scotland-based researchers have developed a software which enables computers to identify deadly bacteria like E.coli. It 'learns' DNA signatures linked with bacterial samples which have caused infectious outbreaks, and compares these signatures to identify animal strains likely to cause similar human infections. Scientists claim the research could be adapted for several other bacteria types.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video explains the science of losing weight
article: A 2-minute video explains how working out leads to growth of muscles and describes the science behind weight loss. According to the video, stress which is heavier than what the body is used to, should be applied for muscles to grow. It further explains how fat is lost from the body in the form of carbon dioxide and water.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Global coral bleaching event might become new normal'
article: The current global bleaching event, the third and worst recorded till date, might become the new normal, according to coral reef experts. A researcher said he was hopeful the current event would end in 2017, but added it was possible the event would continue. Coral starts to bleach under unusually warm water and begins to die unless the conditions change.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: China sends vines into space: Report
article: China has reportedly sent vines (plants from which wine is made) into space on its new Tiangong-2 'space palace’ laboratory to experiment with their resistance to cold weather and drought. The vines include merlot and pinot noir, which are used to make the particular wines. The scientists reportedly hope to trigger mutations in the vines by growing wine in space.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ancient biblical scroll read 'while still wrapped'
article: US-based researchers have used a technique called 'virtual unwrapping' to read an ancient biblical scroll found in an ancient Israeli synagogue. The novel technique digitally scanned, textured and finally unfurled the scroll, which had been reduced to a lump of charcoal. It was identified as the third book of the Greek Old Testament of Christian biblical canons.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Fish recorded 'singing choruses' off Australian coast
article: Perth-based researchers have observed fish off the Australian coast that "sing choruses" underwater, similar to what certain birds do on land. Monitoring coastal waters with sea-noise loggers, the researchers heard choruses formed by overlapping solo calls by fish, predominantly occurring at dawn and dusk. Sound plays an important role in fish behavioural functions, such as feeding and mating.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA spots ice cloud over Saturn's largest moon
article: NASA's Cassini probe has found an ice cloud over Saturn's largest moon, Titan that is made up of dicyanoacetylene, a carbon-nitrogen compound that barely exists in its atmosphere. The finding suggests that the stratospheric cloud might have been formed by "solid-state" chemistry taking place inside the ice particles, a process similar to one seen over Earth's poles.

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video explains what will happen when the Sun dies
article: A two-minute video explains what will happen to life on Earth when the Sun 'dies'. The video states that in a few billion years, the Earth will turn into a "dry barren wasteland" due to the Sun's high luminosity, resulting from the loss of hydrogen in its core. It suggests that the only alternative is to "leave the Earth entirely".

author: Shipra Sharma
abstract: World’s longest lightning bolt travelled 321 kms
article: The longest lightning bolt in the world travelled a horizontal distance of 199.5 miles (approximately 321 kilometres), the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has confirmed. It occurred in Oklahoma, USA, on June 20, 2007. The WMO also revealed that the flash over Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur, France, on August 30, 2012, lasted for 7.74 seconds, becoming world's longest-lasting lightning bolt.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: Bayer invented the drug Aspirin
article: German pharmaceutical firm Bayer invented the drug acetylsalicylic acid, which it marketed under the name Aspirin, in 1897. The drug was created as a safer alternative to the salicylate drugs, which caused damage to the stomach. Founded in 1863, the pharmaceutical major recently signed a $66 billion deal to acquire biotechnology firm Monsanto, creating the world's largest agricultural company.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Lustful' tortoise saves species from extinction
article: A 100-year-old male tortoise from the Galapagos islands has been credited with the single-handed revival of its species from extinction, due to extensive breeding, reports said. Nicknamed Diego, the tortoise has fathered an estimated 800 offsprings, accounting for nearly 40% of the 'Chelonoidis hoodensis' species. Before Diego's repopulation, there were reportedly 14 living specimens remaining.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: New Chinese atomic clock most accurate in the world
article: China's new cold atomic clock in its space laboratory will not slow down for a billion years, reportedly making it the world's most accurate operational atomic clock. While cold Atomic clocks use a laser to decrease the effect of atom movement on the measurements, regular atomic clocks use atomic vibrations to measure time at constant temperature.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Arctic sea ice hits second lowest level ever
article: The National Snow and Ice Data Center in Colorado said Arctic sea ice shrank to its second lowest level ever recorded last Saturday, when it span 4.14 million square km. The lowest area ever recorded was in 2012, at 3.39 million square km. Scientists argue that melting Arctic ice is an "early warning system for climate change".

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Chinese actress chooses folk medicine over chemo, dies
article: According to reports, Chinese actress Xu Ting passed away after she chose traditional Chinese medicine over chemotherapy to treat her cancer. The 25-year-old had announced in July she had lymphoma, a type of cancer that best responds to chemotherapy. Ting had decided to treat her cancer with acupuncture and cupping due to the high cost and side effects of chemotherapy.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Longest-lasting lightning bolt struck France in 2012
article: A lightning strike in France on August 30, 2012, which lasted for 7.74 seconds, was declared as the longest-lasting lightning bolt by the UN World Meteorological Organisation on Friday. The horizontal bolt travelled a distance of over 200 kilometres, WMO added. Notably, a lightning strike covering over 321 kilometres in the US in 2007 is deemed the biggest in distance.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Desert bee species builds nests in solid rock
article: American researchers have found that a desert bee species nests in solid sandstone rocks in southwest United States. Sandstone is a more durable nesting option and elevated nests provide better protection against erosion and flooding, researchers said. Further, lesser organic content in sandstone nests helps control the breeding of threatening microbes, they added.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: World's oldest fish-hooks found in Japan
article: The world's oldest fish-hooks, believed to be around 23,000 years old, have been found in excavations on Okinawa Island in Japan. Researchers claim the fish-hooks are made from snail shells and show that fishing technology was developed earlier than thought previously. The findings of the excavation indicate the island has been continuously occupied by humans for 35,000 years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Astronomers observe star 'rebirth' for 1st time
article: Astronomers have observed the heating and cooling stages of a star's 'rebirth' for the first time. Located about 2,700 light-years away, the star was observed to contract and heat up, before it started to cool again and expand. Most stellar processes are too slow to be seen in a human lifespan, but the new observation is an exception, researchers said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: First 3D map of fruit fly's brain network created
article: Japan-based scientists have created what they claim is the world's first 3D map of a fruit fly's brain network. They pickled a fly brain in silver dye, bombard it with X-rays and measured their scattering intensity in different directions to produce the image intensity map. The map, that took 1,700 man hours to build, displays 100,000 neurons with 600-nanometre resolution.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists create most-detailed human brain map
article: Researchers at Seattle-based Allen Institute for Brain Science have created what they claim is the highest resolution and most structurally complete human brain atlas. Researchers performed their research on a 34-year old donor brain through magnetic resonance and diffusion tensor imaging, creating an atlas with 862 annotated structures. The atlas may help researchers understand the human brain.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Traders in tune with their heartbeat make more money'
article: According to a Cambridge study, traders who are better at listening to the 'gut feelings' or the signals their hearts give them about market patterns, make more money and survive longer in financial markets. The 'gut feelings' provide feedback to brains to avoid loss-making gambles. The study also found that traders have stronger 'gut feelings' than the general population.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Individual atoms observed interacting for 1st time
article: In a first, MIT researchers have observed individual potassium atoms' interactions, with some pairing up and others keeping away from each other, exhibiting “antisocial” behaviour. For this, scientists trapped gaseous atoms in a 2D optical lattice sheet under nanokelvin temperatures, close to absolute zero (−273.15°C). The observations could help in developing room-temperature superconductors.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 100 million-yr-old 'parrot lizard' dinosaur replicated
article: A UK-based artist has collaborated with researchers to accurately replicate a more than 100-million-year-old 'parrot lizard' dinosaur. Based on a well-preserved fossil found in China, artist Bob Nicholls used laser imaging to replicate the 'Psittacosaurus', a turkey-sized, plant-eating, walking dinosaur. It was revealed the dinosaur used countershading, a form of camouflage used by prey animals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Black holes caught 'swallowing stars & burping energy'
article: In a first, American and Chinese astronomers have documented the process of black holes destroying stars through their gravitational pull and ejecting radiation, using images from NASA’s WISE telescope. The event, "stellar tidal disruption", releases high energy, brightening the surroundings in an event called a flare. The findings could help understand galaxy's formation, researchers suggested.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: DiCaprio unveils free tool to monitor illegal fishing
article: American actor Leonardo DiCaprio recently unveiled a satellite-based surveillance system to spy on illegal fishing, called the Global Fishing Watch, which was developed by his nature conservancy-focussed foundation and Google. It allows anyone to track the activities of fishing vessels in the oceans, and illegal fishing activities which reportedly accounts for 35% of the global wild marine catch.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: UK to ban fishing from a million sq kms of ocean
article: The UK government on Thursday said it will ban commercial fishing from a million square kilometres of ocean around British overseas territories, in a bid to protect marine life. However, 'sustainable' local fishing will be allowed in some areas, but activities like oil drilling will be prohibited. This move converts UK's "historic legacy into modern environmental success," officials said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Hubble takes close-up images of disintegrating comet
article: Using NASA’s Hubble space telescope, astronomers have captured what they claim are the most detailed images of a disintegrating comet, 107 million km from Earth. The images taken in January show building-sized pieces of ice-dust mixtures separating from the 4.5-billion-year-old comet. The images suggest the comet may be spinning so fast that the material started getting ejected from its surface.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Gamers beat scientists to discover protein's shape
article: A group of gamers playing a puzzle game 'Foldit' beat scientists, college students and computer algorithms in a contest to identify a particular protein's structure, demonstrating the value of game elements in education. The gamers collaboratively interpreted biochemical data to uncover the protein's structure, which was found to prevent plaque formation, a potential antidote to Alzheimer's.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists detect X-rays from Pluto for 1st time
article: Scientists working with NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory have detected the first X-ray emissions from Pluto, replacing Saturn as the farthest known solar system body to emit X-rays. Pluto lacks magnetic fields and is too far from the Sun, which defies currently known conditions for X-ray emission. Scientists believe the discovery could reshape their understanding of the dwarf planet's atmosphere.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Drinking alcohol removes shyness about sex: Study
article: A Switzerland-based study has confirmed the "conventional wisdom" that drinking alcohol removes inhibitions surrounding sex. Scientists found that moderate amounts of beer-drinking made it easier for volunteers especially women to view explicit sexual images, while making them happier and enhancing concern for positive emotional situations. However, no change was observed in sexual arousal levels.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make 3D 'organoids' mimicking lungs
article: UCLA researchers have created 3D lung-like tissues that mimic actual lungs in several ways, targeting drug-testing studies for pulmonary diseases including idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. The laboratory-grown 3D "organoids" have been created by coating hydrogel beads with lung-derived stem cells, allowing them to self-assemble into the shape of air sacs found in human lungs.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: ISRO releases 1st photo by recently launched satellite
article: ISRO has released the first image of the Earth taken by INSAT-3DR, an advanced meteorological satellite which was launched last week.
