The satellite, which is equipped with a multi-spectral imaging system and atmospheric sounder, can capture images of the Earth disk from 36,000 km above the planet's surface and provide information on parameters like radiation, precipitation and temperature.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains why women live longer than men
article: A two-minute video lists different theories and studies in order to explain why women, on an average, have longer lifespans than men. According to the video, scientists believe that longevity is based on the biological differences between the two genders. The video further discusses two studies in which men who had their testicles removed had longer lifespans than other men.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains why some people are left-handed
article: A five-minute video discusses various theories and studies in order to explain why some people are left-handed. According to the video, evolution in early humans helped to determine the 'language and hand dominance' in certain people while adding that left-handedness is caused by lack of genes. Further, two right-handed parents only have a 9% chance of having a left-handed child.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explores the possibility of recording dreams
article: A four-minute video explains the possibility of recording dreams by stating how brain waves can be recorded during an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scan. The video describes a technique created by scientists to read minds using an MRI scanner and various software. Additionally, by testing it on numerous people, scientists stated that the machine's predictions matched the dreamer's description.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make mice offspring without fertilised egg
article: In a first, English researchers have produced live mice without a fertilized egg cell. The team exposed unfertilised mouse eggs to a strontium chloride bath to 'trick' them into dividing into daughter cells, imitating the process of being fertilised by a sperm cell. They then injected sperm nuclei into these cells, resulting in embryos which were implanted into surrogate mothers.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: India-born scientist wins ₹3.35-crore MIT Award
article: India-born scientist Ramesh Raskar was awarded $500,000 (₹3.35 crore) for his work on ultra-fast imaging camera that can see around corners and a camera that can read closed books. The award, Lemelson-MIT prize, is claimed to be one of the world’s largest single cash awards for inventions. The 46-year-old, who is originally from Nasik, is an imaging scientist at MIT.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: 30,800 kg meteorite discovered in Argentina
article: A 30,800 kg meteorite, reportedly the world's second largest, has been discovered at an ancient meteor shower site in northern Argentina. The meteor shower is believed to have hit the region around 4,000 years ago. The world's largest meteorite, named Hoba, was discovered in Namibia nearly a century ago and weighs over 50,000 kg.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Moon-forming collision more violent than thought'
article: According to a US-based research, the moon was formed by Earth's violent collision with a Mars-sized impactor, contradicting previous beliefs of a low-energy collision. Current theories suggest the impact turned impactor to magma, eventually turning into the moon. The new theory insisted the collision pulverized both bodies, turning them into vapor, which eventually turned into Earth and the moon.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Brain-sensing tech allows monkeys to type 12 words/min
article: Stanford scientists have developed a brain-sensing technology which enables monkeys to type words at a rate of up to 12 words-per-minute. Multi-electrode arrays were implanted in monkeys' brains to read signals from a region that directs hand-arm movements used to drive a cursor moving over a keyboard. The technology could provide a communication method for disabled people, scientists claim.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Russian scientists trapped by polar bears rescued
article: Five Russian meteorologists, who were trapped inside a weather station by 10 polar bears for two weeks, have been rescued. The scientists were reportedly provided help on Wednesday when dogs and flares were delivered by helicopter to scare the bears away. According to a Russian news agency, hunting of polar bears has been banned in Russia for over 50 years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Sugar industry shifted heart disease blame to fat'
article: As per newly released documents, the Sugar Research Foundation, now known as the Sugar Association, paid $50,000-equivalent to Harvard scientists in mid-1960s to challenge the emerging evidence linking sugar consumption to cardiovascular diseases. The blame was instead transferred to saturated fat, even though the industry was aware of high cholesterol level risks due to excess sugar consumption.

author: Parichit Mainra
abstract: US running UK's old UFO-hunting unit: Reports
article: US military intelligence is reportedly running the suspended British UFO-hunting unit in London. While the unit mainly works on the militarisation of space, it also tried to find extraterrestrial life. The program, which is almost fully funded by US taxpayers, is run out of a building in London and is primarily staffed by Americans and employs a few Britishers.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Jeff Bezos announces Blue Origin’s 1st orbital rocket
article: Private aerospace manufacturer Blue Origin's Founder Jeff Bezos on Monday revealed plans for 'New Glenn', the company's first orbital rocket. Named after John Glenn, the first US astronaut to orbit the Earth, the reusable rocket will be able to launch payloads and humans into the orbit. Bezos has said New Glenn will be launched before the end of the decade.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Dolphins communicate via 'spoken language': Study
article: According to European researchers, dolphins, known for their intelligence, are capable of 'highly developed spoken language' resembling human communication. The team suggested that the pulses, clicks and whistles made by one dolphin are listened to fully by another before a response is made. Each pulse is unique in a dolphin's time span and frequency, like a spoken word, researchers added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 1st practical 'artificial photosynthesis' design made
article: European scientists have developed what they claim is the world's first practical design for splitting of water by 'artificial photosynthesis' to produce hydrogen gas. The system consists of a network of solar cells of 1.8 Volt each, necessary for the photo-electrochemical splitting of water. Scientists believe solar energy conversion to hydrogen storage could meet energy demands in the future.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Device that converts body heat to electricity made
article: US-based researchers have developed a new lightweight design for harvesting body heat and converting it into electricity for use in wearable electronics. Previous approaches used "bulky and stiff" heat sinks while the new system is 2mm thick and flexible, said the researchers. The team also identified that the upper arm was the optimal site on the body for heat harvesting.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Humans speak a 'universal language': Study
article: A first-of-its-kind study has found that people tend to use the same sounds for common objects and ideas irrespective of language, suggesting the existence of a 'universal language'. The findings were obtained by analysing over 6,000 languages, accounting for almost 62% of world's languages. The study challenges the century-old belief that the relationship between sound and meaning is arbitrary.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Billion-star 3D map of Milky Way galaxy revealed
article: The European Space Agency (ESA) has released what it claims is the most detailed 3D map of the Milky Way galaxy, pinpointing over a billion stars. The map also features the distances and motions across the sky for more than two million stars. The release is based on data collected by ESA's Gaia satellite from July 2014 to September 2015.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Rotating island discovered in Argentina: Report
article: A 'mysterious' island which rotates on its own Axis has been discovered in northern Argentina, according to reports. It was discovered by filmmakers location scouting for a sci-fi movie six months ago. Director Sergio Neuspiller said, "The Eye is a circle of land surrounded by a thin channel of water with a diameter of 130 yards."

author: Daisy Mowke
abstract: Video lists body parts humans can live without
article: A three-minute video lists some body parts that humans can live without and are therefore completely "useless". These include the wisdom teeth, the appendix, the tailbone, the male nipple and the plica semilunaris or the residual part of the 'third eyelid'. Such "vestigial structures" lose their purpose owing to evolution, which renders them "degenerate" over time.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ants found to have two navigation systems
article: A recent study on 'Cataglyphis', or desert ants, has revealed the two mechanisms these insects use to navigate. A control group of ants were blindfolded, and study findings reveal that ants use 'stride integration' to count number of steps, combined with 'optic flow' to estimate distance while in motion. The two systems work in a redundant manner but independently.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains why human beings cry
article: A three-minute video discussing why humans cry, states that there are three kinds of tears- basal, reflex, and emotional. While the basal tears serve the purpose of eye's lubrication, the reflex tears are released to protect eyes from irritants like smoke and onions. Lastly, emotional tears, which signify sadness or happiness, help to release stress hormones.

author: Saloni Tandon
abstract: Formula E race car driven on Arctic ice cap
article: A Formula E race car was driven by ex-F1 racer Lucas di Grassi across the Arctic’s polar ice cap to raise awareness about global warming and promote the idea of electric cars as they produce zero emissions. The Brazilian racer was runner-up at the 2015-16 Formula E season, the world's first fully-electric racing series that came into existence in 2014.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Google opens online natural history exhibits
article: Google has partnered with more than 50 global natural history institutions to feature interactive stories and virtual reality tours in its new Art and Culture app. The tours explain the history of evolution, from solar system's origins to the "rise and the fall of prehistoric worlds". Users can also explore creatures like predatory dinosaurs and prehistoric giraffes in 360 degrees.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Team creates simulations of virus invading host cells
article: US-based researchers claim to be the first to accurately track the change in virus' shape while it invades a host cell. The goal of the study was to understand the detailed steps of a virus' lifecycle​, like how it enters the host cell, a researcher said. The team believes these findings could help in developing more efficient anti-viral therapies.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains how anesthesia works
article: A five-minute video explains how anesthesia makes a person unconscious and unable to move, feel pain or form memories. According to the video, doctors often combine different kinds of agents to get the right balance of anesthesia. The video further discusses how it helps to calm the electrical impulses of the brain during surgery.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explores prospects of human survival on Mars
article: A one-minute video seeks to explain how human life can be supported on Mars, stating "according to NASA, living on Mars could happen with the existence of water, nitrogen, and oxygen''. Accordingly, it discusses ways to provide these elements on the planet. However, the stripping away of Mars' atmosphere by solar winds would make it difficult to live on.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: NASA releases astronaut training virtual reality video
article: NASA has recently released a 360° virtual reality video which features astronaut training footage from NASA's Neutral Buoyancy Laboratory in Texas. The video shows astronauts complete space-walk training for future missions to the International Space Station (ISS) from various perspectives. The astronauts can also be seen completing simulated missions that they would perform onboard the ISS.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: UK's 1st robotic kidney transplant performed
article: Robots have been used to perform kidney transplants for the first time in the UK. One of the patients, who had previously undergone a kidney transplant by traditional open surgery, reported significantly less pain with the robotic method. Another patient reported a faster post-operative recovery time. Both the patients were reportedly able to recover using only paracetamol rather than morphine.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Technique to draw nanoscale patterns using metal ink
article: In a first, US-based scientists have developed a technique to write nanoscale patterns with metallic ink using an electron microscope. Conventionally, such patterns are made through lithography, which requires masks to prevent material from accumulating on protected areas. The new method, which was able to write at 40 nanometers resolution, is like lithography without the mask, researchers said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Ionising radiation damages DNA, causes cancer
article: English scientists have discovered ionising radiations such as gamma rays and X-rays can cause cancer by damaging DNA. By comparing DNA sequences of spontaneous and radiation-associated tumours, scientists identified two characteristic patterns of DNA damage caused by high-energy radiations. The radiations chop up the genomes causing severe simultaneous damages and ruin the DNA repair mechanism.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: ISRO to launch satellite made by IIT-Bombay students
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) will launch a satellite developed by the students of IIT Bombay. Called ‘Pratham’, the satellite will measure the total electron count of the ionosphere. The satellite was conceptualised by two students of the Aerospace Engineering department - Saptarshi Bandyopadhyay and Shashank Tamaskar - in July 2007.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Team claims to estimate fuel inside Earth by 2025
article: A global research team has claimed it will be able to determine by 2025, the amount of nuclear fuel and radioactive power present inside Earth. Detecting tiny subatomic particles called geoneutrinos that originate from radioactive decay processes within Earth, the team will estimate amounts of uranium, thorium and potassium, which decay to generate the vast majority of Earth's internal heat.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Giraffes divided into 4 species, not one: Study
article: A recent study of giraffe genetics has revealed that there are four species of giraffe, unlike previous thinking that the world's tallest mammal is a single species divided into several sub-species. The four groups have not exchanged genetic material for millions of years. Notably, world giraffe population has declined by 40% in the last 15 years, with 90,000 specimens left.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Newly found asteroid came within 40k km of Earth
article: A newly found asteroid, named '2016 RB1', came within 40,000 km of Earth last week, which is less than one-tenth of the moon's distance from Earth. The 7-16 metres wide asteroid was first spotted on September 5, 2016. Scientists have predicted that it was the closest the asteroid would come near the Earth for at least the next 50 years.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Scientists predict existence of 'Madala boson'
article: Johannesburg-based physicists have predicted the existence of a new fundamental particle, the Madala boson, which can help understand dark matter. The particle is estimated to be heavier than the Higgs boson, discovered in 2012, which completed the Standard Model of Physics. Modern physics dictates that dark matter accounts for around 27% of the mass and energy in the observable universe.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: Why can't you use a phone on an airplane
article: A one-minute video explores the belief that using phones on airplanes emits radio signals that interfere with flight control. Though using phones from high altitudes emits stronger signals to connect with signal towers on ground, installing 'Picocell', a mini cell tower on board, could combat the issue. Additionally, a study suggested that banning electronic use below 10,000 feet is "useless".

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Hair protein better than DNA in identifying humans
article: California-based scientists have discovered a method of identifying humans by extracting genetic information from hair proteins with 98.3% accuracy. The protein analysis was found to have a discrimination power of 1 in 1,00,000 as compared 1 in 10,000 seen in DNA sequencing. Scientists claim the new method could replace DNA sequencing in forensic sciences.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: French most skeptical about vaccine safety: Survey
article: According to a recent survey, the French people have been found to be more skeptical about the effectiveness of vaccines than residents of 66 other countries. Around 41% of French citizens surveyed disagreed with the assertion that vaccines are safe, against a global average of 12%. Bangladesh emerged as the most vaccine-trusting nation, with just 0.2% skeptics.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: The science of pornography addiction
article: A three-minute video discusses the science of pornography addiction, explaining the profound effects it has on the brain. As per the video, excess pornography, like drugs causes addiction and leads to a similar loss of control, compulsiveness for the activity despite negative consequences, and withdrawal. Additionally, continued exposure makes you 'require' the activity, thus affecting your brain.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Massive 'holes' between star trail may be dark matter
article: Cambridge University researchers have discovered two massive 'holes' amidst a trail of stars just outside the Milky Way galaxy, which may be the smallest clumps of dark matter ever detected. Discovery of these massive yet tiny 'sub-haloes' feed the hypothesis that the dark matter, the invisible substance believed to hold galaxies together, is composed of heavier particles than normal matter.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA rover captures layered rock formations on Mars
article: NASA's robotic rover 'Curiosity' has captured detailed colour images of the layered rock formations on Mars. Scientists believe the study of Martian hills in such detail will improve their understanding of the present landscape on the Red planet. Curiosity landed on Mars in 2012 and is investigating the transformation of ancient habitable conditions to current less favourable conditions on Mars.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: MIT develops device that detects ripeness of fruit
article: MIT researchers have developed a new handheld device that can detect whether a fruit is ripe. The device contains a spectrometer that shines ultraviolet light on the fruit's skin to measure the 'glow' of the pigment chlorophyll, which correlates with the fruit's ripeness. The device then relays data to an Android app via Bluetooth to compute the degree of ripeness.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video shows bacteria's evolution to resist drugs
article: Harvard scientists in a two-minute video have demonstrated how bacteria become drug-resistant as they encounter higher antibiotic doses. The experiment, spanning 12 days, shows the bacteria spreading zone by zone to higher drug concentration areas, evolving to survive higher antibiotic concentrations. Scientists have warned indiscriminate antibiotic use may make them ineffective in the long run.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Sleep helps people remember what they value: Study
article: According to a recently study, when people sleep, the experiences they care about are more likely to enter long-term memory. In the study, non-Welsh speaking subjects were taught Welsh words either before or after a period of sleep. Sleepers showed an increased ability to learn the words, with the greatest effect in those who placed personal value on the language.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Brain parts responsible for panoramic memory found
article: MIT scientists have found that the occipital place area and retrosplenial complex in the human brain are involved in creating panoramic memories, linking different views of the surroundings. The two regions help in merging momentary surrounding views into a continuous 360-degree panorama. The response patterns in the two regions were also found to be similar when people saw linked images.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Caltech team creates simulation of Milky Way's birth
article: Astronomers at the California Institute of Technology have created a computer simulation of the Milky Way's formation, using 2,000 computers combining for a total of 7,00,000 CPU hours. The simulation has removed previous confusions that the galaxy should be surrounded by thousands of dwarf galaxies while actually there are 30, claiming that many galaxies were blown away by exploding stars.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Endangered snow leopard numbers rise in Afghanistan
article: Conservation efforts over seven years have reportedly brought the snow leopard back from the brink of extinction in Afghanistan. Researchers estimate there are about 140 snow leopards in Afghanistan's Wakhan National Park, a "sustainable" number. Classified an endangered species by the World Wildlife Fund, the snow leopard has often been killed by hunters for skin and farmers to protect livestock.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Bees are efficient workers even when sick: Study
article: Honeybees efficiently search the environment for nectar even when they are sick, according to a recent study by London-based researchers. The study observed the flight behaviour of 78 bees, some of which were affected by viral or fungal infections. Findings indicated that unhealthy bees fly in the same optimal search pattern as healthy ones, albeit for shorter distances.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Sound-proof material inspired by spider webs
article: European scientists have designed a sound-proof composite material influenced by acoustic web properties of the Nephila spider. The spider-web-inspired acoustic metamaterial is claimed to be more efficient and easily tunable as compared to other sound controlling materials. Its design could also help in vibration-controlled applications like earthquake protection for suspended structures.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Nano-sized 'metal fish' to target drugs to body parts
article: American researchers have developed a nano-scale 'metallic fish' to deliver drugs targeted to specific parts of the human body. The 800-nanometre-long fish, which is 100 times smaller than a grain of sand, is made of gold and nickel body segments joined by silver hinges, and its movements can be controlled using an oscillating magnetic field.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains why hair turn grey
article: According to a two-minute video, hair turns grey due to loss of the colour-giving pigment 'melanin'. Explaining how a person's hair colour depends on the pigment, the video states that factors like genetics, hormones, age and climate can affect hair pigmentation. Interestingly, each hair follicle contains its own amount of melanin, which causes hair to turn grey at different times.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What if Jupiter never existed
article: A three-minute video explores theories that explain what would happen if our solar system's largest planet Jupiter never existed. Some scientists believe that Jupiter helped the super-rocky planets surrounding our Sun collide to form Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars. Additionally, another theory suggests Jupiter's huge gravitational force deflects objects like comets and asteroids away from Earth.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: How many people can the Earth hold
article: A two-minute video discusses the Earth's conditions in reference to the growing human population, which is estimated to be over 10 billion by the end of this century. The video further illustrates how the growing population would cause increased global warming, affect food quality and weather conditions. It also explains how the increase would cause clean-water availability problems.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains how blind people dream
article: A five-minute video explains how visually impaired people dream, stating that dreams usually incorporate the five senses including sight and hearing. According to the video, individuals who lose their eyesight before 5-7 years, have no visual experiences in their dreams. However, people who lose vision over time, usually see visuals in their dreams based on memory.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: Why we can't smell things in cold
article: A five-minute video explains how a person's sense of smell is affected by temperature and the climate's dryness or wetness. Explaining how the nose functions, the video states that it is the odourants' volatile nature, meaning evaporation rate at normal temperatures, that is affected by the change in temperatures. Thereby, the nose 'smells more' in hot and wet weather conditions.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: UK student invents portable vaccine refrigerator
article: A UK student named William Broadway has invented a portable cooling device for vaccines named 'Isobar'. It consists of a heat-proof backpack, a cooling unit that provides long term charge, and a propane burner unit to charge the cooler. The invention can help distribute temperature-safe and effective vaccines to areas in developing countries that lack hospital access.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA using aircrafts to measure greenhouse gases
article: US space agency NASA is conducting low-level aircraft flights to measure greenhouse gas concentrations over the mid-Atlantic region through September. The flights will carry out the 'Carbon Airborne Flux Experiment' to measure the exchange of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide between Earth and atmosphere. The measurements would help analyse the performance of existing atmospheric models.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: World’s 1st robotic eye operation performed in Britain
article: British surgeons have successfully performed the world’s first robotic operation inside the eye, potentially revolutionising the way such conditions are treated. The procedure was carried out at John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford. “With a robotic system, we open up a whole new chapter of eye operations that currently cannot be performed,” said the Surgeon Robert MacLaren.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Bug-in-lizard-in-snake' fossil found in Germany
article: German palaeontologists have found a 48 million-year-old fossil of an insect inside an iguana, which in turn was inside a snake. All three creatures were fossilised when the snake perished in a volcanic lake near present-day Frankfurt. The fossil is the second of its kind ever found, revealing three levels of an ancient food chain nested one inside the other.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Russian river turns bright red
article: The Daldykan river in Siberia has turned bright red, prompting Russian authorities to investigate complaints of unknown chemical pollution. The river is situated near the Nadezhda metallurgical factory run by Norilsk Nickel, reportedly the largest producer of nickel and palladium in the world. Meanwhile, some locals have claimed that the colour of the river has turned red in the past.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: ISS crew lands on Earth after 172 days in space
article: US' Jeff Williams and Russia's Alexey Ovchinin and Oleg Skripochka landed safely in Kazakhstan on Wednesday after their 172-day mission aboard the International Space Station (ISS). The crew made a parachute descent after sailing around 415 km over Mongolia. Williams now has a total of 534 days in orbit, the most for a US astronaut and 14th in the world.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Smoke rings' made from laser light discovered
article: University of Maryland physicists have discovered that high-intensity lasers can generate violent eddies of optical energy resembling smoke rings. The donut-shaped 'spatiotemporal optical vortices' travel along with the laser pulse at the speed of light and control the energy flow around it. These 3D ring structures may aid the design of powerful microscopes and improved telecommunication lines.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: DNA confirms cause of London's 1665 Great Plague
article: Scientists have identified the bacteria that caused the 1665 Great Plague, that killed nearly a quarter of London's population. DNA testing from skeletons found at a mass burial site in Liverpool confirmed the presence of the bacterial pathogen 'yersinia pestis'. The same bacterium was responsible for the 1348 Black Death epidemic, resulting in an estimated 75 to 200 million deaths.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New bacteria species discovered in oil wells
article: Ohio-based researchers have discovered a new species of bacteria, named 'Frackibacter', living in oil and gas wells used for fracking. The type of environments that these bacterial colonies thrive in typically have high temperature, pressure and salinity. Fracking involves the fracturing of shale, a soft sedimentary rock, by pressurising liquid to extract fossil fuels.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: World's largest wind turbine installed off UK coast
article: Denmark-based Dong Energy has installed the first of the world's largest wind turbines at its Burbo Bank windfarm off the coast of Britain. The 8 MW turbine stands 195 metres tall from sea level and has a rotor diameter of 164 metres. The company plans to build 32 such turbines, which can generate enough electricity to power 2,30,000 homes.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Two Gurgaon students discover new asteroids
article: Dhruv Gupta and Deshna Jain, two students from Gurgaon, have discovered new asteroids as part of a campaign conducted by the US-based International Astronomical Search Collaboration (IASC). Their discoveries have been classified as 2016 S21 P10vK9F and 2016 JQ37 P10VlA8. These observations will contribute to the Near Earth Object (NEO) data being collected by NASA.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Indian researchers produce energy from fish scales
article: A Jadavpur University research team has devised a method to produce electricity from fish scales. The researchers used the piezoelectric property of proteins present in fish scales, which allow them to generate an ​electric charge when stress is applied. According to reports, this technique can be useful to develop self-powered flexible electronics in the future.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Parasite named in honour of US President Obama
article: Indiana-based biology professor Thomas Platt has named a parasitic flatworm 'Baracktrema obamai' in honour of US President Barack Obama. The 2-inch long, human hair-thin parasites that live in turtles' blood "are phenomenally incredibly resilient organisms," Platt said. He added that people pay thousands of dollars for the privilege of having a species named after them.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'La Niña' has set in: Japan Meteorological Agency
article: According to the Japan Meteorological Agency, 'La Niña', a weather pattern that typically occurs every two to seven years, has set in and may continue through the winter. This can bring more rains to countries including Indonesia, India and Thailand with chances of flooding, the report added. A La Niña occurs when cooler-than-usual sea surface temperatures trigger an atmospheric reaction.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Device detects marijuana intoxication in 3 min
article: Stanford researchers have developed a mobile device capable of determining whether people are under the influence of marijuana within three minutes. The 'potalyzer' uses magnetic biosensors to detect tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) molecules, the principal psychoactive constituent in marijuana, in saliva. It can also measure THC concentrations in the range of 0-50 nanograms-per-millilitre of saliva.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Cosmic study shows universe has no direction
article: UK-based researchers have analysed the oldest radiation available, or the afterglow of the big bang, and found the universe has no specific direction and is expanding isotropically. By studying the thermal radiations, the team looked for signals that indicate 'special directions' in the universe. However, they found that the universe is same in all directions on a large scale.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Stomach cancer detectable by urine tests: Report
article: Researchers at a China's Rui Jin Hospital have found that tumour markers for stomach cancer can be detected in early stages through urine tests, avoiding painful tests. According to reports, stomach cancer is usually detected in the intermediate or terminal stage as people avoid taking the painful gastroscope test and miss their best chance of an operation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA launches first asteroid-sample return mission
article: US space agency NASA on Thursday launched the OSIRIS-REx spacecraft, its first asteroid-sample return mission. The spacecraft will travel to the near-Earth asteroid Bennu, and is designed to return a sample weighing up to two kilograms by September 2025. Scientists believe the asteroid contains organic material and could potentially impact Earth in the 22nd century.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Indian scientists develop genetically modified cotton
article: A team of Indian scientists has developed a genetically modified (GM) cotton variety which is claimed to compete against the seeds imported from American multinational Monsanto. Scientists claim the home-grown cotton variety is more resistant to pests as compared to Monsanto's Bt cotton. This comes amid Monsanto threatening to pull out of the Indian market.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New drug claims to stop malaria with single dose
article: US-based scientists claim to have found a new compound that can stop malaria infection in a single, low dose. Tests on mice showed that the drug eliminates parasites in the liver before they can multiply and enter the bloodstream. Further development of the drug can potentially reduce treatment costs of malaria, which caused over four lakh deaths globally in 2015.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What if the Earth was twice as big
article: A two-minute video explains what would happen if the Earth doubled in size, assuming its density remained constant and mass increased. The gravity would be twice as strong, causing humans to weigh twice as much and trees to collapse. However, even though the gravitational pull of the earth would be stronger, it wouldn't be enough to break the moon apart.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: Video explores the working of microwave ovens
article: A three-minute-long YouTube video shows the process behind the heating of food in a microwave oven. The kitchen appliance was invented by accident after Dr Percy Spencer, while testing a magnetron in 1946, observed that the candy bar in his pocket melted. Spencer, who created the first microwave oven in 1947, passed away 47 years ago on September 8, 1969.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Slowest rotating neutron star detected: NASA
article: NASA has confirmed that 1E 1613, formed from a supernova explosion 9,000 light-years away, is the slowest rotating neutron star ever detected. It rotates once every 24,000 seconds, much slower than the second slowest neutron star's 10-second period. It is hypothesised that the supernova's debris had fallen back onto magnetic field lines around the star, causing it to slow down.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What if all the ice on the Earth melted
article: A six-minute video featuring actor Bill Nye seeks to explain the effects of the Earth's ice melting. The video states that such a situation would cause the sea levels to rise by about 70 metres, adversely affecting coastal cities like Mumbai, New York and Tokyo. Additionally, the marine flora and fauna would also be affected, causing an ecological imbalance.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Device to analyse components in a vacuum tested
article: US Department of Energy physicists have successfully tested the Materials Analysis Particle Probe (MAPP), a tool to analyse the surface of materials exposed to an ultra-hot plasma within a vacuum. The device allows scientists to study the physical and chemical evolution of materials when they interact with the plasma, which is key to the development of nuclear fusion reactors.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Britain's dormice count down by 38% since 2000
article: Britain's native dormouse population has fallen by around 38% since 2000 and 55% since the mid-1990s, according to a wildlife charity report. One of Britain's most threatened mammals, the hazel dormice have become extinct in 17 English counties since 1885. Habitat destruction and a warming climate have been held responsible for the vulnerable to extinction stage of the golden-brown animals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: MicroRNA leading to major depression discovered
article: US-based researchers have discovered that patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) have elevated levels of a microRNA, named miR-124-3p, in their brains' prefrontal cortex, the part critical for responding to stress. The mental disease, which affects around 250 million people every year, increases suicidal risks and is reported to cause the second-most years of disability after low-back pain.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains the science of love
article: A two-minute video explains the science of love which scientists believe is based on three neurotransmitters- dopamine, adrenaline and serotonin. The video explains how the production of each of these chemicals influence the feeling of love in people. It further discusses pheromones, chemicals produced by humans that affect the behaviour of others around them.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: How exactly do you hear things
article: A three-minute video explains how the ear processes different sound waves, enabling human beings to hear. The video discusses how the sound waves travel from the outer ear through the amplifying ear canal to the inner ear. Furthermore, the sound waves are then converted into electrical impulses which are sent to the brain through the auditory nerve.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Ghost snake' species discovered in Madagascar
article: American scientists have recently discovered a new snake species in Madagascar and named it 'Madagascarophis lolo' or 'ghost snake' owing to its pale grey colouration. The 'ghost snake' belongs to a group of cat-eyed snakes with vertical pupils, often found among nocturnal snakes. Analyses of genetics and physical characteristics helped confirm the distinctly patterned snake to be a new species.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Device makes petroleum from algae in 20 minutes
article: Iranian scientists have invented a device which they claim can produce oil and gas from algae within 20 minutes. The device is claimed to be based on the natural mechanism of oil production, turning algae into petroleum under high pressure and temperature. The flammability of the device's output oil is comparable to that of natural oil, scientists added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Propellant-free engine set for space test
article: US-based firm Cannae will demonstrate a thruster technology that can generate force without any propellant. The engine will be used to launch a demonstration CubeSat​ into low-Earth orbit for at least six months. Although there is no accepted explanation, a similar technology's inventor claims relativistic effects produce different radiation pressures at its two ends, leading to a net force.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Carbon nanotube transistors outperform silicon's
article: In a first, American engineers have created carbon nanotube transistors claimed to perform five times faster than the most advanced silicon transistors. The new transistors achieve 1.9 times higher current levels while using five times less energy, as compared to silicon. For this, researchers isolated ultra-pure semiconducting carbon nanotubes with less than 0.01% metallic nanotube impurities.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Indian scientists find cause of premature births
article: Indian scientists have found that Group B Streptococcus (GBS) bacteria are responsible for premature births, after running tests on pregnant mice. These bacteria produce toxin-containing membrane vesicles that kill both foetal and maternal cells leading to premature rupture of membranes, hampering the development of the embryo sac. Notably, India tops the global preterm births list at 35%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 60 year-old wind pattern changes in stratosphere
article: An anticipated wind pattern in the stratosphere recently changed in a way unwitnessed in the past 60 years. Usually, stratosphere winds circulate the Earth in alternating easterly and westerly directions over a 28-month period, termed “quasi-biennial oscillation”. However, this pattern changed from late 2015 till July 2016. Scientists believe climate change due to global warming caused the change.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Planetary crash source of life-giving carbon'
article: According to a Rice University research, almost all of Earth's carbon, which is the fundamental source of life, may have come from a young Mercury-like planet crashing into Earth about 4.4 billion-years-ago. The research sought to address the question of how carbon-based life developed when modern science dictates that Earth's carbon should have either vaporised or trapped in the core.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Europe's lost comet lander Philae found
article: After almost two years of losing connection, the European Space Agency's robotic lander Philae that accompanied Rosetta spacecraft to comet 67P has been found. Philae had stopped responding after three days its operation as it ran out of battery. Interestingly, the discovery comes few weeks before Rosetta's scheduled​ crash-land on the comet, so as to formally end the comet's investigation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Oil giant's deal helps endangered whale recover
article: Western gray whales, which were listed 'critically endangered' with just 115 living specimens, have recovered over 50% since 2004, following a deal between Russian oil company Sakhalin Energy and scientists to mitigate drilling impacts. This led to an annual increase of 3-4% in their numbers, resulting in around 174 gray whales, including at least 43 breeding females.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 4 of 6 great ape species listed as endangered
article: With the recent addition of eastern gorillas, four of the six great ape species are now listed as 'critically endangered' species by the IUCN. Eastern gorillas, the largest living primate, have seen a 70% decline in the last two decades, leaving only 4,600 specimens globally. Habitat destruction and poaching have been held responsible for the near-extinction of the species.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: '1st gravity waves form 10 mn yrs after merging'
article: Simulations have revealed that gravitational waves first originate 10 million years after the merging of two black holes, making it around 100 times faster than previously assumed. Every galaxy has a central black hole which triggers gravitational ripples through space on collision with another galaxy's black hole. Scientists claim the simulations could aid the research on origins of the universe.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: WHO declares Sri Lanka malaria-free
article: Sri Lanka was on Monday declared malaria-free by the World Health Organisation, which called it a “remarkable public health achievement”. Notably, Sri Lanka is the second country after Maldives in the South-East Asia Region to have eliminated the disease. The WHO will be holding a five-day event from September 5-9 to showcase Sri Lanka’s achievements in the health sector.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 170 mn-year-old marine reptile fossil uncovered
article: A fossilised skeleton of a dolphin-like predator which inhabited the oceans around 170 million years ago, has been uncovered in a Scotland museum where it laid buried for 50 years. A type of ichthyosaur, the marine reptile is estimated to be four metres long with hundreds of cone-shaped teeth. Scientists believe these 'sea dragons' became extinct shortly before the dinosaurs.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Evidence of Zika virus found in tears
article: A new study has discovered Zika virus genes in the eyes and tears of laboratory mice infected with the virus. Reportedly, the virus causes eye disease in about one-third of foetuses while leading to permanent vision loss in some adult Zika patients. Scientists have suggested the eyes could be virus reservoirs and could possibly be transmitting the virus among people.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Ancient dinosaur footprints found in Australia
article: Dinosaur footprints dating back to the cretaceous period have been uncovered on an Australian beach on Sunday, after being buried in sand for almost 50 years. The three-toed tracks are said to belong to a carnivorous theropod, bigger than a velociraptor but smaller than a Tyrannosaurus rex. A researcher estimated the creature to be 3-4 metres long.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Higher resolution 3D imaging technique developed
article: American scientists have developed an imaging method, thermal noise imaging, claimed to capture nanometer-scale higher-resolution 3D images of biological structures. For this, they added reflecting nanospheres to their structures, and then captured their motion around the structure to build the entire image. The advance may help study cell communications and in artificial organs, scientists said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Toxic air pollution particles found in brains
article: UK-based scientists have found toxic magnetite nanoparticles caused by air pollution in human brains in "abundant" quantities and have warned such particles might cause neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's. The magnetite particles were found to form as "molten droplets of material from combustion sources, such as car exhausts, industrial processes and power stations", researchers said.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Giant panda no longer endangered in China: Study
article: The status of giant pandas in China was updated to 'vulnerable' from 'endangered' due to a population rebound, during an update to the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List. There are currently an estimated 2,060 giant pandas in China. Notably, the country recognises giant pandas as its national animal.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Gene-edited vegetables cultivated for 1st time
article: In a first, gene-edited vegetables made from plants, modified with the CRISPR-Cas9 technology, have been cultivated and cooked in Sweden. CRISPR-Cas9 or "gene editing" is a way of changing an organism's genome by inserting, replacing or deleting DNA molecules. Claiming the plants do not come under genetically modified organisms, scientists believe the technology would help to grow healthy plants.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: White House unveils 3D maps of Alaska
article: The first 3D topographical maps of Alaska have been unveiled by the White House following an order issued by United States President Barack Obama in 2015. Part of the ArcticDEM project, the maps were created using commercial satellites. They will help track coastal landscapes affected by global warming and weather pattern changes which have led to erosion and glacial melting.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What if you never left your bed
article: A three-minute video explains what would happen to the human body in case a person never left his bed. Apart from developing bed sores caused by pressure on the skin, a person's muscle strength would also diminish by 10-15% every week. Complete rest would also cause the body's endurance and blood volume to decrease, among other adverse effects.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What if Earth's magnetic field reverse
article: A three-minute video explains the effects of Earth's magnetic field being reversed, which is known to occur every 200,000-300,000 years. According to the video, such reversals have led to no mass extinction earlier. Additionally, if the magnetic field continues to weaken, the atmosphere would protect us from harmful radiations, however, communication systems and power grids could be disrupted.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA releases shrinking time-lapse of Aral Sea
article: NASA has released a time-lapse footage of the once fourth largest lake in the world, the Aral Sea, shrinking since 2000. The footage shows the series of images beginning from 2000, when the lake was already a fraction of what its was in 1960. The lake split into eastern and western lobes saw its eastern lobe completely disappear in 2014.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Laser uses blood to help find cancer tumours
article: US-based researchers have demonstrated a new technique to monitor cell structure and activity at the molecular level by shining laser light through human blood infused with a fluorescent dye. The team analysed the light that was reflected back out to observe cell structures and changes. The team claims this advancement can help in drug testing and improve cancerous tumour monitoring.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains the science behind sleepwalking
article: A two-minute video explains the science behind sleepwalking which is mostly experienced by children in their deep sleep. Scientists suggest that sleepwalking occurs during childhood as a child's brain isn't fully developed, or is possibly induced by growth hormones or neurotransmitters. The video further explains how sleepwalking might be linked to a mental disorder in the case of adults.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains the science behind anxiety
article: A two-minute video explains the science behind anxiety, which the video states "is a normal response to stressful or dangerous situations". However, about 18% people suffer from an anxiety disorder, which is a mental illness that is characterised by distress. In this context, the video further discusses kinds of anxiety disorders such as social anxiety disorder and generalised anxiety disorder.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video gives a 360° tour inside the human body
article: A five-minute 360° virtual reality video explores what happens inside the human body and further shows how processes like respiration and digestion take place. The video also takes the viewer along the bloodstream in order to explain how the body functions. Interestingly, it also shows how the eye actually sees an inverted image and how the brain produces neurotransmitters.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Strong radio signal detected from 95 light-years away
article: A Russian radio telescope has observed a 'strong' signal spike believed to have come from a 6.3 billion-year-old Sun-like star located 95 light-years away, raising speculations about extraterrestrial life. The signal was recorded on May 15, 2015, but wasn't reported until recently. The star has at least one planet about the size of Neptune with a 40-day year, astronomers suggested.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Planet Nine' may push a planet out of Solar System
article: Scientists have suggested if the hypothetical 'Planet Nine' exists, it could eject at least one giant planet from the solar system when the sun starts inflating in around seven billion years. The inflation is predicted to consume the Earth, safely pushing out Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. However, if Planet Nine exists, it may get drawn in, ejecting other planets.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Earth warming at rate unknown in past 1k years'
article: According to a NASA scientist, Earth is warming up at a pace not experienced​ in the last 1,000 years. The temperature rise over the past century was reported to be around 10 times faster than previous rates of warming. This suggests that over the coming century, the warming rate would be at least 20 times faster than the historical average.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Strong 'alien' radio signal found to be terrestrial
article: An unusually strong radio signal, which was believed to have come from a Sun-like star 95 light-years away, was actually from earthly sources, researchers said. The signal was detected using Russia's RATAN–600 radio telescope in May 2015 and was reported earlier in the week. "It can be said with confidence that no sought-for signal has been detected yet", researchers added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New-found asteroid came within 80k km of Earth
article: A newly found asteroid, named '2016 QA2', came within 80,000 km of the Earth on Sunday, which is a little over one-fifth of the moon's distance from Earth. The 25-55 metre wide asteroid was first spotted on Saturday and found to orbit the Sun in a more elliptical​ path than Earth, taking 350 days to complete one revolution, researchers said

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Rare type of deep-Earth seismic waves detected
article: Japenese scientists have detected a phenomenon called "weather bomb", which generated rare "S" type deep-Earth seismic waves through the Atlantic seafloor in 2014. Weather-triggered waves occur when sea waves crash together, sending energy into the ocean floor. The energy spreads as faint "P" and "S" seismic waves, with the latter being slower (over 20 kilometre-per-second) and harder to detect.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: World's oldest fossils dating 3.7 bn years found
article: Australian researchers have unearthed the world's oldest fossils in Greenland dating back approximately 3.7 billion years, pushing back life's earliest evidence by 220 million years. The find showed diverse microbial life, indicating life emerged within few hundred million years of Earth's birth. It can also help determine the possibility of life on Mars, as it contained water during that period.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Satellite hit by tiny space particle, suffers damage
article: European Space Agency's Copernicus Sentinel-1A, a radar imaging satellite launched in 2014, was hit by a millimetre-sized space particle on August 23, the agency confirmed on Wednesday. The impact created a 40-centimetre dent in the satellite's solar panel, causing a sudden small reduction in power. The particle was reportedly traveling at 40,000 kmph at the time of the collision.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Former Pune MP builds science library for public
article: Pradeep Rawat, a Pune-based former MP, has built a library out of his book collection to help people access scientific literature. Named ‘Rawat’s Nature Library’, it consists over 5,000 books on science and evolutionary biology and is open to all for free. The book categories include Brain and Behaviours, Plants and Animals, Environmental Science, Classical Science, and Science in Marathi.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Human brain found to constantly perform maths
article: American researchers have shown that the human brain constantly carries out mathematical computations like probability to make sense of the observations. The team found that our brain can accurately track the likelihood of several explanations for what we observe. This continuous assessment of the surroundings helps us formulate our behaviour and decisions, the research added.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Newly discovered fish to be named after Obama
article: A newly discovered species of fish is set to be named after US President Barack Obama, honouring his decision to quadruple the size of the 'Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument'. The species is the first fish known to live only within the Papahānaumokuākea marine sanctuary, which after expansion houses more than 7,000 species and has become the largest marine protected area.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Spongy solid material made to behave like liquid
article: US-based scientists have found a method to get a solid material to act like a liquid, without liquefying it. Pressing COF-5, a nano sponge-like non-flammable synthetic material, into nail-sized pellets, they found its internal crystal structure arranged in patterns that allow lithium ions to flow easily, like in a liquid. The find may prove helpful in developing safer non-flammable batteries.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Zika pesticides kill millions of honeybees in US
article: Millions of honeybees were killed in South Carolina, US after local officials aerially sprayed the area with the pesticide 'naled' targeting Zika virus-carrying mosquitoes on Sunday morning. A local business co-owner said she lost 46 beehives within minutes of spraying. Officials have reportedly apologised for failing to notify local beekeepers about the aerial spray, the first in 14 years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Future animal movement due to climate change mapped
article: American scientists have created an animated map which shows the hot spots for animal migration in the Western Hemisphere, in response to climate change in future. The colour-coded map depicts separate movement patterns for mammals, birds and amphibians and is based on US' wind flow patterns. The map predicts the Appalachian and Rocky Mountains would be important movement areas.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New drug claims to stop Alzheimer's development
article: Swiss researchers have discovered an antibody that they claim can completely remove the visible signs of the Alzheimer's disease from the brain. The antibody, aducanumab, is based on an immune cell taken from the blood of elderly Alzheimer's-free people. It has been found to slow the rate of cognitive decline in patients who were treated with it for a year.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mechanism controlling alcohol consumption found
article: Swedish researchers have found alcohol dependency stops the production of an enzyme, PRDM2, in brain's frontal lobe, whose deficiency leads to continued use of alcohol despite adverse effects. The team claims to be the first to identify this molecular mechanism. An alcoholic, someone with impaired PRDM2 enzyme, doesn't have sufficient impulse control to refrain from drinking, researchers said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: UK to ban microbeads from cosmetics by 2017 end
article: The UK government has agreed to ban plastic microbeads in beauty products by the end of 2017, following a campaign by environmentalists. When dumped in water bodies, the fish egg-sized beads appear like food to marine life and causes digestive problems, affecting their growth. Notably, the US has already approved the ban on the same starting from mid-2017.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Volcano on dwarf planet erupts ice: NASA
article: NASA's Dawn mission has discovered a volcano on Ceres, a dwarf planet, that is made of ice instead of lava. Ahuna Mons, the 4000-metre high mountain is a cryovolcano, which ejects extremely salty water that freezes on the surface. Ceres, which orbits the Sun between Mars and Jupiter, has witnessed similar geological activity in the past billion years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA observatory witnesses double eclipse
article: NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory caught a 'double eclipse' on Thursday, wherein both the Earth and Moon passed from in front of the Sun. The particular geometrical arrangement of the celestial bodies also resulted in a simultaneous eclipse visible from eastern and southern Africa. The observatory has been observing the Sun since 2010 to understand the solar variations impacting the Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA carries out first DNA sequencing in space
article: In a first, DNA sequencing was successfully carried out in microgravity by a NASA astronaut this past weekend, aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Scientists claim a space-based sequencer could diagnose illness and help protect astronauts' health during long-duration missions. It could also help identify microbes growing on the ISS and even DNA-based life forms outside Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Milky Way saw massive explosion 6 mn-years-ago'
article: A recent study revealed the Milky Way witnessed a "massive" explosion six million-years-ago, when the first human ancestors, hominins, walked the Earth. It led to the formation of a void area at the galaxy's center, extending two-thirds of the way to Earth. The explosion saw some gasses move towards the centre, with other gasses being pumped out at 1,000 km/sec.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA releases Jupiter's pole's close-up pictures
article: US space agency NASA has released close-up pictures of Jupiter's north pole captured by its spacecraft Juno. The detailed pictures show the planet's swirling clouds at the pole including the first evidence of cloud shadowing on Jupiter. The images were captured by Juno last week as it made its closest approach to Jupiter after entering its orbit in July.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA astronauts conduct 7-hour spacewalk
article: NASA astronauts Jeff Williams and Kate Rubins on Thursday conducted a seven-hour-long spacewalk from the International Space Station, the 195th spacewalk ever conducted for station maintenance. During the walk, the astronauts retracted a thermal radiator, installed two enhanced HD cameras on the station’s truss and fixed a joint that enables one of the ISS’s solar arrays to rotate.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA releases video capturing 3 hurricanes
article: US space agency NASA has released a time-lapse video capturing three hurricanes, taken from the International Space Station on Tuesday. The footage shows Hurricanes Lester and Madeline in the Pacific Ocean, and then Hurricane Gaston in the Atlantic Ocean. Notably, the International Space Station orbits the Earth at a speed of over 7.6 km/sec at an altitude of 400 km.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What is causing the Earth to get warmer
article: A six-minute video explores various possibilities to explain the reasons behind the Earth getting warmer. According to the video, the 'wobbly orbit' of the Earth around the sun, along with high use of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane is responsible for the change. It further explains various climate-graphs based on the effects of volcanic explosions and deforestation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'African elephant population down 30% in 7 yrs'
article: According to the Great Elephant Census, the African elephant population has witnessed a decline of about 30% between 2007-2014, largely due to poaching. Reportedly, about one lakh elephants were killed in the African continent between 2010-2012 for their tusks. Currently, there are less than four lakh savanna elephants left and their numbers are further dropping at 8% per year.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Indian-origin boy devises breast cancer treatment
article: A 16-year-old Indian-origin boy in the UK claims to have found a treatment to the most deadly form of breast cancer. Krtin Nithiyanandam has reportedly found a way to make the triple-negative breast cancer into a kind responsive to drugs. Krtin said he devised a way to silence genes that produce ID4, which turns cancer into a less dangerous state.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Scientists leave 'Mars' dome after a year in isolation
article: Six scientists left the Mauna Loa dome in Hawaii on Sunday, after completing a year-long simulation of a Mars mission. The group, which was allowed to go out of the dome only after wearing spacesuits, managed limited resources while conducting research and working to avoid personal conflicts. This was the second-longest such mission after a 520-day mission by Russian scientists.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Coma patient's brain jump-started by ultrasound
article: UCLA doctors have "jump-started" a 25-year-old coma patient's brain using low-intensity focused ultrasound pulsation. Initially, the patient showed a conscious response when the doctors roused neurons in his thalamus, but after few days, he was fully awake. The team claimed a portable low-cost device could be developed to help recover coma patients if the treatment works in future trials.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists plan to replicate sun's core energy
article: American scientists plan to replicate the way the sun and stars create energy through fusion, using spherical tokamaks – experimental machines designed to create and study fusion reactions. Similar to the sun, the fusion reactors produce high-pressure plasmas which fuel the fusion reactions using strong magnetic fields. Scientists claim such advancements could produce limitless carbon-free energy.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA plans to send submarine to Saturn's moon
article: NASA is planning to send a submarine to Saturn's largest moon Titan to explore the depths of its largest ocean and search for signs of "hydrocarbon-based life". Titan is the only known celestial body other than the Earth to have stable pools of liquid on its surface, however, unlike Earth, it features extreme cold temperatures and oceans of liquid methane.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video gives tour of International Space Station
article: A 29-minute video shows Indian-origin American astronaut Sunita Williams, also known as Suni Williams, describing what happens inside the International Space Station. During her tour of the space station, Williams explains how bathrooms are used in space, the food available in the kitchen, and further describes individual sleep stations. She also explains the various laboratories on the satellite.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: MIT 3D-prints structures that 'remember' shape
article: MIT engineers have 3D-printed structures that 'remember' their original shapes. After being stretched, twisted, and bent at extreme angles, the structures went back to their original forms within seconds of heating to a certain optimal temperature. This can be useful for applications like solar panels that track the sun's movement, and drug capsules that open upon early signs of infection.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Huge reef discovered behind Great Barrier Reef
article: Australian scientists have discovered a reef spanning 6,000 square kilometres behind the Great Barrier Reef. It consists of vast fields of "unusual" donut-shaped circular mounds known as Halimeda bioherms, formed by the growth of Halimeda algae. These mounds were found to be around 10 metres deep and are each spread across 200-300 metres.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Vaccine halved cervical cancer rate in 10 years
article: With over 170 million doses of the world's first cancer vaccine 'HPV vaccine' administered across 130 countries, the number of new cervical cancers has reportedly halved 10 years after the vaccine's development. HPV is a virus that lives on the skin and often transmits through sexual intercourse. Notably, Australia has witnessed 90% reduction in HPV infections in last 10 years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study maps changes in Earth's surface over 30yrs
article: According to a study, 1,15,000 square kilometer of land has become water and 1,73,000 square kilometer of water has become land over the last 30 years. The Tibetan Plateau and the Aral Sea have witnessed largest conversions to water and land respectively. Increase in dams, creation of coastline-houses and diversion of rivers for irrigation were held responsible for this shift.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA's Juno makes closest approach to Jupiter
article: NASA's Juno spacecraft on Saturday at 6:21 PM IST reached the point of closest approach to Jupiter. It was about 4,200 km above the giant planet's swirling clouds, traveling at 208,000 kmph with respect to the planet. The spacecraft, which was launched on August 5, 2011, entered Jupiter's orbit on July 4 this year.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Massive dark matter galaxy discovered
article: Astronomers have found a massive galaxy called Dragonfly 44 that consists almost entirely of dark matter. It was revealed when astronomers noted that its few visible stars move at velocities far greater than expected. Star velocities indicate a galaxy's mass. Notably, Dragonfly 44's mass is estimated at 1 trillion times the Sun's mass, 99.99% of which is dark matter.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study reveals facial features are stored in genes
article: According to a recently published study, facial features including nose size, face width, and the distance between the eyes are associated with particular genetic variations. Scientists claim the findings could supplement the study of evolutionary changes in human facial features and could also help forensic scientists to recreate criminal faces using evidence left at the crime scene.​

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Study reveals Calcium's role in learning, memory
article: Calcium in mitochondria, the power generator in cells, affects brain development and cognitive functions like memory and learning in adults, according to recent research. The study, which is based on adult fruit flies, shows that blocking a channel that brings calcium to the mitochondria, called 'mitochondrial calcium uniporter', causes memory impairment but does not hinder learning capacity.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Study finds how Zika virus damages foetal brain
article: Scientists from Yale University have found a key mechanism by which Zika virus affects the human foetal brain. The virus diverts the TBK1 protein necessary for neural cell division. This leads to the death of stem cells instead of forming brain cells, thereby increasing the risk of microcephaly, a defect in which babies are born with 'abnormally' small brains.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: UK's most endangered butterfly revived over 3 decades
article: The 'Large Blue' butterfly which became extinct in Britain in 1979, is thriving after three decades of conservation efforts like scrub clearance and grassland maintenance. With around 10,000 butterflies laying over 2,50,000 eggs, the butterfly species has witnessed the highest numbers seen in over 80 years. Notably, it's the only UK butterfly still on the IUCN's list of threatened species.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video discusses recently discovered Earth-like planet
article: A four-minute video discusses the recently discovered Earth-like planet called 'Proxima b', orbiting in the habitable zone of our sun's nearest star Proxima Centauri. According to the video, the planet is around 30% larger than the Earth and takes about eleven days to complete a single orbit. The planet is also the closest known exoplanet beyond our solar system.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: New model to predict sudden cardiac death
article: American researchers have developed a model to predict the risk of sudden cardiac deaths (SCD). Research suggested cardiovascular risk factors such as smoking habit, blood pressure, diabetes and cholesterol can help predict the SCD risk. The team analysed over 18,000 adults without any history of cardiovascular disease, and found that African Americans have higher SCD risk than white individuals.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: MIT's solar "step cell" doubles cell efficiency
article: By combining layers of gallium arsenide phosphide and silicon germanium, MIT researchers have co-developed a new solar cell with a claimed efficiency of 35%, compared to 15-20% of silicon-based solar cells. The cell, fashioned in a step-like manner using the layers, harvests a broader range of energy and is cheaper as the silicon germanium substrate can be reused, scientists claim.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Magnetic bacteria used for targeting tumours
article: Canadian researchers have demonstrated the process of directly targeting tumours using magnetic bacteria along with cancer-killing​ drugs. Tumours are difficult to target as they are low in oxygen compared to the outer cells, and needs to be targeted differently. The bacteria not only migrates towards magnetic fields, it also tends to swim towards low oxygen concentrations, targeting the tumours.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Climate change may half coffee-produce by 2050'
article: Climate change could halve the coffee production area, which also supports over 120 million people, by 2050, as per a report by Australia-based Climate Institute. The report added in Tanzania, where 2.4 million people rely on coffee, production has witnessed a decline of 50% since the 1960s. Extreme temperatures and high-altitude rains are among the unsuitable conditions for coffee crops.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Extinct 600-gram lion fossils found in Australia
article: The fossils of extinct marsupial lion were recently unearthed in Australia. It has been named 'Microleo attenboroughi' after British naturalist Sir David Attenborough, who had declared the species' discovery site "one of the four most important fossil areas in the world". The species, which lived 18 million years ago and weighed around 600 grams, preyed on insects and small vertebrates.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New method detects cancer, infections in 10 min
article: American researchers have developed a new method which they claim can detect cancer and infectious diseases in 10 minutes, as opposed to 2-4 hours taken by current technologies. Current technologies use enzymes to detect proteins, the biomarkers of the disease. The new method doesn't use enzymes but uses a molecular chain reaction strongly triggered only in presence of target proteins.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Cleaner smelting process discovered by accident
article: MIT engineers have accidentally discovered a more efficient process for smelting metal while trying to develop a new kind of high-temperature​ storage battery. Instead of storing charge, the battery was found to be performing electrolysis, producing a metal 99.9% pure. While traditional smelting processes generate large quantities of greenhouse gas, MIT's accidental method produced almost none.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Boeing simulates worst possible landing scenarios
article: Boeing is conducting ground landing tests to simulate worst possible scenarios including landing angles and velocities at NASA's Langley Research Center for its Starliner spacecraft. This is aimed at making sure that the Starliner spacecraft, which is expected to fly two astronauts to the International Space Station in its 2018 debut, can handle such tough situations.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Fish devolves into ancestral form in just 100 yrs
article: A carp fish species has been found to devolve into its ancestral fully scaled form in just 100 years, a study reports. In 1912, fish with fewer scales were produced using artificial selection and introduced in Madagascar, where no carp had existed. In the recent study, 65% of the nearly 700 carp in Madagascar were found to be fully scaled.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Tiny black holes may hit Earth every 1000 yrs'
article: According to a recent NASA study, microscopic black holes could be hitting the Earth every 1,000 years. These black holes, formed shortly after the big bang, travel across the universe at very high speeds and could weigh as much as the moon. "If one passed near the Earth... it would affect the orbits of all of our satellites, researchers said.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: Moon an interesting place...I recommend it: Armstrong
article: Neil Armstrong, on being asked what it was like to stand on the moon, once said "It's an interesting place to be. I recommend it." The NASA astronaut, who passed away four years ago on August 25, 2012, became the world's first person to set foot on the moon after the Apollo 11 mission in 1969.

author: Trivedi Bhutnath
abstract: Pluto was removed from the planet list on Aug 24, 2006
article: The International Astronomical Union, on August 24, 2006, in a controversial decision, had decided to remove Pluto from the planet list of the solar system. The decision, which came after scientists came up with a new definition of the term ‘Planet’, brought down the total number of planets in the solar system to eight.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: New find pushes earth's oxygenation by 300mn yrs
article: American researchers have unearthed microscopic air bubbles trapped in rock salt, which they claim predates Earth's oxygenation by 300 million years. At that time, the average oxygen content was found to be 10.9%, half of today's concentration. Till now, two major oxygenation events have reportedly occurred in the earth's 4.5-billion-year history, the first being around 2.4 billion years ago​.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover new inflammatory disease
article: American researchers have discovered a rare inflammatory disease, called otulipenia, that primarily affects young children, causes symptoms like fever, rashes and diarrhoea, and can sometimes prove lethal. The disease occurs when the immune system attacks the host's own tissues and is caused by malfunction of a gene which regulates the development of new blood vessels to fight infection.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Number of planets reduced from 9 to 8 ten years ago
article: Following a new definition of ‘Planet’ by the International Astronomical Union, Pluto was removed from the planet list of the solar system ten years ago on August 24, 2006. The decision brought down the total number of planets in the solar system to eight, consisting of Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Human impact on environment found to slow down
article: The rate of impact of human activities on the environment has slowed as compared to population and economic growth rates, according to a recent study. The researchers studied human footprint between 1993 and 2009, using data from satellites and on-ground surveys. Its lead author said the slowing human footprint rate indicates that humans are now using natural resources more efficiently.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Blue lakes observed on Antarctica's ice sheets
article: In a first, scientists have found that atop the coastal Langhovde Glacier in Eastern Antarctica's Dronning Maud Land, nearly 8,000 meltwater lakes have formed between 2000 and 2013. In some cases these lakes have been found draining down into the floating parts of the glacier, potentially weakening the ice shelf and contributing to global sea level rise.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Edible battery created from skin pigment
