article: American scientists have created an edible battery using the skin pigment​ melanin, which could power medical devices put inside the body for diagnosing and treating diseases. Melanin binds and unbinds metallic ions in the battery, which is claimed to power a 5 milliWatt device for 18 hours, a time sufficient to sense bacteria in the gut and release medicine.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Method developed to visualise roots in ground
article: German researchers have developed a method to visualize plants' root activity by measuring their electrical properties. The minerals in soil are usually present as ions that influence the roots' charge distribution, enabling the required visualization process. Although single fine roots can't be recognized, the resolution is good enough to study root's nutrient dynamics, researchers said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Daily coffee habit may be genetic: Study
article: A team of Edinburgh University researchers has found a gene that they believe might be controlling people's daily coffee intake. The research claims a specific PDSS2 gene variant slows down caffeine metabolism in the body, producing a longer lasting effect. People who carry the gene variant were found to consume about one less cup of coffee per day than non-carriers.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: War-induced pollution causes birth defects: Study
article: An Iranian study has found war-induced pollution might be a major cause of birth defects and cancer in war zones like Iraq. Researchers have identified exposure to toxic materials from bombings and military waste burning affects people living near military bases. Reportedly, baby-tooth of an Iraqi child with the birth defect had 50 times more lead than similar Iranian samples.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: '130-km crack in Antarctica ice shelf worsening'
article: A 130-km long, 350-metre​ wide crack in Antarctica's fourth largest ice shelf was reportedly found to get worse significantly. The crack, about the size of Scotland, grew 30 km in the last five years. Predictions suggest if the ice shelf shatters, over 6,000 square kilometres of ice would be lost, raising the global sea level by up to 10 centimetres.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA regains contact with spacecraft after 2 yrs
article: US space agency NASA on Sunday re-established contact with its STEREO-B mission after nearly two years of communications silence. The team had lost its connection during a test of the ship's command lost timer on October 1st, 2014. STEREO-B (Solar Terrestrial Relations Observatory) is one of two probes launched by NASA in 2006 to study the Sun and solar weather.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Fungi used in eco-friendly battery recycling
article: Naturally-occurring fungi are being used by researchers to develop an environment-friendly recycling process for extracting cobalt and lithium from waste batteries. The process involves using the organic acids generated by fungi to leach out metals from the batteries. Reportedly, 85% and 48% of lithium and cobalt respectively were extracted from cathodes of spent batteries using fungi.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Orangutans may get extinct within 10 years'
article: According to an animal rescue charity, orangutans face complete extinction in the next 10 years unless preservation measures are taken. The species, native of Indonesian and Malaysian forests, appeared on the critically endangered list last month. Reportedly, 76 million acres of Indonesia's forests have disappeared in the last 25 years, which is cited as a major cause for the endangerment.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Artificial' atom created in carbon material
article: Researchers have created 'artificial' atoms in the carbon material graphene, which can feature properties beyond those of conventional atoms. The 'artificial' atoms have electrons which can occupy discrete energy levels and can be useful for several applications as their properties can directly be tuned. The artificial atoms can have ideal properties for quantum computers, scientists claim.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Mystery of 'eclipse wind' solved after 300 years
article: The mystery of the 'eclipse wind', first noted in 1715 as the change in wind direction during an eclipse, was recently resolved after over 300 years. The change in wind direction was caused by drop in atmospheric temperature during eclipse, preventing air to rise from the ground and decreasing the wind speed, which leads to a shift in its direction.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Mars had habitable climate 4 bn years ago: Study
article: According to a study by English researchers, Mars had a warm and wet climate, suitable for life, around four billion years ago. The team identified an over 17,000-km network of now-defunct river channels suggesting the planet contained flowing water at that time. These channels were earlier believed to be caused by erosion from rain and surface runoff, similar to Earth.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: First photo of Earth from Moon was taken 50 years ago
article: Earth was first photographed from the Moon 50 years ago on August 23, 1966 by a spacecraft named 'Lunar Orbiter 1'. The spacecraft took the photograph during its 16th orbit when it was just about to pass behind the Moon. The photograph was received at the NASA tracking station at Robledo De Chavela in Madrid, Spain.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover new type of eye movement
article: German scientists have discovered a new type of eye movement synchronised with blinking. The movement helps reset the eye after it twists while viewing a rotating object, in order to avoid moving beyond the mechanical limits of eye muscles. The movement, which also creates an interruption in the visual perception, remains unnoticed as it happens automatically while blinking.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: China unveils probe for its 2020 Mars mission
article: China on Tuesday unveiled a rover, lander and orbiter for its 2020 Mars mission, along with details of the scientific instruments that it will send to the Red Planet. Weighing around 200 kilograms, the aircraft will reportedly carry 13 payloads to study Martian soil, environment and atmosphere. It will also explore the planet's inner structure including water and ice distribution.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Video: NASA's tribute to Neil Armstrong
article: NASA has paid a video tribute to the first man to set foot on the Moon, Neil Armstrong, who died four years ago on August 25, 2012. The video includes photos from the moon landing, with the song 'Tranquility Base'. The song begins with,"...Taking small steps and giant leaps and planting the flag, in a place no one had been."

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Sleep 'resets' brain memory connections: Study
article: German researchers have found that sleep 'resets' the memory and learning connections in the human brain that build up during the waking hours. The scientists conducted tests on 11 men and 9 women aged 19-25 and found the loss of sleep muddled brain's electrical activity. Also, the neurons became over-connected and affected the memory and learning abilities of participants.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Young star 30 times as massive as Sun discovered
article: Astronomers have identified a 'protostar' over 30 times more massive than Sun and located 11,000 light-years away. It is still gathering material from its parent molecular cloud, and may become more massive when fully grown, researchers said. Such stars are created in short time periods of around 1,00,000 years and burn more quickly, making it harder to observe them.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Nanowires created using modified soil bacteria
article: US-based researchers have created nanowires using genetically modified soil bacteria Geobacter, a species abundantly occurring in nature. Replacing the bacterial amino acids with tryptophan to increase conductivity, the team created wires smaller and more durable than conventional ones. If incorporated, future computer processors could reportedly be made using natural resources like plant waste.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Human-induced global warming began 180yrs back'
article: According to Australian researchers, humans have been causing global warming for nearly 180 years, contradicting previous belief that human-induced changes began in the 20th-century. The team studied climate patterns for the past 500 years to identify the global warming trend. Climate change was thought to be a 20th-century phenomenon as 19th-century measurements are rare, a researcher said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 9 antibiotics per day could be harmful: Study
article: According to a recently published study, taking more than nine antibiotics per day may give rise to untreatable antibiotic-resistant superbugs. The study defined 8.54 daily doses per capita per year, hoping to lower the overall use by 17.5% globally. Scientists have estimated that by 2050 around 10 million people could die every year globally as a result of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New species confirmed 16 years after discovery
article: A new species of sea creature, named Nudibranchs, was recently confirmed in Australia, 16 years after it was first observed. Previously mistaken for sea slugs due to early shedding of shells, the soft-bodied organisms are distinguished from other species on the basis of size, anatomy, colouring and distribution and have been nicknamed "butterflies of the sea".

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Humans caught common cold from camels: Study
article: According to a study, humans may have originally caught the common cold virus from camels. Research on about 1,000 camels found pathogens related to the human common cold virus in almost 6% camels. However, tests have confirmed that there is no danger of any cold-epidemic because the human immune system​ has already primed against it.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Jellyfish proteins help create new type of laser
article: In a first, British scientists have created a new polariton laser using fluorescent jellyfish proteins at room temperature. Notably, most materials at room temperature have closely placed light-emitting molecules which don't allow for laser light production. However, in the recent development, each protein shell encloses one light emitting component, which is activated by a pulse of blue light.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Replica of a 'mysterious' manuscript to be made
article: A Spanish publishing company has got the rights to clone Voynich Manuscript, believed to be one of the world's most mysterious books. The centuries-old manuscript is believed to hold magical powers and is written in a language which reportedly hasn't been cracked so far. The company plans to make 898 copies of the historic text and sell each for $7,800-8,900.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US scientists seek volunteers to infect with Zika
article: American researchers are seeking volunteers to get infected with Zika virus in order to test promising vaccines. The "human challenge study" wants to infect healthy people in winter to track the virus' progress and the reaction of human bodies. The researchers are yet to get the approval from government regulators, after which, they'll start testing in December.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Venus-like exoplanet might be 1st to have oxygen
article: According to a research, a Venus-like exoplanet called GJ 1132b, situated 39 light-years from Earth, might be the first exoplanet to have an oxygen atmosphere. The abundant ultraviolet on the planet breaks water molecules into oxygen and hydrogen. However, scientists claim that oxygen could not be a sign of life because of its high surface temperature of about 230 °C.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Himalayas moving northward due to tectonic lift
article: A canyon in the eastern part of the Himalayas is slowly moving northward due to pressure from a tectonic lift, according to a study. Earlier, researchers believed that erosion was the main cause of the migration. The findings were obtained by measuring the age of minerals beneath the surface to determine the rate of rock movements.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: US will witness total solar eclipse next year
article: On August 21, 2017, a total solar eclipse will be visible from 14 US States, marking the first such instance for Americans since 1979. Predicted to last for two minutes and forty seconds, the eclipse is being billed as the "Great American Total Solar Eclipse". Total solar eclipses can typically only be seen from extremely remote locations on Earth.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Zika virus can damage adult brains too: Study
article: According to a recent study, the Zika virus can cause "major, lasting damage" in an adult human brain, contradicting the previous assumption that it only affects foetuses. Experiments conducted on mice revealed that the mosquito-borne virus attacks brain cells linked with memory and learning. Such attacks could eventually lead to brain shrinkage and major cognitive impairment, scientists said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Pacific sea level may help predict temp changes
article: Sea level rise in the Pacific Ocean can be used to estimate future global surface temperatures, according to a study by geoscientists. The study states that sea surface height, not temperature, provides a more accurate estimation of the heat stored in a water column. It estimates that by end-2016, global surface temperatures will rise by 0.28ºC from 2014.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA releases fuel tank construction time-lapse
article: NASA has released a one-minute time-lapse video showing the construction of a liquid hydrogen fuel tank. The 40-metre high fuel tank will be part of NASA's new Space Launch System. It is expected to be used for the first time in 2018 to launch the Orion spacecraft which will carry a crew to deep space, and eventually to Mars.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 2014 Napa quake's 'creeps' lingered for 4 weeks
article: Research at MIT has revealed that the magnitude 6.0 earthquake which hit Napa in the US state of California in 2014, continued to 'creep' for at least four weeks after the main event. The post-quake 'afterslip' caused certain sections of the main fault-area to shift by as much as 40 centimetres in the month following the main earthquake.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New degradable rubber can help reduce tyre waste
article: A new way of making synthetic rubber with degradable materials has been developed by researchers to reduce the harmful effects of scrap tyres on the environment. The rubber material can be easily degraded back to its chemical building blocks and reused in new tyres, researchers claimed. Reportedly, about 270 million tyres were discarded in the US in 2013.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Perseid meteor shower time-lapse images released
article: Florida Institute of Technology has released the time-lapse images captured during the Perseid meteor shower, spanning from July to late August. The images were taken with different specialised cameras developed to monitor, track and analyse meteors in the atmosphere around the globe. The wide angle cameras collect data every moment and are also capable of playing back missed events.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA fires world record 44 rockets in 1 flight
article: The Guinness World Records recently recognised NASA's September 2015 launch which saw 44 rockets being fired in a single flight, as a world record for the most rockets fired in a single launch. The mission, which used 37 engines to create an exhaust cloud, three for the rocket launch, and four for position control, was aimed at studying "dusty plasmas".

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Australian volcanoes threw debris over 2300 km'
article: A study has revealed volcanic eruptions in eastern Australia around 100 million years ago, were so powerful they blasted sand-sized zircon crystals from one side of Australia to the other, almost 2,300 km away. It was found that the crystals didn't match any rock composition​ in Western Australia, but reflected eastern Australia's volcanic rock in terms of age and geochemicals.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Team plans to restore extinct seabird using DNA
article: An international team of scientists plans to restore the Great Auk, a flightless seabird which has been extinct for 200 years, using fossil DNA. Using DNA to sequence its genetic code, scientists hope to program the code into its nearest living relative's cells. Fertilised embryos would then be implanted into a bird big enough to lay a Great Auk egg.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Scientists reconstruct face of mummified woman
article: Scientists have successfully reconstructed the face of Meritamun, a mummified Egyptian woman suspected to have lived over 2000 years ago. The team comprised of researchers from Monash University, University of Melbourne, Victorian Institute of Forensic Medicine and others. The team guessed the gender and age of Meritamun, but they intend to use carbon dating to ascertain the details.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: ISRO plans mission to study the sun by 2020
article: ISRO Director Mylswamy Annadurai recently said that ISRO is planning to launch 'Aditya-L1', the first Indian mission to study the sun, by the year 2020. He also added that the space organisation is planning to launch four more important satellites in the next three months and is working to launch 70 satellites in the next three years.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Human DNA has 7 million variations points: Study
article: According to a study, one person's DNA can differ from another's at more than 7 million points. A person carries tens of thousands of DNA variants and on an average 12.5% DNA bases differs among people. Obtained from gene analysis of around 60,000 people, scientists claim the findings could help in treating diseases like schizophrenia and some heart conditions.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: New sensor detects drugs, explosives from 30 m
article: Researchers have developed a chemical sensor capable of detecting drugs and explosives from 30 metres away. It reads the unique frequencies given off when gases or liquids interact with light. The device claims to make 1,200 detections per hour, over six times better than standard scanners. Such devices can be installed at airport entrances to scan bags for suspicious materials.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Rising sea levels good for coral reefs: Study
article: Global warming caused sea level rise may help moderate water temperatures in many reef habitats that experience strong tidal conditions, according to an Australian study. The researchers added that a moderate sea level rise could substantially reduce local water temperatures in future. The temperature fluctuations in the reef were found to vary by over 10°C over a single tidal cycle.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: ESA builds 3D wind-mapping satellite 'Aeolus'
article: The European Space Agency (ESA) has completed assembling the Aeolus, a satellite which will be launched next year for 3D mapping of winds in the atmosphere. It carries a giant laser called 'Aladin', which will UV-scan the Earth's atmosphere to measure wind speed and direction, and create a 3D wind map from the surface to a height of 30 km.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists map brain at single-neuron resolution
article: Neuroscientists have demonstrated a new method of mapping the brain at the resolution of individual neurons, according to a research published in Neuron. The new technology called 'Multiplexed Analysis of Projections by Sequencing' converts the task of brain mapping into RNA sequencing and claims to be less expensive, labour-intensive and time-consuming than current mapping technologies.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists make 'most efficient' solar receiver
article: Scientists from the Australian National University claimed to have created the most efficient solar receiver with an efficiency of 97%, surpassing the previous best of 93.6%. While converting 3.4% more sunlight into steam and reducing losses, scientists said the efficiency progression could help lower carbon emissions. Such solar dishes can help power a whole street of houses, researchers added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Spider silk found to increase microscope power
article: In a first, UK-based scientists have used spider silk to amplify the resolving power of an optical microscope. Physical laws limit normal optical microscope's resolving power at 200 nm. The team used a cylindrical piece of silk, measuring around one-tenth of a human hair's thickness, from Nephila spider as an added lens that provided a 2-3 fold improvement in magnification.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Climatic conditions affect carbon levels in soil
article: Australian researchers have found that organic carbon buildup in soil can be limited by hot and dry climatic conditions, thereby decreasing crop productivity and limiting measures to counter greenhouse emissions. The ability of soil to store carbon was found to be significantly less in places with less than 450 mm annual rainfall and average daily temperature of over 17.2°C.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains the rise of humans
article: An eight-minute video by YouTube channel 'SciShow' explains the rise of humans by tracing the life forms that existed 65 million years ago. According to the video, the mammals started expanding after the extinction of dinosaurs. It further explains how continents shifted and the climate changed over time. Interestingly, it also mentions that earlier there were numerous human-like species.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: NASA launches $1 million contest to create robot
article: NASA has launched a $1 million contest that seeks to develop the capabilities of humanoid robots to help astronauts on Mars missions. The teams need to build a virtual robot, modeled after NASA's Robonaut 5, to complete several tasks in a simulation. It will be held in a virtual environment, where the robots will face challenges related to Martian habitat.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Polio reappears in Nigeria; 2 reported paralysed
article: According to reports, polio has reappeared in Nigeria, with two children having been paralysed by wild-type polio virus. Findings suggest that the virus may have been circulating undetected for years in the country, with non-existent to poor vaccination in militant-controlled areas. Nigeria, which was celebrating 2 years without a wild polio case, launched a mass vaccination campaign in response.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New less addictive alternative of morphine made
article: Scientists claim to have developed a new drug that is less risky and addictive than morphine, but has the same painkilling power. Initial tests on mice revealed that the new compound activates nerve cell surface receptors responsible for morphine's painkilling effects. However, unlike morphine, it doesn't activate receptors that suppress breathing or release the pleasure-related chemical dopamine.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: S'pore tested quantum tech in space before China
article: A Singapore university had reportedly launched a quantum satellite in space in 2015, prior to China's QUESS on August 16 this year. The 1.65 kg nanosatellite carried basic components to test the viability of quantum-based technology for secure long distance communications. The satellite was one of six Singaporean satellites to be launched by India's Polar Launch Vehicle in December 2015.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Bananas could be extinct in five years: Study
article: Bananas could be extinct in five years because of a fast-advancing disease compound called Sigatoka complex, according to a study. The complex made up of three fungal diseases lowers the banana tree's immunity, posing a threat to about 100 million tonnes of bananas worldwide. Reportedly, 30-35% of banana production cost is in fungicide applications, which most farmers fail to afford.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: MIT team store memories in DNA of human cells
article: MIT engineers have devised an analog memory storage system to record complex histories in human cell DNA, allowing cells to retrieve information about the duration and intensity of past events. Based on a principle that programs cells to flip DNA sections when certain events occur. The system could help scientists study genetic impacts of diseases like cancer.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Indian startup makes ink from air pollution
article: Indian startup Graviky Labs has initiated a venture called 'Air Ink' which creates pens with ink made of recycled air pollution. The venture strives towards arresting carbon from car emissions​ and recycling it into usable ink. Each pen contains an equivalent of 30 to 50 minutes of air pollution generated by car exhaust.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Gene editing shows how fins evolved into hands
article: American scientists have shown the evolutionary link between fish fins and land animals' hands using CRISPR, a gene-editing tool. Programming the fin-related genes in a zebrafish and the finger-related genes in a mouse to glow as they develop, scientists found si​milar glows in both. The scientists suggested the biggest difference between a fin and hand may be the tissue.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Black hole experiment backs Hawking's prediction
article: Experiments conducted by an Israeli professor have supported one of Stephen Hawking's predictions about black holes. He simulated a black hole in a super-cooled state of matter called a Bose-Einstein condensate and observed that particles were spontaneously escaping his replica black hole. This is in accordance with 'Hawking radiation' predicted to be released by black holes.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Viruses more dangerous in the morning: Study
article: Viruses are ten times more dangerous in the morning than at the night, a University of Cambridge study suggests. The study indicates that the clock in every living cell determines how successfully a virus replicates, with a disrupted body clock corresponding to high viral replication. Bmal1, a body clock-controlling gene, was found to be least active during winter.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Mosses create living conditions on Earth: Study
article: A primitive moss is responsible for creating currently known life conditions on Earth, a recent study said. Based on a simulation using fossils and ancient spores, it was revealed that over 400 million years ago, low-growing mosses began extracting atmospheric carbon and spreading over dry land. They then created topsoil for wooden-bodied plants, and raised atmospheric oxygen to current levels.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA astronauts spacewalk to install dock on ISS
article: NASA astronauts Kate Rubins and Jeff Williams on Friday concluded their nearly six-hour spacewalk after installing a new dock onto the International Space Station (ISS). The dock will be used in 2017 by private companies Boeing and SpaceX to start transporting crew to and from the station, marking it the first such instance for private companies.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New method developed to cure corneal blindness
article: Australian researchers have developed a method to cure corneal blindness by growing corneal cells on a layer of thin, soluble film which is implanted in the eye. The film, thinner than a human hair, dissolves within two months, leaving new corneal cells in its place. The disease, corneal blindness, is the fourth most common cause of blindness globally, says WHO.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Robot caterpillar that moves on light developed
article: Researchers at University of Warsaw have created a 15 mm robo-caterpillar that moves on light input. The researchers claim the robot can climb slopes, squeeze into minuscule spaces and move objects ten times its size. The robot is made of shape-shifting materials called Liquid Crystalline Elastomers which contract under a light source and form waves which propel the robot forward.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Satellite imagery may predict regions of poverty
article: A new research study shows that satellite imagery combined with machine learning algorithms can be used to predict regions of poverty in the world. The proposed algorithm combines daytime and nighttime satellite images with economic survey data to create a more accurate distribution of wealth in a region than that provided by conventional 'night lights' models.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA plans to sell the ISS by mid-2020s
article: US space agency NASA plans to hand over control of the International Space Station to a commercial owner sometime around the mid-2020s, a NASA spokesperson has said. "Our desire is to hand the space station over to either a commercial entity... so that research can continue in low-earth orbit", he added. However, NASA did not specify any potential buyer.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: ISS crew to build parking spot for space taxis
article: ISS astronauts Jeff Williams and Kate Rubins will install a parking spot for space taxis in a six-and-half-hour spacewalk on Friday. Power and data cables have been laid out by other crew members, and the structure will be completed with the help of robot Canadarm2. Space taxis from Boeing and SpaceX would carry astronauts to the ISS from 2017 onwards.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: US scientists successfully create RNA strand
article: American researchers claim to have created the first molecules of RNA capable of amplifying genetic information, generating functional molecules and copying other RNAs. This could lead to the creation of synthetic microbes that use RNA as their sole source of genetic information, similar to what is believed to be the RNA world, which existed four billion years ago, preceding DNA.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Eye test may detect Parkinson's before symptoms
article: British scientists claim to have developed a low-cost, non-invasive eye test that can detect Parkinson's disease before symptoms develop. The test, conducted on rats, observed and measured early changes in the retina which occur before brain degeneration triggers disease's external symptoms. Parkinson's is the second most common brain degenerative disease, affecting seven million people annually.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Europe's oldest tree dated to be 1,075 years old
article: A Bosnian pine tree growing in the Pindos mountains of northern Greece has been dated to be more than 1,075 years old, making it the oldest known living thing in Europe. The tree, which has been named 'Adonis' after the Greek god of beauty and desire, survived in a land which has been civilized for over 3,000 years, researchers said.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Laser-like X-rays for better diagnostic abilities
article: Physicists have ideated to combine the advantages of X-ray and laser radiation to form 'European X-ray Free Laser', which they believe will offer the most powerful synchrotron radiation and better diagnostic abilities. The use of laser capabilities with X-rays will reduce scattering and allow its intensity to be focused. This molecular-level-scanning could reveal how drugs affect cells in bodies.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Visible universe found to be 320mn-lt-yrs smaller
article: A recent study using Planck satellite's data found the radius of the visible or observable universe to be actually 320 million light years smaller than what was previously estimated. The findings update the radius of the observable universe from 45.66 billion light-years to 45.34 billion light-years. The updated figure was related to improvements in the measurements' accuracy, researchers said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA offers free access to its research results
article: US space agency NASA has launched a public web access portal to make its research results accessible to the masses for free. This is in response to a 2013 US policy to make government-funded scientific research publicly available. "Through open access...we invite the global community to join us in exploring Earth, air and space", said NASA's Deputy Administrator.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Nova explosion captured for 1st time
article: In a first, Poland-based researchers have captured the before, during and after events of a classical nova explosion. A classical nova occurs in binary star systems, wherein two stars orbit around a common mass-centre. One star pulls matter away from the other and beyond a critical point, a nuclear explosion occurs. The findings provide the first evidence of star hibernation.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Giant goldfish found to damage river ecosystems
article: Goldfish of sizes up to 30 cm and weighing up to​ 2 kg have been found in the river Vasse near Perth, Australia. Researchers have said these fish, released into the wild by pet owners, can have a damaging impact on river ecosystems. They eat the spawn of native fish and uproot plants and stir sediment on the river bed.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 'Graphene-based devices could detect explosives'
article: Russian physicists have found that graphene, a two-dimensional crystalline form of carbon, may be an ideal material to develop devices capable of detecting explosives from a single sample molecule. The team has developed a quantum model of the device that uses plasmons, units of free electron oscillations, to distinguish molecules by focusing infrared light on them.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Stamp-sized device to disinfect water created
article: Researchers at Stanford University have built a stamp-sized device to disinfect contaminated water within minutes when kept out in the sun. The tiny device harnesses the visible portion of sunlight's spectrum, which contains about 50% of total energy. In a sample of 25 ml with a bacterial concentration of 1,000,000 per ml, the device killed 99.99% germs within 20 minutes.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Global warming may lead to saltier beaches
article: According to a study, the increase in temperature and evaporation associated with global warming will lead to beaches becoming saltier. Analysis of sediment samples from a beach on the Delaware Bay show that the evaporation would affect subsurface water flow and salinity in the beach inter-tidal zone. This reportedly will have implications on migration and survival of invertebrates like crabs.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists claim to implant image in mouse brain
article: Columbia University scientists believe they may have implanted an artificial image in the brain of a mouse using a beam of light, reprograming its brain cells. The technique was earlier used to restore the hearing and sight of deaf and blind mice by stimulating clusters of brain cells. The results could help treat conditions like epilepsy in humans, scientists said.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: New bulb transmits data at record 2 Gbps via light
article: Researchers from Saudi Arabia claim to have created lightbulbs that can transmit data at a record speed of 2 GB per second, about 40 times faster than existing Li-Fi devices. Usual methods of Visible Light Communication-based Li-Fi technology transmit data using LEDs, which have a limited bandwidth. The researchers have developed a nanocrystal-based converter that enables faster data transmission.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Plasma could help in bone healing: Study
article: According to a study, cold plasma which is made of electrons that change polarity at microsecond or nanosecond speeds could help bones heal faster. Cold plasma generated using microsecond pulsing can increase bone formation while nanosecond-pulsed cold plasma can inhibit bone formation. The cold plasma can also be used to directly kill cells in cases of skin cancer.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Fixing Great Barrier Reef to cost $8.2bn: Report
article: According to a government report, repair of the water quality of Australia's Great Barrier Reef will cost $8.2 billion over the next decade. The amount is eight times of what has already been set aside. This is part of the Reef 2050 Plan which, if implemented, will keep the reef from being included in the 'world heritage in danger' list.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Roadside testing for marijuana developed
article: Researchers from Stanford University have developed a speedy spit test for detection of marijuana use while driving. The test can detect the presence of THC molecules (chief chemical responsible for marijuana's high) in saliva within three minutes. The portable sensor can deliver the results to phones via Bluetooth, however a prototype is yet to be built.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA mistakenly auctions bag used to gather Moon rocks
article: NASA has admitted that it mistakenly auctioned a bag used by astronauts Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong to collect the Moon's rock samples during the Apollo 11 mission in 1969. The bag was auctioned last year for just $995 following a clerical error, NASA said. The mistake was identified recently when the bag arrived at NASA's Space Center for authentication.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: China launches 1st hack-proof communication satellite
article: China on Tuesday launched the world's first quantum satellite, which will help the country to establish hack-proof communications between space and the ground. The satellite will alert the sender and alter or delete the message when hacking is attempted. If the two-year mission is successful, China will attempt to build a worldwide network that can send uncrackable messages.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Piece of outer solar system meteorite discovered
article: According to a recent study, the Tagish Lake meteorite, which crash-landed on Earth in 2000, came from the Kuiper Belt, present beyond Neptune. A hypothesis said it was pushed inwards four billion years ago when Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune were fighting for a position. Until now, all found meteorites were traced to the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Transparent circuitry to power display on windows
article: Scientists have developed a new technology called atomic layer deposition to improve the performance of transparent circuitry material AZO. The material combines optical transparency with electrical conductivity which can power windscreens, transparent TVs and smart windows. A researcher said that the "properties are the best reported so far for transparent transistors using AZO contacts".

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Oldest oceanic crust dating back 340mn-yrs found
article: An Israeli geologist has identified that the eastern Mediterranean Sea contains the world's oldest oceanic crust which could be almost 340 million years old. The findings were obtained by studying the nature and age of the 7,000 km of marine-magnetic-profiles. Most oceanic crusts are less than 200 million years old as they are typically recycled back into earth's mantle rapidly.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Cancer top cause for death in Euro countries'
article: Cancer has overtaken heart disease as the main cause of death in 12 European countries including France and Britain, revealed a recent study. According to Oxford scientists, improvement in prevention and treatment of heart attacks has reduced cardiovascular deaths. Meanwhile, cancer rates are increasing due to a mismatch between the demand and availability of expensive drugs.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Endangered foxes break record for fast recovery
article: Three subspecies of miniature foxes have made a world record for the fastest recovery of a mammal from the brink of extinction in the 43-year history of the Endangered Species Act. In 2004, the three species native to California’s Channel Islands were reportedly given a 50% chance of going extinct in the next decade.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 1991 volcanic eruption masked sea level rise
article: The extent of the rising sea levels due to global warming was masked by the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo, according to the National Center for Atmospheric Research. The eruption, which was the second largest this century, temporarily cooled the Earth by around half a degree Celsius, triggering sea levels to drop, thereby hiding the extent of greenhouse gases' effects.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Rare tarantulas bred in captivity for 1st time
article: A female Montserrat tarantula has given birth to 200 baby spiders in UK's Chester Zoo, making it the first time the species has been bred in captivity, zoo officials said. After bringing some spiders in 2013, the zoo said it waited for months while the arthropods hid in underground burrows, from where, eventually, 200 baby spiders crawled out without warning.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Astronomers discover closest Earth-like planet'
article: As per a German magazine, astronomers have discovered an Earth-like planet orbiting in the habitable zone of our sun's nearest star Proxima Centauri, allowing it to have liquid water on its surface. Interestingly, a program, founded by Russian billionaire Yuri Milner, Stephen Hawking and Mark Zuckerberg, intends to send nanocrafts to the Alpha Centauri system, which includes the Proxima Centauri.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Exercise counters inactivity's harmful effects'
article: According to American Heart Association, 30 minutes of daily exercise helps individuals counteract the harmful effects, including diabetes risk, heart disease, and early death, caused by being inactive for too long. Several health surveys in the US suggest adults stay inactive for 6-8 hours daily on an average, and each hour of inactivity increases fatal heart disease risk by 6%.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists levitate 5-cm sphere using ultrasound
article: UK-based scientists have demonstrated the acoustic levitation of a 5-cm solid polystyrene sphere using ultrasonic waves. The demonstration using 14-mm acoustic wavelength is one of the first times that an object larger than acoustic wavelength has been levitated. The current setup which uses three ultrasonic transducers has applications for handling very hot materials and liquid samples in space.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Brain part that understands physics found
article: Scientists have conducted a series of experiments to prove that humans have an innate sense of how the physical world works, the brain’s "physics engine" being the source of the intuition. The engine comes alive when people watch physical events and the brain performs constant, real-time physics calculations, helping people to plan their actions accordingly.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Cable connects optical clocks in France, Germany
article: A 1400-km long optical fibre cable has been built connecting the two most precise optical atomic clocks in Europe, located in Germany and France. This marks the first and most accurate comparison of atomic clocks across national borders, a feat that may allow time-sensitive scientific experiments like observing changes in the values of fundamental physical constants over time.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scotland's wind energy covers day's power needs
article: All of Scotland's electricity needs for an entire day were fulfilled solely by its wind turbines last Sunday, according to environmentalists. The high renewable energy output was attributed to the high wind speeds, producing 106% of the country's power requirements for the day. However, the winds reached a high-speed of 115 mph and disrupted transportation in the country.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: SpaceX successfully completes 4th sea-landing
article: Elon Musk-led space exploration startup SpaceX on Sunday successfully recovered its Falcon 9 rocket for the fourth time on a drone ship at sea. The rocket also completed its primary mission of deploying Japanese communications satellite, JCSAT-16, into orbit. The launch marks the eighth SpaceX mission this year, with a proposed goal of 18 missions by the end of 2016.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Venus may have been habitable once: NASA
article: Venus may have had a shallow liquid-water ocean and habitable surface temperatures for up to 2 billion years of its early history, according to NASA's climate models. Currently, Venus has a carbon dioxide atmosphere 90 times as thick as the Earth's and surface temperatures of around 462 °C. Notably, NASA's findings were obtained using a similar model used for Earth.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Britain's last hunter-gatherers discovered
article: Archaeologists have identified 'rare' human bones in Scotland's Oronsay dating around 4000 BC, just before the arrival of farming in Britain, using bone fragment analysis. Researchers believe that the evidence would help in understanding the transition from hunter-gatherer-fishers to agricultural food production. Notably, there is a near absence of human remains in Britain from this period.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Fifth force of nature possibly discovered
article: Physicists have claimed discovery of a new subatomic particle, suggesting the existence of a fifth fundamental force of nature. The particle is estimated to be 30 times heavier than the electron and only interacts with neutrons and electrons at a limited range. The four fundamental forces acknowledged by modern physics include gravitation, electromagnetism, and the strong and weak nuclear forces.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Earth's resources used up at fastest rate in '16
article: Humans have used up a year's worth of natural resources in over seven months, making it the quickest consumption rate ever, according to a new report. The "Earth overshoot day", falling on August 8 this year, fell on August 13 last year. About three-quarters of Earth's annual resources were used in 1961, and by 1970s, the overshooting began, it added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: US to build tool to 3D map the universe
article: The US Department of Energy will build the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument in 2017 to 3D map the nearby universe up to a radius of 10 billion light-years. The device will use 5,000 10-inch cylindrical robots to capture and measure how fast stars and galaxies are moving away from Earth. It will probe dark energy's effects on the universe's expansion.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Magic spells found alongside 2k-yr-old skeletons
article: Archaeologists recently unearthed magic spells engraved onto gold and silver amulets alongside almost 2,000-year-old Roman-era graves in Serbia. The team believes that the inscriptions are magic spells taken to the graves to invoke demons and deities to perform good or evil. Claiming that the language used was Aramaic, researchers said the etchings may never be fully understood.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 50 satellites to explore Earth's thermosphere
article: A fleet of 50 satellites, called cubesats, will be launched from the International Space Station to explore Earth's thermosphere, a layer that blocks sun's harmful UV radiations. Weighing an average of two kilograms each, the cubesats will focus on the 200-380 km region above the Earth, a region said to be "poorly understood" and vital for communications and weather formation.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Dogs' fertility declined in past 26 years: Study
article: A 26-year study of canine sperm by Nottingham University researchers showed an overall decline in sperm quality, which the researchers believe could be related to environmental causes. The team observed a drop of 2.4% per year from 1988 to 1998 in the ability of dog's sperm to swim in a straight line, along with the presence of environmental chemicals.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Startup to launch Virtual Reality camera satellite
article: US-based startup SpaceVR has announced its plans to launch what is claimed to be the world's first virtual reality camera satellite into space in 2017. The satellite, Overview 1, will orbit the Earth and capture high resolution, fully immersive, 360-degree videos through its 4K sensors. The content will be viewable on any virtual reality device, including smartphones.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Smart uniform to protect soldiers from chemicals
article: Scientists have created a highly breathable material that may be made into smart 'second skin' uniforms to protect soldiers from biological agents and chemical hazards in the field. The team integrated the polymer with carbon nanotubes to act as moisture conductive pores. The size of these pores is 5,000 times smaller than the width of a human hair.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: DNA study traces origin of horses' smooth ride
article: Researchers have published a DNA study stating that the gene responsible for smooth gait in 'ambling' horses first appeared in Medieval England around 850 AD. Ambling horses are known for their ability to move with a smooth, four-beat rhythm that is most comfortable for riders. The study suggests that the horses were taken from England to Iceland, and then worldwide.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Side swim style saves sharks' energy: Study
article: A recent study states that hammerhead sharks swim on their sides up to 90% of the time to save energy up to​ 10%. The study has found that these sharks swim mostly at an angle between 50 and 70 degrees due to their exaggerated dorsal fins which generate lift and help to reduce drag.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: DRDO uses bacteria from Antarctica in bio-toilets
article: Bacteria from Antarctica are being used in bio-toilets developed by Defence Research Development Organisation (DRDO), Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar said on Tuesday. He added that the bacteria are used to seed bio-digesters. They are used to convert cheaply available cow dung into an odourless final product that does not attract flies, which is fed into bio-digesters, he said.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: No course correction may cripple Mangalyaan: ISRO
article: A timely course correction needs to be initiated otherwise a long duration eclipse in January 2017 could cripple the Mangalyaan mission, ISRO Chairman AS Kiran Kumar said on Wednesday. Although the mission was meant to last six months, it is about to complete two years, and there is enough fuel for the payloads to last many more years, he added.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: 400-year-old shark is longest living vertebrate
article: With an estimated age of nearly 400 years, a female Greenland shark is the longest-living vertebrate on the Earth. The shark is known to reach sexual maturity at around 150 years, and grows to a length of around five metres. Notably, the record for the longest-living human being is 122 years.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Venus might have been habitable 3 bn years ago
article: According to a study based on recent climate models, Venus could have had moderate temperatures and harbored life about three billion years ago, if its rotation period was slower than about 16 Earth days. Despite an incident solar flux 46-70% higher than the Earth, Venus's climate could have remained habitable until at least 715 million years ago, the study added.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Brain's real-time gene activity viewed 1st time
article: Scientists from Harvard Medical School have developed an imaging technique that shows the gene activity in a living human brain. Injecting and tracking a radiotracer compound into a human brain, the researchers were able to see how the enzymes, that affect the DNA structure, worked in the brain. The advancement could help develop treatments for neurological disorders like Alzheimer's.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: NASA publishes over 1,000 photos of Mars
article: US space agency NASA has released over 1,000 photos of Mars in its monthly batch of Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter photos. Taken through a camera called HiRISE (High-Resolution Imaging Science Experiment), the photos show the red planet's craters, impact sites, dunes, mountains, ice caps and other features. NASA will reportedly use the photos to determine optimal landing sites for future missions.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: NASA to broadcast meteor shower live on Friday
article: NASA has announced that it will broadcast the annual Perseid meteor shower on its stream starting from 7:30 AM IST on Friday. Forecasters predict that the shower will have twice the usual number of shooting stars this year. The meteors will be travelling at 59 kmps, which NASA claims is 500 times faster than the fastest car in the world.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists develop method to immobilize bubbles
article: French researchers have demonstrated the ability to immobilize a microbubble created from water electrolysis by rapidly increasing the electric current frequency. Hydrogen and oxygen molecules continually entered and left the bubble keeping its surface from moving, researchers said. This advancement can be used in medical industry for breaking blood clots and blocking artery to prevent blood loss.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Tsar' is the largest nuclear bomb ever tested
article: The 'Tsar Bomba' was tested on October 30, 1961 and is the most powerful nuclear bomb ever detonated. Developed by the Soviet Union as RDS-220, the 50-megaton hydrogen bomb was detonated in an island of the Arctic Sea. Visible from 600 miles away and capable of destroying everything within a 15-mile radius, it could deliver third-degree burns within a 64-mile radius.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Manmade minerals found to be available naturally
article: Scientists have discovered a class of porous solids known as metal-organic frameworks (MOF) in the form of rare minerals in only Siberian coal mines so far. These minerals were artificially made and introduced in the 1990s and were not known to exist naturally till now. These are "molecular sponges", capable of capturing gases like carbon dioxide or hydrogen, researchers​ said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Ocean sediment may contain supernova remains
article: A European research team has found sediments from the Pacific ocean floor which might be the remnants of a supermassive star's explosion. The sediments on analysis have revealed the presence of iron-60, an isotope of iron that is extremely rare on earth. Iron-60 is launched millions of kilometres across space when a supernova occurs.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Coma patient wakes post brain stimulator implant
article: A 35-year-old man from Poland who had been in a coma since May due to an accident has become conscious and lucid after doctors implanted a brain stimulator in him. The team of doctors at the University Hospital in Olsztyn performed the first procedure of this kind in Poland on numerous patients, some of whom have shown improvement.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA finds flooded canyons on Saturn's moon
article: NASA's Cassini spacecraft has found deep canyons on Saturn's moon Titan that are flooded with liquid hydrocarbons. This is the first direct evidence of the presence of liquid-filled channels on Titan, as well as the first observation of canyons hundreds of metres deep. The finding suggests a similar geological evolution of Titan to that of Earth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA captures 'plasma rain' on Sun's surface
article: NASA's Interface Region Imaging Spectrograph recently captured a mid-level solar flare or 'plasma rain' on the solar surface. Solar flares are powerful explosions of radiation, during which, a large amount of magnetic energy is released, heating the sun’s atmosphere and releasing energized particles. Such flares help study how solar material and energy move throughout the sun’s lower atmosphere.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Neanderthals's death caused by lack of clothing
article: A recent study has found evidence suggesting Neanderthals might have died because of their inability to warm themselves using animal fur. The reason for this, according to the researchers, was either lack of sufficient intelligence or because of cultural traditions. On the contrary, researchers have found evidence suggestive of clothing at some early human sites, including bone needles for sewing.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team observes new soot-free fire 'blue whirl'
article: US-based researchers have discovered a new type of fire, "blue whirl", that evolves from a fire whirl and burns with nearly soot-free combustion. Soot includes fine black particles, composed of carbon produced by incomplete fuel combustion. "Blue in the whirl indicates there is enough oxygen for complete combustion, which means less or no soot, and... cleaner burn", a researcher said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: New method to create superstrong magnetic fields
article: A team of international researchers claimed to have devised a method to generate extremely strong magnetic fields in the lab. The method, 'Inverse Faraday Effect driven by radiation friction', produces magnetic fields of the order of several giga-Gauss, nearly ten times stronger than fields produced using contemporary methods. Fields of such magnitudes are known to exist only in the space.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Objects found to circle sun in reversed orbit
article: Astronomers recently found a group of objects in the outer solar system orbiting the Sun in a direction opposite to that of known planets. These objects' orbits have also been found to be nearly perpendicular to that of other planets. "It suggests that there's more going on in the outer solar system than we're fully aware of", a researcher said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: MIT creates chip to simulate nerve-muscle connection
article: MIT engineers have developed a chip to simulate nerve-muscle connections, in an attempt to better understand neuromuscular conditions like ALS. Created using mice cells, the coin-sized chip houses a muscle strip and some motor neurons. The setup is designed to recreate the neuromuscular junction, the bit of chemical synapse where neurons and muscle fibres meet.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: China launches its first mobile telecom satellite
article: China recently launched its first ever mobile telecommunications satellite, the 'Tiantong-01' from Beijing. The satellite will establish a mobile network serving China, the Middle East, Africa and other areas. The ground service will be operated by China Telecom, which is owned by the Chinese government. The country is also preparing for the next round of its manned space mission.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: Friction with tides slowing Earth's rotation
article: The Earth's rotation is slowing down marginally due to the friction between the Earth and the rising and falling tides in the oceans, caused due to the moon's gravity. Atomic clocks are used to measure the slowing of the Earth and it is estimated that in hundred year's time, a day will be about 2 milliseconds longer than today.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Brains of mid-age obese people '10 years older'
article: A research led by Cambridge University shows that brains of middle-aged overweight people may be 'ten years older' than lean people of the same age. The researchers found that overweight individuals between the ages of 20 and 87 have the same amount of white matter, the tissue that allows the brain to communicate, as lean individuals ten years their senior.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: Neil Armstrong got pilot license before driver license
article: Astronaut Neil Armstrong got his pilot's license at the age of 16, even before he got a driver's license. He had started taking flying lessons when he was 15, and became a NASA astronaut at the age of 32. Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, was born on August 5, 1930, in Ohio, US.

author: Yash Kumar
abstract: Researchers find evidence of great Chinese flood
article: A team of scientists has found sedimentary formations and children's skeletons along the Yellow river in China, indicative of the legendary "great flood" submerging China 4000 years ago. The sedimentary formations revealed an earthquake which may have caused powerful floods 2,000 km downstream. The carbon dating of crushed skeletons put the children's death at 1920 BC, marking the flood's date.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: 99.9% accurate quantum logic gate achieved
article: University of Oxford researchers have achieved a quantum logic gate with record-breaking 99.9% precision, reaching the benchmark required theoretically to build a quantum computer. The logic gate, which is the fundamental unit of a quantum computer, places two atoms in a state of 'quantum entanglement', which means that measuring the property of one atom gives information about the other.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Self-healing diamond-like carbon discovered
article: Scientists at the US Department of Energy's Argonne National Laboratory have developed a self-lubricating diamond-like carbon film that is generated by the heat and pressure of an automotive engine. The discovery of this ultra-durable tribofilm - a film that forms between moving surfaces - could substantially increase the efficiency and durability of future engines and other moving metal parts.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Artificial Intelligence used to diagnose leukaemia
article: University of Tokyo has used artificial intelligence (AI) to diagnose a rare type of leukaemia that had gone undetected using conventional methods. Named Watson, the AI was used by the medical team after unsuccessfully treating the patient for an initial diagnosis. Watson compared the patient’s genetic information with 20 million clinical oncology studies to detect the cancer.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Volcanic activity on Mercury ended 3 bn yrs ago
article: Using photographs of Mercury's surface, US-based researchers have found that volcanic activities on the planet ended about 3.5 billion years ago. The findings will help scientists understand the geological evolution of Mercury and what happens when rocky planets cool down. Effusive volcanism was active on Mars a few million years ago, and still takes place on Earth today.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video describes Earth a billion years from now
article: According to a six-minute video, after a billion years, the Earth would see a "mass extinction" and a spike in the number of species that had suddenly disappeared from the fossil record. Explorers would find that the metals and the rare-earth metals have spread worldwide. Notably, ice cores on Earth would show sudden increase in methane and carbon dioxide.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Neurons responsible for thirst identified
article: A new study by American researchers has found neurons in the subfornical organ in a mouse brain to be responsible for thirst and thirst-quenching. The study revealed that drinking liquid relieves thirst way before the fluid reaches the bloodstream, contrary to current views of thirst regulation, making it likely that some other mechanism is responsible for the activity.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Eco-friendly fashion created using cow dung
article: Dutch artist Jalila Essaïdi weaves fashionable outfits from fabric manufactured from cow dung. Inspired by the availability of excess cow manure in the Netherlands, Essaïdi devised a technique to break down dung with chemical reactions to synthesise bio-paper and plastics, which upon refinement produces a thread-like material. She uses this material to weave the fabric into garments.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: Neil Armstrong once mowed graveyard grass for $1
article: Neil Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, once had a job of trimming grass in a cemetery for $1, at the age of 10. Wapakoneta, the town housing the cemetery, now has a museum named after him. Armstrong, born on August 5, 1930, held several odd jobs in his childhood to pay for his $9-per-hour flying lessons.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: NASA launches projects for eco-friendly aircraft
article: NASA has announced five research projects that may help make planes more efficient and green. The projects are aimed at shrinking fuel use, reducing aviation’s impact on the environment and quieting noise around airports. One of these studies will be based on Lithium-Air "breathing batteries” which expel oxygen as the battery is being charged.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Melting ice could release Cold War era's waste
article: According to York University researchers, melting of the Greenland ice sheet could release radioactive waste into the environment. A US military base built within the Greenland ice sheet in 1959 was used as a nuclear missile testing site. The camp was decommissioned in 1967, abandoning its infrastructure and waste under the assumption that the waste would be trapped there forever.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: X-rays reveal hidden portrait in Degas painting
article: Researchers used a new X-ray technique and found a hidden portrait under an 1876 painting titled 'Portrait of a Woman' by French artist Edgar Degas. Using the technique, the researchers reconstructed concealed paint layers down to single paintbrush bristles, also revealing various stages of the painting. The found portrait of a woman is believed to be a frequent Degas model.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA marks Curiosity's 4th yr on Mars with game
article: NASA has released a game, called 'Mars Rover', to mark the fourth anniversary of its Curiosity rover on Mars. Featuring a standard virtual pad for controls, the game has its mechanics derived from Curiosity's actual experiences on the Martian surface. Curiosity rover landed on Mars on August 6, 2012, with goals including investigating Martian climate and geology, and planetary habitability.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Indian scientists develop nutritional ice cream
article: Indian scientists at CSIR and CFTRI have developed a nutritional ice cream called 'Nutrice', which is an Omega-3 and Vitamin-E enriched frozen nutritional dessert from vegetarian sources. One serving of the ice cream delivers the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) of Omega-3 for children, which is said to aid brain development in children and good health in elderly population.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: IBM builds working artificial neurons
article: IBM has built 500 working artificial neurons to simulate a signal transfer similar to that of an organic brain. Neurons' membranes act as signal gates, which in IBM's version, was mimicked by GST, a common ingredient in optical disks. The advancement may help create computers mimicking the parallel processing design of organic brains for decision-making and processing sensory information.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Dust-sized wireless sensor to monitor nerves created
article: Engineers at the University of California, Berkeley have developed sensors the size of sand grains that use ultrasound to transmit data. The 'neural dust' could be used to monitor internal nerves, muscles or organs in real time and also control prosthetics. The team believes the sensors could help check the effectiveness of cancer therapies in the long run.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: First programmable quantum computer created
article: Researchers at the University of Maryland have built the first fully programmable and reconfigurable quantum computer module. Called a module because of its ability to connect with copies of itself, the device takes advantage of the unique properties offered by trapped ions to run any algorithm on five quantum bits, or qubits—the fundamental unit of information in a quantum computer.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Veins on Mars formed by evaporated lakes: Study
article: A University of Leicester study has shown that mineral veins found in Mars' Gale Crater were formed by evaporation of ancient lakes, providing evidence for the varied history of water on Mars. The researchers used the Mars Curiosity rover to explore Yellowknife Bay in Gale Crater. The evaporated water is estimated to have had high sodium, potassium and silicon content.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: South India's 1st Doppler weather radar launched
article: Southern India's first Doppler weather radar, which can provide advance information about storms, cyclones, and other severe weather conditions, was on Thursday inaugurated at the Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre in Kerala's Thiruvananthapuram. This is India's second C-Band Polarimetric Doppler Weather Radar (C-DWR) as the first was unveiled by PM Narendra Modi in Cherrapunji, Meghalaya, in May 2015.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA twin study probes spaceflight health effects
article: NASA has published a study on astronaut Scott Kelly and his identical twin brother and retired astronaut Mark, to identify spaceflight's effects on human health. It compared nearly identical genomes of Scott, who stayed in space for one year, and Mark. The study was based on omics, a hybrid discipline to study an individual's health at a fundamental, molecular level.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Study identifies 20 most habitable planets
article: A recent study by US-based researchers has identified 20 most habitable planets from over 4,000 exoplanets discovered by NASA's Kepler spacecraft. The study first selected 216 planets present in the "habitable zone" around a star wherein water could remain in liquid form. It then shortlisted 20 planets that are small and rocky like the Earth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Genetically modified mosquitoes okayed for Zika
article: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of genetically modified mosquitoes, a technique proposed by British biotechnology company Oxitec, to combat the Zika virus. The firm plans to trim the population of infected mosquitos by releasing genetically modified 'Aedes aegypti' male mosquitos, that would pass off genes fatal to any offspring produced along with wild female insects.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Yeast-based device produces vaccines on demand
article: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have designed a system to produce  vaccines and other treatments from a portable device containing a small droplet of cells in a liquid. Explaining the utility of the system, a researcher said, "Imagine you were on Mars or in a remote desert... you could program the yeast to produce drugs on demand locally".

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Elephants could be extinct by 2100: Study
article: According to a report published in the BioScience journal, elephants could be extinct by the year 2100. The study listed endangered species across six continents, which includes around 59% of the world's largest carnivores and 60% of the world's largest herbivores, including leopards, gorillas and lions. The situation is worst in sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Lowest temp ever recorded in solids using lasers
article: Researchers at the University of New Mexico have used lasers and a technique called optical refrigeration to achieve the lowest ever temperature in a solid at 91 kelvin or -182.15ºC. Previously, such low temperatures have only been reached using liquid nitrogen or helium. This can aid in several areas like cooling infrared focal plane arrays used for detecting skin cancer.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Study finds major difference between DNA and RNA
article: Duke University researchers have revealed a major difference between DNA and RNA, explaining why DNA is better-suited as the blueprint of life. The study revealed DNA double helix can take different shapes to absorb damages to the genetic code's basic building blocks. While, RNA, in a double helix form, is so rigid that it falls apart completely after experiencing damage.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: 1st private company gets US nod for moon mission
article: Space-exploration startup Moon Express on Wednesday became the first ever private company to receive permission by the US government to travel to the moon. The company plans to fly a suitcase-sized lander to the moon for a two-week mission in 2017. The spacecraft will carry some science experiments on its one-way trip.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Lack of water caused mammoths' extinction: Study
article: A study by American researchers has revealed the extinction of mammoths' remnant population on a remote Alaska island was likely caused by rising sea levels and lack of fresh water. The study added that with increasing temperatures following the ice age, the sea levels rose, trapping mammoths on the island and eventually leading to their extinction around 5,000 years back.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video describes dinosaur-killing asteroid
article: A four-minute video describes the asteroid that struck the Earth, killing dinosaurs. Only 1% of the force travelled into the ground, wiping out the species across the globe. Resulting in an earthquake of 11 magnitude, a rain of fire, and temperatures reaching up to 150 °C, only those creatures who were able to seek shelter from the intense heat survived.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Jack White's label 1st to play record in space
article: Detroit-based 'Third Man Records', an independent record label founded by American musician Jack White in 2001, played the first ever vinyl record in space. The label launched Icarus Craft, a custom "space-proof" turntable attached to a high-altitude balloon, to a peak altitude of 94,413 feet in 1:21:20 hours, where it played Carl Sagan’s "A Glorious Dawn".

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: 'Door To Hell' has been burning for 40 years
article: A two-minute video shows 'Door To Hell', a giant hole of fire in Turkmenistan which has been burning for over 40 years. Soviet geologists were drilling at the site during 1970s and it tapped into a cavern filled with natural gas. They set it on fire to prevent the spread of methane and it has been burning since then.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Huge area near Milky Way's center is void: Study
article: Astronomers have found a huge region around the Milky Way galaxy's center, which is devoid of young stars. Some such stars are present in a region about 150 light years from the galaxy's centre. The region extending from 150 light-years out to 8,000 light-years has not seen any significant star formation over hundreds of millions of years, researchers said.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Exploded star's past life revealed by astronomers
article: Astronomers have managed to uncover the past of a nearby star millions of years before its explosion, using a low-frequency radio telescope in remote Australia. The research probes the star's lifetime back into its red supergiant phase before it became a blue supergiant, finally exploding in what was the closest and brightest supernova seen from Earth in 1987.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains the phenomenon of déjà vu
article: A six-minute video explains the phenomenon of déjà vu which refers to the strong sensation that an event currently being experienced has already happened in the past. According to the video, experiencing déjà vu might have something to do with brain development. Furthermore, it is caused by a disconnect between parts of the brain that process experiences consciously and unconsciously.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New 'temporary tattoo' can detect alcohol levels
article: Researchers from the University of California, San Diego, have developed a disposable tattoo-based device that can accurately measure alcohol levels in sweat and relay the results wirelessly to a phone or smartwatch. When activated, the tattoo releases a drug that passes through the skin and induces sweat. The alcohol-sensitive sensor then measures the alcohol concentration in the sweat.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Video shows footage of first 'car ride' on Moon
article: A YouTube video by NASA shows footage shot during the first 'car ride' on the moon, which happened 45 years ago on July 31, 1971. Astronauts David Scott and James Irwin drove the first Lunar Roving Vehicle (LRV) on the moon during the Apollo 15 mission. The LRV was driven a total of 27.8 kilometres, in about three hours.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: 3,000-yr-old 'living fossil' tree found in China
article: Chinese authorities on Sunday said they had found a rare Chinese yew tree, believed to be about 3,000 years old. The species, harvested to extract a cancer-treating compound called 'taxol', is now under national protection for endangered plants. The Chinese yew is called a "living fossil" of the plant world, as the species has existed 2.5 million years.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Humans found to be using cannabis for 10,000 yrs
article: Researchers at the German Archaeological Institute have discovered that the early humans began using cannabis almost 10,000 years ago. It is believed that tribes in Asia and Europe picked up the plant as the glaciers in Europe started to retreat. The team claimed the plant was used for its nutritional seeds and hemp fibres that could be made into clothes.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Jupiter moon loses its atmosphere during eclipse
article: American researchers have discovered the atmosphere of Io, Jupiter's volcanically active moon, collapses during an eclipse, which occurs for two hours every 1.7 Earth days. The atmosphere consists of sulfur dioxide which freezes during an eclipse due to low temperatures (up to -167ºC). Upon moving out of eclipse, its atmosphere reforms as the ice heats up and converts to gas.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: ESA to beam people's messages to Pole Star
article: The European Space Agency (ESA) is collecting messages from people around the globe to send to Polaris, known as the Pole Star, around 434 light-years away. The deadline for submissions is September 16. The activity's purpose is to have people contribute "to ongoing dialogue concerning how our civilization collectively perceives its role within shaping the future of the environment".

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video: What if the Earth stopped spinning
article: A nine-minute video explains what would happen if the Earth stopped spinning. According to the video by YouTube channel 'Vsauce', humans and all other things would be flung east at more than 1,500 km per hour and gust of winds would blast past the surface causing worldwide storms. Ultimately, the entire planet would become a widespread graveyard.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA to probe asteroid that might hit Earth
article: NASA is planning to probe the asteroid Bennu which might hit the Earth’s surface between 2175 and 2196. Discovered in 1999, the 500-metre, 60-million-ton asteroid, which moves at a speed of over one lakh kilometre-per-hour around the sun, can cause an impact equivalent to three billion tonnes of explosives. Researchers have estimated the chance of impact at about one in 2,700.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: IBM develops virus filter for disease diagnosis
article: IBM researchers have developed a virus filtering tool, nano deterministic lateral displacement (nano DLD), that would enable patients to monitor their health by analyzing saliva or urine samples at home. The new method detects and separates health threats in the 20 to 110-nanometer scale from DNA that could be associated with potential cancers, prior to the appearance of cancer's symptoms.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video: Do transplanted organs carry memories
