article: A two-minute video explores the possibility if transplanted organs carry memories of the donor. According to the video, organ recipients have reported "disturbing experiences" after transplants. Interestingly, a French woman was haunted by images from her donor's death, while in Georgia, a recipient who had the heart of a suicide victim killed himself in exactly the same way.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Video shows how silkworms make silk
article: According to a two-minute video, silk is produced by the larvae of silkworms which feast on mulberry leaves for about 42 days. They spin their silk cocoons for 3-8 days which are then loosened in hot water, unwound and spun into a thread. The video claims that it takes about 2,500 silkworms to make about half a kilogram of silk.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Bar installs Faraday cage to block phone signals
article: Steve Tyler, owner of British cocktail bar 'Gin Tub', has installed a 'Faraday cage' in his bar's walls to block mobile phone signals, hoping that customers will be encouraged to talk to each other. A Faraday cage is an enclosure made of a conductive material and used to block electric fields, an effect discovered by scientist Michael Faraday in 1836.

author: Sanira Mediratta
abstract: Video explains why people dream
article: A six-minute video provides theories to explain why people have dreams. According to one theory, while we sleep, the unconscious part of our brain organises memories which are detected by the conscious brain, thus creating dreams. Another theory suggests that brain stimulates anxieties while we sleep, in the form of dreams, to prepare us for real-life scenarios.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Support for 1st successful comet lander ended
article: The European Space Agency has ended the support system for the Philae lander module, which was launched alongside 'Rosetta' orbiter and performed the first successful comet landing. It landed oddly on the 67P comet in 2014 and was unable to maintain consistent communication with Rosetta. This was done to conserve Rosetta's energy till the end of the mission in September.

author: Twishy Shahi
abstract: NASA has employee to smell objects to be sent to space
article: NASA has employed George Aldrich for nearly 40 years as its 'Chief Sniffer' to smell every object before they can be flown into a space shuttle. Aldrich’s team tests nearly all items that astronauts would encounter during their flight including fabric, toothpaste, circuit boards, and the ink on their checklists. Interestingly, Aldrich can detect more than 10,000 smells.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Oldest known case of human cancer found
article: South African scientists claim to have found the oldest known case of human cancer in a 1.7-million-year-old toe bone, National Geographic reports. Scans of the fossil revealed a tumor on the left foot belonging to a human relative, diagnosed as the osteosarcoma cancer. Another fossil in a separate paper, from a 1.98-million-year-old Australopithecus sediba, revealed the oldest known benign tumor.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Most detailed brain map reveals 97 new regions
article: Washington University researchers, along with the Human Connectome Project, have identified 97 new areas of the human brain in what is being called the most detailed brain mapping till date. They also confirmed the existence of 83 previously reported areas. For this, the team scanned 1,200 test subjects who were given simple tasks to see which brain regions lit up.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Scientists discover clue to galaxy's formation
article: Astronomers have discovered that the 'halo' surrounding the Milky Way is spinning at almost the same rate as the rest of the galaxy, giving "an incredible clue to how the Milky Way formed”, according to a researcher. This information, which was recorded by measuring changes in the halo's light wavelengths, sheds light on how atoms assembled to form stars.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Genomics startup raises $10 mn to test fertility
article: Computational genomics startup Phosphorus has raised $10 million in a Series A funding round led by FirstMark Capital. The startup tests couples for signs of infertility, lets them take preventive measures against potential infertility and informs them when it's safe to start trying to conceive. Its FertilityMap processes genetic data which is useful for both physicians and users.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Early animals caused 1st mass extinction: Study
article: According to a new study by American researchers, the first mass extinction, the end-Ediacaran extinction that took place about 540 million years ago, might have been caused by the first animals. Supported by recent fossil findings in Namibia, the theory revealed that the new species changed the environment making it more difficult for the then-alive species including Ediacarans to survive.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New solar cell turns CO2 into burnable fuel
article: US-based researchers have engineered a new solar cell that can convert atmospheric carbon dioxide directly into usable hydrocarbon fuel using only sunlight. The team used a new catalyst, named tungsten diselenide, which they claim is 1,000 times faster than noble-metal catalysts and about 20 times cheaper. It is more active and able in breaking carbon dioxide’s bonds, a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Cloned sheep still healthy after eight years
article: The four genomic "siblings" of Dolly the sheep, the first mammal to be cloned, are still healthy after eight years with no signs of rapid ageing, a study revealed. Some had early signs of osteoarthritis, which is normal for their age, scientists claimed. Dolly, born in 1996, had died aged 6.5 years, raising concerns over the safety of cloning animals.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Juno to reach farthest point in Jupiter orbit
article: NASA's Juno spacecraft will reach the farthest point in its Jupiter orbit, around 8.1 million kilometers away, for the first time on August 1 at 1:11 AM IST. The spacecraft, which took off in 2011 and entered Jupiter's orbit on July 4, is currently executing the first of two 53.5-day orbits before beginning its science mission, consisting of 14-day orbits.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Jupiter's 'Great Red Spot' heats up atmosphere
article: A recent study has revealed that Jupiter's 'Great Red Spot', a storm three times wider than the Earth, is heating up the atmosphere above it by hundreds of degrees (up to 1,500ºC). It consists of a hurricane-like system of gases swirling at speeds of up to 684 kmph, with the winds taking up to six days to complete one revolution.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: NASA once held beauty contest 'Miss Guided Missile'
article: NASA, which was founded on 29 July, 1958, held a beauty contest in the 1950s for Jet Propulsion Laboratory's (JPL) female staff, where the winner was crowned with the title of "Miss Guided Missile". The title was changed to "Queen of Outer Space" in 1959 to reflect JPL's transition from missiles to spacecraft. However, the contest was discontinued in 1970.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: NASA texts people when ISS passes over their location
article: NASA's 'Spot the Station' service lets observers sign up to receive texts or emails when the International Space Station passes over their location. NASA, founded on July 29, 1958, says the ISS is visible to the naked eye since it's the "third brightest object in the sky and easy to spot if you know when to look up".

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New gene doping test may be used after Rio Games
article: Australian researchers have developed a gene doping test to detect if athletes have artificially adjusted their DNA to enhance performance. Once approved by WADA, the test will be used on Rio Olympics' samples after its conclusion, IOC's medical director said. "We will absolutely not experiment at the Olympic Games. We will use tests that are validated by WADA", he added.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: World's most-expensive man-made object costs $100bn
article: The International Space Station (ISS) is the world's most-expensive man-made object, with a total cost of over $100 billion. With a capacity to support a 6-member crew, its construction was completed in 2011. The spacecraft was created by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), 53 years after the space research agency's establishment on July 29, 1958.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: NASA orders second SpaceX crew mission to ISS
article: NASA has ordered a second mission from Elon Musk-led SpaceX to send astronauts to the International Space Station to ensure US continues to have human access to space. This is the fourth and final order under NASA's Commercial Crew Transportation program, with SpaceX and Boeing receiving two orders each. The flights are tentatively scheduled for late 2017 or early 2018.

author: Rini Kapoor
abstract: Scientists discover purple orb in California
article: Marine scientists have discovered an unidentified purple orb in Arguello Canyon in California. The crew believes that the five-centimetre organism is probably a variant of sea slug belonging to the 'pleurobranch group of gastropods' as it has foot and proboscis. Interestingly, the crew had to fight a crab to ensure that the crab did not get the orb before it.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists grow working mini midbrain tissue
article: Singapore-based scientists claim to have successfully grown functioning 2-3 mm tissue of the midbrain – responsible for controlling auditory, eye and body movement. The team found the tissue can create neuromelanin, a pigment found in the human midbrain. The advancement can offer testing opportunities for Parkinson's disease as a patient's brain in such cases shows depleted levels of neuromelanin.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: Ice Bucket Challenge results in ALS gene discovery
article: A research on ALS (Motor Neurone Disease), funded by the money raised through the viral social media trend 'Ice Bucket Challenge', has resulted in the discovery of a new gene, named NEK1, associated with the disease. Scientists found the gene by searching through genomes of over 15,000 people with ALS. The challenge raised over $100 million in 30 days.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Startup makes 'beef' burger from plant protein
article: Food startup Impossible Foods on Wednesday launched a vegetarian 'beef' burger, the 'Impossible Burger' which uses plant-based protein to give its burgers a meaty taste. The ingredients of the burger are water, wheat protein, coconut oil, and newly-discovered 'heme' proteins. Impossible Food claims the burger has protein and iron comparable to beef without the cholesterol and hormones.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Australia to shift its latitude and longitude
article: A team of scientists will recalculate and shift Australia's latitude and longitude coordinates, which are currently inaccurate by over 1.5 metres. The continent moves north by about 7 centimetres each year, causing a difference between actual coordinates and those currently used by Global Navigation Satellite Systems like GPS. The Australian coordinates were last updated in 1994.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Martian gullies likely not formed by water: NASA
article: New findings from NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter revealed that the Martian "gullies" were likely not formed by flowing water. It was believed that the formation of these "gullies" was similar to those on Earth. The findings showed no mineralogical evidence for abundant liquid water or its by-products, pointing to other mechanisms possibly the freezing and thawing of carbon dioxide frost.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: New species of beaked whale discovered
article: Genetic tests have confirmed the discovery of a new species of beaked whale in the northern Pacific Ocean. Japanese researchers had first sampled three black beaked whales from this yet-unnamed species in 2013. Sightings of the whale, which has a bulbous head and a porpoise-like beak, had been reported by Japanese fishermen, who call them 'karasu' or ravens.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New biosensor detects muscle fatigue from sweat
article: American scientists have developed a wearable, enzyme-based biosensor that can detect conditions like muscle fatigue, stress and dehydration by monitoring the user's sweat. At one point during heavy exercise, lactate production surpasses its consumption, leading to muscle fatigue and stress, a researcher said. The biosensor helps in monitoring lactate levels and thereby avoid such conditions.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Solar-powered urine-to-water machine built
article: A team of Belgian scientists has built a solar-powered machine that can turn urine into drinkable water. They were able to remove 95% of all ammonia in urine through membrane distillation. For this, the urine was first heated in a solar-powered boiler and then passed through the membrane to separate water from other nutrients which can be used in fertilizers.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Two new ant species named after dragons from GoT
article: Scientists have named two new ant species discovered in Papua New Guinea after the dragons that feature on the Game of Thrones (GoT) TV series. Named Pheidole drogon and Pheidole viserion, the species have spiny barbs along their backs and shoulders with unusual muscles. The team realised the jet-black colour and cream of the two ants matched the dragon scales.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: NASA paid people $18,000 to spend 70 days in bed
article: NASA reportedly paid $18,000 to subjects who spent 70 days on a bed tilted downward at a six-degree angle in 2013. Founded on July 29, 1958, NASA recruits volunteers to lie in bed to study effects of long-term space flights on astronauts. NASA also modified a shower device to ensure subjects don't stand to shower or use the bathroom.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Hong Kong project turns waste food into fabric
article: A Hong Kong government-sponsored institute has collaborated with the City University of Hong Kong on a project aimed at turning waste food into fabric. The process involves converting food waste containing sugar into polylactic acid, a type of bioplastic, which is then melted into thread-like filaments. The process can recycle 10 tons of food waste into a ton of fabric.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: One giant leap for mankind: First words on the moon
article: Neil Armstrong became the first person to step on the moon on July 21, 1969 and the first words he said after his descent was "That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind." Apollo 11 mission successfully landed astronauts Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins on the surface of the moon on July 20, 1969.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Da Vinci's 1st notes on laws of friction found
article: In a new study, American researchers have revealed that the notes in one of Leonardo da Vinci's books, which were deemed as 'irrelevant' by historians, were actually the first written demonstration of the laws of friction. The 1493 document traces Leonardo's 20-year-long study and shows square blocks being pulled by a string passing over a pulley with a suspended weight.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Astronauts to mimic Mars missions underwater
article: NASA has sent a group of astronauts on a 16-day mission at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean to simulate Martian atmosphere and test their equipment. They will use a simulated radio delay to replicate the communication difficulties one might experience on Martian missions. The team will also test a wearable prototype that offers hands-free instructions with audio and video.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Record pressure of 1 tn pascals created in lab
article: Researchers from the University of Bayreuth in Germany has successfully achieved a record pressure of 1 trillion pascals in laboratory. A pressure of this magnitude is roughly three times higher than the pressure found in Earth's core. Such extreme pressures and even temperatures help in several areas like explaining the properties and structures of materials and synthesis of new materials.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New remote-controlled microbots for medical use
article: Switzerland-based researchers have designed soft remote-controlled microrobots that could be used to deliver drugs at specific locations in the body or perform precise operations like clearing clogged-up arteries. The team built an integrated manipulation platform that can remotely control the robots' mobility with electromagnetic fields, and cause them to shape-shift by heat them with a laser.

author: Parichit Mainra
abstract: Greenland lost 1 trillion tons of ice in 4 years
article: A satellite study published in Geophysical Research Letters claims that the Greenland ice sheet lost 1 trillion tons​ of ice between the years 2011 and 2014  which led to a 2.5-millimetre rise in sea levels. Reportedly, last century, Greenland's ice sheet lost about 90 billion tonnes a year, but this has now increased to 269 billion tonnes a year.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Process can extend milk's shelf life to 9 weeks
article: Purdue University researchers have developed a new process that can reduce the amount of harmful bacteria present in milk and can increase its shelf life to up to nine weeks. The team demonstrated that increasing the temperature of milk by 10ºC for less than a second followed by cooling eliminates over 99% of the bacteria left behind after pasteurization.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: World’s first test-tube baby was born in 1978
article: The world’s first test-tube baby, Louise Brown, was born on July 25, 1978 after her parents became the first couple to successfully undergo in vitro fertilisation (IVF). Louise was born in Manchester, United Kingdom and turns 38 years old on Monday. Her autobiography, titled ‘My Life As The World’s First Test-Tube Baby’, was published in 2015.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA's Kepler finds more than 100 new planets
article: Astronomers have confirmed the discovery of 104 new planets outside the solar system, which were found using NASA's Kepler spacecraft. The planets, all 20%-50% larger than Earth, are orbiting the M dwarf star K2-72, located 181 light-years away. The discoveries were made by measuring a subtle dip in the star's brightness caused by a planet's passage in front of it.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 6,000-yr-old barley oldest plant to be sequenced
article: An international team of scientists has successfully sequenced the genes of 6,000-year-old barley seeds, making it the oldest plant genome to be reconstructed. Analysis of the remains retrieved from Yoram Cave in Israel revealed that ancient barley was very similar to present-day barley. To determine the age, the team split the grains and subjected half of them to radiocarbon dating.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Painless microneedle drug monitoring system made
article: Researchers in Canada and Switzerland have developed a painless microneedle drug monitoring system. They found the fluid found just below the skin's outer layer could be used to monitor vancomycin levels in the bloodstream. The needle, less than half-a-millimetre long, is designed to punch only the outer layer to collect less than a millionth of a millilitre of the fluid.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Most sensitive dark matter search unsuccessful
article: The Large Underground Xenon (LUX) sensor has failed to find anything in its 20-month long search for the dark matter, that makes up four-fifths of the universe's mass. LUX, which had established itself as the most sensitive detector during its first run in 2013, was operating at four times its original project goals, but yielded no trace of dark matter.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Lowest temperature recorded on Earth is -89.2°C
article: The record for the lowest temperature ever recorded on Earth, as recognised by UN's World Meteorological Organisation, was set on July 21, 1983 at -89.2°C. This temperature was recorded at Russia's Vostok research station in Antarctica. The extreme cold is said to have resulted from absence of solar radiation, calm air for a long duration and the station's high elevation.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: 1st astronauts on moon filled customs form on return
article: Astronauts aboard Apollo 11, which landed on the moon on July 20, 1969, filled out customs forms, a standard procedure for international travellers, on returning from their mission. Their place of departure was listed as “moon” and the astronauts declared "moon rocks" as cargo. Crew member Buzz Aldrin recently shared a photograph of the signed form in a Facebook post.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Genetic portrait of last universal ancestor made
article: Germany-based researchers have created a genetic portrait of the Last Universal Common Ancestor, LUCA, which was a single-cell, bacterium-like organism that lived around four billion years ago. LUCA fed on hydrogen gas and lived in a high-temperature environment devoid of oxygen, the research revealed. The team cited 355 genes that were found to have probably been originated in LUCA.

author: Abhishek Bansal
abstract: Century's longest solar eclipse lasted 6 mins
article: The longest solar eclipse of the 21st century occurred on July 22, 2009, lasting for 6 minutes and 39 seconds. The event began in the Gulf of Khambhat in Gujarat, and could be witnessed in several Indian and Chinese cities. Notably, the duration of the eclipse will not be surpassed until the eclipse of June 13, 2132.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 47 years since first human landing on the moon
article: On July 20, 1969, astronauts Neil Armstrong, Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin and Michael Collins aboard the Apollo 11 spacecraft became the first humans to land on the moon. The spacecraft lifted-off on July 16 and traveled 3,84,400 km to reach the lunar orbit. Armstrong stepped out of the spacecraft on July 21 to become the first man to walk on the moon.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 1st atmospheric study of Earth-like exoplanets
article: Astronomers used NASA's Hubble Space Telescope to conduct the first atmospheric study of Earth-like exoplanets and found that two such planets, 40 light-years away, could be habitable. The two exoplanets, which were discovered in May, are part of a three-planet system, all of which have sizes and temperatures similar to Venus and the Earth, and orbit a red dwarf star.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Sputnik 1 satellite model auctions for $269,000
article: A full-scale laboratory model of the first artificial satellite 'Sputnik 1', which was made by the Soviet Union, was recently auctioned for $269,000 at the Bonhams auction house in New York. The six-and-a-half feet tall, 45 kg model, whose estimated price was between $10,000 and $15,000, is still operational 59 years after the launch of Sputnik 1.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Records miss 1/5th of global warming: NASA
article: A NASA-led study found that 19% of the global warming in the last 150 years has been missed by historical records due to quirks in how global temperatures were recorded. The reasons include fewer historical temperature records of the Arctic because of inaccessibility and shifting record keeping from air to water temperatures in the Arctic sea due to ice melting.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Alloy four times stronger than titanium created
article: Researchers at the Rice University in the US have crafted a titanium-gold alloy which they claim is four times stronger and more wear-resistant than pure titanium, making it a potential replacement for body implants. The alloy was created by mixing three parts titanium with one part gold at high temperatures, allowing it to form an almost purely sturdy crystalline structure.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Sea slug muscle used to create 'biohybrid' robot
article: Researchers have combined muscles from a sea slug's mouth with flexible 3D printed body parts to build 'biohybrid' robots. The benefits of using slug muscles is that they are adaptable to saline environments and can perform lengthier tasks than traditional robots that use batteries. Swarms of such 'biohybrids' could potentially be released to search the ocean floor for black boxes.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: SpaceX plans to land 3 Falcon rockets together
article: After successfully landing its Falcon 9 rocket on Monday, aerospace manufacturer SpaceX is seeking permission for two additional sites in Florida to land three rockets together. The landing sites are needed to recover the rockets from SpaceX's new launch vehicle Falcon Heavy, within minutes from one another. The company said it may attempt drone ship landings instead of ground landings.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: NASA releases one-year time-lapse video of Earth
article: NASA has released a 3-minute time-lapse video spanning nearly one full year of Earth captured by its Earth Polychromatic Imaging Camera (EPIC) placed at a distance of approximately 1.6 million km from our planet. The video is made up of 3,000 different images taken by EPIC, and captures continents, water bodies, weather systems, and even a solar eclipse shadow.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Zika virus found in new type of mosquito
article: Brazilian researchers have found signs of the Zika virus in Culex mosquitoes found in Recife, Brazil. Until now, Zika was believed to be carried only by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. According to the study, Culex mosquitoes are "20 times greater than the population of Aedes aegypti" in Recife. However, it is still not known if Culex mosquitoes can transmit the virus.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: India to make resource mapping satellite with US
article: ISRO and NASA are jointly working to develop a satellite for mapping natural resources, Space Department MoS Jitendra Singh told the Parliament. The satellite, named NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar (NISAR), is expected to be completed and launched by 2021, he added. ISRO will be responsible for some of the satellite's design and development, and all in-orbit operations, he said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists propose bacteria-powered 'windfarm'
article: Oxford University scientists have shown that natural bacterial movement could be harnessed to power microscopic 'windfarms', which in turn may help in powering micro-machines such as smartphone components. Using computer simulations, the team demonstrated that the chaotic bacterial movement could be organised to turn cylindrical rotors in order to provide a steady power source.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Neurons that drive drinking habits identified
article: US-based scientists have identified 'medium spiny neurons' that influence drinking habits in a person. Each neuron has either D1 or D2 dopamine receptor. The study revealed that D1 neurons determine whether one drink leads to two or not, while D2 neurons inhibit drinking behavior. By manipulating neurons' activity, the team was able to change the alcohol-drinking behavior of animal models.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Turtle used shells for digging, not protection'
article: A study by US-based researchers revealed that the earliest instances of turtle shells were used for digging, not for protection. The study was based on the fossils discovered in South Africa that showed signs of broadening ribs in turtles, which restricted their movement and breathing. However, these changes offered them a stable base to operate a powerful forelimb digging mechanism.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New dwarf planet discovered beyond Neptune
article: Astronomers have discovered a new dwarf planet, named 2015 RR245, beyond Neptune which goes around the Sun in a 700-year wide orbit. The new object, which is roughly 700 kilometers in size, is around five billion kilometres to the sun at its closest approach (next in 2096) and over 120 times further from the Sun than Earth at its farthest.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Startup makes wine without grapes, fermentation
article: San Francisco-based startup Ava Winery claims that it can turn water into fine expensive wines without using grapes, yeast or any kind of fermentation. The company, currently focused on replicating three wine clones, analyses molecular profiles of the wines and then reconstructs them as a bioidentical match. The startup was founded in April this year and has raised $2.5 million.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA reveals the design of its new Mars rover
article: NASA on Friday announced that it's ready to build its next Mars rover called 'Mars 2020' and revealed its final design. To be launched in 2020, the rover is expected to land on Mars in February 2021. The rover will collect samples of soil and rock from the surface of Mars to find evidence of past life on the planet.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Smart thread gathers tissue data from stitches
article: A team of researchers have invented threads with integrated nano-scale sensors and electronics that, when sutured through multiple layers of tissue, can gather diagnostic data wirelessly. The threads help determine how a wound is healing, whether an infection is emerging, or whether the body's chemistry is out of balance. The results can be sent to a computer in real-time.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Zika outbreak will end in 3 yrs, study suggests
article: The Zika outbreak will likely end in the next three years, British scientists said, estimating that the infections will become so widespread that populations will develop immunity. This would prevent further transmission of the virus for at least a decade, they added. Zika's transmission data was compared to that of similar viruses, to create a model of projected Zika transmission.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Monkeys have been using tools for 700 yrs: Study
article: Archaeologists have discovered that capuchin monkeys in Brazil have been using stone anvils and hammers to crack open cashew nuts for more than 700 years. Further, they suggested that humans might have found nuts to be edible after coming across these tools. The conclusion was based on 69 stones found with signs of cashew nuts residue and repeated pounding-caused damage.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Densest storage system encodes 1 KB in 100 nm
article: Netherlands-based researchers have created a microscopic storage system that can encode every bit on a single atom. Claimed as the densest storage system, the new development can store a kilobyte in under 100 nanometers – equivalent to about 500 TB per square inch. Every bit consists of two positions on a surface of copper atoms, representing 1s and 0s.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: SpaceX successfully lands its Falcon 9 rocket
article: SpaceX on Monday successfully landed its two-stage Falcon 9 rocket. The landing marks the second time SpaceX recovered a rocket on land and their fifth recovered first stage in all. A Dragon capsule was perched on the top of the rocket carrying 2,267 kg of supplies for six crew members working at the International Space Station.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: NASA releases video of Sun doing a somersault
article: NASA has released a time-lapse video that makes the sun appear to be doing a somersault. NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory took a photo of the sun every 12 seconds for seven hours while rolling 360-degrees on one axis to take accurate measurements of its outer edge. The biannual manoeuvre helps understand changes in the sun's shape over time.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Bornean orangutan declared critically endangered
article: The Bornean orangutan, an orangutan species native to the island of Borneo, has been declared as a "Critically Endangered" species. Its count has reportedly shrunk by over 50% to 1,00,000 since 1973 due to growing human pressures, and is expected to further drop to 47,000 by 2025. The Whale shark, world's largest fish, was also enlisted as an "Endangered" species.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Hotline calls can help predict dengue outbreak
article: Researchers at the New York University have developed a system that can forecast dengue outbreaks two to three weeks in advance by analyzing the calling behavior of citizens to a public-health hotline. For demonstration, the team applied the system to the 2011 outbreaks data and was able to accurately forecast both the number of patients and their locations.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team makes Van Gogh painting from DNA origami
article: Caltech scientists have recreated Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh's "The Starry Night" using delicately-wrapped genetic strands in a process known as DNA origami. DNA origami, developed 10 years ago by another Caltech researcher, allows folding a DNA strand into any desired shape, which then acts as a scaffold where all kinds of nanometer-scale components can be attached.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA releases a video showing Pluto's surface
article: To mark the first anniversary of New Horizons spacecraft's Pluto approach, NASA released a video that shows the surface of the dwarf planet. The video is a compilation of over 100 images taken by the spacecraft. "This video shows what it would be like to ride aboard an approaching spacecraft and see Pluto grow," said New Horizons' Principal Investigator.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: WWF buys $100k shark fishing licence to scrap it
article: The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) Australia has bought a $100,000 shark fishing license on the Great Barrier Reef, and will retire it to save sharks from being caught. WWF said the license, which would've given its owner the right to drag a 1.2 km net anywhere along the Reef's length, was earlier used to catch about 10,000 sharks each year.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers develop 1st underwater microscope
article: Researchers at the University of California, San Diego, have crafted the Benthic Underwater Microscope, which they claim is the first undersea microscope that can study "millimeter-scale" activity. It combines a water-friendly computer with an imaging system which revolves around two lenses that can see shapes in 3D. The setup is used with a combination of LED lights and fluorescence imaging.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New 'sand' to cool electronic devices created
article: A US-based researcher has devised sand-like silicon dioxide nanoparticles coated with a high dielectric constant polymer that can inexpensively provide improved cooling for electronic devices. The coated nanoscale material's surface properties allow it to conduct the heat at potentially higher efficiency than existing heat sink materials, thereby improving heat dissipation.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Firm plans to grow optical fiber in microgravity
article: Made In Space, a California-based company that operates a 3D printer on the International Space Station (ISS), plans to grow optical fiber in microgravity. It will attempt to create better fiber in microgravity as terrestrially produced fiber suffers from glass impurities, potentially resulting in signal degradation. The company is scheduled to send a manufacturing product to the ISS in 2017.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Zika's 1st woman-to-man sexual transmission case
article: The first case of female-to-male sexual transmission of the Zika virus was recently reported in New York City by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Earlier this year, sexual transmission of Zika between two men was reported for the first time. The CDC suggested that woman-to-woman sexual transmission is also possible, although no cases have been confirmed yet.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: African super-telescope reveals 1,300 galaxies
article: While operating at a quarter of its eventual capacity, South Africa-based 'MeerKAT' radio telescope released its first captured image on Saturday, revealing 1,300 galaxies at a location where only 70 were known before. MeerKAT's full contingent of 64 receptors will be integrated next year into a multi-nation square kilometre array, which will make it the world’s most powerful radio telescope.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Biodiversity falls below 'safe levels': Study
article: In what was the most comprehensive examination yet of biodiversity loss, researchers have revealed that the variety of animals and plants has fallen below the 'safe levels' across 58.1% of the world's landmass. A site losing over 10% of its biodiversity is considered to have passed a precautionary threshold. For this, researchers analysed 2.38 million records of 39,123 species globally.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Massive earthquake threat in South Asia: Study
article: A new GPS study of Bangladesh, India, and Myanmar has found evidence of Indian subcontinent's active collision with Asia, that could potentially lead to a massive earthquake. The models suggest that the region, which is home to over 140 million people, could be sitting on an active megathrust fault, that has been accumulating stress for over 400 years.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Vision of blind mice restored for 1st time
article: In a first, Stanford University researchers claimed to have partially restored the vision of blind mice suffering from a glaucoma-like condition by regenerating optic nerve cables and re-establishing their connections with the brain. Glaucoma, which is caused by excessive pressure on the optic nerve causing it to damage, affects nearly 70 million people worldwide, leading to permanent vision loss.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Juno sends back 1st photo from Jupiter's orbit
article: NASA's Juno spacecraft has sent back the first image since entering Jupiter's orbit on July 4. The image shows a sunlit portion of the planet and its three moons. At that time, the spacecraft was 2.7 million miles from the planet and beginning its 53.5-day orbit. Juno had also captured a time-lapse video of Jupiter's moons over a two-week period.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Biggest galactic map with 1.2mn galaxies created
article: Researchers at the University of Portsmouth have created the largest ever three-dimensional map, featuring around 1.2 million distant galaxies, in a bid to help them understand 'dark energy'. Dark energy is an unknown form of energy that is driving the accelerated expansion of the universe. The researchers worked with other institutions for ten years gathering measurements of the galaxies.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop regenerative tooth filling
article: Researchers at the University of Nottingham have crafted regenerative tooth fillings that enable the tooth's own stem cells to regenerate and repair the damaged tissues. The technique can eventually avoid the need of the root canal treatment, where the filling material does nothing other than protecting the pulp of the tooth – one of the four major components of teeth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team creates 'Pac-Man' for microscopic organisms
article: A team of Norway-based researchers has developed a microscopic one-millimeter-wide game of 'Pac-Man' for single-celled organisms. Its maze was made of colourfully lit nanostructures and was populated with two species of unicellular and one species of multicellular microorganisms. Two of the three species took the role of Pac-Man while the third species were the predators who preyed on Pac-Man.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: LHC scientists find family of new particles
article: Scientists working on the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) have discovered new 'exotic' particles that seem to be "tetraquarks". Quarks are the fundamental constituents of matter that combine to form proton-like particles. Until recently, it was believed that quarks only come in groups of two or three, but in 2014, a tetraquark was discovered while a pentaquark was found last year.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: MIT team develops wireless toxic gas detector
article: MIT researchers have developed low-cost sensors that enable smartphones and other wireless devices to detect toxic gases. Researchers claimed that the sensors can detect less than 10 ppm of toxic gases in about five seconds. This technology can help soldiers on the battlefield to detect the presence of chemical weapons and people who work around hazardous chemicals prone to leakage.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA's Juno successfully enters Jupiter's orbit
article: NASA's $1.1 billion Juno spacecraft on Tuesday successfully entered the orbit of Jupiter, the largest planet of the solar system. Launched five years ago, the spacecraft will study Jupiter's composition, gravity, magnetic field and search clues about the planet's formation. Juno will be the second spacecraft to orbit Jupiter, following the Galileo probe which orbited from 1995–2003.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Microsoft writes 200 MB of data in DNA
article: Technology giant Microsoft has written over 200 MB of data into DNA. To do this, the binary code of the data was translated into long strings of the nucleotides that make up DNA strands. This data included a song by the rock band 'OK Go', who had earlier revealed plans to release an entire album as DNA.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New $2 saliva test to detect Zika in 40 minutes
article: US-based researchers have designed a portable $2 saliva test which they claim​ can diagnose Zika in 40 minutes. To make the test highly-selective, researchers identified a stretch of genetic code that is nearly identical for 19 different Zika strains. The system, which only requires the addition of water, contains a dye that turns blue in the presence of Zika virus.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: New food supplement can cut pizza, cake cravings
article: Scientists have claimed that taking a powdered food supplement containing a type of fibre called 'Inulin' can reduce cravings for high-calorie foods such as chocolate, cake and pizza. The supplement decreases activity in the brain areas associated with food craving and reduces the appetite. "Adding this to foods could reduce the urge to consume high-calorie foods," said a scientist.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Sheep Dolly became 1st cloned mammal 20 yrs ago
article: Dolly the sheep, the first mammal to be successfully cloned from an adult cell, was born on July 5, 1996, in Scotland. Scientists cloned Dolly after 277 failed attempts, as most of them ended up in miscarriages and deformed births. Dolly, who later gave birth to several lambs, developed lung disease along with arthritis and eventually died in 2003.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Non-water based life may exist on Titan: Study
article: Cornell University researchers have built a simulation that showed that prebiotic reactions could occur on the surface of Titan, which is the largest of Saturn's moons, without the presence of water. The team analysed data from NASA's Cassini-Huygens and found the possibility of the polymer 'polyimine' being developed on the moon's surface, which is capable of triggering prebiotic reactions.

author: Rahul Raj
abstract: 15 year old hacked NASA systems in 1999
article: Hacker Jonathan James from Florida hacked NASA computers in 1999 when he was 15 years old, resulting in a three week system shutdown and an estimated recovery cost of $41,000. He also invaded computers of a Defense Department agency and intercepted 3,300 emails with 19 employee passwords. He was later traced and sentenced to six months in jail.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA releases 'Juno Mission Trailer'
article: Ahead of the Juno spacecraft's arrival into Jupiter's orbit, NASA has released the 'Juno Mission Trailer' outlining mission details and difficulties. The spacecraft, which aims to study the planet's composition, gravity and magnetic field, was launched on August 5, 2011, and will arrive in the planet's orbit on Monday. This is also the farthest solar-powered trip in space exploration history.

author: Satyaki Das
abstract: Newton's laws of motion published 329 years ago
article: English scientist Isaac Newton's 'Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy' was published on July 5, 1687. The book, originally written in Latin, contains mathematical formulations of Newton’s laws of motion, law of gravity, and a derivation of the laws of planetary motion. In this book, Newton also developed the calculus, a key mathematical tool in the domain of science and engineering.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Exoplanet orbiting three stars discovered
article: Researchers using European Southern Observatory's 'Very Large Telescope' have discovered a rare exoplanet orbiting three different stars located around 340 light-years from Earth. Named 'HD 131399Ab', the planet is four times heavier than Jupiter and has a surface temperature of over 576ºC. In the triple star system, two stars are orbiting each other while also going around the third star.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers use light to kill mice cancer cells
article: Researchers in the US have developed a new method that uses light to kill cancer cells in mice. The technique involves injecting chemical compound 'nitrobenzaldehyde' into the tumor and aiming a beam of ultraviolet light at the chemical-filled tumor to cause the cancer-killing reaction. The researchers estimated that the method killed 95% of the targeted cancer cells in two hours.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Stupidity, greed biggest threats to mankind'
article: Stephen Hawking, during an interview, said that human stupidity, greed and pollution are the biggest threats to mankind. "We have certainly not become less greedy or less stupid" in the treatment of the environment over the past decade, he added. He also raised concerns about the future of artificial intelligence technologies, and the prioritisation of its uses.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: China builds world's largest radio telescope
article: In order to hunt for extraterrestrial life and explore space, China has built the world's largest radio telescope, named FAST (Five Hundred Metre Aperture Spherical Telescope). The radio telescope is equivalent to the size of 30 football fields. It took about five years to build and is expected to begin operations in September.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New material changes shape from heat, light
article: Researchers at the Washington State University have created a multi-functional 'smart' material that can change its shape from heat or light. It reacts to light, can remember its shape as it folds, unfolds and can heal itself when damaged. The team worked with long-chain molecules, that change in response to heat, and added certain atom groups to make it light-sensitive.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Equation to quantify life on other planets
article: Researchers in the US and the UK have constructed a mathematical equation which, when solved, will help in estimating how often life begins on other planets. The equation takes into consideration several parameters like the number of possible building blocks, availability of building blocks during a given time period and the probability of building block's existence actually leading to life.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 1st possible water clouds outside solar system
article: US-based astronomers have found a strong evidence for the existence of water clouds on a brown dwarf 7.2 light-years away, making it the first water clouds detected outside the solar system. Named 'WISE 0855', the brown dwarf, which is five times heavier than Jupiter, is also the coldest known object outside the solar system with a temperature of -23ºC.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers create 3D view of cell's interior
article: Researchers at the Yale University have created a 3D view of the interior of cells that includes mitochondria, cellular power packs and nuclear membranes that envelope the DNA. The team, working with astronomy telescopes, recorded three-dimensional representations of 19 paternal and maternal mouse chromosomes by using coloured fluorescent tags attached to proteins that bind them together.

author: Vani Vivek
abstract: Video explains technology on-board NASA's Juno
article: Scott Bolton, Principal Investigator of NASA's Juno mission to Jupiter, has explained the spacecraft's key on-board technology in a YouTube video in less than three minutes. The microwave radiometer will look below Jupiter's clouds for the first time and create a 3D image of its atmosphere, while the visible-light camera will capture unseen perspectives of Jupiter's north pole.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Earth farthest from the sun today
article: Planet Earth will be farthest from the sun on Monday at 05:24 pm GMT (09:54 pm IST). Called the 'aphelion', the phenomenon wherein the distance between the two celestial bodies is over 94 million miles (15 crore kilometers) always falls around July 4. Opposite of 'aphelion', the 'perihelion', wherein the Earth is closest to the sun, occurs around January 4.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Electronic nose detects pesticides and nerve gas
article: Belgian researchers have developed an electronic nose-like sensor which is capable of successfully detecting low concentrations of pesticides and nerve gas. The sensor uses Metallic-Organic​ Frameworks (MOFs), whose porous structure allows it to absorb phosphonates present in those gases. The sensor will help detect traces of chemical weapons like sarin and identify residual pesticides on food.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Dinosaur extinction caused by multiple factors
article: According to a study by US-based researchers, the extinction of dinosaurs around 66 million years ago was caused by two global warming periods. The first was triggered by large volcanic eruptions in what is India today, and the second was caused by the asteroid crash about 150,000 years later. The incidents recorded around 7.8ºC and 1.1ºC rise in temperatures respectively.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: US Navy funds bomb-sniffing locusts project
article: A US Navy department has provided a three-year $750,000 grant to a project aimed at developing bomb-sniffing locusts. The researchers will use locusts' ability to identify particular scents, by implanting an electrode into its brains and reading the electrical activity. A backpack would also be attached on the insect's back to transmit data about the absence or presence of explosives.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Harvard team builds living robot from rat hearts
article: Harvard University researchers have used 200,000 genetically-engineered rat cells to develop a robot that looks like a stingray. The team used silicone for the robot's body and also to insulate its skleton, which was made of gold wire. The cells were designed to contract when exposed to a specific wavelength of light, helping the robot to mimic a stingray's movement.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Contagious cancer found in shellfish species
article: Researchers at the Columbia University have found that disseminated neoplasia, a leukemia-like cancer, is contagious across multiple shellfish species – mussels, cockles, and golden carpet shell clams. The cancer cells were found to be genetically distinct from their hosts, indicating that the disease originated from some other species and has been spreading from clam to clam, a researcher said.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: 'Ancient Earth's magnetic field was multipolar'
article: US-based researchers have found that around 600-700 million years ago Earth's magnetic field varied in intensity, direction and originated from multiple poles instead of being bipolar. The study claims that the Earth's core went from solid to liquid state 1 billion years ago causing the magnetic field to become multipolar before eventually turning back to solid with bipolar magnetic field.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Pluto may have an ocean beneath its icy surface
article: US-based researchers analysing the data collected by NASA's New Horizons spacecraft revealed the existence of a subsurface ocean beneath Pluto's icy surface. The team claimed that Pluto would have shrunk if its oceans had dried up. The data suggested the planet is still expanding which led the scientists to believe that the liquid ocean under Pluto's icy crust still exists.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Huge helium gas reserve found in Africa
article: England-based researchers have found around 54 billion-cubic-feet of helium gas in Tanzania's Rift Valley, Africa. The gas, which is vital but relatively rare, is critical in areas like MRI scanners, welding, and industrial leak detection. The find is being called a "game-changer" in addressing a critical shortage, as until now the gas was usually discovered accidentally and in small quantities.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: 1st signs of ozone layer recovery observed
article: Scientists at MIT have discovered the first signs of healing of the Antarctic ozone layer. The team found that the depleted ozone layer above the continent has shrunk by more than four million square kilometres, since its peak depletion in 2000. The team attributes the ozone layer's recovery to the continuing decline of atmospheric chlorine originating from chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Beijing sinking by over 4 inches per year: Study
article: China's capital city, Beijing is sinking by over four inches per year, according to a study conducted using the help of satellite imagery. The study states that excessive pumping of groundwater from beneath Beijing has led to the geological subsidence. According to the study, continued subsidence poses a safety threat to the city alongside "a strong impact on train operations".

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: New tool to measure polarization of light
article: US-based researchers have developed a new tool to measure light's polarization based on single light sampling, rather than the multiple samples required by existing technologies. Polarization is expressed as the orientation of light's electromagnetic field. To calculate the polarization, the tool uses three layers of organic polymer detectors, each of which measures the polarization partially.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Jeff Bezos announces new Blue Origin facility
article: Blue Origin Founder Jeff Bezos on Tuesday announced a new facility in Florida, US to manufacture the company's orbital vehicles. The 7,50,000 square feet facility can accommodate manufacturing, processing, integration and testing of orbital rockets. Bezos stated that the new facility is expected to be completed by December 2017.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA successfully tests Mars-bound booster
article: NASA on Tuesday successfully tested the booster designed for its Mars-bound rocket 'Space Launch System', which is the most powerful rocket in the world. The 47-metre booster provided 3.6 million pounds of thrust – almost equivalent to the thrust of 14 Boeing 747-400s at take off. The rocket will take off for its first uncrewed test flight in late 2018.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Hair, feathers came from reptile scales: Study
article: According to a study by Switzerland-based researchers, hair in mammals and feathers in birds evolved from a single ancestor, a reptile that lived 300 million years ago. The team came to the conclusion after finding that some reptiles' embryos formed placodes – thickened skin patches in embryos which have long been known to give rise to hair and feathers.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA captures auroras in Jupiter's atmosphere
article: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has captured images of vivid glows called 'auroras' in Jupiter's atmosphere, ahead of the entry of its Juno spacecraft in the giant planet's orbit in July. The auroras, which cover areas bigger than the Earth, are created when high-energy particles enter a planet's atmosphere near its magnetic poles and collide with atoms of gas.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: US Navy developing electromagnetic canon
article: The United States Navy is developing an electromagnetically propelled ballistic missile system named Railgun. Electromagnetic energy propels a projectile along a set of copper-alloy rails, instead of traditional gunpowder and electric propulsion. The 25-megawatt power consuming railgun can shoot rounds expected to travel at approximately 9,200 kmph and cover around 160 kilometres.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: IBM researchers find new way to recycle e-waste
article: IBM researchers have discovered a one-step recycling process to help convert old smartphones and CDs into non-toxic, high-strength plastics that can be used for water purification, fiber optics and medical equipment. The team added a fluoride reactant and heat to old CDs to create this new plastic that showed to have better temperature and chemical resistance than the original substance.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Rare dinosaur-era bird wings found in Myanmar
article: Researchers have found wings from birds that lived alongside dinosaurs until 66 million years ago when the dinosaur-killing asteroid crashed into Earth. Discovered in Myanmar, the specimens indicate that they are from birds that got trapped 99 million years ago. "We usually get small fragments or isolated feathers... We don't get something like this. It's mind-blowingly cool", a researcher said.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: 4 crops grown in simulated Martian soil edible
article: A study conducted by researchers at the Wageningen University in the Netherlands have found that radishes, peas, rye and tomatoes grown in Martian soil are safe to eat. As part of the study, different types of plants were grown in the soil developed by NASA for simulating Martian soil composition, which contains toxic heavy metals including lead and arsenic.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: New plastic makes it easier to squeeze out soap
article: Researchers at the Ohio State University have developed a kind of plastic which makes it easier to extract remnant liquids like soap and shampoo from bottles made of the material. The plastic contains small structures over which droplets of liquid can move over pockets of air, making the liquid immune to sticking to the inside of the container.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists find source of gravitational waves
article: A study by Poland-based researchers revealed that the two black holes, whose collision was responsible for the first discovery of gravitational waves, were formed as stars 12 billion-years-ago. As per the study, the stars became black holes 5 million years after their formation and then merged 10.3 billion years later, generating the gravitational waves that were detected in September 2015.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Tech improves gravity wave detectors' sensitivity
article: Researchers have developed a technology that they claim could double the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory's sensitivity enabling it to detect faint gravitational waves. Instead of light, researchers used squeezed vacuum source, that was created by modifying vacuum state captured by hitting an optical cavity with laser beams and decreasing the laser power till there was no light.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists turn sewage sludge into concrete
article: Malaysia-based researchers have recycled dried sewage sludge by adding it to cement, forming concrete. They found that with increasing proportions of dried sludge powder in concrete, its compressive strength decreased while its salt-resistance increased for up to 15% sludge concentration. "Overall, there is potential for using waste sludge powder as a partial cement replacement," researchers said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Hawking plans to map the entire known universe
article: Stephen Hawking is expected to announce plans to map the entire known universe using the Cosmos supercomputer centre that he founded at the Cambridge University. The computer centre's Director Paul Shellard said that for the mapping, the computer will use images of radiation from the Big Bang taken by the European Space Agency's Planck satellite.

author: Mirza Mohammed
abstract: US, Canada, Mexico to commit 50% clean energy by 2025
article: The United States, Canada, and Mexico will this week reportedly pledge that they will produce 50% of their power from hydropower, wind, solar and nuclear plants by 2025. Leaders of the three countries will commit to this goal during a summit between them this week. The nations will also reportedly agree on deals with regard to transmitting of clean energy.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 2 new vaccines found to protect mice from Zika
article: A team of US-based researchers has found two potential Zika vaccine candidates that were able to completely protect mice against the virus. The first vaccine was made from genetic material taken from the virus, while the second was made from whole inactivated virus. Both the vaccines caused the rodents to produce antibodies that targeted specific proteins in the virus.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Microsoft launches prototype mosquito trap
article: Microsoft recently launched a prototype mosquito trap that can collect several data points like the breed, temperature, wind, humidity and the time at which a mosquito was captured. The system is then expected to provide faster and more accurate information about where disease-bearing mosquitoes can be found. A pilot program has been deployed in Houston.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Zika virus may not cause microcephaly: Study
article: A study conducted on nearly 12,000 Zika-infected pregnant women in Colombia found zero microcephaly cases, contradicting the assumed connection between Zika and microcephaly. Microcephaly is a condition where a child's brain does not develop properly resulting in an abnormally small head. The study also revealed​ about 50 microcephaly cases in the country, four of which were connected with Zika.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Startup gets $8.9M for food poisoning test tech
article: US-based startup Ancera on Tuesday raised $8.9 million in Series A round of funding to develop 'Piper', a device to test food poisoning and prevent recalls. Launching next month, the device is a small printer-sized instrument which uses disposable cartridges about the size of a smartphone. It can detect and quantify sickness causing bacteria salmonella within one to eight hours.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Frigate birds found to fly for months at a time
article: A team of international researchers has found that the 'great frigate birds' can stay in flight for up to two months at a time. The birds were found to use very little energy as they rely on atmospheric updrafts to keep them aloft. The team also suggested the birds might sleep for minutes while they are carried effortlessly by updrafts.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Some genes can live after body's death: Study
article: A study by US-based researchers found that some genes in mice and zebrafish, including ones that help in embryo creation, can stay alive for up to four days after the body has died. The research could potentially help in reducing the risk of transplant-caused cancer and could also help forensic teams in better estimating the time of a person's death.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: South Pole's carbon dioxide at 4 mn-year high
article: According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, carbon dioxide surpassed 400 parts-per-million at the South Pole for the first time in four million years on May 23. This was the last place where CO2 had not yet reached that mark, a researcher said and added, "Global CO2 levels will not return to values below 400 ppm in our lifetimes".

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: World's 1st magnetic refrigerator launched
article: French firm Cooltech Applications has launched what it claims as the world's first commercially available magnetic refrigeration system. It achieves refrigeration by passing a water coolant through magnetocaloric materials undergoing repeated magnetization-demagnetization cycles. The system works without any refrigerant gas, making it more environmentally efficient than conventional refrigerators.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Climate change claims 1st mammalian extinction
article: According to a new study, an Australian rodent species found only on a tiny island on the Great Barrier Reef is the first mammal to be declared extinct because of human-caused climate change. The species was discovered in 1845 and was last seen in 2009. "The key factor responsible... is almost certainly high tides and surging seawater", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New process turns discarded plastic into fuel
article: Researchers have developed a two-catalyst process that turns discarded plastic into fuel. Plastics are very long chains of mainly hydrogen and carbon atoms. In the process, one catalyst strips hydrogen off adjacent carbon atoms allowing neighbouring​ carbon atoms to form a weak double bond. The second catalyst splits the double bond, forming shorter chains that can be used for fuel.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New asteroid found to be orbiting Earth
article: NASA scientists have discovered an asteroid, named 2016 HO3, orbiting the sun that also appears to circle around Earth. It has a slightly tilted orbit, bouncing up and down through Earth's orbital plane. Described as the best example of a "quasi-satellite", the asteroid has been Earth's stable quasi-satellite for almost a century and will remain one for centuries, researchers said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop sperm sorting device
article: Researchers in the US have developed a device that claims to sort the best sperm cells out of millions in half an hour for assisted reproductive technologies. The device consists of an inlet for unprocessed semen sample and two chambers separated by a porous membrane, which allows healthy, motile sperm to swim through, leaving behind less functional and dead sperm.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Experimental Zika vaccine to be tested on humans
article: An experimental vaccine for the Zika virus is due to begin human testing in coming weeks, after getting the green light from US health officials. The vaccine is intended to prime the immune system to fight Zika by introducing genetically engineered material that mimics the virus. Notably, there are currently no licensed drugs or vaccines for Zika.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Russia makes world's biggest nuclear icebreaker
article: Russia on Monday unveiled the world's biggest nuclear-powered icebreaker 'Arktika'. The twin-reactor icebreaker vessel is 586 feet long and can smash through 10 feet thick and 13 feet deep ice. The giant vessel is a part of Russia's $1.9 billion 'Project 22220'. When completed, 'Arktika' will conduct year-round navigation in the Arctic and process nearly 150 tonnes of water.

author: Vaibhav Gupta
abstract: APPLE was India’s first communication satellite
article: Ariane Passenger PayLoad Experiment (APPLE) was India’s first communication satellite successfully launched in 1981. Incidentally, the satellite was carried on a non-metallic bullock cart to avoid reflections off the metal plates, affecting the satellite’s antenna. It was dedicated to the nation by the then PM Indira Gandhi who said that it marked the ‘Dawn of India’s satellite communication era.’

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Fish may have evolved to live on land 33 times
article: According to a new study by researchers at the University of New South Wales in Australia, fish may have evolved at least 33 times to live on land. The team found 130 fish species that live on land today to some degree. Notably, the first transition where a fish adapted to life on land happened over 350 million years ago.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Analog compiler to simulate organs developed
article: MIT researchers have developed an analog compiler which helps in creating accurate analog simulations of an organ. The compiler translates standard differential equations – often used to represent various cell dynamics – into ​equivalent electrical systems.​ This allowed the compiler to link certain voltages with the equations' values and to find complete, continuous solutions to those equations.

author: Mirza Mohammed
abstract: Solar plane lands after 3-day transatlantic leg
article: After a flight across the Atlantic from New York spanning almost three days, the fully solar-powered plane Impulse 2 landed in Seville, Spain on Thursday. The flight, lasting over 71 hours, was the fifteenth leg of the journey around the world by Swiss aviators Bertrand Piccard and Andre Borschberg. The plane has a cruising speed of 70 km per hour.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists detect most distant signs of oxygen
article: Scientists have detected the most distant oxygen ever seen in the universe, in a galaxy 13.1 billion light-years away. This indicates that several stars are emitting intense ultraviolet light needed to ionise oxygen atoms, the study said. The observation may help understand the cosmic reionization​ phase, few million years post the Big Bang when neutral gas atoms were getting ionised.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Dino-killing asteroid killed 93% mammals: Study
article: A study by England-based researchers revealed that over 93% of mammal species were wiped off by the dinosaur-killing asteroid crash, which took place in the Cretaceous period over 66 million-years-ago. The researchers also found that the remaining mammals took 3,00,000 years to double the species count that had existed before the crash-caused mass extinction, much faster than previously thought.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Scientists find reason behind volcanic lightning
article: Researchers in Japan have discovered the reason behind lightning in a volcanic ash cloud. Using high-speed cameras and acoustic sensors, they found that volcanic lightning flashes are mostly restricted near the volcano's rim. The team added that the lightning occurs as the magma electrifies the rising ash particles and eventually the accumulated electrostatic charge gets discharged as lightning.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: ISS astronauts return to Earth after 6 months
article: UK astronaut Tim Peake and his crewmates, America's Tim Kopra and Russia's Yuri Malenchenko, returned to Earth on Saturday after spending six months on the International Space Station. His mission took him on about 3,000 orbits of Earth, covering around 125 million km. The 44-year-old, who performed over 250 experiments on the ISS, termed his stay as "a life-changing experience".

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: First woman travelled to space 53 years ago
article: Russian cosmonaut Valentina Vladimirovna Tereshkova travelled to space on June 16, 1963, becoming the world's first woman to do so. Tereshkova, who was 26-years-old at that time, completed 48 orbits of the Earth, spending 71 hours in space. Notably, this duration was greater than the time spent in space by all US astronauts combined until 1963.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Living bone grown in lab for 1st time
article: In a first, US-based researchers have grown a living bone in the lab. It was tested on pigs with bone damage and found to be better at regrowing bones than other methods. In the new process, unlike other techniques where a scaffold is implanted to support the growth, the bone was first grown outside in the scaffold before implanting.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Youngest fully-formed exoplanet discovered
article: Astronomers have confirmed the discovery​ of a 5 to 10 million years old exoplanet, making it the youngest ever to be discovered. Nearly 3,000 exoplanets have been discovered so far with most of them aged more than a billion years. The discovery could provide scientists with new insights into how planets and solar systems are formed.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create single-molecule photoswitch
article: Beijing-based researchers have created a switch using a photosensitive molecule whose electrical conductivity can be switched on or off by light. As per the researchers, previous such switches used to get stuck, but the latest development can be switched over 100 times and can function for a year. Such switches can help in solar energy, light-sensing applications and miniaturising electronics.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Gene-editing tool approved for 1st human trials
article: A US panel has approved the first ever human trials of the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing technique, proposed by University of Pennsylvania researchers. The team aims to modify the immune system "T cells" in patients, helping them better fight off several cancer types. CRISPR-Cas9 is currently one of the fastest, simplest and cheapest tools that help geneticists edit parts of a genome.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists find 470 million-year-old alien rock
article: Scientists in Sweden have unearthed what they claim is a piece of a never-before-seen alien rock deeply buried in a limestone quarry for about 470 million years. Named Oest 65, the discovery is thought to be part of a rock 20-30 km wide, which had crashed into a larger rock 100-150 km wide, pouring the Earth with debris.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Gravitational waves detected for 2nd time
article: Researchers analysing Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory data have confirmed the second instance of gravitational waves (recorded in December 2015). The faint ripple, that eventually reached Earth, was produced by the collision of two black holes at half the speed of light, 1.4 billion light years away. Notably, gravitational waves' first detection was reported back in February.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Mars crater named after Nepal quake-hit village
article: The International Astronomical Union has named a 9.8-kilometre​ wide crater on Mars after Nepal's earthquake-hit village of Langtang. The village, which served as a Himalayan base camp, was one of the worst hit villages in the 2015 Nepal earthquake, killing more than 200 people. According to a researcher, the crater showed signs of water flows and remains of former glaciers.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Humans, warm climate led to Ice Age extinctions
article: According to a study by Australia-based researchers, extinction of giant Ice Age species, like elephant-sized sloths and sabre-toothed cats, around 12,300 years ago was caused by rapidly warming climate and human hunting. The species, that lived in South America, were extinct in a century of the beginning of the climate change, which the researchers suggested was also impacted by humans.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Electric current used to make low-fat chocolate
article: US-based physicists have found a new technique to produce low-fat chocolate. Traditionally, manufacturers have to maintain around 40% fat to keep the chocolate in liquid form and keep it from clogging machinery. The new technique applies electric current to the liquid chocolate in the direction of its flow, which helps in maintaining a smooth flow with around 10% less fat.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Birds found able to learn grammatical structures
article: Netherlands-based researchers have found that two songbirds species – zebra finches and budgerigars – are able to learn the rules of abstract grammatical structures. Individual birds were isolated in a chamber and then were taught to recognize sentence triplets in the form of specific sound patterns. The birds were found to recognize sentence structures even with differently ordered sounds.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Three-parent baby' test successfully completed
article: In a first, England-based researchers have successfully completed the 'three-parent baby' test. Theoretically, to make a baby from three parents, using in-vitro fertilization, certain genes from a third person need to be inserted into a growing embryo. This way, the third person will be supplying 0.2% of the kid's genes, none of which control characteristics like hair or eye color.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Oldest computer may have been used for astronomy
article: According to a decade-long study, a 2,100-year-old mechanical computer may be the world's oldest computer and may have been used to track celestial bodies including the sun and moon, and predict eclipses. The computer named Antikythera mechanism was discovered in 1901. The team found 3,500 characters of explanatory text on the computer, that shows its working, according to a researcher.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Planet's layers being torn away by a star: Study
article: A study by US-based researchers revealed that the outer layers of a Jupiter-like newly-born planet, 1,100 light-years away, appear to be ripped away by a nearby star's gravity, which it orbits every 11 hours. "We don't yet have absolute proof this is a planet", lead author said but added that this could be one of the youngest planets yet observed.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Milky Way invisible to one-third of humanity
article: According to a recently created global light pollution atlas, the visible portion of the Milky Way galaxy is hidden from almost one-third of the global population because of artificial lighting. Light pollution, which inhibits astronomical observation, is the brightening of the night sky due to artificial light sources. The atlas showed Australia and Canada to have the darkest skies.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Google marks blood group discoverer's birthday
article: Google Doodle on Tuesday​ marked the 148th birthday of Austrian-American biologist and physician Karl Landsteiner who discovered the existence of different types of blood groups in 1901. His exploration about the exchange of same or compatible blood groups also led to the first successful human blood transfusion in 1907. Landsteiner was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1930 for his discovery.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: France creates meteor-tracking camera network
article: France has developed a camera-based meteor detection network, called the Fireball Recovery and InterPlanetary Observation Network (FRIPON). The network is able to track meteors using a nation-wide camera system which currently employs 68 cameras. The data from the network will help detect meteor trajectory, their source of origin and their likely impact locations.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Largest planet to orbit two suns discovered
article: Astronomers at NASA have discovered what is the largest planet so far to orbit around two suns. Named the Kepler-1647b, the Jupiter-like planet is almost 4.4 billion years old and lies in the Cygnus constellation, approximately 3,700 light-years​ away from the Earth. With a 1,107-day orbit, the planet has the longest period of any transiting exoplanet found so far.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Birds as mentally capable as apes: Study
article: According to a study by scientists at the Charles University in Prague, songbirds and parrots were found to be as mentally​ capable as primates with similar-sized brains. Although lighter than mammalian brains, bird brains are twice as dense, the study claimed. The high neuron​ density, predominantly located in the bird's forebrain, was found to be responsible for faster information processing.
