author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Chiral molecule detected in interstellar space
article: Scientists have detected the first complex organic chiral molecule, propylene oxide (CH3CHOCH2), in interstellar space – near the center of the Milky Way galaxy. Chiral molecules have an identical chemical composition but are the right and left-handed versions. The discovery will help understand why life on Earth relies on a certain handedness to perform key biological functions, the study said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Names of 4 new Periodic Table elements announced
article: The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) has announced the names proposed for the new elements, whose discovery helped complete the seventh row of the Periodic Table in December last year. The names proposed for the elements with atomic numbers 113, 115, 117 and 118 were Nihonium (Nh), Moscovium (Mc), Tennessine (Ts) and Oganesson (Og) respectively.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Ancient geologic events linked to earthquakes
article: Scientists have created new models that link ancient geologic events with earthquakes, mountain formation and other ongoing processes. The models revealed that former plate boundaries may stay hidden at sites away from existing boundaries and trigger changes in the Earth's surface. This changes the widespread view that only continent-sized plates' boundaries trigger such events, researchers said.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Laser scans reveal city under jungle in Cambodia
article: Archeologists have discovered hidden medieval​ cities using laser-based scanning hidden under a jungle surrounding Cambodia's Angkor​ Wat temple complex, the world's largest religious monument. It was constructed from the early to mid 1100s and was among the world's largest pre-industrial cities. The scans revealed a city complex, iron smelting sites and a complex system of waterways.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team detects 'music' from 13 bn-year-old stars
article: Researchers in England have detected acoustic oscillations of one of the oldest known clusters of stars in the Milky Way Galaxy, around 13 billion years old. Using data from NASA's Kepler missions, the researchers studied these oscillations which are caused by the sound trapped inside the stars. They suggested that this 'stellar music' may help determine stars' mass and age.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Arctic sea ice cover fell to record low for May
article: Data from the US National Snow and Ice Data Centre revealed that average Arctic sea ice extent in May 2016 was 5,80,000 square-kilometre smaller than the previous record-low of 2004. It was also around 13.9 lakh square-kilometre below the 1981-2010 average. The average ice loss during May 2016 was 61,000 square kilometre per day – faster than the 1981-2010 average.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New algorithm to determine groundwater levels
article: US-based scientists have developed an algorithm that helps them to use satellite data to determine groundwater levels across large areas. The data was obtained by monitoring tiny changes in the elevation of Earth's surface using electromagnetic waves. "It could be especially useful in agricultural regions, where groundwater pumping is common and aquifer depletion is a concern", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Methane leak spotted from space for 1st time
article: In a first, an instrument onboard a NASA satellite has measured the methane emissions from a specific leaking facility while passing over the Aliso Canyon near Porter Ranch in California. "The percentage of atmospheric methane produced through human activities remains poorly understood", a researcher said. The breakthrough will help monitor methane emissions from space, the study added.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Rainfall over black hole observed for 1st time
article: In a first, US-based astronomers have gathered evidence showing dense clouds pouring down on a massive black hole situated about 1.23 billion light-years from Earth. The team discovered three massive gas clouds travelling at about 1 million kmph towards the black hole and estimated that each cloud spans over 10 light-years across and contains material equivalent to 1 million Suns.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: First spacecraft left solar system on this day
article: After spending more than 10 years in space, NASA's Pioneer 10 outer planetary space probe became the first man-made object to leave the solar system on June 13, 1983. Launched on a mission to probe the planet Jupiter, the Pioneer 10 is the second farthest spacecraft from Earth, lying approximately 15.4 billion kilometres away from the Earth as of 2011.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Second layer of information in DNA confirmed
article: Netherlands-based researchers have confirmed that, apart from genetic information, DNA's folding mechanism also controls human being's evolution. Conventionally, the sequence of letters G, A, T and C in the DNA determines what proteins are made. The discovery revealed that the way in which DNA is folded determines how the letters are read out and, therefore, which proteins are actually made.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New material turns infrared into visible light
article: Germany-based researchers have developed a compound that can convert infrared into visible light. The compound, designed of tin and sulfur in a diamond-like pattern, alters the infrared light's wavelength, producing light at wavelengths that are visible. This process, unlike the earlier ones where visible photons are thrown in random directions, gives the light in the same direction it came from.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Proof of Mars' ancient explosive volcanoes found
article: NASA's Curiosity rover has found evidence of tridymite on Mars, a type of mineral associated with explosive volcanoes on Earth. The evidence points against the geological theory that Mars has never experienced earthquakes and explosive volcanoes since the planet does not have shifting plates. The presence of the mineral in the Gale crater is attributed to sediment deposits​ by rivers.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Primate brain pre-adapted to face any situation
article: According to a study by France-based researchers, brains of human and non-human primates are pre-adapted to face potentially any situation. This leads to their ability to learn novel behaviours​ that couldn't have been directly anticipated by evolution. The study revealed that the brain anticipates all the situations that it may encounter in a lifetime by creating a special neural network.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method can save data in living cells
article: According to a recent report, Harvard University researchers have developed a method to record molecular events in living cells. For this, researchers used a bacterium's built-in immune system – CRISPR. This would allow the modified bacterium to pass on the information to the next generation. The advancement may aid in creating bacteria that could be used as sensors, researchers said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists find fossils of 'hobbit' ancestors
article: According to papers published on Wednesday, scientists in Australia have found what appears to be the fossils of ancestors of extinct half-sized humans, nicknamed 'hobbit', who lived around 7,00,000 years ago on Flores island. The team reported that larger early men probably arrived on the island about a million years ago and started shrinking to adapt to the environment.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Temperature affects sex of lizard species: Study
article: According to a study by Australian researchers, temperature influences the sex of the Australian central bearded dragon, a species of agamid lizard. The study found that if eggs with typically male sex chromosomes were incubated in a nest at 32ºC or greater, they emerged as females. Below that temperature, sex appeared to be completely determined by their genetics.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Experiment turns waste carbon dioxide into rocks
article: For an experiment that started in 2012, scientists in Iceland have been injecting carbon dioxide waste from a geothermal plant into 1,600-feet underground volcanic basalt. According to results, 95% of the stored gas turned into solid carbonate minerals within two years. The process took $30 to capture a ton of carbon dioxide against the $65 to $100 in conventional techniques.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 1st rodent with human-like menstrual cycle found
article: Researchers at the Monash University in Australia claim to have found a rodent, the spiny mouse (Acomys cahirinus), that has a human-like menstruation cycle. For the research, the team tracked 14 female mice and found that the mice, with a ratio similar to humans, had a nine-day menstrual cycle and spent three of the nine days shedding the uterine lining.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Underwater city found to be a bacteria formation
article: Scientists have confirmed the remains of a lost city discovered in 2013 off the Greek island Zakynthos as a bacteria formation that occurred five million years ago. It included circular and rectangular formations which appeared to be man made. Scientists said the structures were formed by the bacteria feeding off the methane gas leaked out from beneath the sea bed.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Flexible OLED built using graphene electrodes
article: Korean researchers have developed efficient, flexible OLEDs using graphene as a transparent electrode. In conventional OLEDs, the transparent electrode being used is brittle and expensive. The new OLEDs, for which researchers sandwiched the transparent graphene electrode between two layers with high and low refractive index, resulted in a comparatively better quantum efficiency of 40.8%.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Magma buildup discovered under New Zealand town
article: Scientists claim to have discovered magma building up under the New Zealand town of Matata. The buildup, which is claimed to be responsible for a number of earthquakes in the past few years, is voluminous enough to fill 80,000 Olympic-size swimming pools. The discovery is claimed to be a signal towards​ the formation of a new volcano.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Mom-to-kid HIV transfer stopped 1st time in Asia
article: The World Health Organization (WHO) on Wednesday said that Thailand has become the first country in Asia to eliminate mother-to-baby transmission of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Further, Belarus and Armenia were also declared free of mother-to-baby HIV transmissions. In July 2015, Cuba became the world's first country to eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV under WHO’s criteria.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Man survives a year with artificial heart
article: A 25-year-old man named Stan Larkin survived on a 'SynCardia' temporary total artificial heart for 555 days until a successful heart transplant earlier this month. His real heart was removed after being diagnosed with a condition that causes heart failure without warning. To keep the artificial heart going, Larkin carried a 6-kg wearable power supply in a backpack.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Proposal launched to create synthetic human gene
article: American scientists have launched a new proposal to string together synthetically made DNA and shape a human genome from it which would be able to power a cell in a dish. The goal of the project, for which the team aims to raise $100 million, is to better understand how DNA works and look for new ways of treating diseases.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Orcas' evolution found to be culture-influenced
article: Researchers have found that cultural groups of the killer whale, also known as orca, have evolved to become genetically distinct from one another. This reportedly makes them the first creatures, other than humans, to exhibit culture-based biological evolution. Being evolved from a single ancestor, the creatures have branched off into five distinct cultural groups approximately 2,00,000 years ago.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Enzyme found that can protect from Alzheimer's
article: Researchers at the Indiana University have found that an enzyme known as NMNAT2 may help protect against the debilitating effects of various degenerative brain diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and Huntington's. The enzyme functions to protect neurons from stress caused by over-excitation, and combats clumped up proteins encountered by the brain because of the diseases.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Pluto's image shows 1st proof of possible cloud
article: NASA's New Horizons spacecraft has captured an image of Pluto, that can prove to be the first evidence for the existence of clouds on the dwarf planet. The dwarf planet's image, which was illuminated by the Sun in the background, showed a presence of wisp-like formations which could be methane clouds as predicted by models.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Gene circuits in cells can perform computations
article: MIT researchers have developed living gene circuits that are capable of performing complex processing operations. The circuit contains a module which acts as a sensor for detecting analogue levels of a specific chemical, which in turn controls another module that acts as a digital switch. These circuits might help regulate levels of chemicals such as insulin and glucose.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Oldest plant root stem cells discovered in UK
article: Scientists at the UK's Oxford University have discovered the oldest known plant root stem cells in a 320 million-year-old fossil. The fossil, a root tip, was found at the university's preserved selection of plants kept for study. It belongs to the plants that grew in the Earth's first global tropical wetland forests.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Tropical fish found to recognize human faces
article: Marine biology researchers at the University of Oxford have discovered that the Tropical Archerfish is capable of recognising human faces with a high degree of accuracy. This is the first time the trait has been observed in fish. Believed to have been carried only by primates and dogs, the fish's trait was found to have been accurate for over 80%.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Arctic may get ice-free for 1st time in 100k yrs
article: Cambridge University professor Peter Wadhams has claimed the Arctic sea may become ice-free this year or in 2017 for the first time in 100,000 years. Wadhams added that sea ice will be in less than one million sq km by September. Satellite data earlier showed 11.1 million sq km of sea ice against an average of 12.7 million sq km.

author: Tanaya Singh
abstract: Scientists create nanoparticle fertiliser
article: Ramesh Raliya and Pratim Biswas, two Indian-origin scientists at the Washington University have used nanoparticles in fertilisers to help increase farm output. These fertilisers reportedly will be more eco-friendly than conventional fertilisers and will not add to the strain on existing natural resources. The nanoparticles can also be fine-tuned to suit different conditions, the scientists said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New planet found to affect its star's rotation
article: An international team of astronomers has discovered a giant exoplanet 2,100 light-years away, named HATS-18b, whose gravity might be influencing its parent star's rotation. The planet has an orbital period of 0.84 earth days. "The high planet mass, combined with its short orbital period, implies strong tidal coupling between the planetary orbit and the star", the paper read.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists find body's own defense against Zika
article: Scientists in the US have shown that a protein present inside the human body, interferon-induced protein 3, can reduce the ability of Zika virus to infect human and mouse cells. In some cases, it can also prevent Zika virus from killing the cells. The protein is common in Asia and Micronesia, and relatively rare in people of European decent.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers create ultra-thin planar lens
article: American researchers claim to have created the first ultra-thin planar lens that works in the visible part of the electromagnetic spectrum. It features an array of minuscule waveguides called "metasurface" that bends the passing light, thereby producing the similar effect to that of today's curved lens. Researchers said that it may replace the bulky lenses used in cameras and telescopes.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: High heat tolerant aluminum alloys developed
article: Researchers at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory have developed new aluminum alloys that are easier to work with and are more heat tolerant than the existing products. The team claims that the new alloys, also containing cerium, can boost the production of rare-earth elements. Rare-earths are key elements in alternative energy, electronics and other modern technologies.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Flowers losing fragrance due to global warming'
article: Flowers may be losing their fragrances because of increasing temperatures associated with global warming, Israeli scientists said. Flowers produce scent to attract pollinating insects to their reproductive organs, ensuring the species' continued existence. A scientist demonstrated an approach to bypass the effect by expressing a gene, which boosts scent production regardless of the temperature.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: New algorithm may take 1st ever black hole photo
article: Researchers at MIT have developed Continuous High-resolution Image Reconstruction using Patch (CHIRP), an algorithm which might help take the first-ever image of a black hole. The algorithm filters out galactic dust and noise to stitch data gathered by the Event Horizon Telescope array, which is an array of several radio telescopes placed at various locations around the world.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers develop new Terahertz camera
article: Researchers at the University of Exeter have developed a new Terahertz camera that can observe at a microscopic level and can be used to find defects in microchips. The camera can scan through solid objects at resolutions almost double than usual terahertz imaging technologies. Scientists claim that the discovery will help scan optically opaque objects and help detect skin cancer.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop new RNA-editing technique
article: American researchers have discovered that a commonplace mouth bacterium, Leptotrichia shahii, is capable of editing the genetic information contained in RNA – molecules that carry information stored in DNA to other cell parts. The technique could help break down viruses, that are frequently based around RNA, or kill a cancer cell by denying it the chance to make vital proteins.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA, Blue Origin partner for flight services
article: NASA on Friday announced that it has selected Blue Origin to help transport new technologies to space on its reusable New Shepard rocket. Blue Origin is the sixth company to get selected for the program that offers ways to transport technologies into space. The six companies will compete for the task orders to deliver payload integration and flight services.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New treatment reverses chronic stroke symptoms
article: Injecting modified stem cells directly into the brains of chronic stroke patients proved effective in restoring their​ motor function, according to a trial done by researchers at the Stanford University. Stem cells were injected into the regions known to control motor movements, and which were damaged by stroke. However, the team doesn't know exactly how this treatment helps mobility.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Hydrogen signal detected from 5bn light-yrs away
article: Astronomers in the US have observed the radio emission from hydrogen gas in a galaxy over five billion light years away. This was the first time that hydrogen was detected this far from Earth, researchers claimed and added, "these signals would have begun their journey before our planet even existed, and after five billion years... they've fallen into the telescope".

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: New graphene device ups fuel-efficiency of cars
article: Researchers in England have developed 'ballistic rectifier', a graphene-based electrical nano-device that converts wasted heat from the car's exhaust and engine body into useable electrical current. The high electron mobility of graphene allows it to retain energy faster and more efficiently. The recovered energy can be used to power additional automotive features like AC and power steering.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New 'artificial leaf' uses sunlight to make fuel
article: Harvard University researchers have developed an 'artificial leaf' that mimics the natural photosynthesis process of splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen, and then turns hydrogen into liquid fuel. After splitting water, researchers used recently developed genetically engineered bacteria capable of converting carbon dioxide and hydrogen to fuels with an efficiency 10 times better than plants.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Mars to come closest to the Earth in 11 years
article: Red planet Mars is set to get the nearest to the Earth in 11 years at 3:05 am on Tuesday. The planet will be 75 million kilometres away from the Earth during its nearest approach. A close approach between the Earth and the Mars, known as opposition, occurs in every two years and two months.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Free access to all research articles by '20: EU
article: European Union (EU) officials recently announced that all scientific articles in Europe supported by public and public-private funds must be freely accessible by 2020. The Competitiveness Council, which is a gathering of ministers of science, innovation, trade and industry, came to this conclusion following a two-day meeting in Brussels last week.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Indian-American wins Springer Theses award
article: Arnab De, a US-based Indian-origin scientist has won the "Springer Theses Award for Recognising Outstanding PhD research" for his research on developing transgenic mice for studying a critical tumor-suppressor. De's research, which also won him the 'Young Investigator Award', will feature in the European Molecular Biology Organization (EMBO) Reports, alongside fetching him a €500 award.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Physicists find new way to 'slow light' down
article: Philippines-based physicists have found a way to 'slow down' light and make it take longer to travel between two points. They used light beams that carry orbital angular momentum and showed that the angular momentum can be changed, thereby making it take longer to cover a specified distance. This would let scientists control next-generation of optical computers and telecommunication systems.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team develops 1st quantum thermal transistor
article: France-based researchers have designed the first quantum thermal transistor that can control heat currents, the same way an electric transistor controls electric currents. It consists of three systems that can exist in two states – up spin and down spin. One system controls the heat current that flows to the other two, switching their spins, thereby producing a transistor-like effect.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria reported in US
article: United States health officials on Thursday reported the first case in the nation of a patient with an infection resistant to all known antibiotics. The infection was not controlled by the antibiotic colistin, usually reserved for "nightmare bacteria," said the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The drug-resistant 'superbug' had been first detected in China last year.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Key building blocks of life detected on a comet
article: Amino acid glycine and phosphorus, two of the key building blocks of life, were detected in the atmosphere of the comet 67P, the European Space Agency announced on Saturday. This "supports the idea that amino acids are common around star-forming regions of the universe and were likely delivered to Earth by a comet or other celestial object", a scientist said.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: ISRO to launch record 22 satellites in a mission
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) will be launching a record number of 22 satellites  in a single mission in June. Of the 22 satellites, three are Indian and the rest are all commercial ones, said ISRO Chairman Kiran Kumar on Saturday. Earlier in 2008, the space agency had sent 10 satellites into orbit in a single mission.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Universe may be expanding faster than expected
article: Astronomers using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope measured distances to nineteen galaxies more accurately and found that the Universe is currently expanding 5% to 9% faster than expected. The findings may help understand the "mysterious parts of the universe that make up 95% of everything and don't emit light, such as dark energy, dark matter, and dark radiation", a researcher said.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Sharks shown to possess personalities
article: In what was the world's first study of shark's personality traits, Macquarie University researchers in Australia have observed the presence of individual personality differences in Port Jackson sharks. The study found that sharks have distinct and consistent responses when exposed to unfamiliar conditions. Sharks are one of nearly 200 animal species to have demonstrated individual personality.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Dino-killing meteor wiped out Antarctic life too
article: According to a study by British researchers, the dinosaur-killing meteor that crashed into Earth 66 million years ago, also triggered mass extinction of Antarctic creatures. Until now, it was believed that creatures in Polar regions were not affected by the event. In the six-year long study, researchers identified over 6,000 marine fossils dating back to 69 to 65 million years.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Planet 1,200 light-yrs away may have life: Study
article: Kepler-62f, a planet 1,200 light-years away and 40% larger than Earth, may be habitable, American astronomers reported. NASA had discovered Kepler-62f in 2013 as the outermost of five planets orbiting a star smaller and cooler than the sun. "We found there are multiple atmospheric compositions that allow it to be warm enough to have surface liquid water", a researcher said.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: New tech captures brain's activity in a snapshot
article: Rockefeller University researchers have developed a technique that captures a detailed snapshot of the activities in a brain. Tested successfully on the brain of a mouse, the method takes a picture of all the active neurons in the brain at a specific time. Researchers said that the technique can help in tracking any biological change or spread of a drug.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: China to launch world's 1st quantum satellite
article: According to a scientist at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, China will launch the world's first quantum communication satellite in July, aimed at improving the security of data transmission. The satellite, which took five years to develop, will use quantum photons, which cannot be separated or duplicated, making the communication immune to wiretapping or interceptions.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Bacteria that converts CO2 to fuel developed
article: Harvard University researchers have developed a genetically engineered bacteria that is capable of consuming carbon dioxide (CO2) and hydrogen, and excreting several alcohol fuels and biomass. The bacteria is claimed to produce adenosine triphosphate which is converted to combustible biomass at an efficiency of 10.6%. Notably, plants' efficiency of producing biomass from sunlight and CO2 is 1%.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Milky Way has mass of 700 billion Suns: Study
article: A study by Canada-based researchers revealed that the mass of the Milky Way galaxy, which spans roughly 1,00,000 light years across, is equivalent to nearly 700 billion times that of the Sun. The team used the velocities and positions of star clusters orbiting the Milky Way galaxy to study the mass of the galaxy and its dark matter components.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA finds 39 unreported air pollution sources
article: Scientists at NASA have located 39 unreported man-made sources of sulfur dioxide emissions, a known health hazard and contributor to acid rain. The sources include coal-burning power plants, smelters, oil and gas operations found in the Middle East, Mexico and parts of Russia. Altogether, the unreported man-made sources account for around 12% of all human-made emissions of sulfur dioxide.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: SpaceX completes 3rd successful landing at sea
article: Elon Musk-owned SpaceX, for the third consecutive time, successfully landed its Falcon 9 rocket on a drone ship at sea after it was launched on Saturday carrying the 'THAICOM 8' satellite. The satellite, which was put into an elliptical orbit 22,000 miles above sea level, is a commercial communications satellite intended to serve parts of India, Africa and South-East Asia.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New test predicts if coma patients will wake up
article: According to a new research, scientists in the US and Denmark found that the amount of glucose consumed by the brain can directly predict whether a coma patient will recover awareness within a year. The team studied 131 brain-injured patients using a well-known imaging technique, known as FDG-PET, and accurately predicted that 94% of patients would regain consciousness.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Injecting fat treats arthritis, surgeons claim
article: According to a claim by surgeons, injecting one's own fat into painful joints can treat osteoarthritis – a type of arthritis that occurs when flexible tissue at the ends of bones wears down. In a trial carried out on 100 patients with moderate to severe knee osteoarthritis, fat's lubrication was used to improve function and reduce pain and stiffness.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: King Tut's dagger made from a meteorite: Study
article: Italian and Egyptian researchers have discovered that a dagger found in the tomb of Egyptian king Tutankhamun was made of the same material as a meteorite found in an Egyptian region. Discovered nearly 100 years ago, the dagger's chemical composition, as observed by X-ray scanning, was found to contain high levels of nickel and cobalt matching that of the meteorite.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Astronomers observe 'Einstein Ring' phenomenon
article: Astronomers have observed the 'Einstein Ring', a rare phenomenon in which two galaxies are positioned such that light from the farther galaxy bends around the nearer one forming a circular ring around it. The observed galaxies lie 10,000 and 6,000 million light-years away from the Earth, creating a blue colored ring around the red colored core of the nearer galaxy.

author: Christine Garcia
abstract: India's PM2.5 pollution up 54% during 1990-2013
article: According to SocialCops' analysis of World Bank data, average annual exposure to PM2.5 pollution in India increased by 54.3% from 1990 to 2013. For the same period, PM2.5 pollution increased by 28.8% in East Asia and Pacific, 30.5% in Latin America, and 10% in the Middle East and Africa. Europe and Central Asia's PM2.5 pollution levels decreased by 28%.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: First implant to treat opioid addiction approved
article: US federal agency Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of Probuphine – the first implantable treatment for opioid addiction. Opioid addiction results in withdrawal syndrome once the addict stops taking the drug. The treatment, which involves implanting small rods under the skin in the upper arm, regularly releases buprenorphine, a drug used to combat opioid addiction.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: 'Majority of coral in Great Barrier Reef dead'
article: Mass bleaching has left around 35% of the coral in​ the central and northern sections of the Great Barrier Reef off the Australian coast dead or dying, according to researchers​. This marks the worst mass bleaching event to hit the site. Aerial surveys conducted earlier had found that 93% of the Great Barrier Reef has been affected by bleaching.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Bees' hairs can detect flowers' electric fields
article: A study conducted at the University of Bristol has found that the small vibrating hairs of a bee help it detect and sense electric signals transmitted by flowers. Using a laser to measure vibrations, researchers found that both the bees' antenna and hairs deflect in response to an electric field, which signals the bee's nervous system about the flower's proximity.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Ex-Microsoft exec accuses NASA of flawed data
article: Ex-Microsoft executive Nathan Myhrvold has accused NASA of making fundamental mistakes in their analysis of the size of over 157,000 observed asteroids. The claim includes mistakes like ignoring error margins while extrapolating from small sample to an entire population. He said that he found 30% error in asteroids diameter calculations and added that the size errors may rise to 300%.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team finds structure of Zika virus helicase
article: Researchers from Tianjin University in China have identified the structure of the Zika virus helicase. The Zika virus helicase is a motor enzyme which is used in an essential step in viral multiplication. This advancement may help target the Zika virus helicase, which in turn might make it possible to stop the viral replication and prevent the disease.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Solar storms may have seeded life on Earth: NASA
article: According to a study by NASA, powerful storms in the early stages of Sun may have been crucial in seeding life on Earth. The study suggested that such violent solar flares smashed nitrogen molecules in the Earth's atmosphere generating the planet-warming greenhouse gas nitrous oxide, along with hydrogen cyanide, that creates amino acids – the building blocks of proteins.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers develop more efficient solar cell
article: MIT researchers have developed a solar cell capable of efficiently increasing the amount of power generated by solar panels. The device, which the team claims could surpass the theoretical maximum solar cell efficiency (around 32%), uses carbon nanotubes to first convert sunlight into thermal energy. The thermal energy is re-emitted as light with optimum wavelength for the cell to absorb.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New catalyst discovery can increase battery life
article: A team of international scientists have found new catalyst materials that could help develop lithium-air batteries. These batteries can last five times longer than the lithium-ion batteries – currently used in mobile phones. Instead of storing an oxidizer internally like lithium-ion batteries, the lithium-air batteries function by taking in oxygen from the air to initiate the chemical reactions.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New system turns vehicles exhaust into power
article: Sweden-based researchers have developed a system that can convert a vehicle's exhaust heat into power, using a process called thermoelectric generation (TEG). TEG works on the principle of thermoelectric effect, which is the direct conversion of temperature differences to electric voltage. The team claimed that the system can also help cut down on fuel consumption and carbon emissions.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Self-healing material for electronics created
article: Researchers at the Pennsylvania State University have developed boron nitrate nanosheets, a self-healing, flexible material that can be used inside electronics even after multiple breaks. The material can completely heal itself with almost no external influence, while retaining its electronic and thermal properties. It remains unaffected by moisture and can be used in high humidity conditions.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Russian firm announces plans for space taxi
article: Russian rocket company, Energia has announced that it's working on a space taxi, called Ryvok, that will shuttle crews from the ISS to the moon, as reported by Russia Today. Energia said that the spacecraft, which will be permanently based on the ISS, is expected to be developed by 2021, with the first launch anticipated to take place in 2023.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New battery that can work at low temperatures
article: Chemists from Hiroshima University in Japan has developed a technique to synthesize organic rechargeable batteries that are non-metallic and can continue to function at below-freezing temperatures. Such type of batteries have the potential to be cheaper, safer, longer-lasting and can recharge faster than current metal-based batteries, as they carry energy chemically rather than physically.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Algae produces valuable chemicals using sunlight
article: Researchers from the University of Copenhagen in Denmark have genetically modified microalgae, which can harness sunlight to turn into various valuable chemicals like bioplastics and fragrance compounds. The team said that they directed energy from algae's photosynthetic system to its genetically modified parts, which then created complex and valuable chemicals at a faster rate without much input.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Breads contain cancer-causing compounds: Study
article: According to a Centre for Science and Environment study, 84% of bread and bakery samples collected from Delhi contained traces of cancer-causing compounds – potassium bromate and potassium iodate. The highest level was found in sandwich bread, followed by pav, bun and white bread, the report said. Notably, several countries including Australia, Canada and China have banned​ its use.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New discovery may be one of the oldest animals
article: Researchers have discovered a 3.5-metre-long sponge near Hawaii – making it the largest ever sponge – which is believed to be among the oldest living animals. While the exact age is unknown, "some massive species found in shallow waters are estimated to live for more than 2,300 years", researchers said and guessed the discovery's age to be around 1,000 years.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Gloves that levitate objects developed
article: Researchers at the University of Bristol have developed, 'GauntLev', a glove that can levitate objects using acoustic traps. It enables users to move objects over their palm or between their fingers in a pinching position. The levitation was achieved by reflecting opposing sound waves to create a standing wave, which acts as a physical acoustic trap for small objects.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Guest access to space observatory from Oct: ISRO
article: Access for guest observers to Astrosat, the country's first dedicated multi-wavelength space observatory, will be open from October, Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) recently said. ISRO, in collaboration with the Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics, Pune, has set up an Astrosat Support Cell to facilitate the proposal making process and the use of Astrosat data.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Mars still recovering from ice age: Study
article: A study published in Science magazine confirmed that Mars has had several ice age cycles in the past and is still recovering from one that ended 400,000 years ago. Using NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, researchers analyzed radar images of the planet's polar ice caps alongside erosion and wind effects which helped understand the ice's advancement and recession over the years.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method to heal solar cells using light
article: According to an MIT study, applying intense illumination to thin films created with organic-inorganic metal 'halide perovskites' may remove tiny defects. The metal can be used in many applications including solar cells, but some limitations hamper its efficiency and consistency. The repair can increase the compound's efficiency which could improve its light capture and light emission capabilities.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Solar Impulse plane lands in Ohio
article: Solar Impulse 2, the solar-powered plane on a record-breaking trip around the world without consuming fuel, reached Dayton, Ohio in the US on Saturday. It reached Ohio after a 16 hours and 34 minutes flight from Tulsa, Oklahoma. This was the 12th leg of its 16-leg trip around the globe which started from Abu Dhabi, UAE on March 9, 2015.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: MIT develops system that can detect explosives
article: MIT researchers have developed a terahertz spectroscopy-based system that can help detect explosive materials in very short time. Terahertz spectroscopy is a system that uses electromagnetic fields to detect the properties of matter. The new system uses a computer chip-sized semiconductor laser that beams terahertz radiation to extract the material's spectroscopic signature in 100 microseconds.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Engineers develop edible supercapacitors
article: Arizona State University engineers have developed edible supercapacitors, which they claim, can power a camera from inside the body for medical applications. The supercapacitors were made from foods including cheese, seaweed, egg white, gold leaf, gatorade, charcoal, gelatin and barbecue sauce. Supercapacitors are high-capacity electrical components that can store electrical energy temporarily.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Magnetic method that speeds up stroke treatment
article: English researchers have developed a magnetic diffusion process for faster treatment of stroke victims. Its functioning comprises injecting microscopic magnetic beads into stroke victims' blood, which by the help of an external fast-rotating magnet, helps 'push' life-saving medications through blood vessels by breaking down clots. The process is capable of speeding up​ drug propulsion by 30 times.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New clock measures the second more accurately
article: German researchers claimed to have found a way to make the most accurate clock ever. The new clock 'ticks' almost 50,000 times more per second than the traditional caesium-based atomic clock, thereby increasing the precision significantly. Researchers claimed that if the clock had started at the Big Bang around 14 billion years ago, it would have lost just 100 seconds.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Graphene increases rubber's strength, elasticity
article: According to a study by two Manchester-based researchers, adding a small amount of graphene, the world's strongest and thinnest material, to rubber can increase its elasticity and strength by up to 50%. To achieve this, researchers combined 0.1% of a form of graphene called graphene oxide with rubber, both of which were in a form that is stable in water.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Immune cells may reverse chemo-resistance: Study
article: A study by University of Michigan researchers revealed that immune cells can help in reversing the chemotherapy resistance in ovarian cancer. Ovarian cancer is typically treated with cisplatin, a platinum-based chemotherapy. Researchers found that immune T cells, part of the immune system, overrule the function of fibroblasts – cells that block platinum and cisplatin from killing tumor cells.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: American wins $1.1m prize for directed evolution
article: American biochemist Frances Arnold was awarded the 2016 Millennium Technology Prize worth over $1.1 million for pioneering "directed evolution". Directed evolution is a method of rewriting DNA that mimics the natural evolution process to achieve goals like developing green fuels and improving medicines. The prize is awarded biennially and Arnold is the first female winner in its 12-year history.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: 3,800-year-old mummy discovered in Egypt
article: A 3,800-year-old mummy of Lady Sattjeni has been discovered at a necropolis in southern Egypt. Unearthed from the tomb in the necropolis of Qubbet el-Hawa, the mummy belongs to a key woman figure in the Middle Kingdom. The mummy was found in an extremely good condition, wrapped in linen and deposited inside two wooden coffins.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New device that can harness solar, wind energy
article: In a first, scientists in the US and China have developed a new device that can harvest solar and wind energy at the same time. For this, scientists integrated a solar cell and a nanogenerator that can generate electricity using the triboelectric effect. Triboelectric effect occurs when materials become electrically charged after coming into frictional contact with another different material.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Instructions for 1st moon landing sold at $175k
article: A three-page document with step-by-step computer procedures, which the American astronauts aboard the Apollo 11 lunar module followed to make the first-ever landing by humans on the moon in 1969, was auctioned for $175,000. Dallas-based auction house Heritage Auctions said that the document was originally from astronaut Buzz Aldrin's personal collection, who was the pilot of the lunar module.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Sheet that can remove viruses from water created
article: Sweden-based scientists have created a paper sheet, mille-feuille filter, that can filter-out viruses from water. It is made of cellulose nanofibers and has a layered internal architecture resembling that of mille-feuille, a French puff pastry. "Our goal is to develop a filter paper that can remove even the toughest viruses from water as easily as brewing coffee", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New process may eliminate need of insulin shots
article: Researchers from the University of Aberdeen and a London-based not-for-profit organisation have developed a new technique that can eliminate the need of taking insulin shots for Type 1 diabetes. In the new process, the researchers transplanted lab-grown islets, manufactured by reprogramming donated pancreatic tissues. Islets are organoids that can produce multiple hormones including insulin.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Liquid wire' inspired by spider silk developed
article: Researchers from the University of Oxford and University of Paris VI, inspired by spider silk, have developed a new type of composite wire, which they are calling 'liquid wire'. The spider silk property which was imitated was that it never sags after snapping back from the stretched state. This advancement can help in engineering, medicine and materials, a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Mirror image of DNA-copying protein created
article: Scientists in Beijing have created a mirror-image version of a protein responsible for two critical functions – copying DNA and transcribing it into RNA. The work is a "small step" along the way to making mirror-image life form, a researcher said. In principle, molecules' mirror versions should work the same way as normal ones, while being resistant to viral attacks.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Genes involved in controlling nose shapes found
article: Scientists at the University College London have discovered four genes that are involved in controlling the shape of human nose. The team believes that this will offer insights into humans' evolutionary past. The study also revealed that the jut of the chin is influenced by EDAR gene, which is also known to influence earlobe size, beard thickness and hair type.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team makes transparent wood stronger than glass
article: A team of researchers from the University of Maryland has made a transparent wood, which they claim is stronger than glass. To manufacture the wood, the team removed lignin – which gives wood its color – from the wood and coated it with an epoxy, a class of reactive prepolymers, to make it stronger than glass.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA shows crew's life at the ISS via Snapchat
article: Celebrating the International Space Station's (ISS) 100,000th orbit around the Earth, NASA on Monday took to Snapchat to show its crew's daily life through Live Stories titled 'Day in Space'. Expedition 47 Commander Tim Kopra created short videos including him rolling around in midair and a view of the Earth. The ISS was launched on November 20, 1998.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: World’s first Zika virus clone developed
article: In a first, US-based researchers have genetically engineered a clone of the Zika virus strain, an advance that may aid the development of vaccine and therapies against the infection. Furthermore, they also engineered a luciferase reporter Zika virus which can be used to track the infection in mosquitoes. Notably, Luciferase is the chemical that causes the signature glow in fireflies.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Evidence of 2nd oldest asteroid crash found
article: Australia-based scientists have uncovered evidence of an asteroid that struck the Earth around 3.46 billion years ago, making it the second oldest known asteroid to hit the planet. The team explained that the event's impact was the largest the human race have ever experienced. Measuring around 20-30 km across, it was one of the largest to have hit the Earth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Firm plans to send people into space in balloon
article: Beijing-based JHY Space Technology (Space Vision) plans to send people into space using a high-tech balloon and return back to earth using a parachute. The company, which had released the country's first-ever space parachuting suit, will test related high-tech equipments in a few months. According to the founder Jiang Fang, the space parachuting trip will cost around $77,000.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Images of galaxy 13 bn light years away captured
article: Astronomers at the University of California have captured images of a galaxy almost 13 billion years away, reportedly one of the most distant to have been observed. Scientists claim that the images could help understand how the early universe transitioned from black void to the currently starlight-illuminated universe. The images have been composed by offsetting the gravitational lensing effect.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Physicists discover new form of light
article: Ireland-based physicists have discovered a new form of light whose angular momentum is exactly half of Planck's constant – a physical constant equivalent to 6.626 times 10 raised to -34. Until now, the angular momentum of a beam of light was found to be a multiple of Planck's constant. The discovery could help in secure optical communications, a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New device can detect bacteria in water faster
article: Researchers from York University in Toronto have developed a device that can help detect the deadly E. coli bacteria in water in a few hours, instead of the few days taken by standard procedures. The results of the water test, estimated to cost around ₹155 per test, can also be broadcasted using a mobile app developed by the team.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New app that can determine freshness of beer
article: Chemists at the Complutense University of Madrid have created a furfural-sensing polymer disk and an app that can determine whether a beer has a fresh or "stale" flavor. Furfural, a chemical related to beer's taste and smell, changes chemically and imparts a stale or cardboard-like flavor as the beer ages, causing the sensors to change its colour.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Genetically modified organisms are safe: Report
article: According to a National Academy of Sciences report on Tuesday, genetically modified organisms are safe for humans and the environment. For the research, the committee reviewed over 900 reports, interviewed 80 experts and delved through over 700 comments from the public. It has created a dedicated website where visitors can explore the source data that was used for its study

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Trees sleep, rest branches during night: Study
article: A study by researchers from Austria, Hungary and Finland found that mature birch trees relax and droop down around four inches during the night. The experiment, conducted using laser scanners in two different locations, found the branches to rise back up during the day. Scientists believe that this may be because of decrease in cells' internal pressure, influenced by photosynthesis.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Solar System may be habitable after Earth's end
article: According to models developed by astronomers at Carl Sagan Institute, in a few billion years from now, after Earth's destruction caused by the Sun's expansion, bodies in outer Solar System may become habitable. The models depicted that Europa and Enceladus, the moons orbiting Jupiter and Saturn, which are currently frozen, will melt into ocean moons, offering a possibility of life.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Fossils of oldest multicellular organisms found
article: Chinese researchers claimed to have discovered fossils of 1.56-billion-year-old multicellular organisms, pushing back the date of multicellular life on Earth by almost a billion years. This means that the "oxygen levels were sufficiently high to allow for such large organisms to subsist", a scientist said. However, some other scientists were unconvinced about the organisms being multicellular.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: 1,600-year-old treasure discovered in shipwreck
article: Archaeologists from the Israel Antiquities Authority on Monday recovered 1,600-year-old statues, coins and other artefacts from the cargo of a shipwreck at the ancient Roman port of Caesarea. This is the largest discovery of marine artefacts in the past thirty years. While some of the objects date to the fourth century, others belong to the first and second centuries

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Engineers set solar cell efficiency world record
article: Australian engineers have developed a photovoltaic cell that has successfully achieved the sunlight-to-electricity conversion efficiency of 34.5% without any concentrators like mirrors, thereby setting a new world record. The team used a 28 square centimeter module embedded in a prism for extracting the maximum possible energy from sunlight. The previous best conversion efficiency was 24%.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Picture of Milky Way taken from ISS released
article: NASA has released a picture of the Milky Way galaxy captured from the International Space Station (ISS) on August 9, 2015, while passing over the Kiribati – an island nation in the central Pacific Ocean. "Scientists were able to match the star field in the photo to charts describing which stars should have been visible at that moment", NASA wrote.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Method produces hydrogen peroxide from seawater
article: Japanese researchers have used sunlight to efficiently turn seawater into hydrogen peroxide, which can be used in fuel cells to generate electricity. They developed a photoelectrochemical cell that absorbed photons and used the energy to initiate the reactions, resulting in 0.28% efficiency. The team found the negatively charged chlorine to be responsible for enhancing photocatalytic activity.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Evidence of ancient tsunamis on Mars found
article: A study by a team of international scientists revealed that two large meteorites crashed into Mars approximately 3.4 billion years ago, triggering two huge tsunamis across the planet. "Cold, salty waters may offer a refuge for life in extreme environments... If life existed on Mars, these icy tsunami lobes are very good candidates to search for biosignature," a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: AI improves Bose-Einstein condensate experiment
article: Australian researchers have developed an Artificial Intelligence (AI) that has performed the experiment to create a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) – 2001 Nobel Prize-winning discovery. A BEC is a state of matter of a dilute gas of photon-like particles cooled to temperatures around –273.15ºC. They found that the condensates can be created faster, under more conditions and in greater quantities.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team identifies new species of horned dinosaurs
article: An international team of paleontologists has identified Machairoceratops, a 77-million-year-old species of horned dinosaurs that diversified in Asia and North America during the final stages of the age of dinosaurs. Estimated to have been 6-8 meters long and weighed around 1-2 tons, the identified species was herbivorous and was known for its parrot-like beaks, facial horns and neck shields.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New glasses for people with severe vision loss
article: Researchers from Harvard Medical School have designed new eyeglasses using high-power prisms to expand the visual fields of patients with hemianopia — a condition in which the visual fields get cut by half. Embedding the prisms in a spectacle lens that has a prismatic power in the opposite direction helped the team to achieve 36° expansion of the visual field.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Google's new app turns phone into a research lab
article: Google on Friday launched 'Science Journal', a new app that turns smartphones into a research lab by using sensors to measure and record data in real time, including movement, light and sound. It also graphs the data collected and allows users to compare the results of their experiments. Users can also add notes and photos while recording the data.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Skin-like material made to hide wrinkles, wounds
article: Researchers from US-based Olivo Labs have created a silicon-based strong, stretchy and adherent material to help users hide their wrinkles, wounds and combat skin diseases. Claimed to be safe, the skin is formed by applying two different creams one after the other. The combination forms an invisible polymer layer over the skin and also provides a breathable layer on top.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: NASA releases high-resolution map of Mercury
article: NASA has released the world's first high-resolution topographic map of the planet Mercury. The map was constructed using images captured by NASA's Mercury Surface, Space Environment, Geochemistry, and Ranging (MESSENGER) spacecraft. The spacecraft orbited the planet for over four years in which it completed 4,104 revolutions, capturing over 100,000 images as a part of the mission.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Clock accurate to 270 quintillionths of a second
article: UCLA researchers have created a new optical clock, measuring one cubic centimeter, that can track time accurately to 270 quintillionths of second – 270 times 10 to the negative 18th power. "If incorporated with other technologies into infrared telescope observatories, this device can enable the detection of Earth-like planets and celestial objects 100 times smaller than that", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New heat engine that maximizes power, efficiency
article: In a new study, American researchers have designed a cyclic heat engine that can simultaneously attain its maximum power and efficiency. In steady state heat engines, their power and efficiency cannot be maximized simultaneously. For this, researchers modeled the cyclic heat engine as a "geometric heat engine", where the work and heat are interpreted geometrically as areas in state space.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: WHO proposes faster test for superbug form of TB
article: World Health Organisation on Thursday proposed a faster and cheaper test for superbug or drug-resistant forms of Tuberculosis. The proposed test identifies genetic mutations in TB strains and provides results within 48 hours when compared to 3 months or longer currently required. The proposed treatment can be completed within 9-12 months and costs 'significantly less' at under $1,000 per patient.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Tiny space debris hits ISS, cracks window
article: British astronaut Tim Peake, aboard the International Space Station, has shared an image of a cracked window hit by space debris. According to the European Space Agency, the debris was "possibly a paint flake or small metal fragment no bigger than a few thousandths of a millimeter." Notably, anything larger than 10 cm could "shatter a satellite or spacecraft into pieces".

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 3 millionth image taken aboard the ISS
article: Astronauts have taken the 3 millionth image aboard the International Space Station (ISS). The photo consists of the Expedition 47 crew including Timothy Peake, Timothy Kopra, Yuri Malenchenko, Oleg Skripochka, Alexey Ovchinin and Jeff Williams. Notably, astronauts have been taking photographs of the Earth and inside activities from the ISS for more than 15 years now.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: First penis transplant performed in the US
article: Thomas Manning from Massachusetts has become the first person in the US to receive a penis transplant. The 15-hour operation of the 64-year-old man who lost his penis to cancer, was performed by a team of doctors from the Massachusetts General Hospital. Globally, two other penis transplants have been reported out of which only one was successful in South Africa.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: UR Rao to be the 1st Indian in IAF Hall of Fame
article: Former ISRO Chairman UR Rao will become the first Indian to be inducted into the 'International Astronautical Federation (IAF) Hall of Fame'. He will receive the 'IAF Hall of Fame' Award during the 67th International Astronautical Congress in September 2016. Rao is being honoured for his outstanding contribution to the progress of astronautics within the framework of the IAF activities.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists identify 12 mn-year-old dog species
article: A team of University of Pennsylvania researchers has identified a new species of an ancient, 'bone-crushing' dog, named Cynarctus wangi, that roamed North America approximately 12 million years ago. "It is quite rare we find fossils from land animals in this region during this time, but each one provides important information for what life was like then", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA records magnetic explosions above Earth
article: In a first, a fleet of NASA's four spacecrafts, dubbed Magnetospheric Multiscale mission, has recorded magnetic explosions above the Earth. Recent revelations of the recordings, taken in October 2015, showed that when two magnetic fields collide, electrons shoot out from the point of impact in straight lines and then slowly begin to curve in response to the new magnetic fields.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: White House launches project to study microbes
article: The White House has launched the National Microbiome Initiative – a new initiative aimed at studying microbial communities that could aid in the development of useful applications in several areas. For the project, the government will invest over $121 million in federal money, while another $400 million will come from non-government organizations, including the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Private meeting held over synthetic human genes
article: About 150 scientists, lawyers and entrepreneurs held a private meeting at Harvard Medical School on Tuesday to discuss a future project to improve techniques for synthesizing human DNA from chemicals. George Church, an organizer of the meeting's project said that the project aims to improve techniques to synthesize long strands of DNA, which could be applied to various organisms.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Discovery of 1,284 new planets announced
article: NASA added 1,284 new planets to the known galaxy on Tuesday, more than doubling the number of confirmed planets orbiting alien stars, in what it said was the biggest single announcement of new exoplanets. Of those, nine are in the "Goldilocks Zone" around their parent stars, meaning liquid water could exist and could potentially be habitable, the researchers​ added.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 1st ever mitochondria-less eukaryote discovered
article: A team led by a University of British Columbia researcher has discovered the first ever eukaryote – complex organisms that contain genetic material – without a mitochondria. The microorganism was originally recovered from a pet chinchilla. Mitochondria is a cell organelle that helps to produce the energy currency of the cell, called ATP, through respiration and regulate cellular metabolism.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: China launches remote sensing satellite
article: China on Sunday successfully launched a remote sensing satellite to carry out land surveys and disaster relief. Named Yaogan-30, the satellite was launched from Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre in northwestern China’s Gobi Desert by a Long March-2D rocket. It will be used for experiments, land surveys, crop yield estimates and disaster relief, state-run Xinhua news agency reported.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Stable, synchronized 4-planet system discovered
article: According to a study by US-based researchers, there is a highly stable and synchronized system of four planets – Kepler-223 planetary system. The ratio of the orbital periods of the members of this system is very precise (3:4, 4:6 and 6:8). "The precisely timed orbits of these planets places strong constraints on how they could have formed", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Astronomers create 3D map of 3000 galaxies
article: Astronomers have created a 3D map of 3000 galaxies 13 billion light-years away from the Earth and found Albert Einstein's general theory of relativity to still be valid. "We tested the theory of general relativity further than anyone else ever has", a researcher said pointing to the fact that galaxies over 10 billion light years away have never been studied.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronomers observe 450-year-old supernova
article: A group of astronomers has compiled data from the Chandra X-ray observatory to show that a supernova explosion, first lit up in 1572, continues to grow till date. Called Tycho's supernova, the 450-year-old phenomenon is located 10,000 light-years away from the Earth. It was visible to the naked eye in 1572 and was observed by astronomer Tycho Brahe.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Scientists use stars to date 2,500 year-old poem
article: Scientists from the University of Texas have used advanced astronomical software to accurately date poet Sappho's "Midnight Poem," which describes the night sky over Greece more than 2,500 years ago. Using the references in Sappho's poem, scientists recreated the night sky of the Greek isle on Lesbos from 570 BC to determine the season in which the poem was written.

author: Shubhodeep Datta
abstract: NASA finds seasonal patterns in Mars atmosphere
article: NASA's Curiosity Mars Rover recorded distinct seasonal patterns through two full cycles of Martian seasons, scientists have claimed. Mars atmosphere is clear in winters, dustier in spring and summers, and windy in autumn, scientists added. The Curiosity rover has measured relative humidity up to 70% during winter nights which can prompt researchers to search for formation of frost on ground.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists find 4.5-bn-year-old pieces of Earth
article: According to a study published in the journal Science, researchers have discovered 4.5 billion-year-old pieces of Earth within the volcanoes in Canada's Baffin Island and in a region near Solomon Islands. These materials were created within the first 50 million years of the Earth's creation, researchers added. The discovery could help them understand the processes that shaped the planet's birth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team measures van der Waals forces between atoms
article: In a first, a team of researchers from Switzerland have successfully measured the van der Waals forces between single atoms, making it the smallest forces ever detected between individual atoms. van der Waals forces, which are significantly weaker than chemical bonds, are caused by fluctuating electric fields around atoms and molecules that generate small repulsive or attractive forces.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Ebola can persist 9 months after recovery: Study
article: According to a study by an international team of researchers, the Ebola virus can persist in the semen of survivors for up to nine months after their recovery. To conduct the study, 450 patients, both men and women, were monitored for a year in Guinea. Further, specimens of their body fluids were taken to detect the presence of the virus.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: IBM creates chemical to fight viral infections
article: IBM Research has created a chemical "macromolecule" that could help fight several viral diseases including Ebola, Zika, dengue and herpes. The chemical has the ability to fight off the viruses regardless of any mutations they naturally make over time. It was designed to combat viruses in three ways – protecting healthy cells, stopping virus's replication and boosting the immune system.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New bio-glass material that can repair cartilage
article: Scientists in England and Italy have collaborated to create a flexible bio-glass material that can help repair damaged cartilage by mimicking the load bearing and shock-absorbing qualities of real cartilage. The material can be made in a biodegradable ink form, allowing the researchers to 3D print it into structures to be inserted into the damaged part of the cartilage tissue.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Discoverer of Neptune's rings dies aged 73
article: French astrophysicist Andre Brahic, one of the discoverers of Neptune's rings, died in Paris on Sunday at the age of 73, his publisher Odile Jacob said. Brahic, along with American astronomer William Hubbard, first spotted the rings in 1984, naming them Equality, Fraternity and Liberty. Further, a minor planet numbered 3488 was named 'Brahic' in tribute to his work.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Gravitational waves discovery team awarded $3 mn
article: The team of nearly 1,000 scientists and engineers responsible for the discovery of gravitational waves was awarded a $3 million prize by Silicon Valley entrepreneurs for the breakthrough. In February, the team, including the three founders of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) group, announced the discovery, which was first predicted by Albert Einstein a century ago.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New species of beetle named after Chewbacca
article: Scientists Matthew H Van Dam, Raymond Laufa and Alexander Riedel have named a new species of beetle after the Star Wars character Chewbacca. The creature, named Trigonopterus Chewbacca, is 3.34 mm long and was found in Papua New Guinea. Scientists claimed that it had dense scales on the legs and the head, which reminded them of Chewbacca's dense fur.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA detects atomic oxygen in martian atmosphere
article: NASA's Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy has detected atomic oxygen in the atmosphere of Mars for the first time since the last observation 40 years ago. However, the amount of oxygen detected was only about half of what was expected. Atomic oxygen has a significant impact on the planet’s atmosphere as it affects how other gases escape Mars.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Cellular protein process observed for 1st time
article: Scientists for the first time have observed the cellular process of 'Translation', which is critical to cell's protein formation process. The discovery will help scientists learn the regulation of the protein generation process and gain insights into diseases that occur when translation is faulty, particularly in cases of neurological and cancerous protein malfunctions.

author: Aman Raj
abstract: Video explains India's NAVIC project in 90 secs
article: Office Chai in partnership with Inshorts, has released a 90-second video explaining India's recently launched NAVIC project. The video illustrates the nomenclature of the NAVIC project and explains how better location data will impact India's fishermen, armed forces, and emergency response systems. With this launch, India joined an elite league of nations to have developed their own GPS system.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA makes 56 patents free for commercial use
article: NASA on Monday made 56 of its formerly-patented technologies including advanced manufacturing processes, sensors, propulsion methods, rocket nozzles, aircraft wing designs and improved rocket safety, freely available for commercial use. It also released a searchable database of its expired patents. NASA said it is encouraging entrepreneurs to explore new ways to commercialise these technologies.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists turn human skin cells into sperm
article: Scientists at the Valencian Infertility Institute in Spain claimed to have created human sperm from skin cells using a cocktail of genes. The team was inspired by a Nobel Prize-winning work of two Japanese researchers who had discovered that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent cells – which can give rise to several other types of cells.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Astronomers create artificial star using lasers
article: Chilean astronomers claim to have created the most powerful artificial star by shooting four 11.8-inch lasers, dubbed as 'Four Laser Guide Star Facility', into earth's atmosphere, causing sodium atoms to glow. "The artificial stars allow the adaptive optics systems to compensate for the blurring caused by the Earth’s atmosphere and so that the telescope can create sharp images", team said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists find two black holes emitting winds
article: According to a research published in the journal Nature, scientists from the University of Cambridge have discovered that two black holes in nearby galaxies are emitting winds at a quarter of the speed of light for the first time. The scientists added that the black holes are consuming their companion stars at rates much faster than currently established limits.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: New wasp species named after Brad Pitt
article: A new species of wasp discovered in South Africa by an international research team has been named after the actor Brad Pitt. Dr. Buntika A Butcher from Thailand named the wasp 'Conobregma bradpitti' after recalling her long hours of studying in her laboratory under the poster of her favourite actor. The team also discovered another new wasp species from India.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Google Doodle marks Sigmund Freud's 160th b'day
article: Google Doodle marked the 160th birthday of Austrian neurologist and the founder of psychoanalysis, Sigmund Freud. Freud entered the University of Vienna in 1873 at an age of 17 and studied medicine there. Freud's major work includes 'The Interpretation of Dreams' wherein he analysed dreams in terms of unconscious desires and experiences.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: World's longest insect discovered in China
article: A new species of stick insect of the genus Phryganistria measuring 62.4 centimetres, which was discovered in southern China in 2014, was recently declared as the World's longest insect. The creature surpassed the previous record holder, another stick insect discovered in 2008, by nearly six centimetres. Zhao Li, who had discovered the species, has named it Phryganistria chinensis Zhao.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Mercury to transit across the Sun today
article: Mercury will transit in between the Earth and Sun today, in what is described as a rare celestial event. The event, which occurs approximately 13 times every century, will be visible from all parts of India starting from around 4:40 pm. Dwarka in Gujarat will experience the longest transit of about 2 hours and 43 minutes.

author: Twishy Shahi
abstract: Robot surgeon outperforms human doctors
article: A robotic surgical system known as The Smart Tissue Autonomous Robot (STAR) outperformed humans and robot-assisted human operators in a soft-tissue procedure on Wednesday. The robot used advanced computer vision tech that worked with fluorescent markers and 3D cameras to get a detailed view of the surgical site. The robot was reportedly superior to humans on a number of metrics.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Earth may be home to 1 trillion species: Study
article: According to a study by Indiana University researchers, earth could be home to nearly one trillion species with only one-thousandth of one percent identified till now. The team combined microbial, plant and animal community datasets from the government, academic and citizen science sources that resulted in the largest compilation of its kind, representing over 5.6 million species across the globe.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: UK conducts 1st successful HIV organs transplant
article: Organs from deceased HIV-positive patients were used in life-saving transplant operations in the UK for the first time. The transplants happened within the last five years but were recently made public. Notably, the first HIV-positive kidney transplant was carried out in South Africa in 2008, while the US reported its first HIV-positive liver and kidney transplants earlier in the year.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: 71 mn-yr-old fossils found in Antarctica
article: Scientists have found a trove of 71 million-year-old fossils in Antarctica. The fossils are mostly carcasses of dinosaurs, prehistoric marine reptiles and birds, including early ducks that lived at the end of the Cretaceous period (145–66 million years ago). Scientists claim the diversity of the find will help them create a detailed account of life in Antarctica in the era.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Luxembourg to launch asteroid-mining spacecraft
article: 'Prospector-X', an experimental resource-mining spacecraft, designed as a collaboration between the government of Luxembourg and California-based Deep Space Industries, will soon be launched into the Earth's orbit to test the conglomerate's asteroid-mining technologies. If the spacecraft's mission proves successful, its successors will be sent to mine near-Earth asteroids for gold and platinum.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New needleless blood glucose monitoring device
article: Researchers from the Cardiff University have developed a needleless glucose monitor that doesn't require the users to prick their finger to keep track of their blood glucose levels. Instead, it uses microwaves to gather the data and then sends that data to an accompanying app. The device features an adhesive which lets its users stick it on their arm.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Skin cells used to restore vision for 1st time
