article: In a first, Japanese scientists have successfully transplanted cells from a patient's skin into her eye, partially restoring her lost vision. In the surgery, conducted in 2014, researchers took out a 4-millimeter piece of skin from her arm and modified its cells, turning them into pluripotent cells – cells that can give rise to any of the cell types.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: World's smallest thermometer created from DNA
article: Canada-based biochemists have developed the world's smallest thermometer from DNA, which is 20,000 times smaller than a human hair. The device is based on a property of DNA, which causes it to fold or unfold depending on the temperature changes. The property allowed the team to create programmable molecules which can aid in measuring temperatures between 30°C and 85°C.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Chinese firms develops graphene-based e-paper
article: China-based Guangzhou OED Technologies has created what it claims to be the world's first graphene-based e-paper. Notably, graphene is the world's strongest and lightest known material with a single layer being only 0.335 nanometers thick, enabling it to make brighter and more flexible screens. The company expects to start production of its graphene e-paper in a year.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Three potentially habitable planets discovered
article: Astronomers have discovered three potentially habitable planets situated 40 light-years away from the Earth. The exoplanets are comparable to Earth and Venus in terms of sizes and temperatures, and are the best targets found so far for searching alien life, the research added. Two of these planets orbit their dwarf star, called TRAPPIST-1, in 1.5 and 2.4 days, respectively.

author: Christine Garcia
abstract: ₹7.5k cr allocated for space dept in FY17 budget
article: According to SocialCops' analysis, ₹7,509 crore has been allocated for the Department of Space in India's 2016-17 budget, 0.38% of the total budget outlay of ₹19.78 lakh crore. The US spends nearly the same percentage on NASA at 0.48% of its $4.15 trillion budget. The Department of Space's budget has increased every fiscal since 2012-13, when ₹6,715 crore was allocated.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: World's smallest engine powered by light created
article: UK-based researchers have created the world's smallest engine – a few billionths of a metre in size – which uses light to power itself. A prototype was made by binding charged gold nanoparticles with temperature-responsive polymers. Heating the device with a laser forced the nanoparticles to bind together, storing elastic energy. Upon cooling, that energy was released as reusable work.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: MIT team creates paper-based test for Zika virus
article: MIT engineers have created a paper-based technique which they claim can diagnose Zika virus in around two hours. The technique uses paper embedded with synthetic bio-molecular sensors made of genes and proteins that can change its colour in the presence of Zika virus. It can also tell the difference between Zika and other mosquito-spread diseases like dengue.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Lens used during Apollo probe sold for $453,281
article: According to Boston-based RR Auction, a camera lens used during the Apollo 15 space mission in 1971 has been sold for $453,281. The 12-inch long Zeiss Tele-Tessar 500mm f/8 lens was used by astronaut David Scott to capture 293 photos of the fourth moon landing. The auction house said the lens was sold to a space collector from the UK.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA invests $67 mn into solar electric engines
article: NASA has awarded a $67 million contract to Washington-based Aerojet Rocketdyne to develop an advanced Solar Electric Propulsion (SEP) system for deep-space missions. NASA said that SEP will deliver twice as much thrust as chemical engines, and be 10 times more fuel-efficient. Notably, solar electric engines supply thrust for longer periods of time, but aren’t as powerful as chemical engines.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Europe to invest $1.13bn in quantum technologies
article: The European Commission has announced plans to launch a $1.13 billion investment project to boost the development of quantum technologies such as secure communication networks, precise gravity sensors and atomic clocks. The project will support research groups across the continent over the next 10 years. The commission also accepted a proposal, which details the plans of utilizing such huge funds.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA launches X-plane program for green aviation
article: NASA has announced the launch of its ‘New Aviation Horizons’ program under which an array of new experimental aircraft, called X-planes, will be built to adopt advanced green aviation technologies. NASA said that the goal of the 10-year initiative is to design planes that generate 75% less pollution and burn half the fuel as compared to a commercial aircraft.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA successfully flies 22 drones simultaneously
article: NASA, in collaboration with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) of the US, has successfully flown 22 drones simultaneously in several locations over the span of three hours to test a drone traffic management system. The space agency called this the most complex test yet of a drone traffic management system and the first and the largest demonstration of its kind.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: 'claude shannon' top Google trend today
article: Following the 100th birth anniversary of American mathematician and electrical engineer Claude Shannon, often known as "the father of information theory", on Saturday, 'claude shannon' was the most trending Google search in India. It was most looked up in Punjab, Andhra Pradesh and Goa. 'Comedk Admit Card' and 'RCB vs SRH' were some of the other trending searches.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA has records of eclipses till 3000AD: Report
article: According to reports, NASA has a catalogue of all eclipses that have or will occur between 1999 BC-3000 AD. It has been able to keep this five-millennium catalogue because of its knowledge of variables like the Earth’s and the moon's orbit. NASA said an eclipse repeats in "eight years, 11 days and eight hours", though not at the same location.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists find proof of lake under Antarctica
article: A team of scientists claims to have found evidence of a huge lake hidden under Antarctica’s ice. The sub-glacial ribbon-shaped lake is estimated to be 100-kilometer long, 10-kilometer wide and may reside life forms existing in isolation. The existence of the lake, reportedly trapped under ice for around 25 million years, will be verified by the end of May.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: ISRO to test its reusable launch vehicle in May
article: ISRO Chairman AS Kiran Kumar on Saturday said that the space agency will test its reusable launch vehicle in May. Called RLV-TD, the vehicle will be released from a height of over 70 kilometre for its re-entry into the atmosphere. Kumar added that it will act as a flying test bed to evaluate technologies like hypersonic flight and autonomous landing.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Weasel shuts world's largest particle collider
article: The world's largest and most powerful particle collider, the Large Hadron Collider was halted when a weasel wandered onto a 66-kilovolt transformer causing a short circuit, European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) said on Saturday. Notably, the machine was used in the 2013 Nobel prize-winning work that proved the existence of the Higgs Boson, also known as the God particle.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: CERN reveals 300TB of Large Hadron Collider data
article: The European Organization for Nuclear Research, known as CERN, has released 300 TB of data of its Large Hadron Collider – world's largest and most powerful particle collider. CERN is also providing a Linux-based virtual machine to access the datasets and tools to simplify the data. Particle colliders are generally used to study the nature of particles that constitute matter.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Designer creates visualization of Cosmic Web
article: Boston-based visual designer Kim Albrecht has created an interactive visualization called 'The Network Behind the Cosmic Web', which represents an interconnected network of 24,000 galaxies with over 1,00,000 connections. The research created three models based on different parameters. In the three models, galaxies were connected based on their distance, their size, and the neighboring galaxies.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Woman undergoes anti-ageing gene therapy: Report
article: Elizabeth Parrish, the CEO of Seattle-based biotech company BioViva, claims to have undergone a successful gene therapy against human ageing. The experimental treatment, developed by BioViva itself and yet to be independently verified, elongated Parrish’s 20 years of telomeres, or chromosome caps that otherwise shorten with age. If confirmed, this will be the first such treatment against ageing.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut runs London Marathon from space
article: British astronaut Tim Peake on Sunday ran the 36th London Marathon from space. He ran the distance of the marathon (about 42 kilometers) on a treadmill aboard the International Space Station (ISS) and wore a harness to counteract weightlessness. Notably, Peake had also run the London Marathon in 1999, finishing it in three hours, 18 minutes and 50 seconds.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Paper-based biosensor made to detect toxic water
article: Researchers have reportedly developed a paper-based biosensor covered with bacteria that can detect water toxicity. The biosensor uses a colouring agent which ranges from yellow colour to transparent, when bacteria come in contact with the water. Within 15 to 30 minutes, the change in the colour on the biosensor is visible through the naked eyes.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA to explore Saturn's moons for alien life
article: Scientists at NASA have proposed to deploy a robotic system, called Icy-moon Cryovolcano Explorer (ICE), to explore Saturn’s Europa and Enceladus moons for alien life. According to the scientists, the surface-to-subsurface robotic system will land on an icy moon, traverse to an ice volcano, descend into its opening and deploy underwater vehicles to explore a sub-surface ocean for alien life.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Microsoft experiments with storing data in DNA
article: Microsoft has partnered with San Francisco-based startup Twist Bioscience to experiment with using synthetic DNA as a means to store digital data. For this, Microsoft is buying 10 million strands of laboratory-made DNA molecules from the startup. According to Harvard scientists, about 700 terabytes can be stored on one gram of DNA, that can reportedly stay readable till 10,000 years.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut controls rover on Earth from space
article: To conduct tests for the European Space Agency’s ExoMars mission, British astronaut Tim Peake controlled a robotic rover, called Bridget, on Earth from space. Peake remotely navigated it in a simulated Martian landscape using a console and drove it into cave-like darkness to search for hidden targets. It will be sent to Mars in 2018 to look for alien life.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: World's 1st space tourist took off on this day
article: The world's first space tourist, Dennis Tito, took off in Russian spacecraft Soyuz TM-32 on April 28, 2001. Tito, a former NASA employee, paid a reported $20 million to fund the eight-day space trip. He first made the request to NASA, but the agency declined his plea saying he was not a trained astronaut, after which he turned to Russia.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: ISRO launches navigation satellite IRNSS-1G
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation on Thursday launched navigation satellite IRNSS-1G successfully from Andhra Pradesh's Sriharikota spaceport. The satellite has a 12-year life span and is seventh and last in the series of Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System (IRNSS). With this launch, India is now among the only five nations that have their own GPS or navigation system.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New fabric that can separate oil from water
article: Australian scientists claim to have created a fabric covered with semi-conducting nanostructures that can separate oil from water. The team added a silver-woven fabric deposited with a copper layer into a solution to grow the nanostructures on its surface. "The fabric could also potentially degrade organic matter when exposed to light thanks to these semi-conducting properties", a researcher said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists discover new reef in Amazon river
article: According to a study published in the journal Science Advances, scientists have discovered a 9,300 square-kilometer reef system at the mouth of the Amazon river. The colourful reef consists of sea fans, sunset-colored fish, pink coral-like crusted algae and sponges in yellow and red. The researchers said they used multi-beam acoustic sampling of the ocean bottom to find the reef.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Alzheimer's symptoms in mice reversed in 1 week
article: British researchers have discovered that a protein called 'IL-33' can help in reversing Alzheimer's-like symptoms in mice in one week. The team was able to restore the subjects' memory to the same levels as healthy mice. "IL-33 is a protein produced by various cell types in the body and is particularly abundant in the central nervous system", lead researcher said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: New primate species spotted in Arunachal Pradesh
article: According to wildlife conservation organisation Aaranyak, wildlife photographers and biologists from north-east India have spotted a new species of primate in Arunachal Pradesh. Called the White-cheeked Macaque, the species’ characteristics include relative hairless short tail, prominent pale to white side- and chin-whiskers, dark facial skin on the muzzle and long and thick hair on the neck.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Physicists discover new state of water molecules
article: US-based physicists have discovered a new state of water molecules, described as tunneling state confined in hexagonal ultra-small channels of a mineral. The state demonstrated properties of water molecules under ultra confinement in soil, rocks and cell walls. "This discovery represents a new fundamental understanding of the behavior of water and the way water utilizes energy", a researcher said.

author: Arjun Bhatia
abstract: Kolkata witnesses rare red-blue ring around Sun
article: A red and blue ring around the Sun, known as ‘22° halo’, was sighted in Kolkata on Saturday from 12:10-12:40 pm. The rare phenomenon occurs when the Sun’s or Moon’s rays get deflected/ refracted through the hexagonal ice crystals present in cirrus clouds, a researcher with the Birla Planetarium said. It was last observed in the city in April 2013.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronomers discover tailless comet
article: According to a research, astronomers have discovered a first-of-its-kind tailless comet called Manx. Researchers believe that the rocky comet was formed around the same time as the Earth itself, roughly 4.5 billion years ago. They said that comets coming in from the same region as Manx are usually made of ice and grow bright tails as they approach the sun.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: System to identify people by their brain waves
article: US-based Binghamton University scientists have developed a new system that can identify people by their brain waves with 100% accuracy. The team recorded several volunteers' brain activity while they saw images designed to evoke unique responses, and found that their brains reacted differently to each image. The system might help in security systems for authentication purposes, researchers said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New stretchy, self-healing material created
article: Researchers at the Stanford University have created a strong, stretchy material that can be stretched by 100 times its original size. The material can also self-repair itself at temperatures as low as -20°C. This advancement could be helpful in creating artificial muscles or skin to help people with prosthetic limbs restore some sensory capabilities, researchers said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method developed to predict Indian monsoon
article: German climate researchers on Thursday said that they have developed a new method to more accurately predict the Indian monsoon. The team found their method to be more than 70% accurate in predicting the start of the monsoon, and over 80% accurate in predicting its withdrawal. "We can predict the beginning of the Indian monsoon two weeks earlier," researchers said.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: 'Apollo 13' returned to Earth on this day
article: US lunar spacecraft 'Apollo 13' returned to Earth safely on April 17, 1970, after suffering a malfunction on its journey to the moon. The mission was commanded by James A Lovell with John L Swigert as Command Module Pilot and Fred W Haise as Lunar Module Pilot. It was the third manned lunar landing mission launched on April 11, 1970.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Hubble telescope captures dwarf galaxy Leo A
article: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has captured an image of a dwarf galaxy called Leo A, that is situated about 2.5 million light-years away from the Earth. Its few million stars are sparsely distributed, enabling scientists to see some distant galaxies in the background. It is a member of the Local Group of galaxies that also includes our Milky Way galaxy.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Biologists debunk report on rising tiger count
article: A group of tiger biologists from India, USA, UK and Russia have debunked the report that claimed that the world's tiger population is on the rise. They said that the report’s implications were not scientifically convincing and that using flawed survey methodologies can lead to incorrect conclusions. They added that tigers have endured 40% habitat loss in the last decade.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: India's first satellite was launched on this day
article: India's first satellite, Aryabhata, built by the Indian Space Research Organisation, was launched on April 19, 1975, by the Soviet Union. Weighing 360 kg and built to conduct experiments in X-ray astronomy, aeronomics, and solar physics, Aryabhata re-entered the Earth's atmosphere in 1992. The satellite was named after an Indian mathematician-astronomer who is believed to have discovered 'zero'.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronauts capture 4K footage of Earth from ISS
article: NASA astronauts have captured a 4K footage of Earth from the International Space Station (ISS). The UHD video, that shows carefully-framed close-up shots of the globe, was recorded using a RED Epic Dragon camera. Earlier, astronauts have captured 4K footages of various science experiments aboard the ISS. Notably, NASA stores all 4K videos on Archive.org under a Public Domain license.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New battery designed with lengthened lifespans
article: US-based researchers have created a nanowire-based battery material that can be recharged over 100,000 times without degrading its power or capacity. A standard lithium-ion battery, used in most of the smartphones, have 300 to 500 charge cycles in it before its capacity starts decaying. In initial testing, the material was recharged 200,000 times without any capacity or power loss.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: LEDs made 60% brighter by replicating fireflies
article: Korean researchers have developed a new organic LED by placing a nano-structured lens on top of a normal LED, improving its brightness by 60%. The team mimicked a firefly lantern's exterior, featuring a fine surface of tiles that reduces the difference in the refractive index of the surrounding air and its body, thereby allowing more light to be emitted.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Japan reveals its first results from Venus probe
article: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency’s Akatsuki spacecraft has sent back the first results from its Venus probe. The images of Venus’ dense, multi-layered clouds, taken from 1,00,000 kilometers away, indicate that its cloud formation is more complex than once thought. The spacecraft also found a bow-shaped cloud that appeared to rotate in sync with Venus’s surface, instead of its atmosphere.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New microscope that uses AI to find cancer cells
article: American researchers have developed a new microscope that uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) to detect cancer cells in blood samples faster and more accurately than current methods. Unlike some current approaches, which may damage the blood cells, the new deep-learning-based technique captures and analyzes 36 million images of the specimen every second to learn its cell's physical characteristics.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Sikkim gets Northeast's fastest supercomputer
article: The north-eastern region of India has got its fastest supercomputer called PARAM Kanchenjunga. Housed at the National Institute of Technology (NIT) in Sikkim, the supercomputer sports a peak computing power of 15 Teraflops and is equipped with the latest Intel-based processor and accelerator technologies. It has been built at a cost of over ₹2 crore.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers use coal to make electronic device
article: In a first, MIT researchers have developed an electrical heating device, which can be used to defrost car windows, using coal. The advancement could help in harnessing properties of coal to create solar panels or batteries, researchers said. For this, researchers developed steps to fabricate the material into thin films by crushing it and then adding it to a solution.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: First expandable habitat installed on ISS
article: NASA on Saturday successfully installed the first ever expandable structure, Bigelow Expandable Activity Module, on the International Space Station (ISS). In May, it would be expanded to 10.5 feet in diameter and 13 feet in length, nearly five times its compressed size. With the project, NASA aims at studying concepts for habitats that can keep astronauts healthy in space.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Heat engine designed that works on a single atom
article: German researchers have designed a heat engine model that can operate on a single Calcium atom. A heat engine is an energy converter that converts thermal energy to mechanical energy. Such engines are generally used in vehicles. After heating the system through electrically-generated noise, the atom experienced a back-and-forth thermodynamic cycle resulting in strokes similar to that of an engine.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: First 'Earth Day' was celebrated 46 years ago
article: The world's first ever Earth Day was celebrated on April 22, 1970, in the United States of America to increase public awareness about environmental problems. It was founded by United States Senator Gaylord Nelson. While the United Nations officially celebrates Earth Day on March 21 every year, more than 193 countries take part in the celebrations on April 22.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists develop embryos in space
article: Chinese scientists have developed early-stage mouse embryos in space for the first time on a microgravity satellite. Launched on April 6, it carried over 6,000 mouse embryos in a microwave oven-sized self-sufficient chamber. The embryos, put under high-resolution camera, developed from their two-cell stage around 72 hours after launch, a timing largely in line with embryonic development on Earth.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Heat from Jupiter moon can support ocean: Study
article: According to a new study, Jupiter’s moon Europa creates enough heat to support an ocean beneath its surface. Researchers said that Jupiter is constantly exerting a gravitational pull on Europa, which creates far more heat on the moon’s ice sheet than previously thought. This could help researchers better estimate the thickness of the moon’s outer shell.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Fish-eyed lens developed to see in the dark
article: Researchers at the US-based University of Wisconsin–Madison have developed a new fish-eyed lens that can see in the dark. The lens combines the features of the eyes of a lobster and an African fish. Researchers claim that the lens could help the search and rescue robots or surgical microscopes to improve the visibility in dim surroundings.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA successfully tests 3D-printed rocket engine
article: NASA has successfully tested a 3D-printed rocket engine turbopump, with liquid methane as fuel, for its future Mars mission, the space agency said on Thursday. Notably, the 3D-printed fuel pump had 45% fewer parts than pumps made via traditional manufacturing. NASA claims that liquid methane is an ideal propellant to power engines for deep-space missions.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Fuel cell to generate power from urine developed
article: Researchers at the UK-based University of Bath have developed a miniature fuel cell that can generate electricity from urine. The cell costs around $2 and uses bacteria to turn organic matter, such as urine, into electricity. A single microbial fuel cell measuring one square-inch can generate enough power to charge a mobile phone.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Dinos were perishing before asteroid hit: Study
article: According to a study by University of Reading researchers, dinosaur population was already declining prior to the asteroid strike that wiped out the entire species. The team statistically analyzed fossil records and revealed that some dinosaur species were going extinct at a faster rate than new ones were emerging for at least 40 million years before the asteroid hit.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Smart skin that self-powers on touching objects
article: China-based researchers have fabricated a new smart skin that gets powered by its own frictional contact with other objects. It uses four electrodes positioned at its four opposite ends to generate electricity. When pressure is applied on the skin, it induces voltages of different magnitudes on each electrode, depending on the electrode's distance from the point of pressure.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 1st fossilised heart in prehistoric animal found
article: Scientists in Brazil recently announced the discovery of a fossilised heart of an extinct 113-119 million-year-old fish, called Rhacolepis, making it the first such discovery found in any prehistoric animal. The team revealed that the found specimen had a very complicated structure – with nine rows of valves as compared to the one row found in modern bony fish species.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Team transmits wireless signals through flesh
article: A team of researchers in the US has demonstrated the transmission of wireless signals through slabs of meat. The advancement, named as 'meat-comms', could prove helpful in remotely controlling medical devices inside human bodies without causing heat damage to the surrounding tissues. Using this technology, the team was able to achieve transmission rates of up to 30 MBps.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Smart scalpel to aid in brain surgeries created
article: A researcher from Brussels has developed a smart scalpel which claims at making brain surgeries less risky. With no edge, the scalpel has a sensor-rich sphere at the tip, and can differentiate between cancerous tumours and normal brain tissues. It can also provide visual or auditory results about the status of brain tissues to surgeons in half a second.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Ribose might have come from comets: Study
article: According to a study by French scientists, the Earth might have received its first portion of the ribose sugar, an important ingredient in RNA, from comets. Scientists believe that there was a period, wherein RNA was the only genetic material present on Earth. For testing, the team recreated the environment found on comet '67P' and exposed it to simulated radiation.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: ExoMars probe captures its first image in space
article: The ExoMars mission, launched by European and Russian space agencies to find evidence of alien life on Mars, has sent back its first image from space. The unmanned spacecraft captured stars close to the southern celestial pole. The image was taken in two frames via a rotating camera mechanism and demonstrates equally offset positive and negative pictures of stars.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Bus to take students on VR ride across Mars
article: Aerospace company Lockheed Martin has launched a Mars Experience bus that takes students on an immersive virtual reality ride across Mars. The bus simulates a ride across the Red Planet by showing 200 square miles of Martian surface on its boarded-up windows. It will tour the US to give students from different regions a chance to try out the experience.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists discover supernova iron on moon
article: German physicists have discovered supernova iron on the moon, confirming that a supernova explosion once took place near our solar system. They found an unusually high concentration of the radioactive 60Fe isotope, created in supernova explosions, in lunar ground samples gathered between 1969 and 1972. Further, the samples indicate that the supernova explosion occurred about 300 light-years away.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Newton's alchemy manuscript to be put online
article: A 17th-century document written by Sir Isaac Newton will be put online by US-based nonprofit 'Chemical Heritage Foundation' after purchasing it recently. The document's main page features a recipe hand-copied by Newton detailing a method to create an ingredient for manufacturing the Philosopher's stone, a substance said to be capable of transforming base metals like lead into gold or silver.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: European Space Agency releases 360° video of ISS
article: The European Space Agency (ESA) has released a 360° video of the International Space Station (ISS). The virtual reality (VR) tour explores the Harmony module, that was installed in 2007 and houses the crew and their beds. Earlier, the ESA had released an immersive video of the Destiny module on the ISS, which is the on-board space laboratory.

author: Aarushi Maheshwari
abstract: 'Fast food may up industrial chemicals in body'
article: People who reported consuming fast food in the past 24 hours had increased levels of certain industrial chemicals in their body, a study published in the Environmental Health Perspectives journal has found. The study examines how fast food may expose people to phthalates (chemicals used to make plastics durable). They may leak into foods from packaging machinery, suggests the research.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA's Saturn probe detects interstellar dust
article: In a first, NASA's Saturn-orbiting Cassini spacecraft has detected interstellar dust coming from beyond the solar system. The tiny dust grains were speeding through Saturn’s system at over 72,000 kilometers per hour and were found to be made of a very specific mixture of minerals. Notably, the Saturn dust grains which Cassini has so far sampled, are made of ice.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA sends expandable human habitat to ISS
article: NASA has sent an expandable human habitat to the International Space Station (ISS) called the Bigelow Expandable Activity Module (BEAM). Once docked, BEAM will become roughly 13 feet long and 10.5 feet in diameter. During its two-year test mission, astronauts will enter the lightweight, fabric module to gauge how well it protects against solar radiation, space debris and contamination.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Hallucinogen effects of LSD discovered 73yrs ago
article: Albert Hoffman, a Swiss chemist had consumed synthetic drug LSD-25 on April 16, 1943, after which he discovered and published his experience of hallucinations for the first time. The drug was created by him in 1938 as part of his research into the medicinal value of lysergic acid compounds. "I perceived an uninterrupted stream of fantastic pictures...," he wrote.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Electronic skin with digital display developed
article: Tokyo researchers have developed a super-thin e-skin that lights up a digital display on a user’s body. The ultra-stretchy e-skin is mounted with thin OLED displays and photosensitive diodes, that when hit with electrical pulses, light up to mimic pixels on a normal screen. This on-skin display can be used to provide information like heart rate and blood sugar.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create new 'Tree of Life'
article: Scientists have redesigned the 'Tree of Life', a diagram depicting the evolution and diversification of life on the planet, after studying the DNA of 1,011 newly discovered and 2,072 known species. The new tree revealed that eukaryotes, which include humans, represent a small percentage of the world's biodiversity while the single-celled organisms – bacteria and Archaea – comprise the majority.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers create bacteria-powered solar panel
article: In a first, American researchers have created a bacteria-powered scalable bio-solar panel, by stacking up nine bio-solar cells. The panel was able to generate 5.59 microwatts of energy from respiratory activities and photosynthesis of the bacteria in 12-hour day-night cycles. As per the researchers, this advancement could be used for permanent power sources and for future research of bacteria.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create world's strongest material
article: In a first, researchers in Austria have synthesized Carbyne, a material 40 times stronger than diamond and twice as strong as the strongest known material 'graphene'. Carbyne, an electrically neutral carbon atom with three non-bonded electrons, has high reactivity that leads to its immediate destruction. To make it stable, scientists used double-walled nanotubes by rolling two layers of graphene.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Three-star system with Jupiter-like planet found
article: Researchers have discovered a rare three-star system that includes a hot Jupiter-like planet. The said gas giant, named KELT-4Ab, has a radius about 1.7 times that of Jupiter and completes a revolution around its central star every three days. Further, the two remaining stars orbit each other every 30 years and the central star every 4,000 years.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: First man travelled into space 55 years ago
article: Cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first man to enter outer space on April 12, 1961. The then 27-year-old orbited the Earth aboard the Soviet spacecraft Vostok 1 for an hour and forty-eight minutes at a maximum altitude of 187 miles. The only statement attributed to Gagarin during his time in space was, “Flight is proceeding normally; I am well.”

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Graphene sensor created to detect air pollution
article: British scientists have developed a power-efficient graphene-based sensor that can detect air pollution inside homes. The sensor detects individual carbon-di-oxide molecules, found in buildings and interior materials, adsorbed onto graphene – a single atomic sheet of carbon atoms. In the study, the team was able to detect gas molecules with 30 parts-per-billion concentration level.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA's planet-hunter recovered from emergency
article: NASA’s Kepler space observatory, used to hunt for alien planets, has been successfully recovered after being in the emergency mode for the last three days. This was the first time the spacecraft was found in the emergency mode in its seven-year lifetime, the reason for which is still not clear. Notably, engineers remotely troubleshot Kepler from 75 million miles away.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Tech to allow clothes transmit digital info
article: Scientists have developed a way to embroider circuits into fabrics with a precision of 0.1 mm, allowing clothes to gather, store and transmit digital information. Such e-textiles can lead to shirts that act as antennas for smartphones, workout clothes that monitor fitness levels, bandages that tell how well a wound is healing and caps that sense activity in the brain.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: One of the earliest traces of humans discovered
article: Archeologists recently announced the discovery of stone age tools as old as 7,70,000 to 8,00,000 years in Vietnam's Central Highlands' Gia Lai Province, hinting at one of the earliest traces of humans. The sites were discovered in 2014 and were studied over the next two years, an official said. However, no human remains have been found yet.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Hawking, Milner announce $100m for space voyage
article: English cosmologist Stephen Hawking and Russian entrepreneur and philanthropist Yuri Milner have announced a $100 million investment for a space voyage to the nearest star system 'Alpha Centauri', 4.37 light years away. The project, to be launched after 20 years, would use a 100 billion-watt laser-powered light beam to accelerate several featherweight robot nanocrafts at 60,000 km per second.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut captures time-lapse video of sunrise
article: European Space Agency (ESA) astronaut Tim Peake has posted a time-lapse video of sunrise on Twitter. Peake, who is currently aboard the International Space Station (ISS), tweeted, “Fade to blue: sunrise approaches”. The video, that also features auroras, was put together from images taken one each second and played back at 25 images a second.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: FDA approves world's smallest pacemaker
article: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved the world's smallest pacemaker, Micra Transcatheter Pacing System, measuring about the size of a large vitamin or one-tenth the size of traditional devices. It is the first miniaturized device with pacing technology to get approval from the US government. In initial trials, the device was successfully implanted in over 99% of patients.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut captures static electricity in space
article: European Space Agency (ESA) astronaut Tim Peake has posted a time-lapse video on Twitter that shows the presence of static electricity in outer space. Peake, who is currently aboard the International Space Station (ISS), tweeted, “The awesome power of static electricity – Mother Nature's Disco.” The video was put together by taking a picture every second for around six minutes.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Scientists find new Zika-linked brain disorder
article: Scientists have found a new brain disorder linked to Zika infections in adults, an autoimmune syndrome named acute disseminated encephalomyelitis, that attacks the brain and spinal cord. Zika has already been linked to the autoimmune disorder Guillain-Barre syndrome, that attacks the peripheral nervous system. The finding shows Zika may also provoke an immune attack on the central nervous system.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: LSD's impact on human brain imaged for 1st time
article: In a first, scientists in the UK have imaged the impact of LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) on the human brain. LSD, also known as acid, is a psychedelic drug known for its psychological effects. "We saw many more areas of the brain than normal were contributing to visual processing under LSD, even though volunteers' eyes were closed",  a researcher said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists record heat moving at speed of sound
article: Scientists have recorded first-ever videos of heat moving through materials at the speed of sound. Traveling at nano-scale, the waves of energy have been recorded moving at about 6 nanometres (0.000000006 meters) per picosecond (0.000000000001 second). The videos were made using an ultrafast electron microscope called FEI Tecnai Femto, and were slowed by over a billion times the normal speed.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New technique to separate oil from water
article: American researchers have found a new technique to remove oils and pollutants from water. In the technique, melamine sponges, found in household cleaning products, were coated with a specific solution that repels water and allows oil to be absorbed. "We believe this [process] can be readily adopted for the cleanup of oil spills and industrial chemical leaks", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method to develop artificial molecules
article: Scientists at IBM Research Zurich and ETH Zurich have developed a new technique to manufacture molecules with tiny spheres of a polymer or silica as the building blocks. Every sphere had a diameter of around one micrometre and possessed different physical properties. This advancement could prove helpful in future for lab-on-a-chip applications or micro-robots for biomedical applications.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists change colour of photons in diamond
article: In a first, researchers in Canada have changed the colour and bandwidth of ultrafast photons using a room-temperature diamond quantum memory. The quantum memory is an interface that allows storage and retrieval of photonic quantum information, by converting photons into a specific vibration of diamond's carbon atoms. This advancement could improve the performance of optical quantum communication.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers design handheld 3D printing biopen
article: Australian researchers have designed a handheld 3D printing biopen that would allow surgeons to draw human stem cells during surgeries. This technology can be used to print cells layer-by-layer to build artificial tissues. Using a hydrogel bio-ink to support living cells and a low-powered light source to solidify the ink, the pen delivers a cell survival rate of over 97%.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers store, recover digital data from DNA
article: University of Washington and Microsoft researchers have created one of the first complete systems to encode, store and recover digital data from DNA molecules. This storage process can help in storing information millions of times more compactly than current archival technologies, like flash drives and hard drives. It can also preserve digital information for centuries without degrading it.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Solar panels that can create energy from water
article: Chinese researchers have designed solar panels coated with graphene sheets that were able to generate electricity from sunlight and raindrops. Rainwater contains several salts that break up into negative and positive ions. The team used graphene sheets to separate the ions and in turn generate power. Early tests showed a 6.53% solar-to-electric conversion efficiency for the newly designed panels.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Radioactive debris discovered in ocean crust
article: Australian scientists have identified radioactive shrapnel from supernovas – huge explosions of stars at the end of their lives – in the Pacific Ocean floor. The team believes the debris came from two explosions, dating back to between 3.2 million and 1.7 million years ago, that could have been 300 light years away and would have been visible from Earth.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: World's first 3D-printed drug unveiled
article: According to Science News Journal, US-based pharmaceutical company Aprecia has unveiled the world's first 3D printed drug, Spritam, which was approved by the Food and Drug Administration earlier in the year. The drug, which is meant to treat epilepsy and is currently available in the US, was produced using inkjet printing, where the drug's elements were created layer upon layer.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Material that heals itself at body temp created
article: Scientists at the University of Reading have created a new material that can repair itself at human body temperature (37°C), making it safe for humans to use. The new material flows like a liquid when scraped or cut, filling in the damage in a few hours eventually binding the molecules together. This advancement can lead to new self-healing wound dressings.

author: Arjun Bhatia
abstract: Nuclear Fuel Complex sets new world record
article: The Nuclear Fuel Complex (NFC) in Hyderabad, under the Department of Atomic Energy, on Saturday announced it has set a new world record with production of 1,503 tonnes of nuclear fuel in 2015-16. NFC had earlier become the world’s leading producer in 2014-15, with a 1,252 tonne-production. Further, it is targetting 2,000 tonnes this fiscal, NFC Chairman N Saibaba said.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Rosetta probe to crash-land on comet in Sept
article: European Space Agency's 'Rosetta' space probe will crash-land into the comet named '67P' in September 2016. The landing will be the completion of the 2014 '67P' mission which was set to gather information about the comet's surface and its transformation in the solar system. Notably, the '67P' is a Jupiter-family comet, with an orbital period of 6.45 years.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Chandrayaan II to be indigenous mission
article: Opting to go solo in its Chandrayaan II project, India has decided not to take Russia on board and keep the lunar exploration programme completely indigenous with 'minor' help from NASA. Earlier in 2010, it was agreed that Russian Space Agency Roscosmos and ISRO would collaborate for the mission, consisting of a lunar lander, a rover and the launch vehicle.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA develops method to study fungi from space
article: A team from NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory has developed a method to detect the type of fungi attached to the roots of trees by studying the satellite images of the forest global Earth Observatory. Using this technique, researchers might be able to predict the impact of climate change on forest habitats and determine where forests will thrive in the future.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Light can control microorganisms' motion: Study
article: Researchers in Sweden, Scotland and England have developed a model in which light with a certain wavelength was able to control the movement of active particles and microorganisms, like bacteria and algae. The particles' movement upon interacting with light resembled a pump-like motion which can be helpful in areas such as medicine, environmental protection and development of programmed materials.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA's planet-hunter goes under emergency mode
article: NASA’s Kepler space observatory, used to hunt for alien planets, has been discovered operating under the “emergency mode”. Engineers are trying to recover the spacecraft, that is almost 75 million miles away from the Earth. Notably, it takes 13 minutes for signals to make round trips between Kepler and the Earth. The observatory had once lost control in 2013 too.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists grow hairy skin transplants
article: Scientists in Japan have successfully grown multi-layered skin with hair and oil-producing glands and have successfully transplanted the skin onto a hairless mouse. It was observed that the skin successfully connected to nerves and muscles. According to the researchers, this technique can be used on humans within the next 10 years, to help burn survivors and people with skin diseases.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: NASA-ASTER's 2.95 mn Earth photos made public
article: NASA announced on Friday that around 2.95 million photographs of the Earth's surface, taken by Japan's ASTER, a thermal emission and reflection radiometer remote sensing instrument, operating aboard NASA’s Terra spacecraft, have been made public. The database, which includes landscapes and natural phenomena like volcanic eruptions and tornadoes, was compiled over a duration of over 16 years.

author: Twishy Shahi
abstract: Blue Origin posts video of rocket's 3rd flight
article: Blue Origin, the space flight company created by Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, has released a video showing the launch and landing of the reusable New Shepard rocket, which successfully made its third flight. The engine restarted at 3,635 feet above ground level "and ramped fast for a successful landing," the company stated. It reached 339,178 feet at its highest point.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Fastest electron diffraction images captured
article: American researchers have captured the fastest Ultrafast Electron Diffraction (UED) images, at a record shutter-speed of 100 quadrillionths of a second using a new superfast electron camera. This is the first research to visualize the process in real-time and with a detailed resolution, researchers said. UED is a pump-probe experiment which uses a beam of energetic electrons to probe samples.

author: Shipra Sharma
abstract: Doctors sew man's arm into stomach to save it
article: Surgeons in Orleans, Brazil, recently saved a man's arm from being amputated by sewing it into his abdomen. Carlos Mariotti, a machine production operator, had suffered an accident at work causing the skin on his hand to rip off. "The patient’s hand must stay in the pocket for 42 days to ensure it develops new tissue", Dr Boris Brandao said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists discover new state of matter
article: University of Cambridge researchers claimed to have found the first real evidence of 'Quantum Spin Liquid', a state of matter first predicted in the 1970s. The state causes electrons, thought of as indivisible building blocks, to break into pieces. It was believed to be present in certain magnetic materials but was found in a two-dimensional material with a graphene-like structure.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Climate change may have caused North Pole shift
article: According to NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, climate change may have caused the shift in Earth's rotational North Pole. Since 2000, the North Pole has shifted eastward by around 75°, heading towards the Prime Meridian. Scientists believe the massive glacier melting taking place around the world could have significantly redistributed Earth's mass, causing the shift in its rotational axis.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers link mass extinctions to 'Planet X'
article: A study by retired astrophysics professor Daniel Whitmire linked mass extinctions on Earth to the undiscovered 'Planet X', which is believed to be the solar system's ninth planet living beyond Neptune. According to the theory, 'Planet X' passes through a belt of comets present beyond Neptune every 27 million years, hammering comets into the inner solar system, causing mass extinctions.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers make world's smallest diode
article: American researchers have developed the world's smallest diode using a DNA molecule. The used DNA molecule had 11 base pairs, as compared to 3 billion pairs that are present in a human genome. A diode is a component that conducts electricity primarily in one direction and has low (ideally zero) resistance. This advancement could eventually lead to more nanoscale electronics.

author: Twishy Shahi
abstract: SpaceX makes its first-ever sea landing
article: Elon Musk-owned company SpaceX on Friday successfully landed the first stage of the Falcon 9 rocket on a drone ship at sea, after launching it to the International Space Station. It's the first time SpaceX has been able to pull off an ocean landing, after four failed attempts. With this, SpaceX has landed its rockets both on ground and ocean.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create detailed model of Planet Nine
article: Swiss scientists have created a detailed model of the undiscovered 'Planet Nine' based on the assumption that it is a smaller version of Neptune and Uranus. Its radius was estimated to be 3.7 times that of Earth with a temperature of around -226°C. Researchers also said that the planet may have a water-ice layer enveloped by hydrogen or helium.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists discuss if universe is a simulation
article: American astrophysicist and author Neil deGrasse Tyson along with some of the high-profile theoretical physicists and philosophers recently held a meeting to discuss the possibility of the universe being a cosmic simulation. According to a panelist, if the universe is a simulation, there would be predictable physical limits which, if found, can prove that the reality isn't real.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists reveal Zika structure for 1st time
article: In a first, researchers in the US have revealed the structure of the Zika virus, providing aid to the development of treatments to combat the disease. The discovery could help in designing vaccines and developing better diagnostic tests for the virus. According to the report, the virus is represented by a spherical structure resembling that of the dengue virus.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Extreme heat may be predicted 50 days in advance
article: According to a new study, meteorologists may soon be able to forecast extreme heat in the US 50 days in advance. The team studied the relationship between heat waves and the water temperatures for 33 summers from 1982-2015. Such warnings can help in preparing for periods when more irrigation, electrical power generation and cooling centers would be needed, experts said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: India may get World's largest telescope
article: Hanle village in Ladakh was short-listed as a prospective site to house the World's largest telescope named 'Thirty Metre Telescope International Observatory', estimated to be worth around ₹98.26 crore. After the permit for the same was cancelled for a site in Hawaii, first choice for the observatory, the board decided on two prospective sites – Hanle and another in Chile.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: First 3D atlas of the extinct dodo created
article: In a first, scientists have created a 3D atlas of the skeletal anatomy of the extinct flightless bird dodo, by studying two skeletons that have remained unstudied for over a century. "Compared to living pigeons, the dodo's skull is very different; it is much larger, with a heavy beak, and it has undergone significant changes in shape", a researcher said.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: Japan kills 200 pregnant whales during hunt
article: According to reports, four Japanese ships on this year's Antarctic whale hunt have killed 333 Minke whales, including 200 pregnant females. The ships were part of a project to conduct "scientific" whaling. Notably, commercial whaling has been banned since 1986. Japan had cut down its whaling activities by two-thirds and made them more "scientific" after the ban.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA to offer virtual tour of Mars via HoloLens
article: NASA, in collaboration with Microsoft, has created ‘Destination: Mars’, a mixed-reality project that will offer visitors at the Kennedy Space Center a guided tour of Mars using the HoloLens headset. Further, the virtual tour will be conducted by a hologram of Apollo 11 astronaut Buzz Aldrin. NASA’s Curiosity rover, stationed on Mars since 2012, provided the data for the project.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Astronomers observe earth-like planet formation
article: Astronomers at the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) have observed an Earth-like planet's formation. The star TW Hydrae, situated around 175 light-years away from Earth, has a planet with Earth-like features forming in its orbit. Researchers claim that at present the system looks similar to what the Solar system would have looked like when it was 10 million years old.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Magnetic method to control brain developed
article: Researchers in the US have developed a new method to control the brain circuits associated with complex animal behaviours, using a special magnetic protein called 'Magneto'. The study performed on a virus, mice and zebrafish demonstrated that Magneto's use can help in remotely controlling the triggering of neurons within the brain, by placing the organisms in a magnetized environment.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists go on globe-spanning research mission
article: NASA is sending scientists on an around-the-globe mission to study climate change and the impact humans have on it. In the next six months, researchers will undertake eight new campaigns in locations ranging from the ice sheets of Greenland to coral reefs of the South Pacific. They will also undertake three airborne research campaigns over the Pacific and Atlantic oceans.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA to send fungi into space for first time
article: In a first, the University of Southern California researchers in collaboration with NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory will send fungi to the International Space Station for the development of medicine. A specimen of 'Aspergillus nidulans' would be sent into the high-radiation and microgravity environment in space to create molecules which couldn't be created in Earth's less stressful conditions.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers discover rare triple-star system
article: Researchers in the US have recently announced the discovery of a rare triple-star system that consists of a planet in a stable orbit, making it the fourth and the closest such discovery. The study revealed a two-star system, orbiting one another, and a gas planet similar in size to Jupiter revolving around the star KELT-A, which serves as the Sun.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Efficient method to split water developed
article: American researchers have designed a new catalyst that can efficiently split water into oxygen, which is released into the atmosphere, and hydrogen, which can be converted into energy through hydrogen fuel cells. Researchers used low-cost metals iron, tungsten and cobalt to create the catalyst which they claim to be three times more efficient at splitting water than the current state-of-the-art.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method that can assess chemotherapy in 8 hrs
article: US-based Indian-origin researchers have developed a technique that can assess cancer treatments' effectiveness in eight hours and can detect if the tumours are shrinking. When cancer cells die, 'caspase' enzyme is activated. The researchers mixed a chemical to the cancer drugs which glows in the presence of the enzyme, thereby helping in assessing the treatment's progress in short time.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Modi, Belgian PM launch Asia's biggest telescope
article: Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Belgian counterpart Charles Michel on Wednesday remotely launched Asia's biggest telescope, the Aryabhatta Research Institute of Observational Sciences (ARIES), built with Belgian assistance. Located at Devasthal near Nainital in Uttarakhand, it has a 3.6-metre-wide primary mirror. The telescope will be used to study structures and magnetic field of stars.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Moon once spun on a different axis: Study
article: According to a new study that used data from NASA’s Lunar Prospector mission, the moon once spun on a different axis. Its axis later shifted about six degrees, likely due to volcanic activity in a region called the Procellarum over several billion years ago. The study also indicated the presence of water ice on the lunar surface.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: MIT develops programming language for bacteria
article: MIT engineers have created a programming language that enables designing DNA-encoded circuits to give specific functions to the 'E. coli' bacteria. To achieve this, computing elements like logic gates and sensors were designed and encoded in the bacteria's DNA. The researchers plan to make the language's interface, which does not require genetic engineering knowledge to use, available on the web.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Planet with pure oxygen atmosphere discovered
article: Researchers have recently discovered a white dwarf planet, nicknamed Dox, with an atmosphere almost completely made up of pure oxygen. Researchers believe that Dox was part of a binary star – where two stars orbit their combined centre of mass – and suggested that the other star's explosion might have caused Dox to lose its lighter elements, leaving only oxygen.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create largest neural network to date
article: American researchers have mapped the neural connections network of a 450x450x150 micrometer chunk of a mice brain, making it the largest neural network mapping to date. The team traced the paths of 1,278 connected neurons and connected those traces to the neurons' spikes while processing visual information. This data could help the researchers in understanding how the brain is organized.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Bottle created that decomposes once empty
article: A biodegradable bottle which disappears as soon as the user finishes its content has been developed by Ari Jónsson, a product design student at the Iceland Academy of the Arts. Jónsson made the biodegradable water bottle out of algae, which shrinks and decomposes once it is emptied. He said that he created the product to replace plastic products.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA sends its largest resupply mission to ISS
article: NASA has launched its largest resupply mission ever to the International Space Station (ISS) with over 7,700 pounds of supplies. Aboard the Orbital ATK’s Cygnus spacecraft, the delivery was captured by Expedition 47 Commander Tim Kopra using a robotic arm. Once detached from the ISS, the spacecraft will also undertake a remote experiment to study a large fire in microgravity.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 100 times stronger heat transfer by radiation
article: American researchers have demonstrated that by bringing two objects extremely close – at nanometer scale – the heat transfer between them can be increased by 100 times than has been predicted. According to a researcher, this strong contactless channel could be used to control the temperature of delicate nanodevices that cannot be touched, or for efficiently converting heat to electricity.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: India, China lead renewable energy investments
article: According to a UN-backed report, China and India led developing countries in investments made in renewable energy in 2015, with $102.9 billion and $10.2 billion respectively. India was also among the top 10 investing nations. Notably, this was the first time that developing countries outweighed developed economies in investing in renewable energy,  with $156 billion and $130 billion respectively.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Material that can detect fuel leaks developed
article: American engineers have developed a fiber material that can detect small traces of alkane fuel vapor, a key ingredient in combustible materials like gasoline and oil. This advancement can prove helpful in developing an early-warning detection system for fuel leaks and fuel-based explosions. Currently, there are no portable sensors that can detect alkane fuel as it is not chemically reactive.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: US Spacecraft 1st visited Mercury on this day
article: 'Mariner 10' became the first spacecraft to visit the planet Mercury on March 29, 1974. It was an unmanned US space probe, launched by NASA in November 1973. Further, Mariner 10 is the only spacecraft to have visited Mercury till date. It flew past Mercury three times; second time on September 21, 1974 and third time on March 16, 1975.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Siberian unicorn lived same time as human: Study
article: A fossilised skull recently discovered in Kazakhstan has led paleontologists to believe that Siberian unicorns existed and even lived alongside human beings, as per findings recorded in the American Journal of Applied Science. The new research indicates that the now extinct animal may have existed until 29,000 years ago. The animal's first existence records to nearly 2.5 million years ago.

author: Tanaya Singh
abstract: ISRO to launch 22 satellites in one mission
article: Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) will launch 22 satellites in a single mission, its highest so far, this May. The launch vehicle PSLV C34 will carry India’s remote sensing satellite Cartosat 2C along with 21 other satellites, including four micro-satellites and 17 nano-satellites. Satellites of foreign agencies like US, Canada, Indonesia and Germany are included in the launch.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop 'transparent wood'
article: Researchers in Sweden have developed a material, dubbed as 'Transparent Wood', that is stronger than glass and can be used for tougher wood-based windows and even cheaper wood-covered solar cells. The researchers first removed structural polymer lignin from commercial balsa wood and embedded the resulting wood with a transparent polymer, known as Plexiglass, to achieve transmittance of up to 85%.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists observe self-impregnating female fish
article: According to a study by British researchers, a female Cichlid hybrid fish was observed to have grown male reproductive organs and impregnated itself. Researchers called the process 'selfing' and suggested that it is rare in vertebrates. It was revealed that the fish discharged sperm into the water and sucked it back into its mouth to fertilize the eggs present there.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: India observes 10th Earth Hour today
article: India will observe the 10th Earth Hour on Saturday between 8.30 pm and 9:30 pm. The annual international event aims at conserving energy by urging people to voluntarily switch off non-essential lights and electrical appliances for an hour. Last year, Delhi saved 200 MWs of energy during the Earth Hour. Notably, the event coincides with the India-Pakistan World T20 match.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Contact lenses may alter bacteria in eyes: Study
article: According to a new study by researchers from the New York University School of Medicine, contact lenses may alter the natural bacterial composition on the surface of the eyes, making it more skin-like. The researchers, however, have said that they are not sure about how these microbial changes occur or if these changes compromise the health of the eyes.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Self-cleaning textiles using light developed
article: Australian researchers have developed an efficient and cheap method to grow special copper and silver-based nanostructures, that can degrade organic matter when exposed to light, directly onto textiles, leading to self-cleaning clothes. According to the researchers, when exposed to light, some textiles embedded with the special nanostructures took less than six minutes to remove dirt and smells.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New theory to explain how sun-like stars evolve
article: Researchers at the University of Rochester, US, have developed a new model to understand and predict how stars similar to the Sun evolve. The model may help in determining the age of stars more precisely. The theory helps explain how the X-ray emissions and rotation of such stars, and the intensity of its stellar winds vary with time.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Living cell built with minimum number of genes
article: Researchers have created a living synthetic cell called JCVI Syn3.0 with 473 genes, making it the smallest and the simplest self-replicating cell known. This number is the minimum number of genes needed for life. Notably, humans have around 20,000 genes. The researchers, however, have admitted that they do not understand the biological functions of one third of the genes.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA finds tallest peak on Saturn's moon Titan
article: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft has identified the highest point on Saturn's largest moon, Titan. The moon’s tallest peak is 10,948 feet high and is found within a trio of mountainous ridges called the Mithrim Montes. Further, the space agency has found that all of Titan's highest peaks are about 10,000 feet in elevation.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Malaria first spread from birds: Study
article: A new study published by researchers at the Cornell University in New York revealed that mosquito-borne disease Malaria first spread from birds to bats and then on to other mammals. For the study, researchers tested malarial DNA discovered in birds, bats and other small mammals from East African countries. Notably, the disease affected around 214 million people worldwide in 2015.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Saturn's moons might be younger than dinos: Data
article: According to researchers from the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence Institute, Saturn’s moons and rings might have formed a mere 100 million years ago, which makes them younger than dinosaurs. An analysis of the orbital data from the planet’s moons shows that they, except the more distant Titan and Iapetus, were formed during Earth’s Cretaceous Period, the era of the dinosaurs.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists spot planet with most eccentric orbit
article: San Francisco State University scientists have spotted an extrasolar planet, around 117 light-years from Earth, that has the most eccentric or elliptical orbit ever seen. With a measured eccentricity of 0.96, the planet, at its farthest, is separated from its star by 2.5 times the Earth-Sun distance, while at its closest, the same distance becomes 0.06 times the Earth-Sun distance.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers discover new reproduction mechanism
article: US researchers have discovered a new reproduction mechanism that could help in the development of new unisex contraceptive pill or fertility treatments. The research revealed a protein receptor as a trigger that powers the sperm cells to fertilise a human egg. The discovery could lead to the creation of a drug that can disable the trigger, the researchers said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New blood test spots Alzheimer's in early stages
article: Researchers in Germany claimed to have developed a new blood test that can detect Alzheimer's 20 years in advance, by identifying an involved protein called amyloid-beta peptides. Previous studies have revealed that the protein begins to form clusters 20 years before the disease symptoms become visible. The new test uses an infrared sensor to detect and extract the disease's biomarkers.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers invent tougher 50% renewable plastic
article: US researchers have created a new moldable and ductile thermoplastic called ABL, that is over ten times tougher than a common thermoplastic polymer ABS, and is also recyclable by melting. "We can call it a green product because 50% of its content is renewable, and technology to enable its commercial exploitation would reduce the need for petrochemicals", a researcher said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method for viewing cells, tissues under skin
article: A team of scientists at the Stanford University has developed a technique, called MOZART, to view tissues, cells and blood vessels under the skin in 3D. According to a team member, this technique could help doctors in future to monitor tumors under the skin and to understand how individual cells break free from a tumor and travel to distant sites.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Man-made sun produces longest pulse discharge
article: An 'artificial sun' experiment in China has successfully produced the longest pulse plasma discharge at a temperature of over 50 million degrees. As of January, the experiment has created a 102-second-long pulse plasma discharge of such high temperatures, according to reports. "An artificial sun can provide limitless clean energy through controlled thermonuclear fusion", a researcher said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Three astronauts launched to the Space Station
article: A new three-member crew launched to the International Space Station (ISS) from Kazakhstan on Friday. The crew includes Jeff Williams, a veteran astronaut set to break the American record for the most time spent in space with his half-year trip. The crew has joined astronauts Tim Kopra, Yuri Malenchenko and Tim Peake at the ISS to continue Expedition 47.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA to send commercial 3D printer to space
article: NASA will send a 3D printer, called Additive Manufacturing Facility, to the International Space Station on March 22. Developed by 3D-printing company ‘Made in Space’, the printer is designed to operate in microgravity and is the first commercial manufacturing device being sent to space. Customers can pay the company to use the printer, which can be remotely controlled from Earth.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases detailed gravity map of Mars
article: NASA has released a gravity map of Mars which provides the most detailed view into the interior of the planet so far. Made by three spacecraft, the map makes an improved estimate of the crustal thickness of Mars, confirms the planet has a molten outer core and reveals that four trillion tons of carbon dioxide cycles annually between the poles.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Wearable patch to track diabetes via sweat
article: Researchers have developed a graphene-based wearable skin patch that monitors blood sugar levels through sweat. The prototype detects the temperature and pH/chemical composition of one’s sweat through sensors, and beams the collected data to an accompanying smartphone app. The see-through patch's microneedle array can also inject specific amounts of diabetes medication into a user’s body.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers discover appetite-controlling switch
article: Johns Hopkins University researchers have discovered that the pathway of the OGT enzyme is involved in triggering the appetite-controlling 'switch'. The enzyme, which has been linked to obesity, can detect food signals and then can shut off the desire to eat. The researchers believe that the study could help in controlling obesity and appetite more effectively than through voluntary dieting.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Rare flying snake found in Tamil Nadu
article: A rare Sri Lankan flying snake was spotted in Coimbatore district of Tamil Nadu. The three-feet-long snake was flying from one tree to another before snake rescuers captured it. The flying snake species, which can fly horizontally in air and move at least 20 feet non-stop, gets its name as it is found in certain parts of Sri Lanka.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Sensors to diagnose diseases from exhaled breath
article: A team of South Korean scientists is developing ultrasensitive gas sensors that can diagnose diseases in real-time by analyzing exhaled breath. According to the researchers, the sensors could be integrated with devices like smartphones, electronic wearables and medical devices for monitoring physical conditions. The technology could be utilized for disease diagnosis as well as air quality control.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Solar storms trigger X-ray auroras on Jupiter
article: A new study has caught solar storms creating X-ray auroras on Jupiter that are eight times brighter and “hundreds of times” more energetic than Earth’s auroras. This occurred as solar storms, huge plasma bursts from the sun, interacted with Jupiter’s magnetosphere. The study was conducted using NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory, a telescope that looks at the universe in X-ray.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA captures shockwave for the first time
article: In a first, NASA’s Kepler space telescope has captured a shockwave, which is a bright flash of light sent out by an exploding star at the end of its life. The shockwave lasted for only about 20 minutes, making the event an investigative milestone for astronomers. Notably, the Kepler space telescope is used to hunt for alien planets.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists use fungi for rechargeable batteries
article: In a first, researchers at the University of Dundee have shown that the fungus Neurospora crassa found in a red bread mold could help in creating better electrochemical materials used in rechargeable batteries. In the study, researchers heated the fungi with manganese to form minerals used in lithium-ion batteries and capacitors, that store electric charge in a chemical form.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Nonlinear rotational Doppler effect observed
article: In a first, University of Birmingham scientists have experimentally demonstrated the nonlinear rotational Doppler effect of light, which was first theorized in 1968. The theory points to the wavelength shift of light while passing through a rotating object. Notably, the Doppler effect is the change in frequency of a periodic wave for an observer when moving relative to the source.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method to regenerate heart tissue found
article: US-based MDI Biological Laboratory announced the discovery of mechanisms that can regenerate heart tissue. The study identified a genetic regulator that helps in stimulating the growth of heart muscle cells and removing scar tissues. For this, the research lead studied zebrafish, which shares 70% of the genetic material with humans and has the ability to regenerate its own body parts.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: First spacewalk was performed on this day
article: Russian cosmonaut Alexey Leonov became the first man to walk in space on March 18, 1965. During the 12-minute spacewalk, Leonov’s spacesuit inflated from its internal pressure against the vacuum of space, making it difficult for him to get back into his spacecraft. Ultimately, he opened a valve to depressurize his suit.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Uranus was discovered on this day
article: English astronomer William Hershel discovered Uranus, the seventh planet from the sun, on March 13, 1781. This was the first planet to be discovered by a telescope. The gas giant orbits the sun once every 84 Earth-years and is the only planet to spin perpendicular to its solar orbital plane. It is also the third-largest planet of the solar system.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Spacecraft to probe evidence of life on Mars
article: European and Russian space agencies on Monday successfully launched ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter, an unmanned spacecraft on a mission to find evidence of alien life that exists or may have existed on Mars. The spacecraft, which is expected to complete the 500-million km journey to Mars in seven months, also includes a Mars lander named 'Schiaparelli'.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: February breaks global temperature records
article: According to NASA data, the temperature recorded in February has broken previous records by being 1.35°C warmer than the monthly average calculated over the baseline period (1951-80). Earlier, January had set the previous high by recording 1.15°C over the average, triggering warnings of a climate emergency. Researchers said the long-term rise in global temperature is due to greenhouse gases.
