author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA discovers "bite mark" on Pluto
article: Scientists from NASA have discovered what looks like a giant “bite mark” on Pluto’s surface. This is suspected to have happened due to sublimation, a process that marks the transition of a substance from solid to gas. Scientists believe that the methane ice-rich surface on Pluto may be sublimating away into the atmosphere, subsequently exposing a layer of water-ice.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New drug that can cure breast cancer in 11 days
article: According to a study by English scientists, using Herceptin in combination with another drug may destroy breast cancer tumours in 11 days. Herceptin is one of the first targeted therapies used for treating breast cancer. The tests were conducted on 66 women of which around a quarter of them saw their tumours shrink significantly or disappear in 11 days.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Albert Einstein was born on this day
article: Born on March 14, 1879, renowned theoretical physicist Albert Einstein is remembered for developing the theory of relativity and for his mass–energy equivalence formula E=mc². Further, his work in particle and energy theory made quantum mechanics and, ultimately, the atomic bomb possible. Recently, the Nobel Laureate's prediction of gravitational waves was proved by physicists.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method to repair spine using spongy material
article: Australian researchers have developed a new treatment to repair damaged spines using a biodegradable spongy polymer that acts as a replacement frame through which the bones can regrow after surgery. In the procedure, doctors would insert the polymer into the damaged part, like a titanium rod, which will absorb fluids from within the wound to grow and fill the gap.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers turn carbon dioxide into concrete
article: UCLA researchers have developed a technique to capture carbon dioxide emitted from plants, and use it to create a building material called 'CO2ncrete'. Researchers claimed that this is the first time a solution has been offered to use carbon dioxide, instead of storing it. The method would be used to create building material that can replace cement, the researchers added.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Stars with masses 100x of the sun discovered
article: Using the Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers have discovered nine monster stars that have masses over 100 times the mass of the sun. These stars are situated in the young star cluster of R136, which is about 1,70,000 light-years away from the Earth. Notably, this is the largest sample of monster stars identified to date.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: China gets APAC's largest nuclear security hub
article: The largest nuclear security centre in the Asia-Pacific region opened in Beijing, China on Friday. Financed jointly by China and the US, the centre is capable of training about 2,000 nuclear-security staff. The site will enable international exchanges on nuclear security, demonstrate advanced technology and promote peaceful use of nuclear power. The construction of the centre had begun in 2013.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New process for improved MRI scan developed
article: University of Nottingham scientists have developed a new Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technology that improves scan quality of patients' lungs. The technology, which uses specially treated Krypton gas as an inhalable agent, could provide a virtual view inside the lungs. Traditionally, for MRI scans, hydrogen protons are used which does not give a detailed picture of lungs' interior.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly to retire in April
article: Scott Kelly, the NASA astronaut who recently returned from a year-long mission in space, is retiring on April 1. However, Kelly will continue to participate in NASA’s on-going research on how the human body responds to extended space missions. Notably, Kelly currently holds the American record for the most time spent in space with a total of 520 days.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: Nuclear-capable Agni-I test fired successfully
article: Nuclear-capable ballistic missile Agni-I was successfully test fired today from a mobile launcher from the Integrated Test Range (ITR) at Odisha's Abdul Kalam Island. The intermediate-range surface-to-surface missile, developed indigenously by DRDO, can carry a one-tonne payload and is capable of hitting a target 700 km away. The single-stage missile was first test-fired in January 2002.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: New thumbnail-sized frog species found in K'taka
article: An Indian-led team of international researchers has discovered a new thumbnail-sized species of a frog near the coastal town of Manipal in Karnataka. Named ‘Microhyla Laterite’, the narrow-mouthed frog measures around 1.6 cms, sounds like a cricket and is pale brown with prominent black markings. The researchers have suggested the species to be classified as endangered.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA successfully tests engines for deep space
article: NASA successfully tested the rocket engine designed for the first deep space mission in over 45 years, which includes exploring Mars and an asteroid. The engine RS-25 is a part of NASA's new Space Launch System (SLS) which is set to launch NASA's Orion capsule in 2018 to 43,000 miles beyond the moon as part of its systems testing.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists discover 250 mn-yr-old reptile fossil
article: Scientists have identified a new fossilized reptile that lived around 250 million years ago. The specimen was discovered last year in Brazil. The discovery was found to be a small, quadrupedal animal, that grew up to about 1.5 metres in length. The discovery may help in understanding the origins of dinosaurs, flying reptiles and crocodiles, the researchers said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: ISRO plans to double its launches in a year
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) plans to double its yearly launches. Chairman AS Kiran Kumar said, “We have reached seven launches in a year. We intend to increase it to 12…immediately following to reach up to 18.” Kumar has asked industries “to take bigger stakes in space programmes” by building entire satellites as well as partnering in rocket integration.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method to control window's opacity developed
article: Harvard University researchers have developed a new technique to quickly change a window's opacity using a switch. The window consists of a sheet of plastic or glass, sandwiched between transparent, soft elastomers coated with silver nanowires. Upon supplying electricity, the nanowires get energized and move towards each other, squeezing the elastomers, thereby causing the window to turn opaque.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists find bacteria that can eat plastic
article: Scientists from Japan have discovered a new species of bacteria, called Ideonella sakaiensis 201-F6, that can eat plastic. However, the scientists found that it takes the bacteria six weeks to eat through a thin layer of polyethylene terephthalate (PET), the most common plastic polymer. This is the first known organism that can completely degrade PET.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers create world's thinnest lens
article: A team of Australian National University researchers has created the world's thinnest lens measuring at 6.3 nanometres, which is around 2,000 times thinner than human hair, and with a radius of 10 microns. The previous thinnest lens was measured at 50 nanometres. For this, researchers used nine 0.7-nanometre thick atomic layers of a chemical compound called Molybdenum disulfide.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New foldable shape-shifting material invented
article: Harvard researchers have invented a new type of foldable material whose size, volume and stiffness can be continuously altered. It is made from thin-walled cubes which can fold down or pop-up to create required structures. "This structural system has fascinating implications for dynamic architecture including portable shelters, adaptive building facades and retractable roofs", a researcher said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Researchers develop ice-repellent coating
article: Researchers at the University of Michigan have developed a spray-on ice-repellent coating that can be used to combat icy buildups on car windshields. Further, the rubber-based coating can help a freezer stay frost-free, and also make it 20% more energy efficient. However, the first commercial application for the coating is expected to be related to frozen food packaging.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: ISRO launches India's 6th navigation satellite
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) on Thursday successfully launched its sixth navigation satellite into the Earth’s orbit from Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota. The 1,425-kilogram IRNSS-1F satellite is a part of the Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System (IRNSS) that aims at providing accurate indigenous navigation at par with the US-based Global Positioning System (GPS).

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: VR has a lot of potential: NASA astronaut
article: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly, who tested Microsoft’s HoloLens aboard the International Space Station, has said that “virtual reality has a lot of potential”. He added that the headset can enable scientists on the ground to directly write things in an astronaut's field of view. Kelly also said that the device didn't make anyone feel disoriented in the weightlessness of space.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA delays its next Mars mission to 2018
article: NASA on Wednesday announced that it has delayed the launch of its next Mars mission 'InSight' to May 5, 2018. The mission is aimed at studying and learning more about the Red Planet's interior and the surface. The launch was originally scheduled for this month but was put on hold indefinitely after a leak was discovered in a spacecraft instrument.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Skin that shields objects from radars developed
article: Engineers at the Iowa State University have developed a new stretchable, flexible and adjustable 'meta-skin' that uses array of small liquid metal devices to shield an object from radars. According to the researchers, the skin, which could be used in next generation stealth aircrafts, successfully suppressed about 75% of the radars in the frequency range of 8 to 10 GHz.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: First successful phone call was made 140 yrs ago
article: The world's first ever successful telephone call was made by the device's inventor, Alexander Graham Bell, on March 10, 1876. He had made to call to his assistant in the next room and his words were, "Mr. Watson, come here; I want to see you". Notably, Bell had received a comprehensive telephone patent three days before making the successful call.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Tall mountain captured on dwarf planet Ceres
article: NASA’s Dawn spacecraft has captured images of a tall mountain on Ceres, a dwarf planet situated in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. Named Ahuna Mons, the mountain is five kilometers high on its steepest side and is shaped like a dome. Dawn's principal investigator said, "We still do not have a satisfactory model to explain how it formed."

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA uses citizen observations to track auroras
article: NASA is using science observations made by citizens to track auroras in real-time. This comes after citizens started documenting some of the biggest and most recent aurora displays under 'Aurorasaurus', a citizen science project that enables people to track auroras through its website, mobile app and Twitter. Auroras are dancing, natural light displays caused by geomagnetic storms.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists make plastic from carbon dioxide
article: Stanford scientists have discovered a way to make plastic using carbon dioxide (CO2) and plant materials like grasses and agricultural waste, which they claim could provide an alternative way to create petroleum-made items. The process could notably reduce greenhouse emissions because the required CO2 could be obtained from fossil-fuel plant emissions or other industrial sites, a scientist said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: China plans to land probe on Mars in 2021
article: China plans to land a probe on Mars in 2021 to coincide with the 100th anniversary of the Communist Party of China, the sole governing political party of the country. China’s earlier attempt to send a probe to Mars had failed in 2011. So far, only India, the US, Russia and the European Union have successfully carried out Mars exploration missions.

author: Anupama K
abstract: New TB diagnostic tool likely in a year: ICMR
article: An indigenous and cost-effective diagnostic tool for tuberculosis is expected to be available in a year, said Indian Council of Medical Research's (ICMR) Director General Soumya Swaminathan. If the evaluation of the new diagnostic tool is positive, it may replace GeneXpert, a popular test for detecting TB, added Swaminathan. The diagnostic tool has been made by a Bengaluru-based company.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 1st Mendeleev periodic table arrived on this day
article: Russian chemist Dmitri Mendeleev presented his first periodic table to the Russian Chemical Society on March 6, 1869. The periodic table stated that certain properties of chemical elements repeat periodically when they are classified by atomic weight. This allowed him to even predict properties of undiscovered elements. Notably, Mendeleev’s periodic table was the one to gain universal acceptance.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Google Glass to help remotely track experiments
article: Researchers have found a way to remotely monitor experiments on tiny models of human organs using Google Glass. Such experiments simulate the activities, mechanics and physiological responses of entire organs and organ systems and require near-constant monitoring. Through this, researchers can also run experiments involving highly infectious bacteria or radioactive materials from a safe distance.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Oldest fossilized lizard found in Southeast Asia
article: Scientists have announced the discovery of the oldest fossilized lizard, found in Southeast Asia, which is 99 million years old, 75 million years older than the previous record holder. It was found decades ago but its analysis was reported earlier in the week. The discovery will help in understanding the unknown ecosystem to which the creature belonged, a researcher said.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Graham Bell patented the telephone on this day
article: Alexander Graham Bell received a patent for his invention of the telephone on March 7, 1876. Bell wanted to create a device that combined the aspects of the telegraph and the record player to allow individuals to transmit speech over wires. The first intelligible telephone message, sent from Bell to his assistant, was, “Mr. Watson, come here, I need you”.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists grow 'living lens' in human eye
article: Scientists at the University of California showcased reversing blindness in patients born with a form of cataract by removing the damaged lens and using nearby cells to regrow living lens. The process regenerated the lens and restored vision in three months. Currently, the disease is being treated using an artificial plastic lens, which can cause inflammation and infections among others.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases video of total solar eclipse
article: NASA has released a video of the total solar eclipse that occurred on Wednesday. The eclipse, that occurs when the moon passes directly between the Earth and the sun, was completely visible from parts of Southeast Asia and partially visible from parts of Alaska, Hawaii and India, among others. This marked the first eclipse of 2016.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Possible new octopus species found near Hawaii
article: Scientists have discovered an octopus species on the Pacific Ocean floor near the Hawaiian Islands that does not belong to any of the described genus. The octopus was found at a depth of 4,290 metres underwater by a remotely operated vehicle 'Deep Discoverer'. The octopus does not have the usual shape and colouring associated with octopus found in deep water.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: UK company develops darkest known material
article: A UK-based company called Surrey NanoSystems has developed a new version of Vantablack which is the darkest known material and is capable of absorbing 99.96% of incident light. The new version is said to be darker than the previous one. The company was unable to determine the percentage of the absorbed light as its spectrometers couldn't measure the same.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scalable Quantum computer developed
article: MIT researchers have built a scalable quantum computer, using five atoms, that can be scaled-up to work on universe-scale calculations by increasing the number of atoms. Quantum computers are believed to find factors of a number easily and more efficiently than a classical computer. Since factoring large numbers is difficult, its concept is used in encryption of users' confidential data.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: ISRO to launch 6th IRNSS satellite on March 10
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) will launch its sixth navigation satellite into the Earth’s orbit on March 10. The 1,425-kilogram IRNSS-1F satellite will be launched on a Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle from Sriharikota in Andhra Pradesh. The seventh and the last satellite under the indigenous 'Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System' is also expected to be launched in 2016.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Cause of recurrent multiple miscarriages found
article: Researchers at the University of Warwick have identified that the lack of stem cells in the womb lining is the leading cause of recurrent miscarriages in women. The discovery will help improve the screening of women at risk of recurrent miscarriages and developing drugs and other interventions to help increase the stem cell populations in the womb lining.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Two new Jupiter-like exoplanets discovered
article: A team of astronomers from Chile have discovered two new exoplanets that have characteristics similar to Jupiter. Discovered using the data from NASA's Kepler spacecraft, the gas giant planets have high surface temperatures and an orbital period of less than 10 days. Till date, about 250 transiting Jupiter-like planets (or hot Jupiters) have been discovered.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: India to launch 25 foreign satellites this year
article: India is set to launch 25 foreign satellites belonging to seven countries in 2016-17. The list includes 12 US satellites, three satellites each from Algeria and Canada, and four from Germany. Jitendra Singh, Minister of State in Prime Minister's Office which looks after the Department of Space said that till now India has launched 57 foreign satellites from 21 countries.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Stephen Hawking appears in new Jaguar ad
article: Renowned British physicist Stephen Hawking has made an appearance in Tata Motors-owned Jaguar’s new commercial for its first performance SUV called the F-PACE. The commercial shows Hawking as a “typical British villain” who is the “master of time and space”. Interestingly, Hawking has earlier made on-camera appearances in various shows and movies including 'The Big Bang Theory' and 'Star Trek'.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New way to grow realistic human tissue developed
article: Scientists in Canada have developed a new technique called AngioChip to grow realistic human tissues outside the body, creating a three-dimensional structure with internal blood vessels. According to the researchers, the new advancement could be used for testing drugs on human tissues. So far, the engineers have built living models of liver and heart tissues that function like real organs.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Researchers turn waste gas into liquid fuel
article: MIT researchers recently demonstrated the conversion of waste gas, from power stations, mills and garbage dumps, into liquid fuels using engineered microbes. After a successful trial in China, the process is being planned on a much bigger scale. In the process, the waste gases were first converted into vinegar using bacteria and then into engineered yeast to produce an oil.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA to launch 4th flight of scientific balloon
article: NASA will launch the fourth flight of its football stadium-sized, pumpkin-shaped scientific balloon in April that will carry a 1,025-kilogram payload of scientific instruments. Further, the balloon is expected to circumnavigate the globe once every one to three weeks. With this, NASA plans to set a record for the longest-ever flight, of 100 days, undertaken by a scientific balloon.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: China to launch its 2nd space laboratory in Q3
article: China will launch its second space laboratory, Tiangong 2, into Earth’s orbit in the third quarter of 2016. The country also plans to launch its Shenzhou 11 spacecraft, that will carry two astronauts, in the fourth quarter to dock with Tiangong 2. China had launched its first space laboratory, Tiangong 1, into orbit in 2011.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA to build supersonic passenger jet
article: NASA has begun work to build a supersonic passenger jet claimed to be safer, quieter and more affordable. The agency has awarded its first contract, worth $20 million, to a US-based company to develop a preliminary design of an aircraft which surpasses the speed of sound. The first flight tests of the supersonic aircraft are expected to start around 2020.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists invent thermometer for nanoscale
article: IBM scientists in Switzerland have created a thermometer that can efficiently measure temperature at the nanoscale. To achieve this, signals of heat flux and resistance to heat flow were measured simultaneously. "The technique is analogous to touching a hot plate and inferring its temperature from sensing the heat flux between our own body and the heat source", a co-inventor explained.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 100% efficiency in water-splitting half-reaction
article: In a new study, researchers have achieved 100% efficiency in the reduction step of the two-step process required to split water, breaking the previous record of 60%. Specially designed 50-nm-long nanorods were used in the Photocatalytic water splitting process. The main application of the resulting hydrogen includes providing energy to fuel cells that power electronic devices and vehicles.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: CV Raman discovered the Raman Effect on this day
article: Indian physicist Chandrasekhara Venkata Raman discovered the phenomenon of scattering of light, popularly known as the Raman Effect, on February 28, 1928. The discovery, showing that the wavelength of light changes when deflected by molecules, won Raman the Nobel Prize in 1930, the first time for an Indian. Notably, the day came to be observed as National Science Day since 1986.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Static electricity used as catalyst for 1st time
article: In a first, Australian and Spanish scientists have harnessed static electricity to control a chemical reaction. By changing the polarity and strength of the electric field from outside the test-tube, scientists were able to improve the reaction rate of the Diels-Alder reaction by five times. This new approach can provide the researchers remote control over chemical processes.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Different brain sides handle different numbers
article: According to a study by Imperial College London scientists, the left side of the human brain processes large numbers from a given set of numbers while the right side of the brain processes small numbers. The recently published study could help in rehabilitation techniques for patients who had suffered some form of brain damage that causes difficulty in processing numbers.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists develop mind-controlled wheelchair
article: Scientists at the Duke University have developed a wheelchair that can be controlled by the thoughts of its users. Tested on a lab monkey, the prototype system relies on an implanted Brain-Machine Interface (BMI) that allows for a higher degree of command with less lag. The researchers hope that the technology, aimed at completely paralyzed patients, can eventually be adapted for human use.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA's Hubble breaks cosmic distance record
article: NASA's Hubble telescope has broken the cosmic distance record by measuring the farthest galaxy ever seen in the universe. The galaxy, named GN-z11 is so far that the light from its stars takes 13.4 billion years to reach the Earth. The galaxy is located in the direction of the constellation of Ursa Major.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA invites India to jointly explore Mars
article: Charles Elachi, director of NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, that pilots most American planetary exploration missions, has said that India and the US could jointly explore Mars and has invited India to send astronauts to the Red planet. Referring to India’s Mars Orbiter Mission, Elachi added, “Reaching the Mars orbit in first attempt was an amazing achievement and that too at such low cost”.

author: Anupama K
abstract: Govt plans to set up more nuclear power plants
article: Union Minister Jitendra Singh on Wednesday said that the government is planning to set up new nuclear power plants in Bihar, Haryana and Punjab. The government also aims to increase the nuclear power generation capacity by three times in ten years. If it is 4,780 MW today, the same would go up to 13,480 MW, Singh added.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut returns from space two inches taller
article: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly has become about two inches taller and roughly 8.6 milliseconds younger after his 340-day long stay aboard the International Space Station. However, Earth’s gravity will eventually drag Kelly down to his original height. Kelly had returned to the Earth on March 1, becoming the first US astronaut to spend the most time in space.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: India ready for its second moon mission: ISRO
article: A S Kiran, the Chief of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), has announced that India is ready to conduct its second moon mission, Chandrayaan II. A completely indigenous mission, Chandrayaan II was earlier slated to launch in 2013, but was rescheduled to 2016 due to technical difficulties. Notably, Chandrayaan I, India's first lunar probe, was launched in October 2008.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Proposal to harness artificial trees for power
article: American researchers have recently proposed a new form of wind power wherein artificial mechanical trees would be harnessed for energy. For this, the vibrations or small movements caused by random forces, like a passing gust of wind or oscillations of bridges, would be used. To test, scientists constructed a tree-like device which produced electricity even when there was unnoticeable movement.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists find new exotic subatomic particle
article: Physicists have discovered a new subatomic particle called X(5568), named after its mass. According to the data, the new particle is from an exotic family of tetraquarks, known for having four types of quarks and antiquarks. A quark is an elementary particle and a fundamental constituent of matter which combine to form composite particles like protons and neutrons.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: India to set up lab to study gravitational waves
article: On National Science Day, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday announced that a Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) will be set up in India to study gravitational waves. He said India will contribute to the scientific research within its limited resources. Notably, physicists have recently discovered gravitational waves, a theory first predicted by Albert Einstein in 1916.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: Astronaut Kelly returns to Earth after 340 days
article: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly today returned to Earth after spending 340 days in space aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Kelly has become the first US astronaut to spend the most time in space, at a total of 520 days. Kelly had left for the station on March 27, 2015 to study the effects of microgravity on the human body.

author: Anupama K
abstract: India ranks 90 in terms of energy security: WEF
article: India has been ranked 90th among 126 countries on the basis of their ability to provide secure, affordable and sustainable energy, in a report by the World Economic Forum. Even though the Indian power sector is facing a vast array of challenges, electrification appears to have progressed in the country, the report observed. The list was topped by Switzerland.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA discovers snow-capped mountains on Pluto
article: NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft has released images of a chain of snow-capped mountains on Pluto. Informally named Cthulhu Regio, the mountain range stretches nearly halfway around Pluto’s equator and is a bit larger than the state of Alaska. Approximately 3,000 kilometers long and 750 kilometers wide, the mountains appear to be capped with methane ice condensed from Pluto's atmosphere.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New breast cancer drug that slows tumour growth
article: UK scientists have engineered a new breast cancer treatment that can slow down the tumour growth by nine months, delaying the need for chemotherapy. It was formed by combining a new treatment called palbociclib with an established hormone drug called fulvestrant. In 67% of the cases, the drug either reduced the tumour size or controlled the disease for six months.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Physicists make energy-efficient magnetic memory
article: Dutch physicists have discovered a new way to make Magnetic Random Access Memory (MRAM) more efficient by using a current pulse. MRAM is faster and more efficient than other kinds of data storage but requires high volume of electrical power. The new concept uses current pulse to bend the electrons in an MRAM bit, making it faster and more energy-efficient.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists find how Zika virus attacks foetus
article: Scientists in the US believe that they have discovered how Zika virus attacks a foetal brain. The team worked on lab-grown human stem cells and found that the virus selectively infected the cells that formed the brain's cortex, neural tissues' outer layer. These lab-grown cells could be used to protect the cells from infections or ease existing infections, researchers suggested.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Rubber products can cause cancer: WHO
article: According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), a chemical called MBT, which is used in rubber manufacturing and found in things like rubber gloves and car tyres, could cause cancer. A research by a UK-based professor linked large amounts of MBT to bladder and blood cancer. However, small amounts in everyday products are not likely to be harmful, he said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Brain reactions to teleportation studied
article: In a published study, a team from the University of California has measured brain's response to a virtual teleportation. For this, patients suffering from a severe form of epilepsy were studied using electrodes, as they navigated a virtual environment during seizures. Researchers found that the brain activity and oscillations were not interrupted while navigating inside the virtual environment.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create 1st biological supercomputer
article: Researchers from the ABACUS project have created world's first biological supercomputer, that uses proteins instead of electrons to relay information around a small circuit. The proteins are powered by adenosine triphosphate, the energy provider to all the human cells. The supercomputer processes information quickly and accurately using parallel networks, like in electronic supercomputers.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists trace 'Fast Radio Burst' for 1st time
article: For the first time, researchers have pinpointed the origin of a 'Fast Radio Burst', FRB150418, which released two days worth of Sun's energy in a fraction of a second. These bursts are energetic pulses that originate from random locations in the sky and last for a few milli-seconds. Astronomers have witnessed 17 such bursts but could never trace the origin.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Japan launches new space observatory ASTRO-H
article: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) has launched a new space observatory called ASTRO-H. The observatory is designed to study celestial objects that emit X-rays like black holes, dying stars and galaxy clusters. The sixth in a series of JAXA’s X-ray astronomy satellites, ASTRO-H is capable of detecting X-rays more than 10 times fainter than its telescope predecessor, Suzaku.

author: Anupama K
abstract: Govt gives approval for LIGO-India project
article: The government today gave an "in-principle" approval for establishing a Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) project in India, in collaboration with USA's LIGO Laboratory. "The approval coincides with the historic detection of gravitational waves a few days ago that opened up a new window to the universe to unravel some of its greatest mysteries," a government statement said.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists reverse some autism symptoms in mice
article: A study by MIT researchers conducted on mice revealed that some behavioural symptoms associated with autism can be reversed by tweaking a gene called Shank3. The gene helps the brain cells communicate with each other. Mice which lacked the gene and showed autism-like behaviour were bred and it was found that tweaking the gene reversed some of that behaviour.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Five Jupiter-like planets discovered
article: UK-based scientists have discovered five Jupiter-like planets, according to a research published in arXiv journal. The radii of the planets, designated as WASP-119b, WASP-124b, WASP-126b, WASP 129b and WASP-133b, is 1 to 1.5 times that of Jupiter's radius. Their orbital period around a star varies from 2.17-5.75 days and their masses range from 0.3 to 1.2 times of Jupiter's mass.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: ISRO to build satellite to monitor air pollution
article: ISRO is set to collaborate with the University of Toronto for a nano-satellite that will monitor the air pollution levels in some of the most polluted cities like Delhi, Lucknow and Amritsar. It will reportedly be placed 500 km above the Earth's surface, and will analyse the sunlight reflected from the earth's surface to determine the nature of suspended particles.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases image of Pluto's north pole
article: NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft has captured an image of Pluto’s north pole, revealing ancient frozen canyons on the dwarf planet. According to the space agency, the deteriorating walls of the canyons are proof of their age, as Pluto's younger canyons look more sharply defined. The biggest canyon on the polar surface is about 75 kilometers wide.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Sea sponges were earth's 1st animals: Research
article: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have claimed that sea sponges were likely the first animals on earth. Sea sponges are the source of a molecule found in 640-million-year-old rocks, which predate the Cambrian explosion, researchers said. Cambrian explosion was an evolutionary period that began around 540 million years ago, during which a large number of new animals appeared.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Unseen region of Milky Way galaxy mapped
article: A telescope at the European Southern Observatory, for the first time, captured a clear image of the southernmost part of the Milky Way, mapping it with high-resolution images. The blue portions represent hot material while the red represents colder regions where star formation will occur. The completed map of the Galactic Plane will help understand the creation of the galaxy.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Boeing patents tech to 3D-print objects mid-air
article: Boeing has patented a technology to 3D-print objects while they are levitating in space. The technology uses multiple printing heads that can increase the speed of printing many-fold. Further, it uses a central nugget of magnetic material that can be twisted as necessary, allowing access to the objects from all sides. Boeing plans to 3D-print aircraft parts using this technology.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: 'Cyberforests' created to predict climate change
article: Scientists at the Washington State University have created 'cyberforests', a computer system that makes 3D forests to study how drought, wildfires and climate-related changes affect forests. The project named 'LES', Russian word for 'trees', includes 100x100 metre stands of drought and shade tolerant trees. The system lets scientists project the impact on forests from changing climatic conditions.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Google science competition for students now open
article: Google has started accepting entries for the 2016 edition of its annual global science competition for students called ‘Google Science Fair’. Individuals and teams between the age of 13 and 18 can participate in the competition free of cost by submitting their science and technology projects till May 18. Further, Google will announce the global finalists on August 11.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Nasa discovers interstellar magnetic field
article: Using data from NASA's Interstellar Boundary Explorer (IBEX) and simulations of the interstellar boundary, scientists have precisely determined the strength and direction of the magnetic field outside the heliosphere. Heliosphere is a bubble-like region of space around the Sun, which extends beyond Pluto's orbit. The study revealed the origin of so-called IBEX ribbon, which was discovered in 2009.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Next NASA telescope to see 100x more than Hubble
article: NASA is developing a new space telescope with a field of view 100 times larger than that of the Hubble Space Telescope. Called Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope (WFIRST), it will also block the glare of individual stars, making it easier to determine the chemical makeup of exoplanets. WFIRST is slated for launch in mid-2020.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Coffee counters liver damage caused by alcohol
article: A review of nine existing studies revealed that drinking more cups of coffee a day could reduce the liver damage caused by drinking too much alcohol. The studies took in more than 4,30,000 people, including 1,990 patients suffering from liver cirrhosis, and found that four extra cups of coffee each day lowers the chance of developing the disease by 65%.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Homeopathy ineffective for most diseases: Study
article: According to a study published in the British Medical Journal, homeopathy, a system of alternative medicine, was found to be effective on zero out of 68 illnesses. The research, penned by Bond University's Professor Paul Glasziou, concluded that "there was no reliable evidence from research in humans that homeopathy was effective for treating the range of health conditions considered".

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA gets record 18,300 astronaut applications
article: NASA on Friday announced that it has received a record 18,300 applications from people who want to become astronauts. This has broken NASA's previous record of receiving 8,000 applications in 1978. However, out of all the applicants, 8-14 individuals will be selected to pursue the NASA's astronaut class that is expected to be announced in the middle of 2017.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases audio recording from space
article: NASA has released a 'strange' audio recording from the space that was first heard by Apollo 10 astronauts when they were circling the Moon in 1969. The space agency said that the unusual whistling noises, which lasted for about an hour, was likely caused due to radio interference. The audio was aired on a TV show that features NASA stories.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronauts to return from space after a year
article: The first one-year crew aboard the International Space Station (ISS) will return to the Earth on March 1. The three-member crew has spent record 340 days in space, which is twice the typical duration of a space mission. Before leaving, Expedition 46 Commander Scott Kelly will officially hand over the command of the ISS to fellow NASA astronaut Tim Kopra.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists grow sperm in lab from stem cells
article: A team at the Nanjing Medical University, China, has successfully made mouse sperm in the lab, which was used to fertilise eggs giving birth to baby mice. The team took embryonic stem cells and used a mixture of hormones, testicular cells and chemicals to turn those into 'spermatids', which eventually turned into sperm after successive meiotic divisions and saturation.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Mathematical model explains how things go viral
article: Scientists have designed the first mathematical model explaining how things go viral online. For this, transmission of social phenomena was compared to that of infectious diseases. "The model shows that people's opposition to accept a new idea acts as a barrier to large contagion until the transmission of the phenomenon becomes strong enough to overcome that reluctance", the study stated.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Stress can increase diabetes risk in offsprings
article: A study, published in the journal Cell Metabolism, revealed that stress hormones cause a change in sperm that gives offspring high blood sugar, meaning stressed men could increase diabetes risk in their children. The study showed that increase in stress hormones adds extra methyl groups to an inheritable gene called Sfmbt2, which results in higher blood sugar in offsprings.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New study links impatience and faster aging
article: A new study done by the National University of Singapore on 1,100 students revealed that impatient people age prematurely. In the study, students had to choose between an immediate cash reward or a bigger reward in future. The team then found the impatient ones had shorter telomeres, the protective caps on the end of chromosomes that grows shorter on aging.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Big-brained mammals more likely to go extinct
article: A study by scientists at the Stanford University, California, has revealed that the mammals with bigger brains are more likely to go extinct. A professor examined samples from over 760 different species of animals and found a clear pattern suggesting the same. In the Americas, this relation was especially strong for mammals with a bigger brain relative to body size.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Physicists simulate five-dimensional black holes
article: For the first time, physicists have simulated the black holes of a five-dimensional world. The simulation, created in the UK, revealed that the intense gravity of five-dimensional black holes would "break down" the laws of physics. These black holes have been hypothesised as very thin rings, instead of holes, which give rise to a series of 'bulges' as it evolves.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Aus surgeon 1st to implant 3D-printed vertebrae
article: An Australian neurosurgeon, Ralph Mobbs performed a surgery by implanting 3D-printed titanium vertebrae in a 60-year-old patient suffering from chordoma, a rare form of cancer that occurs in bones. This was the first time such an operation had been attempted. Mobbs worked with an Australian medical device manufacturer to create perfect replicas of the patient's top two vertebrae for practice.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Astronomers study super Earth's atmosphere
article: Scientists for the first time have studied the atmosphere of a super Earth, called 55 Cancri e, and found a highly poisonous form of hydrogen, called hydrogen cyanide, and helium. The scientists at the University College London also found that the planet is tidally locked, that means there is a permanent 'day' and a 'night' side of the planet.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New polymer that can lift 1,000 times its weight
article: Scientists at the University of Rochester have developed a new polymer that can lift 1,000 times its own weight and can be programmed to hold a temporary shape. The material shifts shape based on its temperature and the amount by which it is stretched. This type of shape-memory polymer could have applications such as for artificial skin and self-fitting apparel.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Thomas Edison was born on this day
article: Thomas Alva Edison, the inventor of the electric light bulb was born on February 11, 1847, in the United States of America's Milan city in Ohio. Edison was home-schooled by his mother and holds a record number of 2,332 patents. The last breath of Edison, who died of diabetes on October 18, 1931, was reportedly saved in a test tube.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: SpaceX to attempt fourth sea landing on Feb 24
article: Elon Musk's SpaceX will attempt to land its reusable Falcon 9 rocket on a floating landing pad in the Pacific Ocean for the fourth time on February 24. The rocket will launch a satellite, which will provide “replacement and incremental capacity for a prime video neighbourhood over Asia”. SpaceX has not been successful in landing its rocket at sea, yet.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA makes its travel posters available for free
article: NASA is giving away its series of vintage-inspired travel posters that were designed for its Jet Propulsion Laboratory's Visions of the Future project. The posters, designed by Don and Ryan Clark, are available for free download online. Each poster represents a specific historic space mission like the Voyager's Grand Tour, the discovery of Saturn's moon Enceladus and the Mars exploration program.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Human tissue-printing 3D bioprinter developed
article: A team of scientists in the US has developed a new 3D bioprinter called the Integrated Tissue and Organ Printing System that can print human tissues made of living cells. The team has so far printed an ear, part of a jawbone, muscle, and cartilage structures. The 3D printed tissues are strong enough to replace human tissues, the researchers reported.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA's Curiosity rover shares Valentine's cards
article: NASA's Curiosity rover today shared a series of Valentine's Day cards from Mars through its Twitter account. The cards feature images taken by the rover with puns like "You make a big impact on me," on a heart-shaped crater. Another card featuring Curiosity's wheel says, "I like the way you roll!"

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Creator of periodic table was born on this day
article: Dmitri Mendeleev, who formulated the periodic table of chemical elements in 1869, was born on February 8, 1834, in Siberia. The modern periodic table used today is an expanded and refined version of Mendeleev's periodic table. Mendeleev organised the elements in increasing order of their atomic masses while the current one is arranged in increasing order of atomic number.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Quality of teaching needs to improve: CNR Rao
article: Bharat Ratna-awardee scientist CNR Rao said today that the ability of teachers in the country and the quality of their teaching needs to improve. He said, “[M]ost teachers themselves don't know enough... and they are teaching our 11th class and 12th class children". Rao was speaking on the sidelines of an event where he announced the 8th annual nanotechnology show 'Bangalore India Nano 2016'.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: New luminous creatures discovered in the Red Sea
article: A team of biologists have discovered a new species of light-emanating fauna in the Red Sea. The team while studying the biodiversity of coral reefs near the Farasan area, South of Red Sea, noticed “fluorescent lantern” polyp hydrae-like creatures. The researchers claim that the glow in these creatures may be a mechanism to attract prey.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: ISRO to launch cryogenic engine satellite
article: Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) will launch the Cryogenic mark-III based GSLV satellite launch vehicle in December, according to senior ISRO official Dr K Sivan. This will be the first time India will use electric propulsion to launch a satellite. The high-thrust cryogenic engine (CE20) was recently test-fired at the ISRO Propulsion Complex (IPRC) in Mahendragiri.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: #gravitationalwaves trending on Twitter today
article: On the day after Gravitational Waves were discovered, #gravitationalwaves was a top Twitter trend in India on Friday. A user excited about the discovery tweeted, "So you read about this supernova some billion light years away and go, that was a long time ago dude! #GravitationalWaves? Now that's cool!". Users appreciated Einstein with tweets reading, "Einstein does it again".

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Video explains concept of gravitational waves
article: A video released by 'The Verge' explains the concept of gravitational waves. The discovery of gravitational waves, proposed by Albert Einstein in 1916, was confirmed on Thursday. Gravitational waves are ripples in the curvature of spacetime propagating as waves, travelling outward from the source, transporting energy as radiation. The discovery could help scientists understand the 'Big Bang'.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: OK Go releases new video shot in zero gravity
article: American band 'OK Go' has shot its latest video, 'Upside Down & Inside Out', in zero gravity inside a reduced gravity Russian aircraft. The video was captured in a single take over eight consecutive periods of weightlessness of 27 seconds each. During this time, the band members are seen floating in the air. Notably, the video debuted exclusively on Facebook.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 1st human genome analysis published on this day
article: The first complete analysis of individual human genomes was published on February 15, 2001. Human genomes are entire sets of genes and their respective DNA sequences across all chromosome pairs. This was the first vertebrate to be completely sequenced, and the draft analysis covered over 90% of all human genomes. The resulting data is used in several fields like biomedical science and forensics.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: UK designing cement that can endure radiation
article: British scientists are designing a new type of cement that could withstand the impact of intense radiation for over 100,000 years. The project could prove vital in dealing with the challenges of Britain’s proposed expansion of its nuclear industry. It was estimated that about 300,000 cubic metres of highly radioactive intermediate waste will have accumulated in the UK by 2030.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Ethnicity influences flu vaccine effect: Study
article: Scientists in the US have found that ethnicity and other inherited factors influence the effect of vaccines against common influenza A virus. The study was based on a gene which is responsible for making protein antibodies and exists in 14 different forms. It was also revealed that some of those forms were more effective when responding to the flu virus.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method to create ultra-thin lens developed
article: Engineers at the University of Utah have developed a new method to create flat and ultra-thin optical lens, called super-achromatic lens, that could perform the basic image producing function. The designed lens could be 10 times thinner than the width of a human hair and can be made of any transparent material like plastic or glass.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Mini-brains created to replace animal testing
article: As an alternative to animal testing, scientists from the Bloomberg School, US, have developed “mini-brains” from human cells to better test drugs. About the size of a housefly, the mini-brains are 350 micrometers in diameter and are made by reprogramming adult skin cells into embryonic stem cells. Further, scientists said that most drugs tested on mice don’t work on humans.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: US startup develops glowing plants
article: A US startup has developed glowing plants that provide natural light without electricity. The glowing plant uses DNA from luminous living organisms like fireflies and other bacteria. These DNAs are collected and imbibed into real plants which glow in the dark. These plants are made using synthetic biology and a special software called Genome Compiler.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Honey destroys blindness-causing fungus: Study
article: As per a study by researchers of the UK's University of Manchester, honey can destroy harmful pathogenic fungi that can cause blindness and even death in vulnerable people. After finding the link between Surgihoney, a medicinal type of honey, and the destruction of fungus Fusarium, researchers concluded that "honey as a healing agent works better than some antifungals".

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Device aims to control robotic limbs by thoughts
article: Australian scientists have developed a device called Stentrode that could allow patients to control robotic or bionic limbs using only their thoughts. The matchstick-sized device will be implanted in a blood vessel over the brain, and will convert brain signals into electrical commands that could wirelessly move exterior body parts. Currently, most bionic limbs are controlled by a joystick.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: Zika virus can stay hidden: Researchers
article: According to researchers, the Zika virus can hide itself in human organs, like eyes, placenta, testes and the brain, that are protected by the immune system. “The virus can continue to persist and or multiply,” a researcher said. This reportedly makes it harder to fight the virus and increases the time in which the virus can spread.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut posts video of lightning from space
article: British astronaut Tim Peake has released a time-lapse video showing how lightning storms hitting the Earth look like from space. He tweeted, “Amazing how much lightning can strike our planet in a short time”. The video was taken as the International Space Station (ISS) was flying over North Africa and Turkey and moving towards Russia.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Discovery of gravitational waves announced
article: Physicists have announced the discovery of gravitational waves, ripples in spacetime, first predicted by Albert Einstein in 1916 as an outgrowth of his theory of relativity. The discovery could pave the way for gaining insights into the formation of the universe, what Einstein called the 'Big Bang'. The early universe was opaque to electromagnetic waves but not to gravitational waves.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Brain cells that cause loneliness discovered
article: In a first, a team of scientists at the MIT has identified the region causing the feeling of loneliness – Dorsal Raphe Nucleus (DRN) – which is present near the back of the brain. The study conducted on mice revealed that the DRN strengthens and motivates social animals to seek out the company of others after periods of isolation.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists experience Martian surface on Earth
article: Scientists at NASA can now experience the surface of Mars directly from Earth by using Microsoft’s augmented reality headset HoloLens. NASA and Microsoft had forged a partnership last year to let astronauts and scientists collaborate remotely through HoloLens. Further, the device will be sent to the International Space Station on SpaceX’s seventh commercial resupply mission on June 28.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Researchers identify drug target to stop dengue
article: Researchers from American Society for Microbiology claim that a protein found in the dengue virus called 'NS4B' can be a promising target to develop anti-viral dengue treatment. The team found that a compound present in common pain relievers inhibits the dengue virus from replicating. The findings will help in developing a vaccination or a treatment procedure for dengue.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Sixth man to walk on moon dies aged 85
article: The sixth man to walk on the moon, astronaut Edgar Mitchell, died on Thursday at the age of 85 years in Florida. As part of the Apollo 14 mission in 1971, he worked over nine hours on the Moon's surface. Mitchell and Apollo 14 commander Alan Shepard Jr set the record for the longest lunar stay time at 33 hours.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: China releases true color, HD photos of moon
article: The China National Space Administration has released hundreds of true colour, high-definition images of the moon. The images were taken in 2013 when the Chang’e 3 mission soft-landed on the moon, making China the third country to achieve this feat after Russia and the United States. Further, it was the first soft-landing on the moon in 37 years.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: First artificial graphene created
article: A group of scientists led by an Indian-origin researcher Srimanta Middey, has created an artificial material with similar structure as graphene. In comparison to silicon transistors for computers, graphene transistors are believed to be faster and more heat tolerant and efficient. "This discovery gives us the ability to create graphene-like structures for many other elements," said Middey.

author: Amritanshu Anand
abstract: Fusion reactor goes online after 19 yrs of work
article: Germany's Max Planck Institute for Plasma Physics switched on Wendelstein 7-X, the first large fusion reactor. The reactor took 19 years to design and is built at a cost of about $1.3 billion. It currently produces hydrogen plasma and won't generate energy. The inaugural test phase will run through mid-March.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Video explains all about Zika virus
article: Declared as a "global public health emergency" by the WHO, the Zika virus is caused by the Aedes mosquito. Babies born to women infected by the virus have abnormally small heads resulting in brain damage. However, 80% of infected adults show no symptoms. Since May 2015, the virus has already spread over 22 countries mostly in South and North America.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Evidence of life seen in Earth's mantle: Study
article: A study by scientists has found that rock samples from the Earth’s shallow mantle have shown signs of life, evidenced by the presence of hydrogen and methane. The samples were collected by drillings from an underwater mountain in the Atlantic Ocean. The study  could help scientists get an insight into how life could exist on other planets.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: 1st Zika vaccine made in India, scientists claim
article: The world's first vaccine against the Zika Virus has been developed in India as per claims by scientists at the Bharat Biotech International Limited in Hyderabad. The organisation said that two vaccines to fight Zika were developed. They claimed that they were probably the world's first vaccine company "to file a vaccine candidate patent about nine months ago" on Zika.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Lifespan increasing drug made, claim researchers
article: Researchers from USA’s Mayo Clinic have claimed to have developed a pill that can extend the lifespan of humans. The drug was administered to mice, successfully removing the non-dividing accumulated senescent cells, increasing the lifespan of the mice by up to 35%. Scientists claim that administering the drug to clear these cells could improve health and lifespan in humans.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA's new video explains Sun's magnetic field
article: NASA has released a video, with real-time observations and computer simulations, explaining how the magnetic field of the Sun works. The invisible magnetic field is responsible for everything from solar explosions to interplanetary radiation, and it can be observed through the guided motion of super-hot charged particles. However, it is not known where in the Sun the magnetic field is created.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Europe's 1st space-based data satellite launched
article: The first satellite of the European Space Agency’s (ESA) SpaceDataHighway project has blasted off to space aboard a Proton rocket from Kazakhstan. The project, also called European Data Relay System, aims to launch a constellation of geostationary satellites that can receive and transmit data in near real-time. This system will help in faster monitoring of natural disasters.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Moon formed after a head-on collision: Study
article: A research from the University of California, LA has claimed that the moon was formed after a head-on collision between Earth and another forming planet 'Theia'. Previously the 4.5 billion-year-old collision was considered an oblique one. The study said that similarity in composition between lunar and Earth's volcanic rocks showed that only a head-on collision could have made this possible.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Youngest conjoined twins separated in Geneva
article: Lydia and Maya have become the world's youngest conjoined twins to be separated successfully. The sisters were operated in Geneva, Switzerland, for separation on the eighth day after their birth. The surgery of the duo, attached at the liver and chest, reportedly had 1% chance of success. Since they suffered from a life-threatening disease, they were not operated at birth.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: New non-addictive, powerful painkiller developed
article: Scientists from Tulane University School of Medicine, US, have synthesized a new endomorphic painkiller that is as strong as morphine but is not addictive and has fewer side-effects. Comparative tests gauging differences between morphine and the new drug were conducted on rats. The new drug, if employed on humans, may reduce morphine drug abuse and associated motor and respiratory side-effects.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Alan Shepard played golf on Moon on this day
article: On February 6, 1971, former NASA astronaut Alan Shepard became the first and the only human to play golf on the surface of the Moon. The second man to travel into space, Shephard secretly carried a six-iron golf club covered with a sock on the Apollo 14 mission. He later donated that golf club to the USGA Museum in 1974.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA captures image of merging galaxies
article: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has captured an image in which two or more galaxies are in the act of merging together to form a single new galaxy. The resultant galaxy, NGC 1487, is situated about 30 million light-years away in the southern constellation of Eridanus. Each galaxy has lost its original appearance as its stars have been displaced by gravity.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut posts image of Himalayas from space
article: NASA astronaut Scott Kelly has posted an image of the Himalayas as seen from space. He tweeted, “The cracking blue ice of the #Himalayas. Brilliant!” Currently aboard the International Space Station, Kelly is on a year-long mission to live in space and is known to periodically post awe-inspiring pictures of the Earth.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Floating hills of water-ice found on Pluto
article: According to the data received from NASA's New Horizons spacecraft, numerous hills of water-ice are floating atop frozen nitrogen on Pluto. The hills, situated on a vast ice plain named Sputnik Planum, move like icebergs floating on nitrogen, carbon monoxide and methane that has the "texture of toothpaste". This happens because "water ice is less dense than nitrogen-dominated ice".

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: First unchained spacewalk was made on this day
article: The world's first ever unchained spacewalk was made by Captain Bruce McCandless and Colonel Robert Stewart on February 7, 1984. They walked freely for 5 hours 55 minutes and orbited the Earth in tangent with their space shuttle 'Challenger' moving at a speed of over 17,500 miles/hour. The duo flew up to 320 feet away from the space shuttle.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Film to conduct current on lenses conceptualized
article: A team of scientists from the Future Industries Institute of the University of South Australia has successfully conceptualized a new polymer film coating that can conduct electric current on a contact lens. The development of the published research can be used to build contact lenses embedded with a minute electrical circuit that would be safe to wear.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Mice can reproduce without Y-chromosome: Study
article: A study by researchers from the University of Hawaii claims that in an experiment, they have been able to oversee successful reproduction by male mice which don't have the Y-chromosome. The experiment included enhancing two specific genes critical for reproduction in those male mice. The creation of functioning reproductive cells in the mice may help treat genetic male infertility.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Phases of moon affects rainfall on Earth: Study
article: A study by researchers from New University of Washington has shown that lunar forces of the moon affect the amount of rainfall on Earth. When the moon is overhead or underfoot the air pressure is greater, which increases the weight and temperature of the atmosphere, causing the moisture absorption capacity to rise, which decreases rainfall in the area.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases 360° video of Mars on Facebook
article: NASA has released a 360° video of Mars on Facebook, enabling viewers to immersively explore the surface of the planet. The video was produced by stitching together photos taken by NASA’s Curiosity Mars Rover and using the "technology created by the 360 video team at Facebook". Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said, “You can look around like you're actually on the planet".

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Indian students develop budget amateur telescope
article: Undergraduates from the Indian Institute of Science Education and Research, Trivandrum, have constructed an affordable and portable amateur radio telescope, along with affordable data analysis tools for schools and colleges. These telescopes could be used to make radio astronomy-related discoveries. A similarly constructed telescope was used to measure the brightness temperature of the sun.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: UK approves genetic modification of human embryo
article: In a first, the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority of UK on Monday approved the genetic modification of human embryos. It would, however, be illegal to implant the modified embryos into women, the authority said. The experiments, which will take place in the first seven days after fertilisation, will help study infertility and the reasons behind miscarriage.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases VR video of flying drone
article: NASA has released a virtual reality video of its battery-powered GL-10 (or Greased Lightning) drone. The video shows the drone flying in the sky, letting users experience the flight in 360°. The drone is a 28-kilogram prototype that can switch between helicopter and airplane modes, enabling it to take off vertically like a chopper, and fly at speed like an airplane.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Computer beats man in Chinese game for 1st time
article: In a major breakthrough for artificial intelligence, a computer program has for the first time defeated a professional player in the ancient Chinese board game of ‘Go’. Developed by Google-owned company DeepMind, AlphaGo has defeated over three-time European Champion Fan Hui by 5-0. Earlier, the strongest computer programs were only able to play at the level of human amateurs.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Video: SpaceX tests spacecraft to ferry humans
article: Elon Musk’s space company, SpaceX, has released a video showing a successful engine test of its Crew Dragon spacecraft that is expected to ferry astronauts to and from the International Space Station in 2017. The spacecraft aims at using eight SuperDraco thrusters to slow down while landing, instead of parachutes, and wants to land with the accuracy of a helicopter.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New technique can print shape shifting objects
article: A team from Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering at Harvard University has developed a technique to print transformable objects. These objects can change shape depending on the changes in the surrounding environment, such as changes in temperature or passing of electric current. This development can have future applications such as in electronics or for creating medical implants.

author: Dishant Sharma
abstract: Blood pressure drug can slow Alzheimer’s: Study
article: A study published by researchers from Georgetown University Medical Center claims that drugs used to treat blood pressure conditions are helpful in reducing cell damage associated with Alzheimer's disease. Candesartan, a drug used by patients of hypertension, was experimentally found to prevent inflammation and glutamate-induced neuron-cell death, the definitive indicators of Alzheimer's disease.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: NASA's Curiosity rover shares a selfie from Mars
article: NASA's Curiosity rover shared a selfie from Mars which shows a car-size  mobile laboratory and an active sand dune from where the rover has been picking samples of sand. The selfie has been taken by the Mars Hand Lens Imager fixed at the end of Curiosity's arm. The rover has been exploring the surface of Mars since August 2012.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: China to develop new supercomputer in 2 years
article: China is planning to develop an "exascale" supercomputer that will be capable of performing more than a billion billion calculations per second. The prototype for such a computer will be released in either 2017 or 2018. The supercomputer will be 1,000 times more powerful than China’s Tianhe-1A, which was identified as the world's fastest computing system in 2010.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Dinosaur found in 2014 could be oldest: Study
article: The new species of carnivorous dinosaur discovered in 2014 could possibly be the oldest known Jurassic dinosaur, according to a new study. The specimen, which was discovered by Welsh paleontologists, was estimated to be 200 million years old. The full analysis of the remains revealed that the animal was a theropod dinosaur and was an ancestor of modern birds.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: US blizzard as seen from space through moonlight
article: NASA has released an image of the 2016 blizzard, that recently hit the USA, as seen from space through moonlight. The image displays clouds lit from above by the nearly full Moon and from below by city lights. The blizzard has killed at least 19 people and an emergency has been declared in around 12 states for the same.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop concrete that can melt ice
article: US-based scientists have recently developed a new variety of concrete that can melt snow using electricity, an advancement that could provide a low-cost and efficient method to de-ice roads in the winters. A University of Nebraska–Lincoln professor, who designed the concrete, added carbon particles and steel shavings to the concrete recipe enabling it to generate enough electricity to melt snow.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists create affordable smart windows
article: A group of scientists at the MIT has figured out a way to create affordable smart windows using a rubber-like polymer which can control the amount of light transmission, depending on its thinness and stretchiness. The scientists have structured an equation that can predict the same, and combined it with an experiment that uses small dyed pieces of the polymer.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: 135 mn-yr-old dinosaur fossil found in Gujarat
article: A team of geologists and paleontologists have found a 135 million-year-old dinosaur fossil in Kutch, Gujarat. Known to be the oldest dinosaur fossil discovered in this century, scientists believe that the dinosaur was a herbivore with at least 10 to 15 metre in length. Its specimen has been sent to the paleontology institute in Munich to confirm the dinosaur's species.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New antibiotic protein discovered in breast milk
article: According to British scientists, an antibiotic protein developed from human breast milk could fight against certain drug-resistant bacteria. A protein fragment less than a nanometer in width called lactoferrin is responsible for the anti-microbial properties. A panel set up by UK Prime Minister David Cameron estimated that, if untreated, these bacteria could cost around 10 million lives by 2050.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: India-born physicist gets Australia's top honour
article: Indian-origin physicist Professor Chennupati Jagadish was on Tuesday awarded Australia's highest civilian honour, the Companion of the Order of Australia (AC). The award was in recognition of his service in physics and engineering. Professor Jagadish was born and educated in India and currently heads the Semiconductor Optoelectronics and Nanotechnology Group at the Australian National University.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: SpaceX tests parachutes that will return humans
article: NASA on Wednesday released a video of SpaceX testing parachutes that will bring astronauts back to the Earth. The drop test, performed in Arizona, involved four large parachutes that were carried thousands of feet above the ground on a C-130 cargo aircraft. They were rigged to deploy as they would when SpaceX’s spacecraft actually returns astronauts from the International Space Station.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: CO2 can be directly converted to methanol: Study
article: A study, led by GK Surya Prakash from the University of Southern California, revealed the first ever direct conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2), captured from air, to methanol using a homogeneous catalyst. To achieve this, scientists developed a stable catalyst, that didn't break down at high temperatures, and used it to speed up the chemical reactions to produce methanol.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Huge gas cloud boomerangs back to Milky Way
article: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has discovered that Smith Cloud, a huge hydrogen gas cloud launched from the Milky Way galaxy around 70 million years ago, is on a return collision course at nearly 7,00,000 miles per hour. It is expected to collide into the galactic disc in 30 million years and burst out enough gas to make two million suns.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New test to predict success of IVF treatment
article: Fertility experts have discovered a specific genetic pattern in the womb that can help in predicting whether IVF would likely be successful or not. IVF is the process of manually fertilizing an egg, and then shifting the embryo to the uterus. For the study, biopsies from women with recurrent implantation failure were compared with those who underwent the treatment successfully.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Mitsubishi develops antenna from seawater
article: Japanese automotive manufacturer Mitsubishi has developed a new antenna called SeaAerial, that uses seawater instead of metallic conductors. The antenna shoots seawater aimed at the sky to transmit and receive radio-frequency waves. The setup also includes a special insulated nozzle that determines the ideal diameter of the jet of seawater which was able to achieve an efficiency of 70%.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronomers discover widest solar system ever
article: Astronomers have discovered the widest known solar system to man, with a huge planet situated about a trillion kilometres away from its sun. One entire revolution of the planet, called 2MASS J2126, takes around 9,00,000 Earth years to complete. Notably, both celestial bodies have been individually known since eight years, but an association was implied only recently.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Stephen Hawking and Paul Rudd play Quantum Chess
article: The Caltech's Institute for Quantum Information and Matter roped in Ant-Man actor Paul Rudd and renowned physicist Stephen Hawking to fight against each other in a game of Quantum Chess. Narrated by Matrix actor Keanu Reeves, the game was dramatised with the aim to demystify the concepts of quantum mechanics. Interestingly, Rudd wins the game.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA Opportunity rover completes 12 yrs on Mars
article: NASA’s Mars Opportunity rover has completed 12 years on the red planet, even though it was only designed to operate for 90 days. The rover, that took six and a half months to land on Mars, costs about $14 million per year to operate. NASA believed it would only function for 90 days because of the extreme level of dust on Mars.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: 'Fish with legs' discovered in New Zealand
article: The Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa has released a photo of a creature described as "fish with legs" that was discovered by scientists in New Zealand. The photo was released on Facebook saying, "This weird creature is likely to be a species of Frogfish, but we won't know until we have a chance to examine it closely".

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: AI pioneer Marvin Minsky dies at 88
article: Marvin Minsky, a founder of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Artificial Intelligence Project, died at 88 due to brain haemorrhage on Sunday. Minsky invented the first head-mounted graphical display in 1963 (modern-day Oculus Rift) and was among the first to develop artificial neural networks, a key technology in the field of deep learning. He received the Turing Award in 1969.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Blue Origin rocket world's first to be reused
article: The New Shepard suboribtal rocket, developed by space company Blue Origin, has become the world's first commercial rocket to be successfully reused. New Shepard was launched and vertically landed for a second time (after November) in Texas on Friday. It reached a maximum altitude of 333,582 feet above the Earth’s surface. Notably, Blue Origin was founded by Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Five eclipses to occur in 2016
article: A total of five eclipses will occur in 2016, starting with total solar eclipse on March 9.
