This will be followed by two penumbral lunar eclipses on March 23 and August 18, an annular solar eclipse on September 1 and another penumbral lunar eclipse on September 16. Notably, two of these eclipses will be visible from India.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists find gene behind Schizophrenia
article: According to a research published on Wednesday, scientists from the MIT and Harvard University have found a specific gene linked to Schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is a mental disorder often characterized by failure to recognize what is real. Around 100,000 human DNA samples were analyzed to find the gene called complement component 4 (C4), which is a part of the immune system.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Possible cure for Type 1 Diabetes developed
article: A team at MIT has engineered a cure for Type 1 Diabetes using implantable insulin-producing cells which were developed at Harvard University in 2014. The team was able to switch-off the disease for six months in mice by implanting the insulin-producing cells. This new breakthrough has the ability to provide independence from daily insulin dose, a professor said.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: New bird species discovered in Arunachal Pradesh
article: A new species of bird, scientifically named Zoothera salimalii, has been discovered by biologists in Arunachal Pradesh. It has been named 'Himalayan Forest Thrush' as it was found in the snow-capped mountains of the Himalayas. As per reports, it is the fourth such discovery in India since independence and first in the past decade.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronauts spot brightest supernova so far
article: According to a new research, astronauts have spotted the brightest supernova yet at a distance of 3.8 billion light-years. Supernovas are huge explosions that briefly outshine an entire galaxy and radiate huge amounts of energy. The supernova, titled ASASSN-151h, was 20 times brighter than the Milky Way galaxy, and over twice as bright as any previously discovered supernova.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: China to attempt 1st landing on far side of Moon
article: According to China's Xinhua news agency, the country will attempt the first-ever landing on the dark side of the moon in 2018. For the exploration mission, China will send its spacecraft named 'Chang'e 4'. The dark side or the far hemisphere of the moon, which always faces away from the Earth, was first observed in 1959 and is still unexplored.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Electric field can transmit brain waves: Study
article: According to a recent study by American researchers, electric fields can be used to mediate transmission of brain waves. The results mentioned tests on a mouse's brain that produced the same results. The study, published in 'The Journal of Neuroscience', stated that low amplitude fields would be able to channel neurons across the brain at about 10 centimetres per second.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: Scientific developments threaten humans: Hawking
article: Cosmologist Stephen Hawking has said that most of the threats the human race faces come from advancements in science and technology. He referred to developments like nuclear weapons and genetically engineered viruses. He emphasised on the need to be careful as he believed humans would not be able to set up self-sustained colonies in space for at least 100 years.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Two new frog species found in Africa
article: Scientists have found two new species of frogs, named Rombophryne ornata and Rombophryne tany, in African country Madagascar. These frog species live in the rain forests of Tsaratanana Massif, which is the highest mountain in the country. "Both species live on the forest floor among the fallen leaves and are difficult to spot," the scientists noted.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: Astronaut shares photo of frozen Himalayan lake
article: American astronaut Scott Kelly has tweeted a photograph of a frozen lake in the Himalayas, which has been identified as the La’ngaCo Lake off Nepal’s North-Western border. Kelly is currently on a year-long mission on the International Space Station and had recently also tweeted photographs of South India, which had gone viral.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Research projects stuck for want of funds: ICMR
article: Biomedical research projects being undertaken by 32 scientific organisations across India were stuck due to lack of funds, the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) said on Thursday. ICMR had asked for ₹10,000 crore for 2012-2017 but has received only 50% of that amount, ICMR Director General said. He urged that empowering research institutes was a must for global competitiveness.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: SpaceX rocket topples over after landing at sea
article: SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket toppled over after a successful touchdown on a floating landing pad in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday. It had carried NASA's Jason-3 ocean-monitoring satellite into space. CEO Elon Musk said, “Root cause may have been ice buildup due to condensation from heavy fog at liftoff.” Notably, the reusable rocket had successfully landed back on Earth last month.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: X-ray machine was formally displayed on this day
article: The X-ray machine was formally displayed by Professor HL Smith on January 18, 1896, months after German physicist Wilhelm Röntgen invented it in 1895. The first X-ray photograph captured the hand of Röntgen's wife which displayed her bones and wedding ring. Röntgen was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1901 for his invention and contribution in the field of physics.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA's Juno spacecraft breaks distance record
article: NASA’s Juno spacecraft on Wednesday became the most distant solar-powered explorer in space at a distance of 793 million kilometers from the Sun. It broke the record of the European Space Agency's Rosetta spacecraft that was 792 million kilometers away from the Sun in October 2012. Juno will reach Jupiter this year to observe it from an elliptical, polar orbit.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: Largest-ever ancient crocodile found in Sahara
article: Paleontologists in Tunisia discovered a fossil of the world's largest sea-dwelling crocodile. "It's almost the size of a bus," researchers said. The species, now named Machimosaurus Rex, is believed to be over 30 feet long and weighed three tonnes. This reportedly challenges the 'mass extinction theory' that claims all marine reptiles died at the end of the Jurassic Period.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Adidas Y3, Virgin to make 1st space apparel line
article: Sports clothing brand Adidas, with its entity Adidas Y3, has collaborated with commercial spaceflight company Virgin Galactic, to design the fist-ever clothing line for space. The collection will feature flight-suits and boots for Virgin’s space pilots. Limited edition jackets have also been created for astronauts who will be passengers of the first-ever Virgin Galactic commercial space flights.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Tim Peake carries out 1st spacewalk by a British
article: Tim Peake on Friday became the first "official" British astronaut to carry out a spacewalk after stepping outside NASA's International Space Station's Quest airlock. The planned six-and-a-half hours walk was, however, cut short after Peake's colleague Tim Kopra reported a "small amount" of water in his helmet. The astronauts had been outside the space station for four hours.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Second largest black hole in Milky Way found
article: Japanese astronomers have discovered the second largest black hole in the Milky Way galaxy. Situated just 200 light years away from the center of the galaxy, the huge gas cloud has a mass one lakh times greater than the Sun. This reportedly might be the first detection of an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH).

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Astronomers claim discovery of new ninth planet
article: Two American planetary scientists, Konstantin Batygin and Mike Brown announced evidence of a new heavenly body, nearly the size of Neptune and 10 times heavier than the Earth, that orbits the Sun. The new planet has an elliptical orbit with a period of 15,000 earth-years. The claim was made after a detailed analysis of the orbits of other distant objects.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New method to see electrons cool-off developed
article: According to a study published in the journal Nature Physics, researchers have developed a new technique to watch electrons cool-off in an extremely short time period, 30 quadrillionths of a second. This new development can improve efficiency in various sectors such as fiber optic telecommunications and solar energy harvesting, where the energy of electrons gets wasted during the heating process.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Spacewalk cut short after spacesuit malfunction
article: NASA on Friday cut short the International Space Station’s (ISS) 192nd spacewalk after a “small water bubble” formed inside the helmet of one of the two astronauts. The leak did not pose any danger, but the crew was called back on the account of precaution. However, the astronauts successfully completed their objective of replacing a failed voltage regulator before returning.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Man-animal conflict to rise in Sunderbans: Study
article: According to a recent study, the growing salinity of sea water will destroy a majority of the mangrove vegetation in the Sunderbans by 2050, leading to a rise in human-animal conflicts. The vanishing mangrove species like Sundari will adversely affect the Royal Bengal Tiger and its main food source– deer, according to the report.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: Heat soaked by oceans rises exponentially: Study
article: Scientists have claimed that oceans have absorbed the same amount of heat in the last two decades as they did in the preceding 130 years, because of global warming. The study was published in journal Nature Climate Change and was majorly based on observation. Scientists have claimed that this has kept human habitats cooler but may disrupt global weather balance.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: First mission to Pluto was launched on this day
article: New Horizons, NASA's first mission to dwarf planet Pluto was launched on January 19, 2006, from the United State's Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The spacecraft made the closest approach with Pluto on July 14, 2015. The mission which aimed to study and investigate properties of Pluto, its moon and the Kuiper belt, has cost $700 million so far.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Extinct frog rediscovered after 150 years
article: A team of scientists have rediscovered a frog species, Frankixalus jerdonii, from the jungles of north-eastern India which is believed to have been extinct 150 years ago. The 20-inch long frog species lives in tree holes up to 5 m (16 ft) above ground. The female of this frog species lay eggs and feed the unfertilised ones to its tadpoles.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: World’s largest dinosaur skeleton unveiled in US
article: New York's American Museum of Natural History unveiled a cast skeleton of the world’s biggest dinosaur, a new species of Titanosaur, on Thursday. The skeleton, made up of fiberglass after analyzing 84 fossil bones, is 122-feet long. The unnamed herbivore, which was discovered in Argentina in 2014, weighed around 70 tons, about 10 times the weight of an African elephant.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: First ever flower grows in space
article: NASA astronaut and Expedition 46 commander Scott Kelly on Saturday shared an image of the first ever flower grown in space. The flower belongs to the zinnia plant and is expected to help astronauts better understand plant growth in microgravity. This is the second plant grown aboard the International Space Station after the red romaine lettuce.

author: Mirza Mohammed
abstract: Putin claims Russia has developed Ebola vaccine
article: Russia has developed a vaccine for the Ebola virus, claimed Russian President Vladimir Putin. "We have registered a drug against Ebola, which after the corresponding tests have been shown to be highly effective," Putin was quoted as saying by RIA Novosti news agency. No approved vaccine for Ebola exists, till date. Ebola has killed over 11,000 people in West Africa.

author: Shipra Sharma
abstract: 5 planets to be visible in sky starting tomorrow
article: For the first time in 10 years, the five bright planets of the solar system, namely, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn, will be visible to the naked eye starting from Wednesday. The planetary alignment, which will occur till February 20, will be visible around 45 minutes before dawn. It will occur again in the evening sky between August 13-19.

author: Mirza Mohammed
abstract: US launches its 1st warships powered by biofuel
article: The United States Navy on Wednesday launched its first ever warships that are powered by biofuels. The mix that is being used now constitutes 10% biofuels and 90% petroleum, according to Navy Secretary Ray Mabus. Mabus said alternative energy options give the US an advantage as it may no longer have to be affected by fluctuating oil prices.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: ESA plans to build Moon Village by 2030
article: The European Space Agency (ESA) presented plans for building a Moon Village on the lunar surface by 2030 using 3D printing technology with lunar soil, regolith, as raw material. Robots will reside in the settlements until it is prepared for human survival. The agency is reportedly also looking to set it as base for missions to other celestial bodies.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: TED-Ed video explains how solar panels work
article: YouTube channel TED Education (TED-Ed) has released a five-minute video that explains the science behind how solar panels work. The video goes on to explain the physical and logistical challenges the world is currently facing to make solar energy a sustainable energy resource. Notably, the earth intercepts 10,000 times more solar power than the planet’s population uses.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Stock telescope can observe black holes: Study
article: A combined study by a group of researchers from Japan and USA, published in the 'Nature' magazine, stated that an 8-inch beginner's telescope can be used to observe black holes. The results indicated that not just X-rays but even optical rays of black hole outburst, an activity in which objects become over 100 times brighter, can provide dependable observations.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Micro cannon that fires drug bullets developed
article: Nanoscientists from the University of California developed a micro cannon that can fire nano-bullets of drugs, containing therapeutic agents, to cure diseased tissues. The research stated the use of ultrasonic waves to focus the one-micrometer nano-bullets into those tissues. The bullets were covered by a compound called perfluorocarbon, which acted as a propellant in the mechanism.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Dinosaurs danced to woo their mates: Study
article: A study by a group of paleontologists, published in the journal 'Scientific Reports' on Thursday, revealed that dinosaurs performed a bird-like dancing ritual to woo their mates. The team studied 50 scrape marks in a 100 million-year-old sandstone left behind by the animals, that indicated the first physical evidence of "dinosaur foreplay", according to the lead scientist of the study.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: Video: "How Are New Medications Developed?"
article: A new DNews video explains the "slow and expensive" process of developing medications. The video claims the process begins with basic research, after which a compound goes through rigorous phenotype and target screenings to check how it affects cells and proteins. The drug is then tested on animals and humans in a clinical trial before it gets an FDA approval.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Want crazy guys who want to do science: CNR Rao
article: Speaking at the 103rd Indian Science Congress in Mysore, Bharat Ratna-awardee scientist CNR Rao on Sunday said that India needs passionate and “crazy guys who want to do science”. He added, "Unfortunately, there are too many normal people". Rao also advised Prime Minister Narendra Modi to create a commission to chalk out a roadmap regarding education of young children.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Astronaut posts images of South India from space
article: NASA astronaut and Expedition 46 commander Scott Kelly on Monday posted three images of South India as seen from the International Space Station (ISS) on Twitter. Capturing the southernmost tip of the country in one of the images, he tweeted, “A rare glimpse of beautiful South India”. Kelly is known for periodically posting pictures of Earth from the ISS.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA finds violent blasts from nearby black hole
article: NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory on Tuesday discovered violent outbursts, an activity astronomers dubbed as burping, from a supermassive black hole 26 million light years away from Earth. The observatory detected two X-ray emitted arcs near the black hole, which astronomers believe "represent fossils from two enormous blasts when the black hole expelled material outward into the galaxy".

author: Arjun Bhatia
abstract: Video on four new elements on the periodic table
article: YouTube channel DNews’ video ‘What Are The Four New Elements On The Periodic Table?’ talks about the elements that recently completed the seventh row of the periodic table. The video calls the discovery of the elements a milestone in scientists’ pursuit of the 'island of stability’, a theoretically stable element with the perfect number of protons and neutrons.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop material that stores sunlight
article: A team of researchers from the MIT has manufactured a new transparent polymer film-like material that can store sunlight which can be used sometime later. For manufacturing the material, the team used azobenzene molecules, which have the capability to enter into charged state once exposed to sunlight. The molecules can then be triggered using specific conditions to produce heat.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: New glove can 'feel' distant underwater objects
article: Researchers at Japan’s Tsukuba University have designed a new glove which lets users ‘feel’ distant underwater objects. The gloves are fitted with an ultrasonic range-finding sonar sensor, an Arduino Pro Mini microcomputer, and three small motors which send jets of water which strike objects. Inspired by a dolphin's echolocation, they are named IrukaTact after Iruka, which is dolphin in Japanese.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: Space mining market worth over $100 tn: Report
article: Space technology companies Planetary Resources and Deep Space Industries have estimated that mining asteroids for metals could be worth over $100 trillion. The two companies are launching multiple spacecraft to analyse asteroids and identify the most valuable mining prospects. The US Senate is currently reviewing the 'Space Act' bill that will allow private companies to mine asteroids.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Low sunlight increases risk of leukaemia: Study
article: According to a study published online in PLOS One journal, those who are exposed to lower sunlight or lower ultraviolet B are at an increased risk of getting leukaemia than those getting adequate sunlight. The researchers noted that the number of cases of leukaemia was higher in countries relatively closer to the poles like the US and Australia.

author: Pragya Swastik
abstract: December 2015 warmest in India in last 115 years
article: The year 2015 saw the warmest December in India in the last 115 years, according to data released by the India Meteorological Department (IMD). The average temperature in December 2015 was recorded 1.2 degree celsius above the normal. The data also revealed that the period between September to December 2015 was warmest in India since the year 1901.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Artist creates scaled map of the Universe
article: Musician and artist Pablo Carlos Budassi created a circular scaled map of the entire known Universe in a single field of view using logarithmic maps and satellite images collected by NASA and ESA missions. Pablo said he got the idea while drawing hexaflexagons, which is a hexagon-shaped paper toy, as a memento for his son's birthday.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Efficient accelerator 'Thor' being built in US
article: US-based Sandia National Labs are working on a new accelerator named 'Thor', which will be 40 times more efficient than the World's most powerful pulsed-power accelerator 'Z Machine'. The machine's 'magnetic field' would be able to reach one million atmospheres, the pressure experienced at Earth's core. Such setups are used to test and study how materials behave at extreme pressures.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop new self-folding material
article: A group of researchers from China developed a new smart material that can be programmed to fold itself into complex shapes. The new material would be able to remember its original shape and the shapes it was physically folded into. The researchers identified 70°C to 130°C as the range of temperature in which the material would work as expected.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: CIRB becomes 2nd in India to clone a buffalo
article: The Central Institute for Research on Buffaloes (CIRB) has become the world's third and India's second institute to clone a buffalo, CIRB Director Dr. Inderjeet said on Sunday. He claimed that their scientists had successfully produced a cloned buffalo offspring on December 11, 2015. The National Dairy Research Institute in Karnal was the first to clone a buffalo in India.

author: Ankur Vyas
abstract: Govt would make research easier in India: Modi
article: Addressing the 103rd Indian Science Congress, PM Narendra Modi on Sunday said that the government would make it easier to conduct scientific research in India. He told the scientists to keep the "5 Es" of economy, environment, energy, empathy, and equity at the centre of enquiry and engineering. He also assured greater scientific collaboration between the centre and the states.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Insulin first used to treat diabetes on this day
article: Insulin was first used in the treatment of diabetes in a human being on January 11, 1922. Frederick Banting, who discovered insulin medication, administered insulin to 14-year-old Leonard Thompson. While the first injection gave Thompson an allergic reaction, the second one was successful. Notably, Banting was awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1923 for the discovery of insulin.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: TestTube video explains "Who Owns the Moon?"
article: In a new video titled “Who Owns the Moon?”, TestTube News explains that celestial bodies and other portions of space cannot be owned by any country. The video discusses the Outer Space Treaty, which dictates that space is a “common heritage of mankind”. Private establishments like hotels in space can, however, be privately owned but are open to inter-planetary debate.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: Scientists recover meteorite 'older than Earth'
article: A meteorite that fell in Australia on November 27, 2015, is older than Earth (over 4.5-billion-year-old), geologists have identified. The rock was recovered hours before heavy rainfall in the area was likely to wash it away. The 1.7-kg meteorite is believed to be among the solar system's early formations and was tracked by a network of 32 camera observatories.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: NASA discovers over 100 new alien planets
article: NASA confirmed that its planet-hunting space observatory Kepler has discovered over 100 new alien planets using an extremely precise technique by observing the brightness dips of a planet during its orbit. "A validation process whittled some of these signals down to planet candidates, each of which has just a one percent chance of being a false positive", an astronomer said.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: DNews explains how the brain can control objects
article: In its new video, DNews has discussed Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) which can enable an individual to move physical objects with their thoughts. The video explains the BCI use Electroencephalogram (EEG) to pick up electrical signals in the brain and translate them into a single command which can direct a programmed device (a prosthetic limb or even a car) to move.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: 'Luna 1' reached moon's vicinity on this day
article: Spacecraft 'Luna 1' passed within 6,000-kilometer range of planet Earth's natural satellite, the Moon, on January 4, 1959, becoming the first spacecraft to achieve the feat. Launched from Kazakhstan on January 2, 1959, by the Soviet Union, Luna 1 was also the first spacecraft to be placed in heliocentric orbit. Notably, the heliocentric orbit is situated near the Sun's surface.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Comets, asteroids reason for extinctions: Study
article: A team of US researchers have concluded that comets and asteroids were responsible for mass extinctions on earth that have occurred in 260 million years. A correlation between impact events and extinctions taking place every 26 million years was found. The correlation was attributed to the periodic motion of the solar system through the mid-plane of the galaxy.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 1st manned mission to moon returned on this day
article: Apollo 8, the first manned mission sent to orbit the Moon, returned safely to Earth in the Pacific Ocean on December 27, 1968. The spacecraft left Earth’s orbit on December 21 with astronauts Frank Borman, James Lovell Jr, and William Anders. The three astronauts were also the first people ever to see the dark side of the moon.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Georgia: Meteor races towards Earth at 29,000mph
article: NASA has identified the bright fireball that was recently spotted over Georgia as a meteor that was hurtling towards the Earth at the speed of 29,000 miles per hour. NASA said, “From its brightness…this piece of an asteroid weighed at least 150 pounds and was over 16 inches in diameter.” The meteor was tracked by six NASA all sky meteor cameras.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: US unveils stamps with Pluto's image for 2016
article: The US Postal Service on Wednesday released a preview of its new stamps for 2016, that included Pluto’s recently captured heart image. Further, the New Horizons spacecraft, which was the first spacecraft to fly by Pluto, was featured on one of the stamps. Celebrating NASA’s planetary space programmes, other stamps showcased colourful images of different planets and the Earth’s moon.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA captures image of merging galaxies
article: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has captured an image of two galaxies - about 230 million light years away - merging into one. According to the space center, stars of the respective galaxies are now out of their original orbits to entirely new paths. The galaxies, currently in a chaotic shape, were attracted towards each other by gravity.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 14-year-old receives world’s 1st 3D-printed nose
article: Dallan Jennet, a 14-year-old US boy, has undergone a nose transplant surgery to receive the world’s first 3D-printed nose. Jennet disfigured his face after he fell onto a live power line at the age of nine. This “may be a breakthrough in facial reconstruction" as Jennet will never have to face standard transplantation issues including a lifetime of immunosuppressive therapies.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Plants' system to find light identified: Study
article: US researchers have found out that plants have cellular sensors that trigger an internal alarm when threatened by the shade of other plants. The sensors are capable of perceiving the diminishment of red and blue light, which are the wavelengths absorbed by them. The researchers also identified a new mechanism of cell growth that helps a plant compete for sunlight.

author: Smrithin Satishan
abstract: Atomic energy chief alleges 'foreign' conspiracy
article: Newly appointed chief of India's Atomic Energy Commission Sekhar Basu on Sunday alleged that attempts were being made by a "foreign country" to "stall or delay" India's development through a "well-designed agenda". Basu was responding to questions regarding Washington-based journalist Adrian Levy's allegations that India's nuclear programme consists of leaky reactors and has poor security.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists to use heat to view cell's internals
article: A group of scientists from the University of Bordeaux and French National Centre for Scientific Research have developed an imaging technique that uses lasers and titanium to view the internal workings of a human cell. Different parts of a cell absorb heat at different rates and generate energy at different rates, a fact which was used in the developed process.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: SpaceX rocket ready for relaunch: Elon Musk
article: SpaceX CEO Elon Musk on Friday said that the booster Falcon 9 rocket is in good shape and is ready for another launch. The reusable rocket successfully landed back on Earth last month in Cape Canaveral after putting 11 small data-relay satellites in orbit. SpaceX aims at reusing rockets to reduce the overall cost of spaceflight.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists complete 7th row of periodic table
article: The seventh row of the periodic table was completed on Wednesday after the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) announced the discovery of element 113 and claimed discovery of elements 115, 117 and 118. The Union awarded credit of element 113 to a group of Japanese researchers while a Russian-US collaboration claimed the discovery of other three elements.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Mangalayaan reveals image of Mars' north pole
article: On New Year’s Eve, the Indian Space Research Organization’s (ISRO) Mars Orbiter Mission spacecraft, or Mangalayaan, posted an image of Mars’ frigid north pole on Twitter. The image was accompanied by a message that read, “#HappyNewYear, dear earthlings! North pole looks wicked cool here!” The image was captured from a distance of 55,000 kilometres.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Researchers find animal that might be immortal
article: According to researchers from the Pomona College, US, Hydra, a centimeter-long freshwater animal found across the globe, does not show any sign of deteriorating with age and shows constant fertility. One of the researchers said, “I do believe that an individual hydra can live forever under the right circumstances”. However, the organism is still prone to predation, contamination and diseases.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: NatGeo lists must-see sky events of 2016
article: National Geographic has listed the most significant sky events of 2016, which begin with a four-minute total solar eclipse on March 8. Parts of the earth will witness the Transit of Mercury on May 9 when the planet will be seen against the sun for seven hours. Furthermore, Mars will look the biggest and brightest from the earth in May.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: New species officially named Ninja Lanternshark
article: Scientists have officially described a new species as "Ninja Lanternshark", scientifically called Etmopterus Benchleyi, which was first discovered by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in 2010. After the description, there are now 37 known Lanternshark species. The 30-50 centimetre long shark's special characteristic includes light-emitting spots along the sides and the fins.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Gene-editing can limit Muscular Dystrophy: Study
article: A group of American researchers have found a possible gene-editing technique to treat Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a rare form of muscular dystrophy that results in muscle degeneration and premature death. Researchers reported the study in the journal Science, mentioning a successful initial test done on a mouse with a defective dystrophin gene that improved the overall muscle strength.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Smartphone-powered 3D printer developed for $100
article: Scientists from Taiwan have developed a smartphone-powered 3D printer for $100. The printer reportedly uses visible light emitted from a smartphone to cure a resin, instead of UV light or lasers. This makes it easier to print 3D models as both the printer and the print management tool are in the same device. However, this technique slows down the entire process.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Scientists develop human-like social robot
article: Scientists from Singapore have developed a human-like social robot, Nadine, that is capable of autonomously expressing emotions. The humanoid has soft skin, brunette hair and a good memory. It can be used as a personal assistant in offices in future. Scientists have also developed a telepresence robot, EDGAR, that can allow users to attend meetings without being physically present.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: New gravity measuring method can find alien life
article: In a bid to search for alien life, a team of scientists has discovered a new method of measuring gravitation pull on distant stars with planets orbiting them with 4% accuracy. Called timescale technique, the method allows scientists to discover if a planet around a distant star “is the right size and temperature to have water oceans, and maybe life”.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: Discovery explains science behind surfing waves
article: Discovery News has, in a new video, explained the science behind big waves and how they become fit for surfing. Surfer Kyle Thiermann compares a sea wave with a sound wave and explains that its height and shape depends upon the wave's amplitude and period, where a higher period forms a more organised funnel, which becomes better for surfing.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Algorithm created to turn phone into 3D scanner
article: Researchers from Brown University, US, have reportedly developed an algorithm that can turn off-the-shelf digital cameras and smartphones, that have the ability to capture uncompressed images in burst mode, into high-quality 3D scanners. After a camera captures an image, the algorithm goes through it, pixel by pixel, to assemble a new sequence that creates a single 3D image.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases image of landslide on Mars
article: NASA on Monday released an image of a landslide on Mars captured by the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter spacecraft on March 19, 2014. The image shows a landslide covered with boulders along a canyon wall. NASA said, “This landslide is relatively fresh, as many individual boulders still stand out above the main deposit”.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Comet makes once-in-a-lifetime appearance
article: Comet Catalina, a double-tailed comet with a greenish glow, is currently passing by the inner solar system for the first and the last time ever. The comet, that can currently be spotted in the northern hemisphere, is expected to reach its closest to Earth on January 17. Earlier knows as C/2013 US10, the space object was first discovered in 2013.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Astronauts grow first flower plants on ISS
article: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station (ISS) have successfully grown the first flower plant, called zinnias, in space as part of NASA's VEG-01 investigation. Zinnias were grown in a veggie chamber with their roots soaked in one-time-use pillows. The chamber, which can theoretically grow any type of plant with customized lightings, was previously used for growing lettuce.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 1st ever video of freely moving animal's brain
article: Researchers from Princeton University have recorded the first ever video of brain activity, down to neuron function, in a freely moving animal. The 3D video captures the brain of a millimeter-long worm. Out of the 302 neurons in its nervous system, 77 light up as the worm thinks or displays specific behavior like backward or forward motion and turning.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Cancer caused by environmental factors: Study
article: A paper published in the journal 'Nature' has suggested that 70-90% of cancers are caused by extrinsic or environmental factors like a poor diet, lack of exercise, stress and pollution while only 10-30% are down to 'bad luck'. Although a healthy lifestyle is not a guarantee against cancer, it helps dramatically reduce the risk of getting one, a researcher added.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Closest potentially habitable planet discovered
article: A group of Australian astronomers on Thursday identified a planet, orbiting a dwarf star 14 light years away named Wolf 1061, as the closest potentially habitable body outside the solar system. "The planet sits within the 'Goldilocks' zone where it might be possible for liquid water -- and maybe even life -- to exist", said the lead of the study.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: 1st manned moon mission was launched on this day
article: The first manned mission to the moon, Apollo 8, was launched on December 21, 1968, from Florida, USA. The spacecraft which took three days to travel to the moon had astronauts Frank F Borman II, James A Lovell Jr, and William A Anders aboard. The spacecraft orbited the moon ten times over the course of 20 hours.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 4th Russian cargo resupply ship reaches ISS
article: After a two-day journey, an unpiloted Russian cargo resupply spacecraft, called Progress 62, reached the International Space Station (ISS) on Wednesday. The spacecraft contains 2.8 tons of food, fuel, and supplies for the Expedition 46 crew aboard the ISS. The spacecraft, that was launched on Monday from Kazakhstan, will remain docked to the ISS until July 2016.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Hawking launches medal for science communication
article: British scientist Stephen Hawking has launched the ‘Stephen Hawking Medal for Science Communication’ for promoting science through media including cinema, music, writing and art. The medal will be awarded in three different categories, namely scientific, artistic and film communities. The first award will be given away next year between June and July at the Starmus Festival in Spain.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Scientists develop hardest known material to man
article: The US Department of Energy has developed a new two-dimensional crystalline allotrope of boron named Borophene, which could be stronger than Graphene, hardest material known to man. Boron, being a non-metallic semiconductor, was fused in its gaseous state with silver to form a single-atom layer resulting in a material with electrical conductivity supposedly higher than any other.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Black holes can be as large as 50 bn Suns: Study
article: According to scientists from the UK, black holes at the center of galaxies could swell to 50 billion times the mass of the Sun. Black holes depend on orbiting discs of gas, that form on its outside, to sustain themselves. Thus, they can become equivalent to 50 billion Suns before losing the discs of gas.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases Christmas image of Pluto
article: On the occasion of Christmas, NASA has released a colourful image of Pluto named ‘Christmas Pluto’. The image was produced by the New Horizons spacecraft’s composition team using infrared wavelength ranges in blue, green and red colour channels. The original image of this Christmas portrait was obtained on July 14 from a mean distance of 108,000 kilometers.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Two astronauts embark on ISS' 191st spacewalk
article: Astronauts Scott Kelly and Tim Kopra embarked on the International Space Station’s (ISS) 191st spacewalk on Monday. The spacewalk was aimed at moving ISS’ stalled mobile transporter rail car by a few inches. This would enable the smooth docking of a cargo resupply spacecraft which will reach the ISS on Wednesday. The spacewalk was planned to last for three hours.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: London buses to run on meat-based fuel by March
article: London’s transport authorities have announced that 3,000 of the city’s 8,900 buses will run on modified fuel made from meat waste by March next year. The waste will mainly include cooking oil and animal fat, which when mixed with B20 green diesel will reportedly reduce the CO2 emission by 21,000 tonnes annually. London’s bus fleet is already the world’s greenest.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: India's 1st artificial human liver tissue built
article: Bengaluru-based biotech startup Pandorum Technologies has used the 3D printing technology to make India’s first artificial human liver tissue. The tissue, which was made using glucose, protein and live human cells as printer ink, is capable of performing functions including detoxification, metabolism and biochemical secretion. The company claims the mini-liver can prove essential in drug research.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Mental time travel is uniquely human: Study
article: According to researchers in Germany, humans are apparently the only species able to remember experiences and mentally time travel to the past or the future. While animals apparently possess episodic memory, there is no proof that they possess the ability to reflect, construct and compare different future scenarios like humans, nor are they able to reconstruct events from the past.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Highest strength-to-weight ratio metal developed
article: A team of researchers from UCLA developed a new high strength metal composite, which is very light in weight, by fusing magnesium and nanoparticles of silicon carbide compound. It has the highest strength-to-weight ratio among the materials with the same density. The applications of such a metal can prove helpful in manufacturing light-weight cars, planes and spaceships.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Rise in oxygen aided animal evolution: Study
article: Researchers from the University College London have concluded that oxygen levels in the oceans and atmosphere rose to a level which allowed animal life to proliferate in 100 million years. The study concluded it was likely that animal evolution was stimulated by increased amounts of oxygen, rather than oxygenation brought about by changes in animal behaviour.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Boeing receives order to ferry astronauts to ISS
article: NASA has given Boeing its second commercial crew order under which Boeing's CST-100 Starliner will ferry astronauts to the International Space Station (ISS). This is the third such order (in a series of four) NASA is placing under its Commercial Crew Program, a $6.8-billion space taxi contract. Boeing received the first order in May and SpaceX received the second in November.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Shortest day of the year occurring on Dec 22
article: The Winter Solstice which marks the shortest day of the year in Earth's northern hemisphere will occur on December 22, 2015. During Winter Solstice, the northern hemisphere is at its farthest from the sun. It also marks the official beginning of astronomical winter in northern hemisphere and summer in the southern hemisphere, which will witness 2015's longest day on Tuesday.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Injectable foam built that can fix bone defects
article: A group of researchers from France developed a self-setting injectable foam capable of repairing damaged or degenerative bones and assisting bone development. Study of the compound revealed that the effects of its use are non-toxic, indicating that the compound can be used for treating bone defects and diseases. The testing phase of the compound would start-off from animal models.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Gianotti to become the 1st woman to head CERN
article: Italian particle physicist Dr Fabiola Gianotti is all set to become the first ever female Director-General of the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) that operates the World's largest particle physics laboratory. Earlier, Gianotti headed a team that was involved in the discovery of Higgs particle in 2012. Organization's operations under the new head would begin from January 1, 2016.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Video: NASA highlights its top stories of 2015
article: NASA has released a yearly roundup video that highlights its top stories of 2015. In September, NASA discovered flowing saltwater on Mars. In July, New Horizons became the first spacecraft to flyby Pluto. In March, two astronauts embarked on the first ever year-long mission to live in space. Interestingly, NASA also helped in the accurate production of 'The Martian'.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: India sets record for largest science practical
article: India has entered the Guinness Book of World Records for conducting the world’s largest practical science lesson. To achieve this, 2,000 students from government and private schools in Delhi simultaneously conducted two mass catalysis experiments at the Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi. Before this, Northern Ireland held the said record by conducting a similar experiment with 1,339 students.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases new high-res Earthrise image
article: NASA's Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter spacecraft, which is currently orbiting the moon, has captured a new Earthrise image. The composite image shows the Earth rising above the lunar horizon with a prominent view of the Sahara Desert, the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of South America. It reportedly resembles Earth's famous ‘Blue Marble’ image taken by the crew of the Apollo 17 spacecraft.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Lakes getting warm by 0.3°C every decade: Study
article: A study conducted by researchers from Washington State University has concluded that the world's lakes are warming faster than previously assumed, at the rate of 0.3°C every decade. The study which tracked lake temperatures from 1985 to 2009, also concluded that major changes could have already taken place such as algal blooms and thinning of fish populations.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Animals' loss could hasten climate change: Study
article: Researchers from the UK have revealed that decline in fruit-eating animals like primates, tapirs and toucans could intensify climate change. These animals are responsible for dispersing large-seeded tree species associated with trees with high wood density which are effective in capturing carbon dioxide as compared to smaller trees. Loss of these animals means less proliferation of such trees.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA discovers "remarkable" galactic gas ribbon
article: NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory has discovered an “extraordinary ribbon of hot gas trailing behind a galaxy like a tail”. The ribbon is at least 2,50,000 light years long, which is twice the diameter of the Milky Way galaxy. It contains hot gas at the temperature of about ten million degrees and is likely the largest such tail detected so far.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA finds high concentration of silica on Mars
article: NASA’s Mars Curiosity rover has discovered high concentration of the chemical compound silica on Mars. At some sites, nine-tenths of the composition of rocks is silica. According to the scientists at NASA, this information will help them learn more about the wet environment on the planet. Silica is a rock-forming chemical that is created by combining silicon and oxygen.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: China launches its first dark matter satellite
article: China has launched its first Dark Matter Particle Explorer satellite, nicknamed Wukong, to hunt for evidences of dark matter decay. The satellite, launched from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre in Gansu province, aims at observing the direction, energy and electric charge of high-energy particles in space. Notably, dark matter is believed to have made up most of the universe's mass.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Chinese scientists develop super capacitor
article: Scientists from the Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, China, have developed a super capacitor that can reportedly make electric vehicles run for 35 kilometers after charging them for just seven seconds. The capacitor was developed using nitrogen and graphene-like carbon. Huang Fuqiang, a material chemist at the institute, said, "We are able to make carbon a much better super capacitor".

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: First planetary encounter was made on this day
article: The first ever successful planetary encounter took place on December 14, 1962, as NASA's spacecraft Mariner 2 flew by Venus, the second planet of the solar system. The spacecraft was launched on August 27, 1962. Mariner 2 made several discoveries about the planet, like its hot surface temperature, high surface pressure, predominantly carbon dioxide atmosphere and no detectable magnetic field.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Urine-powered socks made to generate electricity
article: Researchers from the West of England University, UK have created socks that utilize urine to generate electricity. When a user walks, these socks, that can contain 648 milliliters of urine in integrated tubes, force the liquid through microbial fuel cells that, in turn, create electricity. This is the first autonomous wearable energy generator based on microbial fuel cell technology.

author: Shruti Nagpal
abstract: UK skies witness annual Geminids meteor shower
article: The UK saw the peak of this year’s Geminids meteor shower on Sunday night through Monday morning. The shower is an annual phenomenon and takes place when the Earth’s orbit coincides with that of the 3200 Phaethon asteroid. The meteors are visible to the naked eye and are named so because they appear to be coming from the Gemini constellation.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: Mexico approves world's first dengue vaccine
article: The world's first dengue vaccine, Dengvaxia was on Wednesday approved by Mexico. Created by French drugmaker Sanofi, Dengvaxia can be used for all four dengue virus serotypes for patients aged 9-45 years in areas where dengue is endemic. It took 20 years and around $1.6 billion to create the vaccine for the disease that affects 400 million people annually.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA launches ultra-high definition TV channel
article: NASA has launched a TV channel called NASA TV UHD that will broadcast ultra-high definition videos from the space centre. The channel showed the launch of NASA’s recent resupply mission through the Cygnus spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS). The launch was documented via an array of six 4K+ cameras by video delivery infrastructure company Harmonic.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Arctic's annual average air temp max since 1900
article: A report by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) of the US on the Arctic has revealed that the annual average air temperature has been the highest since records began in 1900. The temperature was 1.3°C above the average. The increasing heat has been accompanied by declining ice with more than 50% of Greenland’s ice experiencing melting in 2015.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: First aircraft flight took place on this day
article: The first ever recorded controlled, powered and heavier-than-air airplane flight took place in North Carolina, USA, on December 17, 1903. The aircraft's name was 'Wright Flyer' and it was designed and built by Wright brothers- Orville and Wilbur, then aged 36 and 32 respectively. The first flight covered a distance of 120 feet and remained in air for 20 seconds.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Hubble spots first predicted supernova explosion
article: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope has captured the first-ever predicted supernova explosion. Supernovas are huge explosions that briefly outshine an entire galaxy and radiate energy equivalent to the Sun. Named Refsdal, the said supernova exploded about 10 billion years ago, while its light took about five billion years to reach Earth. This is the first time such an explosion was predicted accurately.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 3D tool to track worm's brain development built
article: A research team, led by an Indian-origin scientist, has developed an open-source 3D software to monitor embryonic development and neuronal cell movements in a worm. The software precedes a project aimed at creating a 4D neurodevelopmental “worm atlas”, the first catalog of its kind on nervous system development. It is also expected to help scientists better understand human brain development.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Galileo spacecraft reached Jupiter on this day
article: NASA's Galileo spacecraft entered the atmosphere of the fifth and largest planet of the solar system, Jupiter, on December 7, 1995. Launched on October 13, 1989, it took the spacecraft over six years to reach its destination. 'Galileo' measured Jupiter's atmosphere directly and became the first spacecraft to orbit the planet. The mission disclosed the presence of minerals on Jupiter.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA launches resupply mission to ISS
article: NASA finally launched its Orbital ATK’s Cygnus spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) with over 7,000 pounds of cargo on Sunday from Florida. “The mission will deliver experiments, equipment and supplies to the orbiting laboratory and its six-person crew of astronauts and cosmonauts,” NASA said. This is Orbital ATK's fourth cargo resupply mission to the ISS.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: World’s first biologically powered chip created
article: Columbia University researchers have created the world’s first biologically powered chip. They have combined a complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) circuit with an artificial lipid bilayer membrane, containing a biological electronic device called ATP “to create systems not possible with either technology alone”. In humans, ATP transfers energy from one point to another.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA to move out of the ISS latest by 2028
article: NASA will reportedly quit the International Space Station latest by 2028. The space agency’s human spaceflight chief, William Gerstenmaier, said, “NASA cannot afford both a robust space station program and active human exploration program in cislunar space”. The ISS was launched in low-Earth orbit in 2000 and currently orbits the Earth at about eight kilometre per second.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: World's first test tube puppies born in US
article: The world's first test tube puppies have been born, researchers at the Cornell University, United States said. The research published in the journal PLoS One says that a surrogate mother gave birth to seven beagle and cross-bred beagle-spaniel puppies using in-vitro fertilisation. The breakthrough could help conserve endangered breeds and also help in the fight against human and animal diseases.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: 3 astronauts of Expedition 45 return from space
article: The Expedition 45 crew, comprising three astronauts from NASA, Roscosmos, and JAXA, safely returned to Earth on Friday. The crew undertook several research projects aboard the International Space Station including growing veggies in space for the first time. While two astronauts spent 141 days in space, the expedition commander spent 533 days. They landed in Kazakhstan in a Soyuz spacecraft.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: NASA: First full moon on X'mas in 38 years
article: According to NASA, a full moon is anticipated this year on Christmas Eve, a phenomenon called Full Cold Moon, last seen in 1977 and which would happen again in 2034. The event is called the Long Nights Moon in certain Native American cultures, as the winter solstice happens around that time, heralding the longest night of the year.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Video: 3 astronauts launch to the Space Station
article: Three astronauts, from NASA, Roscosmos and ESA, launched to the International Space Station (ISS) in a Soyuz spacecraft from Kazakhstan on Tuesday. This Expedition 46 crew, replacing the three Expedition 45 astronauts who recently returned to Earth, will stay aboard the ISS for six months. With this, flight engineer Tim Peake becomes the first Briton to be travelling to the ISS.

author: Prashanti Moktan
abstract: Indo-US Prof invents 'Supercondom' to fight AIDS
article: Indian-American professor Mahua Choudhury and her research team have developed an antioxidant-rich hydrogel 'Supercondom' which can help prevent the spread of HIV and AIDS. Choudhury was earlier chosen by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation for their 'Grand Challenge in Global Health' grant where recipients were asked to create an affordable, latex-free condom to help battle the HIV epidemic.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Global warming has increased day's length: Study
article: Harvard University researchers have calculated that the length of a day has increased by one millisecond in the past century. The increase is caused by the melting of glaciers shifting the water's weight across the globe changing the axis upon which the Earth spins. It is expected that in the 21st century, five milliseconds would be added to each day.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: IISc scientists create solar desalination system
article: Researchers from the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, have developed a solar hybrid desalination system to convert sea water into drinkable water. The system can purify about 6.5 litres of saline water per square metre of the concerned instrument in six hours. The invention was aimed at reducing the life-span cost of the desalination process while still meeting performance requirements.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: NASA releases graphics on record Chennai rains
article: National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) on Tuesday released graphics that showed Chennai and nearby areas received 400 mm (16 inch) rainfall during 48 hours. NASA added that the city had witnessed the heaviest rainfall on December 1 and 2 since the year 1901, accumulating in 30-minute intervals.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: Australia: First fire-fighting robot launched
article: Australia on Thursday unveiled its first fire-fighting robot called Turbine Aided Firefighting machine (TAF 20). The robot, that can be remotely controlled from up to 500 metres, has bulldozer blades and a high-powered fan to move heavy objects like cars out of its way and clear away the smoke. TAF 20 can also reportedly blast water from 90 metres.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA starts hiring astronauts for Mars mission
article: NASA on Monday started accepting job applications for “a new generation of space pioneers” for sending a human-mission to Mars. The job requires candidates, that might fly on the International Space Station if chosen, to be US citizens. The last date for submitting the job application is February 18 and NASA will announce the list of selected astronauts in mid-2017.

author: Smrithin Satishan
abstract: Delhi: 2000 students attempt largest practical
article: To script a new record into Guinness Books for 'the largest practical science lesson', two thousand students from 40 schools of Delhi-NCR conducted two mass catalysis experiments at IIT- Delhi on Monday. As per Guinness Book of Records, 1,339 students of 7th and 8th standard from North Ireland's Belfast hold the record for a mass chromatography practical in February 2015.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA releases colour mosaic of Pluto
article: NASA has released an “enhanced colour mosaic” of Pluto that includes the planet's sharpest images taken by the New Horizons spacecraft. To create this, lower-resolution colour data of 2,066 feet per pixel was added to the original resolution of 250-280 feet per pixel. Further, the original images were combined with the colour data captured by the Ralph/Multispectral Visible Imaging Camera.

author: Swarnim Bagre
abstract: Six satellites launched from ISRO's PSLV-C29
article: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) successfully launched six Singaporean satellites atop its Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle's (PSLV) C-29 variant on Wednesday. All six satellites were launched into their separate orbits at an altitude of 550 km from earth's surface. The launch included one earth observation satellite called TeLEOS-1, which was the main passenger for the PSLV rocket.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA takes zoomed-in pictures of faintest galaxy
article: Scientists at NASA have captured a zoomed-in picture of the faintest galaxy detected so far through its Hubble Space Telescope. Nick-named Tayna, the ancient galaxy is four billion light years away and came in view through a phenomenon called gravitational lensing. Under this, the galaxy cluster's gravity acts as a magnifying glass and makes it appear about 20 times brighter.

author: Durga Ranjan
abstract: NASA finds signs of water on 5 distant planets
article: NASA has reported that "faint signatures of water" have been found in the atmospheres of five planets outside our solar system. The presence of atmospheric water on exoplanets has been reported before, but NASA says that this study is the first to "conclusively measure and compare" the light signatures that denote the presence of water.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Hawaii scraps permit for telescope on volcano
article: The Hawaii Supreme Court annulled the permit allowing construction of the 180-feet-high Thirty Metre Telescope, which was supposed to be one of the world's largest. The telescope was to be built on a dormant volcano, considered a sacred site by the native Hawaiians. The court observed that the project did not comply with state laws besides violating the native customs.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: NASA reveals Pluto's sharpest images ever taken
article: NASA has released the sharpest images of Pluto till date with resolutions of about 250-280 feet per pixel. Shot from 17,000 kilometers away, the images reveal craters, mountains and icy terrains on a 80-kilometre stretch of the planet. NASA claims the images to be the best close-ups of Pluto that the New Horizons spacecraft is ever likely to send back.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Total solar eclipse, supermoon & equinox today
article: In a rare natural phenomenon occurring today, a total solar eclipse, a supermoon and the spring equinox - all will take place on the same day. Such rare occurrence happens once in a thousand years. The total eclipse will be visible in USA and UK. Furthermore, Friday's moon will appear larger than usual and day-night will be equal in duration.

author: Jatan Desai
abstract: CERN scientists discover new particle
article: Scientists at European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN), which houses the biggest atom smasher in the world, have discovered a new kind of particle called 'Pentaquark'. The study of the particles may help scientists better understand how ordinary matter is constituted. The existence of pentaquarks was first proposed in the 1960s by American physicists Murray Gell-Mann and Georg Zweig.

author: Shankar Venkatraman
abstract: LHC produces primordial state of matter
article: Scientists at CERN have produced quark-gluon plasma, a state of matter thought to have existed right at the birth of the universe, with fewer particles than previously thought possible. The material was discovered by colliding protons with lead nuclei at high energy inside the supercollider's Compact Muon Solenoid detector. Physicists have dubbed the resulting plasma the "littlest liquid."

author: Shipra Sharma
abstract: Breastfeeding may lower leukemia risk: Study
article: As per a study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, breastfeeding a baby for at least six months may reduce the risk childhood leukemia by 19%. "Breast milk contains many immunologically active components and anti-inflammatory defense mechanisms that influence the development of an infant's immune system," the researchers suggested.

author: Shipra Sharma
abstract: Oldest case of leukemia found in skeleton
article: Researchers at the University of Tubingen (Germany), have discovered what may be the oldest case of leukemia in a skeleton which is around 7,000 years old. The skeleton, belonging to a woman who died between 30 to 40 years of age, was found at a Neolithic graveyard in Germany. Researchers used high-resolution computer tomography to make the discovery.

author: Rohan Kumar
abstract: Nobel medical prize goes 2 Americans, 1 German
article: Americans James Rothman (Yale University) and Randy Schekman (University of California) and German Thomas Sudhof (Stanford University) won the Nobel Medicine Prize on Monday. The Nobel Assembly said they "solved the mystery of how the cell organizes its transport system", a process involved in activities such as release of insulin into the bloodstream. They will receive $1.2-million as prize money.

author: Rohan Kumar
abstract: Acid rain led to mass extinction 250 mn yrs ago
article: A new study, published in the journal 'Geology', shows that acid rain and ozone depletion caused the extinction of over 90% marine species and 70% terrestrial species 250 million years ago. Gases released during contemporaneous volcanic eruptions in Siberia resulted in ecology-damaging pH fluctuations and UV radiations. These combined with global warming led to the earth's worst known species die-off.

author: Sumedha Sehra
abstract: NASA's Humans to Mars mission closer than ever
article: Opening the Humans to Mars Summit on Monday, NASA administrator Charles Bolden said that the mission to send humans on Mars is closer than ever, and might be accomplished before the goal set by President Obama. Out of the 6 critical elements needed for the mission, 4 are already being worked on, said an elated Bolden.

author: Durga Ranjan
abstract: Humans emerged from pig & chimp: World's top geneticist
article: As per one of the world's leading geneticists, Dr Eugene McCarthy  (University of Georgia), human species began as the hybrid offspring of a male pig and a female chimpanzee. He points out that though humans have many features in common with chimps, there are a lot more that don't correspond to any other primates, but to pigs only.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: 'Human gene edits in embryos irresponsible'
article: Scientists and ethicists who had gathered at the International Summit on Human Gene Editing in Washington arrived at a consensus that it would be "irresponsible" to use gene editing technology in human embryos. However, the organisers said that research on editing human genes on embryos was permissible as long as they were not used to conceive offsprings by establishing pregnancy.

author: Trivedi Bhutnath
abstract: Scientists discover 5 Earth-sized planets
article: A group of British scientists, led by University of Birmingham, Tuesday announced that they have discovered five Earth-sized planets around a distant star in the Milky Way galaxy, leading to a possibility of finding life out there. "This discovery may now help to pinpoint the beginning of what we might call the era of planet formation," a researcher said.

author: Chhavi Tyagi
abstract: Mountain spotted on dwarf planet Ceres' surface
article: New images of dwarf planet Ceres released by NASA show some pyramid-shaped mountains and mysterious bright spots on its surface. The pictures are taken by NASA's Dawn spacecraft from a height of 2,700 miles (4,400km). Ceres is the closest dwarf planet to the Sun and is located in the 'asteroid belt', which lies between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: X-rays were discovered on this day
article: X-rays were discovered by German physicist Wilhelm Conrad Rontgen on November 8, 1895. Dubbed so because of their unknown nature, X-rays were observed accidentally when Rontgen was testing the possibility of cathode rays passing through glass. The electromagnetic energy waves act at a wavelength which is 1,000 times shorter than those of light rays.

author: Rohan Kumar
abstract: Einstein's brain was different, finds new study
article: A new study suggests that unusually well-connected hemispheres in Einstein's brain could have sparked off his brilliance. The study, co-authored by anthropologist Dean Falk and physicist Weiwei Men, shows that Einstein had a thicker corpus callosum (fibers between the cerebral hemispheres) compared to that of fifteen elderly and 52 younger men from 1905, the 'miracle year' of Einstein's scientific contributions.

author: Rohan Kumar
abstract: Scientists discover free-floating planet
article: An astronomers' team led by Dr Michael Liu at the Maui telescope have found a planet floating by itself merely 80 light-years away from Earth. The planet named 'PSO J318.5-22' is suspected to have broken away from a collection of young stars and being away from a star's glare, it will allow scientists to closely observe a young gas-giant planet.

author: Trivedi Bhutnath
abstract: Solar eclipse seen in Africa, Europe and US
article: A total solar eclipse was seen in Africa on Sunday (with best views in northern Kenya's Sibiloi national park), while the United States and Europe saw partial solar eclipse. The eclipse lasted for about 10 second in Kenya; and in the US, it lasted 45 minute close to sunrise. Partial views were also available in Spain, Italy, Greece, and Iraq.

author: Sai Santosh
abstract: Space storms threaten India's power grids: Study
article: Researchers from Australia and United States have found that space storms across the equator could threaten power grids in regions near the equator like India, previously considered safe from such events. Even minor storms could disrupt the power infrastructure due to amplification by atmospheric electricity. Space storms have previously knocked out power in Europe and North America.

author: Nihal Thondepu
abstract: 90 mn-year-old fossil shows how snakes lost legs
article: A recent study on a 90 million-year-old fossil indicated that snakes lost their legs when their ancestors evolved to live and hunt in burrows. Scientists used CT scans and built 3D models to compare the fossil to modern snakes and lizards. The study showed that snakes did not lose their limbs to live in the sea as previously believed.

author: Bhavika Bhuwalka
abstract: New solid carbon harder than diamond created
article: Researchers at a US university have created a new phase of solid carbon which is harder than diamonds. Named Q-carbon, the isotope can glow at low energy levels and is ferromagnetic. Q-carbon can be used in the domains of drug delivery and power electronics. So far, diamond was considered as the hardest naturally occurring material.

author: Rohan Kumar
abstract: Sun set for 11-year magnetic pole flip
article: The Sun's magnetic field will flip by 180-degrees in the next 2-3 months, an event that happens once in every 11-years at the peak of each solar cycle as the sun's inner magnetic dynamo re-organizes itself. The flip could cause climate-change, storms, disrupt satellites and make weather in space highly hazardous over the next few months, scientists have warned.

author: Prabhat Joshi
abstract: CERN scientists create antihydrogen atoms
article: CERN physicists have succeeded for the first time in producing a beam of antihydrogen atoms by mixing antielectrons (positrons) and low energy antiprotons, an advance that brings scientists closer to solving the antimatter mystery. The comparisons of hydrogen and antihydrogen atoms constitute one of the best ways to perform highly precise tests of matter/antimatter symmetry, researchers said.

author: Shipra Sharma
abstract: Jupiter's twin planet spotted
article: Astronomers at the Universidade de Sao Paulo (Brazil) have spotted a planet with a 'very similar mass to Jupiter' orbiting a sun-like star, named HIP 11915. Jupiter's twin is almost exactly the same distance from HIP 11915 as Jupiter itself is from our sun, researchers said. The discovery implies the existence of a solar system similar to ours, researchers claim.
